headline: NewSchools Fund Attracts More Capital
abstract: NewSchools Venture Fund, a nonprofit that invests in education groups, is entering a partnership with Rethink Education that could result in millions more in financing.
lead_paragraph: NewSchools Venture Fund, a nonprofit that started out channeling philanthropic donations to charter schools and that now invests in a range of education groups and businesses, is entering into a partnership with a new venture capital fund that could result in millions more in financing.

headline: Years Later, Barnes Gets a Big Hit Off Pettitte
abstract: Brandon Barnes had a two-run double off the Yankee veteran Andy Pettitte on Monday, but as Astros teammates in spring training in 2006, Pettitte had the upper hand.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after he had been battered by the Houston Astros on Monday night, Andy Pettitte dissected his performance and was particularly upset about a fourth-inning, 0-2 pitch he threw to Brandon Barnes that Barnes turned into a two-run double.

headline: Equipped to Weather Big Storms, a Jersey City Tower Draws Tenants
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Although Jersey City’s office market has been struggling, a building that already offers backup generators and a fiber optic network has been attracting new tenants.
lead_paragraph: In the six months since Hurricane Sandy hit, office tenants have been flocking to a huge glass tower in Jersey City despite its being right along the waterfront. It may seem counterintuitive for companies to pointedly search for office space near the water, but the 500,000-square-foot building at 111 Town Square Place in Newport is a hybrid data center and office building that offers tenants backup generators, redundant power and an extensive fiber optic network.

headline: Chris Matthews Signs Long-Term Extension With MSNBC
abstract: A host on the network for more than a decade, Mr. Matthews said that under his new deal he would end his syndicated Sunday talk show.
lead_paragraph: Chris Matthews, who has been one of the most prominent hosts on MSNBC for more than a decade, has signed a new long-term deal with the network to continue his “Hardball” program, a network executive confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Advocates Say Managed-Care Plans Shun the Most Disabled Medicaid Users
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Disabilities', 'Medicaid', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Elderly']
abstract: At a meeting with the advocates for disabled people, New York State’s Medicaid director vowed to hold plans accountable when it came to enrolling the most seriously impaired seniors, participants said.
lead_paragraph: Managed-care companies in New York have come under fire for signing up vigorous older adults referred to them by social day care centers, customers whose health needs are relatively small.

headline: In the World of Content, Web Follows a Trail Left by TV
keywords: ['Web-Original Programming', 'Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Upfronts (Television)']
abstract: Internet companies like Hulu, AOL and Yahoo are holding presentations this week about their plans for original programming.
lead_paragraph: IF in real estate, as the saying goes, the three most important things are “location, location, location,” when it comes to wooing viewers and advertisers to online video from television, the corresponding mantra seems to be “content, content, content.”

headline: Miami’s Condo Market Rebounds, Stoking a Building Boom
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'United States Economy', 'Building (Construction)', 'Foreign Investments', 'Condominiums']
abstract: As home prices recover and demand for safe investments by foreign investors rises, Miami is booming again with 25 condo projects.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Of the 22,000 condos created in downtown Miami during the boom years, only about 600 remain unsold — thanks mainly to an influx of Latin American investors seeking a safe haven for their money.

headline: In New Hampshire, Senator Finds Her Vote on Gun Bill Is Hot Topic
abstract: Senator Kelly Ayotte, a Republican in her first term, has become a focus of advocates on both sides of the gun control debate.
lead_paragraph: WARREN, N.H. — It was 45 minutes into Senator Kelly Ayotte’s town hall-style meeting here on Tuesday, and the local Republican official screening question topics had allowed just one query on gun control. A few in the crowd of about 150 started to get agitated.

headline: Chinese Way of Doing Business: In Cash We Trust
abstract: For all China’s modern trappings, many experts say mutual wariness between the government and its citizens means the country still prefers to pay for things the old-fashioned way.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Lin Lu remembers the day last December when a Chinese businessman showed up at the car dealership he works for in north China and paid for a new BMW 5 Series Gran Turismo — entirely in cash.

headline: Massachusetts: Aid Promised for Victims Who Lost Limbs
abstract: A national trade group has promised to provide protheses to anyone who lost a leg in the Boston Marathon bombings if they are uninsured or their insurance fails to cover the cost.
lead_paragraph: The American Orthotic & Prosthetic Association, a national trade group, has promised to provide artificial limbs to any people who lost a leg in the Boston Marathon bombings if they are uninsured or their insurance fails to cover the cost.  More than a dozen people lost limbs in the blasts; it is not yet known how many will need help paying for prostheses. The cost of an initial prosthesis could be $8,000 to $30,000, said Tom Fise, the group’s executive director. Many insurance plans sharply limit coverage, he said.

headline: Kerry Calls Arab League Plan to Revive Talks With Israel a ‘Big Step’
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry called a new initiative “a very big step forward,” but initial reactions suggested that the plan might have difficulty penetrating a years-long impasse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday embraced a proposal by the Arab League to revive peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians as “a very big step forward,” but initial reactions suggested that the new initiative might have difficulty penetrating the years-long impasse.

headline: Deanna Durbin, Plucky Movie Star of the Depression Era, Is Dead at 91
abstract: Ms. Durbin was a teenage actress whose radiant voice and wholesome personality brought box-office gold to Universal Pictures before she vanished from Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Deanna Durbin, who as a plucky child movie star with a sweet soprano voice charmed American audiences during the Depression and saved Universal Pictures from bankruptcy before she vanished from public view 64 years ago, has died, a fan club announced on Tuesday. She was 91.

headline: Leader of Hezbollah Warns It Is Ready to Come to Syria’s Aid
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The leader of Hezbollah edged closer to acknowledging that its fighters were battling rebels in Syria, an intervention that threatens to drag Lebanon deeper into that conflict.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese Shiite organization, edged closer on Tuesday to acknowledging that its fighters were battling rebels in neighboring Syria, an intervention that threatens to drag Lebanon deeper into that conflict.

headline: Critics of Israel’s West Bank Occupation Say Calm Before New Violence Was an Illusion
abstract: Israelis opposed to the occupation of the West Bank argued that an 18-month pause between fatal attacks on Israelis there, which ended Tuesday, had created “an illusion of calm and stability.”
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Isabel Kershner and Fares Akram report, the tension of daily life in the occupied West Bank exploded into deadly violence on Tuesday, when a knife-wielding Palestinian man attacked and killed an Israeli settler at a bus stop. The attacker, identified as Salam Zaghal, a 24-year-old who recently spent three years in jail for throwing stones, then seized the dead man’s pistol and engaged in a shootout with police officers.

headline: The Frankfurter Diaries
abstract: We have an attachment to the foods of childhood, often against our better judgment.
lead_paragraph: I ate two hot dogs the other day. And now I’m going to talk about my feelings about junk food.

headline: No Penalty for Singh for Using a Hormone
abstract: Commissioner Tim Finchem said the tour decided Vijay Singh would not face any penalties after admitting to taking deer antler spray, an insulin-like growth hormone.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Vijay Singh, the 2005 champion of the Wells Fargo Championship, taking place here this week, was asked on the driving range Tuesday morning where his doping case with the PGA Tour stood. It had been 91 days since Singh admitted in a magazine article to taking deer antler spray, a substance included on the tour’s banned list because it contains IGF-1, an insulinlike growth hormone.

headline: With a Friend Like Rudy ...
abstract: Former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is actually hurting, not helping, the Lhota campaign with all his talk of trampling the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani went to a fund-raiser on Staten Island on Monday for Joseph Lhota, his former deputy who is running for Mr. Giuliani’s old job. Thanks to a blogging reporter, Jacob Kornbluh, there is video of Mr. Giuliani reprising his role as the Mayor of 9/11.

headline: ‘Ghost Money,’ and Lots of It
abstract: Americans need an accounting of the C.I.A.’s astounding cash payments to President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The news that the Central Intelligence Agency has been spending lavishly in Afghanistan should come as no surprise. The agency went to work in the country right after Sept. 11, 2001, and has played a dominant covert role hunting down Al Qaeda and the Taliban ever since, while the Pentagon and other agencies have pursued more transparent military and development operations costing many billions of dollars.

headline: Flooded Factory Is Brought Back by Its Workers
abstract: Six months after Hurricane Sandy, IceStone, a Brooklyn factory specializing in making hard surfaces like tables, is back in operation because its employees made what had seemed impossible possible.
lead_paragraph: The day after Hurricane Sandy, Dal LaMagna drove to his factory in Building 12 at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. His company, IceStone, had been making hard surfaces, like countertops and tables, using recycled glass and cement. As he pulled into the yard, his first sight was of the factory’s new garage door, which cost $21,000, peeled back like the lid of a sardine tin. Inside were six destroyed forklifts. The entire place was drowned.

headline: Koch Brothers Plan More Political Involvement for Their Conservative Network
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Despite 2012 setbacks, Charles and David Koch have rejected any notion of stepping back from electoral politics.
lead_paragraph: As the country’s leading conservative donors finished off plates of roast lamb and spaetzle in a Palm Springs, Calif., hotel ballroom on Monday, Charles G. Koch delivered a pep talk.

headline: The President and the Hunger Strike
abstract: Mr. Obama promised, yet again, to close the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. He has failed to keep that promise for five years.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said a lot of important things on Tuesday about the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. It is a blight on the nation’s reputation. It mocks American standards of justice by keeping people imprisoned without charges. It has actually hindered the prosecution and imprisonment of dangerous terrorists. Even if Guantánamo seemed justified to some people in the immediate aftermath of the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, those justifications are wearing thin. It is unsustainable and should be closed.

headline: It’s a 401(k) World
abstract: In today’s hyperconnected world, we all have to learn much more about investing in ourselves in order to succeed.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to have a conversation today with any worker, teacher, student or boss who doesn’t tell you some version of this: More things seem to be changing in my world than ever before, but I can’t quite put my finger on it, let alone know how to adapt. So let me try to put my finger on it: We now live in a 401(k) world — a world of defined contributions, not defined benefits — where everyone needs to pass the bar exam and no one can escape the most e-mailed list.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wall Street bankers and some of the world’s top finance ministers are waging a bitter international campaign to block Washington financial regulators from extending their policing powers far beyond the nation’s shores.

headline: Attention-Deficit Drugs Face New Campus Rules
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'ADDERALL (DRUG)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Misuse of attention deficit drugs has become a problem on campuses, and colleges are reconsidering how — and even if — their student health offices should try to diagnose A.D.H.D.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — Lisa Beach endured two months of testing and paperwork before the student health office at her college approved a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Then, to get a prescription for Vyvanse, a standard treatment for A.D.H.D., she had to sign a formal contract — promising to submit to drug testing, to see a mental health professional every month and to not share the pills.

lead_paragraph: A lawsuit against Harvard provides rare detail on the issues involving a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder from a student-health department.

headline: The Most Hated Bangladeshi, Toppled From a Shady Empire
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Sohel Rana is under arrest after the collapse of his factory building last week left nearly 400 people dead, but until now he has been a powerful figure, trailed by his own biker gang.
lead_paragraph: SAVAR, Bangladesh — Barely 20 miles from the national capital, this gritty suburb is now a dusty, chaotic industrial center littered with factories that produce clothes for leading Western brands. Building codes are often unenforced, regulatory oversight is flimsy and the men wielding power often travel with armed guards.

headline: Retailers Split on Contrition After Collapse of Factories
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Several apparel companies sought to minimize any connections to the building in Bangladesh, while some others quickly acknowledged theirs.
lead_paragraph: The building collapse in Bangladesh that caused at least 386 deaths has produced some jarringly different responses from Western apparel retailers and brands that obtained goods from factories inside the building.

abstract: Maple Leafs star Phil Kessel is one of the main story lines heading into the team’s first-round series with the Bruins, who drafted him in the first round in 2006 and traded him three years later.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A day after causing a stir by not speaking to waiting reporters, Phil Kessel met the Toronto news media Tuesday.

abstract: Two lawmakers will propose letting the United States Anti-Doping Agency enforce antidoping standards and kick violators out of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Two lawmakers who contend that the United States Anti-Doping Agency is the most effective agency to regulate horse racing plan to introduce a bill in Congress to give it the authority to enforce antidoping standards and to kick out violators.

headline: With Democratic Mayoral Field in Flux, de Blasio Assails Quinn
abstract: Bill de Blasio has gone sharply negative in his bid for mayor, as if trying to establish his position as Christine C. Quinn’s chief liberal challenger before Anthony D. Weiner usurps that role.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio has hammered Christine C. Quinn over her closeness to the mayor, mocked her as the “best friend” of the real estate industry, and accused her of being soft on the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — ALOHA and happy LEI DAY, everyone! Paula Gamache is back, and her challenge to you is this lovely Wednesday puzzle. Her challenge to me is to figure out how to discuss this without getting fired.

headline: Guatemala: Former Dictator’s Genocide Trial Resumes
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The genocide trial of a former dictator of Guatemala, Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, resumed Tuesday, 12 days after a judge ruled to annul the court proceedings.
lead_paragraph: The genocide trial of a former dictator of Guatemala, Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, resumed Tuesday, 12 days after a judge ruled to annul the court proceedings. Guatemala’s highest court has yet to issue a clear statement on the legality of that decision, but it made several rulings last week that sent the case back to the chief trial judge, Jasmín Barrios, to restart proceedings. Testimony is almost complete, but Guatemala’s highest court must still consider several more motions related to the trial, and experts say more delays are possible.

headline: Liu Is Prominent Figure in Closing Argument at Ex-Aides’ Trial
abstract: A federal prosecutor told the jury that John C. Liu, a Democratic candidate for New York City mayor, had to have been aware of a scheme to use straw donors for Mr. Liu’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: As closing arguments began on Tuesday in a widely watched political corruption trial in Manhattan, a federal prosecutor asked a jury to convict two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller and a Democratic candidate for mayor, of conspiring to funnel money to his campaign through an illegal fund-raising scheme.

headline: Jason Collins Took Personal Steps Before Coming Out Publicly
abstract: Collins had been filled with fear at the prospect of openly acknowledging he is gay, but the response to his announcement has been overwhelmingly positive.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Jason Collins signed with Boston Celtics last year, he was a player in search of a number. His number for years — 34 — was taken, and 35, which he had with the Nets at the start of his career, had been retired by his new team.

headline: Cuba: U.S. Allows President’s Daughter to Travel
abstract: The State Department will allow President Raúl Castro’s daughter to travel to Philadelphia to receive a gay civil rights award.
lead_paragraph: The State Department will allow President Raúl Castro’s daughter to travel to Philadelphia to receive a gay civil rights award. Mariela Castro, director of Cuba’s National Center for Sex Education, was granted a diplomatic visa to attend United Nations meetings in April, but the State Department did not issue a second visa she requested to attend the Equality Forum 2013 Summit this weekend. Cuban diplomats cannot travel more than 25 miles without prior authorization. Ms. Castro is considered an international leader in the issue of rights for gay and transgender people. The Equality Forum received word on Monday that the State Department decided to lift the 25-mile restriction. “Better judgment prevailed,” said the group’s director, Malcolm Lazin. The State Department did not explain the reversal.

headline: Company’s App Can Now Be Used to Hail Yellow Cabs in City
abstract: One week after a lawsuit by livery and black-car operators challenging the use of such apps was dismissed, the Uber company said its service was available.
lead_paragraph: After a series of court hearings and false starts, New York City’s yellow taxi riders can now, for the first time, legally hail a cab with a smartphone app.

lead_paragraph: This has been a good year for gay rights advocates — with public opinion shifting in their favor and same-sex marriage advancing in the states — but not when it comes to immigration.

headline: Zimmerman Forgoes Pretrial Hearing, Taking Issue of Immunity to a Jury

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — With a softly spoken, “Yes, Your Honor,” George Zimmerman officially waived his right to a pretrial “Stand Your Ground” immunity hearing on Tuesday, choosing instead to lay out his self-defense case before a jury.

headline: Three Outs From Win, Mets Throw It Away
abstract: The Marlins scored twice in the bottom of the ninth and won when Juan Pierre scored on a wild pitch thrown by Mets reliever Brandon Lyon.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Caught in the baseball vortex that had vaporized their offense and drained their confidence, the Mets searched for an escape route before Tuesday’s game at Marlins Park. Some of the players spent additional time analyzing video. Some took extra cuts in the batting cage. Others simply stuck to routine, hopeful that this would be the night they unearthed the ability to score a couple of runs, maybe more.

headline: Looking Ahead to the Jets’ Quarterback Roulette
abstract: The Seahawks’ quarterback controversy last year may hold lessons for the Jets.
lead_paragraph: There were once three quarterbacks: the uninspiring veteran, the free-agent addition and the recent draft pick. They would all compete, team officials said, and compete they did until the winner was selected.

lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Mass. — Doc Rivers said he received a phone call a few days ago. On the other line was Jason Collins, who had appeared in 32 games for the Boston Celtics this season before being traded in February.

lead_paragraph: WRESTLING with my newspaper on the subway recently, I noticed the woman next to me reading a book on her smartphone. “That has to hurt your eyes,” I commented.  Not missing a beat, she replied, in true New York style, “My font is bigger than yours.” She was right.

headline: Tokyo Official Apologizes for Remarks About Olympics Rival

lead_paragraph: Naoki Inose, the governor of Tokyo, apologized for comments he made recently about Istanbul, a rival city hoping to host the Olympics in 2020. headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:30 P.M. (Sundance) NURSE BETTY (2000) Renée Zellweger, above, with Chris Rock, left, and Morgan Freeman, is Betty, a small-town waitress who suffers a nervous breakdown after she witnesses the murder of her husband (Aaron Eckhart) at the hands of two hit men (Mr. Freeman and Mr. Rock). Instead of facing reality, Betty escapes into the idealized fantasy of her favorite soap opera, “A Reason to Love,” which is set in a hospital. She travels to Los Angeles to become a nurse and tries to reunite with her imagined old flame, the fictional Dr. David Ravell (Greg Kinnear). Unfortunately, the hit men are in hot pursuit. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that this dark comedy “takes the most hackneyed dramatic ploy of soap opera, a case of amnesia, and spins it into an irresistibly heady mixture of sadness and hilarity.” He added, “At its giddiest peaks the movie, directed by Neil LaBute, produces that shivery feeling when your heart melts, but at the same moment you want to burst out laughing.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 1
abstract: Arrest in Bangladesh; Obama recommits to closing Guantánamo; cash in China; Berlin names streets for women; and Oslo runs out of trash.
lead_paragraph: The most reviled man in Bangladesh, Sohel Rana, 35, is under arrest. Mr. Rana owned the Rana Plaza, which collapsed last week, killing nearly 400 people. Many others are still missing. On Tuesday, a top Bangladeshi court seized his assets, as the public called for his execution, especially as it appears that the tragedy could have been averted if the frantic warnings of an engineer who examined the building the day before had been heeded. Jim Yardley reports from Savar, Bangladesh.

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 British Soldiers on Patrol in Afghanistan

headline: More Releases of Ailing Prisoners Are Urged
abstract: The Bureau of Prisons could save taxpayer money and reduce overcrowding if it better managed its “compassionate release” program, according to the Justice Department’s inspector general.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal Bureau of Prisons could save taxpayer money and reduce overcrowding if it better managed a program for the “compassionate release” of inmates who are dying or facing other extraordinary circumstances, according to a new report by the Justice Department’s independent inspector general.

headline: Thieves Break Into a Personal ‘Data Vault’ Company
abstract: Thieves penetrate the computer system of a company that specializes in keeping personal data safe from snooping, revealing again the limits of encrypting passwords.
lead_paragraph: A company that describes itself as a vault for personal data has suffered an embarrassing heist: intruders penetrated its computer system and looted its customers’ names, addresses and in some cases, dates of birth and login passwords.

headline: Truck Sales Led a Strong April for U.S. Automakers
abstract: The increase in truck sales fed double-digit sales growth for Detroit and kept the industry on track to sell more than 15 million vehicles this year.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — American automakers said on Wednesday that sales of pickup trucks rose sharply in April because of a revival in the housing market and increased demand from the oil and gas industry.

headline: Sorry We Drifted Apart, Richie Havens
abstract: In a chance encounter with Richie Havens, a fan just cannot find the right words to say.
lead_paragraph: Mark Lutin is a legal-marketing executive and lifelong New Yorker who lives in Bayside, Queens.

headline: Days of the Jackals
abstract: Brooks and Collins compare cooperation among animals in the wild to cooperation among politicians in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, I just got back from a vacation in Botswana. We were cut off from the outside world for quite a while, just looking at nature. One of our guides showed us a wild dog who had wandered into the area a few years before, apparently lost from her pack. So she stole some jackal pups and raised them. Now they’re a team — the dog does the hunting and the jackals keep a lookout for lions.

headline: The Joyce Announces Its 2013-2014 Season
abstract: The season will feature Cloud Gate 2, the Houston Ballet, Pam Tanowitz Dance and the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company, among others.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Pita’s award-winning interpretation of Kafka’s “Metamorphosis,” originally staged by the Royal Ballet in London, will open the fall dance season at the Joyce Theater on Sept. 17, with the Royal Ballet principal Edward Watson dancing the role of Gregor Samsa, and Frank Moon performing his own score live. The production, which runs through Sept. 29, is the first of 16 that the theater has scheduled through February 2014.

headline: Leaving Cars Behind in L.A.
abstract: The “Car Free LA” program offers seven itineraries for tourists up for biking, walking or taking the Metro transit system in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles’s tourism agency is hoping to entice visitors to find new ways to explore the city. Its “Car Free LA” program offers seven itineraries for tourists up for biking, walking or taking the Metro transit system. Trips include the bike route from Venice to Santa Monica and a walking tour of Hollywood, though you may have to take a taxi to the starting point.

headline: A Wholesaler Decides to Abandon His Most Profitable Sales Channel
abstract: If you have determined that none of your retailers are interested in a business, don’t you have every right to do it yourself?
lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a case study about an entrepreneur, new to the furniture business, who had expanded his business selling patio and deck furniture to $7 million in annual sales. Instead of selling through sales representatives, Gerald Shvartsman, founder and chief executive of Source Outdoor, which is based in Miami, employed a multichannel sales strategy.

headline: Cancers Share Gene Patterns, Studies Affirm
keywords: ['Cancer', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Research', 'Leukemia', 'Ovarian Cancer', 'Breast Cancer', 'Uterine Cancer']
abstract: Scientists have found the best evidence yet that cancer will increasingly be seen as a disease defined by its genetic fingerprint rather than by the organ where it originated.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered that the most dangerous cancer of the uterine lining closely resembles the worst ovarian and breast cancers, providing the most telling evidence yet that cancer will increasingly be seen as a disease defined primarily by its genetic fingerprint rather than just by the organ where it originated.

headline: Striking a Pose Above the Clouds
abstract: When the airplane seats are too narrow and the flight is too long, yoga can provide relief for aching backs and stiff hips.
lead_paragraph: No wonder travelers are bent out of shape.

headline: Gun Law Proponents Focus Ads on 2 Senators
abstract: Activists pushing for tougher gun laws are asking them to change their votes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With members of Congress back in their home states for recess this week, activists pushing for tougher gun laws are hitting two senators with new appeals on television, asking them to change their votes.

headline: How to Weaken a President
abstract: For some Republicans, visceral hatred of Obama is their only guiding star.
lead_paragraph: Republicans came up with all kinds of convoluted and made-up explanations for voting against gun background checks, and some are starting to do the same for the immigration bill. A few are even using the Boston bombing as an excuse. But for many lawmakers, the real reason is depressingly familiar. They don’t want to give President Obama anything he wants.

headline: Gulp (Don’t Gag): Modeling the Complexity of the Digestive System
abstract: In this lesson, students research the digestive system in depth, and then create a detailed walk-through model to illustrate each compartment.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Quentin Hardy talks with Mary Roach about her new book, “Gulp: Adventures on the Alimentary Canal.”

headline: Time Warner Revenue Is Flat, Despite Cable Gains
abstract: Quarterly revenue fell at Time Warner’s magazine and movie divisions, partly offsetting gains at Turner Broadcasting and HBO.
lead_paragraph: Sluggishness at Time Warner’s magazine and movie divisions partly offset gains at its cable television networks, leading to virtually flat revenue and a 13 percent increase in operating income in the first three months of the year.

headline: For Ramirez Hidalgo, Little Glamour but a Lot of Tennis
abstract: Ruben Ramirez Hidalgo built his 15-year pro tennis career on the love of the game — and he’s still going, the oldest man in the Top 100.
lead_paragraph: He is 35, a father and wears his cap backward on the court. He is also the oldest man in the Top 100 on the professional tour.

headline: Showing Grass-Roots Support for Immigration Overhaul
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'May Day', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: The May Day gatherings were intended to show Congress that momentum is building in favor of a path to citizenship for 11 million immigrants in the country illegally.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of immigrants, Latinos and other supporters of an overhaul of the immigration system turned out on Wednesday for marches, rallies and prayer vigils, hoping to show Congress that momentum is building for a path to citizenship for 11 million immigrants in the country illegally.

headline: ‘Like an Oozing Brownie’
abstract: Mark Bittman makes a warm, soft molten chocolate cake with Jean-Georges Vongerichten.
lead_paragraph: We’re imagining sinking a fork into the warm, soft molten chocolate cake described by Mark Bittman in his Eat column this week. The column outlines a three-course menu for Mother’s Day, simple for novice cooks to pull off. The dessert is a version of a recipe by Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who helps Mr. Bittman make these small cakes in fluted molds.

headline: A No-Hitter So Rare It Took 6 Pitchers
abstract: Houston’s combined no-hitter on June 11, 2003, was the first no-hitter against the Yankees in the Bronx since 1952. They have not been no-hit since.
lead_paragraph: On June 11, 2003, Roy Oswalt, the ace of the Houston Astros’ pitching staff, had to leave a game against the Yankees with a groin pull after the first inning. The Yankee Stadium crowd sat back and waited for the runs to pile up, figuring that the powerful Yankees lineup — Alfonso Soriano, Derek Jeter, Jason Giambi, Jorge Posada, Hideki Matsui — had the whole game to wear out the Astros’ bullpen.

headline: Girl’s Bones Bear Signs of Cannibalism by Starving Virginia Colonists
abstract: Archaeologists excavating the Jamestown colony site have found in the remains of a 14-year-old girl the first physical evidence of cannibalism by colonists during the harsh winter of 1609.
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists excavating a trash pit at the Jamestown colony site in Virginia have found the first physical evidence of cannibalism among the desperate population, corroborating written accounts left behind by witnesses. Cut marks on the skull and skeleton of a 14-year-old girl show that her flesh and brain were removed, presumably to be eaten by the starving colonists during the harsh winter of 1609.

headline: Survey Shows Strong Support for Fuel Efficiency Standards
abstract: A Consumer Federation of America survey shows that most people want more fuel efficient cars, and that they support stricter federal standards, too.
lead_paragraph: A new survey has found that consumers want more fuel efficient cars and also support the new federal fuel economy standards that the federal government plans to reach by 2025.

headline: Nicolas Ghesquière’s Balenciaga Legacy
abstract: Suddenly there’s a deluge of Nicolas Ghesquière stories — meaty, reflective accounts on his departure last year from Balenciaga, his views on the state of fashion, and some hints about his future.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly there’s a deluge of Nicolas Ghesquière stories. Well, two, but they are meaty, reflective accounts on his departure last year from Balenciaga, his views on the state of fashion, and some hints about his future.

headline: With Initiative, Attorney General Focuses on New York’s Pets
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman unveiled an animal protection campaign with two goals: reducing abuses in “puppy mills” and shutting down dogfighting rings.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Last year, the state attorney general’s office sued an animal hospice center in Delaware County that had been accused of neglect for failing to file required financial reports.

headline: In the Alps of Goethe and James Bond
abstract: Hiking valleys and peaks that were an inspiration for poetry and a movie set.
lead_paragraph: We were hiking in fog and drizzle up the barren slopes of Mount Schilthorn, a 9,748-foot-high peak overlooking the Lauterbrunnen Valley in Switzerland. As I inched along a narrow trail, the mist cleared to reveal a long drop on either side into a boulder-strewn abyss. My legs wobbled; my feet slithered over the soggy ground. I reached out to grasp what seemed like a taut rope line, only to feel it sag beneath my trembling fist. Then the trail widened, I steadied myself, and continued my arduous climb toward the summit.

headline: More Forceful Fed Stands by Stimulus
abstract: Officials said that they would consider an expansion of bond-buying if conditions warranted, and added that federal budget cuts were hurting the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that its economic stimulus campaign would press forward at the same pace it has maintained since December, putting to rest for now any suggestion that it was leaning toward doing less.

headline: French Efforts to Block Sale of Stake in Video Site to Yahoo Are Criticized
abstract: The French government’s objections to plans by Yahoo to buy a controlling stake in the video-sharing site DailyMotion has alarmed entrepreneurs in France.
lead_paragraph: The government of President François Hollande has expressed its objections to plans by Yahoo to buy a controlling stake in the video-sharing site DailyMotion, which is owned by France Télécom, in an effort to keep one of the country’s most successful technology start-ups out of foreign hands.

headline: Yoga After 50
abstract: Yoga teachers are responding to the growing number of longtime practitioners who are raising questions about the best way to continue a yoga practice into midlife and beyond.
lead_paragraph: While many yoga classes across the country seem to cater to the youthful enthusiast who wants to sweat his or her way through an hour-and-a-half workout, a growing number of longtime yoga devotees are raising questions about the best way to safely continue a yoga practice into midlife and beyond.

headline: Properties for $5.9 Million
abstract: Homes include a gated Spanish-style house in Pacific Palisades, Calif.; a midcentury modern outside Boulder, Colo.; and a brick traditional in Charlottesville, Va.
lead_paragraph: Homes include a gated Spanish-style house in Pacific Palisades, Calif.; a midcentury modern outside Boulder, Colo.; and a brick traditional in Charlottesville, Va.

abstract: A gated Spanish-style house in Pacific Palisades, Calif.; a midcentury modern outside Boulder, Colo.; and a brick traditional in Charlottesville, Va.
lead_paragraph: PACIFIC PALISADES, CALIF.

headline: Income Guarantee Swells Crop Insurance
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Insurance', 'Farm Bill (US)']
abstract: The high costs of subsidized crop insurance were mostly a result of policies that paid farmers for declines in their income, not of poor crop yields.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The worst drought in 50 years led to record payouts from a taxpayer-subsidized insurance program created to protect farms from weather-related disasters. But the high costs were mostly a result of policies that guarantee farmers a portion of their projected revenue, rather than coverage that pays them for their damaged crops, according to a study released Wednesday.

headline: Racing Industry Eager to See Bill Allowing Usada Oversight
abstract: Horse racing officials said they had not yet seen the Horseracing Integrity and Safety Act, which is expected to be introduced to Congress next week.
lead_paragraph: Horse racing industry officials said Wednesday that they were eager to see proposed federal legislation that would give the United States Anti-Doping Agency the authority to create a regulatory plan with meaningful penalties to clean up the sport.

headline: A Study in Chinoiserie Dating to the 18th Century
abstract: A princess was the first occupant of this five-bedroom brick home, called the Pagoda. Its owners are entertaining offers of at least $4.54 million.
lead_paragraph: A princess was the first occupant of this five-bedroom brick home, called the Pagoda. Its owners are entertaining offers of at least $4.54 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... London
abstract: Despite the slump after the 2008 housing crash, prices in London have rebounded to their highest levels ever.
lead_paragraph: A CHINESE-STYLE HISTORIC HOME IN SOUTHEAST LONDON

headline: Fighting Corruption in China, One Special License Plate at a Time
abstract: Officials are cracking down on the abuse of privileges that come with a military license plate, in a bid to address public anger at the army.
lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — A photograph in the official newspaper of the People’s Liberation Army over the weekend showed a grinning military officer standing proudly in his green uniform, as if he had single-handedly repelled a foreign invasion.

headline: Criminal Complaints Against Additional Suspects in the Boston Marathon Bombings
abstract: Court documents related to the additional suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings.
lead_paragraph: Court documents related to the additional suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings.

headline: With Upgrade, Headphones Have New Sound, and New Parts
abstract: Sol Republic, maker of headphones with swappable parts, recently expanded its offerings with the introduction of over-ear headphones.
lead_paragraph: Sol Republic, maker of headphones with swappable parts, recently expanded its offerings with the release of its Master Tracks line, which incorporates over-ear headphones for the first time.

headline: ‘Wagonmasters’ Celebrates the Classic American Dream Through Station Wagons
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobiles', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Two filmmakers have produced a documentary celebrating a lost piece of automotive history.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember the last time you saw someone driving their family around in a gargantuan American station wagon as if they meant it? I’m not talking about a college student driving a load of friends around in granny’s hand-me-down or that weird neighbor who’s all “cold dead hands” about his ultimate suburban driving machine. No, I mean run-of-the-mill families of 4.5 who drive to schools, jobs and doctor appointments with mom and dad up front, a surly teenager or two in the back seat and one to one-and-a-half children way in the back, bouncing around on the rear-facing fold down, making faces at people through the back glass.

headline: Shorter Forms for Coverage Under New Health Law
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Earlier versions of the forms to apply for coverage under the new health law ran to 21 pages.
lead_paragraph: Banks and mortgage lenders have made strides in simplifying their disclosure forms so consumers can more easily understand the types of fees and terms they are getting.

headline: New Album From the Civil Wars
abstract: The duo, which split up in November, provided no hint about whether they would reunite or go on tour.
lead_paragraph: The Civil Wars will release a follow-up this summer to the duo’s Grammy-winning debut album “Barton Hollow,” but they provided no hint about whether they would reunite or go on tour.

headline: Telecom Investor Named to Be F.C.C. Chairman
abstract: Tom Wheeler has invested in start-up technology and communications companies, and advised the Federal Communications Commission on technology issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tom Wheeler, President Obama’s pick to be the next chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, knows all about the most advanced telecommunications systems — of the 19th century.

headline: The Interior Performance Art
abstract: Three pairs of readers scattered among the laptop-laden tables of New York University’s Bobst Library for the drama of turning pages, pointing fingers and eerily drifting thoughts.
lead_paragraph: What is the sound of two heads reading?

headline: N.H.L. Stadium Series Announces Date in Chicago
abstract: The N.H.L. will play a series of outdoor games next season, including one between the Blackhawks and Penguins at Chicago’s Soldier Field on March 1.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Blackhawks and the Pittsburgh Penguins will face off in a regular-season matchup at Soldier Field on March 1, 2014, as part of an expanded set of N.H.L. outdoor games next season.

headline: Online, Everyone Can Be a Makeup Critic
abstract: On beauty-focused social networks, amateurs and professionals can see which products are new and popular, and offer reviews of their own.
lead_paragraph: Matin Maulawizada, a makeup artist based in New York, used to spend hours prowling department stores’ beauty floors to find out what was new and noteworthy. Now, Mr. Maulawizada, the global artistry director for Laura Mercier, likes to log on to Pampadour.com, a sleek new beauty-focused social network, to see what products colleagues are using — or, in the company’s parlance, “pamping.” “It really saves me time,” Mr. Maulawizada said.

headline: Window Dressing | Tsumori Chisato
abstract: The Paris-based Japanese designer will make a rare New York appearance tomorrow evening at Kisan boutique in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: Attention, Tsumori Chisato devotees: The Paris-based Japanese designer, who’s earned a dedicated following for her whimsical prints and graceful use of manga, is making a rare New York appearance tomorrow evening. She’ll be hosting a cocktail party at Kisan, the SoHo boutique owned by the Icelandic-French couple Thorunn Anspach and Olivier Bremond. In honor of Tsumori’s visit, the two have created a special window display that showcases her Arizona-themed spring collection, pictured above, which was inspired by a visit to Sedona and includes references to the work of the artist Georgia O’Keefe. Tsumori, a tireless traveler who just returned from Italy, says that she is always on the lookout for fresh ideas for her designs. In New York, she’ll be “walking the streets and feeling the very unique atmosphere,” though she’s mainly looking forward to meeting her fans. “That makes my day!” she says. “Every time I meet a woman wearing my clothes I can tell she feels good in them.”

headline: New Home Planned for Los Angeles County Museum of Art
abstract: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art is planning to build a new home for its collections, a project that will required razing some of the museum’s existing buildings.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art is planning to build a new home for itself on Wilshire Boulevard, designed by the Pritzker Prize-winning architect Peter Zumthor, The Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday.

headline: Building Blocks All in a Row
abstract: VFiles, a social media site with a focus on fashion, trains its eye on nostalgia in its store.
lead_paragraph: GREAT FASHION doesn’t start from the bottom so much as from the outside — kids with ideas and dreams and no clear path to the center. The hungriest of them will study anything they can get their hands on, a bunch of eager would-bes trying to figure out how things work on the inside, faking it until they make it.

headline: Canon Powershot N
abstract: This new 12-megapixel camera is designed to compete with cellphone cameras.
lead_paragraph: This new 12-megapixel camera is designed to compete with cellphone cameras.

headline: For Playoffs, Seven Isn’t Necessarily the Best Number
abstract: The N.B.A.’s best-of-seven format for the first round of the playoffs guarantees more basketball, but is that necessarily a good thing?
lead_paragraph: It was a perfect snapshot of the drama, pressure and excitement of the N.B.A. playoffs, but it was ultimately meaningless.

headline: The Testament of Toibin: A Tony Nod, and a Closing Notice
abstract: The writer Colm Toibin reflects on his first experience as a Broadway playwright with “The Testament of Mary,” which was nominated for a top award and announced its closing on the same day.
lead_paragraph: The Irish writer Colm Toibin was shaving in his bathroom on Tuesday morning, and savoring the news that his “Testament of Mary” had just been nominated for a best play Tony Award, when the telephone rang. The voice on the other end said, “I have Scott Rudin on the line for you.” And so began one of the more surreal phone conversations that Mr. Toibin ever had: He was a freshly minted Tony nominee, but his producer Mr. Rudin was telling him that the play would close on Sunday, after only 43 performances and far earlier than planned, due to poor ticket sales.

headline: A Camera Takes On the Phones
abstract: The Canon N emphasizes features that a smartphone can’t match and can transmit new photos to your phone for immediate sending or posting online.
lead_paragraph: Technologies come and go in waves. And lately, the waves are coming and going faster.

headline: Uncertainty Still Clouds Health Care Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: As concerns arise about implementing the Affordable Care Act, even among its supporters, the White House has another worry: the law is still not well liked or well understood.
lead_paragraph: Three years after President Obama signed the health care reform law, there are concerns that the process of implementing it will be rocky. Even some of the law’s supporters are worried.

headline: Ticketmaster Accuses 21 of Fraudulent Ticket Buying
abstract: The company accused 21 people of circumventing its online security system to try to buy huge numbers of tickets to resell at a profit.
lead_paragraph: Ticketmaster, trying to fight the computer tactics used by some of the most advanced ticket scalpers, has sued 21 people, accusing them of fraud and breach of copyright in circumventing the company’s online security system to try to buy huge numbers of tickets.

headline: Does Depression Contribute to Dementia?
abstract: A new study adds to evidence of a link between late-life depression and dementia.
lead_paragraph: A large body of research has linked late-life depression to social isolation, poorer health and an increased risk of death. Now, a new study finds that depression is associated with subsequent vascular dementia and Alzheimer’s disease, conditions poised to expand dramatically with the aging population.

headline: HBO Orders Third Season of ‘Veep’
abstract: Who needs to wait another three years to choose America’s second-in-command? Not HBO, that’s for sure.
lead_paragraph: Who needs to wait another three years to choose America’s second-in-command? Not HBO, that’s for sure: on Wednesday, that cable network announced it was ordering a third season of “Veep,” its comedy series starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus as the vice president of the United States. In its first season in 2012, “Veep,” created by Armando Iannucci (the author of the political satires “The Thick of It” and “In the Loop”) was an Emmy nominee for outstanding comedy; Ms. Louis-Dreyfus, an Emmy winner for her performances on “Seinfeld” and “The New Adventures of Old Christine,” earned her third such award for portraying the “Veep” title character, Selina Meyer. “Veep” was just three episodes into its second season (which started on April 14) when HBO announced its latest renewal. The network said a third season of 10 episodes will be shown next year.

headline: The Players Meet Those Who Play Them
abstract: At an after-party of the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner, the lineup of famous faces blurred the line between real-life politicians and the Hollywood stars who portray them.
lead_paragraph: Every year, it seems, someone makes a big to-do over the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner and how it has been overrun with celebrities. (This year, Tom Brokaw and Barbara Walters criticized the event’s star turn.) It’s safe to say they didn’t make it to the annual after-party hosted by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Vanity Fair magazine.

headline: Up Close to Entice
abstract: The close-up photograph brings someone deeper into a subject.
lead_paragraph: Outtakes is a behind-the-scenes glimpse of images in the Dining section. Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

headline: High Line Decides to Drop Planned Fee for Visits to Final Section
abstract: The section, now undeveloped, will feature seven sculptures by Carol Bove.
lead_paragraph: The High Line announced on Wednesday that it had begun taking online reservations, at thehighline.org, for visits to the last undeveloped section of the rail line, between West 30th and 34th Streets, where for the next year seven sculptures by the artist Carol Bove will be on view. The High Line originally planned to charge $6 for a visit but decided on Monday to make reservations free.

headline: Goldman Names New Head of Special Situations Group
abstract: Goldman Sachs has named Julian Salisbury to become head of its global special situations group, the elite division that invests in and lends to companies.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has named a new head of its global special situations group, the elite division that invests in and lends to companies.

headline: Michael Bublé Hits No. 1 With ‘To Be Loved’
abstract: “To Be Loved” sold 195,000 copies, giving the Canadian crooner his fourth No. 1 album.
lead_paragraph: Michael Bublé stormed to the top of the Billboard 200 chart on Wednesday with his new album “To Be Loved” (Reprise), which sold 195,000 copies and gave the Canadian crooner his fourth No. 1 set.

headline: At Least Five Protesters Arrested in May Day Demonstration
abstract: A group of protesters marched from Tompkins Square Park to Union Square on Wednesday afternoon in a demonstration meant to criticize capitalism.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested at least five people on Wednesday afternoon as a group of protesters marched from Tompkins Square Park to Union Square in a May Day demonstration meant to criticize capitalism.

headline: Emmy Nomination for Elmo Puppeteer Who Resigned
keywords: ['Elmo (Fictional Character)', 'Emmy Awards', 'Television', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Kevin Clash, who left “Sesame Street” after allegations that he had sexual relationships with minors, has already won more than 20 Emmys.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Clash, who resigned from “Sesame Street” last year amid allegations that he had sexual relationships with minors, found himself back in the news on Wednesday after receiving a daytime entertainment Emmy nomination for his role as the show’s popular Elmo character.

headline: China Is Seen Nearing U.S.’s Military Power in Region
abstract: A report, by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said American-Chinese interdependence would prevent China from trying to force out the United States.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — China’s growing industrial might is likely to allow it to mount an increasingly formidable challenge to the military supremacy of the United States in the waters around China that include Japan and Taiwan, though it will probably seek to avoid an outright armed conflict, according to a detailed new report by a group of American researchers.

headline: Valdespin Turns on a Pitch and Likes How It Feels
abstract: Jordany Valdespin hit a pinch-hit three-run home run in the sixth inning as the Mets avoided a sweep by the Marlins.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Jordany Valdespin had always been a full-time player. Whether it was as a young outfielder in the Dominican Republic or rising through the minor leagues, he was accustomed to taking the field for nine innings. Nobody, he said, wants to spend all game sitting on the bench.

headline: Not Everything Is Political
abstract: Doctrines work or they don’t.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong directs me to a screed by Clive Crook, who sort of admits that I’ve been right about a lot of things but accuses me of being, well, shrill. Where have I heard that before?

headline: Mobile Ads Help Propel Earnings at Facebook
abstract: Facebook reported that about 30 percent of its total advertising revenue came from mobile devices, a significant jump from the last quarter.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This time last year, just before Facebook made its public debut, the social network did not show a single advertisement on its mobile applications. And over time, the cries from investors about its mobile strategy grew louder and louder.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook Beheadings and Privacy Champions
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include opinions, images and consumer stories about Google Glass, a report on how online companies handle government requests for personal information and a warning about the use of data from personal tracking devices and apps.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.
