abstract: Photos from Turkey, Indonesia, Chile and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Indonesia, Chile and Nepal.

headline: Would Anna Settle for a Safety Pin?
abstract: With a theme of punk, many guests of this year’s Costume Institute gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art haven’t a clue about what to wear.
lead_paragraph: IT IS HARD ENOUGH for famous people to decide what to wear to the annual Costume Institute gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, fashion’s party of the year, even though Anna Wintour has been known to offer advice. But imagine the pressure facing guests at this year’s ball, on May 6, where the theme, as you might have heard, will be punk.

headline: No Vote Needed on Abortion Bill, G.O.P. Leader Says
abstract: Senator Dean G. Skelos said a measure to safeguard federally recognized abortion rights was unnecessary because “Roe v. Wade is never going to be changed.”
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is still hoping to pass the whole of his 10-point Women’s Equality Act during the closing weeks of the 2013 legislative session, which ends in late June. But on Wednesday, the State Senate Republican leader suggested that his conference would not support any effort to bring a key part of the act — a state safeguard of federally recognized abortion rights — to a vote.

headline: Beauty Spots
abstract: Bee pollen, venom and royal jelly are being used along with honey, and increasingly in creams and serums for the face.
lead_paragraph: The beauty buzz is all about bees these days. Honey has long been a staple in cosmetics, with Perlier and Laura Mercier making well-loved bath items that contain it. But now other products of the hive, like pollen, venom and royal jelly, are being used as well, and increasingly in creams and serums for the face. Their salubrious properties supposedly include increasing blood circulation, as well as plumping and hydrating the skin. If all else fails, at least you’ll smell sweet.

headline: Year After Resignation, Virginia Quarterly Review Names an Editor
abstract: W. Ralph Eubanks, the current director of publishing at the Library of Congress, succeeds Ted Genoways.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after Ted Genoways resigned as the editor of the Virginia Quarterly Review, the literary journal has named a successor.

headline: British Stars of Yesteryear Are Ensnared in Sexual Offenses Inquiry
abstract: An investigation into offenses that may or may not have been committed decades ago has resulted in a flurry of arrests and has many people asking who will be next.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The suspects include a flamboyant pop star, a sharp-tongued comedian, a disc jockey known as “the hairy cornflake” and a quirky Australian-born entertainer who performed at the queen’s diamond jubilee concert. Most are in their 70s or 80s, and most are, or were, household names — celebrities from a bygone era.

headline: A Google Duo and a Media Maven Explore a Hyper-Connected Planet
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: A brisk chat between Googlers and a media maven about the emerging Knowosphere.
lead_paragraph: After a goofy introductory chat about the White House Correspondents’ Dinner, this Times Talks conversation involving media columnist David Carr and Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen of Google, co-authors of “The New Digital Age: Reshaping the Future of People, Nations and Business,” becomes a fascinating walk through the emerging Knowosphere:

headline: Medicaid Access Increases Use of Care, Study Finds
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Research', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: New results from an Oregon study found that Medicaid coverage reduced the rate of depression and made low-income adults more financially secure, if not healthier.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Come January, millions of low-income adults will gain health insurance coverage through Medicaid in one of the farthest-reaching provisions of the Obama health care law. How will that change their finances, spending habits, use of available medical services and — most important — their health?

headline: Abroad as Her Father Lay Dying
abstract: A colleague writes about one of the most difficult aspects of expat life.
lead_paragraph: Jan Benzel, an editor with The International Herald Tribune in Paris, had one of those impossibly painful decisions to make.

headline: Boîte
abstract: Milk & Honey, a clandestine bar that Sasha Petraske opened in 2000, has reopened on a charmless stretch of East 23rd Street.
lead_paragraph: The modern fixation with speakeasy culture can be traced to Milk & Honey, a clandestine bar that Sasha Petraske opened in 2000, behind an unmarked door with an unlisted phone number on the Lower East Side. Among the novelties now considered the norm: Bars could take reservations. Bars could have rules (No. 1: “No name dropping”). And cocktails could cost $16.

headline: Prom is Easy. The ‘Ask’ Takes Planning.
abstract: Fortune cookies, a band or a flash mob might be a better approach than simply requesting a date.
lead_paragraph: It was almost midnight, and I was perched next to my teenage son at his computer. He was frantically searching the Internet for a Web site that could produce custom Chinese fortune cookies — in 48 hours. Finally he hit upon a company called Tankinz Inc., and his fingers flew over the keys, “Lizzie, will you go to the prom with me?”

headline: Irish Proposal Would Allow Abortions in Emergencies
abstract: The Irish government has proposed legislation to allow abortion in cases where a threat exists to a woman’s life, including from suicide.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The Irish government proposed legislation late Tuesday night that, if approved as expected, would allow abortions in cases where a threat existed to a woman’s life, including from suicide.

headline: Doomed, but Still Dedicated to Verdi
abstract: The conductor Murry Sidlin led a performance of the concentration camp production “Defiant Requiem.”
lead_paragraph: Extreme deprivation, degradation and abuse are not easily evoked in a concert setting, with relatively comfortable musicians performing for well-fed and highly perfumed listeners. But the conductor Murry Sidlin made a remarkable attempt on Monday in his “Defiant Requiem,” a “concert-drama” presented at Avery Fisher Hall by the UJA-Federation of New York, with ticket sales and sponsorships to benefit Holocaust survivors.

headline: He’s Back From the Dead, With So Much More to Do
abstract: “Like Lazarus Did,” by the Stephen Petronio Company, deals with spiritual striving and the urge to break free.
lead_paragraph: In Stephen Petronio’s “Like Lazarus Did,” dance is preceded by the stillness of death. As you enter the Joyce Theater, where the hourlong work had its debut on Tuesday, the choreographer is already on stage, lying on his back in a dark suit, corpselike, his eyes closed, the soles of his bare feet gilded with gold paint.

headline: Two Pleas for Sanity in Judging Saneness
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: In “Saving Normal,” and “Book of Woe,” a psychiatrist and psychotherapist caution against a surfeit of diagnoses in their profession’s ever-expanding official manual.
lead_paragraph: This month a new edition of the “Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders,” the so-called bible of psychiatry, will be released into the world. This revision, known as the D.S.M.-5, is hovering already on Amazon, its cover an appalling shade of purple, available for advance order at a hardcover price of $189.

headline: On the Aesthetics of the Animated GIF
abstract: The animated GIF is the digital equivalent of the hypnotist’s swinging watch.
lead_paragraph: How many hours have I spent looking at loops of acrobatic cats, snowboard stunts, the human insanity recorded by Russian dashboard cameras? The answer, I’m afraid, is many.

headline: Photos Show Vast Destruction of Nigerian Homes in Raid, Group Says
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Photography']
abstract: Satellite images show 2,275 destroyed buildings in a Nigerian village, corroborating residents’ accounts that soldiers burned their homes, Human Rights Watch said.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Satellite images corroborate the accounts of residents of a fishing village north of here who say that thousands of their homes were destroyed by fire during a recent storm of violence carried out by rampaging soldiers, according to Human Rights Watch.

headline: Speaking of Getting It Wrong
abstract: And learning nothing from the experience.
lead_paragraph: My heart goes out to Brad DeLong, who debated Alan Reynolds and discovered that his opponent really doesn’t understand at all how either fiscal or monetary policy work.

headline: Emotional Tugs, Real and Fictional
abstract: In “Memories Look at Me,” the director and star, Song Fang, travels from Beijing to Nanjing, China, to visit her parents.
lead_paragraph: Delicately balanced between fact and fiction, Song Fang’s “Memories Look at Me,” contemplates dying by honoring the living.

headline: G.M. and Mountain Dew Drop Ads After Criticism
abstract: The General Motors ad included a song with lyrics that crudely referred to the Chinese. Mountain Dew’s ad involved a battered woman and a lineup with African-American men.
lead_paragraph: Both General Motors and Mountain Dew withdrew advertisements on Wednesday after receiving criticism that the ads were racially offensive.

headline: A Novella Emerges Tweet by Tweet
abstract: For Steven Soderbergh, a far-reaching speech and a Twitter novella indicate a retirement that is anything but idle.
lead_paragraph: With the release of “Side Effects” earlier this year, Steven Soderbergh’s retirement from filmmaking (at least for the big screen), announced in 2011, finally took effect. Liberation might be a better word, since his recent activities seem to belong to a restless person newly freed from the constraints of his profession, rather than a used-up man at rest.

headline: In Store | A Poolside Pop-Up Shop at the Standard Hollywood
abstract: The Montreal travel brand Want Les Essentials de la Vie heads south for the summer.
lead_paragraph: After a long Canadian winter, the Montreal travel brand Want Les Essentials de la Vie headed south to design a warm-weather-themed temporary boutique in a white-box space next to the pool deck of the Standard Hollywood. The shop, called Poolside, features rattan rugs, beach balls galore and a vintage summer Olympics poster — a perfect setting for Want’s new collection of unisex bags in sea- and sky-inspired colors and natural materials. Dexter and Byron Peart, the twin brothers behind the company, say they strive to design their products so that they’ll fit any lifestyle. “We have a gold and silver zipper on each bag,” Dexter says. “This represents the intersection between structured and relaxed, young and old, men and women.”

headline: The Newest Russia House
abstract: St. Petersburg’s long-awaited and newest cultural landmark, the Mariinsky II, is set to open this week.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — A few weeks ago, as Valery Gergiev and his Mariinsky Orchestra tested the acoustics of their new $700 million theater here, they played one of the most dramatic selections in the symphonic repertory: the rousing finale of Mahler’s Fifth Symphony.

headline: Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan
abstract: Few experts are willing to back their judgment at the table in making what seem on paper to be very much anti-percentage plays. But they are right far more often than not.
lead_paragraph: A few experts — very few — are willing to back their judgment at the table in making what seem on paper to be very much anti-percentage plays. But they are right far more often than not.

headline: Favorites Draw Outside Posts for Derby
abstract: Orb, the Florida Derby winner trained by Shug McGaughey, the morning line favorite at 7-2 odds, will start the Kentucky Derby on Saturday from the No. 16 post, the same position Animal Kingdom started from when he won in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Orb, the Florida Derby winner trained by Shug McGaughey was made the morning line favorite at 7-2 odds and will start the Kentucky Derby on Saturday from the No. 16 post, the same position Animal Kingdom started from when he won in 2011.

headline: A Score or More of Languages in Your Pocket
abstract: Translation apps have improved because more people are using them, allowing the apps to make more accurate associations with sounds, text and meaning.
lead_paragraph: In Douglas Adams’s “The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy,” the hero sticks a so-called Babel fish in his ear and can understand everything said to him in any language. Today’s apps for language translation try to accomplish the same thing. While not as accurate or instantaneous, they are nevertheless useful and greatly improved from just a couple of years ago. And you don’t have to put anything slimy in your ear.

headline: Becoming a Williamsburg Hipster
abstract: A writer wanted to see what the demographic behind nanobatched chervil and the continually cited show “Girls” could teach him about life and craft cocktails.
lead_paragraph: A writer wanted to see what the demographic behind nanobatched chervil and the continually cited show “Girls” could teach him about life and craft cocktails.

headline: Views of an Adopted Nation in Sharp, Colorful Focus
abstract: New York City Ballet opened its spring season with four Balanchine ballets that presented successive visions of the United States that were enthralling and extraordinary.
lead_paragraph: America is a large country, but it looked larger yet on Tuesday night on the stage at New York City Ballet. Its spring season is dedicated to American music, and its opening night presented successive visions of this country that were all enthralling and extraordinary. By turns charming, shamelessly exuberant, romantic, enigmatic, bright and dark: a spectrum of views emerged during the course of four ballets, all of which were choreographed by George Balanchine between 1954 and 1970. Few ballets made in subsequent years have proved so unusual and compelling.

headline: The Digital Stage for Six-Second Zingers
abstract: Twitter’s virtual comedy festival came off like a Comedy Central awards show: a lot of shameless promotion interrupted by the occasional good joke.
lead_paragraph: What’s the point of a comedy festival on Twitter when every day is a comedy festival on Twitter?

headline: In Vain Pursuit of That 15 Minutes
abstract: Bo Burnham has the title role in a new MTV sitcom, “Zach Stone Is Gonna Be Famous,” about a suburban teenager who has hired a camera crew to document his daily life.
lead_paragraph: Everyone of a certain age sees life as a reality show, and maybe that’s right: the urge toward documentation is greater than ever, and with Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram, Vine, Snapchat and more, it’s easier than ever.

headline: A Mariinsky Addition
abstract: The new $700-million, 2,000-seat theater formally opens on Thursday with a gala concert.
lead_paragraph: The new $700-million, 2,000-seat theater formally opens on Thursday with a gala concert.

headline: Rearranging the Furniture, Minus the Aching Back
abstract: Before you move that grand piano or paint the wall crimson, see if you like how it looks.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever sat on your couch and wondered how it would look across the room, or whether the walls would look good in red, that was your inner interior designer speaking. Now apps offer a quick and powerful way to indulge your home design fantasies.

headline: Fighting Global Poverty, One Mosh Pit at a Time
abstract: Musicians have pledged more than 20,000 concert tickets to the Global Poverty Project to spur activism.
lead_paragraph: When the Global Poverty Project staged a benefit concert with Neil Young, the Black Keys and Foo Fighters in Central Park last fall, skeptics wondered if that nonprofit’s attempt to generate pressure on world leaders to help the poor would fade as soon as the amplifiers and guitars were put away.

headline: How I Became a Hipster
abstract: “Brooklyn” is now a byword for cool from Paris to Sweden to the Middle East, so the author, an avowed Manhattanite, set out to explore this artisan-loving borough.
lead_paragraph: You know you’re in hipster Brooklyn when someone who looks like a 19th-century farmer tells you that his line of work is “affinity marketing.”

headline: Come as You Were
abstract: Nostalgia has overtaken downtown streets, where early ’90s style roams again.
lead_paragraph: The year was 1992; the scene, a fitting at Calvin Klein, where Nadja Auermann, the 6-foot fashion Valkyrie, was trying on the nude-tone slip dress she was to model on Mr. Klein’s runway. “She totally filled it out in this voluptuous way,” recalled Nian Fish, whose job as creative director of the KCD public relations agency was to oversee the proceedings.

headline: Tiling 102: The Bathroom Floor
keywords: ['Brick and Tile', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Tackling a bathroom floor is not for those literally weak in the knees. Be ready to learn from mistakes (lots of them).
lead_paragraph: What’s practical, durable and a pain in the knees?

headline: Shopping for Espresso Cups
abstract: Giulio Cappellini, the art director of the Italian furniture company Cappellini, goes shopping for cups for serving his favorite hot drink.
lead_paragraph: Giulio Cappellini, the art director of the Italian furniture company Cappellini, goes shopping for cups for serving his favorite hot drink.

headline: The Home Workshop Gets an Upgrade
abstract: Inside hacker spaces, where inventors and electronic tinkerers share tools and knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Inside hacker spaces, where inventors and electronic tinkerers share tools and knowledge.

headline: Espresso Cups
abstract: Even a tiny espresso cup can make a design statement.
lead_paragraph: Giulio Cappellini has a knack for identifying the design stars of tomorrow. As the art director of the Italian furniture company Cappellini, he was an early supporter of emerging talents like Jasper Morrison, Tom Dixon and Marc Newson in the 1980s, long before they became giants in the field.

headline: One Big Workbench
abstract: Tinkering has moved out of the suburban garage and acquired a real-life social network.
lead_paragraph: Under different circumstances, or in some earlier America, Yair Silbermintz might have spent his weekday evenings tinkering with a soldering iron alone in the basement of a suburban ranch house.

headline: Carrying a Torch
abstract: Scenes from a three-day design-build camp.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from a three-day design-build camp.

headline: Lessons in How to Play With Fire
abstract: At Jack Sanders’s Heavy Metal camp, welding is the medium but adventure is the mode.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, TEX. — Jack Sanders discovered the Newbern Tigers, a century-old sandlot baseball club from the tiny town of Newbern, Ala., one spring weekend in 1998. He was in his second year at the Rural Studio, the breakaway design-build program at Auburn University run by Samuel Mockbee, which paired architecture students with the state’s poorest residents (mostly citizens of Newbern) to create houses and community projects as individual as the folks they were made for.

headline: In a Creative Season, a New Design Fair
abstract: The architect and designer Steven Learner on Collective.1, a fair devoted entirely to design.
lead_paragraph: On May 8, 23 exhibitors will gather on Pier 57 in Hudson River Park for the first Collective design fair. The event, which coincides with the Frieze Art Fair and a gang of Impressionist and Modern art auctions, inaugurates a vigorous two weeks of art and design activity in New York that includes the International Contemporary Furniture Fair and satellite shows. Steven Learner, 52, the architect and designer who started Collective (known as Collective.1 in its first iteration), made a trip uptown to discuss it.

headline: Bespoke Chandeliers Inspired by Bees
abstract: A light festooned with crystals takes up residence near the palace of Versailles.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Guerlain, the French perfume company, opened a boutique and learning center in La Cour des Senteurs on the Rue de la Chancellerie in Versailles, a hundred yards from the main entrance of the royal chateau. Suspended from the shop’s 22-foot-high arched entrance is a frothy chandelier by Marie Christophe, a sculptor in Toulouse. Ms. Christophe said the light was inspired by the chandeliers of the palace and by the gilded bees on vintage Guerlain bottles. Its wire frame is hung with crystals, some from flea markets and some made by contemporary artisans and embedded with gold paper. The LED chandelier is 7 feet high and 4 feet in diameter and sells for $60,000 through the design retailer Lisa Fontanarosa. Custom sizes are available. Information: (505) 872-1929 or lisafontanarosa.com.

headline: Designing Small Tables for the Big Leagues
abstract: Chris Hardy, a 20-something designer, talked his way into the opportunity to make furniture for Design Within Reach.
lead_paragraph: It was the last day of the Hospitality Design show in Las Vegas three years ago when Chris Hardy ventured into the Design Within Reach booth with his portfolio in hand. There, he stumbled on John Edelman, the company’s chief executive. As a result, Mr. Hardy, a designer in Atlanta, found himself on a short list of hopefuls asked to submit ideas for small tables. He was among those who prevailed, and now his Helix side tables and coffee tables are ready for market. They feature asymmetrical walnut- and cast-bronze bases topped by glass. “The brass not only stabilizes the base but creates a nice movement out from the center, with a layered effect,” said Mr. Hardy, 29. The side table comes with a round top ($1,400), while the coffee table is available with a round or square top ($2,200) or an oval one ($2,400). The tables are at DWR Studios nationwide. Information: (800) 944-2233 or dwr.com.

headline: An Oasis From Everything but Mosquitoes
abstract: A haven from hectic Ho Chi Minh City.
lead_paragraph: A haven from hectic Ho Chi Minh City.

headline: Where Coconuts Come Calling
abstract: A thatched-roof oasis amid the monsoons, mosquitoes and fast pace of the former Saigon.
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — To Peter Arts and Hedwig Pira, it doesn’t feel all that long since they uprooted themselves from a comfortable existence in their native Belgium and took on the formidable task of building a business, a house and a life in a foreign country.

headline: Carving Nature into a Canvas of Wool
abstract: Angela Adams’s new Landscape collection was inspired by woodlands, harbors, gardens and dunes.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Angela Adams, a rug designer in Portland, Me., began using scissors and sheep shears to carve shapes into tufted wool. The second generation of this experiment, a collection called Landscape, is being introduced this week. Ms. Adams described the sculptural rugs as “literal translations of nature,” inspired by her favorite places: “open areas in the woods; a garden in July with big bold bursts of color everywhere; a nice beach I like; and what it feels like to be on the water at night.” The rugs are made in Thailand of hand-tufted New Zealand wool. They are available in four designs (Woodland, Garden, Harbor and Dune) and three sizes (9 by 11 feet for $12,000, 3 by 8 feet for $2,200 and 8-feet round for $8,000). Information: (800) 255-9454 or angelaadams.com.

headline: Clutter Cleverly Put in Its Place
abstract: A new storage system from Henrybuilt resembles a high-end pegboard.
lead_paragraph: Henrybuilt, a Seattle manufacturer of custom kitchens, has plenty of experience helping buyers manage countertop clutter. Now it’s moving on to the rest of the home. The company’s new Opencase Storage System is designed to work in an entry hall, library, office, pantry, closet, laundry room or child’s room, among other places, thanks to an assortment of interchangeable attachments.

headline: Sales at Judy Ross, Doris Leslie Blau and Others
abstract: Discounts on embroidered pillows, antique rugs, display lamps and more.
lead_paragraph: Judy Ross is having a sample sale through Sunday, with up to 70 percent off many pillows and rugs (an 18-inch-square hand-embroidered Landscape pillow, shown, regularly $195, is $80; a 6-by-9-foot Tabla hand-knotted Tibetan wool rug, regularly $5,940, is $2,800); 22 East 17th Street, Suite 536, (212) 842-1705, judyrosstextiles.com.

headline: New York Times/CBS News Poll on Gun Control, Immigration and the Federal Budget
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a New York Times/CBS Poll conducted April 24-April 28, Americans were asked about their views on gun control, immigration and the federal budget.
lead_paragraph: In a New York Times/CBS Poll conducted April 24-April 28, Americans were asked about their views on gun control, immigration and the federal budget.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 24 through April 28 with 965 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 24 through April 28 with 965 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Americans’ Unity on Big Issues Doesn’t Bridge Partisan Gap
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Gun Control', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: A New York Times/CBS News Poll found broad support for background checks on gun buyers and a path to citizenship for immigrants, but discord about which party would address those issues best.
lead_paragraph: While the public overwhelmingly supports background checks for gun buyers and a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, Americans largely retreat into their partisan camps when asked whether President Obama or Congressional Republicans will make the right decisions on those and other domestic issues facing the nation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: U.S. to Defend Age Limits on Morning-After Pill Sales
keywords: ['Plan B (Contraceptive)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Women and Girls', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: With its appeal of an order to make the most common next-day birth control pill available to all ages with no prescription, the Obama administration is returning to a charged political issue.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration moved Wednesday to keep girls under 15 from having over-the-counter access to morning-after pills, as the Justice Department filed a notice to appeal a judge’s order that would make the drug available without a prescription for girls and women of all ages.

headline: Americans on Obama, Guns and Immigration
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Gun Control', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The Times’s Richard L. Berke and Ashley Parker break down the latest New York Times/CBS News poll and find a disconnect between ideology and political support.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Richard L. Berke and Ashley Parker break down the latest New York Times/CBS News poll and find a disconnect between ideology and political support.

headline: Americans on Domestic Policy
abstract: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News asking Americans their views on immigration, gun control, and other policy issues.
lead_paragraph: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News asking Americans their views on immigration, gun control, and other policy issues.

headline: ING’s U.S. Unit Prices Its Market Debut Below Expectations
abstract: The American arm of the ING Group, the Dutch financial services firm, priced its initial public offering at $19.50 a share, below its expected range of $21 to $24. But with nearly $1.3 billion in proceeds, the deal is the second-biggest I.P.O. in the United States this year.
lead_paragraph: The American arm of the Dutch financial services firm ING Group priced its initial public offering at $19.50 a share, below its expected range of $21 to $24.

headline: Baby Toys Get an App Extension
abstract: Toy companies are offering their very youngest customers motion-sensing, app-infused toys like the Fisher-Price Apptivity Gym.
lead_paragraph: As more of the very young reach for their parents’ smartphones, toy companies are responding with motion-sensing, app-infused toys like the Fisher-Price Apptivity Gym ($35, www.fisher-price.com).

headline: Court Dismisses Craigslist Suit Against Competitors
keywords: ['Classified Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal court dismissed a copyright claim in which the listings company argued that it held exclusive licenses to advertisements posted on its Web site.
lead_paragraph: Craigslist does not have exclusive licenses to the postings on its classified advertising Web site, a federal court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Boeing Moves to Upgrade Popular 777 Passenger Jet
abstract: An updated version of the jet, with lightweight carbon-composite wings and the potential to cut fuel usage by 20 percent, is being pitched to airlines and leasing companies.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s sales force is starting to pitch airlines and jet leasing companies on an updated, larger version of its 777 passenger jet, a crucial step toward winning approval from Boeing’s board to build the plane, Boeing officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Quinn Announces Another Effort to Make Parking Meters More User-Friendly
keywords: ['Parking Meters', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Parking', 'Elections, Mayors']
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, wants meters shut off during the hours when drivers are not required to pay for parking.
lead_paragraph: There is a line from Bob Dylan, perhaps history’s most prolific purveyor of misinterpreted lyrics, that reads: “Don’t follow leaders, watch the parking meters.”

headline: May Day Protests Around the World
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Strikes', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'May Day']
abstract: Workers around the globe observed the international holiday with demonstrations and rallies.
lead_paragraph: Workers around the globe observed the international holiday with demonstrations and rallies.

headline: Supporters Rally for Immigration Overhaul
abstract: Tens of thousands of immigrants, Latinos and other supporters of an overhaul of the immigration system turned out on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of immigrants, Latinos and other supporters of an overhaul of the immigration system turned out on Wednesday.

headline: Custodians of Rules Say Woods Made Error
abstract: The U.S.G.A. and the Royal and Ancient said in a statement that Tiger Woods violated the Rules of Golf during last month’s Masters tournament.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — It is the drop that nobody in the golf world seems able to, well, drop. On Wednesday, the sport’s ruling bodies issued their interpretation of Tiger Woods’s rules violation at the Masters, 19 days later.

headline: Subway Delays Were Up in 2012, a Group Finds
abstract: The study, conducted by the Straphangers Campaign, focused on so-called controllable delays — problems associated with signals, switches and tracks, among other factors.
lead_paragraph: Almost immediately after Hurricane Sandy delivered unprecedented flooding to New York City’s subway system, transit officials predicted that train delays could increase in the months and even years that followed.

headline: Youkilis, Now on D.L., Gets Diagnosis and Epidural
abstract: Kevin Youkilis received an epidural that relieved some of his pain, and said if anyone was to blame for an ill-advised return Saturday, it was himself.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Youkilis revealed Wednesday that a bulging L4 disk in his spine was the cause of his back pain, forcing him onto the disabled list and necessitating an epidural.

headline: Amid Fealty to Socialism, a Nod to Capitalism
abstract: On May Day in Havana, among the throngs of state employees marching was a novel and increasingly favored breed: private entrepreneurs and employees.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — In many ways, it was a typical May Day: Hundreds of thousands of Cuban workers — doctors, sailors, dancers, bank clerks — marched Wednesday toward this city’s vast Revolution Plaza, waving flags, holding aloft banners that proclaimed fidelity to socialism and tooting plastic horns.

headline: Viacom and Time Warner Report Lower Revenue
abstract: Sluggishness in the film divisions countered strong performances from cable television channels.
lead_paragraph: Despite strong performances from their cable television channels, Viacom and Time Warner both suffered from sluggishness at their film divisions in the most recent quarter, which hindered the companies’ overall performances.

headline: 13 Years After His Father’s Killing, a Bronx Teenager Meets the Same Fate
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Search and Seizure', 'Gun Control']
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg cited Alphonza Bryant III’s killing to point out the impact of illegal guns and the value of the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk tactic.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks before his fourth birthday, his father was fatally shot leaving a bodega.

headline: Condé Nast Introduces Web Series for Magazines
abstract: The company said it hoped to distribute content through partnerships with Yahoo, AOL and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the latest innovation every magazine wanted to release was an iPad edition. This year, it’s online video content.

headline: Bob Brozman, Guitarist, Is Dead at 59
abstract: Mr. Brozman was a self-described “roving guitar anthropologist” who collaborated with musicians from Northern Ireland to Papua New Guinea.
lead_paragraph: Bob Brozman, a guitarist and self-described “roving guitar anthropologist” who collaborated with musicians from Northern Ireland to Guinea to India to Papua New Guinea, died on April 23 at his home in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 59.

headline: What the Oregon Health Study Can’t Tell
abstract: A landmark study of the health and care of Medicaid patients provides some striking findings, but the longer-term conclusions that can be drawn are limited.
lead_paragraph: The Oregon Health Study — one of the most important public-policy studies of the last decade — released a new round of results on Wednesday, showing that Medicaid coverage does not seem to make low-income adults much healthier, judging by biometric data. At least, that is one fair way to interpret the results, and it is basically the way the authors put it at the top of their new paper.

headline: Trade Policy Notes
abstract: Death by PowerPoint.

lead_paragraph: NEWS As workers around the world observed the international Labor Day holiday with demonstrations and rallies, thousands of Greeks walked off their jobs on Wednesday in the second general strike against government austerity measures this year, shutting down tax offices, leaving state hospitals to operate with emergency employees and disrupting public transportation. The Greek protest came as workers in Asia, including Bangladeshis infuriated by the lethal collapse of a garment factory, demonstrated in cities including the capitals of Cambodia, Indonesia and the Philippines. In Istanbul, riot police officers sprayed throngs of people with water and tear gas as they gathered for a rally, defying an official ban. Niki Kitsantonis and Alan Cowell report.

It was Goods and Services, his showroom, calling. Ikram Goldman, the owner of the Chicago boutique Ikram, wanted to see him immediately. headline: Robert Diamond’s Next Life
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: Ten months after being pushed out as chief executive of Barclays, Diamond is trying to be something other than the “unacceptable face of banking.”
lead_paragraph: In the sparse office he now occupies in the Seagram Building in Midtown Manhattan, Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former C.E.O. of Barclays, paced in circles and tried to explain how he had gone from being one of the highest-ranking and highest-paid bankers in Britain to a guy who takes the subway to this office in exile and waits in line for his coffee at a cart on Park Avenue. Not to suggest that times are too tough for Diamond — he’s not complaining, and he still has more money than his grandchildren’s grandchildren will ever need. But for the American investment banker who was arguably responsible more than anyone else for transforming the British finance industry, it has been a pretty spectacular fall.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Start-Up Machine
abstract: At an entrepreneurial boot camp in Silicon Valley, they’re churning out billion-dollar ideas — whether we need them or not.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Crosby, an energetic 37-year-old lawyer in Boise, Idaho, applied for a loan last November from a local bank, Western Capital. She proposed to use the money, $10,000, to help start a new business, Wevorce, which could be described most reductively as an H&R Block for divorces. The bankers liked the idea, and Crosby was a strong candidate. They had even given her an earlier loan to open Wevorce’s first office. But after four weeks, the bank was stalling and Crosby had yet to receive a cent. At the height of her frustration, she received an e-mail from a small group of private investors in Mountain View, Calif. They invited her to an interview and, after listening to her story, promised her $100,000 in exchange for a 7 percent stake in Wevorce. Crosby accepted on the spot. The next day, she found a condo for rent, at $2,500 a month, in Mountain View, and left Boise, and her boyfriend, behind.

headline: Capturing a Vanishing New York
abstract: Sid Kaplan never had the gifts of schmoozing or self-promotion, but his mastery of darkroom technique made him indispensable to generations of well-known photographers. Now, he has a solo show of his own work.
lead_paragraph: Sid Kaplan, a master black-and-white printer and photographer, is the darkroom equivalent of the session man — the go-to guy famous musicians revere and want to work with, but known to few people outside the industry. He made most of Robert Frank’s prints for more than three decades, as well as many of Louis Stettner’s and Cornell Capa’s. Yet, people don’t stand in front of those prints in galleries and say, “I bet that’s a Sid Kaplan.”

headline: Boom, Bust or What?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Who has the better ideas: Larry Summers, who helped design U.S. economic policy under two Democratic presidents, or Glenn Hubbard, George W. Bush’s tax-cutting guru?
lead_paragraph: One cold late-winter afternoon, Larry Summers was standing by the free-throw line at Lavietes Pavilion, on the Harvard campus, somberly shooting a basketball. In the past couple of years, Summers has sworn off Diet Coke, gluten and junk food and lost a fair amount of weight. As a result, his gray White House T-shirt billowed over his loose gym shorts. Summers, the former Treasury secretary and celebrated economist, is well known for his cutting wit and laserlike focus; he is less well known for his jump shot. But Summers, who recalls with anguish being cut from his high-school basketball team, never let his gaze wander as he took, and missed, nearly every shot. Two Harvard players ran down his rebounds.

headline: Is This the Best Education Money Can Buy?
abstract: At Avenues, the $85 million bet on for-profit schooling is meeting its first real test — parents.
lead_paragraph: One night last winter, more than 120 parents filed into the black-box theater at Avenues: The World School in Chelsea, to learn about what their kids were eating. Ever since the $85 million for-profit start-up opened its doors in September, food had been a divisive issue. After the first week of classes, a group of parents sent a seven-page e-mail detailing concerns: there were not enough snacks, not enough “worldly” snacks like seaweed, zucchini bread with quinoa flour and bean quesadillas (so long as the beans came from BPA-free tin cans). Unlike other New York City private schools, with their decades of institutional wisdom, Avenues was founded on the premise that its parents were partners in building a new community. So it was ready to hear them out.

headline: In Ikram Goldman’s Hands, I Became a Model Student
abstract: When I visited Ikram Goldman’s influential Chicago boutique, I couldn’t help myself; I had to know how Goldman would dress me, if she could.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t think for a moment that anything I wore to Ikram, one of the most prestigious boutiques in the country, would ever be considered chic by anyone who knows anything about what chic actually is. So I went for a look that I hoped appeared, at least, as if it was not trying too hard, a look suitable for midwinter in Chicago, where Ikram is located: a knee-length black skirt, suede black boots, a delicate black and beige top and a short, thick, green cardigan. It was an ensemble meant to announce its own modest aspirations. In retrospect, I wish I’d worn a black cardigan instead of the green one, but in the eyes of Ikram Goldman, the owner of the store, the details wouldn’t have mattered anyway, since the very premise of my message, to her, would be considered absurd: for Ikram, the whole point of clothing is to broadcast something bold.

headline: Bang, Boom: Terrorism as a Game
abstract: “Iron Man 3,” with all its explosions so soon after the Boston Marathon bombings, underscores just how thoroughly terrorism and its aftermath have been colonized by the movies.
lead_paragraph: Right before I saw “Iron Man 3,”  a publicist implored the several hundred attendees — professionals and civilians jammed into a multiplex box and throbbing with excitement — not to reveal any crucial information about the movie to anyone else. After the final credits rolled, and I staggered toward the exit, the booms of explosions still ringing in my ears, I wondered what I could possibly divulge that would spoil the pleasure of an innocent ticket buyer. After all, originality isn’t the point of a product like “Iron Man 3,” which, despite the needless addition of 3-D and negligible differences in quips, gadgets, villains and the type of stuff blown up, plays out much like the first two movies.

headline: In the Playoffs, There Is Room for Panic
abstract: The Knicks and the Thunder won their first three playoff games, but not Games 4 and 5. The rumblings have begun.
lead_paragraph: The rumblings always start when an expected sweep turns into a 3-1 series. It grows into a howl when the series reaches 3-2 and everyone starts wondering if this is the year, finally, for the ultimate comeback. Maybe the favorite did not just nap through a game or two, people start to wonder, maybe they are just not as good as advertised. And then, almost always before things become really interesting, the favorite wins and everybody remembers this is the N.B.A., not hockey or baseball, and N.B.A. does not do upsets, at least not big ones. They are so unstylish. Celebrity fans find them so inconvenient.

headline: Life, Interrupted: All in a Day’s Work
abstract: Dozens of chemotherapy treatments and one bone marrow transplant later, I wish I could say that I’ve mastered the art of not working.
lead_paragraph: The first time I fantasized about early retirement, I was 22 years old. It was a rainy spring morning in Paris, and as I waited for the Métro to take me to my new paralegal job, it occurred to me that I’d rather be sleeping in, or playing hooky at the movies, or sailing around the world. I felt grateful to have a job right out of college, but the “real world” that I discovered – long hours at the office making copies and taking orders from the all-male partners of the firm – was a rude awakening. I got a glimpse of a life that the French describe as “Métro boulot dodo” (subway, work, sleep).

headline: A Rag of Riches
keywords: ['Censorship', 'English Language', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Language and Languages', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Another independent newspaper in Egypt closes: Revolution or not, the media here are more vulnerable than ever.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — This week I am one of many readers mourning the disappearance of Egypt Independent, a local English-language weekly that has provided sterling coverage of the Egyptian uprising in 2011 and the painful, deeply confusing transition that followed.

headline: Unlikely Source of Energy Puts Celtics in Striking Distance
abstract: Without a true point guard, Boston is moving the ball better than the Knicks are, and the Celtics were also helped in Game 5 by the play of Terrence Williams, a former Net.
lead_paragraph: As the Celtics’ locker room emptied of players and reporters late Wednesday night, Terrence Williams peered over the shoulder of a team employee who was studying the box score on the screen of a laptop propped on a table.

abstract: When choosing between Yale and Amherst, Leobardo Espinoza Jr. resorted to the “old-school method of deciding where I felt the most comfortable.”
lead_paragraph: The hardest part about choosing a college was making sure a school’s brand name did not become a factor in my decision.

headline: Big Opening for ‘Iron Man 3’ in China
abstract: “Iron Man 3” is said to have taken in almost $21 million on its first day of release in China.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES— “Iron Man 3” has reasserted Hollywood’s place in China, at least for the moment. Hollywood.com, citing a report from China, said the first day’s take on Wednesday for Marvel Entertainment’s action film was almost $21 million, beating the previous one-day record set by “Transformers: Dark of the Moon” in 2011.

headline: Politics and Vetting Leave Key U.S. Posts Long Unfilled
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: A backlog of vacancies in top posts throughout the Obama administration, especially in the State Department, has slowed policy making in a capital already known for inaction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Kerry is practically home alone at the State Department, toiling without permanent assistant secretaries of state for the Middle East, Asia, Europe and Africa. At the Pentagon, a temporary personnel chief is managing furloughs for 800,000 civilian employees. There has not been a director of the Internal Revenue Service since last November, and it was only on Thursday that President Obama announced a nomination for commerce secretary after the job was open for nearly a year.

headline: The Oregon Data and the Health Care Debate
abstract: Just because Republicans are dysfunctional on health policy doesn’t mean that conservatives are wrong.
lead_paragraph: The big news in health care today is the latest data from an ongoing study of Medicaid recipients in Oregon, which finds that while being on Medicaid improves people’s financial situation and boosts their mental well-being, in the interval studied the program seemed to have little or no statistically significant impact on their actual physical health. I’ll try to have more to say about this over the weekend  — for now, I recommend reading Megan McArdle and Jonathan Cohn for a sense of the debate — but since I’ve been writing about the Republican Party’s health policy problem this week I was struck by this line from Matt Yglesias, in a post mostly dismissing the significance of the new data:

headline: The Gun Report: May 2, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, my new friend Jessica Mindich held a gun buyback in New Jersey. She really did. The company she runs, Jewelry For a Cause—which melts down guns and turns them into very cool-looking bracelets—put up $33,000 in proceeds from bracelet sales, allowing the city of Newark to offer cash for guns. More than 200 guns were turned in, including a number of assault weapons. The city touted the success of the buyback with a press conference on Tuesday. Indeed, Mindich and Newark view the buyback as so successful they are planning to hold another one later this summer.

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Nelson D. Schwartz on whether lowering interest rates can have sustained effects on slumping markets.

abstract: Claims of the home mortgage interest deduction vary widely by state and ZIP code.
lead_paragraph: An analysis from the Pew Charitable Trusts finds that the use of the mortgage interest deduction varies widely across the country, with concentrations on the East Coast and in the West, and in areas with higher property values. The average size of the deduction varies, too.

headline: New Venture Firm Opens in New York
abstract: The firm, Bowery Capital, plans to invest in business-oriented start-ups with a marketing or technology focus. It is led by Mike Brown Jr., who previously co-founded AOL Ventures.
lead_paragraph: The field of enterprise technology has been particularly hot among investors recently, especially after a string of well-received public offerings.

headline: Medicaid Nonsense
abstract: I do not think that study means what you think it means.
lead_paragraph: Busy day, no additional blogging until much later. But you should be reading The Incidental Economist on the Oregon Medicaid study that’s creating a lot of fuss today. Basically, budget woes forced Oregon to allocate Medicaid access by lottery, giving a rare randomized experiment. Those who got Medicaid suffered much less financial distress and less depression; they received more preventive care; but on some (not all dimensions) their health wasn’t significantly better than those who lost out in the lottery.

headline: Talking to the 2014 Chevrolet Impala: G.M.’s Improved MyLink
abstract: Automotive voice command systems can be infuriating when they misinterpret your commands. General Motors seems to have worked out the bugs with the 2014 Chevy Impala.
lead_paragraph: Talking to your car can be like trying to reason with a recalcitrant toddler. It often petulantly refuses to obey your commands or, worse, does the opposite of what you want. But in-vehicle voice recognition systems are gradually improving, as demonstrated by the new version of Chevrolet’s MyLink system.

headline: For Sons of ‘Raisin,’ a Back-to-Back Duel
abstract: Kwame Kwei-Armah has written a play inspired by “A Raisin in the Sun” that is being staged in repertory with “Clybourne Park” at CenterStage in Baltimore under the umbrella title “The Raisin Cycle.”
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When Kwame Kwei-Armah took the job of artistic director at this city’s biggest theater, CenterStage, in the summer of 2011, he started hearing a drumbeat about one play in particular.

headline: A Classic’s Behind-the-Scenes Drama
abstract: Richard Nelson’s new play, “Nikolai and the Others,” dramatizes the artists behind the Balanchine-Stravinsky ballet classic “Orpheus.”
lead_paragraph: The tangled themes of “Nikolai and the Others,” a new play by Richard Nelson, swirl around the making of “Orpheus,” a work born from one of the most important partnerships in ballet’s history: the choreographer George Balanchine and the composer Igor Stravinsky.

headline: Venture Capital’s Rocky Road for Entrepreneurs
abstract: New data point to higher failure rates among start-ups that take venture capital and even fewer chances for the founders of companies to earn anything in an exit.
lead_paragraph: In my previous Deal Professor column, I wrote about a Delaware lawsuit involving a venture capital company, Bloodhound Technologies, and how it exposed venture capital’s dirty little secret: in a sale, the founders are often left with nothing even if the venture capitalists profit.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – One of the world’s largest deals in recent years has finally reached the finishing line.

headline: American-Born Children Are at Higher Risk of Allergies
abstract: Children born outside the United States were 48 percent less likely to suffer from allergic diseases like asthma, eczema, hay fever and food allergies than those born in America, a study found.
lead_paragraph: American children born outside the United States may have a significant advantage over the native-born: They are less likely to have allergies.

headline: Market Report | Punk Pieces
abstract: In honor of the upcoming exhibit at Metropolitan Museum of Art, “Punk: Chaos to Couture,” T seeks out the rock legacy in today’s market.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art pays homage to the style influence of iconic enfants terribles like Joe Strummer and Sid Vicious in the new exhibit “Punk: Chaos to Couture,” which will open to the public on May 9. headline: Instagram Deal Is Looking Better and Better
abstract: The acquisition of Instagram by Facebook a year ago was risky, and Instagram is still not profitable. But the potential payout is increasing, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s Instagram option is looking like a better bet than it was a year ago. The social network agreed to shell out $1 billion for the revenue-free photo-sharing app. Even paid for partially in overvalued stock, the deal looked pricey. Instagram’s growth spurt – it passed 100 million monthly users in the first quarter – suggests Facebook is turning a defensive move to its advantage.

lead_paragraph: Those who use Twitter to comment about the Mets – from @MetsMerized and @kranepool to @TheHappyRecap and @metspolice — usually have plenty to say.

abstract: The protagonist of Claire Messud’s new novel is an elementary schoolteacher in need of a fantasy. She finds one.
lead_paragraph: Claire Messud’s latest novel, “The Woman Upstairs,” is an incongruous mashup of a very self-consciously literary novel (invoking the likes of Chekhov) and one of those psychological horror films like “Single White Female” or “The Hand That Rocks the Cradle,” in which someone, ominously, is not who she appears to be.

abstract: In 2011, of the women who reported having had a birth in the previous 12 months, 35.7 percent were unmarried.
lead_paragraph: The share of births to unmarried mothers is up, according to a new report from the Census Bureau.

headline: ‘Buyer & Cellar’ Moving to Larger Theater

lead_paragraph: Solo shows are having a mixed reception on Broadway, with the early closing of “Testament of Mary” (starring Fiona Shaw) on Sunday and the shut-outs of “I’ll Eat You Last” (Bette Midler) and “Macbeth” (Alan Cumming) for Tony Award nominations this week. But Michael Urie’s one-man play “Buyer & Cellar” is flourishing Off Broadway: The critically acclaimed production, about a struggling actor who becomes an assistant of sorts to Barbra Streisand, will transfer from the 99-seat Rattlestick Playwrights Theater to a commercial run at the 199-seat Barrow Street Theater. After closing May 12 at Rattlestick, performances will resume June 18 at Barrow Street, initially for 10 weeks; the producers hope that ticket sales will be good enough to extend for an open-ended run.

The O-train features observatory rooms and sightseeing monitors, and makes a five-hour loop around the central inland region, taking in deep gorges and stopping at 13 stations. keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'E-Commerce', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business']

lead_paragraph: Two years ago, as Charles Kuhn struggled to steer Kopp’s Cycle, the bicycle shop he owns in Princeton, N.J., through a tenuous economic recovery, he noticed that fewer and fewer of the nominal “customers” in his shop were actually buying anything. Instead, he told The Agenda at the time, “People come in with their smartphone and scan a bar code on a product that I have in my showroom, and what comes up on the phone is the three closest places and their price and then also what it is on Amazon.”

headline: Air Pollution’s Role in Heart Disease
abstract: Following more than 5,000 people in six cities and air pollution data, researchers found that the greater the level of air pollution, the greater the thickening of the carotid artery, a known risk for heart attack and stroke.
lead_paragraph: Air pollution has been linked to cardiovascular disease, and now researchers may be closer to understanding why: it increases atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries, a known risk for heart attack and stroke.

headline: Cameristas
abstract: It isn’t possible to tell the story of the Civil War without recourse to the million photographic images that were created, some of the best of which are part of a new museum exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 150 years ago, in March or April 1863, a shocking photograph was taken in Louisiana. Unlike most photos, it was given a title, “The Scourged Back,” as if it were a painting hanging in an art museum. Indeed, it fit inside a recognizable painter’s category — the nude — but this was a nude from hell. The sitter, an African-American male named Gordon, had been whipped so many times that a mountainous ridge of scar tissue was climbing out of his back. It was detailed, like a military map, and resulted from so many whippings that the scars had to form on top of one another. Gordon had escaped from a nearby Mississippi plantation to a camp of federal soldiers, supporting the great Vicksburg campaign of the spring. Medical officers examined him, and after seeing his back, asked a local photography firm, McPherson and Oliver, to document the scar tissue.

headline: Why a UBS Split Would Not Be the Best Move
abstract: The chief executive of the Swiss banking giant, the author says, should see Knight Vinke’s intervention as a warning — stick with the program and don’t stop cutting risk.
lead_paragraph: UBS is the wrong target for an activist-led breakup. Knight Vinke has called on the Swiss bank to separate its risky investment banking business from the core wealth-management arm. The investment firm is right that no one would create a bank modeled on UBS as it is today. But it doesn’t automatically follow that a breakup is the best strategy.

lead_paragraph: Izzy Young, who owned the Folklore Center in Greenwich Village during the height of the folk revival, is famous for having nurtured a young Bob Dylan when he first arrived in New York City. Mr. Dylan would hang around the back of Mr. Young’s store on Macdougal Street, listening to records and writing songs, and it was Mr. Young who organized Mr. Dylan’s first concert in the city in 1961.

abstract: The suicide rate among middle-age Americans rose 30 percent from 1999 to 2010, with more people now dying of suicide than in car accidents.
lead_paragraph: Suicide rates among middle-aged Americans have risen sharply in the past decade, prompting concern that a generation of baby boomers who have faced years of economic worry and easy access to prescription painkillers may be particularly vulnerable to self-inflicted harm.

lead_paragraph: This interview with Wendy Lea, chief executive of Get Satisfaction, a customer experience platform, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Boyle Feels Good but Is Unlikely for Game 1
abstract: Brian Boyle and Marc Staal practiced with the Rangers on Thursday morning, but both are doubtful for the first game of the playoff series against the Capitals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The injured Rangers Brian Boyle and Marc Staal skated with the team at the Verizon Center Thursday morning, but it did not seem likely that either would play in Game 1 of the playoff series against the Capitals Thursday night.

headline: Crowning 1 World Trade Center
abstract: The spire of 1 World Trade Center was hoisted aloft on Thursday and set atop a temporary platform. It will be bolted into place at a later date.
lead_paragraph: Looking a bit like a rocket taking flight, the spire of 1 World Trade Center was hoisted aloft on Thursday and set on a temporary platform atop the nearly completed building. When it is bolted into place at a later date, the spire will bring the building to a height of 1,776 feet.

headline: Revisiting Some Well-Eyed Streets
abstract: Works by the photographer Garry Winogrand — more than any museum has mounted at once — are the focus of a retrospective at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Garry Winogrand refreshed classic street photography in the 1960s and ’70s, influenced by (and influencing) the increasingly warped sensibility that had started to shape the broader culture. Using a snapshot style, he captured the nation’s unseemly nervous breakdown in stark black and white.

headline: That Period Look, Ringlets and All
abstract: A chat with Wrenn Schmidt, who will play the young muse Hilde in a production of Ibsen’s “Master Builder” at the Harvey Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: With her flowing red curls and the spray of freckles dusting her porcelain skin, Wrenn Schmidt looks like a Dante Gabriel Rossetti painting that has swanned off the canvas. She wears 1920s chiffons and cloches on the HBO series “Boardwalk Empire,” on which she plays Julia Sagorsky, the sympathetic girlfriend of the masked and disfigured tough guy Richard Harrow (Jack Huston), like a second skin. (HBO confirms that her character will return in the fourth season.) And the Mint Theater, which traffics exclusively in the curiosities of yesteryear, has drawn on Ms. Schmidt’s talents more than once, most recently in the title role of “Katie Roche.”

lead_paragraph: Performances of the Broadway play “The Nance” will be extended by eight weeks through August 11, Lincoln Center Theater announced on Thursday, aiming to capitalize on the Tony Award nomination this week for lead actor Nathan Lane.

headline: Normandy Invasion Too Keen During Workout
abstract: Normandy Invasion, a 12-1 shot at the Kentucky Derby, ran off with his exercise rider for three-eighths of a mile, but he appeared to be unhurt.
lead_paragraph: The draw for post positions is complete, and the morning-line odds for the 139th running of the Kentucky Derby have been set. None of the key contenders appeared to be compromised by their post-position draw, so the Churchill Downs oddsmaker, Mike Battaglia, did not have to adjust the preliminary line he made before the draw. The favorites are Orb (7-2, Post 16) and Verrazano (4-1, Post 14).

headline: My Tryout of Citi’s Price Protection Service
abstract: A refund service from Citi has some caveats.
lead_paragraph: Awhile back, I wrote about a new service that Citigroup offers on its credit cards called Price Rewind. It lets cardholders register purchases, and then searches for the same items at lower prices. If it finds one, it refunds you the difference.

headline: Corporate Jet Center Exposes Silicon Valley’s Class Divide
abstract: A technology boom that once created middle-class jobs and lifted the overall economy now fuels a growing gap between the very rich and everyone else.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The approval of a new corporate jet center at this city’s struggling airport might have been just another losing skirmish in the battle between Silicon Valley billionaires and middle-class neighborhoods worried about noise pollution. Instead, it is becoming the latest symbol for the rapidly growing gap between the region’s haves, with their private jets and untold wealth, and the have-nots, clinging to more modest lives in the dwindling number of communities they can afford.

headline: Putting Politics Ahead of Science

headline: Albee’s New Play, ‘Laying an Egg,’ Postponed Again
abstract: Edward Albee’s play “Laying an Egg” was to have been the centerpiece of the new season at the Signature Theater, which scheduled and postponed the work once before, in the 2011-12 season.
lead_paragraph: Edward Albee’s “Laying an Egg,” announced six weeks ago as a centerpiece of the Signature Theater’s 2013-14 season, has been postponed for the second time, the company announced on Thursday. Mr. Albee’s work was originally to have had its world premiere as part of the Off Broadway company’s 2011-12 season – its first at the Pershing Square Signature Center, its new Midtown space – but was postponed when the famously self-critical playwright, now 85, decided that it needed revamping.

headline: Study Finds No Single Cause of Honeybee Deaths

The problems affect pollination of American agricultural products worth tens of billions of dollars a year.

headline: Afghan Government Faces Cash Crunch
abstract: A confidential assessment by the International Monetary Fund said the budget shortfall was caused by tax evasion, corruption and slow economic growth.

headline: The Sacred of the Material World
abstract: “At War With the Obvious,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, showcases William Eggleston’s photographs of the real, material world.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like ‘The Shining,’ ” a young man said to his companion, who agreed with a chuckle. I was eavesdropping as they talked about one of William Eggleston’s 36 transcendentally beautiful photographs from the 1970s and early ’80s in “At War With the Obvious,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It depicts a grungy, turquoise-tiled shower and bath alcove. Shot straight-on with deadpan objectivity, the image does have an ominous feeling. Shower scenes being a staple of horror movies, and Stanley Kubrick, the director of “The Shining,” being a master of highly stylized dread, I could understand the comment.

headline: For Love of the Game

lead_paragraph: Last May, the Santa Fe Fuego, an expansion team in the lowly Pecos League, the minor leagues of the minor leagues, threw their first pitch into baseball ignominy. Their starting pitcher was 47-year-old Rodney Tofoya, a former has-been in various Mexican and Canadian leagues, and a V.P. at the Albuquerque branch of Bank of the West. He was supported by an active roster of 22 players, each of whom the team paid $54 per week and 15 of whom Tafoya put up in his own house. The Fuego somehow won their opener, 14-8. Though some people believed the score was 16-8. Whatever. There wouldn’t be too many more wins to savor all year long.

headline: Off Camera, Hopper Wielded His Own Lens

lead_paragraph: DENNIS HOPPER made the black-and-white photograph in 1966: Claes Oldenburg, in blazer and skinny tie, standing tall among slices of white wedding cake laid out on the grass. The story the picture does not tell is that the two men were at a wedding whose guest list was the cream of the Los Angeles art scene, and that the slices were of inedible plaster, Pop objects made by Mr. Oldenburg as party favors. Hopper snapped the shot, then made off with 16 slices — enough to reconstruct a full cake, his first wife, Brooke Hayward, recalled in an interview.

headline: Don’t Bring Daddy to School for Vocation Day
abstract: In “The Iceman” Michael Shannon plays Richard Kuklinski, a notorious contract killer who is as cold as his nickname suggests.
lead_paragraph: In “The Iceman” Michael Shannon’s mesmerizing portrayal of Richard Kuklinski, a notorious contract killer, has the paradoxical quality, peculiar to many great screen performances, of being unreadable and transparent. You can’t really see through Richard, whose pale-blue eyes take in the world from a face as expressionless as a sphinx. But in its tiniest tremors you can sense explosive forces roiling below the mask and grasp the duality with a visceral feeling of dread. It is a performance that has the same life-or-death gravity Mr. Shannon brought to the role of a man driven half-mad by apocalyptic portents in “Take Shelter.”

I noted one example in their Times piece, in which they tried to rebut the reverse-causation argument by associating it with a claim — that it’s all about the business cycle — that, as far as I know, nobody has made.

headline: Matching Albariños With More Than Just Seafood
abstract: This white Spanish wine goes well with cheese and asparagus, too.
lead_paragraph: People say that no wine pairs well with asparagus. I beg to differ. And Eric Asimov wondered whether anything other than seafood should be put with the albariños we tasted. Again, I beg to differ. Seafood is an obvious choice, but there is a long list of cheeses that would work well. Satiny, funky Torta del Casar and rich Mahón come to mind, though there are many other options from beyond Spain. Perhaps cheese with asparagus; these wines, with their persistent citric notes and occasional herbal allure, easily tame that springtime wine challenger. I chose asparagus barely cooked, to dress pasta in pastel green. I kept the tips whole and used the stems to make a finely ground pestolike mixture with garlic, olive oil and cheese, this time Grana Padano. Asparagus done this way also could enrich a risotto, fill an omelet or garnish a fillet of salmon.

headline: Le Carré’s Latest
abstract: In John le Carré’s new novel, “A Delicate Truth,” shortsightedness, hypocrisy, lies and unfettered greed plague the “post-imperial, post-cold-war world.”
lead_paragraph: “I have a theory which I suspect is rather immoral,” George Smiley said in John le Carré’s 1974 classic, “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.” “Each of us has only a quantum of compassion. That if we lavish our concern on every stray cat, we never get to the center of things.” This concept of necessary, if lamentable, sacrifice in the face of the Soviet monolith helped define the espionage masterpieces of the cold war. Such statements gave fans a rush of pleasure, partly aesthetic, partly clandestine — the feeling they were gaining a bit of secret Machiavellian wisdom.

headline: With a Museum for a Neighbor ...
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The American Folk Art Museum isn’t the first important building to get in MoMA’s way.
lead_paragraph: The blogs are aflame with righteous indignation at the Museum of Modern Art’s decision to demolish its new acquisition, the 2001 American Folk Art Museum, at 45 West 53rd Street, designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. Its peculiar but much-admired facade of roughened bronze captures the dark side of high-style modernism, the spaceshiplike surface reminiscent of the planet-destroying Death Star in the “Star Wars” series.

headline: Where the Raises Are: Trucking and Academia
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Compensation growth has been relatively flat across the board in recent years. The biggest raises have been in transportation and higher education.
lead_paragraph: I spoke today with Diane Swonk, chief economist at Mesirow Financial, who mentioned that she has been keeping an eye on which industries and occupations are giving raises. Unfortunately, not many fall under that category.

headline: Blood Ties That Don’t Quite Bind
abstract: Daniel Algrant’s “Greetings From Tim Buckley” is a biopic about two musicians who died young: the folk singer Tim Buckley and his folk-rocker son, Jeff Buckley.
lead_paragraph: Biopics come in a number of flavors, though most turn out either to be hagiographies that clean up the little and big messes of famous lives, burnishing legends for maximum nostalgia, or analytical postmortems that try to put their subjects into play with history and the world. “Greetings From Tim Buckley” takes a look at two musicians who died young and were largely strangers, Tim Buckley and his son Jeff Buckley, and goes right for worship: it’s sweet, sentimental, almost inevitably touching if not especially persuasive, brushing against the thorns in each man’s life without drawing blood. Mostly it plays out as a virtual reunion tour and fantasy father-and-son encounter session.

abstract: Bolivia’s most populous city is at the center of the country’s growing drug trade and an alarming crime wave.
lead_paragraph: Bolivia’s most populous city is at the center of the country’s growing drug trade and an alarming crime wave.

headline: Video of Killing Crystallizes Bolivian Anger Over Crime
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Crime Rates', 'Organized Crime', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A killing captured on video has focused public anger on crime in Santa Cruz, Bolivia’s most populous city and a center of the country’s growing drug trade.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia — The shocking video, taken from a security camera, showed the killer in a backward baseball cap and dark glasses, stalking his terrified prey in broad daylight on a city street. His victim seemed to plead for his life and tried to stumble away before the killer, gripping the pistol in two hands, shot the man dead beside a parked car.

abstract: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev told the F.B.I. that he and his brother finished building their bombs sooner than expected and that they considered suicide attacks, according to two officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings told F.B.I. interrogators that he and his brother considered suicide attacks and striking on the Fourth of July as they plotted their deadly assault, according to two law enforcement officials.

lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The neo-Nazi Golden Dawn party, which has 18 seats in the Greek Parliament, has been widely criticized for attacking immigrants. But now its members seem to have a new target: politicians.

headline: To Do: Wander Aimlessly
abstract: The title of “generation Um ...” captures the disenchantment of post-slacker New York anti-achievers.
lead_paragraph: The title of “generation Um ...” distills the attitude of bored disenchantment shared by its three main characters, a pair of downtown Manhattan roommates — Violet (Bojana Novakovic) and Mia (Adelaide Clemens) — and John (Keanu Reeves), their pal and occasional chauffeur. John, who shares a ratty apartment with two other men, is a driver for an escort service for which Violet and Mia moonlight. In the opening scene, the young women, being driven home from a party, carry on a furious argument about the past tense of an obscenity, as John grows increasingly infuriated by their yammering and crashes the vehicle.

lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has a new look to it.

headline: Baruch Students Break Out the Ray-Bans
abstract: In December, Baruch College, with no outdoor space to call its own, received permission from the city to permanently close its East 25th Street block to vehicular traffic; it has since been reconfigured into an outdoor plaza.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University has its verdant quad, New York University has Washington Square, but until recently, Baruch College, the City University of New York’s outpost in the Flatiron District, had no outdoor space to call its own.
