headline: Rogue Philosopher, Great Communicator
abstract: Soren Kierkegaard’s strategy of “indirect communication” is not too far removed from the “dog-whistling” of modern political campaigns.
lead_paragraph: For years, visitors to the Copenhagen City Museum wandered into a modest room that contains a few artifacts from the Danish philosopher Soren Kierkegaard’s life: portraits, meerschaum pipes, first editions and, best of all, the desk where he stood and produced with preternatural speed a series of original and difficult works, many of them written pseudonymously and published in editions that numbered in the hundreds — among them “Either-Or,” “Fear and Trembling,” “The Concept of Dread” and “Repetition.” The exhibit has been refreshed to mark Kierkegaard’s 200th birthday on May 5th. His belongings — a large library, furniture, paintings, and knickknacks —were pretty well dispersed after his death in 1855, but the expanded version will add an “outer circle” of relevant material. Manuscripts and papers from the Kierkegaard archives will be on display at the Royal Library.

headline: Learning to Love ‘the People’s Food’ in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
abstract: At Vietnamese restaurants in America, all kinds of foods are served together — noodles, soups, stir-frys, spring rolls. But in Vietnam, restaurants are often devoted to a single dish.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1996, fresh out of college, I moved to Ho Chi Minh City for one simple reason: I loved Vietnamese food. At restaurants in Virginia, Maryland and Washington, I’d grown fond of the staples of the cuisine — grilled meats, startling herbs, crunchy vegetables — and particularly of pho, the aromatic beef noodle soup that is Vietnam’s national dish. As graduation approached, I knew I wanted to live overseas, and Communist Vietnam, which had just opened its doors to the West, was the obvious choice. In fact, it didn’t even feel like a choice at all — it felt like destiny.

headline: Love, Light, Strength (and Glue)
abstract: When a mantra no longer helps to put the pieces back together, time and patience do.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, my husband, Miles, who led a tree crew, could work like a horse. A normal week for him was 60-plus hours. In his spare time he built fences and decks for our fixer-upper house. Meanwhile, I fed the kids and ran them around, shopped at Home Depot and paid the bills.

headline: Admissions Anxiety Is Felt Around the World
abstract: What happens when an American family lives overseas and it’s time to apply for college? A writer who specializes in higher education and his daughter begin their search.
lead_paragraph: This week on The Choice on India Ink, we’d like to draw your attention to an international college search that is taking place elsewhere in the world.

headline: What Money, Dear?
keywords: ['ADULTERY', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: How to explain an extramarital windfall; the ‘boyfriend’ salary penalty; and germophobic travel etiquette.
lead_paragraph: I had an extramarital affair for many years with a man I loved. Over time, our sexual relationship matured into a friendship. He died last fall, leaving me a large sum of money in his will, which I have yet to receive. Soon, my husband, whom I love, will learn of this windfall. What should I tell him when he asks where it came from? The affair was over, but the truth would still hurt. Is clearing the air the best protocol?

headline: Drama, Uninvited, Is in the Wedding Party
abstract: A wedding is at the center of “Love Is All You Need,” a romantic comedy starring Pierce Brosnan.
lead_paragraph: The first sign of trouble in the romantic comedy “Love Is All You Need” is the clichéd and incessant use of “That’s Amore.” Ever since that early-’50s Dean Martin hit was used in “Moonstruck” in 1987, the song has been pop culture’s Pavlovian signal to wallow in the jollier side of all things Italian. Much of this movie, about a wedding that goes awry, is set in Sorrento, overlooking the Bay of Naples. But as the story progresses the tune’s insistent levity is contradicted by the awful behavior of some pigheaded characters.

headline: Figuring Out How to Give Teachers Useful Feedback
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: While Texas legislators and educators agree that better methods are needed for teacher assessment, the question of tying evaluations to test scores is a sticking point.
lead_paragraph: When Texas lawmakers rolled out a framework for evaluating public schoolteachers more than 15 years ago, they intended to identify ways to strengthen the state’s teaching corps.

headline: Sex and Sadness After a Failed Revolt
abstract: Olivier Assayas’s “Something in the Air” looks at the aftermath of a promising revolutionary energy that surged through France in 1968.
lead_paragraph: Baby-boomer coming-of-age stories are about as rare as superhero movies or career-girl romantic comedies, and no less bound by conventions. A sensitive child, growing up amid social and political turmoil, feels misunderstood by parents and the universe and discovers what a character in “A Serious Man” memorably called “the new freedoms.” Sex, drugs and heartbreak line the path to a sadder, wiser understanding of life, in which youthful rage and idealism are blunted but not entirely abandoned.

lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The Wells Fargo Championship was not originally on Zach Johnson’s schedule. He added it after pulling out of last week’s Ballantine’s Championship, an event outside Seoul, South Korea, that was co-sanctioned by the European and Asian tours.

headline: What to Do in Tokyo
abstract: Eat, shop and squeeze through the crowds in the giant Japanese city.
lead_paragraph: Eat, shop and squeeze through the crowds in the giant Japanese city.

headline: 36 Hours in Tokyo
abstract: Besides joining the crowds on Tokyo’s shopper-clogged streets, you can take a cruise, see a Buddhist temple or partake of a kaiseki dinner on the 45th floor of a luxury hotel.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s population may be skewing older, leading the global march to demographic gridlock, but Tokyo feels like a city powered by the young. Sophisticated and sprawling, with half a dozen city centers that long ago grew together, it combines the life force of a national capital of everything — politics, finance, culture, style — with a talent for change and renewal that it earned the hard way, bouncing back after repeated flattening by earthquakes, fires and war over its 400 years of existence. The skyscraper race of the ’90s has slowed down, but a new romance with the city’s waterfront is flourishing, spots for sushi and pâté de foie gras are always being added to its 160,000 restaurants, and the teenagers jamming anime-inspired shopping districts update the outlandish costume of the moment every few months.

headline: House of Un-Representatives
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This Republican House is almost like a parallel government, sitting in for some fantasy nation created in talk-radio land.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the congressman from northeast Texas, Louie Gohmert, was talking about how the trans-Alaska oil pipeline improved the sex lives of certain wild animals — in his mind, the big tube was an industrial-strength aphrodisiac. “When the caribou want to go on a date,” he told a House hearing, “they invite each other to head over to the pipeline.”

headline: Gangster Life Beckons for a Fresh Parolee
abstract: “Once Upon a Time in Brooklyn,” directed by Paul Borghese, enlists some familiar faces for a tale about a parolee who rejoins his old gang of thugs.
lead_paragraph: As a rule of thumb, the thicker a film’s publicity notes, the slimmer its rewards. So if I tell you that the notes for “Once Upon a Time in Brooklyn” (previously titled “Goat”) could probably choke a medium-size anaconda, you may not need to read further.

headline: Amtrak Subsidy Gone, States Must Pay the Freight to Keep Rail Routes
abstract: Under pressure to reduce its dependence on federal subsidies, Amtrak is looking at either closing 28 short-haul routes or getting 19 states to share the costs.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGDON, Pa. — The unmistakable wail of a locomotive horn and screeching steel wheels signal the arrival of the evening Amtrak train in this central Pennsylvania town just over an hour west of Harrisburg, the state capital. The train is one of two that stop here daily, a vital link to Harrisburg, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and the entire Northeast Corridor.

headline: Loan Qualifications for Retirees
abstract: For retirees seeking a mortgage, even a spotless credit history and ample retirement accounts may not do the trick.
lead_paragraph: Retirees trying to obtain a mortgage may find that a pristine credit history and healthy retirement accounts are not enough. Lenders are also looking for a consistent monthly income in line with their usual debt-to-income standards.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: World Electronics

headline: New Push to Capture Woman in ’73 Killing of State Trooper
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism', 'Prison Escapes', 'Police', 'Attacks on Police']

lead_paragraph: The end came suddenly for Werner Foerster, a 34-year-old state trooper executed with his own gun on the New Jersey Turnpike in 1973. For many others — his widow, the State Police and the woman convicted of his murder — the end remains elusive, postponed these 40 years by a fight over what justice really means.

headline: Agony Eased by a Gentle Art
abstract: “Free the Mind,” a documentary directed by Phie Ambo, explores how meditation and exercises can be used to alleviate post-traumatic stress.
lead_paragraph: Phie Ambo’s inoffensive documentary “Free the Mind” tries to depict the methodical ways in which meditation and mindfulness can be used to treat life-changing anxiety and trauma. Hitched to the research of the psychology professor Richard Davidson (who is featured), the film switches between a few haunted Iraq war veterans and a fearful foster child with lots of energy. It’s patient and free of shame. But as it briskly shows their progress, broken up by dippy animations of neuron storms, it feels like a demonstration of a point.

headline: Paramount Hopes New ‘Star Trek’ Is a Global Crowd-Pleaser

headline: A Diner, a Family and a Murder Plot
abstract: The Tick Tock Diner in New Jersey is at the center of a scheme in which officials say a manager plotted to have his uncle tortured and killed for cash in the diner’s safe.
lead_paragraph: CLIFTON, N.J. — Explaining the success of Greek diners to an interviewer 15 years ago, Alex Sgourdos talked about “kerdos” — profit — and family. “To show you’re Greek, all you have to do is work 12 hours a day and have lots of relatives who like the business and work with you,” he said.

headline: Plenty of Dust, Bullets and Relationship Drama
abstract: In “Dead Man’s Burden,” a woman and her husband wring a living from her family’s parched homestead, watched over by the accumulating graves of her unlucky kin.
lead_paragraph: “Dead Man’s Burden,” Jared Moshé’s morally complex, stylistically minimalist western, begins and ends with a stone-cold killing. The emotions between, however, are anything but cool, as the film’s small group of primary characters slips from joy to fury to murderous suspicion with faultless fluidity.

lead_paragraph: After racing through yet another PowerPoint presentation filled with numerous bar graphs and small-font economic data, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday took a minidetour during his final budget address to praise someone’s record: His own.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A federal judge said in a ruling filed Thursday that James “Whitey” Bulger cannot tell a jury at his coming trial he had immunity from prosecution — a decision that is likely to hobble the defense strategy for the New England mob leader.

keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'Movies', 'Legal Profession', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']

lead_paragraph: On the night of April 16, Frank Chi, watching television, became upset by the documentary “The Central Park Five,” about an attack on a jogger in 1989 and how the world responded to it.

headline: Venezuela: Legal Challenge to Vote
abstract: Lawyers for the opposition candidate in the recent presidential election, Henrique Capriles Radonski, on Thursday submitted papers to the Supreme Court challenging the result.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the opposition candidate in the recent presidential election, Henrique Capriles Radonski, on Thursday submitted papers to the Supreme Court challenging the result. Mr. Capriles lost to Nicolás Maduro, the handpicked heir of former President Hugo Chávez, by less than two percentage points. Arguing that the voting was marred by irregularities, the lawyers said the goal was to force a new election. Mr. Capriles said this week that he did not expect a favorable ruling from the court, which many say is packed with government loyalists. But he said he hoped that international pressure would impel a change in Venezuela. He has refused to take part in a partial review of digital voting records planned by electoral authorities, calling it a sham.

headline: Obama Can’t Go It Alone in Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States should not intervene unilaterally in Syria. It needs to have Russia and the Arab League on board.
lead_paragraph: THE Obama administration is awash in advice about what to do in Syria. With the administration’s having declared chemical weapons use by the government of Bashar al-Assad a “game changer,” many are advising the president to intervene militarily. The stakes are high: every day that Mr. Assad remains in power brings death and destruction to more Syrians; but after more than a decade of war in Iraq and Afghanistan, the prospect of American military intervention is daunting.

headline: Handpicked Skeptic to Pitch Hardball Questions at Warren Buffett

lead_paragraph: In most years, Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting is a weekend-long ode to capitalism and generally a lovefest for  Warren E. Buffett.

lead_paragraph: Neither Tammy Caplan nor Joe Tyler Gold has directed a feature film before, so forgive them for not knowing how often or how bluntly filmmakers need to make a point for the audience to get it.

lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — On the road from New Orleans to Athens, Ga., site of this week’s Web.com tour event, Derek Ernst’s career took a felicitous turn.

headline: Rhode Island Joins States That Allow Gay Marriage

lead_paragraph: Overcoming years of resistance, Rhode Island on Thursday became the 10th state in the country and the last in New England to approve same-sex marriage.

lead_paragraph: “The Happy House” is trying to be a horror parody, but D. W. Young, the writer and director, forgot to bring along any humor.

abstract: Mandatory government cuts and higher payroll taxes are to blame for the stagnation in job creation, consumer spending and other areas, economists say.
lead_paragraph: Michael Kelly let go of another employee last month.

headline: The Confidence Responses
abstract: Readers’ responses to the confidence questions inspire awe at the diversity of the human experience.
lead_paragraph: A few columns ago, I asked readers to give me their feedback about questions having to do with self-confidence: Are women still less self-confident than men? Do we have more to fear from overconfidence or underconfidence?

headline: The Importance of Testing for H.I.V.
abstract: If the virus is detected early, people can be treated with antiviral drugs before symptoms develop.
lead_paragraph: An expert advisory group has recommended that Americans ages 15 to 65 be voluntarily screened for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and that many of those found infected receive antiviral drugs even before symptoms develop. This authoritative advice reinforces similar recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It is a reminder that doctors and clinics need to test and treat patients as early as possible.

headline: Movement on the Death Penalty
abstract: While Maryland became the 18th state in the country to abolish capital punishment, other states are trying to speed up executions.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland signed a law making life without parole the state’s maximum sentence, repealing the death penalty after more than 300 years. Maryland is the sixth state in six years, and the 18th in the country, to abolish capital punishment.

headline: One Step Forward
abstract: The Arab League offers an improved proposal for peace in the Middle East, a welcome announcement.
lead_paragraph: In any discussion of a negotiated peace between the Israelis and Palestinians, a crucial question involves what the Arab states would do. On Tuesday, the Arab League reaffirmed its 2002 peace initiative and suggested that the proposal could be modified to bring it more in line with American and Israeli ideas.

headline: Celebrating Conspicuous Consumption
abstract: In “Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorf’s,” stars dutifully pay tribute to Bergdorf Goodman, the high-end Manhattan department store.
lead_paragraph: It’s clear that top fashion designers aspire to a presence at Bergdorf Goodman, the high-end Manhattan department store, given the numbingly relentless litany of encomiums in Matthew Miele’s documentary “Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorf’s.” In this glossy, fawning valentine to conspicuous consumption (the title derives from a Victoria Roberts cartoon in The New Yorker), the stars — Karl Lagerfeld, Giorgio Armani, the Olsen twins, Marc Jacobs, Manolo Blahnik, Michael Kors and others — dutifully pay tribute. Thank heaven for a bubble-popping Joan Rivers, who blithely observes, “People who take fashion seriously are idiots.”

headline: Las Vegas Web Site Is Test for Legal Online Gambling
abstract: Ultimate Poker, which is owned by a Las Vegas casino company, became the first online, pay-to-play gambling Web site to operate in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — As the nation’s first legal, pay-to-play poker Web site embarks on a 30-day trial period, players from every state and Europe are logging on, even as casino companies, tech developers, regulators and lawmakers alike examine the technology for strengths and flaws.

headline: Not Enough Inflation
abstract: The economic hole we’re in just gets deeper and deeper.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the financial crisis struck, and the Federal Reserve began “printing money” in an attempt to contain the damage, there have been dire warnings about inflation — and not just from the Ron Paul/Glenn Beck types.

headline: Taxing Online Purchases
abstract: A reader says a sales tax will not deter him from shopping online.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Georgia: Four Morehouse College Students Face Sexual Assault Charges
abstract: The students have been accused of raping two female students from nearby Spelman College in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Four Morehouse College students have been accused of raping two female students from nearby Spelman College in Atlanta. Morehouse administrators said Wednesday that the charges stemmed from two separate episodes in March. Three of the defendants — Chukwudi Ndudikwa, Malcolm Jamal Frank and Tevin Mgbo —  are members of the Morehouse basketball team, and the other, Lucien Kidd, has played for the football team.  Lawyers for Mr. Frank, Mr. Kidd and Mr. Ndudikwa said their clients were not guilty. A lawyer for Mr. Mgbo could not be reached for comment.

headline: Chris Kelly, of Hip-Hop Duo Kris Kross, Dies at 34
abstract: Mr. Kelly was barely in his teens when he became a star who helped bridge hip-hop to pop.
lead_paragraph: A pair of moppets with braided hair who wore their clothes backward, the kid duo Kris Kross was one of the unlikely music success stories of the early 1990s, multiplatinum stars who bridged hip-hop to pop, had indelible style, and showed that rap could sustain a youth invasion.

headline: Sanchez Asserts He Is ‘Cool With’ the Jets’ Quarterback Competition
abstract: Mark Sanchez intends to treat Geno Smith much as he did Tim Tebow — professionally, respectfully, but without any extra favors.

headline: Crispy Twister
abstract: A crispy, twisty puzzle from David Kwong.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Here’s how you make an outstanding Friday puzzle: spend an inordinate amount of time listening and looking for terrific words and phrases that are fun to say, write and think about. Stash those nuggets of brilliance in your crossword database and wait patiently for the day when you can spring them on an unsuspecting public. Salt your blank grid with some of them, at least one in each sector to spread the love around. Eliminate all junk as you go. Resist the common temptation when feeling fill fatigue to add too many partials, obscurities and abbreviations. Rip those sections out when they appear. Harden your heart and rip again. When the grid is filled to within an inch of its life with awesomeness, clue that baby up (make it tough, now: it’s Friday) and then stand back as Will Shortz polishes it to a gleam.

headline: To Catch an (Almost) Thief
keywords: ['Cheating', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: D.I.Y. justice.
lead_paragraph: I work as an accounting assistant. Our bookkeeper stole a presigned check and issued it to herself for $80,000. When she tried to deposit it, her bank did due diligence and called our company. The bookkeeper was fired immediately. When my boss and I reported this incident to the police, the officers said that — since the crime was not actually committed — we could not file a report. They suggested reporting it to the local district attorney. But my boss has been reluctant to take that next step. Six months later, he makes excuses whenever I ask him why he hasn’t gone to the D.A. I’m outraged that the bookkeeper was let go without paying any price for her actions. Should I report the crime? K. W., NEW YORK

headline: When Divas Attack!
abstract: What the dueling judges of “American Idol” teach us about talent.
lead_paragraph: America loves a cat fight — but characterizing the spectacular ongoing clash between the “American Idol” judges Nicki Minaj and Mariah Carey as such is like calling Godzilla’s battle with Megalon a slap fight. Anyone who has watched “American Idol” for more than a few seconds this season knows that their feud is no ratings-boosting prank; contempt of this magnitude can’t be faked. When Minaj raves over a finalist, Carey winces; when Carey coos, Minaj rolls her eyes. The two divas dared to address each other directly a few weeks ago, but their talk quickly devolved into interruptions and condescension. Producers may have recruited these two in the hope that an occasional good-natured spat would reignite the spark that went out when Simon Cowell exited the show three years ago. As it turns out, Minaj and Carey trade harmless barbs about as well as North and South Korea.

headline: My Desperate, Stupid, Emotional Hunt for the Perfect Pants
abstract: How I ended up in the bathtub with my jeans on, thinking I’d found the secret to life.
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid and my mom bought me Levi’s, they were stiff and uncomfortable for weeks. Then over time and multiple washings, they’d fade the way you wanted them to and start to contour themselves to your body. They became more than your pants. They were your skin. They grew with you. They saw what you saw, absorbed your pain, your mistakes, your spills and slides. They scarred and ripped with you. They seemed to last forever. Some part of me can’t understand why I ever got rid of that pair of Levi’s that I had in seventh grade. How did I lose track of those pants?

headline: On ‘Unburnable Carbon’ and the Specter of a ‘Carbon Bubble’
keywords: ['Carbon Capture and Sequestration', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Can climate forecasts and campaigners convince the world’s nations that some carbon is unburnable?
lead_paragraph: A new buzz phrase in the push to limit greenhouse gas emissions is “unburnable carbon” — an effort to define and then wall off the portion of the world’s still-vast reserves of coal, oil or natural gas that might, if combusted, cause unacceptably costly or dangerous climate change. The effort builds, to a large extent, on studies aiming to create a “carbon budget” for the world’s nations — divvying up the amount of emissions (and thus fuels) below that threshold. The most notable paper, published in Nature, was “Greenhouse-Gas Emission Targets for Limiting Global Warming to 2 °C.” (2 °C being 2 degrees Celsius). (Earlier this year, Katherine Bagley wrote a nice piece on the influence of that paper.)

headline: Send In the Contractors
abstract: David Rohde shows the consequences of raising U.S.A.I.D. budgets and cutting its staff.
lead_paragraph: Luckily, David Rohde’s new book, “Beyond War: Reimagining American Influence in a New Middle East,” doesn’t live up to its name. “American influence” is too amorphous, and the “new Middle East” too broad, to be convincingly “reimagined” in 221 pages. To his credit, Rohde, a columnist for Reuters and The Atlantic, barely tries. What he does instead is expose the deep contradiction between Washington’s long experiment in slashing the civilian instruments of American power and its post-9/11 attempt to use those same instruments to remake the greater Middle East.

headline: The Gray Man
abstract: This biography of William Colby, onetime director of the Central Intelligence Agency, reveals a spy who could blend in anywhere.
lead_paragraph: During the Vietnam War, Bill Colby of the Central Intelligence Agency ran the Phoenix program, which set out to “neutralize” the Viet Cong by capturing or killing them. In 1972, when Colby came home to a nation that had turned against the war, his face began appearing around Washington on “Wanted” posters. He was jeered on the street and peppered with death threats. Every day at 5 a.m., he was awakened at home by the same crank caller, accosting him as a murderer and a war criminal. Colby did not bother to get his home number changed. Instead, he began to use the predawn call as an alarm clock.

headline: Significant Others
abstract: Claire Messud’s latest novel depicts a thwarted artist bewitched by a boy and his parents.
lead_paragraph: Reading the title of Claire Messud’s latest novel, anyone of a literary turn of mind will immediately think of the madwoman in the attic, the 19th century’s best-known “woman upstairs.” In “Jane Eyre,” Bertha Mason was the first wife of the master of Thornfield Hall, who shut her away and, in so doing, opened the door to more than a hundred years of impassioned feminist criticism. This connection is entirely intentional, as Messud quickly makes plain. “We’re not the madwomen in the attic,” argues her “reliable,” “organized” protagonist, a teacher named Nora Eldridge, referring to unmarried women like herself, “numerous” in their 20s and 30s, “positively legion” in their 40s and 50s. “We’re the quiet woman at the end of the third-floor hallway, whose trash is always tidy, who smiles brightly in the stairwell.” Outwardly they may seem “benignant” (to use a Brontëan word), but inwardly, Nora declares, they seethe. “People don’t want to worry about the Woman Upstairs,” she reflects. “Not a soul registers that we are furious. We’re completely invisible.” In time, she will resolve to “use that invisibility, to make it burn.”

headline: Basic Training
abstract: The centenary of H. G. Wells’s book that started a hobby and continues to inspire war-game designers.
lead_paragraph: If you happened to visit the Royal Military Academy in Sandhurst, England, in April, you may have spotted neat ranks of red- and blue-coated soldiers converging on the front lines of a grassy battlefield — a miniature battlefield, that is, peppered with soldiers just over two inches tall. Their commanding officers were gathered to celebrate the centenary of the book that gave birth to their hobby and, in so doing, spawned a family tree that has since branched out to include tabletop role-playing pursuits and big-budget video-game extravaganzas.

headline: Iowa Town Named for Muslim Hero Extols Tolerance
abstract: For the fifth year in a row, Elkader, a shrinking town without a single traffic light, will welcome a delegation of Arab dignitaries to celebrate a connection spanning centuries.
lead_paragraph: ELKADER, Iowa — Amid an expanse of undulating farmland, deep in the steep valley carved by the Turkey River, the town of Elkader sits most of the year in remote obscurity. Population 1,200 and gradually shrinking, it is the seat of a county without a single traffic light.

headline: Dear Life
abstract: Ramona Ausubel’s fantastical story collection traces a cycle of transformation: from love to conception to gestation to birth.
lead_paragraph: A good owner’s manual takes the unexpected into account; the more extreme the eventuality the better. In the same spirit, “A Guide to Being Born,” by Ramona Ausubel, the author of “No One Is Here Except All of Us,” deals with the desolation and surreptitious thrills that come to us through ownership of a body and its accompanying life. Or ownership of a life and its accompanying body: these tales allow the body to adjust as needed. In “Chest of Drawers,” a prospective father feels acutely underinvolved in preparations for the birth of his daughter, and so he develops chest cavities that can be pulled open and pushed shut, filling them with tiny babies from the toy shop.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Helen Oyeyemi can’t remember when she started writing.
lead_paragraph: Helen Oyeyemi, who reviews Ramona Ausubel’s short-­story collection, “A Guide to Being Born,” this week, can’t remember when she started writing. It was surely long before her first novel, “The Icarus Girl,” was published in 2005, when Oyeyemi was still a 20-year-old student at Cambridge University, and she has published three more in the eight years since.

headline: The Language of Nobuyoshi Araki
abstract: An extensive exhibition at Mana Contemporary in Jersey City provides a larger perspective behind the Japanese photographer’s erotic works.
lead_paragraph: Nobuyoshi Araki is one of the world’s most prolific photographers. In his 73 years, he has compulsively documented daily life in his native Japan and produced more than 450 books and collector’s editions of film-only prints (a feat made more impressive today by the comparative ease of digital photography). His work appears in permanent collections at the Tate Modern and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and has been exhibited extensively throughout Europe and Asia. But in the United States, Araki is far less well known, and there’s no real mystery why: a substantial portion of his prints feature naked women who, at times, are tightly bound using a method of erotic, Japanese rope-tying called kinbaku-bi.

headline: Against Tyranny
abstract: Fiction meets history in Ismail Kadare’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Every city offers residents a way to chart the well-being of their surroundings. For the Albanian city of Gjirokaster, as depicted in Ismail Kadare’s tragicomic novel “The Fall of the Stone City,” a misperceived rivalry between doctors becomes a barometer to assess the political gales that battered Eastern Europe during World War II and the cold war.

headline: Under Suspicion
abstract: The Polish singer Vera Gran survived World War II, but at a heavy price.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1941 the Jewish cabaret singer Vera Gran began performing at the Sztuka, a cafe in the Warsaw ghetto frequented by intellectuals and remnants of Jewish high society. The place was also popular with collaborators, including the so-called Jewish Gestapo who selected and rounded up their fellow Jews for transportation to Treblinka.

headline: Taxi Driver
abstract: In André Aciman’s novel, an alienated immigrant grad student befriends a volatile immigrant hack.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like a college campus in summer. It’s peaceful. You feel as if you finally own the place, as if you belong. The classrooms are empty, and you can wander the hallways alone. The undergraduates are gone, the professors traveling or holed up in their offices; a handful of shy grad students, the trees and grass, the fountains and libraries take over. It’s like the vanished gardens of Córdoba.

headline: Resetting the Clocks
abstract: The theoretical physicist Lee Smolin examines the role of time in the universe.
lead_paragraph: In one of the more fanciful conceptions of nature, the British physicist and philosopher Julian Barbour proposed that the world is just a “heap of moments,” each an instant of frozen time. There is no order to the moments, no sequence, no cause-and-effect relationship. We exist only from moment to moment. If we experience time passing, it’s because this particular moment has memories of another moment woven into it. Some moments are interesting: they contain complexity, stars and planets, life. Others are boring: they contain only energy, or perhaps nothing at all.

headline: Science Chronicle
abstract: New books by Chip Walter, Jesse J. Prinz, Torkel Klingberg and Ray Kurzweil.
lead_paragraph: LAST APE STANDING  The Seven-Million-Year Story of How and Why We Survived.  By Chip Walter.  Walker & Company, $26.

headline: More Than 200 Colleges Are Still Taking Applications for Fall 2013
abstract: More than 99 percent of the schools still have housing, and all of them are still offering financial aid, according to the National Association for College Admission Counseling.
lead_paragraph: If you are disappointed about your college options or didn’t complete the application process in time, it’s not too late to attend college this fall.

headline: Death and the Maidens
abstract: Anne Perry’s novel “Midnight at Marble Arch” is a sweeping and scandalous exposé of sexual brutality amid the upper classes.
lead_paragraph: Anne Perry has killed off a lot of women in a lot of ways since she began writing her atmospheric mysteries about Thomas Pitt, a detective in late-Victorian London, and his highborn wife, Charlotte. But, strange as it may seem for such an unflinching observer of the criminal justice system, until now Perry hadn’t trained her exacting eye on the subject of rape. MIDNIGHT AT MARBLE ARCH (Ballantine, $27) makes up for that lapse with a vengeance. Without losing her grip on the refined language appropriate to the day, Perry has written a sweeping and scandalous exposé of sexual brutality amid the upper classes.

headline: The Dark Side
abstract: Peter Dimock’s narrator, haunted by the treatment of political detainees, writes to a former Bush administration official.
lead_paragraph: Can fiction make us better people? Harold Bloom’s “Invention of the Human” posits that Shakespeare’s plays forever altered human consciousness. Blakey Vermeule, the author of “Why Do We Care About Literary Characters?,” answers her title’s question this way: “We use them to sort out basic moral problems or to practice new emotional situations. . . . We use them in place of statistics as tools.” Reading Peter Dimock’s second novel, “George Anderson: Notes for a Love Song in Imperial Time,” didn’t automatically make me a better person — but it did make me aware that, as an American, I should try to be one, even if my attempts are probably doomed.

headline: Cracked
abstract: A mysterious Fabergé egg encodes secrets at the heart of Danielle Trussoni’s second tale of evil fallen angels..
lead_paragraph: Angels do in fact walk among us, and they are not at all to be trifled with. Or at least that’s the alarming state of affairs at the heart of Danielle Trussoni’s 2010 best-selling novel, “Angelology.” Called Nephilim, these angels — or, more properly, angel-human hybrids — are the descendants of traitorous, fallen rebel angels. No haloed guardians, these: they want nothing less than dominion over mankind. Set against them are the angelologists, a secret global group dedicated to thwarting the Nephilim’s unholy ambitions. Readers flocked to Trussoni’s first novel (she’s also the author of a 2006 memoir, “Falling Through the Earth”) for its mix of fantasy and religious conspiracy, as well as for the improbable romance between its characters: the art historian Verlaine and Evangeline, an innocent young nun.

headline: Face Value
abstract: In early-20th-century America, two powerful men were engaged in a contest to possess the world’s most remarkable watch.
lead_paragraph: Because our species evolved in stressful environments, the drive to grapple with scarcity is deeply embedded in our psychology. Severe and chronic shortages can of course wear people down. But just as the development of a sound immune system requires exposure to lots of microbes, sound mental health seems to require the challenges presented by moderate amounts of privation. An old cartoon by Gahan Wilson captures the idea. Two middle-aged angels, newly arrived in heaven, are playing harps while perched on a cloud. One, his face a mask of dismay, asks the other, “You mean this goes on forever?”

headline: Common Core Practice | Kentucky Derby, Factory Disasters and Berlin Street-Naming
abstract: Ideas for learning about black history and the Kentucky Derby; exploring historical connections to a disaster in Bangladesh; and arguing ideas of gender parity via a piece about street-naming in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: This week our humanities-class collaborators chose their usual eclectic mix of Times stories to read and write about.

headline: The Little Spanish Grape That Could
abstract: Exploring the albariño, as much a brand name for Spanish whites as pinot grigio is for Italian.
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible to tackle the subject of Spanish wines without recognizing their remarkable ascent in the last 30 years. The trajectory of Spanish white wines has been especially steep and fascinating.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SELECTED LETTERS OF WILLA ­CATHER,  edited by Andrew Jewell and Janis Stout. (Knopf, $37.50.) Cather emerges as a strong and vivid presence, a woman at once surprisingly modern and touchingly — if not always sweetly — old-fashioned.

headline: The Gun Report: May 3, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: This is a photograph of Greg Imhoff, taken by his partner, Shari Telvick, who described him to me the other day as “the love of my life.” On August 7, 2012, while checking on a house in his Florida neighborhood—something he did for many of his neighbors when they were away—he was murdered. His death, and its larger implications for “responsible gun ownership,” will be the subject of my column on Saturday. Here is today’s report.

headline: The Concept: Downsize in Every Way
abstract: Nuna Alberts and Rick Kashuk found good value in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Nuna Alberts and Richard Kashuk moved their family from a Greenwich Village rental to a three-bedroom two-bathroom co-op nearby.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE STRUGGLE FOR EGYPT: From Nasser to Tahrir Square,  by Steven A. Cook. (Oxford University, $18.95.) Cook, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, traces Egypt’s transformation from pride of the Arab world to decaying autocracy. Drawing from archives and firsthand reporting, he weaves a narrative that encompasses the decline of British rule, the rise of Gamal Abdel Nasser, the assassination of Anwar Sadat, and the demonstrations that overthrew Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Counseling Kept at an Arm’s Length
abstract: “Felt,” a reality series on Logo about sex therapy, uses puppets to act out actual sessions of couples counseling.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s a sunny afternoon in a Hollywood recording studio, and deep bass is thumping through the floor. This is a hip-hop studio, usually. But on this day it is doubling as a therapist’s office. A sex therapist’s office, to be exact — and a couple named Donald and Lamar are seated on a black leather couch, midsession.

headline: In the Company of Rap, Garage Rock and a Country Firebrand

lead_paragraph: Wavves

headline: From Country Rebel to Moody Rocker
abstract: With her first solo album, Natalie Maines of the Dixie Chicks embraces a moody, rootsy rock sound.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, TEX. — The Central Presbyterian Church here turns into a concert hall during the annual South By Southwest Music festival, and on a Friday afternoon in mid-March, Natalie Maines of the Dixie Chicks was doing her soundcheck there for a midnight show. It was an early steppingstone for her new solo career, a preview of songs from her debut album, “Mother” (Columbia), which is due for release this week.

headline: Black Onyx Scratches from Derby
abstract: The Kentucky Derby will go off with 19 horses on Saturday after Black Onyx was pulled from the field.
lead_paragraph: 1:07 p.m. | Updated LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Long shot Black Onyx was scratched from the Kentucky Derby field Friday morning, leaving the rail position open and reducing the field to 19 horses, after trainer Kelly Breen said X-rays revealed a non-displaced chip in the colt’s left front ankle.

headline: With Tiny Libraries, Bringing Free Literature to the Streets
abstract: Ten Little Free Libraries — miniature lending libraries where anyone can take or leave a book under the honor system — will pop up all over downtown Manhattan on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: They look like trellises and fishtanks, spacesuits and mailboxes. One squeezes into the cracks of a historic building. Others offer built-in seating.

headline: Complaining Is Hard to Avoid, but Try to Do It With a Purpose
abstract: Many people have a love-hate relationship with complaining. It can be satisfying, but people who constantly whine about the same thing can be annoying.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY had a mundane exchange with an acquaintance that took an odd twist.

headline: Irish Catholic Church Condemns Abortion Legislation
abstract: Irish bishops called the legislation, which would permit abortions in cases where a threat existed to a woman’s life, morally unacceptable.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The Catholic Church in Ireland on Friday condemned the government’s abortion legislation, which would permit abortions in cases where a threat existed to a woman’s life, including from suicide. The church called the legislation “a dramatically and morally unacceptable change to Irish law.”

headline: A Daughter of the Cuban Revolution Visits the Liberty Bell
abstract: The Liberty Bell received a visit on Friday from Cuba’s premier sexologist, who is also the daughter of President Raúl Castro.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 4:55 p.m. Much to the chagrin of conservative Cuban-American exiles, a senior Cuban official was permitted to visit the iconic Liberty Bell in Philadelphia on Friday afternoon. The visitor was Mariela Castro, the daughter of President Raúl Castro and Cuba’s premier sexologist, currently visiting Philadelphia as a guest of the Equality Forum, a gay rights organization that is holding its annual conference there.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | April 2013
abstract: A roundup of articles and multimedia about young people published in the last month on NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Once a month we round up all the latest articles and multimedia published on NYTimes.com about young people, so that teachers and students can find it all in one place.

headline: Mold, Come Out With Your Hands Up
abstract: Bill Sothern has built a career on investigating and remediating environmental hazards, including mold colonies, secondhand smoke, chemical vapors, lead and asbestos.
lead_paragraph: Bill Sothern, an expert at detecting residential mold, has a cedar-lined hot tub on his verdant south-facing terrace at Madison Avenue and 117th Street. The tub holds 3,000 liters of ionized water heated to 101 degrees Fahrenheit in the winter, 95 degrees in the summer, and the terrace has an elaborate irrigation system.

headline: Lehane’s ‘Live by Night’ Wins Edgar Award
abstract: Dennis Lehane’s latest book won the best novel prize given by the Mystery Writers of America, beating out Gillian Flynn’s big seller “Gone Girl.”
lead_paragraph: The 2013 Edgar Awards featured a few surprising winners when they were announced at a banquet ceremony in New York on Thursday night. Among them was “Live by Night,” the latest work by Dennis Lehane, which was crowned the best novel of the year over the best-selling “Gone Girl” by Gillian Flynn.

headline: Jazz’s Skinny Stepchild
abstract: The clarinet, dominant in jazz’s early years, faded into obscurity as the saxophone became the reed of choice. But in the hands of Anat Cohen, the clarinet is cool again.
lead_paragraph: In search of some live Brazilian music a few months ago, I found my way to Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola, in the Time Warner Center, where the Brazilian percussionist Duduka Da Fonseca was leading a quintet. I can’t say I knew much about Mr. Da Fonseca before I heard his band that night, and among the things I didn’t know was that his quintet’s regular reed player was a 38-year-old Israeli woman named Anat Cohen, who has lived in New York since 1999.

headline: With One Bet, Stablehand Becomes Stable Owner
abstract: Conor Murphy was a stablehand in England when he won $1.5 million on a $75 bet. It was a life-changing event, but not everything is different.
lead_paragraph: GOSHEN, Ky. — Last spring, Conor Murphy was a hired hand who spent his days galloping racehorses, combing knotted manes and shoveling manure in a stable in Berkshire, England.

headline: A Fresh Perch on the Career Ladder
abstract: Hee Seo, a South Korean dancer who has risen through the ranks with American Ballet Theater, prepares for her first season as a principal.
lead_paragraph: For Hee Seo, becoming a soloist was a high point of her career. She reached that position in 2010 at American Ballet Theater, and the transition was as natural as breathing.

headline: A Tough Fish Undaunted by Land
abstract: Like the Atlantic salmon, the American eel makes an epic voyage of thousands of miles, but the eel’s can include a climb out of the water.
lead_paragraph: Even in an environment as man-made as New York City’s, nature stubbornly persists — in park woodlands, empty lots and between the cracks of the sidewalk. In an occasional series, Dave Taft, a senior-level park ranger in New York City with the National Park Service, will be offering close-in portraits of the city’s plants and animals.

headline: My Other Car Is: A 1965 Volkswagen Karmann Ghia
abstract: Since 1965, Vince Vespe has driven his Karmann Ghia convertible all over the United States and Mexico, and plans to keep the car until the end of his life.
lead_paragraph: Vince Vespe admits that dating a German woman – and perhaps hoping to make points with her father, a Volkswagen owner and aficionado – influenced his decision to buy a red, white-topped Volkswagen Karmann Ghia convertible in 1961. As it turned out, his relationship with the German car outlasted the one with the German woman.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday named James F. Dobbins, a veteran diplomat who oversaw the return of the United States to Afghanistan after the defeat of the Taliban in 2001, as his third special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, an administration official said on Friday.

headline: The Met Will Return a Pair of Statues to Cambodia
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art said new research backed up Cambodian claims that two 10th-century statues were improperly removed from the Koh Ker temple complex.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks ago the Metropolitan Museum of Art sent two of its top executives to Cambodia to resolve a thorny dispute: whether two pieces of ancient Khmer art that the museum has long prominently exhibited were the product of looting.

headline: Giant Finish, the Last to Arrive at Churchill Downs
abstract: Giant Finish, a New York-bred long shot, did not seem stressed after his late arrival, rolling in the grass and holding his head high.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Arriving late creates a certain amount of stress, even for a horse. So trainers go to great lengths to keep their horses calm by adhering to strict schedules and acclimating them to new surroundings. This is why some trainers bring their horses to a new track weeks in advance so that everything feels comfortable by race day. For races as important as the Kentucky Derby, this can be crucial.

The American poet Nikki Giovanni (shown) is the headliner of the event, which features readings and panels with authors, including the Haitian-American writer Edwidge Danticat and the Anguillan playwright Marcel Fahie. lead_paragraph: Senator Jeff Sessions, the Republican from Alabama who may be the most determined and energetic opponent of an immigration overhaul bill now before the Senate, said on Friday that the legislation is “dangerous” for American workers, and he vowed to offer amendments in coming weeks to “confront the fundamentals of the bill” and slow its progress.

headline: Aerosmith and James Taylor Join Benefit for Boston Bombing Victims
abstract: The concert on May 30 will also include Carole King and New Kids on the Block. Tickets go on sale Monday.
lead_paragraph: Aerosmith, James Taylor and Jimmy Buffett will perform along with several other bands to raise money for survivors of the April 15 bombings at the Boston Marathon and the families of the people killed in the attack, The Associated Press reported. The concert is scheduled for May 30 at the TD Garden. It will benefit One Fund, a collection for victims of the attack. Other musicians who have promised to perform include Jason Aldean, Boston, Extreme, Godsmack, the J. Geils Band, Carole King, and New Kids on the Block. The comedians Dane Cook and Steven Wright are also included in the lineup. Tickets range from $35 to $285 and went on sale Monday.

headline: Panama City Rising
abstract: Over the past 13 years, Panama City has been racing to become a world-class metropolis, and for travelers, the changes have been enormous.
lead_paragraph: Traffic into Panama City was flowing for once, so Miguel Fábrega had only a moment to point out the crumbling ruins in the distance. They were the remains of a 16th-century New Spanish settlement that the British privateer Sir Henry Morgan eventually sacked in 1671. Ahead of us rose Old Panama’s modern replacement: a forest of green, blue and yellow glass skyscrapers that sifted the metallic Central American sky into great vertical columns.

headline: Q. & A. With David Axelrod
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: John Harwood interviews David Axelrod, a former top adviser to President Obama about the president’s setback on guns and America’s shifting political landscape.
lead_paragraph: Two years after leaving the White House, David Axelrod continues to advise President Obama, even as he begins work on his memoir and oversees a new Institute of Politics at his alma mater, the University of Chicago. This week, he sat down with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC to discuss his role in Mr. Obama’s career, the president’s setback on guns, and America’s shifting political landscape, before an audience at Washington College in Chestertown, Md. What follows is a condensed, edited portion of their discussion.

headline: Nine More Years On, and Still Talking
abstract: Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy work again with the director Richard Linklater in “Before Midnight,” the third in a series of movies.
lead_paragraph: The courtship of Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke), the bright, neurotic, hyperverbal pair who met in Richard Linklater’s “Before Sunrise” (1995) and reunited in “Before Sunset” (2004), unfolded to the sound of ticking clocks — there was always a train or a plane to catch, another life to get back to. Nine more years have passed, and in “Before Midnight” (opening May 24), there are no more looming deadlines, save for the ones built into life itself. The screen romance that defined Generation X is now officially middle-aged.

headline: Caffeine-Laced Foods Spur F.D.A. Investigation
abstract: With caffeine now being added to jelly beans, waffles, even potato chips and gum, the Food and Drug Administration is stepping up efforts to investigate the impact on health.

In recent years, growing numbers of well-heeled gearheads have found room on their schedules for overseas events like Rétromobile in Paris and the Goodwood Festival of Speed in England.

headline: An Orgiastic ‘Gatsby’? Of Course
abstract: From 3-D to hip-hop, Baz Luhrmann pursues his vision.
lead_paragraph: “Not to sound idiotic or pretentious, but I never start these things to be controversial,” Baz Luhrmann said recently in his Australian drawl. He was pacing around an upstairs room in the Ace Hotel in Manhattan’s Flatiron district while tugging at the bottom of a several-sizes-too-small navy blazer he was wearing along with a rep tie, a pressed white shirt, carefully untucked, and shiny brown oxfords without socks. “I never start thinking they’re going to be a big deal.”

headline:
Obama’s Defender of
Borders Is Again a
Voice for Migrants
abstract: Cecilia Muñoz, a longtime activist, was denounced after she joined the Obama administration and defended its deportation policy. But her loyalty appears to have paid off.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — For two decades, Cecilia Muñoz was a fiery immigration rights lobbyist who denounced deportations, demanded change in Congress and once wrote of “that hollow place that outrage carves in your soul.” When she was invited to a White House briefing in 1997 on immigration, Ms. Muñoz, who was born in Detroit, was furious after staff members asked twice if she was an American citizen.

headline: Taxes Influence Investment Strategy, and Not Always for the Better
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Tax', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Advisers say that taxes should not be the first concern when deciding whether to buy — or not buy — an investment.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, many investors didn’t worry about the taxes they would pay on the gains in their investments until the bill arrived months later. But this year, with taxes higher, some investors have gone to the other extreme, choosing investments as much for their tax rates as for their risks and returns.

headline: Mario Gabelli, the $750 Million Man
abstract: Mario J. Gabelli, the chairman and chief executive of Gamco Investors, has made more than three-quarters of a billion dollars in total compensation.
lead_paragraph: Mario J. Gabelli is more likely to be listed among the United States’ best-known money managers than among its highest paid chief executives. But that is not because he does not qualify for both lists. He does.

headline: Popcast: Red Bull, Highly Caffeinated Tastemaker

headline: Investing With Taxes in Mind
abstract: Bucks readers discuss whether taxes are now at the top of their investing concerns, or whether taxes are a nonissue because the investments are all in retirement accounts.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, looks at the role that higher taxes on investment gains are playing in investing decisions, especially in the wake of years of low tax rates. Indeed, financial advisers say more of their customers are asking about the tax implications of their buying and selling decisions.

headline: Bulls Out of Gas and Maybe Ideas
abstract: The question is not whether Chicago can come up with a new offensive or defensive scheme. It is whether the Bulls will have enough healthy players to overcome a flawed Nets team.
lead_paragraph: Bulls guard Nate Robinson was vomiting into a trash can in the third quarter of Game 6 against the Nets on Thursday night, but at least he was able to take the court. Forward Luol Deng, who missed the game, said on his Twitter account that he had a spinal tap Thursday to check for meningitis. Point guard Kirk Hinrich remained out with a bruised left calf. Taj Gibson and Joakim Noah played through debilitating leg injuries.

headline: Betty Woodman’s Playful Ceramics
abstract: The iconic sculptor’s new show plays with the distinction between indoors and outdoors.
lead_paragraph: The sculptor Betty Woodman is known for her exuberant riffs on the vase — boldly colored and patterned ceramic pieces which she has said “could be functional, but I really want them to be considered works of art.” Woodman’s new exhibition, “Windows, Carpets and Other Paintings,” which opens May 7 at Salon 94 Freemans in New York City, includes more remixes of the vessel form, but also works that examine the relationship between indoors and outdoors. In “Of Botticelli,” a site-specific mural that fills an entire wall of the gallery, ceramic fragments represent columns wrapped in vines and crowned by vases, hinting at an unseen garden view. Other pieces, which combine ceramics with painting on canvas, hang on the walls and are framed to look like windows. Still others sit on the floor like carpets. And in “Wallpaper,” Woodman recycles 90 cast-off bits of clay — pieces cut away during the making of her ceramics — by glazing them and arranging them on a wall, where they will be free to visitors for the taking.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Faced with a crop of lemons — too much ethanol, a population of cars not tuned to burn it effectively and a driving public leery of the fuel’s properties — the Environmental Protection Agency is proposing to make lemonade.

headline: Hopping From One Galaxy to Another
abstract: A relentless multitasker, J. J. Abrams juggles directing and producing new “Star Trek” and “Star Wars” films.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — A conversation with J. J. Abrams is more like a series of interruptions and distractions, punctuated by occasional exchanges of dialogue. The latest diversion to appear on his iPhone screen one evening in March, as he unwound here at the offices of his Bad Robot production company, was a photograph sent by his producing partner, Bryan Burk, of two tip jars side by side on a coffee-shop counter: one labeled “Star Wars,” and the other “Star Trek.”

lead_paragraph: I was excited to be invited recently to a birthday party in Jamaica. That is, until I realized my work schedule wouldn’t permit me to go under any circumstance.

headline: A Revolutionary Ballet, Then and Now
abstract: “Slaughter on Tenth Avenue” is back with the Encores! revival of “On Your Toes,” starting on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A stripper with a heart of gold falls in with the wrong guys and dies in the arms of her one true love. This story was familiar, but the setting certainly wasn’t when George Balanchine’s ballet “Slaughter on Tenth Avenue” had its premiere in the Rodgers and Hart musical “On Your Toes” in 1936. Balanchine would become famous for his revolutionary subversions of classical ballet, but at the time, the choreographer’s decision to put a sexy jazz-age ballerina on a Broadway stage — without point shoes — was one of his most radical moves yet.

headline: High Tides, With a Rueful Undertow
abstract: In the first of its last two seasons, the weeklong Spring for Music festival at Carnegie Hall celebrates regional orchestras and strong programs.
lead_paragraph: Spring for Music, the annual weeklong festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, has in its two previous outings felt like a grand celebration. And it undoubtedly will again, beginning on Monday: a celebration of artistic ambition and achievement, of civic spirit and generosity. But this year there are also melancholy undercurrents. The festival has already announced that, having failed to secure sponsorship to continue its financing beyond next year, it will end after the 2014 season.

headline: The Death of Jackson
abstract: Thousands died at the Battle of Chancellorsville, but none more famous than General Stonewall.
lead_paragraph: It was around 9 p.m. on May 2, 1863, during what would later be known as the Battle of Chancellorsville in central Virginia. Gen. Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson, with a few aides, was in front of Confederate lines scouting the federal position. The day had been a horrible one; Jackson, a senior general under Robert E. Lee, had attacked the Union’s right flank, demolishing the XI Corps. But the Union troops regrouped and counterattacked, and night fell on a confusing, bloody scene. Thousands were dead; thousands more would die in the coming days.

headline: Treescapes
abstract: A Korean artist provides an Avedon-like quality to his arboreal subjects.
lead_paragraph: For the past decade, the artist Myoung Ho Lee has been wandering around his native South Korea, shooting trees like some kind of arboreal Avedon, in stark relief against a plain white canvas. His pictures possess the glamour and focus of studio portraits, yet they’re set in the landscape — be it a golden meadow or a cloudy blue sky dotted with balloons. It’s a deceptively simple trick, a way of foregrounding what would ordinarily be background. The purity of the final image belies the incredibly complicated rigging that makes it possible — a process that usually involves industrial cranes, ropes and numerous artisans. Lee, 37, retouches the photographs to erase any trace of his own hand. “If the mechanics of the artwork were visible, it would be easier for people to recognize the scale and the method,” he said. “But I want to hide them, to infuse a magical and vague aspect to my work, so that viewers may question and try to find answers themselves.”

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Wonder of Childhood
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Graphic Novels']
abstract: “Marble Season,” by Gilbert Hernandez, is No. 2 on the hardcover list this week.
lead_paragraph: “Marble Season,” by Gilbert Hernandez, arrives at No. 2 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. Mr. Hernandez is better known for his work on “Love and Rockets,” a critically acclaimed independent comic book series that he worked on primarily with his brother Jaime (and occasionally with their brother Mario). Confession time: “Love and Rockets” is beloved by many, but the parts of the sprawling tale that I’ve read have left me cold. “Marble Season” had the opposite effect. In this semi-autobiographical tale, Mr. Hernandez captures the wonder of childhood — the joy of imagination, an appreciation for comic books and all the ultimately petty but seemingly world-shattering trials and tribulations of friendships during that time in one’s life. The 120-page story is told in six-panel grids that reminded me of Sunday newspaper comic strips, which I devoured in my youth. “Marble Season” is published by Drawn & Quarterly.

abstract: Does distraction matter — do interruptions make us dumber?

Odds are high you will check your Twitter feed or Facebook wall while reading this article. Just try to type a memo at work without having an e-mail pop up that ruins your train of thought.

headline: A Meeting of Two Elizabeths, Not at All Related
abstract: In “All of a Sudden,” at Abrons Arts Center, Jack Ferver refers to both Elizabeth Taylor and Elizabeth Berkley in his usual relentlessly campy, self-reflexive style.
lead_paragraph: “All of a Sudden,” the title of the new Jack Ferver show that opened at Abrons Arts Center on Thursday, is a phrase you might use in describing a signature dynamic of any Jack Ferver production. One minute, everything is campy, outrageous, ridiculous, fake, not to be taken seriously. And then — all of a sudden — someone is slapped or spit upon, or real tears seem to flow, and the pain beneath is exposed.

headline: Is There Emergency Contraception in Your Medicine Cabinet?
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Parenting', 'Plan B (Contraceptive)', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Should parents make emergency contraception available to teenagers?
lead_paragraph: This week, a judge ordered that emergency contraception be available over-the-counter to girls and women of all ages, and the Obama administration announced its intention to appeal that order with respect to girls under 15. The Food and Drug Administration announced that the most widely known morning-after pill, Plan B One-Step, would be available to girls and women ages 15 and older, and that it would be stocked on drugstore shelves, rather than behind the counter. headline: 303 Gallery Finds a New Home
abstract: The Chelsea gallery celebrates the opening of its new location under the High Line with a show by the artist Rodney Graham.
lead_paragraph: New York City art galleries tend to move around a lot. But even by those standards, the iconic 303 Gallery has been unusually itinerant. Since it was founded in 1984 at 303 Park Avenue South by its director Lisa Spellman, it has had homes in the East Village and SoHo, and at two addresses in Chelsea. Today, it throws open its brand-new industrial doors at a third Chelsea location, a bilevel space on West 24th Street tucked below the High Line. Designed by the architecture firm StudioMDA for 303, it’s an airy, light-filled space that doubles the gallery’s square footage, with skylights, glass floors and the columns of the High Line running through, all protected by a cast concrete facade.

headline: ‘The New New York’ Ad Campaign
abstract: New York State has set aside $140 million over the last year-and-a-half for a national advertising campaign. The following commercials were the initial productions of the campaign.
lead_paragraph: New York State has set aside $140 million over the last year-and-a-half for a national advertising campaign. The following commercials were the initial productions of the campaign.

headline: Ad Effort Selling State as a Business Haven Is Criticized
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration says the ads are a valuable tool for recruiting businesses, but critics say they are a backdoor way of elevating the governor’s stature.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The Cuomo administration has set aside nearly $140 million for an advertising campaign called “New York State Open for Business,” with the money drawn largely from a state authority created to lower electricity bills and from federal disaster aid, records show.

headline: Death Toll in Bangladesh Building Collapse Tops 500
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The number of dead rose to 517 on Friday, as investigators continued interrogating the building’s owner and others arrested.
lead_paragraph: SAVAR, Bangladesh — The death toll in the Rana Plaza disaster soared to 517 on Friday, as rescue crews spent a 10th day digging through the rubble and investigators continued to interrogate the building’s owner and others arrested in the case.

headline: Visitors From Outer Space, Real or Not, Are Focus of Discussion in Washington
keywords: ['Unidentified Flying Objects (UFO)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Extraterrestrial Life']
abstract: A group of former lawmakers and government officials gathered this week in the capital to discuss what they said was secrecy surrounding aliens and unidentified flying objects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While President Obama was promoting an immigration overhaul in Mexico, six former members of Congress gathered two blocks from the White House to consider what they see as the enforced government secrecy surrounding another kind of visitor: the kind who come from a lot farther away.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: For home cooks who want to rub elbows with some of the most well-known chefs, the New York Culinary Experience on Saturday and Sunday at the International Culinary Center, 462 Broadway in SoHo, offers a chance to learn from and cook side by side with chefs like Andre Soltner and April Bloomfield. Tickets, at $1,395 per person for the all day affair are limited and can be purchased by calling (646) 314-4413 or e-mailing nyce@nymag.com.

headline: Shakshuka Now or Later
abstract: Use fresh or canned tomatoes to make shakshuka, an Israeli baked egg and tomato dish.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s A Good Appetite column and video, I give a recipe for shakshuka, an Israeli baked egg and tomato dish (with North African roots). I use canned tomatoes since good local tomatoes aren’t available yet. But in season, feel free to substitute chopped juicy tomatoes. You might need to cook the mix down longer (by about 10 or 15 minutes) to reach a thick consistency, but the bright flavor will make the extra time worth it.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: An Unusual Headache Solved
abstract: Readers solve the mystery of a 23-year-old woman with a terrible headache who kept getting worse.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to puzzle their way through the case of a 23-year-old woman who started out with what seemed like her usual migraine but who then became more and more ill. By the time the diagnosis was made, she had double vision and she was shaking and confused. And despite the right diagnosis, there was worse to come.

headline: Queen Esther’s Tale, in Yiddish, With Cartwheels, Puppets and a Union Label
abstract: The work of a Yiddish poet and a klezmer composer are combined in “The Megile of Itzik Manger.”
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you could do without the whole megillah. Parts would be just fine.

lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: Hip-Hop Producer Recovering After Gunshot Wound During Robbery
abstract: In a statement, a publicist said AraabMuzik was”currently alive and well” and attributed the shooting to “being in the wrong place at the wrong time.”
lead_paragraph: The hip-hop producer AraabMuzik who was shot in the chest during a a robbery in Providence, R.I., last week remains hospitalized, the police said.

headline: Do-Not-Track Talks Could Be Running Off the Rails
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Protection', 'Online Advertising', 'Privacy', 'Web Browsers']
abstract: Almost two years of talks over an international Do Not Track standard has made little headway to an agreement, but the two sides will meet again next week in California.
lead_paragraph: After nearly two years of negotiating and little progress, the international group trying to agree on a Do Not Track standard is convening its final official face-to-face meeting next week in Sunnyvale, Calif.
