headline: Occidental Chairman Agrees to Step Down Ahead of Schedule
abstract: Activist shareholders had called for the 78-year-old to step down.
lead_paragraph: Conceding to a shareholder revolt, Occidental Petroleum’s longtime chairman, Ray R. Irani, on Friday stepped down from the board, essentially forced into retirement a year ahead of schedule.

headline: Kodak’s Fuzzy Future
abstract: As part of its bankruptcy, Kodak sold well-known businesses to focus on areas that some say are highly competitive or stagnant.
lead_paragraph: When Eastman Kodak emerges from bankruptcy this summer or fall, it will be a shadow of the blue-chip corporate giant it once was.

headline: A Diva Inspires Orchards of Sensuality
abstract: Ann Hampton Callaway was joined by a quintet for “From Sassy to Divine: A Celebration of Sarah Vaughan” at Dizzy’s Coca-Cola.
lead_paragraph: Ann Hampton Callaway, like the great jazz diva Sarah Vaughan to whom she paid tribute at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Thursday evening, has a voice so rich, flexible and extravagantly gorgeous that it hardly matters what use she puts it to. The sound always comes first and is what you most remember.

headline: Take the Plunge With ‘Hamilton’s Pharmacopeia’
abstract: The latest episode of the Web series “Hamilton’s Pharmacopeia” is about sensory-deprivation tanks: you’re immersed in salt water, in complete silence and darkness, and you just . . . float.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, a new episode of the Web series “Hamilton’s Pharmacopeia” appeared. Hamilton Morris is a chemist and general expert in the field of psychedelics and all things mind-bending. In past episodes, he has investigated rare hallucinogenic tree frogs in the Amazon, an abandoned missile silo in Kansas that became the world’s most productive LSD lab and a Haitian drug that supposedly turned people into zombies.

headline: South Africa Is Outraged by a Shortcut to a Wedding
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The use of a military air base to transport civilian guests to the wedding of a wealthy family has set off anger.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — It was to be an affair to remember. The bride was a daughter of a powerful and politically connected immigrant family. Her parents booked all 338 rooms in one of South Africa’s most lavish resorts, complete with exclusive access to its artificial beach. Kathakali dancers with painted faces and turbaned Rajasthani musicians from the family’s native country, India, performed for the guests. A pontoon carried the happy couple across an imitation Roman bath to greet their guests.

headline: Pictures of the Day: California and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from California, Pakistan, Iraq and Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: Photos from California, Pakistan, Iraq and Bangladesh.

headline: Summer Movie Release Schedule
abstract: A listing of films releasing this summer.
lead_paragraph: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Too Many Lives to Live: Old Soaps Reborn Online
abstract: Two revived soaps, “All My Children” and “One Life to Live,” now seen on the Internet, offer little in the way of guidance for newbies.
lead_paragraph: An older gentleman proposes to a woman he has apparently known for a long time, though we have no idea who either one is. An angry man is released from prison, though it’s not clear why he was there or what he’s angry about. Some surly guy with a scar on his cheek annoys everyone he encounters by his mere presence. There are repeated references to dead babies, and DNA testing would help sort out the parentage of almost everyone under 25.

headline: Coney Island, 1:51 P.M.
abstract: Photo: the arcade of the long-shuttered Childs Restaurant provided a nice spot for sunbathing.

headline: A House of Drone, Ecstatic and Raw, With a Potent Aura of Largess
abstract: “Drone Activity in Progress,” a highly idiosyncratic one-night music festival, drew over 1,000 to the Knockdown Center in Queens on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: There’s an irreducible element of music that connects metal, industrial music, power electronics and classical minimalism, and no word exists for it. It involves deep pulsations; excited provocation through sound and concept more than traditional technique; low-end frequencies rarely encountered in life; long sustained tones enlarged through overdrive; or distortion or just force of hands on instruments.

headline: Israel Tightens Border Defense as Syria Erupts
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Errant munitions from Syria’s conflict have landed in the Golan Heights some 30 times. But the concern runs deeper along what was one border Israel didn’t have to worry much about.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT HAZEKA, Israel — Elite infantry and reconnaissance units have been moved into the long-quiet Golan Heights this spring. Bulldozers are making way for new military shelters. And at an Israeli Army outpost on a strategic hilltop here, a Merkava tank sits pointing toward Syria — poised to race up a dirt ramp at a moment’s notice.

headline: A Dark Time in Hungary, Remembered
abstract: Performing at Carnegie Hall, the American Symphony Orchestra presented a program of little-known works by Hungarian composers whose careers were roiled by the rise of the Nazis and World War II.
lead_paragraph: Time has shown that no subject or context is too complex or provocative for the conductor Leon Botstein to investigate in his programming for the American Symphony Orchestra, nor any topic so clear-cut that he will not muddy the waters by incorporating elements likely to prove provocative. “Hungary Torn,” presented on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, offered a textbook example of Mr. Botstein’s professorial zeal for dislodging convention.

headline: Artifacts | The Dinosaur in Anselm Kiefer
abstract: The larger-than-life German artist, famed for his apocalyptic postwar landscapes, softens up a bit in “Morgenthau Plan,” a new show at the Gagosian Gallery.
lead_paragraph: In person, Anselm Kiefer is much more self-mocking and relaxed than his enormous, heart-of-darkness German history paintings and titanic lead or concrete sculptures might suggest. On Thursday morning, clad in white yoga pants, a dark shirt and thin black flip-flops, the 68-year-old artist showed a light spirit as he walked through “Morgenthau Plan,” his exhibition opening tonight at the Gagosian Gallery on West 21st Street.

headline: Beethoven’s Transcendental Meditations
abstract: At Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, the pianist Richard Goode performed three sonatas that a resigned, accepting Beethoven wrote late in his career.
lead_paragraph: “Resignation, what a wretched resource! Yet it is all that is left to me,” Beethoven wrote in 1801, despairing at his encroaching deafness and other physical ailments. A sense of resignation and acceptance pervades the triptych of sonatas that he completed in 1822, given majestic, profound readings by the pianist Richard Goode on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Unheralded Filly Beats Star-Studded Oaks Field
abstract: Princess of Sylmar launched a prolonged rally to overtake Beholder by one-half length and pull a stunning upset in the $1 million Kentucky Oaks.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE — Princess of Sylmar, overlooked among the galaxy of stars trained by Todd Pletcher, launched a prolonged rally to overtake Beholder by one-half length and pull a stunning upset in the $1 million Kentucky Oaks on Friday at Churchill Downs.

headline: Little Ideas, Big Trouble
abstract: The other day I was chatting with a colleague (no, I won’t implicate him) about what to wear to the punk-themed gala at the Met on Monday night, jewels or safety pins, and he suggested I visit a trimmings shop on Sixth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: The other day I was chatting with a colleague (no, I won’t implicate him) about what to wear to the punk-themed gala at the Met on Monday night, jewels or safety pins, and he suggested I visit a trimmings shop on Sixth Avenue.

headline: Gourmet Twists on Tavern Food
abstract: Chiboust, a restaurant popular for its Mediterranean cuisine and desserts, has made changes: a bigger bar, exotic cocktails and pizza.
lead_paragraph: Chiboust opened in Tarrytown in 2004 and quickly became popular for its imaginative Mediterranean-inspired menu. Jill Rose, the chef and owner, was especially loved for her desserts, which were announced by a huge refrigerated display case at the entrance to the restaurant.

headline: Education and Employment
abstract: Employment for college graduates has increased by 9 percent since the start of the recession in 2007, while for those without a high school diploma, it has decreased by 14 percent.
lead_paragraph: Employment for college graduates has increased by 9 percent since the start of the recession in 2007, while for those without a high school diploma, it has decreased by 14 percent.

headline: Coming Soon
abstract: Images of select films releasing this summer.
lead_paragraph: Images of select films releasing this summer.

headline: Tapas That Tease the Eye and the Tongue
abstract: At Ibiza Tapas Wine Bar, a bright dining room with avant-garde artwork sets the backdrop for tapas dishes that are divided between traditional and modern takes on Spanish finger food.
lead_paragraph: Widespread and varied as tapas have become in Connecticut, the arrival of Ibiza Tapas Wine Bar in Danbury in January serves as a refreshing reminder of the heights — and delights — this quintessential Spanish bar food can achieve. Ibiza is the fourth in a growing family of like-named restaurants owned by Ignacio Blanco (other Ibizas are in New Haven, Hamden and Northampton, Mass.). In contrast to the understated, rustic elegance of Mr. Blanco’s earlier venture in Norwalk, Maison Galicia (renamed Meigas and later sold), Ibiza brings a vibrant Barcelona-meets-Caribbean splash of bold colors to the dining experience.

headline: Working Alone, Together
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Telecommuting']
abstract: Many independent workers, finding themselves alienated, are joining a new generation of co-working spaces, some quite exclusive.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Tingle, a New York entrepreneur, once had the common fantasy of ditching the 9-to-5 world, starting her own business and working in the serenity of her home. It did not quite work out as planned.

headline: Stories From Sons of a Storyteller
abstract: Saul Bellow’s three sons gathered at their first public joint discussion of their father to promote “Saul Bellow’s Heart: A Son’s Memoir,” by Gregory Bellow.
lead_paragraph: The brothers Bellow are the three sons of three different wives, and have never lived together for more than a weekend.

headline: Urban Gardening: An Appleseed With Attitude
abstract: Ron Finley is a crusader for planting vegetable gardens in urban areas.
lead_paragraph: Ron Finley was home by the pool recently when his thoughts once again turned to dirt. “People need to realize how powerful the transformation of soil can be,” he said, with a hint of evangelism. “We’ve gotten so far away from our food source. It’s been hijacked from us. But if you get soil, plant something in it and water it, you can feed yourself. It’s that simple.”

headline: Documentary Is as Murky as Vietnam Itself Was
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A day after the documentary “Unclaimed,” which suggests that a former P.O.W. was found alive in Vietnam, played at a film festival, the Defense Department said the man was a fraud.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A new documentary strongly suggests that a man who’s been living in Vietnam for the last 40 years is a former American prisoner of war, John Hartley Robertson, a Special Forces soldier who was aboard a helicopter that crashed in 1968 in Laos after coming under fire.

headline: All of This Restraint in the Service of Beauty
abstract: “The Legend of Apsara Mera,” by the Royal Ballet of Cambodia at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, showcases a form and a story that are steeped in religious worship, utmost politeness and order.
lead_paragraph: Flourishing their hands like fans, the dancers of the Royal Ballet of Cambodia create a measured world of complete etiquette. Everything is recollected in tranquillity. Even a battle is depicted with patterned composure. Nothing is fast. Yet stasis seldom occurs; some flow of movement is almost always in evidence. The planting of the heel or the ball of a bare foot; the flexing of a foot raised behind; the soft, S-bend adjustment of the torso at hip and shoulder in certain prolonged balances: these are all sensuous ingredients of the style.

headline: Seeing Sylvia Plath With New Eyes
abstract: A biography explains how the poet neglected to mention her thirst for glamour and fashion.
lead_paragraph: This year, as anyone of a poetic temperament cannot fail to have noticed, is the 50th anniversary of Sylvia Plath’s suicide. Her death occurred a month after the publication of her autobiographical novel, “The Bell Jar,” and not long after she completed a manuscript of her influential poetry collection, “Ariel.” Plath’s estranged husband, the poet Ted Hughes, published a version of “Ariel” in 1965, ordering and choosing its poems as he saw fit, assuring her posthumous fame — and directing the shape that fame would assume.

headline: Cyberparenting and the Risk of T.M.I.
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'Text Messaging', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: Parents, in an attempt to keep their children safe, access social media, but at the end of the day, is it really too much information?
lead_paragraph: It may be a timeless curse of parenthood to know simultaneously too much about one’s teenager and yet never access the information one actually wants. But the unruly morass of today’s social media and cellphone-infested landscape seems to have made both aspects of the curse worse.

headline: Sandwiches, Rocket-Fast
abstract: At Wild Rocket, the “rocket” in the 12-seat storefront cafe’s name refers to arugula, which is featured in most of the salads.
lead_paragraph: Wild Rocket, a new sandwich shop in Huntington, is the first fast-food venture from the Reststar Hospitality Group, which also owns Bistro Citron in Roslyn and Bistro Cassis and Café Buenos Aires in Huntington, among others. Wild Rocket, which opened in March, is run by Jason Machado, 34, of Huntington, and his brother, Eric, 41, two of the partners in Reststar. They hired Marc Anthony Bynum, a consultant and chef, to create a menu of sandwiches, salads and smoothies that took inspiration from the company’s restaurants.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 3
abstract: Watch a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a five-alarm fire in the Bronx, a motorcycle club in Queens and the cherry blossoms blooming in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a five-alarm fire in the Bronx, a motorcycle club in Queens and the cherry blossoms blooming in Brooklyn.

headline: Remembering Where They Came From
abstract: Graceful Rose has more than good looks going for it; the restaurant hired Massimo Fedozzi, a superstar, as its executive chef in late March.
lead_paragraph: Ever dream about what you would do if you won the lottery? Richard and Mary Morrison, winners in 2010, decided to open a restaurant, Graceful Rose, in Port Jefferson, a tribute to Richard’s mother, Rose, and his grandmother Grace.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Internet Cats Sue, and Google Games
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include a suit against Warner Brothers by the developers of two sites based on cat memes, what Google is up to with game development, and a text service aimed at fans of “Arrested Development.”
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Go the Same Way, or Go the Wrong Way
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: Gone are the days when “conformist” was a slur. Now, if you’re not following the crowd of five-star dispensers, you are a tasteless, undiscriminating shlub.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a friend of mine, a dear man with exquisite taste, took me to dinner at Momofuku Má Pêche in Midtown Manhattan. I point out his taste because, being from out of town, he chose the restaurant on the fly, based on some reviews he had read on Yelp, the social networking site that rates everything from eating establishments to vacuum cleaners to gastroenterologists. The supertrendy place had gotten some raves.

headline: The Right Stance Can Be Reassuring
abstract: The best pose sends positive messages to others as well as reassuring ones to yourself.
lead_paragraph: Watch celebrities on the red carpet, or models on a runway, and you’ll undoubtedly see the classic stop-for-the-flashing-cameras stance: chest open, legs apart, head level, usually with a hand on the hip.

headline: Savoring the Exotic Spices, and the Heat
abstract: Photos of unfamiliar dishes are delivered with the menus at Sigiri Sri Lankan Cuisine, but the aromas say everything.
lead_paragraph: At Sigiri Sri Lankan Cuisine, ignore the folding tables with awkwardly placed legs.

headline: The Real Rock of Ages
abstract: A piece of limestone, worn around the neck, symbolizes what generations endured.
lead_paragraph: LOOKING AT THE STRANGE formation of mighty, 20-foot-tall bluestone totems outside Rockefeller Center, you might imagine them to be the unearthed ruins of some ancient temple: Stonehenge come to Saks. Upon learning that they are the work of the artist Ugo Rondinone, you might wonder if these sculptures (and the tabletop versions in a show opening Friday at Gladstone Gallery) are some kind of mystical portals to the Paleolithic.

headline: In Broadway Tunes, Ballet Finds Its Inner Showgirl
abstract: New York City Ballet is presenting a Richard Rodgers program at the David H. Koch Theater as part of its American Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: Igor Stravinsky is a composer synonymous with New York City Ballet and its co-founder George Balanchine, but what about Richard Rodgers? On Thursday, as part of the company’s American Music Festival at the David H. Koch Theater, City Ballet unveiled an all-Rodgers evening that opened a door to ballet’s jazzy, sensuous side. As the three-week festival continues, others, from Philip Glass to Nico Muhly, will be heard, revealing ways that music gains — or loses — flavor through ballet.

headline: From Triple-A to the Mets’ Lineup
abstract: The Mets called up Andrew Brown from Class Las Vegas and immediately put him in the lineup to hit eighth.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Mets were hitting .191 in the seven games before the start of the weekend series with the Braves, so they could use a serious jolt for their offense, especially among their outfielders. They called up Andrew Brown from Class AAA Las Vegas and immediately put him in the lineup to hit eighth and play right field against the Atlanta left-hander Mike Minor on Friday night.

headline: Missionary Zeal, Baroque Style
abstract: Culminating the sixth annual Clarion Collegium Week, a concert of the Baroque music of Bolivia was performed on Tuesday at St. Paul’s Chapel at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: Jesuit missionaries founded settlements in eastern Bolivia using European music as a means of rendering Roman Catholicism more palatable to the indigenous people. Choir directors, musical instrument makers and composers, including the Italian Baroque composer Domenico Zipoli, moved to South America and taught the locals.

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Final
abstract: Bold bidding often needs to be backed up with accurate card reading.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Bold bidding often needs to be backed up with accurate card reading. The diagramed deal occurred during the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in March. It resulted in a gain of 10 international match points for the winners, Sabine Auken and Morten and Dennis Bilde (father and son) from Denmark, and Roy Welland of New York City.

headline: Early Wildfire Drives Thousands From Homes in Southern California
abstract: No injuries were reported, but the intensity and early arrival of the season’s first major wildfire in California offered a worrisome indicator of what may be a severe fire season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Walls of wind-driven fire swept across Ventura County on Friday, forcing thousands of home evacuations, shutting down schools and offices and ravaging acres of woodland as firefighters struggled for a second day to bring an ominously early California wildfire under control.

headline: New Yorkers Walked Over, for Once
abstract: The artist J R’s “InsideOut” project, the culmination of a wish that was granted after he won a TED prize, has come to Times Square.
lead_paragraph: You may like to look at art, or perhaps collect it. But if you’ve ever had fantasies of being an art piece, the Parisian street artist and photographer known as J R is offering you the chance, by way of his “Inside Out” project.

headline: Crisp Images From a Faded Long Island Past
abstract: The Heckscher Museum of Art is showcasing photographs by Hal Fullerton depicting landscapes, boats, workers and seashore bathers on Long Island in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
lead_paragraph: In 1897, before the commuter age began, the Long Island Rail Road hired Hal B. Fullerton, formerly a business executive, to lure more visitors and settlers to Long Island. During his 30 years as a special agent for the L.I.R.R., he produced many books, pamphlets and promotional events for the railroad, and he started two experimental farms to demonstrate how productive the Island’s land could be.

headline: A 24-Hour Race for Sightings
abstract: In the World Series of Birding, about 100 teams fan out across New Jersey to see as many species as they can.
lead_paragraph: At 12:01 a.m. on May 11, the first of around 1,000 birders in about 100 teams will fan out across New Jersey to see as many species as they can in 24 hours. They will be compiling checklists, raising money and awareness for conservation and, most important for some of them, trying to beat the competition.

headline: Yankees’ Bullpen Takes Another Hit
abstract: A day after Joba Chamberlain (strained oblique) went on the disabled list, the Yankees said Dave Robertson would most likely miss several games with a hamstring injury.
lead_paragraph: This season, while the rest of his roster seemingly dwindled day after day because of injuries, Manager Joe Girardi could always depend on the sturdy back end of the bullpen. Now, the vaunted Joba Chamberlain-Dave Robertson bridge to Mariano Rivera has also collapsed.

headline: A Romantic Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
abstract: Less a lyrical study of an artist’s life, “Himself and Nora” skims through the biographical details to leave ample room for the couple’s love story.
lead_paragraph: Given that James Joyce was a leading avant-garde author of his day, it is a tad paradoxical that “Himself and Nora,” written and composed by Jonathan Brielle, has been devised as a conventional musical theater piece. Still, the intimate chamber musical, at the 199-seat Hamilton Stage in Rahway, is a lively, sometimes lusty, spin through the love life, troubles and literary times of the great Irish writer.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —   The Sea Creatures, who recently sent their recording “Naked in the Rain” to the Library of Congress, probably did not ponder the impact of sequestration on their music’s journey from dream to copyright.

headline: Events in Westchester

headline: To Race’s Owner, Track Is No Longer at Center of the Business Universe
abstract: As the business of horse racing continues its long decline, Churchill Downs Inc. has transformed itself into a full-blown gambling company, with interests in casinos and Internet sites.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Last year, Churchill Downs Inc., the company that runs the most famous track in horse racing, moved its corporate headquarters from beneath the track’s iconic twin spires to the top floor of a glass office building 15 miles away. Robert L. Evans, the company’s chairman and chief executive, has frequently assured investors that while hosting the Kentucky Derby may be the company’s most celebrated endeavor, it is hardly the most important.

headline: JPMorgan Directors Feel Heat in a Vote
abstract: As the bank grapples with regulatory battles, some shareholders are taking public aim at individual directors who hold crucial positions on the bank’s audit and risk committees.
lead_paragraph: As JPMorgan Chase’s annual meeting nears, much of the tension surrounds a critical vote to split the chairman and chief executive roles — a decision that could strip Jamie Dimon, the bank’s influential leader, of the dual titles he has held since 2006. Behind the scenes, though, another battle is brewing.

headline: A Lawyer’s Story, as Only He Could Tell It
abstract: “Kunstler,” at Pace University, takes a journey through William Kunstler’s most famous cases, including those of the Chicago Seven, the Attica prison-riots inmates and the American Indian Movement.
lead_paragraph: Always open with a joke.

headline: Last of a Breed: Postal Workers Who Decipher Bad Addresses
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Handwriting']
abstract: The Postal Service once had 55 centers where workers tried to decipher addresses rejected by scanning machines. In September, one of two remaining centers will close.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Inside a plain warehouselike office building filled with rows of cubicles, Melissa Stark stares at the image of an envelope on a computer screen. The handwriting is barely legible and appears to be addressed to someone in the “cty of Jesey.”

headline: A Grandson Visits China in Footsteps of Nixon
abstract: The trip by Christopher Nixon Cox, 100 years after President Richard M. Nixon’s birth, was organized to lionize both the president’s and the Communist Party’s accomplishments.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Christopher Nixon Cox retraced his grandfather’s historic 1972 trip to China on Friday, trailed through Tiananmen Square by an entourage of aging Nixon administration luminaries, state-news-media paparazzi and Chinese security agents.

headline: Caravaggio, and Some of His Admirers
abstract: An exhibition featuring the works of the great artist and 21 “Caravaggisti” is on view through June 16 at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford.
lead_paragraph: In spite of a life that was brief and often rowdy, Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio changed the face of painting. Rejecting the idealized and decorous classicism of his predecessors, he dramatized his compositions with his use of vivid lighting and insisted on humanizing his subjects by painting from life with all its particulars. Even his saints had dirty feet.

headline: An Ode to Helium
keywords: ['Helium', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Forget the hot air jokes, people. Who said that Congress hasn’t been getting anything done lately?
lead_paragraph: We have not been paying nearly enough attention to helium legislation.

headline: With Help of Two Veterans, Blues Maintain Their Composure
abstract: Jay Bouwmeester and Jordan Leopold, a pair of late season acquisitions, helped the Blues keep their emotions in check while taking a 2-0 lead in the postseason series.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Jay Bouwmeester is not overly excited about the first Stanley Cup playoff action of his career.

headline: Prison Conditions Eased for Ex-Marine Held in Iran
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Political Prisoners', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Relatives see possible signs that Iran eventually could release a man who has been held there for nearly two years on suspicions of spying.
lead_paragraph: A former Marine incarcerated in Iran for nearly two years on suspicions that he was an American spy has been granted monthly visitations by an uncle in Tehran since March and has been permitted to send letters to his family for the first time, according to his sister, who interpreted the eased conditions as possible signs that Iran eventually could release him.

headline: As Old as the Bottles
abstract: A letter from a reader prompted by Corey Kilgannon’s Character Study column about a long-serving Brooklyn seltzer man.
lead_paragraph: Corey Kilgannon’s Character Study column about a long-serving Brooklyn seltzer man prompted the following letter.

headline: Foreign Students to Face New Checks at U.S. Borders
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security ordered changes after finding that Azamat Tazhayakov, a friend of the surviving suspect in the Boston bombings, used a visa that should have been canceled.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security has ordered new security checks for all foreign students entering the United States, according to officials familiar with instructions issued Friday to customs inspectors.

headline: Warriors Use Hint of Lee, and Lots of Curry, to Win
abstract: Stephen Curry scored 22 points and David Lee made a surprising cameo in a quick return from injury as Golden State eliminated the Denver Nuggets in six games.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The end came the way the Denver Nuggets feared it could, with Golden State’s Stephen Curry lobbing 3-pointers, Andrew Bogut crashing the basket and a hyper-charged crowd shaking the arena with earsplitting noise. By the time the first scrap of yellow celebratory confetti fell Thursday night, the Nuggets were off the court and through the tunnel, ushered out of the playoffs.

headline: Mississippi Inmate’s Bid for DNA Tests Is Denied With Tuesday Execution Set
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Forensic Science', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: Turned down by the State Supreme Court, lawyers for Willie Manning, a death row inmate, are lobbying the governor.
lead_paragraph: The State of Mississippi has denied requests for DNA testing of evidence made by a prisoner set to be executed on Tuesday, potentially setting up what experts said would be a rare case in recent years in which a person is put to death with such requests unmet.

headline: Send Judges to Guantánamo, Then Shut It
abstract: President Obama can get past Congress’s ban on bringing Guantánamo detainees north for civilian trials by sending civilian judges to them.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN

headline: Consuming Colonists
abstract: What recent evidence of cannibalism at Jamestown tells us about the earliest English settlements.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.

headline: Drug to Cut Cholesterol Is Approved by the F.D.A.
abstract: The drug pairs Merck’s Zetia, which lowers low-density lipoprotein, with the generic version of Lipitor, the best-selling statin made by Pfizer that lost its patent protection in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved on Friday a combination drug developed by Merck that lowers a patient’s cholesterol but has not been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease or death, the company said.

headline: Leading at Midpoint, Mickelson Looks Sharp
abstract: Phil Mickelson might have taken this weekend off, had the horse in which he has a stake made the Kentucky Derby field.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The surprise is not that Phil Mickelson is part-owner of a Kentucky-bred thoroughbred that once was considered a potential entrant in the Kentucky Derby. Mickelson, who enjoys placing wagers on major sporting events like the Super Bowl, grew up in San Diego, not far from the Del Mar racetrack. The surprise is that the horses never grabbed hold of Mickelson’s imagination or wallet.

headline: 2 Killings and 2 Guns, Unattended
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Why is it that a reckless driver can be prosecuted but not an irresponsible gun owner?
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Aug. 7, 2012, Greg Imhoff — a big, friendly 61-year-old construction superintendent from Madison, Wis., who had moved to Florida with his partner, Shari Telvick — went to check on the home of a neighbor.

headline: Stand Up, Cast Off, Reel In
abstract: During business hours, Pierre A. Champion cuts private equity deals, but in the early morning he is on his stand-up paddleboard, landing unsuspecting fish.
lead_paragraph: Relaxing with a rod and a beer is not the way someone named Pierre A. Champion goes about landing a prize catch.

headline: Winning the Field, but Not the War
abstract: The Civil War marked the end of the age when pitched battles determined the outcome of a conflict.
lead_paragraph: One hundred and fifty years ago this week, more than 133,000 Union soldiers squared off against more than 60,000 Confederates in the Battle of Chancellorsville. Though the battle swung back and forth for several days, it ended with a decisive Southern victory. And yet the war ground on, for another two years. The war only ended when the devastation spilled off the battlefield, as Sherman and his army took the conflict to the farmland and cities of the South.

headline: Florida Lawmakers Approve Overhaul of State’s Problem-Ridden Voting Process
keywords: ['Elections', 'Voting and Voters', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The legislation is a response to hours-long waits for voters in several counties and a deeply flawed early voting program in 2012.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Six months after Florida became the butt of late-night jokes for a chaotic voting process that bedeviled the 2012 presidential election, the State Legislature passed a bill on Friday to remedy many of those problems.

headline: Jobs, Wages and the Sequester
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Working Hours', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Government Employees', 'Editorials']
abstract: The April employment report suggests the distressing shape of things to come.
lead_paragraph: The employment report released on Friday showed some economic resilience. Job growth for March was revised upward to 138,000 new jobs, while the tally for April, at 165,000 jobs, was stronger still.

headline: Small, Cute Sinkhole Swallows Menu and Soda Bottle
abstract: For more than seven hours, a sinkhole in the West Village captivated the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: If you’re like us, you’ve probably read more than enough stories about horrible nightmare sinkholes that swallow up trucks and kill people. Join us, then, in praise of the Little Sinkhole of West Tenth Street.

headline: City Futures, a Poet’s Past
abstract: In “New York and Los Angeles: The Uncertain Future,” two sociology professors examine the demographic, political, economic and cultural forces shaping the country’s two biggest metropolitan areas.
lead_paragraph: One in eight Americans lives in metropolitan New York or Los Angeles, so exploring and comparing the regions is an instructive exercise in where the nation is heading. And in “New York and Los Angeles: The Uncertain Future” (Oxford University Press, $34.95), Andrew A. Beveridge and David Halle, sociology professors at Queens College and the University of California, Los Angeles, enlist experts from the social sciences to do just that.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 3, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, May 3, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “It is the baby boomer group where we see the highest rates of suicide. There may be something about that group, and how they think about life issues and their life choices that may make a difference.”

headline: The Mayor on Stop-and-Frisk
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Editorials']
abstract: Mayor Michael Bloomberg fails to persuade in his defense of a troubled police program.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg trotted out shopworn, discredited arguments this week while defending the constitutionally suspect police program under which hundreds of thousands of innocent New Yorkers have been detained and questioned on the streets every year. His speech, at 1 Police Plaza, castigated civil rights lawyers who oppose what they say is the practice of stopping people based on race instead of reasonable suspicion; Democratic mayoral candidates who want to rein in the stop-and-frisk program; and the City Council, which is considering a perfectly reasonable bill that would create the position of Police Department inspector general, with broad powers to review department policies.

headline: Funeral Home Accepts Suspect’s Body, and Problems
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)']
abstract: In agreeing to bury the bombing suspect Tamerlan Tsarnaev, a Worcester, Mass., funeral director had to answer an official’s questions as he struggled to find a cemetery.
lead_paragraph: WORCESTER, Mass. — Peter A. Stefan sat straight up in a leather chair in the funeral home he owns and looked purposefully at the city councilor who had come to ask him why he of all people was storing the body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev.

headline: College Graduates Fare Well in Jobs Market, Even Through Recession
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: College graduates are the only group that has more people employed today than when the recession started.
lead_paragraph: Is college worth it? Given the growing price tag and the frequent anecdotes about jobless graduates stuck in their parents’ basements, many have started to question the value of a college degree. But the evidence suggests college graduates have suffered through the recession and lackluster recovery with remarkable resilience.

headline: As Senators Head for Exit, Few Step Up to Run for Seats
abstract: At least eight of the 33 senators whose terms expire in 2014 won’t run again, but potential candidates are passing on a position that once was coveted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The retirement of Tom Harkin, a Democrat who has represented Iowa in the Senate for nearly 30 years, should be the kind of rare opportunity that sends the best and brightest of his state’s political class scrambling to get on the ballot.

headline: Dear College Graduates...
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Graduation Rates']
abstract: Congratulations and good luck, Class of ’13. You’ll need it.
lead_paragraph: I’m scheduled to deliver the commencement address Friday at my alma mater, Grambling State University in Louisiana, so I’ve been giving quite a bit of thought to the America into which these students are graduating.

headline: Judge Says Cuban Who Spied on U.S. Can Stay in Cuba
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A federal judge in Miami said a convicted spy could stay in Cuba, where he went for his father’s funeral, if he renounced his American citizenship.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A Cuban man convicted in the United States of spying on behalf of Cuba can stay in Cuba, where he was allowed to go last month for his father’s funeral, if he renounces his American citizenship, a federal judge ruled Friday.

headline: Before Mayweather’s Fight, a Conflict of Story Lines
abstract: The boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr., set for his first fight in a year, is described as a changed man. His words may indicate otherwise.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Floyd Mayweather Jr. entered the MGM Grand Garden Arena flanked by camera crews and boom microphones and four bodyguards roughly the size of Fiats. Sunglasses on, cellphones in hand, he trailed them upstairs, where a series of interviews would simultaneously bolster and diminish the chosen narrative for his latest fight.

headline: A British Pub’s Offense? Favoring the British
abstract: A Brooklyn bar is fighting a $2,500 fine it received for a help-wanted advertisement that said being British was an advantage in getting a job there.
lead_paragraph: Longbow Pub and Pantry, an oak-paneled haven of sport and imbibition on a busy strip in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is a British pub through and through, from the Welsh national rugby jersey framed by the bar to the Old Speckled Hen ale in the fish-and-chips batter to the accents that ring loud off the walls during soccer broadcasts.

headline: Early Voting Means Easier Voting
abstract: New York State has one of the worst voter turnout records in the country. One fix would be to allow early voting.
lead_paragraph: New York State is a national laggard when it comes to voting. The state has one of the worst voter turnout records in the country, not least because the act of voting is cumbersome and uninviting. In November, 53.6 percent of registered voters cast ballots, leaving New York 44th among the 50 states and the District of Columbia for voter participation.

headline: Shooting His Own Foot
abstract: France sent a terrible message to its entrepreneurs and foreign investors when it prevented Yahoo from buying a stake in a French Internet company.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France has recently been on a campaign to change the widely held perception that his administration is hostile to business. He has sounded more welcoming to foreign investment and has promised to lower capital gains taxes. But barely days into his charm offensive, one of Mr. Hollande’s ministers was triumphantly claiming credit for preventing Yahoo from buying a controlling stake in a successful French online video streaming company, DailyMotion.

abstract: Bangladeshis bury their dead as apparel companies discuss factory safety, China’s factories slow down and American job growth exceeds forecasts.
lead_paragraph: Bangladeshis bury their dead as apparel companies discuss factory safety, China’s factories slow down and American job growth exceeds forecasts.

headline: Almost There
abstract: Gird your loins. It’s a Doug Peterson and Brad Wilber puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Here’s when I knew I was in trouble: at 23 Across, the devilishly wicked clue “Resident of Angola, Brazil or Lebanon” taunted me mercilessly as I tried to figure out who might reside in all of those countries. Sure, there were a few brain cells nagging at me that Lebanon was the name of a couple of American towns, but I ignored them. Big mistake.

headline: Knicks Falter in Fourth Before Closing Out Celtics
abstract: The Knicks nearly gave away a 26-point lead in the fourth quarter before steadying themselves to outlast the Celtics. They clinched their first playoff series victory since 2000.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The wait had been long, humiliating, often torturous, and it would not end without one final jolt of stress, one last anxious sensation before the moment of exhilaration finally, mercifully arrived. Delayed gratification never felt this good.

headline: Seeking Flexibility During Storms
abstract: A preliminary map of expanded New York City evacuation zones includes nearly three million residents.
lead_paragraph: A preliminary map of expanded New York City evacuation zones includes nearly three million residents.

headline: Questions Linger for Liu After Ex-Associates’ Trial
abstract: Speculation has begun about John C. Liu’s political viability and legal exposure following the convictions of two former associates in an illegal campaign-finance scheme.
lead_paragraph: When John C. Liu hastily announced late Thursday that he would hold a news conference that night to discuss the convictions of two former associates in an illegal campaign-finance scheme, speculation began to build: Would he criticize the guilty parties and vow not to tolerate similar conduct? Would he be rattled, or even abandon the race for mayor?

headline: Jeff Hanneman, Guitarist, Dies at 49
abstract: Mr. Hanneman, who was a founder of the band Slayer while still in his teens, helped to create some of the darkest music and imagery in metal.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Hanneman, a guitarist for the influential metal band Slayer, who helped shape the group’s sonic assault and wrote some of its most popular — and controversial — songs, died on Thursday at a hospital near his home east of Los Angeles. He was 49.

headline: Adding Evacuation Zones in Response to Hurricane
abstract: The expansion, outlined in a report on the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, would double the number of zones to six and include an additional 640,000 New York City residents.
lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration announced on Friday that it would double to six the number of evacuation zones along New York City’s coast and expand them to include an additional 640,000 residents, saying that the new map would provide more flexibility when major storms hit.

headline: Trading Handshakes for Home Cooking
abstract: David S. Yassky, commissioner of the city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission, spends Sundays with his wife and daughter, walking the dog, going to spin class, cooking and watching classic television.
lead_paragraph: In his former life as a city councilman and candidate for city comptroller, David S. Yassky, 49, saw many weekend hours sacrificed to political events; handshaking, crowd stirring, park-cleaning. But though his current job, as commissioner of the city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission, can intrude on any given weekend, he seems to have recaptured his Sundays. Now they begin with a trip to the dog run near his Brooklyn Heights home and an exercise outing with his wife, Diana Fortuna, the chief financial officer of the Metropolitan Opera. They typically end with a dose of classic television. In between, Mr. Yassky strives to prove his culinary chops to the couple’s 14-year-old daughter, Margaret, a Food Network fan with a discerning palate. Their other daughter, Susan, 19, is finishing her freshman year at Yale.

headline: A Place for Vandals Turns Outdoor Gallery
abstract: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Bushwick had long been a target for graffiti until a lifelong resident decided to change that.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Bushwick had long been a target for graffiti until a lifelong resident decided to change that.

headline: Mike Gray, ‘China Syndrome’ Writer, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Gray dealt with contemporary issues in his work, including race relations and American drug policy.
lead_paragraph: Mike Gray, a writer and filmmaker who tackled thorny contemporary issues in his work, including race relations in Chicago, American drug policy and, most notably, the safety of nuclear power plants — the subject of the 1979 film “The China Syndrome,” for which he wrote the original screenplay — died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77.

headline: Tom Knapp, Crowd-Pleasing Sure Shot, Dies at 62
abstract: Mr. Knapp broke world records by picking off flocks of airborne clay targets with the flair of a western movie hero.
lead_paragraph: Tom Knapp, an exhibition shotgun virtuoso who broke world records by picking off flocks of airborne clay targets with the flair of a western movie hero and dazzled crowds with his effortless precision shattering of golf balls, radishes, aspirin and other flying targets, died on April 26 in Rochester, Minn. He was 62.

headline: Bushwick Gets a Fresh Coat
abstract: Joseph Ficalora, in pain from bad memories everywhere he looked and fed up with vandals tagging his neighborhood with graffiti, has turned the streets of Bushwick, Brooklyn, into an outdoor gallery.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, Joseph Ficalora would sit on the roof of his family’s steel fabrication business. In Bushwick, Brooklyn, in the 1980s, it was one of the few safe places outdoors. The view was grim. The streets were dirty. Graffiti was endless.

headline: Sabathia’s Early Mistake Is All Griffin and A’s Need
abstract: C. C. Sabathia gave up a homer on his first pitch and A’s starter A. J. Griffin made the slim lead hold up with seven shutout innings.
lead_paragraph: In the moments leading up to his start Friday against the Yankees, Oakland Athletics pitcher A. J. Griffin serenaded his teammates by playing his guitar and singing in the middle of the clubhouse. The free-spirited Griffin even sang a song in Spanish for the Cuban outfielder Yoenis Cespedes.

headline: Racing Family Dares to Dream of Victory
abstract: The Phipps family, who owned the Kentucky Derby runner-up in 1989, have this year’s morning-line favorite, Orb.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — With an advertisement in a Pittsburgh newspaper — “a willing boy wishes work” — Henry Phipps Jr. entered the world of 19th-century industry and set out on a career that epitomized the American dream.

headline: Keeping Troubled Youth Near
abstract: New York City’s juvenile delinquents used to be sent upstate to be incarcerated, but a new program is offering rehabilitation closer to home.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s juvenile delinquents used to be sent upstate to be incarcerated, but a new program is offering rehabilitation closer to home.

headline: Google’s Palestinian Home Page Recognizes ‘Palestine’
abstract: Five months after the United Nations General Assembly voted to upgrade Palestine’s status to a nonmember observer state, Google has followed suit.
lead_paragraph: Five months after the United Nations General Assembly voted to upgrade Palestine’s status to a nonmember observer state, Google has followed suit, labeling its local home page “Palestine” instead of the “Palestinian territories.” The Palestine Liberation Organization and the Palestinian Authority began using “State of Palestine” on official documents immediately after the Nov. 29 United Nations vote, and urged international organizations to do the same. A Google spokesman said Friday that the company was making the change “across all our products.” Sabri Saadat, a spokesman for President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, called the move a step in the right direction, but Yigal Palmor, a spokesman for Israel’s Foreign Ministry, voiced displeasure. “It has no diplomatic or political significance,” Mr. Palmor told an Israeli news Web site on Friday. “Precisely because Google is not the U.N. or any international diplomatic institution, this begs the question of whether there is room for any political stance on controversial issues.”

headline: Path From ‘Social Butterfly’ to Boston Suspect’s Widow
abstract: Friends and relatives of Katherine Russell, the widow of one of the suspects in the Boston bombing, are stunned at the turn her life has taken.
lead_paragraph: When Katherine Russell arrived as a freshman at Suffolk University just over five years ago, she seemed to bond so well with her new roommates in their lively dorm opposite Boston Common that one classmate likened them to sitcom characters. “They reminded me of the show ‘Sex and the City,’ ” he recalled. “Two of them were free-spirited, one was materialistic and Katherine was the social butterfly.”

headline: Another Chance for Mone’t
abstract: A centerpiece of an overhaul of the juvenile justice system gives New York City’s young delinquents, like Mone’t, 17, local options for rehabilitation.
lead_paragraph: The end of the road is a yellow brick house in East New York, Brooklyn, that was once a rectory. Mone’t arrived there on Dec. 28 with a bad attitude and four years of baggage.

headline: As Nets and Bulls Go the Distance, the First Round Feels Like the 15th
abstract: The series has morphed into a taut and tense prizefight between two like-minded opponents who never lost faith in their ability to beat each other up.
lead_paragraph: The Nets’ first-round series against the Chicago Bulls will end exactly two weeks after it began, at Barclays Center on Saturday night, after seven games that twisted and stretched and tested the teams in ways they probably never could have imagined.

headline: Braves’ Bullpen Falters, and Mets Take Advantage
abstract: The Mets scored four runs off one of the best bullpens in the National League, including a game-tying homer in the ninth, to escape the Braves.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Mets roughed up the National League’s best bullpen. They handled the league’s best hitter in a key situation, and they beat the best team in the East. So it took Manager Terry Collins no time at all when asked if this was the Mets’ best win of the season.

headline: Out, but Not About That
abstract: Corey Johnson, who plans to run for the New York City Council, came out 13 years ago but has another disclosure to make: He’s H.I.V. positive.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen years ago, Corey Johnson, then an 18-year-old high school student in Middleton, Mass., the son of a truck driver and a cafeteria worker, came out about his homosexuality, and it was no small thing. The captain of his football team, Mr. Johnson also wrestled and played lacrosse and baseball. Not long after his disclosure, he was asked to speak at the Millennium March for Equality in Washington. He became the subject of a  column by Robert Lipsyte in The New York Times, which, to Mr. Johnson’s great surprise, ran on the paper’s front page on a Sunday. A certain celebrity quickly attended him.

headline: A Roller-Coaster Game Mirrors a Tough Season
abstract: The Celtics never led and scored only 47 points through the first three quarters, yet they still nearly managed to steal Game 6 against the Knicks with a scintillating late run.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — They played “Don’t Stop Believin’ ” before the game, perhaps a prophetic tune for the Celtics. But as it was for “The Sopranos” six years ago, the song proved to be endgame music for the Celtics on Friday night.

headline: Game 6: Knicks vs. Celtics Replay
abstract: After blowing most of a 26-point lead, the Knicks stopped the Celtics’ comeback attempt to advance to the Eastern Conference semifinals.
lead_paragraph: After blowing most of a 26-point lead, the Knicks stopped the Celtics’ comeback attempt to advance to the Eastern Conference semifinals.

headline: City Hall Pushed Noted Women to Sign Letter Supporting Candidate for Chancellor
abstract: Officials privately advanced the argument that opposition to Cathleen P. Black, the candidate, was grounded in sexism.
lead_paragraph: The idea was simple: a letter signed by some of the country’s most prominent women endorsing Cathleen P. Black, chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, to lead New York City’s schools.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Showtime) SALMON FISHING IN THE YEMEN (2012) The director Lasse Hallstrom transforms Paul Torday’s absurdist political satire — the tale of a visionary sheik (Amr Waked, above left, with Ewan McGregor) with unlimited financial resources intent on creating a recreational paradise for fishermen in a Middle Eastern desert — into a whimsical romantic comedy. Mr. Hallstrom “is a shrewd commercial alchemist with a soft heart,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, and the result “is the cinematic equivalent of turning salt into sugar.” Mr. McGregor plays Dr. Alfred Jones, a British fisheries expert who is approached to evaluate the feasibility of the concept, which would involve either importing 10,000 North Atlantic salmon to Yemen from Britain, or using farmed salmon. Kristin Scott Thomas is Patricia Maxwell, the press secretary for the British prime minister, who seizes on the opportunity to distract the public from political conflicts and score points for her boss. And Emily Blunt is Harriet, the sheik’s assistant, and the unspoken object of Fred’s affection, whose soldier boyfriend (Tom Mison) has gone missing in action. “Whether Harriet and Fred will get together is a question that hovers over the movie,” Mr. Holden said. “The appeal of the film depends on the charm of Mr. McGregor and Ms. Blunt, whose polite but discreetly charged connection is the story’s emotional center.” And although the sheik is the target of an assassination plot by Islamic extremists, “the biggest moment of suspense has nothing to do with international politics or terrorism,” Mr. Holden said. “It comes when those farmed salmon are finally released into the waters of their new home. Will they mill around in confusion or will they jump? It is enough to say that for this moment to be the film’s dramatic turning point is an indication of its softness.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 4

As it does, the pressure builds on Europe’s most powerful leader, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, and her economic team to find a way to get the Continent growing again. But this puts Ms. Merkel in a bind, as she has to answer to German voters in September when the country holds parliamentary elections. While the European economy may be deteriorating at an alarming rate, the electorate here is still enamored of her as the Iron Chancellor, advocating the austerity policies that are rapidly falling into disfavor elsewhere, among economists as well as the public. Nicholas Kulish reports from Berlin.

Trevor looks like a heavy, swollen water barrel balanced precariously on four skinny legs and swings his head around to stare at you when you say hello. Whether curled up on a bale of hay or standing between barn rows, Trevor surveys all he sees through his raccoon-masked face with weird horizontal eyes that would seem more appropriate in a science fiction movie. lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The official Chinese news media responded in a low-key, if apparently approving, fashion to a shift by the Australian government toward a more conciliatory strategic approach to China, judging by reactions over the weekend.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Xavier Niel is not what you would expect in a billionaire.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, arrived in Beijing on Sunday seeking support from Chinese leaders, days before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is to make a visit of his own, although Israeli officials have said there are no plans for a meeting between them.

headline: Naive Fiscal Cynicism
abstract: What governments don’t actually do.
lead_paragraph: Expansionary austerity has been refuted and even the IMF sayis that short-run multipliers are big. The 90 percent red line on debt was an artifact of fuzzy math. The bond vigilantes remain invisible, and the confidence fairy refuses to make an appearance. Clearly, austerian economics has imploded (and some prominent austerians seem to be personally imploding too).

headline: Talking With My Daughter About My Service in Iraq
abstract: The first time my daughter Shylah asked me about being a soldier in Iraq, she was 6 years old. Her class had been studying the war.
lead_paragraph: “Mom, what did you see over there? What was it like? Did you have a gun? Did you kill anyone?”

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.
lead_paragraph: Caravan magazine digs deep in a profile of the attorney general of India, the federal government’s top law officer, the “Inside Man.” It’s an important piece and one that’s long overdue, as the story correctly and articulately points out: “In an era when fortunes can be made and lost on the whims of government policy (or the manipulation thereof), billions of rupees hinge on the decisions of the Supreme Court, which has become the ultimate arbiter in innumerable disputes between corporates and the state. Today, the country’s top lawyers, who charge upwards of Rs. 10 lakh (Rs 1 million) for a single court appearance, are some of the capital’s most powerful figures, Delhi’s closest equivalent to the Wall Street investment bankers that Tom Wolfe once dubbed ‘masters of the universe’.”

headline: Syria Blames Israel for Fiery Attack in Damascus

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government publicly condemned Israel for a powerful air assault on military targets near Damascus early Sunday, saying it “opened the door to all possibilities,” as fear spread throughout the region that the country’s civil war could expand beyond its borders.

headline: The Board of Education Lives On, if Only to Be Sued
abstract: Many lawyers have discovered that if you have a legal complaint against the city’s school system, you have to sue the department or, better yet, the Board of Education, which many New Yorkers thought was abolished.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 9, 2003, Jamie Perez was slashed by two fellow students at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx. He recovered, and his mother, Nancy Torres, sued the City of New York for negligence, claiming lax security.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: NOON (13) UN BALLO IN MASCHERA Marcelo Álvarez, above with Kathleen Kim, performs the role of the ill-fated King Gustavo III; Dmitri Hvorostovsky is his best friend and eventual rival, Count Anckarstrom; and Sondra Radvanovsky is Amelia, Anckarstrom’s wife and the object of the king’s secret passion, in this Metropolitan Opera production of Verdi’s drama about political intrigue and thwarted romance. “The most interesting aspect of David Alden’s disappointing, metaphor-laden new production,” Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times of this “Great Performances at the Met” presentation, “is that he uses an early-20th-century setting and film noir imagery to emphasize not just the work’s darkness but also its strangeness.” Still, he said, Ms. Radvanovsky was “splendid,” and Mr. Hvorostovsky sang “with his trademark dark sound and supple phrasing, which poignantly brought to life this suffering husband’s love.”

headline: Neighbors Resist a Plan to Clean a Toxic Canal
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency’s $500 million proposal to clean the Gowanus Canal has worried Brooklyn residents about the effects on the air and a beloved swimming pool.
lead_paragraph: Almost everybody wants the Gowanus Canal cleansed of its toxic gunk.

headline: A New Way to Care for Young Brains
abstract: Doctors are pleased that the dangers of concussions are receiving more attention, but they often see overreactions from parents alarmed by high-profile cases.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The drumbeat of alarming stories linking concussions among football players and other athletes to brain disease has led to a new and mushrooming American phenomenon: the specialized youth sports concussion clinic, which one day may be as common as a mall at the edge of town.

headline: Anecdotal Evidence Provides Clues to Youth Concussions
keywords: ['Concussions', 'Sports Injuries', 'Women and Girls', 'Youth', 'Children and Childhood', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: The staff members at youth sports concussion clinics are a valuable repository of information.
lead_paragraph: Youth sports concussion clinics operate at the center of America’s heightened awareness and increasing worry about concussions among young athletes. Listening to the hundreds of stories of how concussions have occurred, examining patients and monitoring their recoveries, the doctors and staff members are a repository of anecdotal and medical concussion information.

headline: Flubbing a Baseline Test on Purpose Is Often Futile

lead_paragraph: In 2011, quarterback Peyton Manning suggested he purposely flubbed a preseason neurocognitive baseline test to make the results of any postconcussion test look better, which might have improved his chances of returning to play sooner.

headline: Obama Delivers Message of Optimism to Class of ’13
abstract: In an address at Ohio State, the president said that government critics “gum up the works” and that he was optimistic about young people’s opportunities.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Acknowledging that commencement addresses are no place for partisanship, President Obama nonetheless skirted close to that political line on Sunday, telling graduates at Ohio State University to ignore antigovernment voices that “gum up the works” and instead aspire to be citizens who value both individual rights and community responsibilities.

headline: Slovenia Falls From Economic Grace, Struggling to Avert a Bailout

After transforming a home-improvement chain, Merkur, into a regional giant, he drew on easy credit from state-run banks to help orchestrate a €400 million management buyout of the company, the largest in the country’s history.

headline: On the Town: Glimpses of Americana, Through the Young
abstract: New York City Ballet performed an all-Jerome Robbins program, including “Interplay,” “Fancy Free” and “I’m Old-Fashioned,” on Friday at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Robbins’s first two dances mapped out his creative life. After choreographing “Fancy Free,” a 1944 hit about three sailors on shore leave, he was clearly headed down the golden path of musical-theater. But a year later he created the playful “Interplay,” which integrated classical steps with a jazzy, American style of moving. This showed his range; Robbins’s other foot belonged in ballet.

They had spent four days crawling through the wreckage of Rana Plaza, tons of concrete and steel pressing down, saving hundreds of people. Now only the dead remained. Except for a lone woman, a garment worker.

lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Many of the questions at Berkshire Hathaway‘s annual shareholder meeting here dwelled on what life after Warren E. Buffett will look like.

abstract: The federal budget cuts known as sequestration are being felt across the country, with some programs coping, some struggling and others closing their doors.
lead_paragraph: Facing the task of cutting 142 children from the Head Start program in Colorado Springs this fall, the teachers and administrators came up with a creative response: Have the children decorate empty chairs, then sell them for $500 apiece to stave off the worst of the across-the-board federal cuts heading their way. So far, in a month, their “Fill a Seat” fund-raiser has filled just two slots in the program.

lead_paragraph: “This is sort of like three children being let loose at NASA,” David Crosby said. “But boy, is it fun.” With his longtime colleagues Graham Nash and Stephen Stills, Mr. Crosby was the most voluble participant in an outlandish musical experiment at Rose Hall at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Friday evening: the conjoining of Crosby, Stills and Nash with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. Talk about worlds colliding.

headline: Up Two, Down Two, Isles Tie It and Lose

lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Pittsburgh Penguins forward Chris Kunitz is exceptionally glad that Sidney Crosby is back on the ice. So are his teammates, who escaped with a win Sunday over the pesky Islanders.

headline: Evoking a Time and Place for Daring Experiments
abstract: Renée Fleming focused on early modern Vienna in the last of her Perspectives concerts at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: From the end of the 19th century through the first decades of the 20th century Vienna was a hotbed of cultural, social and political ferment. The soprano Renée Fleming chose this era as the focus of the final program in her Perspectives series this season at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

headline: An Intentional Spectacle
abstract: Three institutions collectively mounted John Cage’s elaborate “HPSCHD” in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: “I hate the harpsichord, it reminds me of a sewing machine,” the composer John Cage is reported to have said. Yet a commission from Antoinette Vischer, a Swiss harpsichordist who specialized in modern music, prompted Cage to conceive one of his most audacious creations: “HPSCHD,” fashioned in collaboration with another composer, Lejaren Hiller.

headline: Accessories No Longer Tethered to Apple
abstract: Manufacturers are gravitating toward wireless connections for Apple’s products, which is helping the market for competitors’ mobile devices.
lead_paragraph: For years, Apple’s clout in the electronics world could be gauged by how easy it was to bump into devices tailor-made for a connection to an iPhone or iPod.

lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Return to the Nine-Hole Round
abstract: Golf organizations have formed a partnership to promote playing nine holes for players not interested in the time it takes an amateur to get through 18 holes.
lead_paragraph: Less than 30 years ago, nearly half of the golf courses in America had nine holes. There was no stigma to that number. The nine-hole golf round was as common as a slice off the first tee.

headline: Foreign Bride as a Fetish and a Person
abstract: “Seeking Asian Female” on PBS explores the mystique of Chinese women for some Western men.
lead_paragraph: Steven is a 60-year-old parking-garage attendant who lives in a small apartment above a store in the Northern California suburbs. He’s white, which is significant because he has what is politely known as an Asian fetish and popularly known as yellow fever. “They’re all so beautiful,” he says, looking at a display of thumbnail images of prospective Asian brides.

headline: Honoring Songbook’s Dean
abstract: What would the composer Jerome Kern have made of Woodstock? That question was asked but not answered on Saturday evening at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: What would the composer Jerome Kern have made of Woodstock? That question was asked but not answered on Saturday evening at the 92nd Street Y by Deborah Grace Winer, the artistic director of the venerable Lyrics and Lyricists series, in the opening-night concert of its season’s second-to-last program.

headline: With Pettitte Missing His Touch, Yankees Fall to Athletics
abstract: Starter Andy Pettitte allowed four walks, his highest total since 2010, and Josh Donaldson’s home run against reliever Boone Logan gave the A’s a victory.
lead_paragraph: After more than 18 seasons in the major leagues, Yankees starter Andy Pettitte knows what the ball is supposed to feel like once it leaves his hand. There is a certain subtlety that makes it difficult for him to explain the feeling, but he knows by touch. He knows almost immediately after he throws a pitch how it will arrive at home plate without even seeing it land in the catcher’s mitt.

headline: On Script and Off, Giving Voice to the Yankees
abstract: Paul Olden, the team’s public-address announcer since 2009, says he has “free rein pretty much to change stuff the way I would say it.”
lead_paragraph: The day after the Boston Marathon bombings, the New York Yankees honored the fallen in a pregame ceremony at their stadium in the Bronx. The task of leading the fans in this tribute went to Paul Olden, the team’s public-address announcer. He felt something was missing, though.

headline: Mail Letters
abstract: In which I explain the Monday theme.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Warning: vowel run. But not the kind you’re thinking of.

headline: A Fund-Raiser’s Finale
abstract: Reynold Levy, the president of Lincoln Center and a glutton for “the ask,” hopes to raise more than $8 million for its spring gala.
lead_paragraph: There are many artists at Lincoln Center. Reynold Levy, president of the performing arts center, likes to think of himself as one of them. His art is putting the arm on donors, and he is acknowledged to be one of the very best nudges in New York. “I’ve asked everyone for money,” Mr. Levy said in an interview. “They hide behind pillars when they see me.”

headline: Fighting Words Against Big Data
abstract: The computer scientist Jaron Lanier provides insights on technology in his new book, “Who Owns the Future?”
lead_paragraph: As its title indicates, Jaron Lanier’s new tech manifesto asks, “Who owns the future?” But for many of those who will be captivated by Mr. Lanier’s daringly original insights, another question comes first: Who is Jaron Lanier? He is a mega-wizard in futurist circles. He is the father of virtual reality in the gaudy, reputation-burnishing way that Michael Jackson was the king of pop. Mr. Lanier would undoubtedly be more of a household name if he were not a large, dreadlocked, anything but telegenic figure with facial hair called “mossy” in a 2011 profile in The New Yorker.

headline: A Dancing Queen Extends Her Reign
abstract: Agnetha Faltskog of Abba is back with a new album, her first record of new material since 1987.
lead_paragraph: Dance-floor hits like “Waterloo,” “S.O.S.” and “Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight)” hardly seem to be any less ubiquitous in the more than 30 years since they were first recorded by Abba, the best-selling Swedish pop quartet. But if its music is everywhere, its band mates are not: in particular, it’s been almost a decade since listeners last heard from Agnetha Faltskog, the singer whose distinctive voice helped give Abba its carefree Scandinavian charm.

headline: TED Teams Up With PBS on Ideas for Education
abstract: If it is successful, the show could become a template for future joint projects.
lead_paragraph: Television viewers — even those who watch the more sober-minded PBS — are generally not keen on sitting through long speeches. But TED, the nonprofit group that sponsors conferences on ideas, thinks it has found a way to bring its signature 18-minute talks to a TV audience that may not have found them on the Web or through mobile apps.

abstract: Winning numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Mets’ Fielding Miscues Lead to Loss to Braves
abstract: The Mets were not charged with an error, but a series of botched plays helped Atlanta rally for a win.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Mets wrestled with themselves all afternoon Sunday. Wild pitches, misplayed balls, bad swings and walks ruined them. The team that looked spectacularly poised Friday night in a dramatic victory over Atlanta lost to the Braves, 9-4, at Turner Field.

headline: Compensation Compared
abstract: The pay of top media company chief executives compared with other industries.
lead_paragraph: The pay of top media company chief executives compared with other industries.

headline: Wrongfully Convicted Often Find Their Record, Unexpunged, Haunts Them
abstract: Across much of the country, sealing or clearing a criminal record after a wrongful conviction is a tangled and expensive process, advocates and former prisoners say.
lead_paragraph: In Wisconsin, Audrey Edmunds served 11 years in prison in the shaking death of an infant girl for whom she had been baby-sitting. In 2008, a mountain of new medical evidence cast so much doubt on the case that a higher court overturned her conviction and set her free. Leaving prison, Ms. Edmunds hoped that would be the end of it.

headline: George Osborne’s Fear of Ghosts
abstract: The case for austerity is now a complete muddle.
lead_paragraph: Truly, we live in bizarro world. The stern taskmasters of the IMF are coming to Britain, to demand that the government live it up and spend more; the government, defiantly, will insist on continuing to impose suffering.

headline: Kierkegaard’s ‘Antigone’
abstract: The Danish philosopher’s revisionist take on an ancient Greek tragedy grappled with the way acts of love, guilt and redemption are intertwined.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most central theme in Soren Kierkegaard’s religious thought is the doctrine of original sin: the idea that we share in some essential human guilt simply by being born. But guilt is an important concept also in Kierkegaard’s secular writings. He thought that the modern era was defined by its concept of guilt. headline: The Ballot Against the Bullet
abstract: Given all the recent pre-election violence in Pakistan, any voter who even dares make it to the polls on Saturday will be casting a vote against the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — At the start of last week I was in the nation’s capital, Islamabad, which adjoins the country’s most populous and most powerful province, Punjab. Almost all the political talk there was about Punjab, the home province of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, where he and his Pakistan Muslim League-N (P.M.L.-N) have been holding rallies, urging supporters to vote them into power. Most analysts believe that is exactly what will happen, even though Sharif won’t have the easy ride that he might once have expected: The cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan and his Pakistan Tehrik-e-Insaf (P.T.I.) party have strong support in Punjab, and Khan has been traveling the length and breadth of the province to prove the pundits wrong. This is as it should be in a democracy the week before an election.

headline: In a Spiritual Outpouring, a Return to the Holy Land

headline: Video: Bill Cunningham On the Street, Hats Off
abstract: At the Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon of the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, a favorite hat shape was the satellite dish, defying gravity on the side of the head.
lead_paragraph: Louisville has its Kentucky Derby. England has its Royal Ascot. And New York has its Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon of the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. The luncheon drew more than 1,200 elaborately hatted guests, and all of the garden flowers were in tiptop bloom. A favorite hat shape was the satellite dish, defying gravity on the side of the head — a look that in the late ’30s was called the profile brim. The most amusing headdress was one of veiling that covered the face and had an appliquéd eye and lips, evoking a Dadaist mood. The most interesting fashion silhouettes were the revival of Dior’s New Look of 1947 and the Chanel nipped waists, full skirts and flyaway boleros.

headline: Harper Lee Sues Agent Over Copyright on ‘Mockingbird’
abstract: The complaint alleges that the agent “engaged in a scheme to dupe’' the author into assigning the copyright to his company.
lead_paragraph: Harper Lee, who skillfully chronicled courtroom drama in “To Kill a Mockingbird,” is tangled in a legal drama of her own. Ms. Lee, 87, filed a lawsuit last week accusing her literary agent, Samuel Pinkus, of improperly collecting royalties from “Mockingbird” since 2007. According to the complaint, filed in federal court in New York, Mr. Pinkus “engaged in a scheme to dupe Harper Lee, then 80 years old with declining hearing and eyesight,” into assigning the book’s copyright to his company. Ms. Lee does not recall signing the document or discussing it with Mr. Pinkus, the complaint said.
