headline: Illustrator Nigel Peake Brings His Mysterious World to Colette
abstract: In 26 meticulous pen drawings on view at the Paris boutique, the Irish artist tells the story of a young boy who is afraid of the dark.
lead_paragraph: Nigel Peake’s rural Irish roots were the muse for his 2011 book of drawings, “In the Wilds.” This year, the artist moved to Lausanne, the Swiss city on the shores of Lake Geneva, to teach architecture. The new setting influenced a series of 26 pen drawings that will be on view for a month starting today at the Paris boutique Colette. Peake’s “story of drawings,” as he calls it, tells the tale of a young boy who is afraid of the dark and takes solace in building boats. As with his other work, there is no visible human presence—the boy is only implied through images that hint at a larger narrative. For those who can’t make it to Paris to see the originals, Peake has self-published a limited-edition compilation of the images, called “In the Dark.”

headline: Kindness Amid the Slaughter

He and his fellow upstaters had not yet “seen the elephant” – the soldiers’ expression for experiencing combat – and he was reassured to see that they were supported by more veteran units, including the Second Massachusetts and the 27th Indiana. He noted the striking contrast between those units’ faded, bullet-ridden battle flags and the crisp, spotless condition of his regiment’s colors.

abstract: My family has to evacuate our home, for the second time in six months, because of a giant condominium tower going up next door.
lead_paragraph: AT 10 p.m. Friday, my wife, my dog and I will be forced to evacuate our home because the boom of a construction crane atop a luxury condominium tower going up next door might possibly destroy our building. It won’t be the first time: Last October, we had to evacuate for six days after Hurricane Sandy left the boom dangling precariously over West 57th Street, a situation that drew headlines worldwide. But this time, we’re being forced out merely because the city government wants to save the developer of the tower money and time.

headline: New Rules Proposed for Tanning Beds
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday proposed new regulations for tanning beds that would require their makers to affix labels warning young people not to use them.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday proposed new regulations for tanning beds that would require their makers to affix labels warning young people not to use them. Nearly 28 million Americans use tanning beds every year, according to the American Academy of Dermatology. The agency said the proposal was its first step toward potentially restricting access to the beds altogether for minors. Manufacturers would have to apply to the F.D.A. to get approval for their tanning bed products before selling them, “The science is clear,” said Dr. Mary Maloney, vice president of regulator policy at American Academy of Dermatology. “The risk of developing melanoma increases by 75 percent for individuals who’ve been exposed to ultraviolet radiation from indoor tanning.”

headline: California: Court Upholds Ban on Marijuana Dispensaries
abstract: The California Supreme Court on Monday upheld the right of local governments to ban medical marijuana dispensaries.
lead_paragraph: The California Supreme Court on Monday upheld the right of local governments to ban medical marijuana dispensaries. As dispensaries have proliferated since 1996, when California became the first state to allow medical marijuana, many municipalities across the state have used zoning laws to prohibits dispensaries from opening inside city limits. Patients and dispensary owners have argued that these local laws violate the state medical marijuana statutes by reducing patients’ access to the drug. But the court unanimously upheld a ban in the City of Riverside, paving the way for more municipalities to prohibit marijuana dispensaries.

headline: Germany: Ex-Nazi With Link to Auschwitz Is Arrested
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The authorities arrested a 93-year-old former Nazi soldier on Monday, saying they had evidence that he had worked as a guard at Auschwitz and was complicit in murders there.
lead_paragraph: German authorities on Monday arrested a 93-year-old former Nazi soldier, saying that they had “compelling evidence” that he had worked as a guard at the Auschwitz concentration camp and was complicit in murders there. The man, Hans Lipschis, whose name is fourth on the Simon Wiesenthal Center’s list of “most wanted Nazi war criminals,” was taken into custody at his home in the southern German state of Baden-Württemberg, according to Claudia Krauth, a spokeswoman for the prosecutor’s office there. Mr. Lipschis, who emigrated to the United States after the war but was deported in 1983 after an investigation by the Office of Special Investigations brought his Nazi past to light, admitted to the German newspaper Die Welt last month that he had served with a Nazi SS unit at Auschwitz but only as a cook. Charges have not yet been filed, Ms. Krauth said, adding that prosecutors are still investigating Mr. Lipschis’s role at the camp. They believe he worked there from 1941 to 1945.

headline: Torture Against Terrorism
abstract: The success of Mauritania’s counterterrorism campaign means the defeat of efforts to curb torture.
lead_paragraph: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania — Outside our tent on a beach about 100 miles north of the capital, the Atlantic Ocean was glittering under the midday sun and a fresh tuna was searing on a grill. Inside, the conversation with my Mauritanian friends turned to torture and detention. One described how he’d been chained up naked for weeks; another talked about his brother who had a pin inserted under his fingernails. Both victims had been arrested during a crackdown on political dissidents in 2003, in the twilight of the 21-year dictatorship of Maaouya Sid’Ahmed Ould Taya.

headline: A Wunderkind Artist Summons a Barely Bygone New York
abstract: The rising star Lucien Smith evokes Giuliani-era New York—so recent, and yet, so long ago—with a new exhibition and a film made with Glenn O’Brien.
lead_paragraph: He’s just 24, but Lucien Smith has arrived. In the past two years the assemblage artist, known for canvases that mix paint with found objects, has shown in prestigious galleries from L.A. to Milan, including Half Gallery, OHWOW and Brand New. Smith’s new solo show at the Suzanne Geiss Company, “A Clean Sweep,” which opens tomorrow, is an homage to Giuliani-era New York in three parts. The first is a group of free-standing brooms, “collected” off New York City streets by Smith and his friends, that are meant to signify the city’s gentrification. The second is a series of Polaroid grids featuring relics of the city’s urban landscape, including trash cans, crosswalks and playground signs. The third is a film (seen here) made in collaboration with a New York institution: Glenn O’Brien.

headline: Why I Would Rather Pay My Employees Too Much
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Paid Time Off', 'Small Business', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Am I compromising my own financial future for the sake of starry-eyed idealism? Would my approach work in your business?

I was surprised by the number of comments, but I guess that any discussion of pay is going to push someone’s button. That said, I’d like to respond to a couple of points that were raised and also make a few new ones.

headline: How to Tell Google Now to Stop Peeking
abstract: The Google Now app anticipates what information you might want and puts it on your phone screen before you ask for it, which can seem wonderfully prescient or intrusively creepy, but there is an easy adjustment if you don’t like the feeling that Google is watching your every move.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that every new phone was heralded as “the iPhone killer.” Now the preoccupation is with “the Siri killer,” the app that will replace the sometimes frustrating Siri personal assistant on the iPhone.

headline: In the N.B.A., Celebrate at Your Own Risk
abstract: N.B.A. players mimic each others’ celebrations and wander over the line between respect and disrespect.
lead_paragraph: Celebrations in the N.B.A. exist at the margins. They might not be as rigorously scrutinized as touchdown dances in the N.F.L., but there are consequences. When LeBron James stared down Jason Terry after knocking him to the floor on an alley-oop, he received a technical foul. When Kevin Durant topped off a slam in transition with a throat slash, the league fined him $25,000. But their transgressive nature is what gives these gestures their power. This goes double when they’re taken from an opponent, as when the Knicks’ Iman Shumpert stole Jason Terry’s flight plan and broke out Terry’s signature “JET” celebration after draining a 3-pointer in the Knicks’ Game 6 win over the Celtics.

headline: Sweet and Spicy or Assertive Wines With Eggplant
abstract: Eggplant’s tendency toward bitterness makes it a difficult pairing.
lead_paragraph: Eggplant is often described as a polarizing food, one that people either love or hate. I’m the counterexample. I like it well enough, unless it’s overcooked, which emphasizes the mushy texture and slight bitterness that seem to repel so many. That tendency toward bitterness, especially when combined with the spinach in Mary McCartney’s dish of eggplant wraps, makes it a difficult pairing. I think of reds first, but nothing too tannic, which would clash with the bitterness. The sweet and spicy fruit of a lighter-weight zinfandel would work well. So might a lively Sicilian red like a nero d’Avola or a cerasuolo di Vittoria. Assertive whites would work well, too, like a sauvignon blanc, even a flamboyantly styled example, or a good, dry chenin blanc, like a Vouvray or Savennières.

headline: The Garden He Left Behind
abstract: The author remembers her late father’s superior garlic, grown in the upper Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: My dad John and I started growing garlic about 20 years ago. I purchased my planting stock at a harvest festival, John through mail order. Eventually I came to admit his variety was much nicer than ours for both marketing and culinary purposes. He’d always announce sometime in April that it was up and about a foot high. Even though dad lived south of us in the upper Hudson Valley, my husband Jim and I assumed he was just embellishing, and we’d smirk to each other. He was always positive and optimistic, whether gardening, dealing with three different cancer episodes or rooting for Philadelphia sports teams. I finally grew enough garlic from his stock to completely replace my varieties. And yes, it is quick to emerge in the spring, gaining good height early. This year’s is already up. It looks good — a summer harbinger of the grilling season ahead.

headline: In Store | Amanda Hearst’s Ethical Fashion Pop-Up
abstract: The editor and activist has made it her mission to prove that sustainable can be stylish with the ongoing retail series Maison de Mode.
lead_paragraph: “I think some people still don’t really know what ethical fashion is,” Amanda Hearst says. The editor and activist, a contributor to Town and Country and a former Marie Claire columnist, has for several years sought to spread the word by promoting (and wearing) labels that use organically grown, recycled and sustainably harvested fabrics and employ artisan collectives in the developing world. When Hearst met the young New York designer Hassan Pierre — whose Way It Should Be and Basic collections use materials ranging from organic cotton jersey to discarded cassette tape — the two discovered a shared wish to create a retail platform for the movement’s best offerings. The resulting collaboration is Maison de Mode, a series of ethical fashion pop-up boutiques whose second event happens this weekend at the Hole Gallery as part of the Frieze Art Fair.

headline: Tradition Performed With a Twist
abstract: Sonia M’barek, a Tunisian vocalist, brought the malouf style of singing to her show at a festival in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: At the center of Sonia M’barek’s concert on Friday night at the French Institute Alliance Française in Manhattan was a song she performed a cappella: “Al Kalimat” (“The Power of Words”), with lyrics by the 20th-century Tunisian poet Mnaouer Smadeh: “Speak up and suffer, even if you die for the sake of the words,” it urged. headline: Marginalia, Added by the Author
abstract: I devoured the details that came from an annotated version of Pamela Colloff’s 28,000-word article.
lead_paragraph: Here at the magazine, you might say we have a thing about marginalia. So perhaps it’s not a surprise that I’m mildly infatuated with Nieman Storyboard’s Annotation Tuesday! (That’s not an unwarranted exclamation mark.) It’s a series produced every other week in which authors answer questions about their reporting and writing, which is obviously cool. (Who doesn’t want to know how a reporter got a witness to talk? Or where that detail about the marigolds came from?) But Annotation Tuesday! serves up the answers in the body of the story itself — kind of like the obsessive highlights and notes I tend to make with my Kindle, but in this case with actual answers.

headline: Yanking Broadband From the Slow Lane
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Most Americans are mired in broadband mediocrity, but Google’s networking initiatives could change that.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost two decades since @Home Network offered perhaps the first broadband plan in the country. It was right after the 1996 Telecommunications Act allowed cable companies to get into the business. Milo Medin, one of @Home’s co-founders, still recalls the price of the pioneering service, offered to residents of Fremont, Calif.: $34.95 a month — $51.85 in today’s money — for a maximum speed of 10 megabits per second. The memory inspires not a little frustration about the Internet’s progress since then: 17 years after @Home plugged in its first customer, the residents of Kansas City pay Time Warner, their local cable company, $46.90 for a 3 Mbps connection and $55.40 for a top speed of 15 Mbps.

headline: Mexico: U.S. Penalizes Drug Traffickers
abstract: The Treasury Department announced sanctions against eight Mexicans on Tuesday whom it identified as the main bosses for the Sinaloa Cartel.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department announced sanctions against eight Mexicans on Tuesday whom it identified as the main bosses for the Sinaloa Cartel just south of Arizona and Mexicali, Calif. A joint investigation including the Drug Enforcement Agency and United States Customs and Border Protection identified the cartel leaders, and law enforcement officials said they expected additional penalties to follow, including the freezing of assets and bank accounts. “We rely on these types of enforcement actions to really lower the hammer,” said Adam Szubin, director of the Office of Foreign Assets Control at the Treasury Department. He added, “These are some pretty serious players.” Several other Sinaloa operatives have already been penalized, including Joaquin Guzmán, also known as El Chapo, the cartel’s leader.

headline: Russia: F.B.I. Director in Moscow to Discuss Boston Bombings
abstract: The F.B.I. director Robert S. Mueller III met with Russian officials in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the  the Boston bombings, according to American officials.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. director Robert S. Mueller III met with Russian law enforcement and intelligence officials in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the bureau’s investigation of the Boston Marathon bombings, according to American officials. The investigation has focused in part on intelligence the Russian government provided the F.B.I. in 2011 that one of the bombing suspects was a Muslim extremist. Since the attacks, President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have pledged to work closely together as law enforcement officials in both countries have tried to determine how they could have thwarted the attacks. In 2011, the F.B.I. investigated the Russian warning about one of the suspects, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, but ultimately told the Russians that it had not found any information to back their assertions. In response to several follow-up requests from the F.B.I., the Russians declined to provide more information about the intelligence. In recent weeks, however, the Russians have provided F.B.I. agents with that additional information.

Karen and Jim Reynolds will receive 80 percent of the reward. Mr. Dorner tied them up and stole their car, after they found him hiding in their Big Bear Lake condominium. They freed themselves and called the police. He killed himself hours later, surrounded by law enforcement officers. Daniel McGowan, who reported seeing Mr. Dorner’s burning truck, will receive 15 percent of the reward. Lee McDaniel, who spotted Mr. Dorner and his truck in Corona, Calif., will receive 5 percent.

There, the German artist Tobias Rehberger has constructed Bar Oppenheimer, a facsimile of his favorite Frankfurt watering hole, which he describes as both a sculptural artwork and a utilitarian space. The space, which opens May 10 and will remain open until July 14, dazzles the senses with its salonlike atmosphere, tight dimensions and prismatic black-and-white stripes; it’s also a functional bar where anyone can stop in for a drink during the life of the project.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) DON’T SAY NO UNTIL I FINISH TALKING: THE STORY OF RICHARD D. ZANUCK (2013) Laurent Bouzereau chronicles the life of Richard D. Zanuck (1934-2012), the Oscar-winning producer, through recollections of his childhood on the 20th Century Fox lot as the son of the studio head Darryl F. Zanuck and his wife, the actress Virginia Fox. When Richard had the chance to produce his first film, “Compulsion,” starring Orson Welles, he said his father told him: “You know I had it a lot easier than you will have it. You have to overcome the circumstances of your birth. You carry baggage with you — I am the baggage you carry.” When Darryl Zanuck was installed as chairman of the studio in the 1960s, he asked his son for a list of possible names to be appointed president of the company. Richard, above, submitted a piece of paper that read, simply, “Me.” Films like “The Sound of Music” (1965), “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid” (1969), “M*A*S*H” (1970) and “The French Connection” (1971) followed. But films like “Doctor Dolittle” (1967) and “Hello, Dolly” (1969) resulted in debt, and just before Christmas 1970, Richard was fired by his father. Shortly afterward his father also lost his job. This documentary, with Steven Spielberg as an executive producer, is followed at 9:45 by “Driving Miss Daisy” (1989), the Oscar best picture winner starring Jessica Tandy as a Southern widow and Morgan Freeman as her driver; it was the first movie produced by the Zanuck Company, which Richard and his wife, Lili Fini Zanuck, founded in 1988. “Cocoon” (1985), about a group of elderly people rejuvenated by aliens, follows at 1:15 a.m., and “Compulsion” (1959), Richard Fleischer’s take on the Leopold-Loeb case, at 3:30.

abstract: The Powerocks Tarot is about the same as a stack of credit cards and can charge an iPhone more than half way.
lead_paragraph: Backup batteries usually trumpet their capacity, but capacity results in size: they are sometimes as large as a paperback book. The Powerocks Tarot, though, trumpets its size, because it’s just about the same as a stack of credit cards.

headline: Where Private School Is Not a Privilege
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: How does BRAC, the world’s largest NGO, educate more than 1.25 million of the world’s poorest children for free — and do a better job than government?
lead_paragraph: In the United States, private school is generally a privilege of the rich. But in poorer nations, particularly in Africa and South Asia, families of all social classes send their children to private school. The private schools within reach of the poor, however — usually a single classroom a woman runs in her house — are not a big improvement. But two school systems — Bridge International Academies in Kenya and BRAC in Bangladesh — are offering something different: they are making decent education accessible to the world’s poorest on a giant scale.

headline: How We Keep Our Mentors and Investors on Board
abstract: I didn’t want to go into debt learning business principles so that I could one day hope to build Fashioning Change; I wanted to build Fashioning Change.
lead_paragraph: When I came up with the idea for Fashioning Change, I had no idea what it meant to create a technology start-up. I just knew that I wanted to create something that would rival big fashion brands and e-commerce sites like Amazon, and I knew there was a lot I needed to learn. So I sought out resources to help me.

headline: Who Would Kill a Monk Seal?
abstract: An endangered-species murder mystery.
lead_paragraph: The Hawaiian monk seal has wiry whiskers and the deep, round eyes of an apologetic child. The animals will eat a variety of fish and shellfish, or turn over rocks for eel and octopus, then haul out on the beach and lie there most of the day, digesting. On the south side of Kauai one afternoon, I saw one sneeze in its sleep: its convex body shuddered, then spilled again over the sand the way a raw, boneless chicken breast will settle on a cutting board. The seals can grow to seven feet long and weigh 450 pounds. They are adorable, but also a little gross: the Zach Galifianakises of marine mammals.

headline: If Practice Makes Perfect, Why Don’t Companies Practice More?
abstract: Once a year, someone would say, “Maybe we should do some training.”
lead_paragraph: In his terrific book “Outliers,” Malcolm Gladwell writes about the importance of practice and, specifically, the necessity of completing 10,000 hours of practice in a particular field to become proficient. This makes sense to me. Everything I did before starting in business taught me that practice was essential to achieving success. In school, I had two or three exams each semester, but I went to class every day. Moreover, I had voluminous amounts of homework each night to refine my skills in a particular subject. In football, there were 10 games in a season, but nearly 100 practices.

headline: Objects | Towel Off With Designer Pieces for One Kings Lane
abstract: The online home marketplace commissioned eight limited-edition collections to benefit different charities this summer.
lead_paragraph: Continuing its series of philanthropic collaborations with fashion and interior designers, the online home marketplace One Kings Lane tapped eight talents to create limited-edition prints for its inaugural Designer Series Beach Towels sale. The prints range from kitschy silhouettes of beach gear and diamonds (by Robert Verdi) to floral motifs (by Tracy Reese and Nanette Lepore) to geometric patterns (by Rebecca Minkoff, Celerie Kemble, Steven Alan and Jenni Kayne). Because they’re produced in the same basic colors, they can be mixed and matched easily. Beginning Monday, each designer will take a turn having a sale on OneKingsLane.com, offering several prints each for a few days at a time, with the proceeds benefiting a charity of the maker’s choosing. The first is Tracy Reese’s collection in support of AIDS Fund-New York Community Trust on May 13; the last is Jenni Kayne’s set to benefit Baby 2 Baby on June 18.

headline: California Modern
abstract: A forthcoming show at the Hammer Museum spotlights A. Quincy Jones’s innovations in indoor-outdoor design.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles architect A. Quincy Jones (1913-79) was equally at home designing middle-class housing developments as he was creating luxurious dwellings for celebrities like Gary Cooper and wealthy couples like Walter and Leonore Annenberg. This month, a retrospective examines his extraordinary body of work, which is as influential in its own way as that of better-known West Coast Modernists like Charles Eames and Richard Neutra. The show, at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, spotlights Jones’s innovations in indoor-outdoor design and includes photos and original blueprints of a number of his notable projects, like the colorful, airy Burbank headquarters of Warner Bros. Records (above) — an embodiment of the California dream if ever there was one.

Dr. Fishman is medical director of Manhattan Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation in New York City, an assistant clinical professor at Columbia Medical School and an associate editor of the journal Topics in Geriatric Rehabilitation. Users can upload a photo of their driver’s license or passport and confirm personal historical data about themselves, and Airbnb will compare that information with their Facebook or LinkedIn profiles or Airbnb reviews to verify their backgrounds.

lead_paragraph: In the Great Hall of the world’s soccer minds, there is undoubtedly a special wing for the practitioners from Scotland.

headline: Keeping His Fans Happy With a Half-Century of Classicism and Virtuosity
abstract: Evgeny Kissin, the Russian pianist, played a program covering the half-century from Haydn to Liszt to an overflow crowd at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The popularity of the Russian pianist Evgeny Kissin, who has impressed listeners with his immense gifts since his days as a child prodigy, remains as strong as ever, evident from the capacity audience at his recital on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall. The stage was crowded with extra seating to accommodate listeners, as it occasionally is for a handful of celebrity artists.

headline: For First Time on Record, Black Voting Rate Outpaced Rate for Whites in 2012
abstract: A Census Bureau survey also found that Hispanics and Asians continue to turn out at much lower rates than other groups, and that women turn out at higher rates than men.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The turnout rate of black voters surpassed the rate for whites for the first time on record in 2012, as more black voters went to the polls than in 2008 and fewer whites did, according to a Census Bureau report released Wednesday.

headline: Outsmarting Smartphone Thieves
abstract: Prudence in using your phone can help thwart thieves, and there are ways to protect your information in the event the phone is stolen.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the month since two men violently shoved him to the ground and stole his iPhone 5, Dalton Huckaby has almost completely stopped calling his mother. It usually takes him a full day to text his friends back. Nothing personal, but Mr. Huckaby is just too frightened to take his replacement iPhone out in public.

headline: The Dwindling Deficit
abstract: Not a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Bad news for Dr. Evil fans: the days of a ONE TRILLION DOLLAR deficit are over. In fact, the deficit is falling fast.

headline: A Solitary Soul Whose Pained Voice Heads Into Strange Realms
abstract: The paradox at the core of James Blake’s music became clear at a Terminal 5 show: tools that bring communal joy to a dance floor also carry his songs deeper into solitude.
lead_paragraph: James Blake could easily have been a ballad singer. He showed how with his last encore on Tuesday night at Terminal 5, alone on piano, singing and playing “A Case of You” by Joni Mitchell in his sustained and tremulous voice, rapt in melancholy and need. But Mr. Blake has other ambitions.

headline: Prospect of Iran’s Election Stirs Little Hope This Time Around
abstract: In the run-up to the June 14 presidential election, the enthusiasm of 2009 has been replaced, for now at least, with an indifference bred of fear.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s state television broadcast a live program on Tuesday in which passers-by were placed in a chair and asked what they would do if they were president.

headline: On Stubborn Bulls, Robinson Is a Standout
abstract: Nate Robinson, the Chicago guard, has helped the Bulls create a new offensive identity.
lead_paragraph: Cool. Calm. Collected.

headline: The Shop That Punk Built
abstract: Trash and Vaudeville, around since 1975, remains a fixture in a very different East Village.
lead_paragraph: To anyone passing by Trash and Vaudeville, the rock-and-roll emporium on St. Marks Place, the sinewy peacock with a bleached shag on the outside steps is a familiar sight.

headline: House Hearing Puts Benghazi in Spotlight
abstract: In a show of partisan politics, a House committee held a hearing on the Sept. 11, 2012, terrorist attack on the American compound in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans.
lead_paragraph: In a show of partisan politics, a House committee held a hearing on the Sept. 11, 2012, terrorist attack on the American compound in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans.

headline: The Season for a Program to Be the Star
abstract: The Baltimore and Albany symphonies performed in the first two nights of the Spring for Music festival at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: A simple idea lies behind Spring for Music, the six-day festival at Carnegie Hall that began on Monday with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and continued on Tuesday with the Albany Symphony Orchestra. Ensembles from North America are chosen to participate based not on their institutional prestige but for the originality of their proposed programs.

headline: Icon’s Re-imagination of a ’65 Dodge Pickup
abstract: Dodge’s D200 crew cab pickup was always a solid vehicle, but Icon 4×4 turned one into an imagineered melange of luxury and utility.
lead_paragraph: Restoring classic cars and trucks with modern mechanical guts is nothing new. But trying to get inside the heads of the people who designed those vehicles in order to re-create them without the interference of corporate bean counters is quite something else. That’s where Jonathan Ward’s lively imagination comes into play. He takes a vehicle that has always possessed a charismatic aesthetic and focuses on its details, doing his best to make each one perfect.

headline: Teenager Charged With Homicide by Assault in Referee’s Death
abstract: The 17-year-old Utah soccer goalie accused of punching a referee who later died was charged on Wednesday and could face five years in prison if convicted.
lead_paragraph: The 17-year-old Utah soccer player accused of punching a referee who later died was charged Wednesday with homicide by assault, a charge that could carry a penalty of up to five years in prison if he is convicted.

headline: A Quantum Computer Aces Its Test
abstract: An Amherst computer scientist hired by D-Wave Systems found that one of its computers, said to be using quantum properties, achieved speeds 3,600 times that of a conventional computer in one test. But for theorists, questions remain.
lead_paragraph: The long-sought quantum computer, a machine potentially far ahead of today’s best supercomputers, is almost as hard to define as it is to build. For at least a few particular uses, however, the unusual computer made by D-Wave Systems now seems to be very fast indeed.

headline: From Crashes to Exorcism, His Own Cut
abstract: From “The French Connection” to “The Exorcist,” a new memoir from the director William Friedkin serves up interesting tidbits on his iconoclastic career.
lead_paragraph: When William Friedkin was doing research for his controversial film “Cruising,” he showed up on jockstrap night at the Mine Shaft, the famed gay bar in Manhattan, dressed for the occasion. When he shot the car chase in “The French Connection,” he took few precautions for the safety of drivers and bystanders. And when he prepped for “Rampage,” about a bizarre serial killer, he watched a Rorschach test being given to a man convicted of killing his mother. The killer saw angels and butterflies; Mr. Friedkin saw monsters.

headline: Verizon Wireless Chief Sees Demand for New BlackBerry Phones
abstract: BlackBerry’s phones have been off to a weak start in Canada, the company’s own home turf. But the Z10 touch-screen is getting a warm welcome from Verizon Wireless, the biggest American carrier.
lead_paragraph: BlackBerry’s phones have been off to a weak start in Canada, the home turf of the struggling handset maker. But the new BlackBerrys are getting a warm welcome from Verizon Wireless, the biggest American carrier.

headline: ‘Salinger’ the Documentary, Craftily Promoted With a ‘Psst’
abstract: Harvey Weinstein and Shane Salerno, the producer and director of a documentary about J. D. Salinger, are seeking to build momentum for the film by offering only tantalizing hints about its content.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — J. D. Salinger was good at keeping secrets.

headline: Thompson Picks Up Backing of a Fiscal Repairman
abstract: Richard Ravitch, a former lieutenant governor known for righting wobbly institutions’ finances, has become an adviser to William C. Thompson Jr., who is running for mayor.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, William C. Thompson Jr. has been increasingly unfurling mayoral endorsements from African-American and Hispanic leaders, hoping to solidify his base.

headline: A Shifting Electorate
abstract: The overall turnout rate fell by nearly two percentage points from the 2008 to 2012 election, driven in part by a large drop in the youth vote. Black voters turned out at a higher rate than any other group in 2012, passing whites for the first time on record.
lead_paragraph: The overall turnout rate fell by nearly two percentage points from the 2008 to 2012 election, driven in part by a large drop in the youth vote. Black voters turned out at a higher rate than any other group in 2012, passing whites for the first time on record.

headline: Chesney Tops Album Chart
abstract: Kenny Chesney has his seventh No. 1 album on the Billboard 200 chart as “Life on a Rock” sold 153,000 copies in its first week.
lead_paragraph: Kenny Chesney has his seventh No. 1 album on the Billboard 200 chart as “Life on a Rock” sold 153,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Garth Brooks is the only country act with more No. 1 songs on the chart, with eight. Last week’s No. 1, Michael Bublé’s “To Be Loved,” slipped to No. 2 in its second week, with 96,000 in sales. Justin Timberlake’s “20/20 Experience” holds at No. 3 with 68,000. Fantasia’s “Side Effects of You” was No. 4 in its second week, with 36,000, while “The Heist,” from Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, rose from No. 11 to No. 5, with 35,000.

headline: Iron Man’s Iron Men
abstract: A look at the visual effects process for creating Tony Stark’s suits in “Iron Man 3.”
lead_paragraph: A look at the visual effects process for creating Tony Stark’s suits in “Iron Man 3.”

headline: Manic Duets, Sometimes in a Mist
abstract: The Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet presented the world premiere of “Horizons,” by the Greek choreographer Andonis Foniadakis, as part of its program at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: A man and a woman stand in the mist. Sheepish at first, they pull each other into embraces, the woman wrapping her legs around the man or straddling him. As the precipitation increases, the loose, long hair of both partners gradually dampens. Their clothing turns transparent. Except perhaps for when they stick out their tongues to lap the moisture, the scene might be a racy commercial for shampoo. But it is the end of “Horizons,” by the Greek choreographer Andonis Foniadakis.

headline: It’s Lunchtime: Let’s Dance
abstract: Put that sandwich down, say party organizers, and come boogie for an hour.
lead_paragraph: When lunchtime comes around, Laurie Batista often grabs a salad near the Flatiron ad agency where she works as an executive assistant and eats it at her desk.

headline: A Father’s Passage, Set to New Movements
abstract: The choreographer Jonah Bokaer draws on family history, and his father, for a dance of migration at the French Institute Alliance Française’s World Nomads: Tunisia festival.
lead_paragraph: In February 2011 the choreographer and dancer Jonah Bokaer was to perform a duet, “Replica,” in Carthage, Tunisia. The performance, significantly, would have been Mr. Bokaer’s first visit to his father’s native land.

headline: The Public May Now Comment
abstract: “City Council Meeting,” a theatrical work created by Mallory Catlett, Aaron Landsman and Jim Findlay, uses audience members as councilors and real local issues as focal points.
lead_paragraph: At a little after 7 on a recent evening, the mayor of Bismarck, N.D., banged a gavel to call the city’s board of commissioners to order. They were a motley group — mostly young, clad in jeans and sneakers or boots — and seemed ill at ease. They glanced cluelessly at the agendas before them, checked their name plates as though reminding themselves of their names, and waited for an indication of what to do.

headline: For Ackman, a Day Without Drama
abstract: William A. Ackman, who has been embroiled in controversy with Herbalife and J.C. Penney, focused on his investment in Procter & Gamble on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: For a hedge fund manager who has had his share of drama in recent months, William A. Ackman was notably subdued in a presentation on Wednesday.

headline: Rally Turns Deadly in Southern Afghanistan
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Local officials greatly differed in their accounts of how violence started at an event that was said to have begun as a peaceful pro-government rally.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan – A demonstration that officials said had begun as a peaceful pro-government rally in southern Afghanistan on Wednesday instead turned into a bloody melee, with as many as 10 people killed and 14 wounded as the police fired on demonstrators.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Bangladesh, Italy, Pakistan and Boston.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Bangladesh, Italy, Pakistan and Boston.

headline: Sales at Jonathan Adler, Pollack and Others
abstract: Discounts on fabrics, linens, furniture, lighting and more.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Adler’s warehouse sale, through Sunday, will include furniture, lighting, pottery and home décor at up to 70 percent off (the Whitaker sofa, regularly $2,800, is $1,400; the Charade Wave vase, regularly $250, is $75); 513 Irving Avenue (Eldert Street), Brooklyn, jonathanadler.com.

headline: The Allure of Simplicity in Leather and Wood
abstract: A furniture collection by Roman and Williams for the SoHo design shop Matter.
lead_paragraph: Robin Standefer and Stephen Alesch, of the design firm Roman and Williams, have created interiors for such era-defining buildings as the Ace and Standard hotels in New York. But their new furniture collection doesn’t stray from tradition. The couple have worked with the SoHo design store Matter in creating a chair, a side table, a coffee table and a series of lights, all in alluring woods like walnut, teak and reclaimed oak. Ms. Standefer described the style as American vernacular. “We’re embracing simple structures,” Mr. Alesch added. This leaves room for laserlike attention to details. The chair, shown, with its custom brass hardware and fine leather ($6,500), makes that point. Information: (212) 343-2600 or mattermatters.com.

headline: A Second Roche Bobois for New York
abstract: Forty years after opening its first showroom in Manhattan, the French furniture company is back with a second.
lead_paragraph: Forty years ago, Roche Bobois, the French producer of lush modern furniture, opened its first American showroom on Madison Avenue and 35th Street in New York. Gilles Bonan, the company’s chief executive, said that, after the French, Americans are the most avid Roche Bobois customers, drawn by the furniture’s comfort, quality and “what I call the French flair.”

headline: Boxes Full of Secrets
abstract: Pieces by the French artist Line Vautrin are for sale at 1stdibs.com starting May 15.
lead_paragraph: These days, the jewelry, mirrors and small boxes designed by the French artist Line Vautrin (1913-1997) are much in demand among collectors, commanding thousands. But not so long ago Ms. Vautrin was passé. “Like everything in fashion,” said Benoist Drut, an owner of the New York gallery Maison Gerard, “the trend had changed.”

headline: She Won’t Put Away Her Toys
abstract: Leah Dumigan’s work is included in MoMA’s Destination: Design series, which finally features New York City’s homegrown talent.
lead_paragraph: One day last summer, Leah Dumigan noticed an open call on Twitter urging New York designers to submit their American-made products. The Museum of Modern Art Design Store, which in its international Destination: Design series has presented goods from countries including Finland, Mexico and Japan, was finally getting around, in its 11th iteration, to featuring hometown talent. Ms. Dumigan, a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology’s toy design program, and a new mother, sent in nearly every piece in her line, then added a couple of ideas still percolating but not produced.

headline: Life Among the Dolls
abstract: Four generations of the author’s family contributed to a collection of more than 700 dolls.
lead_paragraph: Four generations of the author’s family contributed to a collection of more than 700 dolls.

headline: Who’s More Vulgar? The Performer or the Crowd?
abstract: Danny Brown, touring with Kitty, came to Irving Plaza on Tuesday in a pairing that captures many of the contradictions of today’s independent hip-hop scene.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through Kitty’s opening set at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night, a pair of young women walked into the room, looked onstage and squealed, turning to each other and talking animatedly about how happy they were to see her.

headline: The 700-Doll Question
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Dolls', 'Elder Care', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Hoarding', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: What to do when your inheritance is more of a burden than a blessing?
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, when my mother was in the throes of dementia, I left New York, bought a home in North Carolina near my brother, and moved her in with me.

headline: Face-off Circle Is Focal Point of Leafs-Bruins Series
abstract: Boston lead the best-of-seven Eastern Conference quarterfinal series, two games to one, after a 5-2 on Monday in Toronto. Success in the face-off circle has been key, as it has all season for the Bruins.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — As the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Boston Bruins prepare for Wednesday’s Game 4, the gamesmanship between the two veteran coaches is in full swing.

headline: Google’s Aggregator Gives Way to an Heir
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Google Reader is scheduled to end July 1. And Feedly.com is just the newsreader to replace it.
lead_paragraph: Well, if we didn’t get it before, we get it now: Google giveth, and Google taketh away.

abstract: A selection of rooms from the Kips Bay Decorator Show House.
lead_paragraph: A selection of rooms from the Kips Bay Decorator Show House.

lead_paragraph: Q. There’s a large window near my shower that’s covered by a temporary blind. I’d like to fix it up before showing my home to buyers. What’s the best treatment for such an awkwardly placed window?

headline: House of Your (Vivid) Dreams
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Design', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The Kips Bay Decorator Show House vanquishes existential anxieties by going to extremes.
lead_paragraph: Desire is a reliably unreliable guide to happiness, as Alain de Botton notes in “The Architecture of Happiness,” the fifth or sixth book from the prolific professional intellectual who has tackled everything from status anxiety to sex. In it, the author observes that bad buildings are like bad relationships, “an example expressed through materials of the same tendency which in other domains will lead us to marry the wrong people, choose inappropriate jobs and book unsuccessful holidays: the tendency not to understand who we are and what will satisfy us.”

headline: Political Handouts Thrive in Pakistan
abstract: Amid the talk of change in Saturday’s elections, Pakistan remains a place where handouts can decide votes and lawmakers are sought out for protection.
lead_paragraph: MULTAN, Pakistan — In Multan, a self-described city of saints in central Pakistan, one holy politician is banking on more than prayers to ensure victory in Saturday’s national elections.

headline: Why Hit a Flower When It’s Down?
abstract: A selection of comments from readers on Anne Raver’s article, “A Mold Devastates Impatiens.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from letters and postings at nytimes.com, about Anne Raver’s article on a mysterious strain of downy mold killing one of the home gardener’s favorite annual flowers, Impatiens walleriana.

headline: Microsoft Names First Female Finance Chief
abstract: Microsoft named Amy Hood as its chief financial officer, the first woman to hold the job. She was most recently the chief financial officer of the business division, which oversees Office applications.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft named Amy Hood, an executive at the company, as its chief financial officer, the first woman to hold the top finance job at Microsoft.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times asked selected Tony Award nominees who they would like to tell, “I told you I’d get a nomination one day.”

lead_paragraph: Jamie Ahn, the owner of Acqua Beauty Bar and the Townhouse Spa, goes shopping for home spa accessories.

headline: Home Spa Accessories
abstract: From scents to lighting to the tub, what you need to outfit a home spa.
lead_paragraph: Living in a city like New York can be stressful, and retreating to a spa isn’t always an option. Unless it’s a home spa.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Someone once asked Gere Kavanaugh what she liked to design best, and with a typical mix of humor and bluntness, she answered, “Anything I can get my hands on.”

headline: The Legendary Gaetano Pesce on Work and Life
abstract: The 74-year-old legend opened a four-day exhibition today at the Collective.1 Design Fair at Pier 57 in Chelsea. Watch our exclusive video.
lead_paragraph: At the cavernous entrance to Pier 57 in Chelsea, an ancient loading dock has become a makeshift stage for the work of Gaetano Pesce, the 74-year-old Italian design legend who moved to New York 32 years ago because the city “was the capital of the 20th century.” He arrived with a splash, one of a who’s who of modern Italian designers included in MoMA’s groundbreaking 1972 show “Italy: The New Domestic Landscape.” But Pesce hasn’t had a comprehensive solo show in his adopted hometown since a 1999 exhibit tucked away at Columbia University’s School of Architecture. “He’s a legend and a New Yorker, so that tragedy needed to be corrected,” said Steven Learner, the creative director of the new Collective.1 Design Fair, where Pesce’s retrospective opened today.

headline: On View | The Designs of Gaetano Pesce
abstract: The 74-year-old Italian design legend discusses his highly personal career retrospective at the inaugural Collective.1 Design Fair in New York.
lead_paragraph: The 74-year-old Italian design legend discusses his highly personal career retrospective at the inaugural Collective.1 Design Fair in New York.

lead_paragraph: Danny DiMauro and Colin Tunstall talk surf, New York and the release of issue two of their hit magazine.

headline: Raids Yield Stolen Gems and Arrests in Europe
abstract: The raids rounded up more than 30 people and recovered some of the $50 million in diamonds stolen in a Brink’s armored car robbery in Brussels in February.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than 200 Belgian police officers and authorities in two other countries on Wednesday swept up more than 30 people and recovered some of the $50 million in diamonds stolen in a carefully orchestrated robbery in Brussels in February, investigators said.

headline: A Soaking to Talk About
abstract: With several hours left to the day, Wednesday was the fifth-rainiest May day in the modern history of New York, according to a weather historian.
lead_paragraph: Ladies, gentlemen and children, fold your umbrellas for a moment and take a bow. You have just lived through the fifth-rainiest May day in the modern history of New York and the rainiest day since Tropical Storm Irene battered the city two summers ago, according to the weather historian Steve Fybish.

headline: Austria Is Pressured to Reveal More About Tax Evaders
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Tax Evasion', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: The lack of a single tax authority governing all 27 members of the European Union has long allowed the country to make tax affairs more opaque than other members.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Austria faced renewed pressure on Wednesday to reveal more about tax evaders after senior officials of the European Union called for automatic information sharing to apply more widely and rapidly within the bloc.

headline: Europe Inches Closer to Establishing a Banking Union
abstract: The cabinet of Chancellor Angela Merkel approved legislation that would grant oversight of such institutions to the European Central Bank.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Europe inched closer Wednesday to establishing a European banking union for the Continent’s largest lenders after the German cabinet approved legislation that would grant to the European Central Bank oversight of such institutions.

headline: Turning a Smartphone Into a Workout Buddy
abstract: If your body is not all it should be, there is help available digitally, much of it free.
lead_paragraph: Summer is coming at last. Like me, you may be thinking that a few improvements to your fitness and physique might be in order before you hit the beach. It’s also possible that, like me, you find it hard to motivate yourself to exercise or to head to the gym, and you don’t like the idea of a personal trainer. Time for an app, in other words, and there are many out there to help us get in shape.

headline: Versace x Haas
abstract: A look at the home collection by the Haas Brothers for Versace.
lead_paragraph: A look at the home collection by the Haas Brothers for Versace.

headline: Faces in the Crowd, Printed in 3-D
abstract: An artist creates life-size masks of people she’s never seen before, using DNA they leave behind on cigarette butts.
lead_paragraph: Imagine someone collecting a strand of your hair from the subway floor. What would that person do with it? Frame you for a crime? Weave it into a wig?

headline: Cable Channels Lift News Corp.’s Profit
abstract: Publishing businesses, which will soon be split into a separate company, dragged on overall profit.
lead_paragraph: Fueled by the strength of its cable channels and retransmission fees at Fox Broadcasting, News Corporation reported a 4 percent increase in operating income, to $1.36 billion, in the three months that ended March 31.

headline: Jabra Revo Lets You Shape Your Sound
abstract: Jabra, best known for its Bluetooth phone accessories, is making its first foray into Bluetooth premium headphones with the $250 Revo Wireless.
lead_paragraph: Jabra, best known for its Bluetooth phone accessories, is making its first foray into Bluetooth premium headphones with the $250 Revo Wireless.

headline: Vijay Singh v PGA Tour
abstract: Vijay Singh filed suit in New York’s state supreme court, charging the PGA Tour with “violating its duty of care and good faith” in suspending the golfer for his use of deer antler spray.
lead_paragraph: Vijay Singh filed suit in New York’s state supreme court, charging the PGA Tour with “violating its duty of care and good faith” in suspending the golfer for his use of deer antler spray.

headline: Senate Panel Postpones Vote on Obama’s Labor Nominee
abstract: Senate Democrats on Wednesday postponed a committee vote on the nomination of Thomas E. Perez to lead the Labor Department after the chamber’s top Republican raised doubts about Mr. Perez’s ethics.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans on Wednesday forced Democrats to postpone a committee vote on the nomination of Thomas E. Perez to lead the Labor Department after the chamber’s top Republican raised doubts about Mr. Perez’s ethics.

headline: Brad Drewett, President of Men’s Tennis Tour, Dies at 54
abstract: Mr. Drewett was a former professional tennis player who became president of the ATP last year and won a greater share of Grand Slam tournament revenue for players.
lead_paragraph: Brad Drewett, a former professional tennis player who became president of the ATP last year and won a greater share of Grand Slam tournament revenue for players, died on Friday at his home in Sydney, Australia. He was 54.

headline: Tesla’s Disappearing Data
abstract: Tesla Motors has stopped detailing how many reservations exist for its cars at the end of each quarter.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors regularly gave out a crucial number that gave the public a good idea of how much demand existed for its electric cars.

headline: Ferguson’s Tenure With Manchester United
abstract: Alex Ferguson, in his 26 years as manager, transformed United into one of the world’s most lucrative, and dominant, soccer clubs.
lead_paragraph: Alex Ferguson, in his 26 years as manager, transformed United into one of the world’s most lucrative, and dominant, soccer clubs.

headline: Jeanne Cooper, ‘Young and the Restless’ Star, Dies at 84
abstract: Ms. Cooper played the fabulously wealthy matriarch Katherine Chancellor for four decades and was the longest-serving cast member of the television soap opera.
lead_paragraph: Jeanne Cooper, the enduring actress on “The Young and the Restless” who had much in common with her character, the forthright Katherine Chancellor — apart from everyday occurrences in the soap opera universe like being stranded on a desert island with nothing but her jewelry, having a shopping center fall on her and inadvertently giving one of her grandchildren away — died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 84 and continued to appear on the show until her death.

headline: A Chance to Return
abstract: Senators have proposed an immigration bill that could give a legal second chance to tens of thousands of deportees.
lead_paragraph: Senators have proposed an immigration bill that could give a legal second chance to tens of thousands of deportees.

headline: State Department Official on Demotion
abstract: Gregory Hicks, a State Department veteran, explained how raising questions about the Benghazi attack negatively affected his career.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Hicks, a State Department veteran, explained how raising questions about the Benghazi attack negatively affected his career.

headline: Court Upholds Berlusconi Tax Fraud Verdict
abstract: An appeals court in Milan sentenced former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi to four years in prison and imposed a five-year ban on his holding public office.
lead_paragraph: ROME — An appeals court in Milan upheld a conviction on Wednesday of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi for tax fraud, sentencing him to four years in prison and imposing a five-year ban on holding public office.

headline: Einhorn Is Beaten to the Punch
abstract: Just days before David Einhorn was to present his latest investment idea, another hedge fund manager stole his thunder.
lead_paragraph: Just days before David Einhorn was to present his latest investment idea, another hedge fund manager stole his thunder.

headline: Israel Moves to End Gender Segregation in Public Spaces
abstract: The attorney general called on public agencies “to act fast, efficiently and decisively” on sweeping new rules after years of legal battles over the treatment of women.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s attorney general on Wednesday advised ministers across the government to immediately end gender segregation in public spaces, issuing guidelines that would change many aspects of daily life here — from buses to burials, health care to radio airwaves.

headline: Colorado Lawmakers Approve Driver’s Licenses for Illegal Immigrants
abstract: The measure passed in a Legislature controlled by Democrats and buoyed by an influx of young Latino lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — In one of their final acts before wrapping up the Colorado legislative session on Wednesday, lawmakers approved a bill allowing immigrants who are in the country illegally to obtain driver’s licenses, making the state one of only a handful to have passed such a measure.

headline: A Day Later, Everyone Still Talks About Harvey
abstract: After his one-hit, nine-inning performance against the White Sox on Tuesday, the superlatives keep piling up for Matt Harvey.

Ms. Arias was accused of stabbing Mr. Alexander almost 30 times, shooting him in the head and slashing his throat from ear to ear during a fit of jealous rage in 2008. Her lawyers argued he had been abusive to her, and that she killed him in self-defense. abstract: Both Windows and Mac OS X can quickly give you information about your computer’s wireless network connection, along with built-in troubleshooting tools.

headline: Shimmying Off the Literary Mantle
abstract: In detail and dialogue “The Great Gatsby” largely adheres faithfully to F. Scott Fitzgerald’s novel, but Baz Luhrmann has colored it lavishly with his feel for the era.
lead_paragraph: The best way to enjoy Baz Luhrmann’s big and noisy new version of “The Great Gatsby” — and despite what you may have heard, it is an eminently enjoyable movie — is to put aside whatever literary agenda you are tempted to bring with you. I grant that this is not so easily done. F. Scott Fitzgerald’s slender, charming third novel has accumulated a heavier burden of cultural significance than it can easily bear. Short and accessible enough to be consumed in a sitting (as in “Gatz,” Elevator Repair Service’s full-text staged reading), the book has become, in the 88 years since its publication, a schoolroom staple and a pop-cultural totem. It shapes our increasingly fuzzy image of the jazz age and fuels endless term papers on the American dream and related topics.

While the choosing of an Academy Awards host is an annual cycle of wondering who’s available to do it; wondering if the person or people chosen are up to the task; and then wondering what went wrong the morning after, the Tonys have dispensed with such uncertainty by naming Neil Patrick Harris to host the awards program for a fourth year.

headline: This Year, Off Broadway Dug Deeper
abstract: While Broadway plays seemed moribund this season, some of the work presented Off Broadway was terrific.
lead_paragraph: The season just concluded was a terrific, even inspiring one for new American playwriting. But if you confined your theatergoing to Broadway, you really wouldn’t know it. And with the expertise of Lilith Spencer, who had been at Bklyn Larder, the cheese and provisions shop, they are stocking their bright little place with some real finds. Among them are a goat’s milk ricotta from Edgwick Farm in Cornwall, N.Y.; a couple of tommes from the Kokoborrego Cheese Company in Mount Gilead, Ohio; and an organic Parmigiano-Reggiano from Italy. They also carry pistachios and almonds from Sicily, a mead vinegar from Italy, breads from Bien Cuit in Brooklyn, and a sweet white miso made in Conway, Mass. Charcuterie is sliced on what Ms. Spencer says is the Rolls-Royce of slicing machines; Wedge, 728 Franklin Avenue (Sterling Place), Crown Heights, Brooklyn, wedgeonfranklin@gmail.com, facebook.com/wedgeonfranklin.

lead_paragraph: Sir Harold Evans (otherwise known as Harry) has spent his life around words — reporting, editing and writing books. Born in Manchester, England, in 1928, he began his career as a journalist when he was only 16, rising rapidly through the years and accumulating honors as he went. He was the editor of The Sunday Times of London from 1967 to 1981, moved to the United States in 1984 and became — to mention only a few of his positions — editorial director of U.S. News and World Report, president of Random House and founding editor of Condé Nast Traveler. In 2001, British journalists voted him the all-time greatest British newspaper editor. He was knighted in 2004.

headline: On the Brink
abstract: Two new books take the reader back to the complicated web of events leading up to World War I.
lead_paragraph: Nobody at the time called the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo on June 28, 1914, “a shot heard round the world.” The phrase, filched from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s “Concord Hymn,” epitomizes a judgment that crystallized only as the horrendous sequels played out. Some parts of the international community weren’t listening at all. America was serene in its isolation and prosperity. “To the world, or to a nation,” The Grand Forks Herald in North Dakota declared, “an archduke more or less makes little difference.” President Wilson, pacing the lonely corridors of the White House, was distraught over the first lady’s failing struggle for life. Paris was engrossed in a murder trial brimming with sex and political scandal. London was too obsessed with Irish home rule to sustain attention until closer to midnight.

It’s the kind of domestic horror show that certain British filmmakers either mock or sentimentalize, and which the British director Ben Wheatley (“Down Terrace”) takes to with a very heavy, very unforgiving ax.

headline: 36 Hours in Las Vegas

New restaurants, shows, clubs and hotels are constantly reinventing Sin City with the aim of getting repeaters back to the tables. Big construction projects continue, and there are currently two competing Ferris wheels under construction on the Strip. But lately, developments have eschewed kitschy copies of foreign landmarks like an Egyptian pyramid in favor of celebrating Las Vegas’s own swinging style, as indicated by two new downtown museums. Yes, traffic still snarls the Strip, but a new terminal at McCarran International Airport has eased congestion for fliers.

headline: Family Opens Its Diary, With Mother as Subject
abstract: In “Stories We Tell,” the actress and director Sarah Polley sat down with relatives and friends to talk about her mother, who died when Ms. Polley was 11.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, I suspect, our first sense of the past begins with the simple childhood request for a story about our families and ourselves. In her quietly moving, intelligent documentary “Stories We Tell,” the Canadian actress and director Sarah Polley sat down with relatives and friends and asked them to talk about her mother, Diane Polley, who died in 1990 when Ms. Polley was 11. The idea, or so it first seems, is that every fondly unearthed detail, anecdote and memory will fill in the biography of a woman whose seemingly ordinary life — of tending children, husband and home — contained multitudes and mysteries, and with tugging and shaping can be tidied into a story.

There has been an increase of visits to the Catedral Metropolitana, where the pope celebrated Mass before his elevation, and to Flores, the neighborhood where he grew up and home to the basilica where he was a priest, said Pamela Resnik of the tourism ministry’s development office.

headline: Using Darkness, With Enlightenment in Mind
abstract: The conductor Paul Haas led a concert on Wednesday under dimmed lights at the Church of the Ascension in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas has written several works to be performed in pitch darkness, including “In Vain,” his hourlong masterpiece for chamber orchestra. With artificial light everywhere, “we do not have any night in our modern life,” he said in an interview in 2011. “But I think our body and our souls desire night, and I give this in my art.”

headline: Youthful Charisma Unleashed, Violin in Hand
abstract: Benjamin Beilman, a rising 21-year-old, performed chamber works from several masters at Merkin Concert Hall.
lead_paragraph: In college I used to drive a matchbox-size Volkswagen Polo with, according to the manual, a maximum speed of 142 kilometers (about 88 miles) per hour. But on empty stretches of a speed-limit-free German autobahn, I would floor the gas pedal until the needle climbed past 160 kilometers, and the car shook so hard that the keys jingled in the ignition, and the cassette threatened to pop out of the stereo.

headline: A Cuban Art Collective’s Revelations in Reverse
abstract: A new exhibition by Los Carpinteros centers on a remarkable installation in which a traditional dance processional is performed entirely backwards.
lead_paragraph: Since the early 1990s, the Cuban art collective Los Carpinteros has been creating elegant sculptures, drawings and installations that engage the public with a mix of wry humor and political resonance. For last year’s Havana Biennial, the artists directed a film called “Conga Irreversible,” in which 100 performers enacted a traditional Cuban comparsa — a ceremonial procession — down Havana’s historic Paseo del Prado, entirely in reverse. Marco Castillo, one of the group’s founders, compared the experience to directing an opera. “An original score was composed,” he recalled. “All of the costumes were custom designed.”

headline: Merrill Brockway, Producer of TV’s ‘Dance in America,’ Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Brockway, who was also a director, brought high art to millions of Americans though the PBS series.
lead_paragraph: Merrill Brockway, a director and producer who brought high art to millions of Americans by presenting many of the 20th century’s greatest dancers and choreographers on the PBS television series “Dance in America,” died on May 2 in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 90.

headline: Fredrick L. McKissack, 73, Children’s Book Author, Dies
abstract: Mr. McKissack, with his wife, Patricia, wrote over 100 children’s books about African-American history.
lead_paragraph: Fredrick L. McKissack, who quit a career in construction to join his wife in writing more than 100 children’s books about African-American history, a piece of which his family owned as distinguished builders and architects, died on April 28 in Chesterfield, Mo., a St. Louis suburb. He was 73.

headline: Back to the Future Portraiture
abstract: Like modern-day photo booths, cartes de visites in the mid-1800s allowed people to be playful with the camera.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I came across a very old photograph on Facebook that seemed to be a formal portrait . . . of someone’s back. Intrigued, I tracked down the owner of the image, Paul Frecker, who runs a Web site called the Library of Nineteenth-Century Photography. A Londoner, Frecker is a former fashion stylist who used to work for magazines like The Face and i-D in the 1980s, and then on music videos and commercials in the 1990s. In 2001, he stumbled on an album of carte de visites in an antiques store, and soon after that he gave up styling for collecting and trading photographs from that era. Some of his favorite images in his collection, he says, are his 60 or so “back to camera” carte de visites, small, mounted photographs — mostly portraits — that became popular in the second half of the 19th century.

headline: Sixth Suit Filed by Client Against Former Knoedler Gallery
abstract: A new lawsuit was filed last week that challenges the authenticity of a painting sold by the former Knoedler & Company gallery.
lead_paragraph: The once-celebrated Knoedler & Company gallery has been closed for more than a year and a half but the lawsuits keep coming. Last week, the philanthropist and former ambassador to Romania, Nicholas F. Taubman, became the sixth former client to sue the gallery in federal court in Manhattan, charging that Knoedler’s former director Ann Freedman duped him into buying a fake painting by Clyfford Still for $4.3 million in 2005.

headline: Electronic Music in Chelsea
abstract: Laurie Anderson is the curator for an installment of Synth Nights at the Kitchen, featuring Yuka C. Honda, late of Cibo Matto, and Nels Cline of Wilco.
lead_paragraph: The Miser can’t leave home these days without encountering the AutoTuned pipes of one pop star or another. But while AutoTune’s vocal effect may seem like just the latest pop music craze, historians of electronic music point out its distinguished antecedents, in, say, Elvis Presley’s slapback echo, Peter Frampton’s talk box, or the vocoder used by Laurie Anderson in her unlikely 1981 pop hit, “O Superman.”

headline: In Praise of Public Libraries (Personal and Trivial)
abstract: Peace, quiet, a chair, and a connection.
lead_paragraph: Nothing professional or deep here, just an interesting (to me) discovery I’ve made. For complicated reasons, mainly family-duty-related, I’ve lately had to do a lot of hopscotching around central New Jersey, with various appointments and tasks here and there but often with gaps of several hours in between. And, as always, lots of work to get done in the cracks. What to do?

headline: Singh Plays in Relative Peace
abstract: Following Tiger Woods on the course means golfing in front of only a few people, even if you’ve just sued the PGA Tour.
lead_paragraph: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — By the time Vijay Singh arrived at the par-3 17th hole Thursday afternoon, the fans who had blanketed the grassy areas around the island green minutes earlier were gone, leaving behind a trail of empty water bottles. Tiger Woods, who was playing in the group directly ahead of Singh, is like a magnet, pulling fans to whichever hole he is playing.

headline: Suspect in Boston Bombing Talked Jihad in Russia
abstract: Acquaintances of Tamerlan Tsarnaev in Russia said he was already interested in waging jihad when he arrived there last year, but they discouraged him from joining a militant group.
lead_paragraph: KIZLYAR, Russia — It’s not every day that a well-dressed American shows up in this town, where shaggy cows meander over deeply rutted roads, so people remember Tamerlan Tsarnaev. Among the things that made the young visitor stand out, two acquaintances recalled on Thursday, was his avid interest in waging jihad.

abstract: There are over 110 facilities statewide that store at least 10,000 pounds of ammonium nitrate, the source of an explosion at a fertilizer plant that killed at least 14 people.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRAUNFELS — Off a dirt road connected to ever-flowing Interstate 35, a little metal sign on a wooden fence is the only indication of what lies ahead. Nearby, Buckley Powder, a mining and construction supply company, stores large quantities of ammonium nitrate, the source of the explosion at a fertilizer depot that killed at least 14 people and injured hundreds more last month in West.

headline: Champions Face Challenges, Too
abstract: The documentary “Venus and Serena” focuses on 2011, a year when the sisters’ domination of women’s tennis seemed threatened.
lead_paragraph: “Venus and Serena,” a new documentary by Maiken Baird and Michelle Major, focuses on 2011, when the Williams Sisters Era of women’s tennis seemed to be coming to an end. Flashing back to earlier moments of glory, the film follows Venus and Serena through injuries and other health problems. Venus, the older sister and the first to rise to prominence, seems to be fading quietly from the scene, while Serena, always more dramatic and more controversial, struggles with frustration and disappointment.

headline: A Mad Man Someone Should Hire
abstract: In “And Now a Word From Our Sponsor,” an ad executive is reduced to speaking only in slogans.
lead_paragraph: To describe “And Now a Word From Our Sponsor” as a one-joke skit stretched well beyond the breaking point isn’t entirely fair, because when used ingeniously, which is very seldom, the joke lands. The movie’s unwitting clown, Adan (Bruce Greenwood), is the chief executive of an advertising agency who is found unconscious in front of an electronics store. He wakes up in a hospital, and the only words to come out of his mouth are familiar advertising slogans. Asked how he is feeling, Adan replies, “Please don’t squeeze the Charmin.”

headline: Playing Jazz in High Heels and Skirts
abstract: “The Girls in the Band” tells the story of women faced with racism and sexist male musicians in the 1930s and ’40s.
lead_paragraph: “The Girls in the Band” is everything a worthwhile documentary should be, and then some: engaging, informative, thorough and brimming with delightful characters. Shining a long-overdue spotlight on the shamefully forgotten women who flourished as jazz musicians at a time when men ruled the beat, Judy Chaikin’s beautifully assembled film gives voice to performers whose names are too often unknown even among their musical sisters of the present day.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Those Aiding Iran
abstract: The actions appeared to signal an accelerated effort by the United States to squeeze Iran economically over the lack of progress in negotiations on its disputed nuclear program.

It also singled out two other companies, including a Venezuelan-Iranian bank, accused of helping Iran evade other Western-imposed prohibitions on oil sales and financial dealings.

lead_paragraph: Tyler Perry “presents” Tina Gordon Chism’s “Peeples,” but this pleasing ensemble comedy, while manifesting Perry trademarks, is very much Ms. Chism’s own. And that is to its benefit.

headline: The Wilderness Next Door
abstract: Every region has a Mount St. Helens of its own — something that does not respond to human will, something with the potential to do harm but also bring out the universal Huck Finn.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT ST. HELENS, Wash. — You’re on the crater rim of a volcano that is in a tenuous snooze. You expect the few burps of steam coming from the lava dome down below. You expect the sense-surround view of the Cascade Mountains on a day from perfection’s vault. What you don’t expect is finding a New Yorker, sitting near a snow cornice, munching a bagel.

headline: Bernanke, Blower of Bubbles?
abstract: With all the talk about financial bubbles lately, do current bond and stock prices make sense?
lead_paragraph: Bubbles can be bad for your financial health — and bad for the health of the economy, too. The dot-com bubble of the late 1990s left behind many vacant buildings and many more failed dreams. When the housing bubble of the next decade burst, the result was the greatest economic crisis since the 1930s — a crisis from which we have yet to emerge.

headline: Far From China’s Bustling Cities, the Grind of Poverty
abstract: In the documentary “Three Sisters,” the director Wang Bing focuses on an impoverished farmer’s family, including the 10-year-old daughter left behind to fend for herself.
lead_paragraph: Not for the faint of heart or weak of bladder, Wang Bing’s two-and-a-half-hour “Three Sisters” documents extreme poverty in rural China with the compassionate eye and inexhaustible patience of a director whose curiosity about his country’s unfortunates never seems to wane.

headline: Started at the Bottom
abstract: Four Hispanic young people peel back the curtain into a different wiring of aspirations and loyalties than those held by the empirical kids I described in March.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I devoted a column to the mostly upper-middle-class students at elite universities — the empirical kids. I thought it would be interesting to devote a column to students who at least started at the other end of the social scale. So the Times researcher Anne Snyder and I interviewed a bunch of young people whom we had met earlier through the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute.

headline: After Plant Explosion, Texas Remains Wary of Regulation
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Explosions', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Last month’s devastating blast in West, Tex., did little to shake local skepticism of government regulations, and recent efforts to push for more oversight have faced strong resistance.
lead_paragraph: WEST, Tex. — Five days after an explosion at a fertilizer plant leveled a wide swath of this town, Gov. Rick Perry tried to woo Illinois business officials by trumpeting his state’s low taxes and limited regulations. Asked about the disaster, Mr. Perry responded that more government intervention and increased spending on safety inspections would not have prevented what has become one of the nation’s worst industrial accidents in decades.

headline: In Its Efforts to Integrate Roma, Slovakia Recalls U.S. Struggles
abstract: Eastern Slovakia’s elementary schools are a microcosm of one of Europe’s biggest challenges: how to bring its most disadvantaged minority into the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: SARISSKE MICHALANY, Slovakia — Gazing out his window during morning recess on his first day at work, the principal of an elementary school here, Jaroslav Valastiak, was caught up short: all the children playing in the asphalt-covered yard were white, a strikingly monochromatic scene at a school where a majority of pupils are dark-skinned Roma.

headline: Civilization Comes Crashing Down
abstract: In “Aftershock” an earthquake in Chile sets the stage for a pell-mell disaster movie that dispatches its characters with the efficiency of a horror film.
lead_paragraph: The first face we see in “Aftershock” belongs to Eli Roth, a sighting that will, depending on your moviegoing preferences, make you grin with anticipation or run for the exit. Yet despite Mr. Roth’s blood-drenched directing rap sheet (including “Cabin Fever” and both “Hostel” movies), this latest project — which he helped write and produce but left to Nicolás López to direct — is far more fixated on gasps than on gore.

headline: Slovakia Struggles to Desegregate Its Schools

headline: Wartime Enemies Do an About-Face in Peacetime
abstract: In “The Second Meeting,” a documentary, an American stealth-bomber pilot shot down over Serbia meets his enemy a dozen years later, in peace, and in friendship.
lead_paragraph: In 1999 Dale Zelko, a husband and father from New Hampshire, was part of a NATO operation, flying an F-117A Nighthawk stealth fighter over Serbia. Zoltan Dani, a husband and father from Skorenovac, was a colonel in the Yugoslav Army. He shot down Mr. Zelko’s stealth bomber, becoming a national hero, having proved that there is no such thing as an invisible plane.
