headline: The N.L.R.B.’s Contested Poster
abstract: A federal appeals court dominated by conservative judges rules against a requirement that employers post notices about union rights.
lead_paragraph: The subject of the latest outrageous ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit is an 11-by-17-inch poster. The National Labor Relations Board requires nearly six million private employers to display the poster, which informs employees of their right to join or form a union or to take action together to improve their working conditions.

headline: The Republicans’ Benghazi Obsession
abstract: While they focus on the attack that killed four Americans in September, Libya is unraveling.
lead_paragraph: Before Wednesday’s hearing on the attack in Benghazi, Libya, Republicans in Congress promised explosive new details about the administration’s mishandling of the episode. Instead, the hearing showed, yet again, that sober fact-finding is not their mission. Common sense and good judgment have long given way to conspiracy-mongering and a relentless effort to discredit President Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: The Man They Trust With Their Keys
abstract: When Scooter Bottega opened in Brooklyn in 2001, vintage Italian scooters, let alone shops that could service them, were a relative rarity in the city — but not anymore.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon at the edge of Red Hook, the sun shone on a small flock of Vespas parked in front of Scooter Bottega’s electric-blue storefront. The block was quiet, but the tiny garage buzzed with machinery and the steady stream of riders rumbling up to the curb to hand their keys to Robbie Rhodes.

headline: App-Armed and YouTube-Educated, Taking Care of My Baby
abstract: When I was growing up in the ’60s, girls were never encouraged to take auto-shop courses. Now I want to know more about what’s under the hood. Like, where’s the radiator?
lead_paragraph: I took my car, after its winter storage, to a Manhattan dealership last month for a spring tune-up. headline: Texas: Web Site Removes Do-It-Yourself Gun Plans

abstract: Downloadable files that can be used to make a gun with a 3-D printer were removed after the State Department said that posting the files may violate arms-exporting regulations.
lead_paragraph: A Web site run by a Texas law student has removed downloadable design files that can be used to make a gun with a 3-D printer after the State Department said that posting the files may violate arms-exporting regulations. In a letter to the student, Cody Wilson, a department official wrote that by posting the files, the site, defcad.org, may have released “technical data” without authorization. The files, for a simple gun called the Liberator, were posted this week along with a video showing the weapon, which is largely made of plastic, being fired. Mr. Wilson, who had earlier used 3-D printers to make parts of assault rifles, said that he would try to claim an exemption for the regulations because on the Internet the files would be in the public domain.

headline: Gin Doesn’t Make You Sad
abstract: It’s just the opposite. Blame William Hogarth for the bad rap.
lead_paragraph: Few spirits bear so heavy a semiotic burden as gin, which is regarded by many as mother’s ruin, the destroyer, the devil, the drink that shall not be named. More often than not, when I try to nudge wary customers gently toward gin (instead of, you know, vodka), they look at me as if I’ve offered them a live grenade. This bad rap, I think, is partly the fault of the English artist William Hogarth. The gin of 18th-century England — harsh and cheap — is very different from what we drink now, but anyone who was shown a slide of Hogarth’s “Gin Lane” in history class is unlikely to forget the images of those dissolute Londoners: here, a man fighting a dog for a bone; there, a woman dropping her baby over a railing.

headline: Should I Protect a Patient at the Expense of an Innocent Stranger?
abstract: Exploring the limits of a vow to “do no harm.”
lead_paragraph: I am a physician. Years ago, I saw a young patient with headaches, who disclosed — reluctantly — that he had committed a serious crime and that somebody else took the fall for it. I believe he was telling me the truth (his headaches soon resolved after the confession). Before his admission, I assured him that whatever he told me would not leave the room. Later, without giving specifics, I consulted our hospital lawyer, who told me that we were under no obligation to report the incident, because the patient wasn’t in danger of hurting himself or others. But the future of an innocent man hinges on two people’s consciences, my patient’s and my own. I feel like a coward, hiding behind the Hippocratic oath, doing nothing. NAME WITHHELD

We were just part of a much bigger effort to repeal decades of progress on women’s health and rights.

headline: Confessions of an Art Conservator’s Sidekick
abstract: No one gets to lay hands on untouchable cultural icons the way we do.
lead_paragraph: Out in Malibu, the billionaire’s gardener has nicked a bronze with his weed whacker. In Echo Park, the Lady of the Lake is missing her benediction hand. Somewhere in Pasadena, a stone female nude has mysteriously sprouted pubic hair, accomplished with what appears to be hide glue and combings from an auburn Irish setter. Who knows how long it was there? No matter. A few brush strokes with warm distilled water, and she is returned to immodesty once more.

headline: Exclusive Premiere: O.M.D.’s ‘Dresden’
abstract: The premiere of a new music video by Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark.
lead_paragraph: The premiere of a new music video by Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark.

headline: Who Made That Digital Camouflage?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Camouflage', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: From suitcase-size splotches of green and brown to a “Harry Potter” cloak.
lead_paragraph: “I was basically designated the weird-projects officer,” says Timothy O’Neill, who worked with an Army team to improve the camouflage painted on tanks in the early 1970s. At the time, the military covered its vehicles with suitcase-size splotches of green and brown. The pattern could trick the eye at a distance, but it didn’t work well at close range. O’Neill set out to find a better solution. At the Aberdeen Proving Ground, a test site in Maryland, he and his team put an armored personnel carrier out in a field and painted it with two-inch squares in woodland colors. From far away, the flecks seemed to coalesce into a large pattern, so that the vehicle blended with the trees behind it. The tiny squares also mimicked close-up details: individual leaves, tufts of grass and shadows on a branch. O’Neill’s tests showed that this digital camouflage — as it would later be called — fooled the eye into seeing tank and landscape as one.

headline: The Plot Against Rock
abstract: Thirty-five years ago, Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark was certain that the overthrow of the electric guitar was imminent. They still haven’t given up hope.
lead_paragraph: Andy McCluskey and Paul Humphreys have devoted much of their artistic lives to a war on rock nostalgia, but when you’re showing a first-time visitor around Liverpool, what can you do? You’re obliged to end up at the Cavern Club, a not-completely-uncharming replica of the vaulted, subterranean bar where the pre-Fab Four honed their fabulousness.

headline: Taiwan Demands Philippine Apology for Fisherman’s Killing
abstract: A 65-year-old man died after his boat was fired on by a Philippine government ship after coast guard officials said his boat had tried to ram the Philippine vessel.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Taiwan and mainland China reacted with anger Friday over the death of a Taiwanese fisherman who was fatally shot when the Philippine Coast Guard opened fire on his boat, saying it had tried to ram a Philippine ship.

headline: Daily Report: International A.T.M. Theft Takes $45 Million
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: The authorities said suspects used laptops and the Internet in more than two dozen countries to steal from A.T.M.’s, including 2,904 machines in New York, in a single day, Marc Santora reports in The New York Times..
lead_paragraph: It was a huge bank heist — but a 21st-century version in which the robbers never wore ski masks, threatened a teller or set foot in a vault, Marc Santora reports in The New York Times.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Ways to Stay Fit
abstract: With summer approaching, it’s the perfect time to improve your fitness levels.
lead_paragraph: This week I wrote about apps that can take the place, at least in part, of a personal trainer. These fitness apps can coach and provide encouragement as you try to get fit. With summer fast approaching, now may be a great moment to take advantage of these apps to improve your overall fitness, lose some weight or tone your muscles.

headline: The “OMG, Who Is O.M.D.?” Playlist
abstract: An introduction to Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark.
lead_paragraph: When I was a teenager, there was nothing in the world I liked half as much as my Walkman. I listened to it compulsively, like an addict, blasting music into my head and causing major damage to my ears. As mind-blowingly wonderful as it is to now carry 25,000 songs in my pocket, the Walkman forced a deeper engagement with the music you loved. Nobody carried around lots of cassettes. Maybe one or two extra. And if you were like me, you often kept the same one in there for weeks at a time, creating an intimacy that seems quaint now. Fast-forwarding and rewinding were a drag, so you tended to listen through entire albums, sometimes falling in love with songs you hated on first listen. This was commitment. The melodies and lyrics on these albums in particular — “Hatful of Hollow,” by the Smiths; “Murmur,” by R.E.M.; “Let It Be,” by the Replacements; “Head on the Door,” by the Cure; and “Architecture & Morality,” by Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark — are practically etched on the inside of my skull.

headline: A Fresh Challenge to Dell Buyout
abstract: Carl C. Icahn and Southeastern Asset Management are preparing a rival bid for Dell. | California’s attorney general has accused JPMorgan Chase of debt collection abuses. | SAC Capital Advisors has extended a deadline for investors to decide whether to withdraw money. | The Securities and Exchange Commission appears to have softened its tone in a settlement with Philip A. Falcone.
lead_paragraph: ICAHN AND SOUTHEASTERN READY RIVAL BID FOR DELL  |  The billionaire Carl C. Icahn and Southeastern Asset Management, two of the biggest shareholders of Dell, plan to bid for the computer maker in a last-ditch effort to stop what they call “the great giveaway,” the $24.4 billion management buyout led by Michael S. Dell, the company’s founder, and the private equity firm Silver Lake, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook.

keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: If its slate of directors is approved next week, Hess will appoint John Krenicki, a former vice chairman of General Electric, as its nonexecutive chairman, while John B. Hess will remain chief executive.
lead_paragraph: The Hess Corporation said on Friday that it planned to separate its chairman and chief executive roles, hoping to blunt a campaign by an activist investor and assuage restive shareholders.

headline: Recovery in Germany Is Faster Than Elsewhere
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Unemployment in Germany is lower than it was when the financial crisis began, and below that of the United States and other European Union countries.
lead_paragraph: THE recovery from the Great Recession has been slow, or even nonexistent, in most of the developed world.

headline: Helping Glass Slippers and Kinky Boots Shine
abstract: “Kinky Boots,” which had a run in Chicago before coming to Broadway, and “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella,” with no out-of-town run, both got major surgery because of surveys of preview audiences.
lead_paragraph: When “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” started preview performances on Broadway in January, one of the most memorable climaxes in all of fairy tale history — the prince sliding the glass slipper onto Cinderella’s foot — was treated like an afterthought. The show’s book writer, Douglas Carter Beane, wanted to put a modern, offhand spin on well-worn scenes, so the slipper revelation became a meh moment during a very busy sequence in Act II.

headline: A Young Person’s Guide to a Hopper Painting
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A second-grade student viewing a famous Edward Hopper painting of a restaurant wondered how clean the place was.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Vettel Leads in Practice for Sunday’s Grand Prix of Spain
abstract: Sebastian Vettel enters the Formula One event leading in points as his boss criticizes Bernie Ecclestone’s tire rules
lead_paragraph: Practice for Sunday’s Grand Prix of Spain started on Friday at the Circuit de Catalunya, the 2.9-mile road course just outside Barcelona that was a winter test site for the teams. The Spanish race will be the fifth of the 19 races that count toward the Formula One World Drivers Championship and the beginning of the circuit’s European swing that continues into September (punctuated by the Montreal race in June).

headline: Q.& A.: Getting More (or Less) Mail from Facebook
abstract: You can tell Facebook what types of e-mail notifications you would like to receive by adjusting your account settings.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Friday Reading: Owning a Dog Linked to Lower Heart Risk
abstract: Owning a dog is linked to lower heart risk, thieves get millions in an A.T.M. scheme, many never turn off electronics in flight and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Album of Unreleased Andy Kaufman Material Coming in July
abstract: “Andy and His Grandmother,” a new collection from the independent record label Drag City, is culled from more than 82 hours of recordings that Kaufman made in the late 1970s.
lead_paragraph: It would be just like Andy Kaufman to find a way to keep releasing records long after his death. The pioneering comedian and “Taxi” co-star’s reputation for pranks and provocations was such that, even when he died of lung cancer at age 35 in 1984, some fans believed that this, too, was one of his outrageous acts of fakery.

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Urges Faster Action to End Fighting in Syria
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Navi Pillay, the high commissioner for human rights, said she feared that international outrage had been numbed by two years of conflict.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Navi Pillay, the top United Nations human rights official, called Friday for “much greater urgency” in efforts to end the conflict in Syria, saying massacres carried out in recent days should spur international action.

headline: King of Mangoes Comes to See the Queen
abstract: The Alphonso mango was the star attraction at the first mango festival in Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Inside a white canvas tent in Trafalgar Square, a light orange liquid was poured into several small cups. These shots of Alphonso mango lassi vanished almost as soon as they were set down. Many had to be politely told, “Just one sample per person, please.”

headline: Land of the Rising Sums
abstract: The Japan shock, continued.
lead_paragraph: The good news for Abenomics keeps rolling in; of course, it’s not over until the sumo wrestler sings, but there has clearly been a major change in Japanese psychology and expectations, which is what it’s all about.

headline: Nascar Superstar Selling Central Park West Condo
abstract: A customized three-bedroom in the 20-story limestone frontispiece of the building, with intimate treetop views of the park.
lead_paragraph: An inventively embellished three-bedroom condominium at the reigning superstar of Manhattan trophy residences, 15 Central Park West, is about to enter a trophy-conscious marketplace priced at $30 million.

headline: Q. and A. on the ‘Shell Game’ of College Aid
abstract: In a question-and-answer exchange, the author of a new report on financial aid describes problems in making college affordable for low-income students, and potential solutions.
lead_paragraph: “With their relentless pursuit of prestige and revenue, the nation’s public and private four-year colleges and universities are in danger of shutting down what has long been a pathway to the middle class for low-income and working-class students,” writes Stephen Burd, a senior policy analyst at the New America Foundation, in a new report that’s getting considerable attention.

headline: Warburg Pincus Closes Latest Fund at $11.2 Billion
abstract: It is one of the biggest private equity fund-raising rounds since the end of the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: 12:19 p.m. | Updated Warburg Pincus said on Friday that it had closed its latest fund at $11.2 billion, in one of the biggest private equity fund-raising rounds since the end of the financial crisis.

headline: Does the Pentagon Take Sexual Assault Seriously?
abstract: It’s too hard for victims to get compensation and treatment.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon released a depressing report on Tuesday stating that the number of sexual assaults in the military grew from about 19,000 last year to 26,000 this year. Obviously something must be done to reverse that trend but, in the meantime, the federal government could do more to help the victims.

headline: Love Affair With Swale Extends Well Beyond His Death
abstract: Swale possessed the undeniable appeal of the underdog; he was Claiborne’s stand-in for their star, Devil’s Bag, and he shocked many fans with his Kentucky Derby upset over horses like Althea. Swale’s most famous moment, however, was not that Derby win, but his death.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, I was in the seventh grade, and I fell in love with Swale, who looked very much, I thought, like the picture of the Black Stallion on my copies of those books. I read everything Andrew Beyer and Tony Kornheiser wrote about him in The Washington Post. I cut out photographs from the sports section: Swale standing regally, chin raised, wind ruffling his mane; Swale and his assistant trainer, Mike Griffin, regarding each other with affection over a Pimlico stall door, a list of Preakness winners posted above them.

headline: All About the ECB
abstract: And nothing to do with austerity.
lead_paragraph: Joe Weisenthal has a good post going after Roger Altman’s assertion that European austerity was necessary to satisfy the markets. As Paul De Grauwe has been arguing for a while, what has been needed all along to calm the markets isn’t austerity — which doesn’t seem to help at all — but a liquidity backstop from the ECB, which works wonders.

headline: In Brussels, Private Art Collections With Open Doors
abstract: A growing number of art collectors in Belgium — especially those favoring Contemporary works — are finding ways to share their collections with the public.
lead_paragraph: When you walk into the 1920s-era converted warehouse in central Brussels, you’re confronted with an out-of-the-ordinary greeting: a five-meter-wide red sign stabbed through with knives whose handles spell out “Run Like Hell.”

headline: Too Old for Camp, Too Young to Work: What to Do?
abstract: A reader is looking for activities for young teens and tweens in the summer.
lead_paragraph: A reader writes with this quandary: What do parents encourage young teenagers to do all summer?

lead_paragraph: Wheee! The Heritage Foundation is engaged in frantic damage control; not only did its big anti-immigration-reform report turn out to be a steaming heap of, um, bad research, but one of the co-authors turns out to have a serious white supremacist background.

headline: Reaching 1,776 Feet
abstract: The 408-foot spire was set into place at 1 World Trade Center on Friday, raising the building to its full height.

headline: Poison Attack Revives Fury in China Over ’95 Case
abstract: Nearly two decades after Zhu Ling was poisoned, her case has electrified the nation with questions about the power of China’s political elite in a society where justice remains elusive.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The mysterious illness began with crippling stomach pain, followed by blurry vision and sudden hair loss. By the time Zhu Ling, a talented musician and chemistry student at one of China’s top universities, emerged from a coma weeks later, she was partially paralyzed and nearly blind, her faculties reduced to those of a child.

headline: Bend, Stretch, Reach, Teach, Reveal, Reflect, Rejoice, Repeat
abstract: A short guide to limiting big regrets on the human journey.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a proposed strategy for sustaining human progress on a finite planet, in nine Twitter posts. What would you add or take away?

lead_paragraph: In the strongest indication yet that the N.H.L. will participate in the next Winter Olympics, the league’s deputy commissioner said Friday that it had drawn up plans to send its players to Sochi, Russia, next February.

headline: Virtual Gold: Recording Association Adds Streams in Handing Out Awards
abstract: The Recording Industry Association of America decides that 100 streams is about the same as one downloaded single.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when a gold-record single was simple to define: You got the designation from the Recording Industry Association of America when you sold 500,000 copies of your record.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Rick Riordan’s “Percy Jackson” series has been on the kids’ list for 287 weeks — the reigning champion, thanks to a recent change in how the lists are assembled.
lead_paragraph: RESETTING THE CLOCK: What current best seller has been on the list the longest? At 287 weeks, the winner is “Percy Jackson & the Olympians,” by Rick Riordan, which you’ll find on the children’s series list at No. 8. Second place goes to “The Devil in the White City,” by Erik Larson, at No. 18 on the paperback nonfiction list after 267 weeks, while another children’s series, Jeff Kinney’s “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” (at No. 3 on that list), has stuck around for 225 weeks.

headline: Regrets Only
abstract: When her husband deserts her, this novel’s protagonist becomes a public relations adviser for sinful celebrities.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to say “I’m sorry”? Increasingly, in this age of ceremonial, highly ritualized apology, it’s hard to distinguish between true remorse and savvy public relations. Jonathan Dee’s sixth novel, “A Thousand Pardons,” was written before Lance Armstrong’s public shaming, but it speaks to something similar in the zeitgeist: the idea of confession as business strategy. Is reputation just a form of capital? What does it mean to apologize publicly for private sins, or privately for public ones? When one person grants another forgiveness, which of them is redeemed?

headline: Mr Porter Taps Top Designers for a Capsule Collection
abstract: Each week through June 4, the top-notch men’s e-tailer will feature collaborations with brands such as Raf Simons and Beams Plus.

headline: Seussian Software
abstract: The Cat in the Hat and other old friends are keeping up with the technological times.
lead_paragraph: Judging by the frequent sight of youngsters grabbing for Mom’s smartphone at the table and toting Dad’s tablet on car trips, it’s a safe assumption that touch screens have captured the attention of many children. But for parents (or grandparents) overwhelmed by the abundance of age-appropriate software, it helps to look for familiar faces in the crowd. Several internationally popular 20th-century children’s book characters have expanded beyond the confines of the printed page into the world of apps.

headline: Eternal Flame
abstract: From the restraints of her Irish childhood to literary stardom — Edna O’Brien reflects on a fraught and distinguished life.
lead_paragraph: “Are you or are you not a good girl?” Edna O’Brien’s mother wants to know. The options are telling; they imply a less-than-even division of territory. Imagine a small saintly island, surrounded by a raging, pagan sea of non-goodness, mortal sin and diabolical decadence. The miniature haven is, of course, Ireland. And at the time Lena O’Brien poses the question, in the early hours of the morning, from the bed in which she has listened for her delinquent daughter’s footsteps, Edna O’Brien has fled the country, at least physically.

headline: Trash and the City
abstract: New York’s sanitation workers are arguably invisible but unquestionably essential, Robin Nagle writes.
lead_paragraph: If the Police Department represents New York’s Finest and the Fire Department New York’s Bravest, what about the Sanitation Department? Could New York’s Strongest also qualify as New York’s Most Invisible? Writing about Sanitation’s “consistent state of not-there-ness,” Robin Nagle comments that workers are “willfully unseen by the public.”

headline: Bad News for Baby
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: A journalist finds flaws in the care of mothers and infants.
lead_paragraph: Americans, you may have noticed, live in a capitalist society. In practical terms, this means someone is often trying to sell us something. John Updike saw a kind of glory in this: “America is a vast conspiracy to make you happy,” he wrote. Jennifer Margulis sees a vast conspiracy too, only its purpose is to make you miserable, sick and quite possibly dead, especially if you are a pregnant woman or a new mother.

headline: Planet Waves
abstract: A British astronomer attempts to signal Mars in Ken Kalfus’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Set in the scorching heat of the Egyptian desert at the end of the 19th century, Ken Kalfus’s new novel follows a fictional British astronomer’s attempt to make contact with Mars. Hundreds of thousands of men are digging the gigantic equilateral triangle with which Sanford Thayer intends to send a signal to his fellow astronomers on the red planet. Once finished, each side will consist of a paved trench more than 300 miles long and exactly one seventy-third of Earth’s circumference. The trenches, five miles wide, are deep enough to be filled with a 12-inch layer of petroleum that will flow from 309 taps connected to a pipeline. The huge black triangle set against the white desert sand will prove the existence of terrestrial intelligence to the Martians, Thayer argues, because the equal-sided triangle is part of the two planets’ “shared knowledge of trigonometry.” The equilateral triangle is, he believes, the “basis for all human art and construction.”

headline: Killing Machine
abstract: Mark Mazzetti argues that the C.I.A. gave up its traditional functions as it embraced manhunting.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to remember, but for the last quarter of the 20th century, the C.I.A. took no part in assassinating bad guys. How the agency transformed itself into “a killing machine, an organization consumed with manhunting,” is the subject of Mark Mazzetti’s fascinating, trenchant, sometimes tragicomic account, “The Way of the Knife.”

headline: The Graduate
abstract: Arnon Grunberg’s hero wants to throw his daughter the best party ever.
lead_paragraph: Pop quiz: you are writing an insightful, strange, funny and dark investigation into a family of four coming together for the younger daughter’s high school graduation. Who will be your point-of-view character?

headline: The Postcolonial
abstract: Albert Camus’s writing on Algeria reveals both hope and dread.
lead_paragraph: Albert Camus was that rare writer who enjoyed a celebrity usually reserved for rock stars, even while being taken very seriously as an artist and a public intellectual. His first novel, “The Stranger,” published in 1942 when he was 29, made him famous; after that came more novels, plays, lyrical essays, short stories, two major philosophical works (“The Myth of Sisyphus” and “The Rebel”), and countless newspaper articles, editorials and political commentaries. In 1957, at age 44, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature, the second-youngest writer ever to receive the prize (after Rud­yard Kipling). Less than three years later, in January 1960, he was killed in a car crash; people the world over mourned.

headline: Spectral Souls
abstract: A collection of short stories by the Russian writer Nikolai Leskov, a contemporary of Dostoyevsky and Tolstoy.
lead_paragraph: Over the past century, the Russian writer Nikolai Leskov (1831-95) has been repeatedly rediscovered. As Richard Pevear points out in the introduction to “The Enchanted Wanderer” — a collection of 17 stories vibrantly translated by Pevear and Larissa ­Volokhonsky — this has happened at least three times. The first rediscovery took place during Leskov’s own lifetime: in the 1880s, after he had suffered for years “an almost total critical neglect,”the young Chekhov hailed his oeuvre, declaring him “a mixture of an elegant Frenchman and a defrocked priest.” Leskov, Chekhov continued, “was considerable.”In the 1920s, the formalist critic Boris Eikhenbaum discerned Leskov’s influence in the work of such diverse writers as Andrei Bely, Isaac Babel and Maxim Gorky, who frankly “declared himself Leskov’s disciple.”And again, at the hands of critics like Walter Benjamin and Irving Howe, Leskov was the subject of yet another revival. “To go back to certain earlier writers is to regain a sense of human possibility,” Howe wrote. “To go back to Leskov is to regain a sense of the passion, sometimes the joy, that can be part of the human enterprise.” Now, thanks to this delicious new collection, the time is once again ripe for Leskov’s resurgence.

headline: Ask Well: Replacing a Dental Crown
abstract: Crowns need not be replaced simply because they are decades-old.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Lost and Found
abstract: A diary washes ashore, linking a teenager in Japan and an author in Canada in Ruth Ozeki’s latest novel.
lead_paragraph: Nao, a 16-year-old schoolgirl, is in a cafe in Tokyo, writing in her diary. She is, she declares, a “time being,” with all the ambiguity that phrase implies. Many months later, after Japan’s devastating earthquake and tsunami, a Japanese-American novelist named Ruth, living on an island off the coast of British Columbia, finds a barnacle-encrusted freezer bag washed up on the beach. It contains, it appears, a copy of Proust’s “In Search of Lost Time” and a broken watch, along with some letters. But Proust’s book is no more than a cover. Inside is Nao’s diary, written in purple ink.

headline: Things Haven’t Gone Exactly as Planned
abstract: In Jennifer Haigh’s linked stories, restlessness and regret loom over a Pennsylvania coal-mining town for generations.
lead_paragraph: “For a certain kind of teenager, a small town is a prison. For another kind, it is a stage.” The speaker is a smart high school girl working at the town’s diner, watching “the athletes and beauty queens who’d blossomed early and fierce,” and the setting is Bakerton, a western Pennsylvania coal-mining town, where Jennifer Haigh’s 2005 novel “Baker Towers” was also set. The 10 stories in “News From Heaven” move chronologically from the town’s modest boom before World War II to its postindustrial depletion as the mines close, one by one:

headline: Late Bloomers
abstract: Jill McCorkle returns to the fictional Fulton, N.C., in her sixth novel.
lead_paragraph: From the knowing grandmother in the novel “Tending to Virginia” to the failing mother stressing out her daughter in the short story “Going Away Shoes,” elderly characters have always played their parts in Jill McCorkle’s small-town, intergenerational fiction. But the “manly voice” with “pipes and whistles in his sound,” as Shakespeare put it, reverberates in its own distinctive fashion in the retirement home setting of McCorkle’s new novel, where the yoga class finds “a whole roomful of old folks breathing deeply and chanting — one sounding like a sewing machine and another a squirrel.”

headline: Packing the Courts
abstract: A primer on the Federalist Society and its extraordinary influence.
lead_paragraph: More than two decades ago, when I was a law student, I used to sneak into meetings of the conservative Federalist Society for lunchtime conversations about constitutional issues. Although neither conservative nor a Republican, I had libertarian leanings and appreciated the society’s openness to debating its political opponents. I felt slightly illicit in crossing ideological lines: once, when the dean spotted me leaving a meeting, I felt as if I’d been caught walking out of an X-rated movie. But the discussions themselves were always intellectually engaging, and my fellow law students seemed more interested in converging around a shared approach to interpreting the Constitution than in squabbling about partisan differences.

headline: NBC News Is Said to Pick a Woman as Its Chief
abstract: Deborah Turness, who worked at ITV News in Britain, would become the first woman to lead the news division at a major network.
lead_paragraph: NBC News is on the verge of naming Deborah Turness, the head of ITV News in Britain, as its next president, according to several people with knowledge of the appointment.

headline: The One Least Likely
abstract: Brandon Sanderson’s hero longs to join a magical cadre.
lead_paragraph: There’s always a boy, and there’s always a girl. They may not like each other at first, but they find a way to work together. Friendship always blossoms, sometimes romance. There’s a society they have to fight against and a secret to uncover that changes the world. They win in the end, though there’s heartbreak along the way and more danger ahead.

headline: What Price Beauty?
abstract: The plain heroine of Paul Rudnick’s novel is transformed.
lead_paragraph: When I was 5 years old, my mother explained the world to me: “Beauty is pain,” she said, yanking my hair into submission with Dippity Do-slimed fingers and some bobby pins. If I didn’t sleep in scalp-scraping pin curls to look my best for Sunday school, the terrorists would win.

headline: Over, Under and Through
abstract: There’s never a dull moment for the explorers in these picture books.
lead_paragraph: Spring is for busting out and rediscovering the world, so these four picture books come along just in time to help kids do some exploring — from the backyard to overseas to underseas to outer space — and they all let the visuals lead the charge.

headline: Endangered Daughters
abstract: In far-flung regions, two girls’ dreams are impeded by family obligations.
lead_paragraph: Middle-grade and adult fiction share territory largely ignored by young adult literature: the exploration of countries and eras beyond the borders of the contemporary teenager’s navel. Two new middle-grade novels, “The Vine Basket,” by Josanne La Valley, and “A Girl Called Problem,” by Katie Quirk, are set, respectively, in a Uighur community in Central Asia and rural Tanzania in the late 1960s.

headline: The Playing’s the Thing
abstract: A girl pushed into musical excellence confronts her own desires.
lead_paragraph: Leopold Mozart shuttled Wolfgang Amadeus around Europe for years, parading his son in front of endless royalty to secure commissions and performances. More than two centuries later, a bullying stage father helped propel the Chinese pianist Lang Lang to superstardom.

headline: The Stuff of Legend
abstract: Norse mythology and the occult intrude on the modern world in these tales.
lead_paragraph: Want to write a middle-grade fantasy adventure series? It’s easy! First, conjure up a plucky, prickly team of three — children who have to learn to trust one another and work together. Make the stakes really high; saving the world is always good. Use lots of wisecracking humor. Ensure the parents are absent (dead, missing, away — you’ll figure it out). Invoke classic themes and figures from folklore and mythology, but don’t bother becoming slavishly wedded to them. Be sure to include an intellectually or physically butt-kicking girl.

headline: Rites of Passage
abstract: A multigenerational series by the creator of the Baby-Sitters Club.
lead_paragraph: For some girls who grew up in suburbia in the ’80s and early ’90s, the defining cultural touchstone of the time might be New Kids on the Block or “Saved by the Bell.” For me, it’s “The Baby-Sitters Club,” Ann M. Martin’s block­buster middle-grade series.

headline: Fragile Things
abstract: Three friends must lay a ghost to rest in Holly Black’s latest novel.
lead_paragraph: In Holly Black’s newest middle-grade novel, “Doll Bones,” the main characters, Zach, Poppy and Alice, are at that intermediate stage between childhood and adolescence, when alliances shift and friendships subtly develop into something more, when children outgrow identities as quickly as they outgrow clothing, when boys and girls sometimes appear awkwardly patched together with emotional and physical features from various stages of development, like an evolutionary experiment gone haywire. For years, the three best friends have played a continuous, ever evolving game of make-believe embracing fictional kingdoms, characters and allegiances, using toy figurines and hastily assembled objects to stand in for the real thing. The Queen, a porcelain doll with vacant eyes and blond ringlet curls, presides over the kingdoms from her position in Poppy’s mom’s glassed-in cabinet.

headline: Ordinary Courage
abstract: In a novel set in 1944, a family in Florence aids the partisans.
lead_paragraph: Historical fiction has an interesting place in the world of children’s literature. Regularly celebrated by adults with awards like the Newbery, these books nonetheless raise the question of whether the intended audience feels the same enthusiasm. What I’ve observed as a classroom teacher is that while not in the multitudes that flock to the goofy fun of Wimpy Kid or the wild fantasies of Percy Jackson, there are still plenty of young readers who can’t get enough of the past.

headline: Uneven Field
abstract: A 14-year-old rugby player pines for an older classmate.
lead_paragraph: Of all the young adult genres — the Dystopian Hellscape, the ­Human-Monster Romance, the Elite School-or-Camp for Nonmortals — the most popular right now may be the quietest: Aspiring John Green. GreenLit, as I like to call it, consists of realistic stories told by a funny, self-aware teenage narrator. These novels tend to have sharp dialogue, defective authority figures, occasional boozing, unrequited crushes and one or more heartbreaking twists.

headline: Make No Mistake
abstract: A teenage boy, who is caught acting as his brother’s drug courier, is sent to a juvenile detention center.
lead_paragraph: James, a scrawny, thoughtful 15-year-old, is trapped in brutal penury in upstate New York. His father walked out long ago. His defeated mother, a barely functioning cocktail waitress, has brought home an abusive addict of a boyfriend. And his older brother, Louis, who left in a fury, is a muscle-bound drug dealer whom the police have in their sights.

headline: All in the Family
abstract: Three picture books look at intergenerational relationships.
lead_paragraph: Extended family is not in the full-time business of being your family, and that is mostly to their advantage. They visit, they leave — even when they live with you, it is rarely forever.

headline: The Stratospherians
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Luxury Goods', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: For the very rich, a sky-high apartment can top the must-have list.
lead_paragraph: No sooner do acquisitive urbanites negotiate their peace with the manic pulse of New York City than some escape it without actually leaving. The strategy is an aggressively vertical lifestyle, and prescient developers are enabling it.

headline: Common Core Practice | Hit Films, Glowing Trees and an Underwater Menagerie
abstract: Three recent STEM-related articles that inspired simple student projects exploring video design and gaming.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Mrs. Gross, Mr. Olsen and their students explored how they might pair Times content with basic computer coding to practice Common Core skills. This week they show how the news and the standards can be jumping-off points for exploring video design and gaming.

headline: Married With Children, a Dedication That Held It All Together
abstract: For Lola and Bill Keyes, working on the “we” in their relationship has helped their marriage last 32 years.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Gatsby in a Duesenberg? More Fiction
abstract: The new movie of the Fitzgerald book shows Jay Gatsby driving a Duesenberg. Good luck finding a mention of that car in the book.
lead_paragraph: Jay Gatsby, the mysterious title character of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The Great Gatsby,” fancied luxury cars, but he would not have been driving a 1929 Duesenberg Model J.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: HOUSE OF STONE: A Memoir of Home, Family, and a Lost Middle East,  by Anthony Shadid. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) In 2006, after years spent covering the Iraq war, Shadid began renovating the abandoned house of his great-grandfather in the Lebanese town of Marjayoun. (A correspondent for The New York Times, Shadid died last year while reporting from Syria.) This elegiac memoir combines stories of Shadid’s struggles with workmen, tales of his ancestors and their world, and reflections on his family’s journey to America.

headline: Considering the Universe From Deep in West Texas
abstract: In its 34th year, the Texas Star Party drew more than 500 amateur astronomers from across the United States and Canada to gaze together into the vast open skies.
lead_paragraph: FORT DAVIS, Tex. — With a lime-green fleece blanket over his shoulders, Samuel David, 10, of Houston, bounced on his toes as dusk raced over the mountains. Attending his first Texas Star Party this week with his family, Samuel could not wait for a rare phenomenon in a lighted-up, night-denying world — a sky full of nothing but stars.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: A DELICATE TRUTH,  by John le Carré. (Viking, $28.95.) Le Carré seems to hold the moral relativism of his old cold-war heroes up to a harsh light in his 23rd novel, in which — to the benefit of a private American security firm — “war’s gone corporate.”

headline: The Demented Imagineer
abstract: Paul McCarthy may qualify as one of the grand old men of the art world, but his vision is perverse as ever — and much, much bigger.
lead_paragraph: “Now, I see this as pantsless,” the artist Paul McCarthy announced one winter morning to a group of male actors standing at the edge of a massive soundstage in a warehouse east of downtown Los Angeles, flanked by a plumbing supply and an auto impound yard. Normally, McCarthy looks like a hipster carpenter, broad and bandylegged, with gnarled fingers and wiry white hair poking out around his baseball cap. But this morning he was nearly unrecognizable in a tuxedo and gray toupee, a regal prosthetic nose glued over a neatly trimmed mustache.

headline: Singing Proust
abstract: Kelli O’Hara sings the love song “If It Is True,” accompanied on piano by composer Ricky Ian Gordon. Gordon’s music was inspired by the work of Marcel Proust.
lead_paragraph: Kelli O’Hara sings the love song “If It Is True,” accompanied on piano by composer Ricky Ian Gordon. Gordon’s music was inspired by the work of Marcel Proust.

headline: Rummaging Among Skins and Skulls
abstract: Sometimes you have to leave the forest for the museum — boxes with slow loris skeletons have as much to tell as the trees.
lead_paragraph: Mary E. Blair is a postdoctoral researcher in the American Museum of Natural History’s Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, where she coordinates the Enhancing Diversity in Conservation Science Initiative.

headline: Getting the Full Picture on Annuities and Insurance
abstract: While there are tax advantages to permanent life insurance or an annuity, fees and penalties can erase gains.
lead_paragraph: LIFE insurance and annuities are supposed to accomplish straightforward goals: life insurance provides for your family if you die unexpectedly and annuities guarantee a steady stream of income in retirement. But right now, both are being promoted for their tax benefits.

headline: When Taxes Aren’t the Only Consideration
abstract: Bucks readers discuss their experience in buying life insurance or annuities.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week is about the marketing of two straightforward financial products — life insurance and annuities — for their tax benefits. As Paul has written before, the increase in taxes this year is prompting many people to make taxes their priority — it’s determining what to invest in or how to set up their estate or buying life insurance — when taxes should be only one factor in the decision.

headline: Set to Lead, From the Podium Anyway
abstract: James Levine returns to the podium after an extended break caused by back injuries, but questions remain about his role at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: It’s one week and counting until James Levine’s return to the podium.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Origins of World War I and More
abstract: This week, Harold Evans discusses two new books about the events leading up to World War I; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Pamela Paul talks about the spring children’s books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Harold Evans discusses two new books about the events leading up to World War I; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Pamela Paul talks about the spring children’s books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: If You Knew Then What You Know Now
abstract: When you live in a foreign country, a lot more than you might have expected can be foreign. Was there one piece of advice you wished you had had before you moved? Is there one invaluable source of information about your adopted city or country that you would recommend?
lead_paragraph: When you live in a foreign country, a lot more than you might have expected can be foreign.

headline: In Big-Dollar Philanthropy, (Your Name Here) vs. Anonymity
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Religion and Belief', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Why do so many donors ask that buildings and professorships be named after them? Judeo-Christian tradition cautions against self-promotion.
lead_paragraph: One hundred million dollars. As The New York Times reported this week, that’s how much Ronald O. Perelman pledged to Columbia University for the planned Ronald O. Perelman Center for Business Innovation. It’s the amount Stephen A. Schwarzman promised to the New York Public Library, which renamed its main building after him.

headline: Kicking Off Uncomfortable Toe Shoes
abstract: Pam Tanowitz returns to her usual strain of modern choreography in “The Spectators,” after an attempt at a more classical ballet turned out bone dry.
lead_paragraph: For the past year, Pam Tanowitz has been haunted by a ballet. Her own.

headline: Blind Teenagers Compete in Pole Vault
abstract: The legally blind students Charlotte Brown and Aria Ottmueller practice and compete in the pole vault.
lead_paragraph: The legally blind students Charlotte Brown and Aria Ottmueller practice and compete in the pole vault.

headline: It’s Just Another Hurdle for Blind Athletes
keywords: ['Pole Vault', 'Blindness', 'Disabilities', 'Track and Field', 'Interscholastic Athletics', 'Education (K-12)', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Aria Ottmueller, 17, and Charlotte Brown, 15, are pole vaulting in their high school state meets this weekend, further redefining the able-bodied athlete.
lead_paragraph: CHANDLER, Ariz. — Holding a fiberglass pole, Aria Ottmueller bent and touched the runway to locate her starting mark. A coach helped position her front foot. The foam vaulting pit at her high school appeared only as a blue smudge. The crossbar was invisible to her.

headline: In Nature | Room With a View
abstract: When booking a place to stay, don’t think only about location and beautiful rooms. Consider this crop of hotels that include stunning gardens on their list of luxurious amenities.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most thrilling nuances of a great landscape only become apparent in the brightness of dawn or when the afternoon light casts sharp shadows. But since many of the best gardens are private, gaining access to them at these magic hours can be a challenge. Thankfully, this is changing, as hoteliers across the globe have tapped major landscape architects to plant and design the greenery around their hotels. The result: a set of properties with outdoor spaces that are destinations in and of themselves. From the manicured grounds of a manor house in the Cotswolds, to a walled courtyard in Stockholm, to a working Cape Dutch farm in South Africa (and even to the lush tropicals planted by Arnaud MauriËres and Eric Ossart at Dar Al Hossoun in Morocco), these are gardens worth traveling for.

headline: Student Debt Slows Growth as Young Spend Less
abstract: The anemic economy has left millions struggling to get ahead. Student debt is making it even harder for many of them, as they delay purchases of things like homes and cars.
lead_paragraph: The anemic economy has left millions of younger working Americans struggling to get ahead. The added millstone of student loan debt, which recently exceeded $1 trillion in total, is making it even harder for many of them, delaying purchases of things like homes, cars and other big-ticket items and acting as a drag on growth, economists said.

headline: Think of It This Way: Stairs Are an Amenity
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Christian and Sofia Hasselberg wanted to live in the West Village or on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Having visited Manhattan on several occasions, Sofia and Christian Hasselberg of Stockholm knew New York was one place they wished to live.

headline: Own a Mysterious Artifact? Go Show It to a Scientist
abstract: Tomorrow is Identification Day, the American Museum of Natural History’s annual spoiler fest at which scientists and anthropologists examine your mysterious objects and tell you what it might be.
lead_paragraph: Life is full of mysteries. Some lives are full of mysterious objects. The necklace-looking thing you found on the beach that looks as if it probably came from an animal or maybe a plant. That rock your grandfather always told you was a meteorite. The dead turtle in a box on your desk — bog turtle or box turtle?

headline: A ‘Cagney & Lacey’ With Constables
abstract: Amelia Bullmore, Suranne Jones and Lesley Sharp play investigators in Manchester, England, in “Scott & Bailey,” a television hit in Britain.
lead_paragraph: One of the more interesting crime dramas currently on either side of the Atlantic started with a concept that was only about three decades old.

headline: Garbled Noise, Playful Blues and Whispery Echoes
abstract: New CDs by the Fall, Pharmakon, Donald Brown, Ceramic Dog and an Icelandic duo.
lead_paragraph: The Fall

headline: TowerBrook to Purchase True Religion Apparel for $835 Million
abstract: The buyout by the private equity firm underscores the rise of premium-priced jeans as a high-fashion staple and status symbol.
lead_paragraph: It’s a high-priced deal for high-priced denim.

headline: “Maxwell”
abstract: A new song by Terre Roche.
lead_paragraph: A new song by Terre Roche.

headline: In a Pickle
abstract: The Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman offers recipes for pickling less conventional vegetables.
lead_paragraph: Barbecue season is just around the corner, which means that it’s time to break out the Mason jars and make some crisp, briny pickles to accompany your smoky sandwiches and slaw. But why should pickling be relegated to cucumbers alone? In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman writes:

headline: The Gun Report: May 10, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that some sex offenders in Iowa can openly carry guns? An astute reader pointed us to this recent exclusive in The Des Moines Register, which revealed that 50 sex offenders in Iowa are currently carrying a gun in public. It’s news that has surprised some state lawmakers and alarmed a few Iowa and national law enforcement officers, Jason Clayworth reported.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Tyler Brûlé and Jan Morris
abstract: A dual review of what’s new, by magazine impresario Tyler Brûlé and Welsh historian Jan Morris.
lead_paragraph: A dual review of what’s new, by magazine impresario Tyler Brûlé and Welsh historian Jan Morris. See the chart, and watch the stop-motion airplane safety video for VistaJet, below.

headline: Hip-Hop Stars as Disposable Spokesmen
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the conflicts between commercial interests and art in several recent cases of rappers losing corporate endorsement deals over their edgy content.
lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the conflicts between commercial interests and art in several recent cases of rappers losing corporate endorsement deals over their edgy content.

headline: United Nations Agency to Discuss Internet Governance Again
abstract: Remember that international debate about government control of the Internet? It’s back.
lead_paragraph: Here we go again. The United Nations is trying to take over the Internet! Or maybe it isn’t.

headline: A Pioneer, Reluctantly
abstract: Fallon Fox is the first openly transgender athlete in mixed martial arts and the most prominent in a professional sport in decades.
lead_paragraph: SCHAUMBURG, Ill. — Fallon Fox climbed inside the steel cage, past the sign that read “The Beating Will Continue,” and onto a black mat. She followed right jabs with left hooks and kicks flung at imaginary kneecaps, safe, if only for a moment, from the questions and insults and the suffocating fame that descended overnight.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Everyone’s Nostalgia
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about how we’re permanently nostalgic for everything: music, clothing, our own lives, and now, the World Wide Web.
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about how we’re permanently nostalgic for everything: music, clothing, our own lives, and now, the World Wide Web.

headline: Rescue in Bangladesh
abstract: How a woman trapped beneath the rubble of a collapsed building in Bangladesh was able to survive for over two weeks before being rescued.
lead_paragraph: How a woman trapped beneath the rubble of a collapsed building in Bangladesh was able to survive for over two weeks before being rescued.

headline: Airplane Safety Video
abstract: Tom Sachs and Van Neistat's stop-motion safety video for VistaJet.
lead_paragraph: Tom Sachs and Van Neistat's stop-motion safety video for VistaJet.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Stratford, Ontario; Nashville; Venice
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the world curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Venice Biennale This biennial exhibition, dedicated to chronicling contemporary art, opens June 1, with artists’ works (colorful gondolas from 2011, above) showcased in pavilions divided according to country. Angola, Maldives and the Republic of Kosovo are among the 10 countries that will participate for the first time in the exhibition, which spreads across the Giardini park and the winding galleries of the Arsenale.

headline: How to Stop Government
abstract: A field guide to obstruction.
lead_paragraph: In a recent Pew Poll, 80 percent of respondents said the president and Republican leaders were not working together to address important issues — and, by a two-to-one margin, said the G.O.P. was more to blame for gridlock.

headline: Obama to Bookend Group of Eight Summit With Belfast and Berlin Visits
abstract: President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, will make a three-day trip to the United Kingdom and Germany around the G-8 summit in June.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, will make a three-day trip to the United Kingdom and Germany around the Group of Eight summit in June, the White House said Friday.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Origins of World War I
abstract: Harold Evans talks about two new books that explore the events leading up to the war.
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Harold Evans reviews two new books about the complicated web of events leading up to World War I: “The Sleepwalkers,” by Christopher Clark, and “July 1914,” by Sean McMeekin. Mr. Evans writes:

headline: Wheelies: The Best-Car-Ever Edition
abstract: Consumer Reports says the Tesla Model S is the best car it has ever tested, and Aston Martin may team up with Daimler A.G.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Dream Is a Wish Your Id Makes
abstract: Walt Disney’s insistence on steamrolling over, or editing out, those aspects of the world that did not fit his vision is one aspect of him that Lucas Hnath explores in his new play.
lead_paragraph: There’s certainly a twinkle in Uncle Walt’s blue eyes, but it’s not the glimmer of benevolence you’d expect from the man who brought joy to countless children as the creator of Mickey Mouse and the Magic Kingdom.

headline: Hey Mom, Call Me When You Find My Wife
keywords: ['Dating and Courtship', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Online Dating']
abstract: Some think they are entitled to help in the choice of a mate because marriage unites not only a man and a woman, but two families.
lead_paragraph: Some mothers — and some fathers, too — will do just about anything to see their marriage-age offspring settle down, even if that means going where parents ordinarily should never go — online and into their children’s posted dating profiles.

headline: Heat-Trapping Gas Passes Milestone, Raising Fears
abstract: The amount of the gas in the air has not been this high for at least three million years, and scientists believe the rise portends large changes in the climate and sea level.
lead_paragraph: The level of the most important heat-trapping gas in the atmosphere, carbon dioxide, has passed a long-feared milestone, scientists reported Friday, reaching a concentration not seen on the earth for millions of years.

headline: Sport Gains Hoofhold on a Scholastic Level
abstract: The United States Polo Association is trying to make polo financially feasible for everyday college and high school students who want to play.
lead_paragraph: Many polo players will tell you that it is not really the horses that most effectively propel them across the field, it is the adrenaline.

headline: Popcast: Hip-Hop Stars as Disposable Spokesmen
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss several recent cases of rappers losing corporate endorsement deals over their edgy content.
lead_paragraph: Advertisers, theoretically, love hip-hop. They love it until it gets loud and messy, challenges taste and morals, causes offense. And then advertisers pull away.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Going Way Back
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about how we’re permanently nostalgic for everything: music, clothing, our own lives, and now, the World Wide Web.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about how we’re permanently nostalgic for everything: music, clothing, our own lives, and now, the World Wide Web.

headline: Technology as a Driver of Growth (or Not)
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: A new study looks at why the divide between rich and poor nations remains so large in an age when technologies spread so much more quickly.
lead_paragraph: 4:21 p.m. | Updated with table on relative adoption levels.

headline: Charles Read’s Raider
abstract: The unlikely story of a Confederate captain who terrorized East Coast shipping.
lead_paragraph: On May 6, 1863, the same day that Gen. Joseph Hooker’s Union Army retreated northward over the Rappahannock River following defeat at Chancellorsville, Va., Second Lt. Charles Read of the Confederate commerce raider Florida began one of the most astonishing adventures of the war.

headline: Caregiver and Patient, Bound by Blood and Whining
abstract: “The Memory Show,” a musical, reflects the tensions of caring for someone with Alzheimer’s disease — and being someone with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: “We’re on the same side.”

headline: Rangers’ Staal Says He Decided to Sit Out Game 4
abstract: Rangers defenseman Marc Staal missed 29 games after a puck struck him in the right eye in March, but he returned for Game 3, but then did not dress for Game 4.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaking to reporters for the first time since his surprising absence from Game 4 because of the lingering effects of an eye injury, defenseman Marc Staal explained Friday that it was his decision to sit out, and that he was not sure when he would come back.

headline: Russian Revelation
abstract: The Moscow designer Vika Gazinskaya is making a name for herself, finding inspiration even in the unexpected.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a woman in Florida contacted Vika Gazinskaya, a designer in Moscow, and bought $12,000 worth of clothes. Ms. Gazinskaya’s designs can be seen online, and purchased at Net-a-Porter, Moda Operandi and the Manhattan boutique Fivestory, as well as Forty Five Ten in Dallas. Maybe it didn’t occur to the Florida woman to contact those outlets, or maybe there were sizing or availability issues, but she ended up writing a letter to the designer.

headline: A Social Media View of the Davos of Hedge Funds
abstract: A look at some of the social media dispatches from SALT conference in Las Vegas. The SkyBridge Alternatives Conference brings together more than 1,800 wealthy investors and hedge funds for four days of conferences, concerts and revelry.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the social media dispatches from SALT conference in Las Vegas. The SkyBridge Alternatives Conference brings together more than 1,800 wealthy investors and hedge funds for four days of conferences, concerts and revelry.

headline: A Creative Partnership, in Life and in Art
abstract: Two creative people, both pursuing expression and abstraction in their work, find that they have even more in common.
lead_paragraph: The first time Yotam Haber was introduced to Anna Schuleit, in 2010 at the MacDowell artists retreat in Peterborough, N.H., she was helping a fellow artist bend steel spikes over a flame. She wore a bandanna over her blond hair and seemed utterly dedicated to her task — so much so that she took no notice of him. Still, he thought “she had an aura.”

headline: Singer Accused of Trying to Hire Hitman Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Tim Lambesis, the lead singer of As I Lay Dying, had bail set at $3 million.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors say the lead singer of the band As I Lay Dying, who is accused of trying to hire someone to kill his estranged wife, handed an envelope containing $1,000 in cash to an undercover officer, along with instructions, a photograph, an address, security gate codes and dates when he would have an alibi, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Mockumentary Digs for Roots
abstract: When Christopher Guest has his director’s hat on droll is generally the order of the day.
lead_paragraph: When Christopher Guest has his director’s hat on, as for films like “Best in Show” and “A Mighty Wind,” droll is generally the order of the day. He carries that tradition to the small screen with “Family Tree,” a new comedy series that he created with Jim Piddock, which has its premiere Sunday night on HBO. The show, shot mockumentary style, centers on a 30-year-old named Tom Chadwick (Chris O’Dowd) who inherits a trunk that is full of family memorabilia. He begins poking through it and tries to learn more about the family members he encounters, beginning in the premiere with the man in full uniform whose photograph he finds.

headline: Indie in Brooklyn, Electric in Queens
abstract: It’s May, and dueling outdoor festivals have arrived.
lead_paragraph: It’s May, and dueling outdoor festivals have arrived. There’s a clear aesthetic choice — synthetic and transnational versus handmade and local — between Electric Daisy Carnival, at Citi Field on Friday and Saturday, and the Great Googa Mooga Festival, in Prospect Park Friday to Sunday. Electric Daisy presents more than 80 electronic dance music acts on five stages in and around the stadium. Trance, house, techno and dubstep dominate the lineup, with acts like Steve Angello, Dirty South, Afrojack, Richie Hawtin and 12th Planet. (electricdaisycarnival.com; two-day tickets are $239.83 general admission, one-day $132.05.)

headline: Sweden and Israel Via Chicago
abstract: When it comes to trendy, glamorous repertory, it’s hard to think of an American company as well stocked as Hubbard Street Dance Chicago.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to trendy, glamorous repertory, it’s hard to think of an American company as well stocked as Hubbard Street Dance Chicago. The list of choreographers who have worked with this immaculately technical group reads like an international who’s who of contemporary dance. Take, for instance, Sweden’s Mats Ek, revered in Europe but rarely seen in the United States; Aszure Barton, originally from Alberta, Canada; and Israel’s Ohad Naharin, the director of the Batsheva Dance Company, whose improvisation method, Gaga, has a global following.

headline: From Romanticism To Apocalypse
abstract: As a guest conductor, Mr. Rattle will lead the orchestra in its Carnegie Hall concert on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Though the conductor Simon Rattle’s work has been defined for over a decade by his adventurous tenure as principal conductor of the great Berlin Philharmonic, he has continued to maintain associations with other important ensembles, especially the Philadelphia Orchestra. As a guest conductor, Mr. Rattle will lead the orchestra in its Carnegie Hall concert on Friday night. The program opens with Webern’s Passacaglia, Op. 1, a glittering score written in 1908 when the composer was in his mid-20s and still under the allure of lush, late Romanticism. Then Mr. Rattle conducts Three Fragments from Berg’s opera “Wozzeck.”

headline: New Cooking Show on Fox to Feature Children as Chefs
abstract: The new show, “Junior Masterchef,” will be one of five reality shows from Gordon Ramsay on the network.
lead_paragraph: How else to tinker with cooking reality shows? How about putting children in the kitchen?

headline: At Met, Park Views Big and Small
abstract: This year’s exhibition on the Met’s roof garden, which opens Tuesday, is also a study in perspective.
lead_paragraph: In 1998 when Ellsworth Kelly became the first living artist to exhibit on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he called the picture-postcard setting “an instant background.” When his sculptures — as tall as 14 feet — were installed there they looked enormous and the skyscrapers behind them tiny. Mr. Kelly compared this reversal of scale to Chinese landscape painting in the way it played with perspective.

headline: Judge Refuses to Drop His Order Allowing Morning-After Pill for All Ages
abstract: In a scathing ruling, the judge said the process of denying broad distribution of the drug has been “corrupted by political interference” for years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday stepped up his criticism of the Obama administration, accusing the Justice Department of making “frivolous” and “silly” arguments in its attempt to delay making the morning-after emergency contraceptive pill available to women and girls of all ages without a prescription.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. to Investigate Corvette Headlight Failures
abstract: N.H.T.S.A. may investigate a problem with Corvette low-beam headlights.
lead_paragraph: After receiving complaints from owners of 2005-7 Chevrolet Corvettes about low-beam headlights failing, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is opening an investigation, according to a report posted on the agency’s Web site. The action comes as the agency continues to mull over whether to investigate low-beam failures on about 248,000 General Motors crossovers.

headline: Early Salvos From ‘Bloody Sam’
abstract: Two new DVDs — “The Deadly Companions” from VCI Entertainment and “Major Dundee” from Twilight Time — present Sam Peckinpah at two stages in his development.
lead_paragraph: Sam Peckinpah’s life, like many of his movies, ended in a kind of apocalyptic debacle. Too many arguments with producers, too much alcohol-fueled misbehavior and (always the real problem) too many disappointments at the box office had rendered the director of “The Wild Bunch” (1969) effectively unemployable by the time he died in 1984, at 59.

headline: Small-Batch Pulled Pork
abstract: Melissa Clark demonstrates a way to make tender pulled pork slathered in a tangy barbecue sauce for a smaller crowd.

headline: Tasting ‘Modern Hungarian’ in Budapest
abstract: Chefs are energizing the culinary scene in the capital by transforming Hungarian ingredients and serving up vibrant new flavors.
lead_paragraph: Budapest is a city of coat-takers. Walk into any restaurant, no matter how humble, and you will barely be through the door before someone is graciously easing you out of your wrap. That warm hospitality, coupled with menus filled with creamy soups and meaty stews, can make dining in this city feel like stepping back in time. But all is not so sepia-tinged. A movement that began several years ago toward lighter and brighter food, served in more modern environs, has been gathering steam.

headline: Food Matters | When Eating and Art Became One
abstract: The artist-run SoHo restaurant FOOD, which is being revived this weekend at Frieze New York, was revolutionary a generation ago. Now it’s the norm.
lead_paragraph: A few months before the artists Carol Goodden and Gordon Matta-Clark opened their restaurant-slash-art installation, FOOD, on the corner of Prince and Wooster Streets in New York City in the fall of 1971, they roasted a pig beneath the Brooklyn Bridge. Alanna Heiss, who would soon found P.S.1, installed work by Matta-Clark, Carl Andre, Sol Le Witt and Keith Sonnier in a raw, junk-filled space. On nearby Pier 14, Philip Glass performed and the year-old avant-garde theater company Mabou Mines staged a Samuel Beckett play. The artist Tina Girouard, who would cook at FOOD during its nearly three-year run, helped out with the hog. “The pig burnt on the outside,” she recalled, “and raw on the inside.”

headline: How Cooper Union’s Endowment Failed in Its Mission
abstract: Cooper Union recently announced that it would begin charging tuition, a decision made after decades of bad financial choices and recent treacherous markets.
lead_paragraph: Since Peter Cooper’s heirs gave the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art the land under the Chrysler Building in 1902, the school’s endowment has enabled it to offer students a high-quality, tuition-free education through two world wars, the Great Depression and multiple stock market crashes and financial crises.

headline: A Jay-Z Sighting … in 1939 Harlem
abstract: A man in an old photo found in the New York Public Library’s vast collection bears a striking resemblance to the hi-hop mogul, and the discovery isn’t the first of the library’s pictures to cause a double take.
lead_paragraph: Yes, the New York Public Library swears, the old photo of the guy who looks scarily like Jay-Z really is an unretouched, un-Photoshopped image from 1939. “We’re 100 percent certain it’s legitimate,” Adenike Olanrewaju, a library spokeswoman, said on Friday. Here’s the original:
