headline: Pulled Pork, for Crowds Large or Small
abstract: Melissa Clark’s recipe can be doubled to feed more.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s column and video, I give a recipe for a small batch of pulled pork. Instead of the usual 7-pound bone-in hunk of meat, I use a 3-pound chunk. That said, if you want to use the same recipe with the larger cut, you certainly can. Double the spice rub and barbecue sauce, and if you love coleslaw, consider making one and a half times that recipe. You will very likely need to cook the meat longer. Just check it every 30 minutes or so after the four-hour mark, and when it reaches an internal temperature of 200 degrees, it’s done. The recipe for pulled pork is here.

headline: Katherine Boo’s ‘Beautiful Forevers’ Headed to the Stage
abstract: David Hare’s adaptation of Ms. Boo’s award-winning book will be produced by London’s National Theater in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Boo brought the Annawadi slum to vivid life in “Behind the Beautiful Forevers: Life, Death, and Hope in a Mumbai Undercity,” one of the most acclaimed books of 2012. The National Theater in London hopes to do the same in a stage version of the book next year.

headline: A Parade of Vintage Trains, Unnoticed in the Harlem Night
abstract: A collection of privately owned train cars made their way to Grand Central late Thursday night, though Harlem appeared unmoved.
lead_paragraph: The trains lurched through the Harlem darkness, rattling above an all-night pawnshop, a swell of reggaetón music and a man in a headdress, squawking from his bicycle.

headline: ‘Great Gatsby’  Is Poised for a  Strong Opening, No Thanks to Critics
abstract: The box numbers from Thursday’s late night screenings indicate a first weekend that could be the most successful in Baz Luhrmann’s directing career.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As very early box-office numbers for “The Great Gatsby” rolled in — a strong $3.25 million from the Thursday late-night shows, Warner Brothers said on Friday morning — it was already becoming clear that the audience has a mind of its own.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: Santa Teresa, a Venezuelan rum producer, will conduct four free tastings of its flagship rum, Santa Teresa 1796, at Union Square Wines and Spirits, 140 Fourth Avenue. The rum will be served neat, on the rocks and in cocktails. The first session is on Friday from 6 to 9 p.m., paired with chocolates for Mother’s Day. The three other sessions are on May 17, 24 and 31.

headline: An Eclectic Automotive Wish List From ‘Counting Cars’
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobiles', 'Reality Television', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Television']
abstract: If you’ve seen History’s “Counting Cars,” you may be surprised by the list of cars Danny Koker said he would like to have.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve seen “Counting Cars,” the reality show on the A&E Network’s History, you’re used to the sight of Danny Koker, known as the Count, and his best buddy, Kevin Mack, cruising the streets of Las Vegas in search of restoration projects for their Count’s Kustoms shop. They spot old cars and trucks in parking lots, peeking out of garages and sometimes even cruising in the next lane. Some they restore and pass on to new owners whose smiling faces are displayed prominently on the show. Other cars Mr. Koker keeps; he owns at least 58 cars and 10 motorcycles.

headline: Health Law Is Defended With Vigor by President
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: President Obama told consumers not to be fooled by misinformation and said access to care was a right he would defend.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama came out fighting in defense of his health care law on Friday, saying that he was “110 percent committed” to delivering its benefits on schedule, and that consumers should not be bamboozled by critics spreading misinformation about the law.

headline: A Brazilian Designer Finally Gets Her Due in New York
abstract: Claudia Moreira Salles will have a show in TriBeCa, her first solo exhibition outside Brazil, after creating furniture and interiors for than three decades.
lead_paragraph: Brazilian designers have reached higher levels of recognition (and sales) lately, but for every Oscar Niemeyer and Sergio Rodrigues there are flocks of Brazilian designers flying under the radar. Claudia Moreira Salles could be considered a real find by many, despite more than 30 years’ creating furniture and interiors for architects including Ricardo Legorreta and projects like the rooftop bar of the Hotel Americano in Chelsea.

headline: A Tongue Made for Slurping
abstract: How does Pallas’s long-tongued bat collect nectar mid-flight? Using a long, barb-lined tongue, of course.
lead_paragraph: How does Pallas’s long-tongued bat collect nectar mid-flight? Using a long, barb-lined tongue, of course.

headline: Tables Inspired by African Stools
abstract: The designers behind the firm Grain branch out from personal accessories to furniture, introducing two versions of their Dish table at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair.
lead_paragraph: Though they’ve been in business for five years, the product designers behind Grain, a firm based on Bainbridge Island off the Seattle coast, have only just gotten around to doing furniture. Before this, the team — Chelsea Green, 32, and James Minola, 30 — designed what they call “personal accessories,” like a recyclable shower curtain and a hand mirror. At the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, May 18to 21 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, they plan to introduce two versions of their Dish table (one is a side table, the other a coffee table). The models were hand-carved African stools that Ms. Green received from her parents and grandparents, who grew up in Africa (her father was born in Nigeria; her mother lived for a time in Ethiopia and Ghana). “We were a bit inspired by the scooped-out shape but wanted it to be more functional, so we flattened it out and cleaned it up a bit,” she said. The tables are made of ash and available in either a clear oil finish or black stain; the side table is $1,950, and the coffee table is $2,500. Grain also plans to present a new mirror and candlesticks at the fair. Information: (206) 965-9302 or graindesign.com.

headline: A Strong Response to Paying Board Nominees
abstract: Eight partners at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are proposing that company boards consider adopting a bylaw prohibiting shareholder activists from compensating director nominees.
lead_paragraph: The stakes just got higher for shareholder activists.

headline: Tongue Like a Mop
abstract: One species of bat has evolved a way to eat while flying.
lead_paragraph: Certain bats, like Pallas’s long-tongued bat, hover over flowers and suck nectar. Hovering takes a lot of energy, so the bats need to gather as much liquid as possible with each flick of their long tongues. Scientists have long known that hairlike structures known as papillae at the tips of the bats’ tongues help trap the nectar. Now, using high-speed video cameras, researchers at Brown University have seen that as the tongues extend, the papillae flare outward, becoming perpendicular.

headline: Kiefer Sutherland and Fox Ratings
abstract: The actor’s Fox drama “Touch” steadily lost viewers, but its exit has inspired talk of a return to “24.”
lead_paragraph: Fans of the Fox drama “Touch,” which stars Kiefer Sutherland, would be wise to savor the Season 2 finale on Friday. A day before, the network announced that this episode would in fact be the series finale.

abstract: Food film festivals, exploring the art of the preparation, are cropping up across the country.

headline: Karl Rove Versus Hillary Clinton
abstract: The first attack ad of the 2016 campaign accuses the former secretary of state of helping “cover up” what really happened in Benghazi.
lead_paragraph: American Crossroads, the Karl Rove-led super PAC, has released the first attack ad of the 2016 campaign, accusing Hillary Clinton of mishandling the Benghazi killings. It’s a pretty shameless spot, filled with innuendo and as many unflattering pictures of the former secretary of state as possible.

headline: Big Ticket | $16.295 Million for Wraparound Views

lead_paragraph: A pristine 12-room sponsor unit at 535 West End Avenue, a 1920 brick building reinvented, expanded and marketed as a luxury destination by the Extell Development Company, sold for $16.295 million and was the most expensive residential sale of the week, according to city records. The 6,637-square-foot residence, No. 16, had an original listing price of $16.9 million.

headline: In Immigration Bill Talks, House Group Raises Voice
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A bipartisan group in the House of Representatives has been meeting sporadically to create a comprehensive immigration bill, but the Senate debate is dwarfing the group’s efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group in the House of Representatives has been meeting on and off for four years behind closed doors, working on its own version of legislation to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws. But with a comprehensive bill already making its way through the Senate Judiciary Committee, the House group is fast losing its chance to shape the debate percolating on Capitol Hill, let alone put forth a proposal of its own.

headline: In Vancouver, It’s Time to Re-evaluate
abstract: The Canucks lost to the Sharks in the first round, four games to none, the first time since 2001 that Vancouver was swept in a playoff series.
lead_paragraph: Mike Gillis, who took over as the general manager of the Canucks in April 2008, says it is time to hit the reset button after Vancouver was swept in the first round of the playoffs by the San Jose Sharks.

headline: A Director Who Doesn’t Fake It
abstract: The Icelandic director, Baltasar Kormakur, whose 2012 movie “The Deep” opens in America this week, is directing a Hollywood action film, “2 Guns,” set for release this summer.
lead_paragraph: The Icelandic director Baltasar Kormakur made his international reputation with such offbeat films as “101 Rekjavik,” a comedy about a sexually confused slacker, and “The Sea,” about dark family secrets in a remote fishing village. Yet he is making an impressive transition to American filmmaking with action fare like “Contraband,” a hit last year, and the comic-book-based “2 Guns,”coming this summer.

headline: When Helping Hurts
abstract: Certain forms of help can dilute the recipients’ sense of accountability for their own success. Support, don’t substitute.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN parents are more involved in our children’s lives than ever: we schedule play dates, assist with homework and even choose college courses.

headline: Activist Is Detained in Egypt for ‘Inciting Protests’ Against Morsi Government
abstract: Ahmed Maher, founder of the April 6 Youth Movement group, was arrested at the airport in Cairo after his trip to the United States. The Egyptian authorities are accusing him of vandalism and destruction in connection with the group’s underwear-waving demonstration two months ago.
lead_paragraph: The Egyptian police arrested Ahmed Maher, a high-profile figure from the country’s 2011 revolution, at Cairo International Airport on Friday as he returned from a 13-day trip to the United States. The authorities ordered that he be detained for four days pending investigation into charges of “inciting protests” in connection with a demonstration held in March, according to local media reports.

headline: A Record-Setting Gala for Lincoln Center, With a Bonus Tribute for Reynold Levy
abstract: The Lincoln Center spring gala raises $9.4 million, a record for the organization.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts raised $9.4 million at its spring gala on Thursday night, a record for the organization. The gala honored Lincoln Center’s president, Reynold Levy, who is stepping down in December after 11 years. The evening started with the total at $8.2 million, but during the speeches, Katherine Farley, Lincoln Center’s chairwoman, announced that an additional $1.2 million had been raised for the creation of the Reynold Levy Fellowship for Harvard Business School graduates interested in nonprofit organizations.

headline: On Eve of Pivotal Election, Pakistan Orders Times Reporter to Leave
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The New York Times has protested an election-eve expulsion order for Declan Walsh, a veteran correspondent.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s Interior Ministry has ordered the expulsion of the Islamabad bureau chief for The New York Times on the eve of national elections, the newspaper said Friday. The Times has strongly protested the move and is seeking his reinstatement.

headline: Despite Convictions, Brazil Corruption Case Drags On
abstract: Defense appeals may mean reduced sentences and overturned convictions in a case of vote-buying that was celebrated as a watershed in public accountability.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Just six months ago, Brazil’s highest court handed down stiff prison sentences to powerful political figures found guilty in a vast vote-buying scheme, a move widely praised here as a watershed moment in a country where citizens long expected little more than impunity from politicians caught in corruption scandals.

headline: Band Members Say Slayer Guitarist Died of Cirrhosis of the Liver
abstract: Reports that a flesh-eating bacteria had led to the death of the Slayer guitarist, Jeff Hanneman, turned out to be false.
lead_paragraph: The surviving members of the metal band Slayer said that the guitarist Jeff Hanneman had died of alcohol-related cirrhosis of the liver, not from an infection of flesh-eating bacteria.

lead_paragraph: Photos from Bangladesh, Pakistan, Egypt and Israel.

headline: In Celebration of Food, and Art
abstract: The Frieze Festival paid tribute to FOOD, a SoHo restaurant from the ’70s.
lead_paragraph: The iconic SoHo restaurant FOOD, run by Carol Goodden and the artist Gordon Matta-Clark in the 1970s, was recreated at the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island on Thursday, offering a $15 prix fixe meal for survival: beef jerky, hardtack, dried fruits and cheese on a divided paper plate, along with a pickle; a cup of Jjigae, or Korean stew, and a cup of Tang.

headline: Straying a Bit Beyond Its Own Comfort Zone
abstract: By auto industry standards, the new Avalon is hardly revolutionary, but by Toyota’s staid standards, the car  represents an advance on modern territory, a dowager edging onto the electronica dance floor.
lead_paragraph: Big, puffy and comfortable, the Avalon has served Toyota like a trusty Barcalounger. Since 1995 it’s been a staid sedan, in a staid full-size class, from a staid company.

abstract: The 2013 Avalon finds itself the unlikely avatar of a purportedly new — more adventurous and design-driven — Toyota.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 Avalon finds itself the unlikely avatar of a purportedly new — more adventurous and design-driven — Toyota.

headline: Using a Trowel to Erase Time
abstract: Mohammed Ashraf Uddin is among the Bangladeshi immigrants who have made a specialty of restoring brownstone facades.
lead_paragraph: Mohammed Ashraf Uddin grew up in a round wooden house on the Bangladeshi island of Sandwip, on a 30-acre farm where his family grew rice, eggplant, peas and green peppers. The farm’s inhabitants included cows, goats and chickens — “so many animals,” Mr. Uddin said, “that we never had to buy anything from the market.” While helping till the soil, he studied accounting at the local college, where he also learned English.

headline: Creating an Ad Campaign for Oreos, as They Turn 101
abstract: The 100th birthday of the cookie led to a well-received yearlong advertising effort. The challenge is what to do next.
lead_paragraph: The question “What do you do for an encore?” may be asked after a hit almost as often on Madison Avenue as it is in Hollywood or on Broadway. No sooner does a popular advertising campaign conclude, it seems, than everyone begins to wonder what an appropriate follow-up or next step would be.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: 3-D Smartphone and Hacking the Onion
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include a judge dismissing a privacy lawsuit against Delta Air Lines over a smartphone app, a 3-D phone screen that is said to be one of a number of devices Amazon is working on, and a company that says it can make a smartphone while treating its employees well.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Tavares, Islanders Star, Is Hart Trophy Finalist

lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders had just lost, 4-0, in Game 5 of their playoff series with the Pittsburgh Penguins, but there was some good news for the star center John Tavares.

headline: A Change of Plans, Thanks to a Bird
abstract: Sandra Lee, the host of a television cooking show, explains why she is often changing clothes in restrooms.
lead_paragraph: Sandra Lee, 46, is the host of “Semi-Homemade Cooking,” in its 15th season on the Food Network. Her first novel, “The Recipe Box,” will be out this summer. Born in Santa Monica, Calif., she lives in Manhattan and shares a home in Westchester County with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: A Roving Art Fair Finds a Home Court Advantage
abstract: The roving NADA NYC art fair finds an unusual but appropriate place to show off objects both large and petite.
lead_paragraph: The roving NADA art fairs have set up camp at some distinctive places, including an oceanfront hotel in Miami Beach and a former factory in Hudson, N.Y. But they have found their best home yet on a set of basketball courts on the Lower East Side. On Thursday, a day before the fair opened to V.I.P.’s at Basketball City, a complex on Pier 36, gray carpet covered the hardwood, and white wallboard had been erected to create neat grids. The scoreboards were still up, but that somehow felt right in this packed week of fairs, shows and events.

lead_paragraph: Properties include an 1800s village cottage, a house with a lush garden, a barn conversion near the beach, a home with Montauk water views and a five-bedroom near the village.

headline: A Peasant Pie Comfortable at Any Table
abstract: Torta pasqualina, which was considered peasant food, has evolved into a beloved tradition, served even in times of plenty with great delight.
lead_paragraph: In the sunnier climes of Italy, Greece and the south of France, there’s a long tradition of frugal, savory pies made with a humble filling of cooked greens (usually wild foraged ones, like dandelion or nettles), stewed onions and a little grated cheese. Though tasty, they were meatless — this was peasant food. The family cook probably heard, “What, pie again?” more often than not. But it was a way to stay alive.

headline: Exploring His Tunisian Roots, With His Father by His Side
abstract: The choreographer Jonah Bokaer let down his guard when he performed alongside his Tunisian-born father, Tsvi, at Gould Hall.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “The Ulysses Syndrome,” Jonah Bokaer and Tsvi, his Tunisian-born father, take their places at the back of a stage illuminated by six fluorescent tubes, arranged in a hexagon, each dangling like a low swing. Sitting on the floor, the men remain still, leaning against the wall with one knee up.

headline: The Trek to a Yogurt Less Sweet
abstract: Dannon cut the sugar in its Danimals Smoothies for children, but it did so with the utmost care to make sure children couldn’t taste the difference.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Dannon yogurt had a secret it didn’t want you to know. Until recently.

headline: 2 Key JPMorgan Directors Back Dimon’s Dual Roles
abstract: Jamie Dimon has received a spirited defense against calls by some shareholders to split his jobs of chief executive and chairman of JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon has received a spirited defense against calls by some shareholders to split his jobs of chief executive and chairman of JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Author of Study on Immigrants’ I.Q. Leaves Heritage Foundation
abstract: Jason Richwine, whose critique of an immigration bill in the Senate was undercut by his graduate dissertation on Hispanic immigrants’ intelligence, has parted ways with the conservative research group.
lead_paragraph: Jason Richwine, a senior policy analyst at the conservative Heritage Foundation who argued in a graduate school dissertation that Hispanic immigrants were less intelligent than white Americans, resigned from his post with the foundation on Friday.

headline: Inside the Frieze Art Fair
abstract: A parade of the fine and fancy made an appearance at Frieze Art Fair, including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Renee Rockefeller.
lead_paragraph: A parade of the fine and fancy made an appearance at Frieze Art Fair, including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Renee Rockefeller.

headline: At Frieze, the Elite Browse and Forage
abstract: The Frieze Art Fair’s New York iteration has become the latest stop for wealthy buyers of contemporary art, a well-established, defining marker of social status.
lead_paragraph: “Just go with it,” Patty Smyth, the rocker, said to her husband, the tennis legend John McEnroe, urging him to tip up a coupe of Bobby Burns, a potent cocktail of whiskey, sweet vermouth, Bénédictine and a twist of lemon. “Go with the flow.”

headline: Complaint Against Bryce Reed
abstract: Bryce Reed, a paramedic who helped evacuate people after the fertilizer plant explosion in West, Tex., was charged with possessing bomb-making materials.
lead_paragraph: Bryce Reed, a paramedic who helped evacuate people after the fertilizer plant explosion in West, Tex., was charged with possessing bomb-making materials.

headline: Student Debt’s Impact on Young Graduates
abstract: Annie Lowrey fielded questions on Twitter about the effects of mounting student debt on the financial lives of young graduates.
lead_paragraph: Student loan debt now exceeds $1 trillion, and as Annie Lowrey writes, that debt is an increasing burden to the financial lives of young graduates. It is forcing them to delay purchases of things like homes, cars and other big-ticket items and acting as a drag on growth, economists say.

headline: All the Rage | This Year’s Frieze New York Artists Are Mad About Plants
abstract: As we show in our visual roundup, flora is everywhere you look at this year’s edition of the massive art extravaganza.
lead_paragraph: Considering the dozens of languages, thousands of artworks and billions of dollars coursing through the tent at Frieze New York — the second edition of which opened to the public on Friday and runs through Monday — you might expect the fair to offer a decisive statement about what matters in art right now. In truth, that’s probably expecting too much from what is ultimately a highbrow pop-up shopping mall, but certain motifs always emerge from these extravaganzas, and what’s more fun than sussing out the pattern? This year, the predominant trend is flora, with plant life sprouting up in photographs and potted into sculptures. A reflection of the mania for sustainability and urban gardens? A nod to the season? Decide for yourself. We’ll see if the greenery rakes in the green, but watch out for some of these leafy highlights as you venture past the air kisses and hipster restaurants into Frieze New York’s white cube jungle.

headline: Actavis in Preliminary Talks With Warner Chilcott
abstract: Actavis, the maker of generic drugs, said it was in early talks to acquire Warner Chilcott.
lead_paragraph: Actavis is in talks with another drug maker about a potential merger after talks with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International fell through.

headline: Printable-Gun Instructions Spread Online After State Dept. Orders Their Removal
abstract: A 25-year-old Texas law student explains why he posted instructions on how to make a gun using 3-D printing technology, which were downloaded more than 100,000 times before being taken down.
lead_paragraph: The State Department, citing possible compliance concerns regarding the export of firearms, has ordered a Web site to remove what are believed to be the world’s first online instructions on how to build a 3-D printable handgun.

lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: El Museo del Barrio’s Board President to Leave
abstract: The museum’s fund-raising has slipped, its days of operation have been slashed from six to four, and roughly a fifth of its staff was laid off this year.
lead_paragraph: El Museo del Barrio’s board president, who was named in a recent discrimination claim by the museum’s former director, will leave her position at the end of her term on June 30, museum officials said on Friday. The official, Yaz Hernández, is departing as the museum searches for a new director and struggles to find its fiscal footing.

lead_paragraph: More photographs.

headline: Searching for Roots, Finding Characters
abstract: With “Family Tree” on HBO, Christopher Guest brings the mockumentary format he pioneered in film to a television scene that’s been saturated with imitations of his work.
lead_paragraph: “Family Tree” is a half-hour HBO comedy about a lethargic, unemployed young British man who becomes obsessed with tracking down his ancestors. It’s largely improvised and poses as a documentary, though to such a slight degree that it hardly matters. That this does not sound like a terrible idea for a television show is largely because of the past work of Christopher Guest, who, as it happens, created and wrote “Family Tree” with Jim Piddock. Depending on your taste, that’s either a tribute or a reproach.

headline: Keeping Peace in a Vertical Village
abstract: An interview with Doug Weinstein, a building manager for luxury co-ops and condominiums in New York City.
lead_paragraph: As director of operations and compliance for AKAM Associates, a property management company for luxury co-op and condominium buildings in New York City, Doug Weinstein is responsible for all physical projects in 125 buildings. He fields daily calls from cooperative and condominium boards about everything from code issues to job bids. Mr. Weinstein started in the business nearly 30 years ago, working for his cousin, Martin Raynes, of M. J. Raynes Inc., a large real estate developer in the city in the 1980s.

headline: Using Darkness, With Enlightenment in Mind
abstract: The conductor Paul Haas led a concert on Wednesday under dimmed lights at the Church of the Ascension in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas has written several works to be performed in pitch darkness, including “In Vain,” his hourlong masterpiece for chamber orchestra. With artificial light everywhere, “we do not have any night in our modern life,” he said in an interview in 2011. “But I think our body and our souls desire night, and I give this in my art.”

headline: The Boy Toy’s Story
abstract: Scott Thorson knew the high life as Liberace’s lover and the low life as his ex. Now, an HBO movie is about to revisit the days of wine and sequins.
lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — Soon after moving into Liberace’s gaudy Las Vegas mansion in 1977, Scott Thorson, then a teenage hunk in the foster care system, learned that the jewel-smitten showman could love just as extravagantly as he decorated. Touring the premises before their relationship began, Liberace pointed out some decorative highlights, which included 17 pianos, a casino, a quarry’s worth of marble and a canopied bed with an ermine spread. On the ceiling was a reproduction of the Sistine Chapel with Liberace’s face painted among the cherubs.

headline: Details Emerge About Syrian Electronic Army’s Recent Exploits
abstract: This week, after The Onion, a parody news site, became the latest publication to have its Twitter account hacked by the Syrian Electronic Army, details of how the attacks took place were made public.
lead_paragraph: At The Onion it’s all fun and games, except when the company’s Twitter account gets hacked.

headline: Braving Frostbite in Search of Ratings
abstract: Several cable channels are offering reality shows that feature people facing the challenges of very cold climates.
lead_paragraph: The weather in much of the United States is finally beginning to warm up, but on television things are getting noticeably colder. A burst of new and returning reality series seem intent on leaving us envious of, or in awe of, or terrified for, those who live where the wind blows cold almost year-round.

headline: A French Jet Maker Is Approaching a Crossroad
abstract: Despite its pioneering work with all-digital designs, Dassault faces a challenging future in both its military and private-jet businesses.
lead_paragraph: SAINT-CLOUD, FRANCE — As Jérôme Camps, an engineer at Dassault Aviation’s main design center, showed off a ghostlike 3-D model of one of the company’s small jets here recently, his hand passed through the plane’s skin to reveal an intricate web of support structures as well as a jumble of multicolored cables and pneumatic tubes, rendered in vivid detail.

headline: 40 Nations, 1,000 Artists and One Island
abstract: Art fair haters should put aside their disdain and enjoy Frieze New York, whose spacious quarters on Randalls Island feature a strong showing this year.
lead_paragraph: Some people hate art fairs all of the time, and most people hate them some of the time. It’s fashionable to be snarky and condescending about them, but that’s too easy. Art fairs are here for the foreseeable future and represent the collective efforts — if not the hopes and dreams — of thousands of people who want art to be at the center of their lives.

headline: In Blow to NBC News, ‘Rock Center’ Is Canceled
abstract: The show was meant to be a showpiece for the anchor Brian Williams, but it moved around the schedule and had a hard time finding an audience.
lead_paragraph: Among the cancellations announced this week in anticipation of Monday’s unveiling of a new prime time schedule, surely the hardest to take for NBC News is the closing notice for “Rock Center,” the ambitious newsmagazine program that hoped to stake out new territory for both the news division and its chief anchor, Brian Williams.

headline: A Line Between Sweet and Skimpy
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: The issue of appropriate clothing for girls has been the subject of increasing academic and popular scrutiny, fed by panties printed with “wink wink” or leggings that say “cute butt sweat pants.”
lead_paragraph: It first happened to me this spring. My daughters, who had just turned 8, came bounding into the room to show off new outfits they were wearing to an extended-family gathering. My eyes bulged. The dresses drooped provocatively off the shoulder and offered other peekaboos of their bodies. Sure, as a parent, I figured I would one day face clothing battles with my children. Politicians aren’t the only ones who draw red lines.

headline: Ever Separated by Sound
abstract: “The Good Boy,” Michael Bonnabel’s solo show about his experience as a hearing son with deaf parents, is at Abingdon Theater.
lead_paragraph: The man looks like an aging bachelor bank teller in a 1962 episode of “The Twilight Zone.” Or like the hopelessly square dad in a midcentury sitcom. But Michael Bonnabel — in his suit, narrow tie and eyeglasses — is the son in the Abingdon Theater Company’s production of his autobiographical solo show, “The Good Boy.”

headline: E.M.T. at Fertilizer Plant Blast Faces Charge of Possessing Bomb Parts
abstract: Officials would not say whether the case was related to a deadly fertilizer plant explosion in West, Tex., last month, but they opened a criminal inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Texas authorities said on Friday that they had opened a criminal investigation into last month’s deadly explosion at a fertilizer plant that killed 14 people and injured some 200 others.

headline: Not Just the Standards, but Storytelling, Too
abstract: At a Lincoln Center gala, Audra McDonald displayed not only her phenomenal voice, but also her gift of balancing singing and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Absolutely thrilling. That describes Audra McDonald’s Avery Fisher Hall performance at Lincoln Center’s spring gala on Thursday evening. The very sound of the word “thrilling,” with its suggestion of an embedded trill, evokes qualities inherent in Ms. McDonald’s soprano, which seemed to unfurl in ever-richer textures as she imbued songs with a sense of bursting possibility.

headline: An Artist Recreates a Smoking Room With Flowers and Perfume
abstract: For the Frieze Art Fair, Maria Loboda created a garden and a fragrance meant to summon the atmosphere of a bygone Viennese smoking room.
lead_paragraph: Maria Loboda’s newest installation, an artfully arranged flower bed called “Smoking Room in a Private Palais in Brussels as Seen From the Entrance, 1905,” greets visitors as they exit the tents of the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island in New York. The outdoor exhibition is a tribute to two early 20th-century design phenomena: a smoking room in Vienna, designed by the secessionist production cooperative Wiener Werkstätte, and color-charted gardens, a bygone fad for mapping flowers by shade to create a plot that feels almost like a Pantone chart. Loboda potted groups of different plants in an arrangement that mimics the floor plan of the smoking room. “The idea is to take the domestic situation, an interior, and to translate it into something wild, into a landscape,” she said.

headline: Bumpy Road for Trophy Cars
abstract: A new willingness to spend among the growing affluent class in India has lured high-end automakers to India. But driving supercars there can be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — It’s not easy being the owner of an exceedingly expensive car in India. Just ask Rishabh Jain, whose Lamborghini Murciélago LP640, in a shade of metallic gray called Grigio Telesto, spends an inordinate amount of time under a cover in the parking lot of his apartment building in the affluent Malabar Hill neighborhood here.

headline: Conspicuous Consumption, With a Few Caveats
abstract: Facing rough streets and high taxes, India’s owners of supercars and high-end luxury vehicles are finding that riding in style isn’t always easy.
lead_paragraph: Facing rough streets and high taxes, India’s owners of supercars and high-end luxury vehicles are finding that riding in style isn’t always easy.

headline: Country Stars Playing Musical Chairs
abstract: Lady Antebellum and Pistol Annies, both of which represent polar ideas of what modern country music can be, are off their mark on their new albums, in part because each is creeping in the direction of the other.
lead_paragraph: For Lady Antebellum, lipstick represents optimism. For Pistol Annies, it’s a tool of the oppressor.

headline: A New Town, a New Focus on Dinner
abstract: With an expanded menu and new talent in the kitchen, Sweet Basil’s Cafe has become a draw for dinner — with its seafood dishes standing out.
lead_paragraph: Sweet Basil’s Cafe and Grill made its reputation as a place for brunch and lunch, first in West Orange and later in Livingston, where it moved last July. An expanded menu and new talent in the kitchen now make it an equally fine place for dinner.

headline: Recalling Chimps and Brel, in Her Own Way
abstract: The French chanteuse Yvonne Constant, accompanied on piano by Russ Kassoff, sang “Comme d’habitude” in an autobiographical program titled “One of a Kind.”
lead_paragraph: Not many people know that the grandiose Sinatra anthem “My Way,” had an earlier life in France under the title “Comme d’habitude” (“As Usual”) whose morose narrator describes a deteriorating relationship that has settled into a chilly routine. Juiced up with new lyrics by Paul Anka, it became the triumphal ego trip we all know and have learned to tolerate.

headline: 13-Year-Old Playwright Awaits His Big Night
abstract: A class assignment led to Kyle Abrahams’s winning entry in the Worldwide Plays Festival Competition, and it will be performed by professional actors on Saturday evening.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Abrahams had never tried to write a play before his drama teacher, John McEneny, required him to try for a middle school class in Brooklyn. Kyle had always liked acting – he recently performed in a production of “Frankenstein.” Now, though, he’d be the one giving other actors instructions.

headline: Kobe Bryant’s Sentimental Shot
abstract: A court filing earlier this week detailing Bryant’s prized high school memorabilia is kind of humanizing.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday a friend and fan of all Philadelphia sports directed me to a Philly.com story about the former Notre Dame football player Manti Te’o’s “girlfriend” making the Maxim Hot 100; his reaction was basically “Phew, glad the Iggles didn’t draft this guy.”

headline: Isabella Rossellini’s Sly Maternal Instinct
abstract: Isabella Rossellini follows up her shorts about animals’ sex lives with a new set aimed at motherhood, as played out among animals.
lead_paragraph: Some Mother’s Day tributes are less wholesome than others, and thank heaven for that. “Mammas” — a set of short films, two to three minutes each, appearing Sunday on the Sundance Channel and sundancechannel.com — reflects the distinctive character of its creator, Isabella Rossellini: a blend of innocence, sophistication and sly smuttiness. It’s a long way from flowers, chocolates and brunch.

abstract: The Rose Room restaurant in Mount Kisco provides an elegant setting for customers and a good excuse for getting dressed up.
lead_paragraph: The Rose Room, which opened in Mount Kisco in February, is a place of hits and misses.

headline: Umpire Suspended for Blown Call
abstract: Major League Baseball handed a two-game suspension to Fieldin Culbreth, the umpire who incorrectly allowed an illegal pitching change in a game between the Astros and the Angels.
lead_paragraph: In a week in which umpires twice became the story of games because of high-profile mistakes, Major League Baseball took action on Friday, handing a two-game suspension to Fieldin Culbreth, the umpire who on Thursday incorrectly allowed an illegal pitching change in a game between the Houston Astros and Los Angeles Angels.

abstract: Rainbow Thai in Westport features uncommon dishes, bare tables and a place to converse.
lead_paragraph: Two suggestions if you visit Rainbow Thai in Westport: first, reserve ahead, as this tiny place seats only 40, and second, request, if it is available, a table overlooking the Saugatuck River. If you are lucky you might even catch a glimpse of crews rowing below you on the river.

headline: Editor’s Letter | Away We Go
abstract: Travel, and travel writing, should be able to open our minds — and even to change them.
lead_paragraph: Travel journalism often falls into one of two camps — the highly didactic and servicey piece, “go here, stay there, see that,” or the long-winded narrative in which the writer has the experience and we are meant to be satisfied by the first-person blow-by-blow he or she has brought back for us: “the road into town was dusty and unpaved and the driver kept getting lost.” The former is best served up by the Internet on demand. (You can find all of our hotel and restaurant suggestions for the stories in this issue at tmagazine.com.) And the pure version of the latter is perhaps best left to brilliant writers who promise to reward you for coming along (Edith Wharton, Patrick Leigh Fermor, Evelyn Waugh, Jan Morris). There are of course also intellectual and cultural histories of locales, in which the writer seeks to tease out the influences — historical, economic, social, stylistic, culinary and political — that make the place uniquely what it is (V. S. Naipaul, Bruce Chatwin, Ryszard Kapuscinski). The type we favor at T is a hybrid of the three, in which great writing and personal narrative is done in the service of not just traipsing along with the writer who got to go on an amazing journey that we didn’t, but of bringing you back a new understanding of a place that is enlightening and satisfying regardless of whether you ever plan to visit. And yet, if you do choose to go, we’re there to guide you.

headline: For Casual Crowds, Second Labels
abstract: The wines sold under second-label programs can be serviceable, pleasurable and not too far in quality from their superior siblings.
lead_paragraph: When the number of guests at a party or a barbecue threatens to overwhelm the wine budget, second labels can come to the rescue.

headline: A Lively Little Party of Plenty
abstract: La Cucina is the kind of place you leave with at least two resolutions: to eat nothing at all the next day, and to return as soon as you can.
lead_paragraph: As we walked into La Cucina, a year-and-a-half-old Italian restaurant in Hewlett, on a recent Saturday night, something resembling a dinner party was in full swing. The owner, Luigi Muto, greeted us with a warm smile and a worried glance over his shoulder. Behind him, the small minimalist dining room — awash in soft jazz, seductive aromas and animated conversation — was packed.

headline: Meals of Imagined Bounty
abstract: It is often said that A. .R. Gurney writes about a dying breed. But the characters in “The Dining Room,” the Westport Country Playhouse, are very much alive onstage.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it’s easy to tell which part of the 20th century we are seeing in “The Dining Room.” When one man mentions the horrors of “instant coffee on Eastern Airlines,” for instance, you know we’re in the era of the beloved hourly shuttle to Washington or Boston. At other times, it can be more difficult, as when a father complains, “The government is systematically ruining this country.”

headline: The Secret of Baxter’s Success
abstract: Mike Baxter has developed into a pinch-hitting weapon for the Mets. His manager attributes Baxter’s success to his attention to detail.
lead_paragraph: In trying to figure out why Mike Baxter has been such a good pinch-hitter for the Mets, Manager Terry Collins pointed to his attention to detail. It is a rare player who pays such close attention while being stuck on the bench. But Baxter does. This season, he is 5 for 9 as a pinch-hitter, including leading the Mets to two final-inning wins this week. After Thursday’s hit, Baxter became the first pinch-hitter since 1991 to have game-ending at-bats twice in a three-day span.

headline: T Summer Travel 2013
abstract: T’s Summer Travel issue is all about trying something new.
lead_paragraph: T’s Summer Travel issue is all about trying something new: whether it’s staying in a stranger’s home (Gideon Lewis-Kraus writes about Airbnb), taking a trip alone (Andrew O’Hagan delights in traveling solo) or considering a place off the beaten path (Adam Sachs has a love-hate relationship with Marin County, Calif.). Inside, there is T’s usual mix of art, entertainment and fashion with a profile on the artist James Turrell by Edward Helmore, a visit with the actor Rupert Everett by Sarah Lyall and a round-up of black bikinis and leather cover-ups photographed by Craig McDean and styled by Joe McKenna. headline: Why Federal Efforts to Ensure Clean Tap Water Fail to Reach Faucets Nationwide
abstract: Bureaucratic and technical obstacles have slowed the distribution of federal aid in places where water is laced with nitrates and other pollutants.
lead_paragraph: MONSON, Calif. — Laura Garcia was halfway through the breakfast dishes when the spigot went dry. The small white tank beneath the sink that purified her undrinkable water had run out. Still, as annoying as that was, it was an improvement over the days before Ms. Garcia got her water filter, when she had to do her dishes using water from five-gallon containers she bought at a local store.

headline: Egypt: Prominent Activist Jailed
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Egyptian activist Ahmed Maher was arrested on accusations of inciting protests in front of the Interior Ministry in March and was transferred to a high-security prison.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Egyptian activist was jailed Friday on accusations of inciting protests in front of the Interior Ministry in March, state news media said. The activist, Ahmed Maher, was arrested at the Cairo airport upon arriving from abroad and transferred to a high-security prison where he will be held for four days while the accusations are investigated. Mr. Maher is a leader in the April 6 Youth Group that help organize the protests that ousted President Hosni Mubarak in February 2011. He has recently spoken out against President Mohamed Morsi and his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Pre-1492, Artistic Notions Worth Borrowing
abstract: An exhibition under way at Purchase College features four contemporary artists who make use of early images and motifs from Mesoamerica.
lead_paragraph: If modern art was characterized by the shock of the new, recent decades have seen an obsession with recycling. History is treated like an archive from which images and objects can be borrowed, appropriated, and repurposed — just like in popular music, where sampling was born, and which is alluded to in the title of “Pre-Columbian Remix: The Art of Enrique Chagoya, Demián Flores, Rubén Ortiz-Torres, and Nadín Ospina” at the Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase College.

headline: Pakistan’s Tyrannical Majority
keywords: ['Elections', 'Minorities', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Discrimination', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: A democratic milestone masks rising intolerance of religious minorities.
lead_paragraph: JUST after the stroke of midnight on Aug. 14, 1947, the Peshawar broadcast station of All India Radio crackled to life: “This is Pakistan Broadcasting Service.” Next came the words of the Urdu-language poet Ahmed Nadeem Qasmi: “Pakistan bananay walay, Pakistan Mubarak” — “Oh, maker of Pakistan, congratulations on Pakistan.”

headline: Rebuilding After Sandy, but With Costly New Rules
abstract: A new law will cause flood insurance premiums to skyrocket and require stricter, and thus more expensive, rebuilding standards.
lead_paragraph: It’s been more than six months since Hurricane Sandy hit the East Coast, yet many people whose homes were ravaged by the storm still do not know how to put all the pieces back together.

headline: Shunned Elsewhere, Body of Marathon Bombing Suspect Is Buried in Virginia Cemetery
keywords: ['Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The problem of what to do with the body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of two suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing, was solved when a small cemetery agreed to take it.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The mystery surrounding the burial of the body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev has come to an end. The Boston Marathon bombing suspect was buried this week at a small Muslim cemetery in Doswell, Va.

headline: Report Your Hurricane Sandy Repair Stories
abstract: Bucks readers tell about their experiences in dealing with damage to their homes from Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column looks at the tough position of many homeowners whose houses were severely damaged by Hurricane Sandy. They are still figuring out the best way to put their homes back together, and how they will pay for the repairs.

headline: CBS to Add 4 Comedies, Including Another From Chuck Lorre
abstract: There also will be two new dramas; among the actors involved are Robin Williams, Sarah Michelle Gellar and Toni Collette.
lead_paragraph: CBS joined other networks in sending out orders for new series Friday and, for CBS, that list was longer and included some untraditional ideas.

headline: George Sauer, Jets Receiver and Rebel, Is Dead at 69
abstract: Mr. Sauer, who was a wide receiver for the Jets, played a pivotal role in the team’s Super Bowl III win, but he grew to hate the life of a pro football player and retired at 27.
lead_paragraph: George Sauer, who as a wide receiver for the Jets played a pivotal role in the team’s stunning victory in Super Bowl III, and who later quit professional football because he considered it dehumanizing, died on Tuesday in Westerville, Ohio. He was 69.

headline: The Hitless Songwriter
abstract: The series on songwriting resumes, with a piece — and a new track — from Terre Roche.
lead_paragraph: Michael Tannen, The Roches’ manager, was yelling into the phone at me. Why don’t you just listen to the radio and figure out how to write a commercial song? Then the phone went dead.

headline: The Family Unfriendly Act
abstract: If this is caring, I would hate to see what contempt looks like.
lead_paragraph: There are two good things to say about the Working Families Flexibility Act, which passed the House this week with 220 Republican and three Democratic votes.

headline: Samuel Noyes, Mountaineer
abstract: How a frail boy from New Hampshire became a valiant Civil War soldier.
lead_paragraph: Few Union units were as esteemed for their collective strength as the 12th New Hampshire Infantry. It was magnet for strapping young fellows from the farms that dotted the state’s White Mountains. “No wonder that a regiment, having so many giant-like men, should have been called the ‘New Hampshire Mountaineers,’” mused one of its captains, Asa Bartlett, about the origin of the unit’s nickname.

headline: Privacy Breach on Bloomberg’s Data Terminals
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Privacy']
abstract: Bloomberg News confirmed that reporters for its news service used the the company’s terminals to monitor subscribers’ usage.
lead_paragraph: A shudder went through Wall Street on Friday after the revelation that Bloomberg News reporters had extracted subscribers’ private information through the company’s ubiquitous data terminals to break news.

headline: New Technology and Risks Enter a Venerable Event
keywords: ["AMERICA'S CUP", 'Sailboats and Sailing', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The death of a leading British sailor, the Olympic champion Andrew Simpson, shows how technology and modern danger have found their way into the America’s Cup.
lead_paragraph: On a sun-kissed afternoon in the Bay Area last week, Larry Olson, a 39-year-old from San Francisco, backed his car into a parking space next to Marina Green, flipped up the hatch to create a viewing platform and watched with his young children as Artemis Racing’s America’s Cup catamaran sped by in the stiff breeze on San Francisco Bay.

headline: Former Leader of Guatemala Is Guilty of Genocide Against Mayan Group
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Mayans', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The judge who sentenced former dictator Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt to 80 years in prison said the court was “convinced of the intent to destroy the Ixil ethnic group.”
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — A Guatemalan court on Friday found Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, the former dictator who ruled Guatemala during one of the bloodiest periods of its long civil war, guilty of genocide and crimes against humanity.

headline: Retailers Are Pressed on Safety at Factories
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: Organizations have been growing impatient because only two companies have signed onto a binding agreement on safety standards for factories in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: A wide spectrum of government officials, investors and religious groups are warning major retailers like Walmart, Benetton and Gap that they could face financial repercussions from consumers, damage to their stock value or sustained public protests if they do not adopt stricter garment manufacturing standards.

headline: Technology Industry Lobbying Group Loses Supporters
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Online Advertising', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Elon Musk of Tesla and David Sacks of Yammer have left Mark Zuckerberg’s Fwd.us, which faces criticism from environmentalists over its lobbying tactics.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, a founder of the electric carmaker Tesla and one of the technology industry’s most outspoken exponents of clean energy, has stepped down from a prominent Silicon Valley advocacy group that is pushing for changes to the nation’s immigration laws and that has sponsored advertisements that promote a contentious oil pipeline.

headline: A Meal in Borough No. 5: Manhattan
abstract: Five years, five boroughs and five restaurants: A couple’s unusual dining tour is capped with dinner at Alder, the chef Wylie Dufresne’s newest restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Consider the crush of publicity and the lines that have formed on Second Avenue outside Wylie Dufresne’s newest restaurant. Note that Mr. Dufresne and his muttonchops are television celebrities. Add that last week Mr. Dufresne won the James Beard Award for New York’s Best Chef. So how refreshing it was that not everybody in Alder’s rustic-chic dining room on Wednesday was caught up on the place’s reputation. One food-loving couple transplanted from San Diego and Venice (Italy) came for their own adventure: the end of a five-borough birthday tour. They were delightfully unaware of WD-50, Mr. Dufresne’s celebrated flagship. And instead of debating the hype, they reveled in the whimsy of the evening and Alder’s modernist spin on comfort food, savoring their journey as much as the dehydrated pastrami.

headline: Former Major Winner Provides Tough Love as a Caddie at the Players
abstract: While Mark Brooks provided tough love and instruction to a pro who missed the cut at the Players Championship, Sergio Garcia and Tiger Woods took over the tournament.
lead_paragraph: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — A seven-time PGA Tour winner missed the Players Championship cut by two strokes without even hitting a shot. Mark Brooks, whose tour victories include one major, the 1996 P.G.A. Championship, caddied for J. J. Henry, who finished at two over, 13 strokes higher than the 36-hole leader, Sergio García.

headline: Troubled Life in Malcolm X’s Shadow Comes to a Violent End
abstract: Malcolm Shabazz, the grandson of Malcolm X, died in Mexico City on Thursday night after spending much of his life seeking to make peace with his own past and that of his famous family.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Malcolm Shabazz, the grandson of Malcolm X, was talking to his friend Daniel Stevens when he learned that Mr. Stevens was worried that his fledgling rap career was going nowhere. Mr. Shabazz vowed to help, saying that he could get Mr. Stevens’s music into the right hands.

headline: With Many Despairing, Bulgaria Heads to Polls
abstract: Six self-immolations since February, and the resignation of Prime Minister Boiko Borisov, have characterized the mood of the nation as it prepares to vote.
lead_paragraph: VARNA, Bulgaria — Early one morning this past winter, Plamen Goranov, a 36-year-old photographer, stood on the steps of City Hall in this once grand and now crumbling port city on the Black Sea and held up a sign demanding that the mayor and City Council resign. He then took a bottle of gasoline from his backpack, poured it over himself and set himself on fire. He died 11 days later in a hospital.

headline: A Composer’s Best Friend
abstract: Lucy Mann, executive director of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation, regularly celebrates the birthdays of 20th-century American composers so music students will have a clue who they are.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Lucy Mann was out there again, standing behind her table just inside the entrance to the Manhattan School of Music.

headline: New Error Found in Scoring of Test for Gifted Programs
abstract: The Education Department said Friday that roughly 300 additional students had been wrongly excluded from eligibility in public school gifted programs because of another mistake by the testing company.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after New York City disclosed that thousands of students had been wrongly excluded from eligibility in public school gifted programs, the Education Department said that roughly 300 additional students received incorrect scores because of another mistake by the testing company.

headline: Rodman Says He’ll Ask North Korea to Free American
abstract: Dennis Rodman told TMZ that he planned to return to North Korea on Aug. 1 to try to free Kenneth Bae, a Korean-American sentenced to 15 years of hard labor.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Rodman, the flamboyant former basketball player who has managed to engage with North Korea’s leader — something United States officials have been unable to do — said he planned to return to the North to try to gain the release of an imprisoned American citizen, according to a video posted Friday on the celebrity news Web site TMZ.

headline: Pay People to Cook at Home
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Working Hours', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Labor and Jobs', "Women's Rights", 'Parenting', 'Obesity']
abstract: Give families the time and money they need for better eating.
lead_paragraph: THE home-cooked family meal is often lauded as the solution for problems ranging from obesity to deteriorating health to a decline in civility and morals. Using whole foods to prepare meals without additives and chemicals is the holy grail for today’s advocates of better eating.

headline: Storm Plans for Disabled Are Inadequate, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Disabilities', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hurricane Irene (2011)']
abstract: New York City violated federal law because its emergency management plans failed to address the needs of the disabled during Tropical Storm Irene, the government said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: New York City is in violation of federal law because its emergency management plans “do not adequately protect the rights of individuals with disabilities,” federal authorities said in a court filing on Friday.

headline: Five Children. Any Questions?
abstract: Jim Gaffigan, comedian, actor and author, spends Sundays with his wife and five children, at home, in church and at the park.
lead_paragraph: On Sundays, the comedian and actor Jim Gaffigan, 46, takes a day off from stand-up. Instead of performing, he collects new fodder during family outings with his wife, Jeannie Noth Gaffigan, and their five children, Marre, 9; Jack, 7; Katie, 4; Michael, 22 months; and Patrick, 7 months, and time spent at their home, a fifth-floor walk-up on the Bowery. Some of this material can be seen and heard in Mr. Gaffigan’s Grammy-nominated, downloadable comedy special, “Mr. Universe,” and on his national tour. It also fills the pages of his new book, “Dad Is Fat,” which was released last week.

headline: A Return Poses a Risk to the Knicks
abstract: Amar’e Stoudemire is healthy enough to play after a two-month layoff, but the Knicks’ rotation and identity has been firmly established without him.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, May 11, 2013.
lead_paragraph: "We are with you. We will not move out from this place without rescuing you.”

headline: The Man at the Piano
abstract: A treasured institution, and its revered maestro, celebrate a 25th anniversary with a concert Monday night.
lead_paragraph: This Monday evening, a small, vibrant arts organization, The New York Festival of Song, which I’ve long treasured, will be celebrating its 25th anniversary with a gala concert.

headline: After Malaysia Election, Political Attacks Continue as Opposition Calls for Protests
abstract: Analysts say that the political turmoil since Sunday’s national election brings concern of a potentially explosive showdown between the prime minister and the opposition leader.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — If there was a moment after the nail-biting national election on Sunday when Malaysians could envision a respite from five years of political turmoil, it did not last long.

headline: Protecting Cinnabon and the Gap, and Still Getting No Respect
keywords: ['Police', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: Many came to the defense of Port Authority police officers after Joseph J. Lhota, a candidate for mayor, compared them to mall cops. But no one came to the defense of the mall cops.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, somebody noticed a black suitcase on the ground floor of the Manhattan Mall in Herald Square. The response was immediate.

headline: China Officials Seek Career Shortcut With Feng Shui
abstract: China’s ambitious civil servants are increasingly — if discreetly — seeking supernatural shortcuts to wealth and power, much to the dismay of the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: ZOUMAJIE, China — Outraged peasants protesting land grabs. Jilted mistresses plotting revenge. Provincial investigators seeking out graft.

headline: In A.T.M. Robbery Case, a Splashy Trail of Big Spending
abstract: Seven Yonkers men charged with carrying out part of a $45 million theft executed internationally did not stand out until they started to flaunt Rolex watches and luxury cars.
lead_paragraph: Three worked as bus drivers for special-needs children, two worked at Kmart and another delivered pizza for Domino’s.

headline: From the Archives: Letter From Malcolm Shabazz, 2003
abstract: An excerpt from a letter Malcolm Shabazz sent to Michael Wilson, a reporter for The New York Times, in 2003.
lead_paragraph: An excerpt from a letter Malcolm Shabazz sent to Michael Wilson, a reporter for The New York Times, in 2003.

headline: Giants Rookies Find Familiarity in Camp
abstract: Offensive lineman Justin Pugh and quarterback Ryan Nassib played together in college and were reunited as Giants draft picks.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was a crowded Giants rookie minicamp Friday, with more than 60 players — most of them undrafted free agents — swarming multiple practice fields. There was a lot of young, energetic football muscle parading back and forth, a throng that often ran the wrong way or looked lost in the middle of an assignment.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Corrections: May 11, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on May 11, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Taking Things Into Account
abstract: Will Matt Ginsberg help us figure out which way to turn?
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I know. It will be O.K., I promise. Here comes the explanation.

headline: Music for Violin, With Faustian Strings Attached
abstract: A program of deviltry and mischief features Miranda Cuckson, violin, and Blair McMillen, piano, at Columbia University’s Italian Academy.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that the Devil has the best tunes. And we also know what he plays them on: a fiddle. From Tartini’s “Devil’s Trill” Violin Sonata of 1713 to the Charlie Daniels Band’s 1979 country music ballad “The Devil Went Down to Georgia,” the instrument most readily associated with the Crafty One is a violin.

headline: Before You Can Plant, Dance Through the End of the World
abstract: Jill Sigman’s “Last Days/First Field” includes apocalyptic dance and a ritual planting of seedlings.
lead_paragraph: There is a vigorous dance component in “Last Days/First Field,” but its choreographer, Jill Sigman, has even bigger ambitions in mind. The two-hour work, as she explains in program notes, “is a movement ritual for our time.” In the first half, “Last Days,” the focus is on dancing: there’s an apocalyptic feel as performers move frantically in packs or alone, gesticulating wildly as their feet slap soundly onto the floor. The ritual part comes to light in the second half, “First Field.” Ms. Sigman attempts to alter the landscape, both physically and spiritually, by bringing nature inside.

headline: Expelled by Pakistan
keywords: ['Elections', 'News and News Media', 'Editorials', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Islamabad should expand news coverage, not restrict it.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan is facing daunting challenges, including a violent insurgency that threatens the state and a critically important general election on Saturday. Yet its Interior Ministry this week had nothing better to do than to expel Declan Walsh, The Times’s bureau chief in Pakistan. The move was unjustified and should be reversed.

headline: Racism in a Texas Death Case
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Editorials', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A resentencing fight reflects a wide and disturbing pattern.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of racism in the Texas criminal justice system, seven death penalty cases are in a class by themselves. In 2000, after the Supreme Court ordered a new sentencing hearing in one of them, Senator John Cornyn, who was then the state attorney general, called for new sentencing hearings in the other cases for the same reason: because race was improperly and explicitly considered as a factor in determining the sentence.

headline: Beyond Basketball and Bigotry
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Law and Legislation', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Editorials']
abstract: It’s past time to address a profound impediment to real equality: workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.
lead_paragraph: The overwhelmingly supportive response to Jason Collins, who came out last week as the first openly gay male athlete playing in a major American team sport, is an encouraging measure of the nation’s civil rights progress. But his barrier-breaking announcement a dozen years into his N.B.A. career also carries a reminder of a reality millions of gay people live with every day: being open about their sexual orientation could put their job and career at risk.

headline: Ceaseless Pressure on Whales
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Editorials']
abstract: The recovering marine mammal still needs all the protection it can get.
lead_paragraph: Since 1986, when the International Whaling Commission imposed a moratorium on whaling, there has been a steady resurgence in whale populations. The recovery of several species pushed to the brink of extinction by commercial whaling is a reminder of the resilience of nature. Even so, there is a nearly constant push to ease the restrictions that have protected the whales and, in some cases, to resume hunting. There are two cases in point: fin whales near Iceland, a nation that has never accepted the I.W.C. moratorium, and humpback whales near Hawaii.

headline: France: Concern Over New Virus
abstract: French officials said Friday that they are examining three people who came into contact with a man hospitalized with a new respiratory coronavirus related to SARS.
lead_paragraph: French officials said Friday that they are examining three people who came into contact with a man hospitalized with a new respiratory coronavirus related to SARS, to see if they have also contracted the disease. The man, 65, hospitalized in late April, got the disease on a package tour to Dubai. Officials are now examining a nurse at the hospital, a doctor and a former roommate of the man, all of whom are being monitored  by doctors. The concern is how easily the new virus might spread from one person to another. Since the virus emerged last year, 18 people have died worldwide, but the man is so far the only confirmed case in France. He is in serious but stable condition.

headline: Rivera Is Able to Laugh It Off
abstract: Back in Kansas City for the first time since his season-ending injury last May, a healthy Mariano Rivera was able to joke about what happened.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — About two hours before the first pitch of the Yankees’ game against the Kansas City Royals, and nearly 53 weeks after Mariano Rivera suffered the worst injury of his career, two men carried a 12-foot sign out to the spot where Rivera went down.

headline: Europe’s Careless Dithering
abstract: European countries need to make bold moves toward full integration of their economic policies.
lead_paragraph: EUROPE’S economic problems are growing steadily worse, with unemployment in parts of the Continent now above the level reached in the United States during the Great Depression.

headline: Benghazi E-Mails Put White House on the Defensive
abstract: A disclosure of e-mails showed the White House was more involved in revising talking points about the attack in Benghazi, Libya, than officials have previously acknowledged.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A long-simmering dispute over the White House’s account of the deadly assault on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, flared up on Friday, with a disclosure of e-mails that show the White House was more deeply involved in revising talking points about the attack than officials have previously acknowledged.

headline: Britain: Cleric May Head to Jordan
abstract: After battling Britain’s courts to avoid deportation, a militant Islamist preacher said he will fly home to Jordan if a treaty regarding torture is ratified.
lead_paragraph: After years of battling in Britain’s courts to avoid deportation to Jordan and a retrial there on terrorist bombing charges, a militant Islamist preacher of Palestinian descent known as Abu Qatada told an immigration court through his lawyer on Friday that he will fly home voluntarily if Britain and Jordan ratify a treaty concluded last month that will ensure that no evidence obtained by torture will be used in the case. The two countries have said they expect the ratification process to be completed within months. The 52-year-old cleric, whose real name is Omar Mahmoud Mohammed Othman was sentenced in absentia to life imprisonment on the bombing charges by a Jordanian court in 1990. In Britain, where he sought refugee status, he has become a symbol for many in Britain of the exploitation of the country’s immigration, welfare and justice systems by migrants seeking to use Britain as a haven for terrorist activities. Mr. Othman’s new pledge was met with widespread skepticism, with some legal experts saying he might be seeking to pre-empt a move favored by some in the government who have urged that Mr. Othman, currently held in prison for breaking bail conditions forbidding his use of cellphones and computers, be flown back to Jordan peremptorily, in defiance of British and European court rulings in his favor.

headline: Baxter’s Attentiveness Helps in the Pinch
abstract: It’s a rare player who pays such close attention while being stuck on the bench. But Mike Baxter does. This season, he is 5 for 9 as a pinch-hitter.
lead_paragraph: In trying to figure out why Mike Baxter has been such a good pinch-hitter for the Mets, Manager Terry Collins pointed to his attention to detail.

headline: Year Later, Rivera Is Back on His Feet and Stingy as Ever on the Mound
abstract: For some, it might seem inappropriate to laugh about a season-ending injury. But Mariano Rivera has focused on celebrating his return instead of lamenting what occurred last season.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — About two hours before the first pitch of the Yankees’ game against the Kansas City Royals, and nearly 53 weeks after Mariano Rivera sustained the worst injury of his career, two men carried a 12-foot sign out to the spot where Rivera went down.

abstract: Moscot, which has been selling glasses at the corner of Delancey and Orchard Streets since 1936, will have a new, nearby, location.
lead_paragraph: Moscot, which has been selling glasses at the corner of Delancey and Orchard Streets since 1936, will have a new, nearby, location.

headline: Head of Teachers’ Union Tests Candidates’ Views
abstract: Michael Mulgrew, president of the teachers’ union, has been dangling a wish list of ideas to candidates who are hoping to win the backing of the powerful union.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Mulgrew, the president of the city’s teachers’ union, looks out on a ballroom at the New York Hilton Midtown on Saturday, he will deliver a stinging speech about “mayoral dictatorship” and call for an investigation into 11 years of Department of Education data.

headline: Alan Abelson, Who at Barron’s Was a Thorn in Wall Street’s Side, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Abelson was an editor and a columnist at Barron’s magazine who delivered sharp and influential commentary on the stock markets.
lead_paragraph: Alan Abelson, a former top editor of Barron’s magazine who made waves — sometimes tsunamis — by writing a pugnacious, sagacious stock market column that denounced Wall Street hucksterism and routinely rocked share prices, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Trying to Be Hip and Edgy, Ads Become Offensive
abstract: Some of the biggest names in marketing have had to apologize after consumers objected to ads that hinged on race, rape and suicide.
lead_paragraph: Madison Avenue is learning a painful lesson: cutting edge advertising can slice both ways.

headline: F.D.A. Rejects Request to Block Sales of Generic Painkiller
abstract: The agency’s decision on generic Opana ER came just weeks after it reached the opposite conclusion in the case of another frequently abused painkiller, OxyContin.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration announced Friday that generic versions of the painkiller Opana ER can remain on the market, dealing a blow to the brand-name manufacturer, Endo Health Solutions, which had asked the agency to declare the generic versions unsafe.

headline: Environmental Review to Delay Two Engineered Crops
abstract: The Agriculture Department said approval of the crops might affect the environment and human health.
lead_paragraph: Genetically engineered crops that could sharply increase the use of two powerful herbicides are now unlikely to reach the market until at least 2015 because the Department of Agriculture has decided to subject the crops to more stringent environmental reviews than it had originally intended.

headline: Saying Zei Gezunt to an Eyeglass Store
abstract: Despite the short distance the store is moving, there is a feeling of nostalgia at Moscot, which has been selling glasses at the corner of Delancey and Orchard Streets since 1936.
lead_paragraph: Abe Schneider has been buying eyeglasses at the same store on the Lower East Side for more than 20 years, so when he needed new lenses, where did he go? Where else?

headline: Fortuneteller Pleads Guilty to Grand Larceny Charge
abstract: A spiritual adviser who promised to cure a woman’s father of cancer and said she needed to cleanse evil spirits from her cash agreed to a one-year sentence.
lead_paragraph: It began with a simple offer from a stranger on a Manhattan sidewalk, a promise to introduce a woman who appeared to be carrying a heavy emotional load to someone with spiritual powers.

headline: Dissatisfied Supporters of Manchester United Built Their Own U
abstract: The origins of F.C. United of Manchester can be traced to the dissatisfaction of Manchester United fans with the takeover by Malcolm Glazer.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — The e-mails and phone calls flow in regularly from all over the world, as soccer players, parents and fans want to get in touch with the club here known as United. The club’s staff members understand the interest in the team that famously wears red and black, so they do their best to reply to each request, whether it comes from Africa or Asia or America.

headline: Fourth No Confidence Vote for the President of N.Y.U.
abstract: The vote this week of the Steinhardt School of Culture, Education and Human Development was 117 to 45 against the president, John Sexton.
lead_paragraph: Two recent overwhelming votes of no confidence against the president of New York University have brought to four the number of N.Y.U. schools or campuses whose faculties have rejected his leadership.

headline: Father Held for Letting His Children Fire BB Guns
abstract: A man who let his 5-year-old daughter and his 3-year-old son shoot illegal weapons in a Queens park faces reckless endangerment and other charges.
lead_paragraph: The park in Queens was filled with parents and small children enjoying the spring morning on Tuesday when Zbigniew Pawlowski, 54, arrived to join the crowd of families with two children of his own — and, according to prosecutors, two illegally owned BB guns.

headline: Rutgers Coach Never Completed Degree
abstract: Eddie Jordan, a former Scarlet Knights star who went on to play and coach in the N.B.A., did not graduate from the university, although its Web site said he had.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Jordan stepped into a mess when he took over as the Rutgers men’s basketball coach last month. Now, within three weeks of arriving, he finds himself in an embarrassing situation of his own.

abstract: Fancy saris are covered with intricate embroidery and beading, which make them hard to dry clean.
lead_paragraph: Fancy saris are covered with intricate embroidery and beading, which make them hard to dry clean.

abstract: For generations, Valencia Bakery has produced cakes for Latinos in the Bronx to celebrate family milestones.
