headline: Sugary, but Real
abstract: Martine Fougeron photographs Valencia Bakery, a South Bronx institution that has made birthday, baptism and wedding cakes for generations of jubilant Latinos.
lead_paragraph: If you give a photographer coffee, she’s going to want cake. And if she wants cake, she’s going to Valencia. And if she goes to Valencia, she’s going to stay and shoot. A lot.

headline: Panel Recommends Building New School at Site of Sandy Hook Elementary
abstract: A task force on Friday unanimously recommended tearing down Sandy Hook Elementary School and building a new one on the site where a gunman killed 26 children and adults on Dec. 14.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn — Confronting imperfect options, but in a spirit more hopeful than resigned, a task force of local leaders on Friday unanimously recommended tearing down Sandy Hook Elementary School and building a new one on the site where a gunman massacred 26 children and educators on Dec. 14.

headline: Al Fritz, Who Put Youngsters on Stylish, Colorful Bikes, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Fritz designed a rugged, compact bicycle, recognizable by its banana seat and high handlebars, which Schwinn sold in the millions.
lead_paragraph: Al Fritz created stylish roadsters that were yearned for by young hot-rodders in the 1960s and ’70s. But his rolled on two wheels, not four.

headline: In Rout of Royals, Girardi Wins His 500th Game as Yankee Manager
abstract: Joe Girardi became the seventh Yankee manager to reach the milestone as the Yankees broke open a back-and-forth game with a five-run sixth.

lead_paragraph: Years ago, a friend who had moved to New York from Minneapolis to go to college marveled that the people she met who had been raised on the Upper East Side spoke with “no accent.” Although she hadn’t expected them to sound like Buddy Hackett, she was intrigued by the notion that members of the city’s upper classes didn’t particularly sound as if they were from anywhere. headline: IHT Quick Read: May 11
abstract: Survivor pulled from factory collapse; desegregating the Roma; Athens museum confronts crisis; and sailing death clouds America’s Cup.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Day after day, the grim drudgery of digging for bodies had progressed at Rana Plaza. Talk of rescuing survivors had faded. This was the recovery phase, and what was being recovered were corpses, the numbers spinning remorselessly forward: 700 dead became 800, then 900, with no end in sight. By Friday morning, the number had pushed above 1,000. And then, late in the afternoon, a soldier from the Bangladeshi Army, standing atop the rubble of the wrecked building, noticed an iron rod that seemed to be moving. There was a noise, a voice. Rescuers hurriedly carved a hole through a concrete pillar. Television stations in Bangladesh cut to the scene: a woman, gasping, was alive in the wreckage, nearly 17 full days after Rana Plaza had collapsed. A new number was announced: One. A female garment worker named Reshma. A survivor. A miracle. “Save me!” rescuers heard her shout, before they pulled her into the afternoon light, her face powdered in dust as she was placed on a stretcher. Julfikar Ali Manik reports from Dhaka, Bangladesh and Jim Yardley reports from New Delhi.

Still, I believe gin has the most fearsome reputation of all liquors, and it just doesn’t seem deserved. headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:30 P.M. (HBO) FAMILY TREE In this new, largely improvised series from Christopher Guest and Jim Piddock, Chris O’Dowd plays the down-on-his-luck Tom Chadwick, a 30-year-old Briton grappling with his identity since losing his girlfriend and his job. But when his Great-Aunt Victoria bequeaths him a chest of curios, he starts investigating his lineage to understand better who he and his unconventional family actually are. The ventriloquist Nina Conti plays his sister, Bea, who speaks through a monkey hand puppet; Michael McKean, above right, with Mr. O’Dowd, is their father. In this premiere episode, Tom finds a black-and-white portrait thought to be of his great-grandfather Harry and tracks down Neville St. Aubrey (Christopher Fairbank), an oddball antique photography expert. Tom’s best friend, Pete (Tom Bennett), meanwhile, fixes him up with a model. But what kind, exactly, no one is sure. “There is a familiarity to the series,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “As in Mr. Guest’s films, its story is less important than the presentation of a gallery of eccentrics, ranging from mildly odd to completely loony.” One result, Mr. Hale said, is that the series “can feel a little loose and inconsequential” as Tom “unearths one dotty, inglorious relative after another.” But “that also means that we get to spend more time with Mr. Guest’s crack cast of improvisers,” he added, “and there are moments in each half-hour that pay off.”

headline: A Card Game at Lunchtime
abstract: A program encompassing works by Dvorak, Brahms and Franck was performed at a lunchtime chamber-music concert on Thursday at the 92nd Street Y.

It was the lunchtime performance of the final run of chamber-music concerts presented and, in part, performed by the violinist Jaime Laredo with a program encompassing works by Dvorak, Brahms and Franck. The auditorium was divided into two camps. In the front half, the musically literate, as evidenced by the significant number of musical scores spread out on laps. In the back, 150 high school students. For the former, chamber music was a necessity on par with a well-brewed cup of coffee; for the latter, a novelty.

lead_paragraph: “Although I’ve never read a book all the way through, I’m sure excited to write one.” This is how Martin Short, in a statement from his publisher, announced Sunday that he had struck a deal to write his first book, a memoir of his life and enduring career in show business. Harper, the imprint of HarperCollins that published an autobiography of Amanda Knox last month, will release the book in fall 2014. Mr. Short, a comedian and actor who created some of his most famous characters on SCTV and “Saturday Night Live,” will write about those years, as well as his time working on films like “The Three Amigos.” He will also cover his 30-year marriage to Nancy, who died in 2010, and his longtime friendships with fellow Hollywood stars. A title is forthcoming, Mr. Short added: “I haven’t named my book yet, but I’m toying with the title ‘If I’d Saved, I Wouldn’t Be Writing This.’ ”

headline: In Suit Over Death, Boogaard’s Family Blames the N.H.L.
keywords: ['Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy', 'Concussions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hockey, Ice', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Sports Injuries', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Brain']
abstract: The family of the National Hockey League enforcer Derek Boogaard, who died of an overdose of painkillers in 2011, says the league failed to monitor his prescriptions.
lead_paragraph: The family of Derek Boogaard has filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against the National Hockey League.

headline: An Orchestra in the Throes of a Lockout
abstract: The Minnesota Orchestra, which has made remarkable artistic achievements over the past decade, lost an entire season to a lockout of the musicians by management.
lead_paragraph: When the Finnish conductor Osmo Vanska took over as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra in 2003, he told the players that he wanted it to be “the best orchestra in this country in four or five years,” he recounted in a 2006 interview.

headline: Music for Violin, With Faustian Strings Attached
abstract: A program of deviltry and mischief, with Miranda Cuckson, violin, and Blair McMillen, piano, at Columbia University’s Italian Academy.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that the Devil has the best tunes. And we also know what he plays them on: a fiddle. From Tartini’s “Devil’s Trill” Violin Sonata of 1713 to the Charlie Daniels Band’s 1979 country music ballad “The Devil Went Down to Georgia,” the instrument most readily associated with the Crafty One is a violin.

headline: Rocking and Rapping in Assorted Spots Below Houston Street
abstract: The two-night Downtown Festival, largely on the Lower East Side, offered acts like Black Hippy and Palma Violets in a range of performance spaces.
lead_paragraph: Why throw a music festival? There are so many easier things to do. An undertaking of such scale requires aesthetic vision, pinpoint organization, an ability to corral like-minded listeners into one place and at least a little hubris, but hopefully not too much.

headline: Searching for Meaning With Britten as a Guide
abstract: The Orion String Quartet was featured in the conclusion to the Britten centennial series at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concluded its Britten centennial series with a program at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night that, on paper, looked like a curious collection of pieces. In the first half there were four chamber works, three written when Britten was in his early 20s. One was composed when he was just 18: the Phantasy Quartet for oboe and strings, played dazzlingly by the virtuosic young oboist James Austin Smith and three members of the Orion String Quartet.

headline: There Is Something Rotten in the Kingdom of Rome
abstract: Two characters serve as male and female choruses, commenting on the action in Britten’s “Rape of Lucretia,” presented by the Mannes Opera.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a strong few weeks for productions of operas from the 1930s and ’40s at New York conservatories. First, on April 24, came a powerful vision of Brecht and Weill’s “Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny” at the Manhattan School of Music, a reminder of the continued relevance of that sharp and moving work.

headline: ABC to Live-Stream Its Shows via App
abstract: The live stream, which will be available only to cable and satellite subscribers, is the first time that any major broadcaster has turned on such a technology.
lead_paragraph: This week ABC will quietly revolutionize its app for iPhones and iPads with a button called “live.” Users around New York and Philadelphia will be able to live-stream all the programming from ABC’s local stations there, the first time that any major broadcaster has turned on such a technology.

headline: You’ve Heard It Many Times Before
abstract: Allan E. Parrish gets us mixed up.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Mondays are tough enough, but did Allan E. Parrish have to get us all mixed up as well?

headline: Greek Crackdown on Tax Evasion Yields Little Revenue
abstract: Tax evasion lies at the heart of the Greek financial collapse, yet efforts to collect billions of euros in taxes from deadbeat residents have yielded little additional revenue.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — If ignominy were tax revenue, Greece might be a big step closer to ending its budget problems.

headline: Rivera Again Finishes Where He Left Off
abstract: Robinson Cano and Vernon Wells hit back-to-back home runs, and Mariano Rivera got the save in what could be his final appearance in Kansas City.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — As Mariano Rivera jogged in from the Kauffman Stadium bullpen in the ninth inning for the 28th and probably final time, the fans gave him a loud ovation, even if it meant they were cheering for the opposing team.

headline: It’s Ballet, With Booze and Bulls
abstract: The Washington Ballet ventures into the world of Ernest Hemingway in Septime Webre’s two-act drama dance at the Kennedy Center’s Eisenhower Theater.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The very idea of a ballet adaptation of Ernest Hemingway’s novel “The Sun Also Rises” ought to invite snickers. I confess that I was looking forward in cynical spirit to solemn ballet mime grandly indicating Jake’s erectile dysfunction — not to mention the war wound that caused it — and, of course, a frisky dance version of the running of the bulls at Pamplona.  Yet there was no derision in evidence on Thursday night, when the Washington Ballet gave the world premiere of Septime Webre’s two-act staging at the Kennedy Center’s Eisenhower Theater.

headline: The Outlook for the Next TV Season, as Presented to Advertisers Upfront
abstract: A roundup of what worked — and what didn’t — in the 2012-13 television schedules, and what to expect from the coming upfronts.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of what worked — and what didn’t — in the 2012-13 television schedules, and what to expect from the coming upfronts.

headline: NBC Looks to Past Stars as It Rebuilds Its Schedule for a Turnaround in Prime Time
abstract: The network announced an aggressive new schedule on Sunday, crowded with new shows and familiar names.
lead_paragraph: Looking for what has been an elusive turnaround in prime time, NBC announced an aggressive new schedule on Sunday, crowded with new shows and familiar names both in front of and behind the camera.

headline: Public University Presidents Are Prospering, Annual Compensation Study Finds
abstract: According to the annual pay report by The Chronicle of Higher Education, four public university presidents had compensation packages topping $1 million.
lead_paragraph: In the 2011-12 fiscal year, the nation’s highest paid public university president was Graham B. Spanier, the president of Pennsylvania State University, who was forced out in November 2011 over his handling of a child sex abuse scandal involving a football coach.

headline: Warriors Young and Old Help Square the Series
abstract: With Stephen Curry hobbling because of an ankle injury, rookie forward Harrison Barnes and veteran guard Jarrett Jack responded with a combined 50 points to lead the Warriors past the Spurs.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Golden State Coach Mark Jackson spotted guard Stephen Curry on Sunday morning before the Warriors faced the San Antonio Spurs, he asked Curry for an update on his injured left ankle.

headline: Big Vote on Dimon May Hinge on Views on JPMorgan’s Top Director
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: A shareholder vote on whether to split Jamie Dimon’s roles as chief executive and chairman could turn on whether the board’s lead director, Lee Raymond, is seen as strong enough to stand up to Mr. Dimon.
lead_paragraph: In his 12 years as chief executive of Exxon Mobil, Lee R. Raymond had a reputation for bulldozing analysts and long-winded shareholders and going toe-to-toe with government authorities.

headline: Giving Voice to Women’s Game
keywords: ['Golf', 'Writing and Writers', 'Retirement', 'News and News Media', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Rhonda Glenn, who literally wrote the book on women’s golf, retired last week after nearly 50 years as a journalist and an employee of the United States Golf Association.
lead_paragraph: SUMMERFIELD, Fla. — When Rhonda Glenn was a young woman in 1966, she was the publicity coordinator for the L.P.G.A.’s Louise Suggs Invitational in Delray Beach, Fla. She was an amateur at that event and was paired in the first round with Mickey Wright and Betsy Rawls, who went on to become Hall of Famers.

headline: No Rest and No Margin of Error for the Rangers
abstract: The Rangers’ Derick Brassard sent a long slap shot past Braden Holtby in the second period to send the first-round playoff series back to Washington for a decisive Game 7.
lead_paragraph: The fans were tense and worried in the second period at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon. The Rangers were locked in a scoreless tie in an elimination game against the Washington Capitals. They began to nervously overpass, declining to shoot, flubbing scoring chances. The crowd responded with chants of “Shoot the puck! Shoot the puck!”

headline: Afghans Say an American Tortured Civilians
abstract: An arrest warrant has been issued for a man that Afghan officials say is an American and part of a Special Forces unit operating in Wardak Province.
lead_paragraph: MAIDAN SHAHR, Afghanistan — The authorities in Afghanistan are seeking the arrest on murder and torture charges of a man they say is an American and part of a Special Forces unit operating in Wardak Province, three Afghan officials have confirmed.

headline: Officials Say Homophobia Motivated Murder in Russia
abstract: Three men were arrested in connection with the death of a 23-year-old man in Volgograd, and the findings were a rare acknowledgment during a period of rising antigay sentiment from officials.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The brutal murder of a 23-year-old man in the southern city of Volgograd was motivated by homophobia, investigators said Sunday, a rare acknowledgment that comes during a period of rising conservative and antigay sentiment from Russian officials.

headline: Sophomore Slump Afflicts Once-Promising TV Shows
abstract: Some of the most popular new series from a year ago declined in the ratings in their second seasons.
lead_paragraph: The last thing network television needs is a sophomore slump.

headline: Hospital Mergers Reset Abortion-Access Battle
abstract: A wave of proposed and completed mergers between secular and Roman Catholic hospitals have prompted concerns in the left-leaning Pacific Northwest.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT VERNON, Wash. — Politicians seeking to restrict access to abortion, a marked trend this year from North Dakota to Arkansas, tend not to get much traction in this part of the country.

headline: Higher Bid for Kings Adds Twist to Battle
abstract: The N.B.A.’s owners will soon vote on a recommendation that the Kings be prohibited from moving to Seattle, but the group that wants to buy and relocate them raised its offer by about $49 million.
lead_paragraph: The fight for ownership of the Sacramento Kings, one of the N.B.A.’s most beleaguered franchises, will take a big step toward resolution Wednesday when the league’s owners vote on a recommendation that the team be prohibited from moving to Seattle.

headline: Newspaper Monopoly That Lost Its Grip
abstract: The New Orleans Times-Picayune announced it would return to producing a printed product every day after losing both readers and advertisers and gaining competition.
lead_paragraph: A year after announcing a plan to reorganize The Times-Picayune of New Orleans into a more digitally focused enterprise that produced a newspaper just three days a week — enraging local residents — its owners have added a new innovation: they will go back to producing a printed product every day.

headline: Jack Butler, an Undrafted Football Hall of Famer, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Butler, who in nine seasons with the Steelers intercepted 52 passes, was a first-team all-N.F.L. player three times and was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Jack Butler, who was ignored in the National Football League draft but became a Hall of Fame defensive back with the Pittsburgh Steelers and was chosen for the league’s all-decade team of the 1950s, died on Saturday in Pittsburgh. He was 85.

headline: Catskill Cultural Center Saved, and Renewed, Thanks to a Fiddler’s Tune
abstract: Jay Ungar and Molly Mason’s “Ashokan Farewell,” heard on Ken Burns’s Civil War series, helped preserve an area of the Catskill Mountains that inspired the song.
lead_paragraph: OLIVEBRIDGE, N.Y. — On a spring Sunday in the Catskill Mountains, Jay Ungar, a fiddler wearing a black vest and hiking boots, and his wife, Molly Mason, playing guitar, stood on a stage in a barnlike performance hall that did not exist a year ago. “Can you stand to hear this tune one more time?” he asked the audience.

headline: A New Direction for a Hasbro Stalwart
abstract: Hoping to build on the popularity of My Little Pony, Hasbro plans a theatrical release as part of a campaign for its brand extension, Equestria Girls.
lead_paragraph: Hasbro, the toy company that brought its Transformers and G.I. Joe properties to movie theaters, has set its sights on its next summer blockbuster: My Little Pony.

abstract: The Knicks, down two games to one against the Pacers, have gotten away from the balanced attack that was their calling card in the regular season.

headline: Cyberattacks Against U.S. Corporations Are on the Rise
abstract: Officials said the aim in a new wave of attacks was not espionage but sabotage, and that the source seemed to be in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new wave of cyberattacks is striking American corporations, prompting warnings from federal officials, including a vague one issued last week by the Department of Homeland Security. This time, officials say, the attackers’ aim is not espionage but sabotage, and the source seems to be somewhere in the Middle East.

headline: ‘Equestria Girls’ Trailer
abstract: Hoping to build on the popularity of My Little Pony, Hasbro is planning a theatrical release as part of a campaign for its brand extension, Equestria Girls.
lead_paragraph: Hoping to build on the popularity of My Little Pony, Hasbro is planning a theatrical release as part of a campaign for its brand extension, Equestria Girls.

headline: Seeking Clues to Heart Disease in DNA of an Unlucky Family
abstract: Scientists are studying the DNA of the Del Sontro family for mutations or aberrations, hoping to see if genetics can explain why heart disease strikes apparently healthy people.
lead_paragraph: Early heart disease ran in Rick Del Sontro’s family, and every time he went for a run, he was scared his heart would betray him. So he did all he could to improve his odds. He kept himself lean, stayed away from red meat, spurned cigarettes and exercised intensely, even completing an Ironman Triathlon.

headline: Ace’s Moral Victories Move the Mets Closer to Real Ones
abstract: With the Mets, there is nothing more important than the development of 24-year-old Matt Harvey, who has become the best pitcher in the league after only 18 starts.
lead_paragraph: None of the Pittsburgh Pirates had faced Matt Harvey before Sunday, but they were familiar with him. It is hard to miss the first pitcher in the last 100 years to strike out at least 125 and allow fewer than 25 runs in his first 17 career starts.

headline: Pakistani Party Leader Looks Forward, as Claims of Vote-Rigging Swirl
keywords: ['Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was projected to be the big winner in Saturday’s election, which was marred by violence and reports of fraud at the polls.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif began talks on Sunday to form a new government, as partial election returns suggested that he and his party would have a commanding hold on Parliament. But Pakistani election officials said final results would take days, even as outrage grew over accusations of rampant vote-rigging, particularly in Karachi.

headline: E Pluribus Me
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ted Cruz and the politics of selfishness.
lead_paragraph: Logic, thy name is not Ted Cruz. The very junior senator from Texas is a well-credentialed windbag, with degrees from Princeton and Harvard Law, and a stint clerking at the Supreme Court. After a few months in Congress promoting Ted Cruz, smartest guy in the room, it looks as if he now wants to be Ted Cruz, extremely obnoxious president. But he keeps saying things that make no sense.

headline: New York State to Ask Smartphone Makers to Help Prevent Thefts

lead_paragraph: Concerned about an increase in smartphone thefts, the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is trying to get the nation’s largest cellphone makers to do more to discourage the thefts.

headline: How Austerity Kills

abstract: People do not inevitably get sick or die because the economy has faltered. Fiscal policy can be a matter of life or death.
lead_paragraph: EARLY last month, a triple suicide was reported in the seaside town of Civitanova Marche, Italy. A married couple, Anna Maria Sopranzi, 68, and Romeo Dionisi, 62, had been struggling to live on her monthly pension of around 500 euros (about $650), and had fallen behind on rent.

headline: Google’s Offer to Europe
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Editorials']
abstract: The company’s proposal is a good start, but policy makers must remain watchful so Google does not abuse its power and limit competition.
lead_paragraph: Google’s competitors, like Microsoft, Expedia and Yelp, have long complained that the company uses its dominant search engine — it has more than 90 percent market share in Europe and about 70 percent in the United States — to promote its own services, like YouTube, Google Maps and others, at the expense of rivals.

headline: Last Word to Woods as García’s Game Sinks on Last 2 Holes
abstract: Tiger Woods shot a final-round of 70 for a 13-under 275 to overtake Sergio García and win the Players Championship for his 78th career victory.
lead_paragraph: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — As the Players Championship wound down Sunday, there were as many compelling stories on the leader board as there were golf balls in the water surrounding the tournament’s signature hole, the par-3 17th.

headline: Student Debt and the Crushing of the American Dream
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Student Loans', 'United States Economy']
abstract: With soaring costs, stagnating incomes and little help from the government, there is only one way to pay for higher education: debt.
lead_paragraph: A CERTAIN drama has become familiar in the United States (and some other advanced industrialized countries): Bankers encourage people to borrow beyond their means, preying especially on those who are financially unsophisticated. They use their political influence to get favorable treatment of one form or another. Debts mount. Journalists record the human toll. Then comes bewilderment: How could we let this happen again? Officials promise to fix things. Something is done about the most egregious abuses. People move on, reassured that the crisis has abated, but suspecting that it will recur soon.

headline: San Diego Mayor Building Economic Bridges to Tijuana
abstract: Mayor Bob Filner sees the border as a potential economic engine for the region, a remarkable shift in a city once viewed as a hotbed for illegal immigration.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Opening a satellite city office in a far-flung neighborhood is not unusual in sprawling cities like this one. But one thing sets apart Mayor Bob Filner’s newest outpost: it is in another country.

headline: Another Round of Promises in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Even after the building collapse, it’s unclear whether the government will carry out labor reforms.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure to respond to the collapse of a factory building that killed more than 1,100 people, the government of Bangladesh recently pledged to impose reforms to its labor laws and safety standards. If carried out fully, the much-delayed changes could go a long way toward improving working conditions in the country’s garment industry. But that is a big if.

headline: Scrutiny on Prosecutors After Questions About Brooklyn Detective’s Work

lead_paragraph: As the Brooklyn district attorney’s office pledged a complete review of about 50 murder cases after questions arose regarding the conduct of the detective assigned to them, renewed scrutiny has also focused on the role prosecutors play in what turn out to be wrongful convictions, and whether they should be held responsible when justice goes awry.

headline: Who Can Take Republicans Seriously?
abstract: A peace offering is pointless when they refuse to be real negotiation partners.
lead_paragraph: It is time for President Obama to abandon his hopes of reaching a grand budget bargain with Republicans.

abstract: The Rangers have dropped 10 of their last 11 playoff games in Washington and have strained to muster any offense.
lead_paragraph: As impressive as the Rangers were against the Washington Capitals on Sunday, their strong all-around performance left them to face a grim reality.

headline: City Plans New Approach to Disciplining Mentally Ill Inmates
abstract: New York City’s new policy, which will include counseling and medicine, is intended as an alternative to solitary confinement and aims to address the increase in such prisoners.
lead_paragraph: New York City will soon change the way mentally ill inmates are disciplined after breaking rules while in jail, creating alternatives to the more traditional approach of solitary confinement used for most inmates.

headline: As Minutes Add Up for Bulls’ Starters, Time Seems to Be on Heat’s Side
abstract: The Heat have a key tactical advantage — reinforcements — with Bulls Coach Tom Thibodeau being forced to lean heavily on whatever healthy bodies he has.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Chicago Bulls want to play rough, and they have made no secret of it. They have turned their second-round Eastern Conference playoff series against the Miami Heat into a black-and-blue affair, defined by bumps, bruises, elbows and shoves.

abstract: The Benghazi hearings have raised questions about Hillary Clinton's role in that incident. But what of her overall tenure as our top diplomat?

headline: Alarm Bells in Albany
abstract: After the recent scandals, there is growing pressure on lawmakers, especially recalcitrant Senate Republicans, to pass electoral reforms.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who promised to clean up state government in his 2010 campaign, has now become so alarmed by the latest scandals in Albany that he has issued a threat lawmakers ought to take seriously. If the Legislature does not pass a package of electoral reforms, including public financing, before the session ends in June, he says he will consider appointing a Moreland Act Commission that can investigate and subpoena government officials suspected of misconduct. The commission would be able to make public its findings and pass those findings on to local or federal investigators.

headline: Dark Heritage
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: What we can learn from a think tank’s over-the-top attack on immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: Last week the Heritage Foundation delivered a report claiming that legalizing undocumented immigrants will create a more-or-less permanent underclass of benefit-sucking, wage-lowering, economy-crippling parasites, with a cost to American taxpayers of — megaphone, please — SIX POINT THREE TRILLION DOLLARS! The report was promptly denounced, not least by reputable conservative economists, for example here and here and here. Then one of the report’s co-authors resigned from Heritage after The Washington Post discovered that he had once proposed blocking immigrants with low I.Q. scores. (More on that later.)

headline: As TV Ratings and Profits Fall, Networks Face a Cliffhanger
abstract: The broadcast networks are preparing to unveil new fall lineups for an audience that is shrinking rapidly, lured away by new rivals on all sides.
lead_paragraph: As the major television networks prepare to unveil their new fall lineups in New York this week, they face threats from seemingly every corner.

headline: What Racial Profiling? Police Testify Complaint Is Rarely Made
abstract: City lawyers suggested that police profiling in the use of the stop-and-frisk tactic was largely a fiction created by civil rights lawyers.
lead_paragraph: He had naturally heard the accusations of racial profiling, from civil rights organizations and some politicians. But in more than a decade as the top chief in the New York Police Department, Joseph J. Esposito said he never once heard a private citizen complain about a racially motivated stop-and-frisk encounter.

headline: Central Park Group Is Seeking Better Playgrounds
abstract: The Central Park Conservancy said it would initiate a $40 million fund-raising campaign on Monday to pay for renovations to the park’s 21 playgrounds.
lead_paragraph: The Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit group that manages Central Park, said it would initiate a $40 million fund-raising campaign on Monday to pay for the restoration and improvement of the park’s 21 playgrounds.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Stranger Bearing Gifts
abstract: A man finds a seeming kinship with his daughter’s suitor in “A Family for All Occasions,” Bob Glaudini’s play about familial dysfunction, at Bank Street Theater.
lead_paragraph: Domestic disintegration seems to be taking place in real time in “A Family for All Occasions,” a grindingly dull new play by Bob Glaudini that opened on Sunday night at the Bank Street Theater in a production directed by Philip Seymour Hoffman.

headline: Walters to Announce 2014 Retirement on ‘The View’
abstract: Network television’s first anchorwoman plans to announce Monday that next year she will leave the business where she broke barriers and rules for more than 50 years.
lead_paragraph: On the program she invented, on the network where she worked for the past 37 years, on the medium where she broke barriers and rules for more than 50 years, Barbara Walters will announce on Monday morning, definitively and with no regrets, that she is calling it a career.

headline: Newark Archbishop Is Criticized for His Handling of an Abuse Case
abstract: A state senator has called for the archbishop, John J. Myers, to step down after reports that a priest barred from being around children unsupervised had been working recently with youths.
lead_paragraph: COLTS NECK, N.J. — With 10 children knelt around the altar for their first communion and the pews at St. Mary’s Church packed with families gathered for Mother’s Day, there was little sign on Sunday of the turmoil that has struck the parish, and threatens the Archdiocese of Newark.

headline: When the Pinstripes Get Ruffled

lead_paragraph: The Yankees have long gone by the nickname the Bombers, but they could just as easily be known as the Bronx Bickersons. And this weekend’s latest version is no exception.

headline: Valuable as Art, but Priceless as a Tool to Launder Money
abstract: Criminals are increasingly using expensive artworks — bought and sold in secret and with little regulation — to hide ill-gotten profits, the authorities say.
lead_paragraph: According to the air bill slapped on the crate that arrived at Kennedy International Airport from London, an unnamed painting worth $100 was inside. Only later did federal investigators discover that it was by the American artist Jean-Michel Basquiat and worth $8 million.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 13
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 13.
lead_paragraph: “We need to make the border the center, not the end — but the biggest problem we have is not security, it is openness and communication.”

headline: Bottled Secrets of the Geisha
abstract: The Japanese skincare line Tatcha has created oils and balms using camellia and gold leaf created to protect and enhance skin.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco-based skin care expert Victoria Tsai has built her business by studying the beauty secrets, passed down over generations, of the traditional Japanese entertainers known as geisha. After many trips east and countless hours studying makeup regimens, Tsai founded Tatcha, a line of 95-percent-natural products made and formulated in Japan. One of her first discoveries was aburatorigami, the traditional handmade blotting papers used in ancient Japan to protect gold as it is hammered into delicate gold leaf. Several centuries ago, geisha realized that the papers could also absorb facial oil, without disturbing their signature stage makeup. “I tried to do exactly what the geisha were doing, but also make products that are a little bit easier to use,” Tsai said. “And they use our stuff now.”

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13) THE INVISIBLE WAR (2012) The Department of Defense estimates that there were 22,800 sexual assaults in the United States military in 2011. Veterans Affairs studies have shown that one-third of women seeking assistance have been sexually assaulted, and that more men than women are assaulted while in service. This Academy Award nominee for best documentary feature, directed by Kirby Dick and produced by Amy Ziering, uses interviews with retired and active service members to investigate the epidemic of rape within the military. (A female soldier in a combat zone is more likely to be attacked by a fellow soldier than killed by enemy fire.) “Military service is often a family tradition, and the military itself, with its customs of loyalty, solidarity and shared sacrifice, can be a kind of family for its members,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “This means that the violations chronicled in ‘The Invisible War’ are compounded by a deep and terrible betrayal, which ripples outward from the various branches of the service into the society as a whole. This is not a movie that can be ignored.” (Above Kori Cioca, who served in the Coast Guard, and her husband, Rob.)

headline: Focaccia: One Basic Bread, Endless Delicious Options
abstract: Easy flatbreads made with whole-wheat flour are a terrific vehicle for all kinds of vegetables and herbs.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago I gave you a recipe for a walnut fougasse, or focaccia. The bread was so easy to make, and such a great vehicle for the walnuts, that I got onto a focaccia kick and started making it just about every day, topping it with vegetables and sometimes filling it with them. I tried different proportions of whole-wheat and all-purpose flour, never using less than half whole-wheat, and found that the same overall recipe worked no matter how I varied the proportions. I’m working with a terrific whole-wheat flour produced in California, available online and now carried by Fairway, called Community Grains. But I also made the focaccia with King Arthur white whole-wheat flour (I used 100 percent in that version; the result had a slightly denser, tighter texture than the other focacce).

headline: I Was Groped on the Subway
abstract: Why hadn’t I yelled, or elbowed him? The truth is, I thought for a moment I might be crazy, that I was making it all up.

It was Friday, a few weeks after my 29th birthday. I was on my way downtown to my job at my family’s taxi business, casually dressed in leggings and a striped orange dress. I pushed my still wet hair out of my face and found a sliver of space to stand. As the doors were closing, one more person shoved his way in and the car let out a collective groan.

headline: The Birth of the ‘Stainless Banner’
abstract: Why did the Confederacy replace its national flag in 1863?
lead_paragraph: On May 1, 1863, the Confederate Congress approved a new national flag – colloquially dubbed the Stainless Banner – to replace the so-called Stars and Bars, the Confederacy’s national flag since March 1861. The new flag was a plain white field emblazoned with what was already a powerful and famous Confederate symbol, the Southern Cross, the star-bedecked blue saltire, or diagonal cross, that had been a famous battle flag since the fall of 1861. Its incorporation into the national flag confirmed the Southern Cross as the de facto symbol of Confederate nationalism.

lead_paragraph: If the words “audience participation” make you queasy, then “Everyone Was Chanting Your Name” probably isn’t for you. The lights are up at the Abrons Arts Center, and the rectangular seating arrangement is small enough to mean that everyone has a front-row seat: there’s nowhere to hide in this latest production by the rising young theater company 600 Highwaymen.

headline: Upgrades on Schedule for Gowanus Canal Pumping Station Despite Hurricane
abstract: Work on the facility that directs sewage was interrupted by Hurricane Sandy, and plans were modified to reflect lessons learned from the storm, but the project is still expected to be completed this year, officials announced.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Sandy swept across the Gowanus Canal last year, a pumping station that redirects sewage to a pollution-control plant was damaged and went offline for almost 33 hours, according to a report released by the city after the storm. About 13 million gallons of raw sewage flowed into the canal before the city installed a generator that restored power to the station.

headline: Mental Evaluations Endorse Insanity Plea in Colorado Shootings, Defense Says

lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — Mental health experts who evaluated the man accused of killing 12 people in a Colorado movie theater last year have offered a diagnosis that bolsters an insanity plea in the case, his lawyers said at a hearing here on Monday.

The hiatus was not by choice, but was mandated by a stroke — the out-of-the-blue variant, the rare kind of “brain attack” (the term preferred by some neurologists) that is most often seen in otherwise healthy, youngish middle-aged people.

lead_paragraph: Cowboys, horses, disaffected teenagers snapping fingers, pedestrian traffic — the three ballets danced by New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday included images of all those. The music was all American, for the ballet company’s American Music Festival, and it all had populist appeal. George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins knew how to exploit that appeal choreographically while remaining themselves.

headline: Letting Go of Whimsy in Favor of Feeling
abstract: The comedy “New Girl” ends its second season, which changed its approach and rescued the series from whimsy.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a traditional sitcom setup: A new person is introduced into a circle that has established relationships and routines, and high jinks ensue. Everyone regards the contagion funnily, moves around him or her to avoid confrontation, and professes not to understand the mannerisms of the intruder, which don’t neatly align with How Things Have Always Been Done. Eventually, of course, things line up — sweet, sweet resolution.

headline: She’s 88, and Swings From Saucy to Somber
abstract: At the age of 88, the jazz pianist Barbara Carroll, playing at Birdland, still exudes the spirit and enthusiasm of a teenager.
lead_paragraph: One of the many reasons Barbara Carroll has been called the first lady of jazz piano is her quietly expressive breadth. At Birdland on Saturday evening, Ms. Carroll, who is 88 but exudes the spirit and enthusiasm of a very sophisticated teenager, played a set whose moods ran from playful to reflective to a light stomp, sometimes all in the same song. Ms. Carroll has always had special simpatico with the rarefied wit of Cy Coleman and Carolyn Leigh. Singing and playing the obscure “I Wanna Be Yours,” she evoked the golden age of screwball comedy with the sly, teasing innuendo of lines like, “I wanna be all the cream in your dairy/your favorite tooth fairy.”

Leonard Slatkin conducted the Detroit Symphony Orchestra on Thursday and Friday, and Christoph Eschenbach led the National Symphony Orchestra on Saturday.

abstract: The I.R.S. is supposed to enforce the tax code. Under current law, however, it has little choice but to exercise discretion in the constitutionally dangerous waters of campaign finance.

headline: Patrick Demarchelier’s Bodies of Desire
abstract: A new exhibition of work by the influential French photographer shows his knack for capturing the female form.
lead_paragraph: The French photographer Patrick Demarchelier famously started out taking passport pictures as a teenager, and ever since then he’s been creating images that take people to unfamiliar places. Now 69, he is internationally renowned for his portraits of supermodels, princesses and celebrities for publications like Vogue, Harper’s Bazaar, Elle and Vanity Fair. Since his career took off in the 1970s, he has had an outsize influence on the way artists portray fashion and stardom. “Desire,” a new exhibition of his black-and-white photographs opening tomorrow in Paris, is a testament to Demarchelier’s ability to capture the female body. The 20 images include Laetitia Casta, stretching her naked ribcage taut; Helena Christensen, crouching and eyeing the camera with a panther stare; and Kate Moss and Carla Bruni, sitting together like interlocking puzzle pieces. Every contour suggests both purity and provocation, speaking to the very essence of desire.

headline: Temporary Limit Put on Sales of Morning-After Pill
abstract: The Justice Department appealed the Obama administration’s request for a stay of an order that the pill be available without a prescription for everyone.
lead_paragraph: At least through the end of May, the Plan B One-Step morning-after contraceptive will not be sold over the counter for all ages. A federal appeals court on Monday temporarily granted the Obama administration’s request for a stay of an order by Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court that the pill be available without a prescription for everyone. The Justice Department has appealed that order and the appeals court said it would keep the order from being implemented until it hears from both sides. In the interim, the pill is available without a prescription for women and girls ages 15 and older.

headline: The Art of Repetition

Harper, lead author of a paper on the research. The nimble camera work, she said, produced “the ‘aha’ moment” of the study — read on for the results.

headline: China: Former Police Official Detained

Mr. Tang was a close associate of Wang Lijun, the former Chongqing police chief who had a falling out with Bo Xilai, the disgraced Communist aristocratic politician. Mr. Wang was sentenced last year to 15 years in prison for various crimes, and Mr. Bo awaits trial. Mr. Tang was detained last year after the fall of both of those men. Mr. Tang received an award on Feb. 28, 2010, for his role in the “strike black” campaign, a drive led by Mr. Wang that ended up with many innocent civilians under detention and being tortured. Mr. Tang was promoted to deputy police chief after receiving the award.

Until I got to biology class in high school and got turned off by my teacher — which does happen, even if we’d rather talk about teachers who inspire their students. By the time I applied to college an interest in government had displaced gills — or so I thought, listing political science as my intended major.

headline: Vermont Passes ‘Aid in Dying’ Measure
abstract: Vermont is the first state to permit physician-assisted suicide by legislation, rather than referendum or court order.
lead_paragraph: Vermont will become the fourth state to make it legal for a physician to prescribe lethal medication to a terminally ill, mentally competent patient who wants to end his life. It has also become the first state to approve the practice through legislation, instead of via a public referendum (as in Oregon and Washington) or a court decision (in Montana).

headline: Bruins Save Best for Last
abstract: The Bruins became the first team to overcome a three-goal deficit in the third period of a Game 7 in the N.H.L. playoffs.
lead_paragraph: You have to hand it to the Boston Bruins. They have this Game 7 thing down to a science. Seriously. How do you top a 2011 Stanley Cup run that featured three Game 7 victories, including a first-round tightrope walk/grudge match in overtime against Montreal? How do you make fans forget last year’s Game 7 overtime loss at home in the first round against Washington? How do you wipe away the epic face plant of 2010, losing not only a 3-0 series lead to hated Philadelphia, but also a 3-0 lead in Game 7 at home?

Yet they know more about the horse at the end of their lead line than anyone else at the racetrack.  Often, by the time the horse is loaded into the starting gate, their groom has already spent more than nine hours by their side that day.

headline: Beyoncé Cancels Show in Belgium
abstract: A publicist said the singer was ordered by her doctors to rest, but she plans to resume performing Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé has canceled a concert in Belgium that was scheduled for Tuesday night because she is dehydrated and exhausted, The Associated Press reported. The pop diva’s publicist told the wire service that she has been ordered by her doctors to rest. She had been slated to perform at the Sportpaleis in Antwerp. She has another show at the arena on Wednesday, and her publicist said “she is awaiting word from her doctors before making a decision” about that performance. Beyoncé, 31, started her Mrs. Carter Show World Tour last month in Belgrade, Serbia, and it will finish on Aug. 5 at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Lots of Lancaster at Lincoln Center
abstract: With the possible exception of Marlon Brando, no male star radiated more magnetism than Burt Lancaster.
lead_paragraph: With the possible exception of Marlon Brando, no male star of his era radiated more raw magnetism than Burt Lancaster, whose centennial is being celebrated by the Film Society of Lincoln Center this Friday through May 23. Nowadays, macho preening too often passes for the kind of feral grace radiated by Lancaster in films like “The Killers,” the 1946 noir classic adapted from a Ernest Hemingway short story and directed by Robert Siodmak.

headline: States Urged to Cut Limit on Alcohol for Drivers
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board is recommending that states reduce the allowable blood-alcohol content to 0.05 percent, instead of the current 0.08 percent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thousands of people are killed or injured every year by drivers who have not reached the legal standard for being drunk but who have a reduced ability to see, make decisions or operate a vehicle, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday, and it recommended that the states reduce the allowable blood-alcohol concentration by more than a third, to 0.05 percent from 0.08 percent.

headline: The Gun Report: May 14, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Brandon Holt, 6, was shot and killed by a 4-year-old boy in Toms River, N.J., kicking off a bloody month in which several toddlers accidentally shot other toddlers. The 4-year-old got a hold of his father’s .22 caliber rifle and brought it into the yard, where it went off, hitting Holt in the head. Yesterday it was announced that Anthony Senatore, 33, the father of the “gunman,” was arrested for having multiple unsecured weapons accessible to children.

headline: A New Executive Director for Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center
abstract: Suzanne Davidson will replace Norma Hurlburt, who has held the post since 2000.
lead_paragraph: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has appointed Suzanne Davidson as its new executive director, starting on July 1. She succeeds Norma Hurlburt, the society’s director since 2000. Ms. Hurlburt is leaving to start her own consulting business for nonprofit organizations. The society also announced that its artistic directors, the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han, who are married, had renewed their contract for a third term, which will take them through the 2018-19 season.

headline: The Rickshaw Driver’s Curry

My family journeyed last year from the verdant tea plantations of Munnar down to the Cardamom Hills of Kerala, in southwestern India. Our driver, Janaki Raman, who had proved himself by dodging many a cow on the winding mountain roads, asked whether we might like to go to a local cooking class.

lead_paragraph: Microsoft is shedding the Windows Blue code name for the next installment of its operating system. The official name of the software will be — drumroll, please — Windows 8.1.

Against all odds, Mr. Benamer had broken out of the rough suburb, or banlieue, where he grew up in a family of poor Moroccan immigrants just northeast of Paris, and hit on a formula that would soon turn into a business success beyond his dreams.

lead_paragraph: Shortly after the Emancipation Proclamation declared that African-Americans, “of suitable condition, will be received into the armed service of the United States,” the governor of Massachusetts, John Albion Andrew – one of the most aggressively antislavery officials to hold public office during the Civil War – put out a call across the North for men to fill the ranks of an exclusively black volunteer regiment.

headline: The Obama Synthesis Under Siege
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Medicaid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Why the latest wave of scandals poses a particular challenge to Obama-ism.
lead_paragraph: The true ideological inclinations of the Obama White House can be endlessly debated, but slightly more than halfway through this presidency I think it’s fair to make the following generalization: Obama has governed as a business-friendly social democrat and an aggressive social liberal, as a hawkish interventionist when intervention seems cheap and easy (drones, missiles, etc.) and a cautious realist when it doesn’t, and as a surprisingly vigorous defender of presidential prerogatives across a variety of fronts. A few weeks ago, I characterized Obama-era liberalism as featuring “an imperial presidency, a corporatist economic policy, and then a libertarian turn on almost every social issue,” and while that line misses various nuances and complexities, as one-sentence summaries go I think it’s pretty good.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Permanent Job Crisis
abstract: An author says we need to adapt to a changing job market. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Jolie’s Disclosure of Preventive Mastectomy Highlights Dilemma

lead_paragraph: One of the defining moments in the history of breast cancer occurred in 1974 when the first lady, Betty Ford, spoke openly about her mastectomy, lifting a veil of secrecy from the disease and ushering in a new era of breast cancer awareness.

They’ll be wearing bespoke jewelry made from the precious metal, commissioned by Roitfeld, including the cuffs seen above by the chic, celebrity-endorsed designers (from left) Kimberly McDonald, Hoorsenbuhs and Ana Khouri. The pieces will subsequently be made to order at LoveGold, an online community dedicated to gold jewelry. headline: A Quest for Justice in Guatemala
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Photography', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Daniel Hernández-Salazar’s life has been shaped by his quest — as an artist and Guatemalan — to see justice for the crimes committed during that country’s civil war. Last week, his vigil ended.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Hernández-Salazar is used to waiting. Two decades ago he abandoned his photojournalistic career to devote himself to documenting the search for justice in the wake of Guatemala’s 36-year civil war. He stood at exhumations alongside indigenous Maya, as they waited to spy a bracelet or scrap of muddy fabric that would allow them to finally locate the bones of a loved one. More recently, he stood among them in a Guatemala City courtroom as the former dictator, Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, was sentenced to 80 years for genocide and crimes against humanity.

headline: Suspicious Substance Disrupts U.S. Consulate in China
abstract: The unidentified substance was found in an envelope in the consulate in the southern city of Guangzhou, prompting the closing of some operations.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Staff members at the United States Consulate in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou discovered a suspicious substance in an envelope on Monday, prompting the closing of some operations. The substance, which was found in a part of the consulate not open to the public, has yet to be identified. No consulate workers have suffered any ill effects and no visitors are believed to have been exposed, said Nolan Barkhouse, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Beijing. “The consulate has notified Chinese authorities and is maintaining close contact with them in case any assistance becomes necessary,” Mr. Barkhouse said. The consulate was closed for visa interviews on Tuesday and will remain closed Wednesday pending an investigation. The consulate handles 121,000 visa applications annually and processes all immigrant visas for Chinese children adopted by American citizens.

Last week, it recorded its first quarterly profit and received the best score that Consumer Reports has bestowed on a car for six years. The company’s stock has since surged as much as 70 percent, leaving Tesla worth more than Fiat and Peugeot combined. Its stock is also trading at a whopping 27 times estimates for earnings in 2016.
