headline: T-Mobile USA Bumps Up Price of iPhone by $50
abstract: When T-Mobile USA first started offering the iPhone 5, it had the cheapest deal in town: $100 up front — half the cost of the iPhone on a rival network like AT&T or Verizon Wireless. But now the cost of the iPhone on T-Mobile is closer to the competition, at $150.
lead_paragraph: When T-Mobile USA first started offering the iPhone 5, it had the cheapest deal in town: $100 up front (not including the monthly bill) — which is half the cost of the iPhone on a rival network like AT&T or Verizon Wireless. But now the cost of the iPhone on T-Mobile is closer to the competition, at $150.

headline: No, He’s Not, but the Bullies Still Won’t Give Him a Break
abstract: “QueerSpawn” is a comedy about a straight teenager who is picked on because some of his peers think he’s gay.
lead_paragraph: Every day of high school is a fresh hell for the unhappy young hero of “queerSpawn,” a slight but compassionate and bleakly funny play by Mallery Avidon that opened at Here Arts Center on Tuesday night. If one tormentor is not spray-painting a gay slur across his locker in vivid neon, another is shoving him in a big cardboard box and taping it shut.

headline: Feeling For | Asprey Private Collection Handbags
abstract: The leather goods brand has created 41 bespoke pieces using exotic skins and semiprecious stones.
lead_paragraph: As a second act to her debut collection for Asprey last summer, the accessories designer Katie Hillier unveils another line of handbags, called the Private Collection, for the English jewelry and leather goods brand early next month. Hillier worked with a small team to create 41 bespoke pieces that, she says, “appeal to clients that are looking for a unique piece of art.” Influenced by hand-painted mosaic motifs, Hillier used a rainbow of exotic skins and semiprecious stones to dress up the simple, timeless designs. One standout is this Rothkoesque bag in crocodile with over four carats of diamonds.

headline: Vagabonds, Sharing Wine and Bonhomie, Traverse Their Inner Worlds
abstract: “The Hotel Colors,” Eliza Bent’s debut play about a day in the life of a group of bedraggled travelers in Italy, is at the Bushwick Starr.
lead_paragraph: “Most rudest people I have ever met!”

headline: Revolutionary Coming-of-Age in Wisconsin
abstract: “Pinkolandia,” by Andrea Thome, recounts the story of a family of Chilean exiles that has relocated to Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: “Pinkolandia” runs a tad long and talks a little too much and could use a slightly sharper plot. Yet I’m not sure how much I’d change about this ambitious and often beautiful new play.

headline: A Museum Plot for Green-Wood Cemetery
abstract: Brooklyn’s Green-Wood Cemetery, now 175 years old, is the subject of a new show, “A Beautiful Way to Go,” at the Museum of the City of New York.
lead_paragraph: Death may not be pretty, but for 175 years many families have chosen a grave site at the bucolic Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn to help make eternity a charming affair.

headline: Church Plans Art Pavilion at Biennale
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church will open its first pavilion at the Venice Biennale this summer, featuring the Czech photographer Josef Koudelka and the artist Lawrence Carroll.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — It commissioned the Sistine Chapel, countless portraits of popes and even Matisse’s chapel in Vence, France. Now the Roman Catholic Church will sponsor its first pavilion at the Venice Biennale, featuring the Czech photographer Josef Koudelka, the Milan-based multimedia group Studio Azzurro and the artist Lawrence Carroll.

headline: Leak Investigations Are an Assault on the Press, and on Democracy, Too
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: The seizing of A.P. phone records has broad and worrisome implications.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be the administration of unprecedented transparency. President Obama promised that when he took office, and the White House’s Web site says so on this very day. It reads:

headline: The Envelope Please: Sush Krishnamoorthy
abstract: In the beginning, my dream of attending college in the United States with limited funds seemed to be just that: a dream. However, I am grateful to have had friends and family who were supportive.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, my dream of attending college in the United States with limited funds seemed to be just that: a dream. However, I am grateful to have had friends and family who were supportive.

headline: An Opera Star, Freckles, Blemishes and All
abstract: “Becoming Traviata” follows the soprano Natalie Dessay through rehearsals in this documentary directed by Philippe Béziat.
lead_paragraph: A behind-the-scenes look at an Aix-en-Provence staging of Verdi’s “Traviata,” the impressionistic, handsomely shot “Becoming Traviata,” directed by Philippe Béziat, may not be fully satisfying as a documentary. But it has what any good movie needs: a star — the ever-game soprano Natalie Dessay.

headline: Wigs and Whips, Songs and Maces, and Legislation, Too
abstract: The National Theater’s production of “This House,” a re-creation of British parliamentary politics in the 1970s, will be shown in a live screening at selected theaters on May 16.
lead_paragraph: It was with a leaden sense of duty that I dragged myself — through a stinging March snowfall, no less — to the National Theater to see “This House,” by James Graham. What lay before me was nearly three hours of re-enactments of life in the House of Commons four decades ago. What did I know from parliamentary politics, especially from the 1970s?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hidden Online Audiences and Cicada Math
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include the job you can’t list any more on LinkedIn, an imaginary response from Bloomberg News about its scandal and technology investors financing coffee shops.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: A Scruffy Hound That Money Can’t Buy
abstract: “Old Dog,” by the novelist and director Pema Tseden, centers on a tug of war over a Tibetan mastiff.
lead_paragraph: The beast at the center of “Old Dog” — a Tibetan tale of pride, principle and family priorities — is one of the sorriest-looking creatures ever to grace a movie screen. Scruffy, matted and with a tail that resembles a filthy feather duster, this forlorn specimen, known locally as a nomad mastiff, is nevertheless the catalyst for an astonishing tug of war.

headline: Revisiting a ‘Previvor’
abstract: In 2007, Deborah Lindner, then 33, underwent an elective double mastectomy after finding out she had a gene carrying a high risk of breast cancer. Six years later, Dr. Lindner offers an update.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, Deborah Lindner, then 33, underwent an elective double mastectomy after finding out she had a gene carrying a high risk of breast cancer. Six years later, Dr. Lindner offers an update.

headline: Q. & A. | Daft Punk’s Secret Weapon: Producer Todd Edwards
abstract: “Todd the God,” as Mr. Edwards is known to fans, talks about his role on the electronic duo’s new album and the state of dance music today.
lead_paragraph: The storied house music producer Todd Edwards is two decades into a groundbreaking career in which he pioneered the cut-up sample technique that gave birth to the U.K. garage style of dance music, earning him the nickname “Todd the God” with aficionados. But it feels like he’s only been warming up the decks. A frequent collaborator with Daft Punk — he wrote and sang “Face to Face” from their 2001 album “Discovery” — Mr. Edwards reunites with the helmet-wearing pair for a track on their much-anticipated album “Random Access Memories,” out May 21 (and streaming now on iTunes).

headline: Google Expected to Start a Competitor to Spotify
abstract: The service is expected to be announced as early as Wednesday, and reflects agreements the company has made with the three major music labels.
lead_paragraph: Google is set to introduce a subscription music feature to compete against fast-growing streaming services like Spotify, according to several people briefed on its plans.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Bangladesh, Turkey, Kenya and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Bangladesh, Turkey, Kenya and Iraq.

headline: Management Flaws at I.R.S. Cited in Tea Party Scrutiny
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Inspectors General', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling']
abstract: An inspector general’s report described a failure to stop the singling out of conservative groups as Congressional aides tried to find out how far knowledge of the effort reached.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An inspector general’s report issued Tuesday blamed ineffective Internal Revenue Service management in the failure to stop employees from singling out conservative groups for added scrutiny. Congressional aides, meanwhile, sought to determine whether the Obama administration’s knowledge of the effort extended beyond the I.R.S.

headline: Living in Mariners Harbor, S.I.
abstract: The residential and industrial coexist in this corner of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The residential and industrial coexist in this corner of New York City.

headline: Coastal Perch; Varied Nests on Offer
abstract: Mariners Harbor, in northwestern Staten Island, is a place within the city limits where a sizable house in good condition is within reach for a civil servant.
lead_paragraph: The city trend toward transforming decayed industrial shoreline into public space has not yet made landfall in the northwestern Staten Island neighborhood of Mariners Harbor. But José Marrero, betting that the tides of gentrification wash over every area eventually, moved here a decade ago from a two-bedroom rental in Coney Island.

headline: In the Living Room, Still No Sign of Google
abstract: While other companies, including Microsoft, Apple and Sony, continue to enter the living room with successful consumer electronics that connect the TV to the Internet, Google has continually failed.
lead_paragraph: If you walk into my living room you will see a standard, flat television surrounded by a dozen gadgets. There’s a Microsoft Xbox, a Sony PlayStation, the Apple TV, and there’s even a computer with a wireless mouse. But you might not recognize one of the gadgets, a round black ball that I haven’t used in a year: the Nexus Q made by Google.

headline: Is the I.R.S. an Independent Agency?
abstract: The president said it was. But technically, it’s not.
lead_paragraph: There is no evidence that President Obama knew about the Internal Revenue Service’s recent practice of singling out conservative groups that applied for tax-exempt status, subjecting them to unusually detailed questioning. Calling the reports “outrageous,” he has promised to “make sure that we find out exactly what happened on this.” That’s as it should be. But the president misspoke on Monday when he said that the I.R.S. was an “independent agency.” It is not.

headline: Billie Sol Estes, Texas Con Man Whose Fall Shook Up Washington, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Estes’s life captured America’s imagination, with its tales of business scams, political payoffs, covered-up killings and White House conspiracies.
lead_paragraph: Billie Sol Estes, a fast-talking Texas swindler who made millions, went to prison and captivated America for years with mind-boggling agricultural scams, payoffs to politicians and bizarre tales of covered-up killings and White House conspiracies, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Granbury, Tex. He was 88.

headline: Syrian Rebel Reportedly Defends Sinking Teeth Into Dead Soldier’s Flesh on Camera
abstract: A Syrian rebel commander who appeared to bite into the flesh of a government soldier’s corpse in a horrifying video clip posted on YouTube this week defended his actions in an interview with Time magazine.
lead_paragraph: A Syrian rebel commander who appeared to bite into the flesh of a government soldier’s corpse in a horrifying video clip posted on YouTube this week defended his actions in an interview with Time magazine on Tuesday. The rebel, Khalid al-Hamad, known by the nom de guerre Abu Sakkar, confirmed that he sank his teeth into an internal organ that he had laboriously carved out of the dead soldier’s chest as a colleague recorded the scene. “Our slogan,” he said, “is an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.”

headline: If You’re a Tree-Hungry Beetle, Run
abstract: The state was bug-eyed with excitement to announce that the Asian longhorned beetle was gone from Staten Island and Manhattan, though the fight continues for Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island.
lead_paragraph: The tree-devouring Asian longhorned beetle has not yet been driven from the gates of the city, but, by Jove, pest-control authorities have it on the run. The state announced on Tuesday that the beetle had been eradicated from Manhattan and Staten Island.

headline: Greek Civil Servants Walk Out Over Ban on Teachers’ Strike
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Organized Labor', 'Strikes', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: The workers were protesting the government’s use of an emergency law to battle trade unions that oppose austerity measures.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greek civil servants walked off the job on Tuesday to protest the government’s use of an emergency law to ban a planned strike by teachers. But a popular rally in the capital was the smallest in several months, a sign that public support for the country’s once-mighty unions may be dwindling.

headline: Washington Projects Invite the Small Local Investor
abstract: Real estate upstarts like Fundrise are allowing people to invest in their neighborhoods in a way that has traditionally been the exclusive domain of wealthy investors and private equity firms.
lead_paragraph: The practice of crowdfunding real estate is spreading from South America — where Prodigy Network recently raised around $239 million from 3,100 Colombians to build a 66-story skyscraper in Bogotá — to New York, where the developer Urban Muse is hoping to offer a slice of a Brooklyn Bridge Park project to the public.

headline: Three Foes Unite to Keep Wrestling in Olympics
abstract: Wrestlers from the United States, Iran and Russia appeared at the United Nations the day before they were to compete at Grand Central Terminal in an effort to save wrestling as an Olympic sport.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Rarely, if ever these days, do you hear the United States making nice with Russia and Iran at the United Nations.

headline: Subscribers Fear Bloomberg Is Becoming Their Rival
abstract: Long thought of as a company that serves Wall Street firms, Bloomberg L.P. is quietly becoming more like them.
lead_paragraph: Long thought of as a company that serves the needs of Wall Street firms, Bloomberg L.P. is quietly becoming more like them, moving recently into businesses that have been the domain of the largest banks.

headline: Inspector General’s Report on I.R.S. Audits
abstract: A report offered new details on the scope and duration of the Internal Revenue Service’s effort to target conservative non-profit groups for scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: A report offered new details on the scope and duration of the Internal Revenue Service’s effort to target conservative non-profit groups for scrutiny.

headline: Brooklyn Race Grows; So Does Security
keywords: ['Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Marathon Running', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: In the wake of the Boston Marathon attack, bomb-sniffing dogs will be out at the Brooklyn Half Marathon this weekend, and runners will have to use clear, race-issued bags for their belongings.
lead_paragraph: When New York Road Runners reinvented the Brooklyn Half Marathon, turning a sleepy March race into an event that will host about 25,000 competitors this weekend, it was meant as an economic boon to Coney Island. But recent events have turned it into something bigger, including a much larger security challenge in the wake of the Boston Marathon bombings last month.

headline: A Better Picture
abstract: The budget deficit is now projected to be less severe than it was previously and much less than it has been in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The budget deficit is now projected to be less severe than it was previously and much less than it has been in recent years.

headline: As Thieves Troll Spanish Farmland, Villagers Begin Patrols
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Unemployment', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Many of Spain’s small, isolated farming communities seemed immune from the economic crisis. But now many believe the problem is at their doorstep.
lead_paragraph: ALBELDA, Spain — José Briá finds it hard to sleep these days. Sometimes when he wakes up in the middle of the night, he drives out to his farmland a few miles from the center of this tiny village just to make sure everything is all right.

headline: Bob Sickinger, Chicago Stage Innovator, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Sickinger believed that theater wasn’t presented to a community but arose from it, and that was the model he followed in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Bob Sickinger, a director whose mostly nonprofessional productions in the 1960s seeded a Chicago theater scene that evolved into one of the country’s greatest, died on May 9 at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 86.

headline: An Atrocity in Syria, With No Victim Too Small
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A mass killing has revealed new depths of ruthlessness in Syria’s conflict, inflaming sectarian divisions and making any hope of reconciliation appear ever more distant.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After dragging 46 bodies from the streets near his hometown on the Syrian coast, Omar lost count. For four days, he said, he could not eat, remembering the burned body of a baby just a few months old; a fetus ripped from a woman’s belly; a friend lying dead, his dog still standing guard.

headline: For Insurers, No Doubts on Climate Change
keywords: ['Insurance', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A new institute, financed by the insurance industry, not only believes in global warming but also supports a carbon tax to combat it.
lead_paragraph: If there were one American industry that would be particularly worried about climate change it would have to be insurance, right?

headline: South Carolina: Sex Surgery Unnecessary, Lawsuit Alleges
abstract: A Southern legal advocacy group has claimed in a lawsuit that the State of South Carolina should not have surgically altered a 16-month-old child in its custody.
lead_paragraph: A Southern legal advocacy group has claimed in a lawsuit that the State of South Carolina should not have surgically altered a 16-month-old child in its custody who was born with both male and female genitalia. The suit, filed in both state and federal courts, was brought on behalf of the child’s adoptive parents and is intended to restrict the practice of medically unnecessary sex assignment surgeries on infants, said lawyers with the Southern Poverty Law Center. The child was in the care of the South Carolina Department of Social Services when doctors, in cooperation with social services employees, removed the child’s male genitals. The child, now 8, identifies himself as a boy, according to his parents, Mark and Pam Crawford of Richland County. “They disfigured him because they could not accept him for who he was,” Mrs. Crawford said in a statement, “not because he needed any surgery.” Increasingly, doctors and those who were born with a condition once called hermaphroditism recommend that children be assigned a gender at birth but postpone surgery until they are old enough to choose. A spokeswoman for the state’s Social Services Department said there would be no comment on pending legal action.

headline: How They Do It Elsewhere
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Social Security (US)', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Scores of other countries have elaborate retirement schemes and policies that Americans could learn from to address some of the biggest pitfalls of their system.
lead_paragraph: THE United States can boast that it has the world’s best basketball players, fighter jets and country and western singers. But hardly anyone would ever boast that the United States has the world’s best retirement system.

headline: R. Donahue Peebles
abstract: Mr. Peebles is the chief of the Peebles Corporation, one of the largest African-American-owned development companies in the country.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Peebles, 53, is the chairman and chief executive of the Peebles Corporation, one of the largest African-American-owned development companies in the country. The company, which has its headquarters in Coral Gables, Fla., specializes in residential and hospitality developments.

headline: Virginia Tech President to Retire
abstract: Charles Steger, the Virginia Tech University president who led the college during the 2007 mass shooting, this week announced plans to retire as soon as a successor is found.
lead_paragraph: Charles Steger, the Virginia Tech University president who led the college during the 2007 mass shooting, this week announced plans to retire as soon as a successor is found. Dr. Steger,  65, has had a long Virginia Tech career, as a student, instructor, department head, dean — at 33, the youngest architecture dean in the nation  — vice president and, since 2000, president.  After the  shooting, in which a student, Seung-Hui Cho, killed 32 people, Mr. Steger was criticized for not warning the campus quickly.  Next month, in a case brought by the parents of two slain students, the State Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether he should stand trial for his actions during the massacre.

headline: Afghan Commandos Step Up Their Combat Role
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A combination of allied Special Operations forces and Afghan troops are set to assume more responsibility in Afghanistan as NATO gradually hands over security operations.
lead_paragraph: AT A CLASSIFIED COMMANDO BASE, Afghanistan — One day this month, a pair of Russian Mi-17 assault helicopters delivered two teams of Afghan commandos, their faces obscured by black masks, in a touch-and-go landing at this camp in a lush valley encircled by frosty peaks about 50 miles from Kabul.

headline: Georgia Tech Will Offer a Master’s Degree Online
abstract: The Georgia Institute of Technology will offer a master’s degree in computer science that can be earned entirely through so-called massive open online courses, or MOOCs.
lead_paragraph: Starting in the fall, the Georgia Institute of Technology, together with AT&T and Udacity, an online education venture, will offer a master’s degree in computer science that can be earned entirely through so-called massive open online courses, or MOOCs. While the courses would be available free online to the general public, students seeking the degree would have to have a bachelor’s degree in computer science, and pay tuition that is expected to be less than $7,000  Initially, the program will be limited to a few hundred students from AT&T and Georgia Tech corporate affiliates, but enrollment is then expected to expand in the fall of 2014.

headline: ABC’s Programming
abstract: The Times’s Bill Carter discusses ABC’s programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Bill Carter discusses ABC’s programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

headline: Chuck Muncie, Troubled N.F.L. Star, Dies at 60
abstract: Mr. Muncie blended speed and power to become one of the N.F.L.’s leading running backs of the late 1970s and early ’80s, but his career was cut short by drug abuse.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Muncie, who blended speed and power to become one of the N.F.L.’s leading running backs of the late 1970s and early ’80s, but whose career was cut short by drug abuse, died on Monday at his home in Perris, Calif. He was 60.

headline: Iranian Officials Threaten Two Candidates for the Presidency
abstract: The political establishment has not responded well to Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei, who entered the race at the last minute.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian officials on Monday issued blunt threats of violence against two last-minute registrants for the June 14 presidential election whose unwanted presence on the ballot has angered the country’s governing establishment.

headline: Pleased by Effort, if Not by Ending, Isles Pledge to Build on a Breakout Season
abstract: The young Islanders surprised many by reaching the playoffs for the first time since 2007, but next season will bring fresh challenges, primarily from the N.H.L.’s realignment.
lead_paragraph: As the ice at Nassau Coliseum melted and workers used heavy machinery to dismantle its hockey rink, the Islanders resolutely spoke of building for the future.

headline: Minnesota: Governor Signs Same-Sex Marriage Into Law
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Gov. Mark Dayton signed a measure Tuesday giving gay couples the right to marry, making Minnesota the 12th state in the nation to permit same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mark Dayton signed a measure Tuesday giving gay couples the right to marry, making Minnesota the 12th state in the nation to permit same-sex marriage. During a signing ceremony outside the State Capitol in St. Paul, where thousands of Minnesotans gathered and cheered in 90-degree weather, Mr. Dayton, a Democrat, praised the choices of state lawmakers as changing the course of history.

headline: French Lawmakers Loosen Labor Rules in a Victory for the President
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Law and Legislation', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The measures, an important win for President François Hollande, give employers more flexibility to lay off employees, but also contain concessions for workers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French legislature gave President François Hollande an important victory on Tuesday, passing a modest loosening of the country’s labor code even as Mr. Hollande’s foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, revealed severe tensions within the Socialist government by criticizing the stewardship of the economics and finance minister, Pierre Moscovici.

headline: Pentagon Furloughs Are Set
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Government Employees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel announced Tuesday that most civilian Pentagon employees would be order to take unpaid furloughs of up to 11 days.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, left, announced Tuesday that most civilian Pentagon employees would be ordered to take unpaid furloughs of up to 11 days between July 8 and the end of September. The measure, which is a response to across-the-board spending reductions called sequestration, is less punitive than plans that would have seen Pentagon civilians forced to take 14 to 22 days of unpaid leave. “The department has been doing everything possible to reduce this shortfall while ensuring we can defend the nation, sustain wartime operations and preserve D.o.D.’s most critical asset — our world-class civilian and military personnel,” Mr. Hagel said.

lead_paragraph: Recent Sale

headline: Wheeler, Mets’ Top Pitching Prospect, to Miss Next Start
abstract: Zack Wheeler, expected to join the Mets this summer, will visit doctors in New York after experiencing soreness near his right clavicle.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The proper level of concern will become clearer Wednesday, but regardless, it was precisely the type of injury news the Mets and their fans did not want to hear.

headline: A Full House at an Older Age
abstract: Rebecca Gawboy, 60, and her husband, Jim, 76, take care of 12 adopted children.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Gawboy, 60, and her husband, Jim, 76, take care of 12 adopted children.

headline: Bad Enough
abstract: Many of us are understandably afraid of the way our food is produced, but exaggeration doesn’t make our case stronger.
lead_paragraph: Things are bad enough in the food world that we don’t need to resort to hyperbole to be worried or even alarmed.

headline: Filling Up an Empty Nest
abstract: Some older parents never got their fill of child-rearing; others never had children and finally have the time and means to try raising some.
lead_paragraph: RETIRING from work? Then it might be time to think about raising a family. Some brave older adults are turning the idea of retirement on its head by choosing to adopt children — this when many of their peers are traveling, socializing, taking up intellectual or entrepreneurial pursuits, or just plain relaxing.

headline: No Frills on the Road Back
abstract: Alisa Kleybanova, who was forced off the tour in 2011 by Hodgkin’s lymphoma, recently recorded three qualifying wins in a low-level event.
lead_paragraph: LANDISVILLE, Pa. — There were a lot of tennis tournament essentials missing on Sunday at the $10,000 U.S.T.A. Pro Circuit tournament at Hempfield Recreation Center here.

headline: Univision Resets Sights After a Ratings Victory
abstract: Univision and many other television networks and channels aimed at Hispanics made their presentations to advertisers for the coming fall season.
lead_paragraph: AT its upfront presentation on Tuesday, Univision continued to promote its dominance of the Hispanic media landscape in the hope of attracting more advertising dollars to the network’s expanding empire.

headline: Entertainment News
abstract: A TV personality’s biggest achievement: tearing down the walls between news and entertainment.
lead_paragraph: BARBARA WALTERS’S announcement this week that she would soon bring her long career to a close elicited the obligatory tributes to her as a trailblazer for women and an exemplary figure in broadcast journalism.

headline: Doubts About Restricting Salt
abstract: Emerging evidence that suggests that lowering sodium intake might actually be harmful, not helpful, highlights the need for more research on the issue.
lead_paragraph: After years of warnings to cut sodium consumption to reduce heart attacks and strokes, it is disturbing to learn how little evidence exists that such reductions would actually be beneficial to health. There is even emerging evidence that some groups in the population could suffer harm from levels that are too low.

headline: The Knicks’ One-Man Play Badly Needs Stagehands

headline: Sony Meets Outspoken Activist Investor, but Courtesy Reigns
abstract: Daniel S. Loeb, often caustic dealing with others, had a polite meeting in Tokyo with executives of Sony, where he is trying to engineer a major shake-up.
lead_paragraph: For a hedge fund manager whose fame first came on writing invective-filled letters, Daniel S. Loeb’s latest missive was a model of politeness.

headline: ‘A Long Ride Toward a New China’
abstract: Every summer, the blogger "Tiger Temple" bikes around China to report on rural news stories censored by state-run media.
lead_paragraph: Every summer, the 59-year-old Chinese blogger Zhang Shihe rides his bicycle thousands of miles to the plateaus, deserts and hinterlands of North Central China. In this Op-Doc video, we meet Mr. Zhang, known to his many followers online as “Tiger Temple,” as he goes to great lengths to document the stories of struggling rural villagers whose voices are seldom heard in China’s state-monitored media.

headline: Brazilian Court Council Removes a Barrier to Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The council ruled on Tuesday that notary publics could not refuse to perform same-sex marriage ceremonies, a decision that effectively legalizes gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The council overseeing Brazil’s judiciary ruled on Tuesday that notary publics cannot refuse to perform same-sex marriage ceremonies, a decision that opens the way for gay couples across Latin America’s largest country to marry.

headline: With Detroit Under State Control, Candidates Seek Posts Stripped of Power
abstract: The evolving political dynamics of Detroit mean that the flurry of campaigning happens in a city where elected officials no longer have final say.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Candidates seeking to become the next mayor of this deeply troubled city are calling it a historic election. headline: Some of My Best Friends Are Germs
abstract: Medicine used to be obsessed with eradicating the tiny bugs that live within us. Now we’re beginning to understand all the ways they keep us healthy.
lead_paragraph: I can tell you the exact date that I began to think of myself in the first-person plural — as a superorganism, that is, rather than a plain old individual human being. It happened on March 7. That’s when I opened my e-mail to find a huge, processor-choking file of charts and raw data from a laboratory located at the BioFrontiers Institute at the University of Colorado, Boulder. As part of a new citizen-science initiative called the American Gut project, the lab sequenced my microbiome — that is, the genes not of “me,” exactly, but of the several hundred microbial species with whom I share this body. These bacteria, which number around 100 trillion, are living (and dying) right now on the surface of my skin, on my tongue and deep in the coils of my intestines, where the largest contingent of them will be found, a pound or two of microbes together forming a vast, largely uncharted interior wilderness that scientists are just beginning to map.

headline: Daft Punk Gets Human With a New Album

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Thomas Bangalter, half of the influential French dance-music act Daft Punk, has a house high in the Hollywood Hills here. He and his musical partner, Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo, divide their time between Los Angeles and Paris, where their families live. But for all their jet-setting, there’s little evidence of rock star flash to be seen (well, apart from the Porsche that Mr. de Homem-Christo has parked in the driveway). Built in the midcentury style called post and beam, the bungalow exudes a subtle retro feel, with white carpeting, a cross section of a tree trunk as a coffee table, and a gravel fireplace in the living room. The swimming pool, a small square of radiant Hockney blue, is visible through the glass walls.

abstract: Dual-time display, made popular by Pan Am pilots, has made a prominent return.
lead_paragraph: Rolex debuted the first G.M.T. watch, which featured an additional hour hand to represent Greenwich Mean Time, in the 1950s. Pan Am pilots popularized the dual-time display, which allowed them to keep track of local time while flying across time zones, and inspired a slew of watchmakers to create their own G.M.T. products. Although they’ve been less popular in recent years, a recent wave of releases shows that these watches are coming back in a big way. Here are 12 of the best newcomers.

headline: Battlefield Update: The Fight for Isolated Government Outposts in Northern Syria
abstract: As world leaders and commentators of every stripe have debated President Obama’s “red line,” there have been significant developments on the ground.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks considerable public attention has turned to questions of whether government forces in Syria have used chemical weapons. And all the while, conventional fighting with conventional weapons – the dominant form of violence and source of killing in this and most every war of our time – has continued to rage. As world leaders and commentators of every stripe have debated President Obama’s “red line,” there have been developments on the ground, which might herald tactical shifts and point to the verifiable, actual slog that is the Syrian civil war.

headline: In Andhra, Maoist Rebels Pin Hopes on Memories of the Dead
abstract: Maoist leadership is facing a crisis, mainly because most of the top rebel leaders have either been killed or arrested in the last few years.
lead_paragraph: On April 16, Maoist rebels, operating in the dense forests of central and eastern India received a major blow when security forces killed one of their senior commanders, along with his wife and seven other rebels in Chhattisgarh, very close to the border of Andhra Pradesh. The slain commander, Marri Ravi, alias Sudhakar, was entrusted by the outlawed rebel group Communist Party of India (Maoist) to revive its movement in Andhra after the rebels were crushed seven years ago in their erstwhile bastion following a sustained military operation against them.

In both “Construction Kitties,” by Judy Sue Goodwin Sturges, with illustrations by Shari Halpern, and “Dig, Dogs, Dig,” by James Horvath, a crew of smiling pets get to work building — what else? — a playground.

lead_paragraph: The farthest I’ve ever felt from civilization was when I spent two nights in an old fire lookout in the Sierra Nevada of Northern California. Built in the 1930s and situated at almost 6,000 feet, the tower had tremendous views of the dense pine forest blanketing Tahoe National Forest. What I remember most was the retreat of city lights, the lack of cellphone reception and the kind of stillness that makes the hours seem to hold more time: for reading, for hikes, for star-spotting, for meandering conversations around the campfire.

headline: The Gun Report: May 15, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of gun violence.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that the gun lobby doesn’t want you discussing handgun safety with your doctor? In June 2011, Florida governor Rick Scott signed a bill that made it the first state in the nation to prohibit doctors from asking patients if they own guns. Oklahoma, Tennessee and West Virginia all introduced “physician gag law” bills that would restrict physician firearm counseling. Shortly thereafter, the American Academy of Pediatrics reaffirmed its commitment to advocating for the strongest possible firearm regulations, arguing that fewer guns means safer homes for children.

headline: Roundabout Theater Announces Changes to Fall Season
abstract: A Broadway revival of “The Winslow Boy” will take the place of a planned production of “The Philadelphia Story.”
lead_paragraph: A Broadway revival of Philip Barry’s classic comedy “The Philadelphia Story,” which the Tony Award nominee Alex Timbers (“Peter and the Starcatcher”) was to direct this fall, has been postponed, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Wednesday. Replacing that show will be a revival of Terence Rattigan’s 1946 drama, “The Winslow Boy,” starring Roger Rees (a Tony winner for “The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby”) and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and directed by Lindsay Posner, who recently staged the play at the Old Vic in London.

headline: For Rent: Airstreams
abstract: Starting this month, the travel company Airstream 2 Go will rent current-model Airstream trailers.
lead_paragraph: If ever a recreational vehicle could be called iconic, it would be the Airstream. The sausage-shaped silvery aluminum trailer has been a fixture of American road trips since the company’s founding in 1931, but before this year it was available only for purchase. Starting this month, the travel company Airstream 2 Go will rent current-model Airstream trailers outfitted with flat-screen televisions, camping chairs, tables and barbecue grills, as well as GMC Yukons to pull them for journeys of at least five days. Initial rental locations include Las Vegas and Los Angeles, but there are plans to expand to other cities across the country.

headline: Subaru to Recall 5,400 Vehicles for Possible Steering Failure

lead_paragraph: Subaru will recall nearly 5,400 2013 Outback and Legacy models because the steering may fail, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In a report posted on the agency’s Web site, Subaru said the inner and outer shafts of the steering column assembly could lose contact with one another, in which case “the driver would lose the ability to steer the vehicle.”

headline: Advice on Practicing Yoga in Middle Age, Part 2
abstract: Dr. Loren Fishman, a rehabilitative medicine specialist, addresses reader questions about yoga, aging, osteoporosis,  shoulder pain and other issues.
lead_paragraph: This is the second set of answers to reader questions from Dr. Loren Fishman, a back-pain and rehabilitative medicine specialist who has long incorporated yoga into patient care. In 1972, before applying to medical school, he studied yoga with B.K.S. Iyengar for a year in Pune, India. Dr. Fishman is the medical director of Manhattan Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation in New York City, an assistant clinical professor at Columbia Medical School and an associate editor of the journal Topics in Geriatric Rehabilitation. He is also an author of eight books, including “Yoga for Osteoporosis: the Complete Guide.”

lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, as you know, I’m from Cincinnati. Some people may think of it as just another city in Ohio, but there has been a lot of drama coming out of Cincinnati over the years. One of the stars of the savings and loan scandal of the ’80s, Charles Keating, used to lecture at the Catholic girls’ high school I went to. The book consists of interviews conducted by Michael Kamber, who covered the war for eight years for The New York Times and is a co-founder of the Bronx Documentary Center.

headline: Kirk and Spock, in Their Roughhousing Days
abstract: In “Star Trek Into Darkness,” the U.S.S. Enterprise crew hunts for a terrorist in the latest film in the franchise.
lead_paragraph: There is some intermittent complaining, in “Star Trek Into Darkness,” about the militarization of the Federation’s Starfleet. You may recall that the historic mission of the starship Enterprise was “to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations.” While the crew on the first television series found its way into plenty of fights, the show itself always tried to stay true to the ideals of peaceful intergalactic ethnography.

headline: The Music Teacher’s Raid
abstract: The remarkable story of an unlikely cavalry campaign through Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: After months of failed efforts to take Vicksburg by assaults from the north, by the early spring of 1863 Ulysses S. Grant had settled on a radically different approach. He would send a force over to the western bank of the Mississippi River; his troops would then march down through northern Louisiana, cross back over the river and establish a base of operations at Grand Gulf, Miss., about 30 miles south of Vicksburg, where there was less of a rebel presence. Grant could thus exploit advantageous terrain and weaker rebel defenses to move against the Confederate stronghold from the south.

headline: Photos Take the Spotlight in Updates to Google’s Social Network
abstract: Google is using its expertise in algorithms to offer users better social sharing tools through its Google Plus network. The company’s software will now select the best photos and fix their flaws, offer more links to topics mentioned in posts by members of a user’s social network and archive long-running chats.
lead_paragraph: Google may dominate Web search, but when it comes to social networks, the company’s Google Plus service is an underdog against Facebook and Twitter. As of December, Google Plus users were spending about 12 minutes a month on the service, according to the company, a smidgen of time compared with the hours that Facebook users spend on that site every month.

abstract: When it comes to moving house and children, mom-stress shared is mom-stress multiplied.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this spring I wrote a post describing the ways I am trying to teach my children all of the lessons surrounding the idea of emotional contagion. “You catch more flies with honey than you do with vinegar,” I tell them (they say they don’t want flies). “You get what you give,” I say. A soft answer turneth away wrath, but grievous words stir up anger.

Also making its debut this evening is Chopard’s decadent collection of 66 one-of-a-kind pieces, one for each year of the festival’s history. Jewelry made with pastel-colored gems like kunzite, paraiba tourmaline and mauve spinel plays a supporting role to diamond pieces. headline: Conservatives and Health Care Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: No, the slowdown in cost inflation hasn’t undercut the conservative position on health care reform.
lead_paragraph: Nested within the news about falling deficits is news about slowing health care cost inflation, which seems to be outlasting the recession and which is driving the long-term projections for Medicare spending downward. Since one of the big questions in the Great Obamacare Debate was whether the new health care law would accelerate cost growth (as expanded subsidies and regulations often tend to do) or reduce it (thanks to the various cost-containing experiments and pilot programs embedded within the bill), the news that costs are falling in advance of the bill’s implementation has some liberals crowing. Jonathan Chait, in particular, has taken to explaining why “the growing mass of evidence that the health-care-cost inflation problem is indeed solvable” cuts the legs out from under the entire right-of-center take on health care, deficits and entitlements, and puts the data squarely on the side of health care reform’s proponents. Here’s his elaboration on this theme:

abstract: The Gil Evans Project featured “Gypsy Jump,” a song not played since 1942, in its set at the Jazz Standard.
lead_paragraph: The Gil Evans Project, a large-format repertory band in residence at the Jazz Standard this week, brings painstaking precision to its task but also an air of unburdened pleasure. Its driving purpose isn’t re-enactment so much as revelation, which helps guard against the pull of nostalgia. That’s tantalizingly rare in the jazz repertory game. And sometimes the band’s chosen music proves rarer still.

headline: A Child of Two Lands
abstract: In “We Need New Names,” NoViolet Bulawayo tells the story of Darling, who arrives from Zimbabwe to live with her aunt in Detroit and is conflicted in her feelings of her old and new homes.
lead_paragraph: “When things fall apart, the children of the land scurry and scatter like birds escaping a burning sky,” NoViolet Bulawayo writes in her deeply felt and fiercely written debut novel. “They flee their own wretched land so their hunger may be pacified in foreign lands, their tears wiped away in strange lands, the wounds of their despair bandaged in faraway lands, their blistered prayers muttered in the darkness of queer lands.” They leave behind their mothers and fathers and “the bones of their ancestors in the earth” — they leave behind “everything that makes them who and what they are, leaving because it is no longer possible to stay.”

abstract: Mark Wise, a former Army officer, will trek alongside other wounded veterans through some of the harshest climates on the planet.
lead_paragraph: This November, I will join a team of three other wounded American veterans — Therese Frentz, Ivan Castro and Margaux Mange — on a 225-mile race across Antarctica for the Walking With the Wounded South Pole Allied Challenge. We will travel on skis while dragging sleds packed with approximately 150 pounds of survival equipment through the harshest climates on the planet. We will be racing for more than two weeks against similar teams of wounded veterans from the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia. Our goal is not just to win the race, but also to raise awareness.

headline: The Wind Collector
abstract: The Dutch designer Merel Karhof on using the power of the wind to make furniture.
lead_paragraph: This week, Merel Karhof, a 34-year-old Dutch designer who lives in London, set up a small, temporary factory in the Netherlands to make furniture with wind. For the project, called Windworks, she collaborated with the owners of two neighboring windmills in Zaanse Schans, in the province of North Holland: one, a sawmill that cut the wood used in her collection of chairs, stools and benches; the other, a paint mill that ground the minerals with which she dyed wool upholstery fabric produced through her own wind-powered knitting machine. Speaking by phone from the Netherlands, Ms. Karhof, who studied at the Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands and at the Royal College of Art in London, discussed the evolution of her interest in the invisible forces of nature.

lead_paragraph: The Milanese designer Paola Navone is famous (at least in Europe) for mixing North African and Asian artisanal handicrafts into modern goods. But now her reputation is about to make an Atlantic crossing. She recently introduced an outdoor furniture collection for Janus et Cie, and she’s working on interiors for the Como Hotel in the South Beach district of Miami, which will be presented in the fall. This week, Anthropologie, the quirkily stylish lifestyle chain, will release what Ms. Navone has described as her “dream bedroom collection.” This 20-piece line includes bed linens, furniture, suitcases, lighting and accessories. Prices range from $10 for a mercury-glass mushroom to $4,200 for a four-poster bed. Information: (212) 343-7070 or anthropologie.com.

headline: Even Duchesses Have Tag Sales
keywords: ['Nineteen Hundred Twenties', 'ART DECO', 'Auctions', 'Furniture', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Art Deco masterworks from a palace in Madrid will be up for auction on May 23.
lead_paragraph: Most people don’t associate bathrooms with patinated floor lamps that have carved bronze birds for feet. Then again, most people don’t live in a palace. In the early 1920s, Armand Albert Rateau, an Art Deco master, created furniture for the Liria Palace in Madrid for the apartments of the Duchess of Alba, María del Rosario de Silva y Gurtubay, who married the 17th Duke of Alba in 1920. The palace was damaged in the Spanish Civil War, and some of Rateau’s pieces are lost to time. Now, the House of Alba is selling the rest of her collection at Christie’s France. Among the seven Rateau pieces included in the May 23 sale are the lamps (estimated at about $1.95 million to $2.6 million each); a carved and gilded wood daybed (shown, $520,000 to $780,000); and a Carrara marble tub (about $195,000 to $260,000). If only we could all scrub like royalty. Information: christies.com.

headline: Pakistan: Imran Khan Seeks Vote Inquiry
abstract: Imran Khan gave a three-day ultimatum to the national election commission on Wednesday to look into his political party’s claims of vote-rigging in last week’s election.
lead_paragraph: Imran Khan, the politician and former cricket star, gave a three-day ultimatum to the national election commission on Wednesday to look into his political party’s claims of vote-rigging in the contests for 25 parliamentary seats during last week’s general election. Mr. Khan warned that his party would start countrywide protests if the grievances were not addressed. Most of the accusations of voter fraud concern election districts in Lahore and Karachi. Election officials say repolling of 43 election stations in a wealthy Karachi district will take place on Sunday. According to the latest official tally, the party of Nawaz Sharif, the presumptive prime minister, leads with 124 seats in the 272-seat assembly. The Pakistan Peoples Party, the former governing party, won 31 seats, while Mr. Khan’s party won 27. The counts for 11 seats have yet to be officially verified.

headline: Egypt: Reports of Embassy Plots
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Three Egyptian men arrested last week and accused of plotting terrorist acts in Egypt sought to carry out suicide attacks against the United States and French Embassies, the state news media said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Three Egyptian men arrested last week and accused of plotting terrorist acts in Egypt sought to carry out suicide attacks against the United States and French Embassies, the state news media said Wednesday. One of the men had been deported from Iran and another from Algeria for engaging in militant activities. All three were imprisoned in Egypt in 2009, but broke out during the uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak in 2011. The men, who the government says have ties to Al Qaeda, said they planned to attack the French Embassy in revenge for France’s military intervention against militants in Mali, the state news media said. After their arrests were announced Saturday, a Western official identified the United States Embassy as one of their targets.

lead_paragraph: The head of the federal consumer protection agency was fired Wednesday, weeks after his daughter got inspectors to briefly shut down a restaurant that refused her the table she wanted. Four officials from the agency had been suspended after the episode became a Twitter sensation highlighting the deep sense of entitlement of the privileged in Mexico. The father, Humberto Benítez Treviño, had defied calls to resign, but President Enrique Peña Nieto, who had promised more accountability from his government, decided to fire him. A government statement said that while Mr. Benitez Treviño did not play a role in the inspection that led to the closing, the case had damaged the image and prestige of the agency.

headline: Tennessee: Home-schooling Family Is Denied Asylum
abstract: A federal appeals court ruled Wednesday that a German family could not claim asylum in the United States because it would face penalties in Germany for home-schooling its children.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled Wednesday that a German family could not claim asylum in the United States because it would face penalties in Germany for home-schooling its children. The Romeike family wanted to educate five children at home “largely for religious reasons,” the decision stated, but were prohibited by German law and faced prosecution. The Romeikes moved to Tennessee in 2008 and were granted asylum by an immigration judge, but the Board of Immigration Appeals overturned that decision in 2012. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, ruled unanimously Wednesday that the Romeikes could not prove that home-schoolers were singled out for persecution in Germany, and thus were not eligible for asylum. The family intends to appeal.

headline: Illinois: Lawsuits Filed Over Chicago School Closings
abstract: Parents in Chicago have filed two federal lawsuits opposing proposed school closings. In March, the Chicago Public Schools identified 53 schools that it planned to close.
lead_paragraph: Parents in Chicago have filed two federal lawsuits opposing proposed school closings. In March, the Chicago Public Schools identified 53 schools that it planned to close to save $560 million over 10 years. The school board will vote on the proposal next Wednesday. The suits, filed Wednesday in Federal District Court for the Northern District of Illinois Eastern Division, say the closings would violate the Americans With Disabilities Act. In a complaint seeking to postpone them for a year, three parents seeking class-action status allege that the closings would pose “significant disruption” to special-education students. The second suit, which seeks to stop the closings altogether, alleges that they would “needlessly uproot, transfer and destabilize the children.” The suit further says the closings would violate Illinois civil rights law because the schools fall disproportionately in areas where the vast majority of students are black.

The lawyer, Jaye M. Schlachet, said his client had been “demonized” in news reports and expressed concern about a fair trial. Mr. Castro, 52, has been accused of kidnapping and raping the women, who vanished between 2002 and 2004. They were rescued last week, along with a daughter that one gave birth to in captivity. A paternity test confirmed that Mr. Castro is the father of the child, who is now 6.

headline: Texas: Investigation of Abortion Doctor
abstract: The Harris County district attorney’s office said that it would investigate charges that a Houston doctor, Douglas Karpen, had delivered live babies during abortions and killed them.
lead_paragraph: The Harris County district attorney’s office said Wednesday that it would investigate charges that a Houston doctor had delivered live babies during third-trimester abortions and killed them after they emerged, which federal and state laws forbid. The anti-abortion group Operation Rescue made the charges based on statements by three former employees of the abortion doctor, Douglas Karpen, which could not be independently verified. The organization said the doctor’s actions echoed the charges that led to the murder conviction of Dr. Kermit Gosnell in Philadelphia. Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst said he had read the allegations “with disgust,” and called for a full investigation.

headline: California: Suspensions End for Defiant Students
abstract: he Los Angeles Unified School District has voted to end the practice of suspending students who are defiant.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Unified School District has voted to end the practice of suspending students who are defiant. Concern has grown that “zero tolerance” disciplinary policies, which sometimes led to suspensions for acts like refusing to remove a hat in class, have disproportionately affected minority students, hindered academic achievement and lowered graduation rates. More than a third of all suspensions result from “willful defiance,” according district officials. Los Angeles Unified, with more than 600,000 students, is the first large school district in the country to curtail suspensions for defiance, officials said.

headline: Washington: Cancer Patients More Prone to Bankruptcy
abstract: A study of cancer patients in Washington State has found they were twice as likely to file for bankruptcy as people without cancer.
lead_paragraph: A study of cancer patients in Washington State has found they were twice as likely to file for bankruptcy as people without cancer. The study, led by researchers from the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, linked bankruptcy court records and information from the regional cancer registry on about 200,000 cancer patients, and compared them with a similar group of people from the same area who did not have cancer. Young people with cancer experienced the highest bankruptcy rates, the study found, up to 10 times the rate of bankruptcy filings among older age groups.

abstract: The mayor of Athens, Giorgos Kaminis, came to City Hall looking for guidance on how to give young people a sense of civic engagement while Greece’s government-debt woes continue.
lead_paragraph: Could Michael R. Bloomberg save Athens?

headline: Trying to Get to ‘Heaven,’ Onstage
abstract: The creative team behind the musical “Far From Heaven,” in previews at Playwrights Horizons, grappled with translating the source film’s cinematic style for the stage.
lead_paragraph: Scott Frankel recalled sitting next to his grandmother at a movie theater in suburban Cleveland, visibly moved as she watched the 2002 Todd Haynes film “Far From Heaven,” a deconstruction of the Eisenhower-era melodramas of the director Douglas Sirk. He had first seen the film, set in 1957 Connecticut, a few months before in Chelsea with an audience of devoted cinephiles, who nodded approvingly at its evocation of the overripe cinematic style of Sirk and laughed knowingly at its commentary on the past.

headline: Amtrak Upgrades Wi-Fi Service on Trains
abstract: The railroad said it had upgraded its cellular-based Wi-Fi offering using broadband technologies that will improve speed and reliability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of criticism of the wireless service on its trains, Amtrak announced on Thursday that it had upgraded its cellular-based Wi-Fi using broadband technologies that will improve the speed and reliability of the Internet in its passenger cars.

headline: U.S. Routs Russia to Reach Semifinals at World Championships
abstract: The United States upset the defending champion Russia, 8-3, in the quarterfinals at the International Ice Hockey Federation world championships. The Americans will play Switzerland in the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — In stunning fashion, the United States beat defending champion Russia, 8-3, on Thursday in the quarterfinals at the International Ice Hockey Federation world championships. It was the most goals allowed by a Russian team in this tournament.

headline: Is There Really a Second-Term Curse?
abstract: Two-term presidents since World War II tended to be quite popular in their first terms, and significantly less so in their second terms. Is this proof of a second-term curse? In reality, there are some complications.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is facing one of his roughest stretches in office after questions about the government’s response to the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, the admission by the Internal Revenue Service that it inappropriately targeted conservative groups which sought tax-exempt status, and the revelation that the Justice Department subpoenaed communications by The Associated Press.

headline: The Rembrandt of Basketball
abstract: The first time I talked to Phil Jackson, he spontaneously sketched a play on his placemat. I have to admit there was a not-tiny part of me that was squealing, internally.
lead_paragraph: The first time I talked to Phil Jackson, at a diner, he spontaneously sketched a play on his place mat. I try to keep things professional when I’m doing an interview, but I have to admit there was a not-tiny part of me that was squealing, internally: OMG the winningest N.B.A. coach of all time is literally drawing me a play right now, just like he drew Michael Jordan plays during time outs — OMG I’ve finally achieved my childhood dream of turning into Michael Jordan. (Phil Jackson, whom I wrote about in this weekend’s magazine, was leading Jordan to his first championships during the peak years of my adolescence, so the Jordan/Jackson mythology is still plugged into some pretty preprofessional emotional zones for me.)

headline: Why Basketball Won’t Leave Phil Jackson Alone
abstract: There is no such thing as life after basketball for the 13-time N.B.A. champion. Life is basketball.
lead_paragraph: Everyone wants to know what Phil Jackson is doing.

headline: Theater
abstract: Nationwide theater listings.
lead_paragraph: ARKANSAS

headline: Behind the I.R.S. Mess: A Campaign-Finance Scandal
abstract: The behavior of some individuals at the tax agency is inexcusable. What it reveals about our election laws is worse.
lead_paragraph: Let’s stipulate that the scandal involving the Internal Revenue Service’s targeting of conservative nonprofit groups portrays government as if drawn in caricature — an almost Keystone Kops-style comedy of errors on the part of low-level staffers, with a vein of possible political bias.

headline: Swipe a Card, Get a Car
abstract: Car2Go, the car-sharing service in Austin, Tex., has plans to add up to five cities to its North American roster this year.
lead_paragraph: Car2Go, the car-sharing service in Austin, Tex., from the German luxury-car maker Daimler, has plans to add up to five cities, including Denver, Minneapolis and Montreal, to its North American roster this year. The service’s fleet of electric and standard Smart cars allows for rentals by the minute and in one direction. It frees drivers from picking up and returning cars to a specific location by letting them use their smartphones to locate available cars and unlock them by scanning their membership cards.

headline: Market Report | Carry-On Essentials for Spring Jet-Setters
abstract: For those frequent fliers, a primer on what to pack for this season.
lead_paragraph: This season’s spring basics are unusually versatile, coming together to carry an outfit from day to night, business class to cocktail hour, the flyover states to the South of France — say, for the Cannes Film Festival, which kicked off yesterday. Here, a roundup of what should be in the jet-setter’s carry-on, including neutral accessories to complement any outfit and ballet flats with a punch of color. The only thing missing is the trip.

headline: Prospect Sent Down Is Told to Keep His Chin Up
abstract: Chris Nelson’s stay with the Yankees was brief, but Jayson Nix wanted him to know that if he continued to work hard at his game, he would be back.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after he heard the news that his brief stay with the Yankees was over, Chris Nelson stood in a hallway near the team’s clubhouse talking to someone who had been in the same situation: depressed, frustrated and returning to the minor leagues.

headline: Spreading the Wealth
abstract: Addressing issues over inheritance, online attractions, legible thank-you notes and store terminology
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are preparing our wills. We have two adult children: a daughter who is more successful than we are, and a son, who has been down on his luck for years. He also has three young children to educate. Everyone, including our lawyer and close friends, tells us that we should leave our money to them in equal shares to avoid hurt feelings. But that doesn’t seem right. Our son needs the money. Still, we don’t want to hurt our daughter. What would you do?

headline: Pandit Rejoins Banking With Stake in Indian Financial Firm
abstract: Vikram Pandit, the former Citigroup chief executive, and his business partner Hari Aiyar have bought a 3 percent stake in the Indian firm JM Financial. Mr. Pandit will also help manage a new $100 million distressed asset fund.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Vikram Pandit is getting back into banking.

headline: New Apps Arrive on Google Glass
abstract: Google announced seven new apps for its Internet-connected glasses, including ones from Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, CNN, Elle and Evernote.
lead_paragraph: Google Glass, the company’s Internet-connected glasses, will soon have seven new apps, including breaking news alerts from CNN, fashion features from Elle, Twitter, Tumblr and Facebook posts and reminder notes from Evernote.

headline: Pills Tracked From Doctor to Patient to Aid Drug Marketing
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Vast databases of patient and doctor information being used by drug makers let them know which medications physicians are prescribing and how they compare to colleagues.
lead_paragraph: In the old days, sales representatives from drug companies would chat up local pharmacists to learn what drugs doctors were prescribing. Now such shoulder-rubbing is becoming a quaint memory — thanks to vast databases of patient and doctor information being used by pharmaceutical companies to market drugs.

headline: Bruins’ Marchand Is Expected to Play Game 1, Despite Apparent Injury
abstract: Boston winger Brad Marchand left the team’s morning skate with an apparent injury Thursday, but Coach Claude Julien said Marchand would play against the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The big news from the morning skates before Game 1 Thursday was an apparent injury sustained by the pesky Bruins winger Brad Marchand that forced him from the ice. There was no contact or collision; he simply doubled over, apparently in pain, as he was skating and then left the ice.

headline: Senate Panel Advances Nominee for E.P.A.
abstract: The committee voted 10-to-8 along partisan lines to send the nomination of Gina McCarthy to the Senate floor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sharply divided Senate committee on Thursday approved the nomination of Gina McCarthy to serve as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: The Tale of Wrong-Way McKenry
abstract: We ask readers to write a caption for an amusing photograph.
lead_paragraph: We are no longer accepting comments for this post. Thanks for participating. We’ll look to do it again.

headline: A Case for Getting Far, Far Away
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: An obsession with the least-visited National Park Service property in the country animates an argument for vanishing.
lead_paragraph: For a decade now I’ve been obsessed with one of the most overlooked patches of real estate on the American Monopoly board — a place I’ve never even seen and that you’ve probably never heard of called Aniakchak National Monument and Preserve. Aniakchak, which is in Alaska, is the least-visited of the 401 National Park Service properties. Just 19 people stopped by Aniakchak last year, which makes the runner-up, Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial in California — visitors: 533 — a logjam of humanity by comparison.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Getting Away
abstract: One of the hardest parts about developing leukemia at age 22 was how restrictive it was: My treatments left me highly susceptible to infection, airplanes were strictly off limits and even a trip to my neighborhood bodega required a protective face mask.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of other cancer patients lying in hospital beds or in chemotherapy suites, I have spent a fair amount of time fantasizing about jetting off to a tropical island. A certain part of me knew that the fantasy was really about escaping my disease, but even so, I made a pastime of watching planes in the sky and dreaming of white, sandy beaches.

headline: 2013 Mille Miglia Features Record Entry Numbers
abstract: The 415 cars starting in this year’s Mille Miglia Storica are a record number for the historic Italian road race.
lead_paragraph: BRESCIA, Italy – The 2013 Mille Miglia Storica tribute rally began Thursday evening here in a driving rainstorm, but the inclement weather did little to dampen the enthusiasm of a record entry of 415 starters. The list included a star-studded collection of film actors, musicians, major and minor celebrities, business executives, fashionistas, professional racing drivers and classic-car enthusiasts from around the world.

headline: Decoded: Upfronts Get Bigger and Broader
abstract: The Times's Brian Stelter decodes why television networks are trying to broaden their offerings.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Brian Stelter decodes why television networks are trying to broaden their offerings.

headline: Unemployment Rate Falls to Lowest Level in Over Four Years
abstract: A surge in hiring offset continued weakness on Wall Street, according to a report from the State Labor Department.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate fell in April to 8.4 percent, its lowest level in more than four years, as widespread hiring easily offset continued weakness on Wall Street, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: ‘A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder’ Coming to Broadway
abstract: The musical comedy “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” is coming to the Walter Kerr Theater in the fall.
lead_paragraph: The musical comedy “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” which has received critical acclaim in Hartford and San Diego for the dexterous performance of the Tony Award winner Jefferson Mays in multiple roles, will transfer to Broadway this fall, the producers confirmed on Thursday. The musical is to begin preview performances at the Walter Kerr Theater on Oct. 22 and open on Nov. 17, with Mr. Mays (“I Am My Own Wife”) again playing eight different heirs to the D’Ysquith family fortune – all of whom become targets for a disinherited distant relative.

lead_paragraph: Federal regulators approved new rules on Thursday to shine a light on Wall Street trading, but they also softened a crucial aspect of the plan in the face of lobbying pressure from the nation’s biggest banks.

lead_paragraph: A large coalition of religious groups and investors is pressing major American retailers to join a sweeping plan to improve safety in Bangladesh apparel factories, calling on them to act together to force changes in overseas workplaces.

lead_paragraph: In his first book, “Class A: Baseball in the Middle of Everywhere,” Lucas Mann chronicles the year he spent following the LumberKings, a minor league team in Clinton, Iowa, affiliated with the Seattle Mariners. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Mann discussed the team’s fan base, the strange incentives of minor league existence and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: A Historic Immersion Before Whitney Moves
abstract: T. J. Wilcox is creating a panoramic film chronicling one day in Manhattan for a forthcoming show at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago the Manhattan artist T. J. Wilcox moved his studio from the lower floor of a Union Square building to its penthouse, where he suddenly had 360-degree views. “At first I spent weeks just staring out of the window,” he said. “I pretty much thought it was the end of my art making.”

lead_paragraph: Updated | May 22, 2013 We apologize: the video we used for this lesson seems to have been taken down, though you can, of course, still do the activity ideas we’ve listed.

headline: Woodson Turns to Copeland, but Won’t Desert Kidd
abstract: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson said Chris Copeland would get playing time early in Game 5 against the Pacers, but Jason Kidd will also continue to play.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – Knicks Coach Mike Woodson made a number of statements Thursday after what could be his team’s final shootaround of the 2012-13 season. With the Knicks on the brink of elimination in their Eastern Conference semifinals series against the Pacers, Woodson said he would demand his players be a tougher group in Game 5, which is Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. He also said all five players on the court would need to rebound in order to win.

lead_paragraph: The WSJ highlights a speech by Jaime Caruana, general manager of the Bank for International Settlements, warning of the dangers of easy money and the need to raise rates now to avert … something or other. And his views matter, says the Journal:

headline: Exercise Class, Obedience Not Required
abstract: In a new class in Brooklyn, dogs and their owners can work out and play together.
lead_paragraph: DOGS may be our best friends, but that doesn’t necessarily make them the easiest exercise partners. The fitness trainer Angi Aramburu thinks otherwise, though, and this spring she started Go Fetch Run, an exercise class in which owners and their dogs can work out and play together.

headline: Knicks Losing the Scrum at the 3-Point Line
abstract: The Pacers’ defense, which is adept at stopping 3-point shots, has had the upper hand on the Knicks’ offense, which is adept at making them.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. playoff series between the Knicks and the Indiana Pacers can be seen as a battle for the 3-point line. And, so far, the Pacers are winning.

headline: New Provocations From the Belgian Bad Boy Wim Delvoye
abstract: In a new Manhattan gallery show, the Belgian artist Wim Delvoye offers a more mature version of his usual pot-stirring antics.
lead_paragraph: The Belgian artist Wim Delvoye is known for making his friends perform sexual acts in front of X-ray machines, tattooing live pigs to look like Louis Vuitton handbags (and selling the hides and taxidermied animals from his farm in China) and finding the “humanness” in processes, like digestion, that don’t exactly scream “artful.” But the show he opened last weekend at the Bowery gallery Sperone Westwater suggests a new maturity.

headline: What We See When We Look at Wild Animals
abstract: Jon Mooallem’s first book explores our complicated relationship to endangered species.
lead_paragraph: Jon Mooallem, the author of last week’s cover story about the mysterious murders of some Hawaiian monk seals, has written often for the magazine about animals and what they mean to us. He has explored same-sex coupling in the animal world (“The Love that Dare Not Squawk Its Name”), for example, and helping turtles hatch after an oil spill (“The BP-Spill Baby-Turtle Brigade”). His first book, “Wild Ones,” published today, is also about animals or, more properly, about “looking at people looking at animals.”

lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco Giants won the 2010 World Series, the post-victory celebrations got out of control. Revelers smashed windows, got into fistfights and started fires. A Muni bus and the metaverse were both set alight.

headline: Savagery, Mulled in Airy Precincts
abstract: The artist Imran Qureshi has splattered the roof terrace of the Metropolitan Museum of Art with red paint in a work that suggests the potential for hope amid bloody violence.
lead_paragraph: The roof garden at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is one of the lovelier places to go in New York during the warm seasons. Every year its pastoral bliss high above Central Park is complemented by some sort of benign sculpture exhibition, usually three-dimensional works of formal decorum or playful ingenuity.
