lead_paragraph: PARIS — Faced with a deepening economic malaise and mounting public dissatisfaction with his leadership, President François Hollande of France said on Thursday that he would “go on the offensive,” promising new measures to reduce unemployment and harmonize economic policies among the countries using the euro.

headline: Theater Talkback: Farewell to ‘Smash’
abstract: A theater critic says goodbye to the disappointing NBC series about the making of a Broadway show.
lead_paragraph: The race for the big Tony for best musical is a real nail-biter, right? Will the award go to the front-runner, that splashy old-fashioned musical about a famous screen goddess? Or will there be an “Avenue Q”-type upset, with the funky downtown show about dueling pop stars taking home the big trophy?

headline: Bronx Week Festival
abstract: The Bronx Week Festival celebrates its final weekend with many events that are free.
lead_paragraph: The Beatles sang about a love affair so all-consuming that it required “Eight Days a Week.” The Bronx borough president, Ruben Diaz Jr., must know how they felt; he has taken a page from their songbook for this year’s annual Bronx Week festival, which takes 11 days to represent adequately the depth and diversity of Bronx culture. The celebration’s final weekend is bursting with offerings, many of which, the Miser is happy to report, are free.

headline: Killing Reveals the Still-Dark Side of a Gentrifying Capital
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: The beating death of Malcolm Shabazz, the grandson of Malcolm X, was in a district of Mexico City that has not benefited from the city’s recent improvements.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — This sprawling city has been described recently as “vibrant” (Elle Decor), “rich with historical heritage and incredible food traditions” (Saveur), “scrubbed and safe” (New York magazine) and “inviting and exciting” (Fodor’s).

headline: Recalling the Life of the Party
abstract: James Naughton hosted a Bobby Short tribute, with performances by Barbara Carroll, Paula West, Billy Stritch and the rising cabaret star T. Oliver Reid.
lead_paragraph: Year after year, the pianist and singer Barbara Carroll recalled on Wednesday evening, she and her close friend Bobby Short used to share tea, cookies and gossip before his shows at the Café Carlyle, where he held forth for three and a half decades. Ms. Carroll worked as the resident pianist across the hall at Bemelmans Bar for almost as many years. Short’s jovial exit line after their tête-à-têtes: “I gotta go in and cook them greens.”

headline: Enigma Machines Fetch High Prices at Auctions
abstract: The technology of the Enigma code machines, used by Germans to transmit messages in World War II, still fascinates the public.
lead_paragraph: Late in World War II, fleeing German soldiers tried to destroy the equipment they used for transmitting messages in their Enigma code. Hundreds of salvageable machines, however, were left behind, and the technology, with alphabet keyboards and hidden rotors, still fascinates the public.

headline: Silver to Seek Lopez’s Expulsion From Assembly Over Harassment Claims
abstract: Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly, said on Thursday night that he would ask for a vote on sanctions, including possible expulsion, against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly, said on Thursday night that he would seek the expulsion of Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, the once-powerful Brooklyn Democrat, over accusations of sexual harassment by multiple women who worked for the Legislature.

headline: An Artist With an Ever-Increasing Desire to Disappear
abstract: The Jewish Museum’s exhibition “Jack Goldstein x 10,000” centers on the performance-based films he made in the 1970s and 1980s.
lead_paragraph: “Jack Goldstein x 10,000,” the first American museum retrospective of this brilliant but elusive artist, is both a celebration and a cautionary tale. It revels in Goldstein’s posthumous influence as it reveals the tragic disconnect of his life and his art, the desire to disappear complicated by an intense careerist drive. For his master’s thesis exhibition, he had himself buried in a wooden box fitted with a breathing tube; above ground, a blinking red light reassured the audience that he was still alive.

abstract: The Consumer Protection Finance Bureau has created a Spanish language Web site.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has created a Spanish language Web site, joining a growing list of online resources for Spanish-speaking consumers.

lead_paragraph: Inside the Ridgewood, Queens, restaurant featuring Vietnamese street-style food.

headline: Reaping the Benefits of Lessons Well Learned
abstract: The chef at Bunker in Ridgewood, Queens, trailed street vendors in Vietnam for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Flames leap out of a sawed-off oil barrel at the 24-hour scrap-metal yard across the street. Power lines droop, above them nothing but blue. It is practically big-sky country out here on the eastern edge of Ridgewood, Queens, buildings slouching and sun smacking down.

headline: A Time When Things Started in Chicago
abstract: In “The Third Coast,” Thomas Dyja describes Chicago before and after World War II, when that city was a greenhouse for skyscrapers, McDonald’s and rock music.
lead_paragraph: “The Third Coast” is an odd title for Thomas Dyja’s engrossing, wide-angled cultural history of Chicago in the middle of the 20th century.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Frances Ha’
abstract: Noah Baumbach, the director of “Frances Ha,” narrates a scene featuring Greta Gerwig, Mickey Sumner and Adam Driver.
lead_paragraph: The director Noah Baumbach appreciates long takes. In this video, he narrates a scene from “Frances Ha,” which he directed and also co-wrote with the film’s star, Greta Gerwig. The scene features Ms. Gerwig and Mickey Sumner, who plays Frances’s friend Sophie. Adam Driver plays Frances’s roommate Lev. Mr. Baumbach discusses the structure of the scene that mostly plays as a long take with minimal cuts.

headline: Frenchman Staves Off Extradition in Diamond Theft
abstract: Lawyers for Marc Bertoldi, owner of a luxury car business, argued that the Belgian authorities had not spelled out his precise role in the $50 million theft in February.
lead_paragraph: METZ, France — The French owner of a luxury car business — accused of masterminding a $50 million million diamond theft at Brussels Airport — temporarily fended off extradition to Belgium on Thursday, arguing that the authorities there had not spelled out his precise role.

headline: ESPN to Gain Full Rights to U.S. Open in 2015
abstract: The latest assault on the fraying broadcast sports model came Thursday when ESPN announced it would pay $825 million over 11 years for complete control of the tennis tournament.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the United States Open tennis tournament was a mainstay of broadcast television, along with the Super Bowl, the World Series and the Masters. From Billie Jean King and Rod Laver to Roger Federer and the Williams sisters, viewers knew they could watch superstars, rising talents and upstarts play in the men’s and women’s finals and semifinals — and more — on CBS.

headline: Drug Marketers Use Social Network Diagrams to Help Locate Influential Doctors
abstract: Consulting companies like Activate Networks use social network diagrams to help pharmaceutical marketers identify prescribing histories and relationships among doctors.
lead_paragraph: Consulting companies like Activate Networks use social network diagrams to help pharmaceutical marketers identify prescribing histories and relationships among doctors.

headline: A Meet-Up of Freedom, Innovation and Intensity
abstract: Pam Tanowitz’s “Spectators” is an intense and complex work that borrows from ballet.
lead_paragraph: Pam Tanowitz is sometimes described as a deconstructionist of ballet and modern dance. This makes her sound formidably cerebral, and it’s true that throughout much of last year’s lecturelike “Untitled (Blue Ballet)” you had to pinch yourself to stay awake. But “The Spectators,” her new dance that opened at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, is almost unbearably exciting. It’s a return to form that pushes further. The experience it offers a spectator is exhilarating enough to make “spectating” an inadequate verb.

headline: The Overtime Hero Is Anyone’s Guess

headline: From a Moving Van to an Arts Complex

Mana Contemporary in Jersey City, part of the Moishe’s Moving and Storage empire, envisions itself as a full-service art center in a couple of years.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — MANA Contemporary might be one of the art world’s best-kept secrets. From the outside, at the moment, it looks like what its shell actually is: a cluster of warehouse and factory buildings left over from a grimy industrial age, tucked into the heart of this city.

headline: Why National Guard and Reservist Suicide Numbers May Be Misleading
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: One aspect of suicide statistics that is often overlooked is the number of National Guard and Reserve members who commit suicide when they are not on active duty.
lead_paragraph: More than 80 percent of the services members who committed suicide in recent years had never been in combat. This is one of the many statistics that the Pentagon and researchers are currently struggling to explain. My colleague James Dao and I explore the tragic rising military suicide numbers in an article today.

headline: A Fine Line Between Social and Political
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Is tax law being widely flouted by political groups determined to avoid disclosure of their donors?
lead_paragraph: As everyone from Republican senators to President Obama denounces the Internal Revenue Service for singling out Tea Party organizations for extra scrutiny, it is worth asking how we got to the point that the I.R.S. is supposed to investigate political activities. It is also worth asking whether the tax law is being widely flouted by political groups determined to avoid disclosure of their donors — and whether successive administrations have failed to enforce the law.

headline: Breaking the Mold
abstract: In Helene Wecker’s novel, two folkloric creatures emerge onto the streets of 1899 New York.
lead_paragraph: In Helene Wecker’s first novel, two more than usually disoriented foreigners emerge onto the streets of 1899 New York. One is a golem, a clay woman fashioned near Danzig, then shipped across the ocean as the wife of a man who inconveniently dies on the voyage. The other is a jinni from the Syrian desert, trapped inside a copper flask until a hapless tinsmith sets him free during a routine repair. “It was ludicrous,” thinks the surprised tinker. “Such things were only stories. But then, the only alternative was to conclude that he’d gone mad.” There is in fact plenty of madness in this clever story, but the magic of it often makes more sense than the ways of the humans with whom the golem and the jinni now live.

headline: What’s Real Today (Check Again Soon)
abstract: Well over half the artists in the International Center of Photography’s fourth triennial use ever-changing digital technology in their work or mimic its properties.
lead_paragraph: Digital makes, and the art world takes. That’s reality today. So “A Different Kind of Order,” the title of the International Center of Photography’s fourth triennial, and its best yet, is apt.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:15 p.m. | After half a century, New York still loves Michael very, very much.

headline: Doctor and Patient: A Gothic Love Story
abstract: Alice Winocour’s “Augustine” depicts the relationship between the 19th-century French neurologist Jean-Martin Charcot and a young housemaid who becomes his patient.
lead_paragraph: The 19th-century French neurologist Jean-Martin Charcot is best remembered as a teacher of William James and Sigmund Freud, and also for the haunting, fascinating photographs he collected of patients in various states of symptomatic mental distress. Like other important figures in the history of medicine, he is a complicated figure in retrospect, at once a charlatan and a pioneer, a monster and a modernizer.

headline: Justice Dept. Lost Track of Terrorists, Report Says
abstract: The department also did not disclose until recently the fictitious identities it created for terrorism-linked witnesses to the agency that generates watch lists, a new report said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department temporarily lost track of two former terrorists who had participated in its witness protection program and until recently did not disclose the fictitious identities it created for terrorism-linked witnesses to the agency that generates watch lists, allowing some who were on the no-fly list to take commercial flights under their new names, according to a new report.

lead_paragraph: A new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts reinforces what many economists have been saying for some time: the mortgage interest deduction primarily benefits high-income homeowners.

headline: If 27 Is Old, How Old Is Grown Up?
abstract: Greta Gerwig is the co-writer and star of “Frances Ha,” a look at a vaguely artistic, post-collegiate New York cohort, directed by Noah Baumbach.
lead_paragraph: One day an unexpected tax refund arrives in the mail, and Frances, giddy over this windfall, decides to spend it treating a young man to dinner. (His name is Lev, he is played by Adam Driver, and this is the only time I will mention Lena Dunham or “Girls” in this review.) The restaurant rejects her credit card and won’t take a debit card, so Frances sets off through the black-and-white streets of New York in search of an A.T.M. Sprinting back to the table, she trips and sprawls headlong onto the sidewalk, the full calamity of her fall blocked from the camera’s view by a parked car. Then she gets up and keeps running.

headline: 36 Hours in Texas Hill Country
abstract: Just west of Austin you’ll find the Hill Country, an area home to Comfort and Welfare, the echoes of Willie and Waylon and the tension between rural and refined.
lead_paragraph: There are two ways to think about the Texas Hill Country. Physically, it spreads across the undulating Edwards Plateau, with Austin to the east and San Antonio to the south. Near the center is Fredericksburg, which was once the main show in these parts, but no longer. To get a feeling for the Hill Country in the second sense — the state of mind where cool mingles with tradition, and industriousness and idleness are equally esteemed values (depending on the time of day) — head out among the limestone knolls full of live oak groves and cypress-lined creeks, and to the gritty pin-dot towns built largely of native stone. Here you’ll find a delicious tension between rural and refined. Inns and restaurants are bringing a clever touch to Lone Star hospitality and mythology, and with the vineyards and boutique farms (lavender, olives), some people make comparisons to Napa Valley or even Provence. But those assessments ignore something fundamental: the Hill Country — being Texas at its finest — is like nowhere else in the world.

headline: Beyond the Pale as Well as the Els
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: When it was built in 1928, 333 East 68th Street, between First and Second Avenues, was considered too far east.
lead_paragraph: The elite residents of the Upper East Side from Fifth Avenue to Park generally balked once they got to Third Avenue, the elevated train forming a last barrier between the gentry and the working class. But a few visionaries breached that Chinese wall, including the developers of 333 East 68th, who braved the forbidden zone, adding white-gloved doormen in among the tenements.

headline: The Sounds of Tunisia, Mixed With the World’s
abstract: Two very different kinds of current music from Tunisia  were part of the French Institute Alliance Française’s monthlong World Nomads Tunisia festival.
lead_paragraph: Two very different kinds of current music from Tunisia — one for the concert stage, one for the dance floor, both wide open to global connections — were part of the French Institute Alliance Française’s monthlong World Nomads Tunisia festival on Wednesday night. At the institute’s auditorium, Ghalia Benali performed songs that were rooted in Tunisia but that could float east or west. Then, at the meatpacking district club Catch, disc jockeys from the Waveform collective in Tunis wielded laptops and mixers in music that moved from molten and experimental to crisply propulsive.

headline: Juvenile Inmates Found to Be at No Greater Risk for Prison Rape
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sex Crimes', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Juvenile Delinquency']
abstract: A government survey of prison and jail inmates challenged the notion that minors in adult facilities face a higher risk of sexual abuse than other prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Youth advocates have long argued that juveniles incarcerated in adult prisons and jails are at heightened risk for rape and other forms of sexual abuse because of their age. But a government survey released on Thursday found that juveniles did not report significantly more sexual victimization than adult inmates.

Fans of that show might expect a lot of laughs from “Black Rock,” since it was written by a “League” cast member, Mark Duplass, and stars another, Katie Aselton, who also directed it.

headline: In a Vicious Sadist, the Faintest Glimmer of Soul
abstract: “Pieta,” a brutal drama by the South Korean director Kim Ki-duk, centers on a violent loan shark approached by a woman claiming to be his mother.
lead_paragraph: Morally cunning and with a tone as black as pitch, “Pieta,” the 18th film from the South Korean director Kim Ki-duk, is a deeply unnerving revenge movie in which redemption is dangled like a cat toy before a cougar. The beast in question is Kang-do (Lee Jung-jin), a merciless bag man for a powerful moneylender who cripples slum-dwelling debtors to collect on their insurance claims. As cold to himself as to his clients, he lives in a comfortless flat where the entrails from the previous night’s chicken dinner still decorate the bathroom floor. So when a strange woman (Cho Min-soo) begins to stalk him, claiming to be the mother who abandoned him long ago, Kang-do barely hesitates: he rapes her.

headline: Performing From Space, Canada’s Low-Orbit Star
abstract: Chris Hadfield’s exploits in space may have cemented his reputation as the world’s best-known singing astronaut, not to mention Canada’s newest celebrity.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — As far as YouTube hits go, Canada’s contribution has not yet approached the popularity of South Korea’s “Gangnam Style.” And perhaps because of the limitations of weightlessness, the music video lacked any dance moves at all.

headline: Out of Necessity, Yanks Call Up Betances
abstract: Dellin Betances, once a top 50 prospect, has struggled at Class AAA, but after a couple of encouraging outings the Yankees called him up to shore up their overtaxed bullpen.
lead_paragraph: Before the 2012 season, Dellin Betances was a top 50 prospect in baseball and one of the Yankees’ most promising young players. But after a season in which he posted a 6.44 earned run average, Betances dropped off top prospect lists and was thought to be far away from making the majors.

headline: Keeping Kosher in Nigeria, a Tiny but Fervent Minority
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The documentary “Re-emerging: The Jews of Nigeria” focuses on a minority that claims to be descended from ancient Israelites.
lead_paragraph: Are the Ibo people of Nigeria a lost tribe of Israel? A longstanding tradition among the Ibo says they are, and points to similarities in Ibo and Jewish cultures: a prescribed day of rest, circumcision (male, that is), the prohibition of pork. And now some Ibo have embraced Judaism, considering it the religion of their ancestors.

headline: Battle of the Bullhorns as a Wind Project Beckons
abstract: “Cape Spin” examines the fierce struggle over a proposed wind farm off the Massachusetts coast.
lead_paragraph: From the initial proposal in 2001, the Cape Wind project — 130 turbines across a 24-square-mile stretch of Nantucket Sound — has stirred furious dissent. The installation would be the nation’s first offshore wind farm, reducing the fossil fuel emissions around coastal Massachusetts and helping to develop a clean-energy industry. But residents howl that the project would despoil a pristine seascape, damage fishing grounds, foul ferry and air traffic and even disrupt the religious practices of the Wampanoag tribe.

headline: Greece: Teachers Abandon Strike Plan
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Law and Legislation', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Greek high school teachers on Thursday called off a strike after the government essentially banned it by enacting an emergency law that threatened strikers with arrest or dismissal.
lead_paragraph: Greek high school teachers on Thursday called off a planned strike after the government essentially banned it by enacting an emergency law that threatened strikers with arrest or dismissal. The teachers were unable to attract widespread political and public support for the planned Friday walkout, and after the government’s move a vote by the teachers failed to secure a majority. Only 23 percent voted in favor of joining the strike. The two main labor unions also refused to back the proposed strike, instead staging a four-hour walkout on Thursday that disrupted public services and flights. The teachers object to the government’s plans to increase their working hours, fearing the move will lead to job cutbacks. Amnesty International condemned the government’s “blanket prohibition on the teachers’ right to strike,” describing the use of an emergency law as “unnecessary and disproportionate” and a human rights violation.

headline: Sudden Impulse, and a Warrior Is Born
abstract: The documentary “Bidder 70” focuses on Tim DeChristopher, who would serve time in prison for disrupting a federal auction of oil and gas drilling rights in Utah.
lead_paragraph: At the end of 2008, Tim DeChristopher, a young economics student at the University of Utah, strolled into a federal auction of oil and gas drilling rights to prime Utah wilderness. Although he was opposed to the auction, which he considered “illegal and unethical,” he had no plans to disrupt it, but when he was mistakenly handed a paddle, he chose to use it, knowing that he had no way to pay for the parcels he would eventually win.

headline: That Elusive Seat at the U.N. Table
abstract: “State 194” explores the Palestinian Authority’s struggle for a two-state solution and member status at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations currently has 193 member nations. The dream of, and the work toward, member status for Palestinians is the subject of “State 194,” an intelligent, evenhanded Israeli documentary by Dan Setton about a two-state solution for coexistence. Mr. Setton, a Peabody Award- and Emmy-winning director and producer, was inspired by a 2009 radio speech by Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority, who left office last month.

headline: The Morning Nine
abstract: Breaking down the nine-horse field for the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes.
lead_paragraph: The horses for the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses for the race. The morning-line odds were set by Frank Carulli of Pimlico Race Course.

headline: Clips, Quips and Snips: A Wrap-Up of Upfronts
abstract: A look back at what television executives offered Madison Avenue for the 2013-14 season.
lead_paragraph: HERE is a look back at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual upfronts week, which took place from Monday through Thursday as television executives offered Madison Avenue previews of their schedules for the 2013-14 season.

headline: Jockey Is Atop the Favorite, and All of Racing
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Preakness Stakes', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: After a string of impressive victories, Joel Rosario is the leading money winner among the nation’s jockeys, and he stands a good chance to increase his earnings in the Preakness.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — It was a claiming race with a modest purse of $30,000, but Joel Rosario strode into the paddock of Belmont Park last Sunday with the laser focus that has made him the top jockey in America. He was riding the mare Delightful Dawn for the first time, but had watched video replays of her races and knew she liked to stalk the leaders and try to get past them in the stretch.

headline: Uzbek Man in Idaho Is Held in Bomb Plot
abstract: Federal authorities arrested an Uzbek man in Boise on charges that he assisted a foreign terrorist group and possessed bomb-making materials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal authorities arrested an Uzbek man on Thursday in Boise, Idaho, on charges that he provided a foreign terrorist group with help in building an explosive device.

headline: A Last Stand for Nature Against Mighty Odds
abstract: The documentary “Elemental” follows a water expert in India, an Australian inventor and a Canadian activist.
lead_paragraph: The back-to-basics title of “Elemental” seems to herald another pious lesson about a world out of balance, but the filmmakers, Gayatri Roshan and Emmanuel Vaughan-Lee, have made a documentary that is more about environmentalists than about environmentalism. Following an indigenous Canadian activist, a crusading government official in India and a struggling inventor, this sensitively scored film complicates the typical missionary’s-progress arc by acknowledging its would-be heroes’ weaknesses and the day-to-day obstacles to doing good.

headline: Syria Begins to Break Apart Under Pressure From War
abstract: A constellation of armed groups battling to advance their own agendas is effectively creating the outlines of separate fiefs.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The black flag of jihad flies over much of northern Syria. In the center of the country, pro-government militias and Hezbollah fighters battle those who threaten their communities. In the northeast, the Kurds have effectively carved out an autonomous zone.

headline: Debating the Legal Basis for the War on Terror

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top Pentagon official said Thursday that the evolving war against Al Qaeda was likely to continue “at least 10 to 20 years” and urged Congress not to modify the statute that provides its legal basis.

headline: Aiming for the Top, Again
abstract: Fred Eckert was once a star investor, but by 2011, he was bankrupt, divorced and had spent two months in a coma.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, the wheel of fortune can spin around and around, from enormous cash bonuses and luxurious perks one year to the unemployment line the next.

headline: Outrunning Assassins, Sulky Daughter in Tow

lead_paragraph: For his first film in English, the German director Philipp Stölzl travels a long way from the cheeky flirtations of “Young Goethe in Love” to “Erased,” a bearable if unremarkable composite of the “Taken” movies and “Three Days of the Condor.”

headline: Gunshots on Warm Spring Evenings
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Firearms', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Gun violence wreaks havoc on a community. But it’s not just about blood and mayhem.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — A FEW Saturdays ago, at the early evening hour when children linger outside to wring the last fun they can from the day, a series of gunshots split the air near the corner of Chadwick and Avon Avenues. Everyone scattered. After the cops arrived and taped off the intersection and determined that no one at the scene had been hit, the street slowly stirred back to life.

headline: Learning From Litigation
keywords: ['Malpractice', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hospitals', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: How malpractice risk can make hospitals safer places.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — MUCH of the discussion over the Affordable Care Act has focused on whether it will bring down health care costs. Less attention has been paid to another goal of the act: improving patient safety. Each year tens of thousands of people die, and hundreds of thousands more are injured, as a result of medical error.

headline: How Latin Culture Got More Gay
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: How can we reconcile the advancement of legal same-sex marriage in much of Latin America with the stereotype of Latin culture as a bastion of religiosity and machismo?
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — BRAZIL is potentially poised to become the third and largest country in Latin America to legalize same-sex marriage, following a judicial order on Tuesday. Argentina was the first, in 2010, after the government brushed aside objections from Cardinal Jorge Bergoglio of Buenos Aires, now the pope. The Uruguayan legislature followed suit last month. Mexico City has allowed such unions since 2010, and the Mexican state of Quintana Roo since 2011.

headline: Stacks of Bibles, and Graphic Novels

lead_paragraph: To readers of philosophy, “logos” means reason and rational argument. To readers of the Gospels, it is the word of God made incarnate in Jesus Christ. But for seekers of all kinds on the Upper East Side, Logos is also a cozy bookshop with a lumpy recliner and a black cat named Boo Boo, who sleeps near a stack of Bibles.

lead_paragraph: Foxconn Technology, the company that manufactures Apple’s popular iPads and iPhones, has made substantial progress toward improving safety and other working conditions at three of its Chinese plants dedicated to making Apple products. But it has not yet achieved the most difficult goal: reducing the average workweek to the maximum allowed by Chinese law, a global monitoring group said on Thursday.

A few workout shirts hung on a bar, and a Jets hat rested on a shelf. It looked as if he had stepped away for a few minutes, to take a shower or answer a phone call, and not wandered straight into retirement.

keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']

lead_paragraph: It sounded like an alternative ending to “Dr. Strangelove,” subtitled: “How They Grew Careless Managing Nuclear Missiles.” Seventeen Air Force officers assigned to launch control for nuclear-tipped Minuteman missiles were removed from their posts last month for violating safety and code protection procedures and showing poor attitudes.

headline: Scandal Machine
abstract: Behind their loud condemnations of President Obama, Republicans continue to damage the economy and society.
lead_paragraph: When politicians want to turn scandals into metaphors, actual details of wrongdoing or incompetence no longer matter. In fact, the details of the troubles swirling around the White House this week are bluntly contradicting Republicans who want to combine them into a seamless narrative of tyrannical government on the rampage.

headline: The Murky World of Hospital Prices
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Editorials']
abstract: Consumers need a clearer picture of costs to make rational decisions about medical care.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the federal government made public a vast trove of information on the list prices charged by hospitals for a large array of procedures commonly performed on hospitalized patients. It was a good start toward providing greater transparency in hospital billing, which has long been shrouded in secrecy. But it fell short of providing full information that patients need to make informed decisions about which hospitals to use and which insurance to buy.

headline: A Lower Standard for Drunken Driving
abstract: There is good reason to lower the blood-alcohol level to 0.05, while taking separate steps to get the hard-core drinkers off the roads.
lead_paragraph: It is surprising how few drinks can impair a driver’s judgment. A report from the National Transportation Safety Board estimates that alcohol-impaired driving contributes to thousands of deaths and tens of thousands of serious injuries each year. It is right to urge states to reduce that toll by lowering the allowable blood-alcohol concentration for drivers from 0.08 percent to 0.05 percent.

headline: Veeck’s Son Dusts Off Old Idea and Crowdsources the Umpiring
abstract: Mike Veeck, whose father, Bill, had a knack for inventive promotions for baseball games, organized a game without umpires for his St. Paul Saints.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — The left-handed batter tried to check his swing in the first inning. In a reflex honed through thousands of innings behind the plate, Dwight Childs, a catcher for the St. Paul Saints of the independent American Association, pointed up the third-base line, appealing for a swinging strike call.

headline: Nerdy Passions of the Stand-Up Patriot
abstract: In “Unconstitutional,” his stand-up show at the Barrow Street Theater, Colin Quinn digs deep into the historical weeds while keeping the audience in tow with jokes and barroom metaphors.
lead_paragraph: As the cultural status of stand-up comics has risen, these restless gypsies who moved from hotels and coffee houses to comedy clubs and alternative rooms have migrated in growing numbers to the theater. One pioneer is Colin Quinn, who after two solo shows on Broadway (the first in 1998), now mounts off Broadway a pleasingly funny amble through American history in “Unconstitutional.”

headline: Love Away From the Battlefield
abstract: In “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812” the characters pursue their fates, happy and otherwise, in the grand houses of 19th-century Moscow.
lead_paragraph: The clash of armies is not to be heard during “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812,” the vibrant, transporting new musical adapted from a potent slice of Tolstoy’s “War and Peace.” True, Napoleon is nominally present, presiding with a stern semi-smile over the proceedings from within a copy of a Jacques-Louis David portrait. But the roiling sounds of battle do not intrude on the romantic drama unfolding before us in Dave Malloy’s freshly imagined pop opera, which opened on Thursday night at a custom-built cabaret called Kazino, in the meatpacking district.

headline: Dangerous When Leaked
abstract: Fun Friday with Josh Knapp.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — You can always get on my good side by stretching DR. STRANGELOVE across the middle of a grid. Oddly, the name of the Peter Sellers character hasn’t been seen since 1988, so we might as well consider it sort of a debut. It’s crossed by SILICON VALLEY, another debut, and the other two 13s include “DEATH IN VENICE,” another favorite of mine and POST-MODERNISM. We’re off to a good start on this Josh Knapp puzzle.

headline: 16 Accused of Smuggling Cigarettes Worth Millions
abstract: Officials said the defendants profited by buying the goods in low-tax states in the South and selling them illegally in New York, avoiding the state’s high taxes.
lead_paragraph: One of the men had once lived in the same Brooklyn building as the personal secretary of a senior Hamas member, the authorities said. Another was something of a father figure to the terrorist who fatally shot at a van full of yeshiva students on the Brooklyn Bridge. And a third is said to have once received an investment from Omar Abdel Rahman, the so-called blind sheik, who is now serving a life sentence for a terrorism plot.

headline: Case Casts Harsh Light on Family Art Business
abstract: Hillel Nahmad, owner of Helly Nahmad Gallery, has been accused of playing a leadership role in a gambling and money-laundering network.
lead_paragraph: For years, high-end auctions at Sotheby’s and Christie’s have featured a familiar tableau — members of the Nahmad family spread out in the front row, sometimes six or seven people across. Little known outside the art market but a pivotal force within it, the family, whose worth is estimated at $3 billion, has amassed one of the largest collections of Impressionist and Modernist art in the world, including one of the largest holdings of Picasso in private hands. They did it with a purchasing style that has never been subtle: they chase as many as a third of the works offered in an evening and then warehouse them for years until it is the right time to sell.

lead_paragraph: Inside a crew room at the new South Ferry subway station, once flooded wall to wall with the waters of Hurricane Sandy, transit officials on Thursday offered a sobering progress report on a system that continues to feel the storm’s effects.

lead_paragraph: In the final moments of her young life, she danced in the playground next to her apartment building with her big sister and friends, joyfully oblivious to the bloody turf fights roiling from block to block all around her.

lead_paragraph: A decision by the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, to let his office be the subject of a six-part CBS News series has prompted another volley of criticism — this time from a lawyer complaining that the show, “Brooklyn D.A.,” would prejudice prospective jurors when his client goes on trial.

lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — Most climate scientists agree that global warming is caused by human activity, according to a new survey of published papers on climate science.

headline: Missouri: Diocese Settles Abuse Case
abstract: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph has settled a lawsuit for $600,000 brought by the family of a girl who was 2 years old when Rev. Shawn Ratigan took pornographic pictures of her in 2006.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph has settled a lawsuit for $600,000 brought by the family of a girl who was 2 years old when Rev. Shawn Ratigan took pornographic pictures of her in 2006. The diocese discovered hundreds of lewd photos of young girls on Father Ratigan’s laptop in 2010, and the case involving the 2-year-old is one of several civil suits against the priest and the diocese brought by the girls and their families. Father Ratigan pleaded guilty last year and is awaiting sentencing. His bishop, Robert W. Finn, was convicted on a misdemeanor charge of failing to report suspected child abuse to authorities.

headline: Fecal Matter Found in Public Pools
abstract: More than half of water samples from about 150 public swimming pools in Atlanta contained traces of fecal matter, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found.
lead_paragraph: More than half of water samples from about 150 public swimming pools in Atlanta contained traces of fecal matter, a level of contamination that is most likely similar to levels across the country, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found in a study.

headline: Louisiana: 2 Arrested in Shootings at New Orleans Parade
abstract: The New Orleans police charged two brothers with 20 counts of attempted murder in connection with a parade shooting spree on Sunday that wounded 20 people.
lead_paragraph: The police in New Orleans arrested two brothers and charged them both with 20 counts of attempted murder in connection with a shooting spree at a parade on Sunday that left 20 people wounded, 3 of them in critical condition. Akein Scott, 19, was arrested late Wednesday night and Shawn Scott, 24, was arrested on Thursday morning. The police also arrested and charged four others, ages 19 to 32, for providing “comfort and aid” to Akein Scott after investigators identified him as the likely gunman. The police said that the younger brother was a member of a gang, and several news outlets reported that he had been targeting a rival gang member from another neighborhood, who is recovering from bullet wounds.  Akein Scott was already out on bail for gun and drug possession charges. His bail on the attempted murder charges was set at $10 million.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) RIGOLETTO Michael Mayer, who won a Tony Award for directing “Spring Awakening,” made his Metropolitan Opera debut with this Verdi work, in a new production known as “the Rat Pack ‘Rigoletto,’ ” which moved events from a decadent 16th-century Italian court to the Las Vegas strip around 1960. The Polish tenor Piotr Beczala is the Duke, here a Sinatra-like playboy whose entourage includes the world-weary comedian Rigoletto, sung by the Serbian baritone Zeljko Lucic. The German soprano Diana Damrau, above with Mr. Lucic, plays the innocent Gilda, Rigoletto’s daughter and the victim of the predatory Duke. The Italian Michele Mariotti leads the ensemble in what Anthony Tommasini, writing in The New York Times, called “an excellent outing for this rising conductor.” Mr. Tommasini also noted that Mr. Mayer “had modeled Rigoletto on aggressive comics like Don Rickles, who could crack up Sinatra.” But “the vagueness of the concept undermines Mr. Lucic’s otherwise affecting performance,” he added, writing “the production was a frustrating mix of inventive and half-baked thinking.”

headline: Does the Postal Service Owe Me Money?
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Endorsements', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: It’s all in the delivery.
lead_paragraph: I recently sent a parcel via U.S. Express Mail. It was guaranteed to be delivered the next day by noon. The final delivery scan was at 12:03 p.m. I am entitled to a full refund of the postage I paid. However, the difference between noon and 12:03 is negligible — it did not affect me or the recipient. I simply needed the item delivered overnight and received the service I paid for. I’m fully satisfied. Is it ethical to request a full refund under these circumstances? ROSS NIZLEK, BURLINGTON, VT.

headline: Khaled Hosseini on How the Iraq War Hurt Afghanistan
abstract: It also almost killed his literary career.
lead_paragraph: In your new book, “And the Mountains Echoed,” one of the main characters is an Afghan-born physician in America, like you. He is embarrassed that he’s sweating the details of his new home theater while his countrymen are suffering. Do you have similar guilt?  Of course. I always have. The only reason I’m not where they are is just pure luck, it’s just a stupid genetic lottery. It’s an unmerited gift to have this life. My books became successful way beyond any reasonable expectation and were about those people on the streets. I felt that in some way I had profited from their wretchedness.

headline: Who Made That Motorcade?

abstract: The ride that spurred a redesign of presidential travel.
lead_paragraph: “Here is a fine new word,” wrote an Iowa sports columnist in 1911. Back then, the slang term “motorcade” — a riff on “cavalcade” — described any kind of derring-do by a team of drivers. Before there was a highway system, auto enthusiasts tore off on 1,000-mile safaris to prove the mettle of their horseless carriages. In 1912, representatives of Indiana car companies traveled the Midwest in a motorcade that drove into towns accompanied by a rain of confetti and a blast of organ music — pipes were hooked up to the fan shaft of one of the cars.

headline: The Rabbis’ Campaign
abstract: The campaign to elect Israel’s top rabbis is more competitive, fractious and, yes, dirty than running for the Knesset.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The two presiding rabbis of Israel’s Chief Rabbinate — one Ashkenazi, the other Sephardic — completed their 10-year term three months ago, but they were asked to stay until new chief rabbis are elected. The new rabbis can’t be chosen until a so-called electing body — 150 members, including mayors, rabbis and other assorted appointees — is selected by a committee of five, comprising two politicians, two rabbis and a judge appointed by the minister of religious affairs. And the new electing body can’t be selected until Israeli politicians can agree on how.

headline: Objects | Chris Lehrecke and Gabriella Kiss’s Wooden Wonders
abstract: A creative couple collaborates to create gorgeous, white oak furniture for Ralph Pucci International.
lead_paragraph: The furniture designer Chris Lehrecke and the jewelry designer Gabriella Kiss have been married for more than two decades, and their upstate studios are a stone’s throw from one another. Given their mutual affinity for nature — he treats wood in an organic way, and her subject matter includes plants and insects — it’s a bit surprising that they’ve never done a big project together. Until now, that is. “After the Storm,” a collection that makes its debut on Monday at Ralph Pucci International, is the couple’s first major collaboration. Although the show features solo designs by each (wooden tortoises and lily-pad tables by Kiss, and tree-mushroom-shaped wall shelves by Lehrecke, to name a few), their joint efforts include a series of pieces in white oak designed by Lehrecke with cast-bronze pulls (also mushroom-shaped) by Kiss. The long, lean chest of drawers shown here, which incorporates a branch from a dead oak tree, is $22,000 at Ralph Pucci International (44 West 18th Street).

headline: That Hideous Strength
abstract: It’s always sunny in Ireland.
lead_paragraph: The FT has an interesting article on problems with Irish GNP (not GDP) accounting; essentially, measured Irish income is being inflated by foreign companies with no real activity there that nonetheless find ways to make profits materialize in a low-tax jurisdiction. We sort of knew this was happening — that, for example, a lot of the apparent rise in productivity was just a shift to pharma companies that produce a lot of reported value-added but add little to the Irish economy. But the new ESRI report suggests that the problem is bigger than realized.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: College graduates who grew up in New York know what they are up against when they move back.
lead_paragraph: For young New Yorkers seeking their first postcollege apartment in the city, the setting of one’s childhood can cast a long shadow. The home where they grew up, whether it was a Classic 6 or far more modest, can leave a strong imprint.

headline: For Acclaimed Wagnerian, Less Excess
abstract: As Wagner’s 200th birthday approaches, one of his interpreters, the German conductor Christian Thielemann, is in the process of scaling back the excess in his own life.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, AUSTRIA — On a cool afternoon in March, a crowd filled the Festspielhaus here to see the German conductor Christian Thielemann lead the Dresden Staatskapelle in Wagner’s “Parsifal.” It was the dress rehearsal, three days before the production’s premiere as the opening-night attraction of the Salzburg Easter Festival and an early celebration of Wagner’s 200th birthday, which falls on Wednesday.

headline: Injuries Mount, but Girardi Still Believes
abstract: After a quarter of the schedule, the bruised Yankees lead the A.L. East, a testament to a manager, Joe Girardi, who saw more than a team of has-beens.
lead_paragraph: Joe Girardi was not supposed to have the kind of career he did. Not as a player with limited speed and power, from Peoria, Ill., who was undrafted until his senior year at Northwestern. Coaches had to believe in him along the way.

headline: A Trophy by a Tower
abstract: A 12,000-square-foot apartment created by combining 12 units on the 55th and 56th floors.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to tap into the trophy apartment craze that has gripped New York City’s luxury market, Joseph Moinian, the developer of the W New York Downtown Hotel and Residences, is bringing a $40 million duplex penthouse to the market.

headline: Where the I.R.S. Investigation May Go From Here
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling']
abstract: In the criminal investigation into how the Internal Revenue Service processed tax-exempt applications from conservative organizations, the critical issue may hinge on what agency officials told Congress rather than the underlying actions.
lead_paragraph: If Washington scandals have taught us anything, it is that the most trouble comes from the cover-up, not the conduct.

headline: A Fresh Approach to Soft-Shell Crabs
abstract: It’s hard to go wrong with a sauce of browned butter, preserved lemon and toasted almonds.
lead_paragraph: I once worked for an old-school chef who claimed that everything sold better with the name “amandine” (or “almondine” as it was called, incorrectly, on the menu).

headline: Balanchine’s Palm-Fringed Muse
abstract: Dance troupes pay tribute to Balanchine’s legacy in Los Angeles, where he enjoyed a creative spurt in the 1930s and ‘40s before heading to New York.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Unlike certain 20th-century artists who found themselves miserable in Hollywood — F. Scott Fitzgerald comes to mind — George Balanchine was fond of the place in the 1930s.  He loved the orange groves, Romanoff’s glamorous boîte and choreographing dances for movies.

headline: This Week’s Movies: ‘Star Trek Into Darkness,’ ‘Frances Ha’ and ‘Augustine’
abstract: Times critics on “Frances Ha,” “Augustine” and “Star Trek Into Darkness.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s video includes reviews of “Frances Ha,” “Augustine” and “Star Trek: Into Darkness.” Read all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: New in the Review
abstract: Changes to the best-seller lists and this column, Open Book, are new to the Book Review.
lead_paragraph: New in the Review

headline: In a Life of Moves and Commutes, the Wife’s the ‘Steadying Anchor’
abstract: Jeanne and Bob Potter learned to be a good team  and to work  together for crisis solutions by asking themselves, “now how do we solve this problem?”
lead_paragraph: Booming’s Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Are You My Father?
abstract: An unhappy woman discovers a distressing secret in Patrick McGrath’s novel.
lead_paragraph: At a party in 1960s Manhattan, a beautiful blonde named Constance meets a professor of poetry many years her senior. After a brief and not especially rigorous courtship, she agrees to become his wife. And, perhaps unsurprisingly, this psychologically fragile young woman — whose emotional and sexual frigidity is strongly signposted right from the start — seems trapped and unhappy, resisting her husband’s apparently good-hearted attempts to make her feel loved and secure. Meanwhile, across town, her sister, Iris — equally beautiful and blond, but with a disheveled, bohemian promiscuity and a deliciously described aptitude for “being not withholding with the cleavage” — is engaged in an affair with a man who plays the piano in the bar of a shabby hotel. When Constance is introduced to this married “lush” from Miami, his very presence so unsettles and (she imagines) repulses her, that she persuades him to break off his affair with Iris. Who promptly falls apart.

headline: Pop and Jazz Music
abstract: Nationwide pop and jazz listings.
lead_paragraph: CALIFORNIA

headline: Family Feuds
abstract: Brian Stelter recounts the intrigue, infighting and personal crises in the morning TV shows’ ratings wars.
lead_paragraph: Was Matt mean to Ann? How is Robin’s health? Is Charlie, that nocturnal man about town, ­really suited to rise-and-shine rigmarole? That most readers need no help in supplying context — the players here are Matt Lauer and Ann Curry on NBC’s “Today” show, Robin Roberts on ABC’s “Good Morning America” and Charlie Rose on whatever that daytime CBS program is called these days — is a testament to how personally so many millions of viewers take their morning TV. Specifically, it’s a toothbrush-holding thumbs-up to their watch-it-then-and-there network morning TV, an impressive distinction (not to mention a relic) in a DVR-time-shifted world of countless cable and Internet options.

headline: Mother of Children Slain in Nanny Case Is Pregnant
abstract: After two of their children were fatally stabbed in their Upper West Side home last fall, Kevin and Marina Krim announced on Facebook that Ms. Krim is expecting a baby.
lead_paragraph: Just over six and a half months after two of their children were found fatally stabbed in their Upper West Side apartment, Kevin and Marina Krim announced to the world this week that Ms. Krim is pregnant.

headline: Aberrations and Apparitions
abstract: The troubles of Tom Drury’s characters seem to stretch back into the inscrutable past, and out into an equally murky future.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a paragraph you might find a little strange: “Micah had ridden three times, got thrown once. He found horses hard to read. Their thoughts might go back to the beginning of horse time, or they might be afraid of a candy wrapper on the ground. He was wary of anything that big that bit.”

headline: Love Me. Leave Me Alone.
abstract: Fiona Maazel’s antic new novel examines the contradictory but concurrent urges for solitude and intimacy.
lead_paragraph: Loneliness can be divided into two types: transient and chronic. The first is more common than the second, meaning most people feel lonely sometimes and some people feel lonely most of the time. Transients aren’t interesting. Like hunger or fatigue, their loneliness comes and goes and isn’t defining: talk to them for an hour and they forget it. Chronics, though, are another story. They feel lonely playing games and being with family and moving through crowds and having sex. They can rack up thousands of Facebook friends and build a nation of Twitter followers, and it doesn’t matter. They know they are inescapably alone.

headline: When Words Sing
abstract: Recording an audiobook requires talent, discipline and a lot of coffee.
lead_paragraph: If you spend a lot of time with audiobooks, you start paying close attention to the people who read them, and probably develop a stable of favorites. Listeners know that the best narrators can make a good book take wing and a merely decent book grow more engaging. They can carry us through the dry parts of nonfiction, and might get us to try something we otherwise might not have. (That’s how I ended up enjoying Elmore Leonard’s “Stick” — I wanted to hear the great Frank Muller.) A mediocre reading? Well, I stop listening, and if it’s a book I really need to read, I switch to paper.

headline: Funny Talk
abstract: Stuck in traffic with David Sedaris.
lead_paragraph: Interstate 95 between New York and Washington, D.C., is no one’s idea of a pleasant piece of real estate, and that went double for a recent Sunday afternoon. Fuming at the stop-and-go jam, I jabbed at the radio, looking for something, anything, to divert me from the conga line to nowhere.

headline: An Audible Feast
abstract: A comprehensive collection of Ernest Hemingway’s novels, nonfiction and short stories.
lead_paragraph: In a foreshortened life that didn’t make 62, Ernest Hemingway got a lot down on paper. If, by his middle and later years, enough of it seemed self-­parodying and sometimes even mawkish, great swaths of it remain immortal — and not just the early work, as some critics would claim. Hemingway changed the look and sound of American speech on the printed page. But how did he get so much work done, the stories, the novels, the nonfiction (not to mention the thousands of letters he wrote), amid all that wasteful boozing and boasting, the depressions, the freakish accidents, the bouts of soaring blood pressure, the stark-awake and Seconal-stoked nights?

headline: Present at the Creations
abstract: From the birth of the Republican Party to the Spanish-American War, John Hay was a seminal 19th-century figure.
lead_paragraph: To understand the career trajectory of John Hay (1838-1905), one should imagine Colin Powell, George W. Bush’s first secretary of state, as having somehow served John F. Kennedy, 40 years earlier, as a personal assistant. Between Hay’s time as Abraham Lincoln’s secretary and Theodore Roosevelt’s top diplomat, the United States changed even more than it did between Kennedy and Bush. Hay saw the country disintegrate during his first months with Lincoln, but in his last years with Roosevelt he was helping to construct a democratic-­imperial colossus, getting America ready for the American century.

headline: In the West, Old and Bland May Win the Race
abstract: The San Antonio Spurs rode their championship brand of smooth and steady to beat the Warriors in six games, and will face Memphis in the Western Conference finals.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Say it again: they are too bland. Say it again: they are too old. Say it again: they are once again the favorites in the West.

headline: Humane Society
abstract: A novel and essay collection by Elinor Lipman showcase her urbanity and optimism.
lead_paragraph: What an easy, delightful way to spend a weekend, curled up on the sofa, a vase of daffodils unfurling in a warm room as rain streams down the window and, close at hand, two new books by Elinor Lipman. More addictive than that bag of peanut M&M’s: a collection called “I Can’t Complain: (All Too) Personal Essays.” More delicious than my cup of steaming cocoa: a new novel, “The View From Penthouse B,” a tender, funny story of two middle-aged sisters. Food was constantly on my mind as I read, because Lipman’s books are marvelous pantries. The pages of her 10th novel are replete with bouillabaisse and roast chicken, ripe with exotic fruits and rich with marzipan and macaroons.

headline: A Solo Trip Takes a Mother Home
abstract: Our filled-to-the-brim schedule went on for years. One day, I realized I’d had enough.
lead_paragraph: For years, I was lost in that delicate dance of working and raising young children. Breakfast at 7. Clothes picked out. Backpacks filled. Off to school. Drive to sports … or music lessons … or friends’ houses. Dinner. Homework. Bed. And in between babies’ naps and play dates and taxiing, I fit in my “real” job — online teaching and academic advising. Phew.

headline: Man of His Words
abstract: William Gaddis’s letters reveal the struggle and self-doubt behind the novels.
lead_paragraph: For an author who spent seven years writing “The Recognitions” (1955), a big, elbow-straining novel that most people didn’t read, and the next 20 years writing “J R” (1975), an almost-as-big novel that most people also didn’t read, it will come as no surprise that William Gaddis’s selected letters are consumed with worries about how little money his books are making, how few people understand them and how he plans to pay his bills until the next book comes along. As he writes his literary agent, Candida Donadio, in the mid-1970s, just when “J R” was failing to secure a much-needed paperback rights advance:

headline: ‘The Office’ Ends the Way It Began: Modestly
abstract: “The Office” ended on a modest, and slightly saccharine, note.
lead_paragraph: There’s a temptation for a long-running television comedy to go out with a high-concept twist — the “Seinfeld” trial, the “Newhart” bad dream, the “Frasier” plane ride. “The Office” was having none of that on Thursday night, when it closed its nine-season run on NBC with an episode that was in keeping with the show’s modest, utilitarian style.

headline: The Gun Report: May 17, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Maryland’s governor, Martin O’Malley, signed a bill that made the state’s gun laws among the strictest in the nation. Under the new legislation, anyone buying a handgun will have to submit fingerprints to obtain a license. The bill also bans 45 types of assault weapons; gun magazines will be limited to 10 bullets; gun ownership by people who have been involuntarily committed to a mental health facility will be banned; and police will be able to suspend the licenses of gun dealers who fail to comply with record-keeping obligations.

headline: Big Data Is Watching You
abstract: The digital-age transparency we’ve grown accustomed to may threaten the spirit of democracy, Evgeny Morozov warns.
lead_paragraph: How can you resist a book whose first chapter begins: “Have you ever peeked inside a friend’s trash can? I have.” Trash is like “one’s sex life,” the book continues, “the less said about it, the better.”

headline: Fiction Chronicle
abstract: New books by Rebecca Miller, Louisa Hall, Thea Goodman, MacKenzie Bezos and Naomi Alderman.
lead_paragraph: JACOB’S FOLLY  By Rebecca Miller  Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE PRICE OF INEQUALITY,  by Joseph E. Stiglitz. (Norton, $16.95.) The top 1 percent of Americans control some 40 percent of the nation’s wealth. This disparity, Stiglitz argues, isn’t the result of uncontrollable technological and social change; it stems from the unrestrained power of well-heeled interests. In this comprehensive counterargument to both neoliberalism and laissez-faire theories, the author, a Nobel laureate and economics professor at Columbia, examines the effects of inequality on the economy, democracy and globalization.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SLEEPWALKERS: How Europe Went to War in 1914,  by Christopher Clark. (Harper, $29.99.) A Cambridge professor offers a thoroughly comprehensible account of the polarization of a continent, without fixing guilt on one leader or nation.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “Happy, Happy, Happy” by Phil Robertson is No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list — the second best seller spawned by the reality show “Duck Dynasty.”
lead_paragraph: DUCK SEASON: Phil Robertson, the backwoods Louisiana patriarch and hunting entrepreneur who stars on the A&E reality show “Duck Dynasty,” rules the hardcover nonfiction list this week — his memoir, “Happy, Happy, Happy” (written with Mark Schlabach), is new at No. 1. It’s not the first best seller the show has spawned, either: “The Duck Commander Family,” by Phil’s son Willie and daughter-in-law Korie (with Schlabach again), is at No. 7 in its sixth week, riding the coattails of a season finale that drew 9.6 million viewers last month. “Happy, Happy, Happy” takes its title from Robertson’s catchphrase, and presents itself as a rustic guide to the good life — one chapter, “Redneck Caviar,” declares that “Rule No. 11 for living happy, happy, happy” is to “suck the head of a crawfish (you’ll want to do it again and again).” Part of the Robertsons’ charm is that they seem genuinely well adjusted, like the Waltons’ hairier cousins; every episode ends with a family prayer and a dinner prepared by Phil’s wife, Kay, whom he married when he was 16 and she was 15. “If you can find a nice, pretty country girl who can cook and carries her Bible,” he advises readers, “now, there’s a woman. She might even be ugly, but if she cooks squirrels and dumplings, then that’s the woman you go after.”

headline: Paid to Be Good
abstract: At the center of the plot lines in Jean Thompson’s novel is a philanthropist who wants to bribe people into virtue.
lead_paragraph: Linnea is a good kid from a home that lies somewhere in that wide gray zone between stable and chaotic, more dysfunctional than not — in other words, an emblematic American household. Her stepdad is “O.K.,” her younger half-brother is “pretty cool,” her stepsister is a mean girl and a bully; but Linnea loves her mom, and since she can’t remember her feckless, long-lost father, she doesn’t really miss him. Theirs is a typical blended family, so sadly representative that the nightmare that demolishes their relative peace and turns Linnea into an unreachable, volatile teenager is a school shooting — a signature American tragedy. Suffice it to say that the details of that awful day are blood-chilling and unbearable. As survivors go, Linnea is especially unlucky. She’s earned her trauma, and she wears it like a badge.

headline: Bigger Than Soccer Itself
abstract: Sportswriters used the soccer star David Beckham’s retirement to analyze his global appeal and to recall him as a brand as much as a player.
lead_paragraph: For a while, Thursday seemed like a perfect day for goodbyes. And in a way, the timing was perfect. It is, after all, graduation season. David Beckham kicked things off by announcing he would graduate to being just a global icon, minus the soccer-playing part. The Knicks seemed poised to move on to the golf-playing portion of their season with an elimination game against the Indiana Pacers, but decided to stick around, perhaps just to annoy people, including their doomsaying fans. But we did say goodbye to Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist’s perfection and any chance the N.B.A.'s Western Conference playoffs would be moderately fun to watch.

headline: Beautiful Creatures
abstract: Charles Kingsley’s 150-year-old morality fable reflects the contradictory impulses of the Victorian era.
lead_paragraph: The golden age of children’s literature — beginning in the 1860s with Charles Kingsley’s “Water-­Babies” and Lewis Carroll’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” and ending with the publication of the Winnie-the-Pooh books in the 1920s — earned its name by turning stories into luminous contact zones for adults and children. A million golden arrows point to Neverland, and you can reach Oz by passing through a gate studded with glittering emeralds. The heft of “Or else!” in cautionary tales about children going up in flames after playing with matches was replaced with the incandescent beauty of “What if?” Writers aspired to lure children into fantasy worlds that would leave them, as Frances Hodgson Burnett put it, “breathing quite fast with excitement, and wonder, and delight.”

lead_paragraph: CALIFORNIA

headline: Classical and Opera
abstract: Nationwide classical music listings.
lead_paragraph: ARIZONA

headline: Heading North, With an Appetite
abstract: It is early April, and another whale season is drawing to a close.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Cartwright teaches biology at California State University Channel Islands and has been studying trends in habitat use in humpback whale mother-calf pairs in Hawaiian waters. This is her final post.

headline: Anthologies That (Mostly) Stand the Test of Time
abstract: Reading collections of fiction from the 1940s and 1990s for classics and rediscovered gems.
lead_paragraph: Fiction anthologies don’t always stand the test of time. There is, surrounding prize anthologies especially, an inevitable whiff of Ozymandias — these were the best writers of their day, the editors proclaimed, yet who today has heard of most of them? But I love old anthologies partly for the light they cast on the flip side of the Ozymandias legend: sure, the king will crumble into dust just like the rest of us, but he still managed to create great works while he lived. And even if we’re not familiar with all of the writers in these volumes, they still wrote some pretty good stories in their time. Look on their works, ye Mighty, and celebrate.

headline: Smoke Permeates Nonsmoking Hotel Rooms
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Smoking and Tobacco']
abstract: Staying in a nonsmoking room in a hotel that allows smoking elsewhere does not prevent exposure to tobacco smoke, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: Staying in a nonsmoking room in a hotel that allows smoking elsewhere does not prevent exposure to tobacco smoke, a new study reports.

headline: A Toehold for China on Wall Street
abstract: The China Investment Federation, a new organization supporting Sino-American deal-making, celebrated the opening of its New York office on Thursday with officials from Wall Street and China.
lead_paragraph: Shaolin-style martial arts. A plate-spinning acrobat. Musicians playing the dizi, a Chinese bamboo flute, and the yangqin, a hammered dulcimer.

headline: The 5.5.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.

headline: Inside the New York Times Book Review: ‘The Golem and the Jinni’
abstract: This week, Helene Wecker discusses her novel “The Golem and the Jinni”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; David Carr talks about David Sedaris’s “Let’s Explore Diabetes With Owls”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Helene Wecker discusses her novel “The Golem and the Jinni”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; David Carr talks about David Sedaris’s “Let’s Explore Diabetes With Owls”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: The Monarch as a Work in Progress
abstract: Two new images of Queen Elizabeth II by Chris Levine, who has a show opening today in London.
lead_paragraph: A solo exhibition devoted to the art of Chris Levine opened at the Fine Art Society Contemporary in London today. Levine, who created pictures of the Olympic Stadium and the Shard skyscraper for our London Issue last year, is perhaps best known for his holographic portrait of Queen Elizabeth II (above, but you have to see it in person to fully appreciate its 3-D-ness). The work was produced as part of an assignment a decade ago by the Jersey Heritage to commemorate the Isle of Jersey’s 800 years of allegiance to the British crown. A similar picture that was ultimately chosen to be the organization’s commission was printed on a 100-pound note for the queen’s diamond jubilee last year.

headline: Making a Hard Choice for a Soft Landing
keywords: ['Love (Emotion)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Bipolar Disorder', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: If I had to change — and it was clear that something had to give — I wanted to become someone who could love and be loved, for the long haul.
lead_paragraph: In the romantic comedy “Silver Linings Playbook,” Pat emerges from a mental institution and finds new love with a dark-haired loose cannon named Tiffany. Pat is bipolar, a condition that reveals itself mainly in manic episodes of aggressive optimism. He runs for miles a day in a trash bag vest to make himself “sweat more,” fixates on his ex-wife and keeps score of his life’s silver linings.

headline: Home on the High Line
abstract: A growing number of developers cater to the needs of families looking to settle in West Chelsea, home to the popular High Line park.
lead_paragraph: In the whitewashed art galleries of West Chelsea, parents pushing baby carriages are now as commonly seen as quirky art students, while the recently opened Avenues: the World School has brought streams of well-heeled school children flowing through 10th Avenue.

headline: ‘Griner Effect’ May Change the Game at Baylor
abstract: The announcement by the basketball star Brittney Griner that she is a lesbian has altered an awkward relationship between Baylor University and its gay students.
lead_paragraph: From the day in 1983 when he graduated cum laude from Baylor University, Tim Smith fit the profile of a star alumnus. He went on to earn an M.B.A. at Harvard and to lead an information technology company with 300 employees. The business school at Baylor invited Mr. Smith to speak to classes about “entrepreneurial finance,” and he was named twice to its advisory board.

headline: State Legislator Facing Expulsion Says He’ll Resign
abstract: Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, who was accused of sexually harassing multiple female employees, said he would resign and instead run for New York City Council.
lead_paragraph: State Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, the once-powerful Brooklyn Democratic leader who has been accused of sexual harassment by several women, said on Friday that he would resign. But his offer only inflamed an uproar over his behavior because, a few words later, he said the resignation would not take effect for five weeks, and then he would run for a seat on the New York City Council.

headline: The Other Climate Science Gap
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: A flurry of discussion about public misperception of climate scientists’ views misses another science perception gap.
lead_paragraph: Much has been made this week of the gap between what the public thinks about the consensus among climate scientists over the human factor in global warming and the actual level of consensus. The discussion has centered on a new study reviewing how anthropogenic global warming was characterized in more than 12,000 climate science papers between 1991 and 2011. More than 97 percent of the papers stating a cause for warming, the authors found, pointed to humans. In contrast, surveys consistently show that Americans are pretty evenly divided when asked whether they think scientists agree that humans are causing global warming. (Read my e-mail exchange with two authors for more background.)

headline: I.R.S. Chief Apologizes Amid Scandal
abstract: Steven T. Miller, the acting I.R.S. commissioner who has resigned, called the agency’s actions “obnoxious,” but told the House Ways and Means Committee they were not motivated by partisanship.
lead_paragraph: Steven T. Miller, the acting I.R.S. commissioner who has resigned, called the agency’s actions “obnoxious,” but told the House Ways and Means Committee they were not motivated by partisanship.

headline: Perilous Fantasies Stoked by a Naïf
abstract: The Brooklyn Academy of Music presents a major new production of “The Mater Builder” starring John Turturro.
lead_paragraph: “The Master Builder,” Ibsen’s mysterious 1893 drama of ambition and erotic obsession, is staged far more rarely than the familiar (and generally less mystic) dramas of his major realist period. The Brooklyn Academy of Music is remedying the lack this spring with a major new production starring John Turturro as the title character, Halvard Solness, the dream-drunk architect who seems to bring about good luck and ill fortune in equal measures.

headline: Objects | Let’s Stay Together
abstract: This season’s menswear collections revealed a trend toward shirts and trousers designed to be worn at the same time.
lead_paragraph: To the relief of men everywhere who struggle with pairing their shirts to their pants, this season designers proposed the idea of matching sets. Whether in the form of head-to-toe prints, like Calvin Klein’s digitized floral jacket, shirt and shorts, or the monochromatic uniforms put forth by Dior or Prada, these are tops and bottoms that make the biggest statement when worn together. One less decision to make in the mornings!

headline: Heeding Master, Heart in Mouth
abstract: “It’s kind of like, you know, going to the lion’s den,” Dallas Akins says before performing Trinculo’s monologue from Shakespeare’s “Tempest” for the actress Kathleen Turner.
lead_paragraph: “It’s kind of like, you know, going to the lion’s den,” Dallas Akins says before performing Trinculo’s monologue from Shakespeare’s “Tempest” for the actress Kathleen Turner. “She seems like someone you wouldn’t want to mess with.”

headline: Hip-Hop Freshmen Rule the Roost
abstract: XXL Freshmen Live 2013, at the Best Buy Theater, isn’t really the rookie show it purports to be.
lead_paragraph: Every year since 2008, the hip-hop magazine XXL has anointed a group of up-and-coming rappers as part of its Freshman Class, giving over a month’s cover to a gaggle of relatively little-known faces. But as the Internet has become more vital in building hip-hop careers, these lists aren’t gambles so much as aggregates of established online wisdom.

headline: An Anarchic Genius, Remapping a Genre
abstract: Beginning Friday, IFC presents Mel Brooks’s groundbreaking satire of westerns.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good time to be the former Melvin Kaminsky of Williamsburg, Brooklyn — known to the world as Mel Brooks. Now 86, this Oscar-, Tony- and Emmy-winning writer, director, performer, producer and indefatigable comic force of nature will receive the American Film Institute’s Lifetime Achievement Award on June 6 in Los Angeles. “Mel Brooks: Make a Noise,” an “American Masters” portrait, will be shown on Monday on PBS (check local listings), and “History of Mel Brooks Part I,” a film retrospective, runs through July 21 at the IFC Center. (The program also includes David Lynch’s “Elephant Man” (1980), made under the Brooksfilms banner.)

headline: Stroke by Stroke, He Nailed Arcadia
abstract: One of the more sibilant names in American art belongs to the 19th-century landscape artist William Trost Richards.
lead_paragraph: One of the more sibilant names in American art belongs to the 19th-century landscape artist William Trost Richards (1833-1905), the best-known of the all-but-forgotten Pre-Raphaelite offshoot that sprang up briefly in the United States during the 1860s. The group avoided the flamboyant narratives of their English counterparts and the Romanticism of the Hudson River School. Instead, they focused on meticulously realistic renderings of nature.

headline: Telling the Truth on Fees, Warts and All
abstract: When discussing investment returns, Evercore Wealth Management factors in fees, taxes and inflation — and loses some potential clients in the process.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a sales pitch you don’t often hear: Let us invest your money. You can count on a return of 3 percent, though there is a chance it will be less. But we can guarantee this return for 10 years.

headline: Family Boredom, Upended by a Tutor
abstract: Opening on Tuesday is American Ballet Theater’s premiere of Frederick Ashton’s “A Month in the Country.”
lead_paragraph: Wedged between “Onegin” on Monday and “Don Quixote” on Friday is a gem, as American Ballet Theater continues its season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Opening on Tuesday is the company premiere of Frederick Ashton’s “A Month in the Country.” Choreographed in 1976, this ballet is a retelling of Turgenev’s play about a young tutor’s impact on a Russian household.
