headline: France’s Same-Sex Marriage Legislation Ruled Constitutional
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The court’s action cleared the way for President François Hollande to sign the legislation into law.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s constitutional high court on Friday rejected legal challenges to legislation that grants same-sex couples the right to marry and adopt children, clearing the legal text for passage into law by President François Hollande, who said he would do so on Saturday. The leftist majorities in both houses of Parliament passed the legislation last month amid mass demonstrations by opponents of same-sex marriage and an acrimonious political debate. Legislators from the right challenged the constitutionality of the law before the high court, the Constitutional Council, but it was widely expected that the legislation would be approved. In its ruling, the Constitutional Council found that the law would not create a “right to a child” for same-sex couples, a contention made by some opponents of the legislation. Those opponents say they fear the new law will open the way to medically assisted procreation for lesbian couples and the use of surrogate mothers, neither of which are legal practices in France.

headline: Single Yellow Fever Shot Offers Lifetime Protection, W.H.O. Says
abstract: One shot confers lifetime protection and the “booster shot” given at 10 years is no longer necessary, the World Health Organization said.
lead_paragraph: One yellow fever shot confers lifetime protection and the customary “booster shot” given at 10 years is no longer necessary, the World Health Organization announced Friday. Yellow fever vaccine is relatively safe but causes more dangerous side effects than many other vaccines and is therefore normally given only to healthy people who are at risk. The mosquito-borne disease, for which there is no cure, strikes about 200,000 people worldwide each year and kills about 30,000 of them. Cases are increasing as deforestation increases contact with forest mosquitoes and the monkeys that harbor the virus. Only nine cases have been found in the United States over the past 30 years, all in travelers returning from Africa or Latin America, but eight were fatal, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Dr. Thomas P. Monath, a yellow fever expert at the Harvard School of Public Health, said that the W.H.O. announcement made sense for almost all vaccine recipients, but that booster shots might still be needed for laboratory technicians working with the virus and for a few travelers who had one shot many years ago but whose immunity had waned.

abstract: Some conservatives are alleging that the I.R.S. targeted not just conservative groups, but also individual conservative taxpayers. But a handful of anecdotal data points are not worth very much in a country of 300 million people.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service is under fire for inappropriately targeting conservative groups that sought tax-exempt status. headline: A Look Back at Art Glass
abstract: A show at DDC will offer a retrospective of architectural-scale glass designs by resident artists at the Blenko Glass Company.
lead_paragraph: Most exhibitions taking place during the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York present the newest of the new, but “Big Color,” which opens at DDC on Friday, will offer a retrospective of architectural-scale glass designs created in the 1950s through the 1970s by resident artists at the Blenko Glass Company in West Virginia. Eight years in the making, the show is directed by Damon Crain, a 38-year-old former gallery owner and art consultant, who discovered art glass as a child in Ottawa and amassed a large collection of antique bottles by the age of 12. At DDC, he will show 120 pieces created by the Blenko designers Wayne Husted, Joel Philips Myers and John Nickerson. “Sometimes people aren’t sure how to live with the pieces,” he said, “but when they see them grouped together as a landscape, something clicks and it makes sense.” Prices range from $700 for a 22-inch cylindrical vase by Joel Myers to $5,500 for a 38-inch-tall decanter by Wayne Husted. DDC: 136 Madison Avenue (32nd Street), (212) 685-0800, cultureobject.com.

headline: Where Did the Kitchen Go?
abstract: Effeti USA’s first showroom opens at the Terminal Stores building, showcasing two new kitchen designs by the Buratti brothers, including one that keeps the ovens and fridge hidden.
lead_paragraph: The historic Terminal Stores building along 11th Avenue has taken another step toward becoming a Manhattan design destination with the addition of Effeti USA’s first showroom, which opens on Friday. Effeti, the 40-year-old Florentine manufacturer of high-end modern kitchens, is showcasing two of its newest designs: the BK1 and BK2, by the brothers Gabriele and Oscar Buratti. The BK1 kitchen is for those who want everything hidden: it can be configured so that doors conceal the ovens, the refrigerator and even a fireplace. The BK2 is made of matte-lacquered scraped oak, with doors that slide open to reveal colorful lacquered interior cabinets. “We have about 10 door-front styles, which are clean, modern and not fussy,” said Shelly McClure, a president of Effeti USA. “Every drawer and cabinet interior can be completely customized with dividers, and in a New York City kitchen, I think those details make a huge difference.” The showroom is at 645 West 27th Street (11th Avenue). Information: (212) 502-8916 or effetiusa.com.

headline: Honoring the Woodstock of the Cabaret Universe
abstract: Mabel Mercer and Bobby Short shared the stage at Town Hall in an epic concert on May 19, 1968; a concert on Thursday night paid tribute to these titans of cabaret.
lead_paragraph: For every musical genre there is usually an event that more people claim to have attended than could possibly have been there. In rock, the Woodstock Music and Art Fair in 1969 leads a long list of touchstones. Many would cite Benny Goodman’s Jan. 16, 1938, Carnegie Hall concert as Woodstock’s swing equivalent. For cabaret, a prime date is May 19, 1968, when Mabel Mercer and Bobby Short, who are now regarded as the field’s patron saints, shared the stage at Town Hall in a concert recorded by Atlantic Records.

headline: Budget Office Says Obama Plan Would Cut Deficit by $1 Trillion

headline: Picturing Him in Sequins and Capes
abstract: Steven Soderbergh’s HBO film “Behind the Candelabra” explores the relationship of the ostentatious pianist Liberace, played by Michael Douglas, and his lover Scott Thorson (Matt Damon).
lead_paragraph: When audiences looked at Liberace, they saw a bundle of contradictions wrapped in layers of fur, gold lamé suits and ostrich-feather capes. Here was a consummate entertainer who could make fans feel as if they were sitting next to him on his piano bench, yet who kept them at arm’s length. As much as his sexuality seemed to be on display — a detail that many close observers could detect in his flamboyant stage presence and outrageous costumes — it was something Liberace would never openly share with his adoring public.

headline: All Around, a Tapestry of Sound
abstract: In “Fama,” the composer Beat Furrer seamlessly blends notions from two disparate sources: Ovid’s depiction of a house in “Metamorphoses” and Arthur Schnitzler’s novella “Fraulein Else.”
lead_paragraph: “For each piece I want to create the material and the interrelationship of the intervals anew,” the prominent Swiss-Austrian composer Beat Furrer has said about his life’s work. How fitting, then, that “Metamorphoses,” Ovid’s seminal chronicle of the world and its myths, has proved a lasting influence for Mr. Furrer, who has spun notions from that epic into several works.

headline: Leaving the Met, but Not for Valhalla

No Valkyries or Rhinemaidens or gods were around, just stagehands assigned to take it apart and send it off to storage.

headline: Travel Essentials | The Fairgoer’s Guide to Venice’s Other Attractions
abstract: Where to eat, drink and shop when you’re in town for the Venice Biennale.
lead_paragraph: Some people live for Venice in May. For many, it means bottomless Prosecco on the warm, breezy esplanade of the Zattere; for others, it signifies the beginning of the Venice Biennale, one of the world’s most important contemporary art events, held once every two years. While many attendees come primarily to ponder esoteric installations at various pavilions, anyone in town for the big opening week should make to time to discover what’s new and classic in Venice, no matter when the party ends.

lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include vintage trains in Grand Central Terminal, security at the World Trade Center and an oversize sandwich at Katz’s Delicatessen.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company was a victim of online attacks earlier this week that slowed down The New York Times Web site and limited access to articles and other types of content.

headline: A Curious Cost/Benefit Analysis of a Park Fund-Raiser
abstract: The Great GoogaMooga festival has in the past left Prospect Park beaten up and scarred. It is back this weekend, and questions continue whether local residents end up losers in the enterprise.
lead_paragraph: 8:39 p.m. | Updated  In 2004, I spoke with Adrian Benepe, who was then the parks commissioner, about the desire of hundreds of thousands of Americans to protest the Iraq War and the Bush administration by marching through the streets of our city for a rally at Central Park’s Great Lawn.

headline: Seahawks’ Irvin Suspended for Four Games
abstract: Seattle Seahawks defensive end Bruce Irvin has been suspended for four games after the league announced he violated the N.F.L. policy on performance-enhancing substances.
lead_paragraph: Seattle Seahawks defensive end Bruce Irvin has been suspended for the first four games of the 2013 season after the league announced he violated the N.F.L. policy on performance-enhancing substances. (AP)

headline: The Role of a Dictionary
abstract: Good writing may exceed the boundaries suggested, if not intended, by dictionary definitions.
lead_paragraph: When it happens I feel as if I have stepped into a Far Side cartoon. I am a magazine editor, and the galley of an article will come back from a proofreader with a low-frequency word circled and this comment in the margin: “Does this word even exist?” or “Is this a real word?”

headline: At Least One Enchanted Evening
abstract: At Taiim Cellar, there are flights of wine and flights of fancy that come in the form of snacks, salads and sandwiches.
lead_paragraph: On a recent spring night, the folks at Taiim Cellar — a new Middle Eastern wine bar tucked into a corner of the suburban souk that is downtown Scarsdale — had opened their door wide to let in a soft breeze. Petals floated from trees in the nearby public garden. Tidy place settings awaited guests. The scent of caramelized sugar hovered near the tiny kitchen, and jazz guitar drifted through speakers. Who could resist the spell? Zamir Iosepovici and his partners, Erion Hasko and Altin Sinai, have transformed a shoe repair shop using exotic veneers and furnishings: toffee-colored leatherette banquettes, plush chocolate-brown ottomans, brunet wood alcoves, jet-black bar stools and a stylish wine rack of latticed wood and copper.

headline: Searching for the Blues
abstract: Juke joints, the Blues Highway and the Deep South.
lead_paragraph: Juke joints, the Blues Highway and the Deep South.

headline: A Blackhawk Hushes Doubters and Goal Horns
abstract: After a stellar regular season, Chicago goalie Corey Crawford is having his best postseason, earning his first series victory.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For most of Wednesday’s game against the Detroit Red Wings, Chicago Blackhawks goaltender Corey Crawford stood in his crease, watching the action on the other end of the ice. He tapped his stick against his blocker, then against a goal post. He shifted his weight from leg to leg. He skated in circles and took sips from his water bottle.

headline: Abortion Law in Arkansas Is Blocked by U.S. Judge
abstract: A ban on abortion at the 12th week of pregnancy is likely to be declared unconstitutional, a federal district judge said.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday temporarily blocked enforcement of one of the country’s most stringent abortion laws, an Arkansas ban on the procedure at the 12th week of pregnancy, saying the law was likely to be declared unconstitutional.

headline: Rights Group Says It Finds Proof of Torture in Syria
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture', 'Detainees', 'Solitary Confinement', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Human Rights Watch said Friday that visits to two Syrian security centers contained proof of widespread, arbitrary detentions and torture by the government of President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An international human rights group said Friday that visits to two Syrian security centers recently captured by rebel fighters contained proof of widespread, arbitrary detentions and torture by the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: The Harvey Weinstein Show
abstract: A new tradition at the Cannes Film Festival involves Harvey Weinstein previewing his slate for the year. Last year’s show included “Django Unchained,” “The Master” and “Silver Linings Playbook.” This year’s ranged from an auteur’s kung fu film to a biopic of Nelson Mandela.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — If there are lines separating art and commerce in the film world, they are obliterated annually at the Cannes Film Festival. The world’s most respected auteurs see their films have premieres in the Grand Palais, just above the Marché, the international film market in the basement, where distributors sell the rights to those same films as well as to B-movie action sequels like “Outpost III: Rise of the Spetsnaz” — whatever that is and wherever it’s rising from.

headline: Bye-Bye Bohemia
abstract: The Cedar Tavern site is becoming a beauty salon. Good riddance.
lead_paragraph: THE other evening I passed by 82 University Place in Greenwich Village, where a new European Wax Center was being constructed on the first floor, in a space once occupied by a fabled artists’ hangout, the Cedar Tavern.

headline: Dueling Budget Proposals
abstract: The President’s budget proposal for 2014 would reduce spending and combined with increased tax revenue, would reduce the deficit. But the Republicans’ and Democrats own plans are far apart.
lead_paragraph: The President’s budget proposal for 2014 would reduce spending and combined with increased tax revenue, would reduce the deficit. But the Republicans’ and Democrats own plans are far apart.

headline: Former I.B.M. Chief to Lead Bloomberg Privacy Review
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The company named Samuel J. Palmisano, former I.B.M. chief, to review its practices after complaints that Bloomberg reporters were snooping in data terminals.
lead_paragraph: In a continuing effort to address concerns that reporters at Bloomberg L.P.'s news division looked at terminal subscribers’ data, the company on Friday appointed Samuel J. Palmisano, the former chairman and chief executive of I.B.M., to review its privacy and data standards.

headline: Hard of Hearings
abstract: Don’t worry, people. If you missed the heated hearing on the I.R.S. held by the House Ways and Means Committee on Friday, we have a complete rundown.
lead_paragraph: Before Congress is finished with the Internal Revenue Service, there’s a serious danger some of us are going to wind up feeling sorry for the auditors.

headline: U.S.-Russian Diplomacy, With a Personal Touch
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry and Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, have found a common purpose in trying to negotiate a Syria settlement, even though positions have not changed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, clashed over Syria last year with Hillary Rodham Clinton, then the secretary of state, he called her hysterical, the sort of impolitic remark that showed just how sour their relationship had become.

headline: What the Woodpecker Told Me
abstract: Stuck without a lyric in sight, pondering the intricacies of a little bird’s brain, I suddenly thought about crazy Mary Sweeney.
lead_paragraph: Last September, in one of those early red-gold days of autumn, I was awakened by a tap-tap-tapping out in the backyard. A woodpecker was hammering at the old Box Elder out past the prickly pears near the back alley. I lay in bed awhile letting my thoughts circle:

headline: A Black Mound of Canadian Oil Waste Is Rising Over Detroit
abstract: Refining Canada’s petroleum-soaked oil sands produces petroleum coke, and the question of what to do with it has found at least one answer in Detroit, where a large coke pile covers an entire city block.
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, Ontario — Assumption Park gives residents of this city lovely views of the Ambassador Bridge and the Detroit skyline. Lately they’ve been treated to another sight: a three-story pile of petroleum coke covering an entire city block on the other side of the Detroit River.

headline: The Salacious and the Sober Collide, Illustrating Hurdles for Italy’s Government
abstract: On the same day, a young Moroccan woman testified in a sex scandal involving former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, and Italy’s new prime minister announced the suspension of a reviled tax.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A young Moroccan woman embroiled in a sex scandal with former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi took the witness stand on Friday, recounting wild parties in which an attractive politician once dressed up as a nun and performed a striptease for Mr. Berlusconi.

headline: Trying Unlikely Comeback, Ex-Iran President Strikes Chord With Public
abstract: Though once widely reviled, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and his reputation as an economic pragmatist and modernizer seem to be resonating with the Iranian public.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — There was a time when Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani seemed to have it all. A founder of the Islamic Revolution, he headed a family empire that owned the second biggest Iranian airline, Mahan, had a near monopoly on the lucrative pistachio trade and controlled the country’s largest private university, Azad.

headline: Investor Group Wants Real-Time Access to Proxy Votes
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission was asked  to intervene after a main company that provides real-time tallies of shareholder votes stopped giving the information to proposal sponsors.
lead_paragraph: The Council of Institutional Investors asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to intervene after Broadridge, the main company that provides real-time tallies of shareholder votes, stopped giving the information to the groups that sponsor proposals. At the behest of the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, a group that lobbies for Wall Street, Broadridge stopped giving shareholder sponsors real-time updates. The move drew fire from some who say the ability to obtain real-time votes helps both sides devise their campaigns.

headline: Angelina Jolie’s Disclosure
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Breast Cancer', 'Mastectomy', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Editorials', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: Public awareness is raised, as are concerns about insurance coverage for preventive mastectomies.
lead_paragraph: Angelina Jolie’s revelation on The Times’s Op-Ed page that she had a double mastectomy to reduce her risk of breast cancer greatly raises public awareness of the genetic testing she used, as well as concerns about insurance coverage for this kind of testing. Ms. Jolie had a family history of cancer and tested positive for genetic flaws in the BRCA1 gene, which indicates an elevated risk for breast and ovarian cancer. Her doctor estimated that she had an 87 percent chance of developing breast cancer.

headline: Toronto Mayor Is Besieged by Questions of Crack Use
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A video being shopped by two men with drug connections apparently shows Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto smoking a crack pipe.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto has long been dogged by controversy over his often boorish behavior and less than diligent attention to work. On Friday, Mr. Ford faced his greatest political test following two reports that he is seen in a video apparently using crack cocaine.The Toronto Star and the Web site Gawker reported on Thursday night that they were shown the video on a smartphone by two men who were trying to sell it. The Star, which said that two of its reporters had watched the recording, reported that it was made by a man who said he had sold crack to Mr. Ford.

headline: Sales Taxes and the Internet
keywords: ['Sales and Excise Taxes', 'E-Commerce', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Rationality and fairness are the fundamental issues.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-one Republicans voted with 46 Democrats (and 2 Independents) recently to pass the Marketplace Fairness Act, a long-overdue bill allowing states to require online retailers to collect sales taxes and remit them to the state where the customer lives. Will the House be so rational? It’s a long shot.

headline: Unforgivable Conduct in Albany
abstract: The Assembly should expel Vito Lopez and remove Sheldon Silver from the leadership.
lead_paragraph: The sordid details of how a once-powerful Brooklyn politician pawed, groped and taunted young women on his staff are more than an indictment of one politician, Assemblyman Vito Lopez. They provide a galling picture of the way Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker and one of New York’s top legislative leaders, failed to provide an environment in which young women could work without fear of being sexually assaulted by a bully like Mr. Lopez.

headline: Cracking the Brand-New 1940 Census
abstract: A rich trove of archives and resources at the New York Public Library cross-references names and addresses with the long-awaited 1940 data, and the results are eye-opening.
lead_paragraph: All pack rats should be as creative as the New York Public Library, the obsessive collector of the most complete sets of bulky, outdated telephone directories in the world. Skeptics in the cellphone era might wonder why. But the library’s Milstein Division, a rich trove of national and local history archives and free genealogy resources, digitalized old New York phone directories to create a free Web site. It cross-references residents’ names and addresses with the long-awaited 1940 census data made public last year, which includes the person’s age, income, education, job and migration record.

headline: Europe’s Economics Chief Tries to Peel Off ‘Mr. Austerity’ Label
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']

headline: At Preakness, Orb’s Challengers Include Childhood Friend
abstract: The Kentucky Derby winner Orb and one of his Preakness rivals, Departing, were yearlings together in Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — They shared the same paddock and gamboled in the same Kentucky bluegrass as weanlings and yearlings. Orb hit the ground first at Claiborne Farm, with Departing tumbling out of his mother a month later. Now 3 years old, the two horses will be reunited Saturday in the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Pettitte Goes to 15-Day Disabled List
abstract: After failing to complete five innings in his latest start, against the Mariners on Thursday, the Yankees’ Andy Pettitte was added to the team’s list of injured players.
lead_paragraph: The mounting list of injured Yankee stars added another member on Friday when Andy Pettitte was placed on the 15-day disabled list with a strained trapezius muscle.

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A comprehensive report on drug policy in the Americas released Friday by a consortium of nations suggests that the legalization of marijuana, but not other illicit drugs, be considered among a range of ideas to reassess how the drug war is carried out.

headline: Long Before Crack Cocaine Allegations, Toronto Mayor Was a Source of Controversy
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Politics and Government', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Questions have been raised about Mayor Rob Ford’s conduct, temperament and public statements since his early days as a member of the Toronto City Council.
lead_paragraph: As our colleague Ian Austen reports, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto angrily dismissed allegations on Friday that he had used crack cocaine in a 90-second cellphone video that is being peddled to United States and Canadian news organizations for more than $100,000.

headline: Immigrant Workers Give New Direction to Los Angeles Unions
abstract: Maria Elena Durazo, a labor leader, has pushed for safeguards for workers, including those not authorized to work in the United States, and an overhaul of immigration policy.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As the head of the hotel workers’ union here in the 1990s, Maria Elena Durazo negotiated a contract with provisions rarely seen by labor unions: The jobs of workers who were deported or lost authorization to work in the United States would be held open for two years, with the same pay.

headline: N.B.A. Concussion Policy Becomes Major Factor in Series
abstract: The N.B.A.’s protocols on concussion recovery will affect when Pacers guard George Hill can return to the court.
lead_paragraph: Professional basketball players do not routinely collide at full speed, or fire small objects at one another with extreme velocity. They do not tackle, ram or body-check. Their heads may rise to startling heights, but they are not in harm’s way as often as the skulls of football, hockey or baseball players.

headline: Not Just Another Face in the Crowd
abstract: A crunchy Saturday puzzle by Martin Ashwood-Smith.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you ever have, even for the briefest instant, a slight feeling of dread when you see all that wide open white space in a quad stack? I do, especially on a Saturday puzzle, because I know I’m in for quite a tussle between the 15-letter entries and the crossings. Oh, and don’t forget the ramped-up, cryptic nature of the clues. Did I mention that this is Saturday?

headline: Energy Exports Are Good!
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Natural Gas', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Why is the Dow Chemical Company lobbying to keep a lid on them?
lead_paragraph: What first caught my eye was the op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal. Published in late February, it was written by Andrew N. Liveris, the chairman and chief executive of the Dow Chemical Company. Liveris, an Australian, has become quite the Washington player in recent years. Among other things, he heads President Obama’s efforts to revive manufacturing.

headline: After Many Miles in a Chevy Van, a Rough Gig in a Place Called Hindsight
abstract: After winning over a Webster Hall crowd, the band Wild Cub said on Facebook: “Thank you New York. You gave us two sold out shows in one week, we gave you half our equipment.”
lead_paragraph: There are joyless pockets of New York City that should be renamed Hindsight, based on the stories from visitors. “In Hindsight,” these tales begin, rarely ending well.

headline: Tortorella Stays Positive Despite the Rangers’ Latest Overtime Failure

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Rangers Coach John Tortorella insists his players’ psyche has not been affected by the team’s 0-3 overtime record in the playoffs.

abstract: The deal between Extell and Related Companies would make Related the largest landowner in the 50-block Hudson Yards district on the Far West Side of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a lot of love lost between the rival developers Gary Barnett of Extell and Stephen M. Ross of Related Companies.

headline: Images From Connecticut Train Derailment
abstract: Commuters on the trains that collided late Friday, and local reporters, began posting images from the scene almost as soon as the crash occurred.
lead_paragraph: Two Metro-North trains collided after a derailment near Bridgeport, Conn., on Friday, injuring at least 60 people, five of them critically, according to Governor Dannel P. Malloy. Commuters on the trains, and local reporters, began posting images from the scene almost as soon as the collision occurred.

headline: Schools Chancellor to Strike Back at Candidates Critical of Mayor’s Policies
abstract: Dennis M. Walcott, in a speech to administrators, will defend Michael R. Bloomberg’s record on issues like charter schools against harsh campaign criticism from Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Charter schools would no longer be allowed space in traditional school buildings. Neighborhood school boards would be given more oversight over superintendents and principals. Cellphones, long considered contraband in schools, would again be permitted past the door.

headline: Merkel Offers a Peek Into Her Private Life
abstract: In her rise to power, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has kept her private life private, but she has loosened up during the election campaign.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Throughout her rise to power and as Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel has kept her personal life strictly private, to an extent that is hard to achieve in the age of social media.

headline: Nathaniel Hawthorne’s Funny Civil War
abstract: How the writer alienated himself from his pro-war neighbors in Concord, Mass.
lead_paragraph: In early 1863, Nathaniel Hawthorne wrote a letter to his friend Henry Bright in England. In it, he informed Bright that he had become a pariah in his close-knit community of Concord, Mass. “The war-party here do not look upon me as a reliably loyal man, and, in fact, I have been publicly accused of treasonable sympathies.” What had the silver-haired author of “The Scarlet Letter” done to upset his neighbors?

headline: Newark Mayor Discloses $1.3 Million in Speaking Fees
abstract: In forms filed this week in preparation for his campaign for a United States Senate seat, Mayor Cory A. Booker reported being paid $1,327,190 for 96 speeches since 2008.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Mayor Cory A. Booker has turned his office into a platform for national celebrity, and he has been richly compensated for it, taking in more than $1.3 million in speaking fees over the last four and a half years.

headline: Kuroda Stifles Toronto Over 8 Innings
abstract: The Yankees’ Hiroki Kuroda limited the Blue Jays to two hits over eight shutout innings to raise his record to 6-2.
lead_paragraph: On any given day this season, the Yankees’ clubhouse can  be crowded with reporters, team employees and, most recently, a host of players rotating back and forth from the minor leagues in place of Alex Rodriguez, Derek Jeter and Mark Teixeira. Almost each day there is a new face to make even the most slightly recognizable player seem like a longtime regular.

headline: Trial Weighs Importance of Arrests in Police Stops
abstract: A judge is determining the constitutional significance of so-called hit rates, which have long been at the center of the public debate over stop-and-frisk tactics in New York City.
lead_paragraph: It was only a single word — “yes” — but it stands as one of the more interesting acknowledgments in two months of testimony in the federal trial over the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk tactics.

headline: 5th Ave. Poker, With $25,000 Chips and an F.B.I. Ace in the Hole
abstract: Recordings made over the last two years provide a glimpse into the shadowy, and illegal, world of high-stakes gambling in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The all-night games were held in rarefied settings like a suite at the Plaza Hotel. One pink chip was worth $25,000. Masseuses were on hand to help relieve the tension, while the players were fueled by food and drink. And the stakes climbed into the stratosphere, with as much as $2 million on the table to be lost or won.

headline: Albert Seedman, Chief of Detectives in New York for Short, Tumultuous Time, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Seedman was the New York Police Department’s chief of detectives for only 13 months, but he helped modernize and restructure the way detectives and patrol officers did their jobs.
lead_paragraph: Albert Seedman, the New York Police Department’s chief of detectives in the early 1970s who became something of a celebrity as the savvy, cigar-chomping personification of the tough-guy cop while modernizing a tradition-bound force, died on Friday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 94.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Full Bloom
abstract: A focus of fashion is the length of the leg, seen in tights or just bare.
lead_paragraph: A focus of fashion is the length of the leg, seen in tights or just bare.

headline: In Document, Lhota Puts His Worth at $13 Million
abstract: With a fortune of at least $13 million, Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican candidate for mayor, is significantly wealthier than his Democratic rivals.
lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor, has amassed a fortune of at least $13 million from real estate and investments, a new document shows.

headline: McIlroy Charts a New Path, Again
abstract: Rory McIlroy, on the heels of several blockbuster endorsements, appears to be forming his own management company, in which his father, Gerry, will figure prominently.
lead_paragraph: Three years after he won his first PGA Tour title, Rory McIlroy returned last month to Quail Hollow, the scene of that inaugural victory, as the recently dethroned world No. 1 in search of his game and his first win of the new season. The simplicity that characterized McIlroy’s swing thoughts and his life in 2010 was a bygone memory, so he was asked what sticks out in his mind when he looks back at the 20-year-old who won for the first time on tour.

headline: Kennett Love, Times Correspondent in 1950s, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Love was in Iran in 1953 when the C.I.A. plotted against the government, and he also reported on the Suez Canal crisis of 1956.
lead_paragraph: Kennett Love, a foreign correspondent for The New York Times who covered tumultuous events in the Middle East in the early days of the cold war, died Monday in Southampton, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: As Obama Pushes Overhaul of Food Aid, Panels in Congress Favor Smaller Changes
keywords: ['Farm Bill (US)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Food Aid']
abstract: After the Obama administration proposed moving the international food aid program out of the Agriculture Department, the Congressional Agriculture Committees took lesser actions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In response to the Obama administration’s plans to overhaul the nation’s international food aid program, which provides food to disaster-stricken regions, Congress this week began laying the groundwork for its own changes.

headline: Witnesses to Horse Racing’s Two Sides
abstract: Jimmy McCue, a photographer, has chronicled racing’s winning moments, while the equine ambulance driver Joe Miller has witnessed the darker side.
lead_paragraph: Joe Miller and Jimmy McCue work in different environments at the same racetrack. McCue, 66, has been a staff photographer at Pimlico Race Course since 1970. Miller, 50, has been the track’s equine ambulance driver since 1997, though he has worked there since 1981.

headline: In Response to Sex Assaults, Military to Review Staffing
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel signed an order that requires the military to review and recertify personnel assigned to programs for preventing sexual assault and assisting victims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel signed an order on Friday requiring the military to review and recertify each person assigned to programs for preventing sexual assault and assisting victims.

headline: Ken Venturi, U.S. Open Golf Champion and Broadcaster, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Venturi won the 1964 United States Open, nearly collapsing from heat exhaustion. He later became a chief golf analyst for CBS Sports, where he worked for 35 years.
lead_paragraph: Ken Venturi, who won the 1964 United States Open while nearing collapse from heat exhaustion and who was later the longtime chief golf analyst for CBS Sports, died on Friday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Idaho: Uzbek Man Pleads Not Guilty to Charges of Supporting Terrorism
abstract: An Uzbek man, Fazliddin Kurbanov, pleaded not guilty to three federal terrorism charges that accuse him of providing support to a terrorist group in Uzbekistan.
lead_paragraph: An Uzbek man pleaded not guilty on Friday to three federal terrorism charges that accuse him of providing support to a terrorist group in Uzbekistan. Wearing slippers and yellow and white striped prison garb, the defendant, Fazliddin Kurbanov, entered the federal courtroom in Boise in shackles and spoke primarily through a Russian interpreter. Federal agents arrested Mr. Kurbanov, 30, a truck driver, on Thursday after an extensive investigation into his activities in Idaho and Utah over the last nine months. A federal grand jury has charged him with providing support to a terrorist group in Uzbekistan. He is scheduled to appear Tuesday for a detention hearing.

headline: Subpoena for Head of Benghazi Panel
abstract: Representative Darrell Issa issued a subpoena to Thomas R. Pickering, a retired diplomat, to force him to appear at a deposition to answer questions about his panel’s report.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee on Friday issued a subpoena to the chairman of the independent panel that investigated the attacks last year on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya. The congressman, Darrell Issa of California, issued the subpoena to Thomas R. Pickering, a retired diplomat, to force him to appear at a deposition Thursday to answer questions about his panel’s report. Mr. Issa and other Republicans have criticized the report, saying it did not hold senior State Department officials accountable. Mr. Pickering and Adm. Mike Mullen, the retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who also led the five-member panel, have agreed to testify at a public hearing, but they have balked at a private deposition.

abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Starz) BRAVE (2012) Kelly Macdonald lends her voice to Pixar’s first female protagonist: Merida, above, a Scottish princess and ace archer crowned by a mass of wild and woolly persimmon-hued tendrils and riding a high-stepping Clydesdale, Angus. Her mother, Queen Elinor (Emma Thompson), wants her to behave more like a lady. The queen has also beckoned local clan leaders to bring their sons by the castle to compete for her daughter’s hand, causing a furious Merida to rebel. When her defiance doesn’t work, she seeks help from a witch (Julie Walters), who casts a spell that sidelines the queen — and eventually prompts Merida to embark on a mission to rescue her mother and, in the process, save her family. Entering “the big business of little girls,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, “hasn’t been easy, to judge by the deep divide between the movie’s seductive pictorial splendor and its discouragingly uninspired script by Mark Andrews, Steve Purcell, Brenda Chapman and Irene Mecchi. (Ms. Chapman, the first woman hired to direct a Pixar feature, either left or was removed from “Brave” and now shares directing credit with Mr. Andrews.)” Still, “the animation, particularly in the outdoor scenes, can be transfixing with the photorealist details — every blade of grass and each hair in Angus’s mane looks perfectly individuated — blending seamlessly with the cartoon impressionism,” Ms. Dargis wrote, adding: “The association of Merida with the natural world accounts for some of the movie’s most beautifully animated sequences, and in other, smarter or maybe just braver, hands it might have also inspired new thinking about women, men, nature and culture.”

headline: A Racer Known to Many, and Now a Mystery
abstract: Long before he came to Nascar, Dick Trickle was a renowned driver in the Midwest. He died Thursday at age 71 from a self-inflicted gunshot wound.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.C. — Dick Trickle had a name that was so easy to mock that anchors on ESPN’s “SportsCenter” made him famous by mentioning him regularly during the network’s auto racing reports in the 1990s. If that playful teasing ever overshadowed what he accomplished as a short-track racer in the Midwest and as a mentor to some of Nascar’s best, it never diminished Trickle’s impact on the sport.

lead_paragraph: Ivorie Manning, an N.B.A. shooting consultant, highlights the key components of a good jumper, using sharp shooters from the N.B.A. playoffs.

headline: Restoring the Rockaways
abstract: The city of New York is investing $140 million to restore Rockaway Beach.
lead_paragraph: The city of New York is investing $140 million to restore Rockaway Beach.

headline: Racing the Clock in the Rockaways
abstract: Hurricane Sandy left the parks department with the onerous task of having the beach ready for a Memorial Day weekend opening.
lead_paragraph: In mid-March, a waterline still marked the wall in the basement of the Robert Moses-era parks building at Beach 97th Street in Rockaway Beach, Queens. It was Hurricane Sandy’s calling card, a vestige of the wall of seawater that broke down doors and gushed through the interior, destroying mechanical equipment and soaking Sheetrock, more than four months earlier.

headline: Rebuilding the Coastline, but at What Cost?
keywords: ['Coast Erosion', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Beaches', 'Coastal Areas']
abstract: Beach nourishment projects will restore shorelines but require expensive upkeep and affect ecosystems; federal taxpayers will foot the bill.
lead_paragraph: When a handful of retired homeowners from Osborn Island in New Jersey gathered last month to discuss post-Hurricane Sandy rebuilding and environmental protection, L. Stanton Hales Jr., a conservationist, could not have been clearer about the risks they faced.

headline: Racing to Save a Champion
abstract: Rachel Alexandra, who in 2009 became the first filly to win the Preakness Stakes in 85 years, nearly died from an infection she developed after giving birth.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Alexandra, who in 2009 became the first filly to win the Preakness Stakes in 85 years, nearly died from an infection she developed after giving birth.

headline: Looking Beyond the Mediterranean
abstract: With Red Hen, the chef Shelley Deproto moves away from her usual style and opens her menu, saying “If it’s Cuban one day, it’s Cuban.”
lead_paragraph: On the last day of 2011, the chef Shelley Deproto packed up her kitchen and closed Lupo, the Mediterranean-style restaurant she had owned and operated in Chester since 2003. Her new venture, Red Hen Restaurant in Old Saybrook, opened last fall. The name is borrowed from a children’s book and evokes no particular culinary culture. This is intentional. After 8 ½ years of hewing to Mediterranean cuisine, Ms. Deproto wants to take inspiration where she finds it.

headline: Keep an Eye Out for the Sliders
abstract: Five.Five 2, with its host of charming dining rooms, offers outstanding dishes and makes a good first impression.
lead_paragraph: Five.Five 2, a restaurant named for its address on North Country Road in St. James, makes a good first impression. The cheery copper-topped bar has a fireplace, and the rabbit warren of dining rooms is charming: one is small and cozy, another light and airy, and a third enhanced by bright colored paintings.

headline: A Long Menu, and Swift Servers
abstract: Chung Sol Bat is a restaurant a short distance from the Boston Market in Edison, but it has very different offerings.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Market on Route 1 North in Edison serves fast, casual food, with choices that include chicken and lots of vegetables. But turn in before you reach that chain outpost and head for the strip mall behind it, and you will discover Chung Sol Bat.

headline: A First Fest for Local Tastes
abstract: The inaugural Montclair Food and Wine Festival takes place on June 1 and 2 at the Woman’s Club of Upper Montclair, with a “grand tasting” the first night and a gala dinner the second.
lead_paragraph: Melody Kettle said she began planning the Montclair Food and Wine Festival in 2011, after writing about food events in towns like Summit and Madison on her blog, Hot From the Kettle. “I started wondering,” she said, “Why don’t we have our own festival?”

headline: In a Painter’s Home, Works From Local Closets
abstract: Local collectors and artists provide most of the items on display in the John F. Peto Studio Museum in Island Heights, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Works by the artist John F. Peto are in the permanent collections of major museums including the Newark Museum, the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. But even locals in the small, waterfront town of Island Heights, where he lived and worked from 1889 until his death in 1907, are not always familiar with his name.

headline: A Tale of College, Romance and the Big Game
abstract: “Good News!” a 1927 musical comedy adapted Jeremy Desmon and being presented at the Goodspeed Opera House, combines all the trademarks of shows from that era.
lead_paragraph: If college rankings had been around in the Roaring ’20s, Tait College would belong at the bottom. On this campus, football comes first with the guys, football players come first with the coeds — yes, that’s what female students were called back then — and school events usually culminate in ecstatic eruptions of tap dance.

headline: An Old Technology, Transformed
abstract: “Artists in the Archives,” at the Greenburgh Public Library, revitalizes the antiquated card catalogs by filling them with art.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Carla Rae Johnson riffled through an array of cards in one of the narrow wooden drawers of a card catalog at the Greenburgh Public Library. But she wasn’t doing research, and the cards she was examining had nothing to do with books. She was inspecting her installation, the “Alternet,” a 50-drawer card catalog that she repurposed to hold more than 15,000 three-by-five-inch works of original visual art.

headline: Another Dark Corner of the Holocaust
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Photography', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Art']
abstract: An exhibition about the history of the hard-hit community of Greek Sephardic Jews is at the Tolerance Center in Glen Cove, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The photographs of proud Greek Jewish families in the early 1900s and the richly decorated artifacts from centuries past on display at the Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center of Nassau County reflect a vibrant community. But images from the 1940s, of sobbing people on their way to Nazi death camps and of postwar commemorations of the murdered, document a darker era.

headline: First, Four Lattes. Then, the Ballet.
abstract: Patsy Tarr and her husband, Jeff, have two espresso machines and drink four lattes each to start the day.
lead_paragraph: Ballet often figures into a Sunday for Patsy Tarr, 65, the philanthropist and publisher who runs the 2wice Arts Foundation, which specializes in digital and print projects uniting dance and design. Her latest endeavor, an interactive iPad app in which Tom Gold, a former New York City Ballet soloist, dances with an image of himself to a score by Charles Yang, will be available in mid-June. She lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Jeff, 68, a former Wall Street risk arbitrageur who runs the JCT Foundation, and their Shih Tzu, Coco. Their children, Jeff Tarr Jr. and Jennie Tarr Coyne, and five grandchildren all live nearby.

headline: A Comedian for Life
abstract: D. F. Sweedler, 61, has become a mainstay at the Comic Strip on the Upper East Side, having performed at the club since it opened in 1976.
lead_paragraph: The wall of fame at the Comic Strip on the Upper East Side of Manhattan is lined with publicity shots of comedy legends like Eddie Murphy, Chris Rock, Adam Sandler and many others whose careers have roots at the club. There is even Jerry Seinfeld’s audition sign-in sheet from his first appearance in the late 1970s.

headline: A Cloudy Revelation From a Mayoral Candidate
abstract: Christine C. Quinn’s recent disclosure that she had suffered from bulimia in her 20s was part of an effort to deepen her image with voters, but the effect is unclear.
lead_paragraph: The current issue of Vogue features a portrait of the mayoral contender Christine C. Quinn standing on the steps of the New York Public Library with a windswept lift to her pageboy, wearing beige stilettos and a cobalt blue sheath designed by Carolina Herrera.

abstract: Eastern Parkway, which extends a little over two miles in Brooklyn, was mapped out in 1868 by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux.
lead_paragraph: Looking down Eastern Parkway from Grand Army Plaza’s Memorial Arch, past the Brooklyn Public Library, past the Botanic Garden and McKim, Mead and White’s Brooklyn Museum, you might be reminded of Paris and the broad avenues that radiate from the Arc de Triomphe. Mapped out in 1868 by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, Eastern Parkway extends a little over two miles, from Prospect Park to Ralph Avenue.

keywords: ["Great Depression (1930's)", 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In “City of Ambition,” Mason B. Williams explores what drove a patrician Democrat and a street-smart Republican to revive New York City from the Great Depression.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Stieglitz titled his stark 1910 photograph of the percolating Lower Manhattan skyline “City of Ambition.” Fittingly, Mason B. Williams borrows the name for a book about two transformative figures whose political and civic genius helped New York deliver on that promise.

lead_paragraph: Q. Can you tell me anything about the African-American holiday Pinkster that used to be celebrated in New York?

headline: North Korea Reportedly Launches Short-Range Missiles
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: The tests broke the recent relative silence from the North, but the move was much less provocative than what had been feared earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea launched three short-range missiles into the sea off its east coast on Saturday, the South Korean Defense Ministry said. The tests broke the recent relative silence from the North, but the move was much less provocative than what had been feared in the tense weeks after the country’s nuclear test in February.

lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Why My Heart Aches When Worthless Cars Go to the Crusher
abstract: Worthless cars get crushed for scrap all the time, but sometimes it’s hard to say goodbye.
lead_paragraph: Expanding upon my previous rumination about today’s worthless cars becoming tomorrow’s relatively pricey classics, I had another experience involving a car that isn’t worth a whole lot that was dumped, whole, into a line of cars to be crushed at a scrap yard on the outskirts of Denver.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir:  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh has promised a package of 7 billion rupees, or $128 million, over a span of five years to promote sports in Jammu and Kashmir, according to a Press Trust of India report in The Business Standard. With the funding, the state proposes to build hockey and soccer grounds, as well as an indoor stadium in every town with a population of more than 50,000, the state’s sports minister said Friday.

headline: The Liquidationist Urge
abstract: It’s real — just ask Kinsley.
lead_paragraph: I’m stayed out of the fracas over Mike Kinsley’s somewhat bizarre attack on my recent writings; Mark Thoma, Brad DeLong, and Dan Drezner have it covered. And I owe a debt to Kinsley, who hired me to write for Slate way back when, letting me establish a reputation as someone who could write short-form pieces about economics for a broad audience, which led down a path to, well, you know.

headline: Almost 80, He Continues the Ruckus
abstract: The filmmaker Ken Jacobs, inspired by action painting and his years as a cinema professor, is seeing his work celebrated as he turns 80.
lead_paragraph: There are artists who burn out at 30 and others who, accelerating as they mature, begin to seem like forces of nature. One such force is Ken Jacobs, who turns 80 next Saturday — an occasion marked by a recent tribute at the Museum of Modern Art, with another next weekend at Anthology Film Archives.

headline: Is It Time to Bag the Plastic?
abstract: Some cities have done away with the plastic shopping bag, but much of America seems more addicted than ever.
lead_paragraph: IN my New York City apartment, the kitchen drawers, the coat closet, even the wine rack are overflowing with a type of waste that is rapidly disappearing elsewhere — the used plastic shopping bag.

headline: The Government’s Worst Face
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Many Americans, left and right, feel ambivalence not just toward the I.R.S. but toward the federal government and the outsize part it plays in our daily lives.
lead_paragraph: THE reported targeting by the Internal Revenue Service of conservative organizations seeking tax-exempt status has led some to revisit the long history of presidents, or their administrations, using tax regulations to punish enemies. Some have drawn comparisons with the crimes of Watergate, when President Richard M. Nixon loosed the I.R.S. on an array of Democrats (including potential challengers to his re-election in 1972). Another example, parallel to the current episode, came in 1961, when President John F. Kennedy, alarmed by the growing strength of right-wing groups, “asked the director of audits at the I.R.S. to gather intelligence on organizations receiving tax exemptions,” as Rick Perlstein wrote in “Before the Storm,” his 2001 history of Barry M. Goldwater’s 1964 presidential campaign.

headline: How to Be a ‘Woman Programmer’
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Women and Girls', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: There is always that moment when you are alone with the prejudice: the joke, the leer, the disregard, the fact that the moment you walk through the door you are seen as lesser.
lead_paragraph: I WAS an ordinary computer programmer. I wrote code that ran at the levels between flashy human interfaces and the deep cores of operating systems, like the role of altos in a chorus, who provide the structure without your taking much notice of their melodic lines. I made realistic schedules and met my deadlines. Those were decent accomplishments.

headline: Bernanke Says Better Days Lie Ahead
abstract: In an address to graduates at Bard College at Simon’s Rock, the Fed chairman says nothing about his day job, but he sketches a world in which competition to produce innovations yields ever-greater rewards.
lead_paragraph: Ben S. Bernanke is, of course, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, but he always seems most comfortable as an educator, a role he slips into for a commencement address on Saturday at Bard College at Simon’s Rock.

headline: Get a Life? No Thanks. Just Pass the Remote.
abstract: “Breaking Bad,” like classic literature, explores the mystery of the human heart.
lead_paragraph: ALL I want to do is watch “Breaking Bad.”

headline: Promoters Circling One Another as M.M.A. Takes Root in Asia
abstract: Organizations like the U.F.C. and One Fighting Championship are hoping to mine an untapped population with a long history in martial arts.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — It was late on a Friday night at Singapore Indoor Stadium. The 12,000 seats were full. The shouts in English, Mandarin and Malay were reverberating, and between sending Twitter messages from his cage-side chair, Victor Cui kept leaping to his feet in response to the takedowns, submissions and other codified mayhem happening at close range.

headline: Haunting Relic of History, Slave Cabin Gets a Museum Home in Washington
abstract: The Smithsonian is dismantling a cabin, plank by plank, and moving it to the National Museum of African-American History and Culture.
lead_paragraph: EDISTO ISLAND, S.C. — The floors creaked. The walls swayed in a strong breeze. Rot and termites had destroyed parts of the rickety structure built before the Civil War.

headline: Hollande Signs French Gay Marriage Law
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: For President François Hollande, passage of the law despite public opposition was a significant victory given his campaign promise to legalize gay marriage within the first year of his administration.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The rush toward France’s first same-sex marriage officially began Saturday morning, after President François Hollande signed the country’s “marriage for all” act into law.

headline: Tangling in Shadow of Wrigley’s Ivy Walls
abstract: Since purchasing the Cubs in 2009, the Ricketts family has been pushing for a renovation of Wrigley Field. A deal has yet to be completed and resentment is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — About the time the first pitch was thrown at Wrigley Field in a game between the Cubs and the St. Louis Cardinals on a recent night, a local group, the East Lake View Neighbors, called a meeting to order two blocks away. The agenda was to discuss proposed Wrigley renovations that the Cubs had submitted to the City Council.

headline: Jackie Robinson and a Barrier Unbroken
abstract: In the film “42,” Phillies Manager Ben Chapman is portrayed accurately as a meanspirited, unreconstructed bigot.
lead_paragraph: Two big surprises have emerged from the film“42,” which deals with Jackie Robinson’s breaking major league baseball’s color barrier with the Brooklyn Dodgers. One, it appears that many people who never set foot in Ebbets Field in the 1940s and ’50s have been flocking to see it. And two, the chief tormentor of Robinson, Philadelphia Phillies Manager Ben Chapman, is portrayed exactly as he was in life: a meanspirited, unreconstructed bigot.

headline: Scandal Involving Gifts and Theft Charges Complicates Politics in Virginia
abstract: The drama includes an accusation that a $15,000 gift from a donor to the governor went unreported and a chef who calls himself a whistle-blower.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — A celebrated chef. A political donor with a private jet to lend and a product to pitch. The state’s top two elected officials.

headline: Prisoners Onstage
abstract: Inmates in Italy find redemption in acting.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the inmates at Prison Volterra in Tuscany put on plays. They are directed by Armando Punzo, who established the “Compagnia della Fortezza” in 1988. About a third of the 170 men imprisoned participate. Many are dangerous felons, in prison for life. Most of them come from criminal gangs.

headline: Disease and the Public Eye
abstract: I had never heard of dystonia — until my doctors told me I had it.
lead_paragraph: I’M in line at the supermarket holding three items close to my chest. But I might as well be juggling my Kleenex box, toothpaste tube and an orange. Because — as you’d surely notice if you were behind me in line — I‘m bent forward at a sharp angle, which makes holding things difficult. I know you don’t want to stare, but you do. Maybe you think you’re being considerate when you say, apropos of nothing, “You look like you’re in pain.” Well, thanks, I am — but I’ll resist replying the way I want (“You look like you’re having a bad hair day”). I’m sorry. I know you mean well. Anyway it’s my turn at the register which means I’m closer to being at home where I can lie down and wait for the spasms to subside.

headline: Prisoners Onstage

lead_paragraph: At a Prison Volterra in Tuscany, Italy, inmates become actors.

headline: Afghanistan Hit by Wave of Violence
abstract: Nearly two dozen Afghan police officers and civilians have been killed in the last few days, including a district police official assassinated over a recent anti-Taliban campaign.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A spate of violence across Afghanistan has claimed the lives of nearly two dozen Afghan police officers and civilians in the past few days, including a district police official assassinated over a recent anti-Taliban campaign.

headline: Variety: A Lovely Acrostic
abstract: The wonderfully prolific team of Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon off us a quote with a moral lesson.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s quote by short story author Alice Munro is a lovely and evocative sentiment: the idea that HATE is infectious and spreads through the soul like A DROP OF BLACK INK IN MILK. Not only did I love the idea that hate, if it has to exist, needs to be curbed within one’s self so that it doesn’t spread, but the stark contrast of the ink and the milk is a lovely mental picture. Finally, the idea that, as a child, Ms. Munro was more enchanted by the idea of trying the ink in milk experiment but was hesitant to WASTE THE MILK is particularly moving. I’m truly not sure which part of the quote I liked best.

headline: The 1 Percent Are Only Half the Problem
keywords: ['Education', 'Income Inequality', 'Organized Labor', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The other half of the inequality story, the skills gap, should also command our attention.
lead_paragraph: Most recent discussion about economic inequality in the United States has focused on the top 1 percent of the nation’s income distribution, a group whose incomes average $1 million (with a bottom threshold of about $367,000). “We are the 99 percent,” declared the Occupy protesters, unexpectedly popularizing research findings by two economists, Thomas Piketty and Emmanuel Saez, that had previously drawn attention mainly from academics. But the gap between the 1 percent and the 99 percent is only half the story.

headline: Former Ski Racer Developed Swing That Sounds as Good as It Looks
abstract: Marina Stuetz, 19, of Austria, an L.P.G.A. Tour rookie, says her swing has not changed much since her first attempt at age 6.
lead_paragraph: The Austrian teenager Marina Stuetz’s path to the L.P.G.A. Tour did not go through an American college program, Golf Channel’s “Big Break” or the Ladies European Tour. She arrived like a snowstorm in spring, catching everyone by surprise.

headline: Top 16-Year-Old Runner Has a Long To-Do List
keywords: ['Running', 'Track and Field', 'NCAA Track and Field Championships', 'Marathon Running']
abstract: Alana Hadley of Charlotte, N.C., the top 16-year-old long-distance runner in the country, practiced for her first marathon by running 110 miles a week for seven weeks.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — In anticipation of her first marathon, Alana Hadley did a test run late last month on the quiet, tree-lined streets near her home here. She set out on a three-mile loop that was as familiar to her as the cadence of her breathing. Soon, the laps and miles began to fall away.

headline: Raising Bar for Female Jockeys
keywords: ['Preakness Stakes', 'Horse Racing', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Rosie Napravnik, who recorded the highest finish by a woman in the Kentucky Derby, again raised the bar for women in the Preakness, guiding Mylute home in third.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — As Rosie Napravnik prepared to become the third woman to ride in the 138-year history of the Preakness Stakes, she reflected on how far she had come.

headline: Ivorie Manning,  Shot Doctor, Drops In for a Visit
abstract: Knicks guard Raymond Felton credits much of his success to Ivorie Manning, one of the shooting coaches working in today’s specialized N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: About a week before the playoffs, Knicks point guard Raymond Felton, who had never been on a team that won a playoff series before this season, his eighth in the N.B.A., thought he needed extra time on the court. So he sent a text message to his shooting coach, Ivorie Manning.

keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Pipelines', 'United States International Relations']

lead_paragraph: MADAY ISLAND, Myanmar — The pipelines are finished. The oil storage tanks gleam in the tropical sun. The deep-sea port set in jade-colored waters awaits the first ships bearing crude from the Middle East.

lead_paragraph: Belgium’s soccer team, which is having a renaissance under Coach Marc Wilmots (the former captain of the national team), is bringing a top-flight team to the United States for a friendly game in Cleveland on May 29.

headline: Without Water, Revolution
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Water', 'Drought', 'Global Warming', 'Unemployment']
abstract: The Syrian disaster is like a superstorm. It’s what happens when drought, a fast-growing population, a repressive and corrupt government, and sectarian and religious passions combine.
lead_paragraph: TEL ABYAD, Syria — I just spent a day in this northeast Syrian town. It was terrifying — much more so than I anticipated — but not because we were threatened in any way by the Free Syrian Army soldiers who took us around or by the Islamist Jabhet al-Nusra fighters who stayed hidden in the shadows. It was the local school that shook me up.

headline: Le Grand Jerry Lewis
abstract: A hysterical and wondrous child will get a top honor at the Cannes Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — EVERY year the organizers of the Cannes Film Festival choose to recognize one towering figure in cinema. This year, they are paying homage to Jerry Lewis with a special screening of “Max Rose,” the latest film for the 87-year-old American. In it, he plays an aging jazz pianist.

headline: All the Lonely People
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Is there a link between suicide and weakened social ties?
lead_paragraph: OVER the last decade, the United States has become a less violent country in every way save one. As Americans commit fewer and fewer crimes against other people’s lives and property, they have become more likely to inflict fatal violence on themselves.

headline: We Need to Talk
abstract: Shouldn’t news of our planet’s complete vulnerability come from a parent rather than a “friend”?
lead_paragraph: Avoiding any frank talks with your children about the dangers lurking “out there” in the universe is completely natural. Pointing out a full moon or the Big Dipper is way easier than telling your little Johnny flat-out that a single meteorite the size of his school bus would wipe out everything in the region, including us, and so all his crying now isn’t going to change that.

headline: Card Company Changes Numbering System Collectors Counted On
abstract: A change in the Topps company’s numbering system for its baseball cards has upset some fans and collectors.
lead_paragraph: When Cee Angi was young, a neighborhood bully forced her to trade her 1992 Topps Dave Winfield card for a David Segui. The bully did not know much about baseball, but he knew that the number Topps had assigned to the back of Winfield’s card, 5, made it more valuable than Segui’s, which was 477.

headline: Effort to Strengthen an Afghan Law on Women May Backfire
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Domestic Violence', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Amending a law that holds families accountable for the mistreatment of women risks losing minimal protections.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even with some legal protections in place, Afghan women, and sometimes even little girls, can be sold to pay family debts. In the country’s vast rural areas, just talking to a man who is not a close relative can be punishable by death. And in some places, girls are routinely married at puberty.

headline: Show Us Your Woe
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Television']
abstract: From “American Idol” to American politics, it’s all about the suffering. And it’s exhausting.
lead_paragraph: IN the service of what I’m about to write, an admission I’m loath to make: I watch “The Voice.”

headline: Beware Social Nostalgia
abstract: In looking back at the past, we need to remove the rose-colored glasses.
lead_paragraph: AS a historian, I’ve spent much of my career warning people about the dangers of nostalgia. But as a mother, watching my son graduate from medical school on Thursday, I have been awash in nostalgia all week.

headline: Wesley Schultz
abstract: The lead singer of the Lumineers on snakes, documentaries and the perfect egg.
lead_paragraph: Wesley Schultz is the lead singer and guitarist for the Lumineers, a folk-rock band based in Denver. The group’s eponymous debut album has reached platinum sales status and its singles “Ho Hey” and “Stubborn Love” are among the most streamed and shared songs on Internet music sites.

headline: Plane Makes Belly Landing at Newark Airport
abstract: A US Airways aircraft carrying 34 people had inoperable landing gear and had to land without its wheels; no injuries were reported.
lead_paragraph: The pilot of a US Airways plane with malfunctioning landing gear managed to successfully land the aircraft on its belly at Newark Liberty International Airport early Saturday, transportation officials said.

headline: Tattoo Removal on the Photo Desk
abstract: The rules of photographic integrity find some leeway at T magazine.
lead_paragraph: A POWERFUL picture taken by the Swedish photographer Paul Hansen last year, of men carrying the bodies of dead children through the streets of Gaza City, was artfully composed and filled with anguish.

headline: Beyond the Brady Rule
abstract: To make criminal cases more efficient and fair, prosecutors should open up their files to defendants.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, in the landmark case Brady v. Maryland, the Supreme Court laid down a fundamental principle about the duty of prosecutors — to seek justice in fair trials, not merely to win convictions by any means. The court said that due process required prosecutors to disclose to criminal defendants any exculpatory evidence they asked for that was likely to affect a conviction or sentence.

headline: The Immigration Bill Presses On
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: After two weeks of markup, the fundamental support for immigration reform looks strong.
lead_paragraph: When the Senate Judiciary Committee meets on Monday to resume marking up an immigration bill, it will have two weeks of solid achievement to build on. The bipartisan “Gang of Eight” that drafted the deal has so far held together. The full committee has rejected an array of amendments designed to cripple or kill the bill, while adopting technical fixes and other amendments to make the system fairer, smarter and more generous.

headline: Climate Warnings, Growing Louder
abstract: Given new evidence on carbon pollution, President Obama should get moving on global warming.
lead_paragraph: The news that atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, the most important global warming gas, have hit 400 parts per million for the first time in millions of years increases the pressure on President Obama to deliver on his pledges to limit this country’s greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: The Corporate-Friendly Court
abstract: The current Supreme Court has been more sympathetic to corporate interests than any court since World War II.
lead_paragraph: There is little doubt, statistically, that the Supreme Court presided over by Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. has been more sympathetic to corporate interests than any court since World War II. A comprehensive study of more than 1,750 decisions from 1946 to 2011, published recently in the Minnesota Law Review, found that the Roberts court has repeatedly shielded business from lawsuits involving class actions, workplace disputes and consumer complaints. (The Times’s Adam Liptak has reported about this and related studies.)

headline: Before You Buy That T-Shirt
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Sweatshops', 'Editorials']
abstract: Do consumers have the power to change factory conditions abroad?
lead_paragraph: The deaths and injuries of thousands of garment workers in Bangladesh raise the question of how American and European consumers might assert their power to change appalling factory conditions half a world away. Stop buying clothes made in Bangladesh? Look for labels from other countries, like Indonesia, where conditions might be a little better? Seek out “sweatshop free” clothes, like “fair trade” coffee?

headline: If the Boss Rides a Harley, He Must Be Human
abstract: Harry Herington of NIC Inc., a provider of online services for government, says that by seeing their leaders as humans, employees can better build trust in them.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Harry Herington, chief executive of NIC Inc., a provider of online services for federal, state and local governments, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

abstract: As Orb, the Preakness favorite, awaited his shot at the second leg of the Triple Crown, excitement was rising both inside and outside his barn.
lead_paragraph: It’s 8:52 on Preakness morning.

headline: Old-fashioned Austerity
abstract: Working harder to deal with debt? How silly!
lead_paragraph: Matthew Yglesias piles on Michael Kinsley too, and makes a point I’ve also tried to make in the past: if the real problem is that we overspent and lived beyond our means, we should be working harder, not throwing millions of people into unemployment. Yglesias makes his point with the case of Iceland, which has indeed restored relatively full employment while continuing to suffer somewhat reduced real income.

headline: Trains May Not Run for Days in Crash Area
abstract: Service through New Haven will be suspended into the beginning of the week, the authorities said Saturday, as investigators seek the cause of a derailment.
lead_paragraph: Metro-North and Amtrak train service through New Haven will remain suspended, perhaps for several days, the authorities said Saturday, as investigators continued to seek the cause of a train derailment and collision during the Friday evening rush that injured at least 70 people, five of them critically.

headline: Dueling Jobs (and Big Paydays)
keywords: ['Real Estate Investment Trusts', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Shareholders of PennyMac, a real estate investment trust, have profited since it went public, but not as much as its C.E.O., who also leads the financial services company that manages it.
lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH it carries something of a dubious pedigree, the PennyMac Mortgage Investment Trust has generated pretty good profits for investors since it went public in 2009. Overseen by former executives at Countrywide Financial, ground zero for the subprime mortgage mess, PennyMac has generated a total return of 32 percent to shareholders over that time. Its current annual payout rate of 9 percent is generous among other mortgage real estate investment trusts.

headline: Telling It Like It Is
abstract: When it comes to how it should be told, each story has a mind of its own.
lead_paragraph: Like many writers, I was interested from a very early age in the relationship between the way a story was told and what it was telling.

His solution was to make his own wind-blocking coat from scratch, using plastic garbage bags, spray-on adhesive and fleece.

abstract: Beyond providing fuel for the workday, our daily coffee rituals can say much about our personal finances and attitudes.
lead_paragraph: THE caffeine rituals of my co-workers are many and varied. In the morning, there are at least eight places where you can buy coffee on 40th Street in Manhattan between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, including the cart where the lady says “Hi, beautiful!” and puts your $1 cup in a brown paper bag with a little white napkin.

headline: Next Up for the Spurs: A Look in a Mirror
abstract: The San Antonio Spurs seem aware that the Memphis Grizzlies are also a team willing to grind things out in the all-function, no-form style that the Spurs have patented.
lead_paragraph: In a league dominated by superstars, the San Antonio Spurs built the most mundane of dynasties. There was never any question that Tim Duncan belonged on the short list of the greatest power forwards in N.B.A. history, or that Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili were fantastic players, but the team was seemingly easy to forget in a world of Kobe Bryants and LeBron Jameses.

headline: Pacers’ Hill Is Working His Way Back From Concussion

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Pacers point guard George Hill participated in the team’s shoot-around Saturday as part of the exertion testing he must pass to be cleared to resume play after sustaining a concussion in Game 4 of Indiana’s playoff series against the Knicks.

headline: Cashman and Injury-Riddled Yanks Keep Dealing

lead_paragraph: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman continues to tweak his roster at the margins, making yet another move aimed at upgrading the talent on a team riddled with injuries. Late Friday, he acquired infielder Reid Brignac from the Colorado Rockies for cash and designated Alberto Gonzalez for assignment to make room on the roster.

A growing number of organizations identifying themselves as part of the Tea Party had begun applying for tax exemptions, the manager said, advising the workers to be on the lookout for them and other groups planning to get involved in elections.

headline: Grizzlies Make Up for Lack of Flash With Grit
abstract: In lieu of high-flying pyrotechnics, the Memphis Grizzlies are best known for their grit-and-grind mentality, an approach that resonates in a lunch-pail city.
lead_paragraph: When Tony Allen was interviewed on live television after an otherwise meaningless midseason game in 2011, nobody could have known that he would wind up altering the culture of the Memphis Grizzlies, or that the words he delivered would soon adorn billboards and T-shirts, posters and towels.
