headline: After 75 Years, Knoll International Goes Retail
abstract: The company’s first-ever store is opening in a two-story space on Avenue of the Americas.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to become more accessible, Knoll International has opened its first retail store in its 75-year history. The shop, on the ground floor of the furniture company’s new corporate headquarters in New York, is a two-story space on Avenue of the Americas, around the corner from the Museum of Modern Art. It was designed by ARO, an architectural firm whose credits include the newly renovated Donald Judd Home and Studio. The architects used end-grain oak flooring and bright colors and fabrics to make the shop feel more like a living room. Illuminated lacquer shelving lines the back wall, taking advantage of the double-height space to display rows of chairs, including classics by Mies van der Rohe, Marcel Breuer and Eero Saarinen. For the official opening on June 13, Richard Schultz’s outdoor furniture will take center stage, and Mr. Schultz will be in the store from 4 to 7 p.m.to sign his Petal tables. Knoll will sell new designs as well, including Jonathan Olivares’s stackable, outdoor-friendly aluminum chairs. Fabrics from Knoll Textile’s Luxe line designed by Rodarte, Proenza Schouler and the company’s design director, Dorothy Cosonas, will be part of the mix, as will lush wool felt rugs by Filzfelt. The store is at 1330 Avenue of the Americas (54th Street); Information: (212) 343-4190 or knoll.com.

headline: Reshaping Familiar Pop With a Maternal Caress
abstract: Jane Monheit is singing at Birdland, and her best performances on Tuesday evening were of familiar songs that she turned into heartfelt reflections on motherhood.
lead_paragraph: Well over a decade has passed since the sultry pop-jazz singer Jane Monheit, then in her early 20s, was greeted with the ecstatic hyperbole often accorded to vocal wunderkinder. My memories of Ms. Monheit in the early 2000s are of a phenomenally well-equipped singer wielding an instrument that made a wonderful sound but that left much to be desired when it came to interpreting lyrics. The beauty of her voice and her facility at decorative improvisation spoke for themselves.

Ms. Salonga is a performer whose formidable talent is matched by her unstoppable drive and keen intelligence. As Broadway divas go, she is a cut above most.

lead_paragraph: It’s a common situation for any inquisitive musician: too much curiosity about disparate pieces and few opportunities to play them all within a single ensemble. headline: Abscesses Reported After Steroid Injections
abstract: At least seven people have reported complications after being injected with a potentially contaminated medication made in a pharmacy in Tennessee, federal and state health officials said.
lead_paragraph: At least seven people have reported complications after being injected with a potentially contaminated medication made in a pharmacy in Tennessee, federal and state health officials said. The Food and Drug Administration said that it had not yet determined the nature of the illnesses, but that at least one person seemed to have a fungal infection. Last fall, fungal contamination of the same type of medication, an injectable steroid produced by a compounding pharmacy in Massachusetts, caused the deaths of more than 50 people. Officials in North Carolina, where two of the new cases were found, said that the symptoms were skin abscesses and that there had been no reports of meningitis, stroke or other life-threatening conditions. Illinois said it was investigating five cases of patients who developed abscesses after receiving the medication, which is used to treat back pain and swelling in joints, among other conditions.

headline: Raiding the Keokuk
abstract: Why did Confederates spend weeks salvaging a sunken Union ironclad in Charleston harbor?
lead_paragraph: Late on an April night in 1863 a flotilla of small boats circled a partially sunken ship off the coast of Morris Island, S.C., not far from Fort Sumter in Charleston Harbor. Soon two iron towers studded with bolts rose like islands from the dark waters. Onboard the ship, a Union ironclad called the Keokuk – sunk a few days before in the failed Union attempt to bombard Fort Sumter into submission – stood several men, silently waiting, their eyes on Adolphus W. LaCoste, the civilian in charge of the Confederate salvage operation. His hand raised, they held their breath as a Union picket boat rowed past, towards the lights of the blockading fleet. As the voices of the rowers faded, LaCoste gave the signal to resume. In water up to their waists, with hands and wrenches tugging and turning, they strained at the armored decks over the guns of the sunken ironclad. They had one thing in mind: the guns.

headline: Russia: Earthquake Hits Eastern Coast
abstract: An 8.3-magnitude earthquake struck Russia’s Far East on Friday, sending tremors that prompted evacuations as far away as Moscow, more than 4,000 miles to the west of the epicenter.
lead_paragraph: An 8.3-magnitude earthquake struck Russia’s Far East on Friday, sending tremors that prompted evacuations as far away as Moscow, more than 4,000 miles to the west of the epicenter. The United States Geological Survey recorded the earthquake at 5:44 p.m. local time at a depth of approximately 373 miles below the Sea of Okhotsk, off the coast of the Kamchatka Peninsula. Officials initially told residents on Sakhalin and the Kurile Islands to head for higher ground in case of a tsunami. Russia’s Emergency Ministry later lifted the tsunami warning and said in a statement that no injuries had been reported. Tremors were felt in more than a dozen regions spanning Russia; in Moscow, local law enforcement officers evacuated 850 people from two apartment buildings after residents said the buildings were shaking.

But while the artists’ communities of Cos Cob and New Hope were rediscovered in the late 1970s and the 1980s, those of the Jersey Shore were “generally overlooked” by art scholars, according to Richard Boyle, a historian and former director of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

headline: France: Investigators Tie I.M.F. Chief to Fraud Inquiry Involving Sarkozy
abstract: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was made an “assisted witness” on Friday in an investigation into allegations of possible fraud and misuse of public funds.
lead_paragraph: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was made an “assisted witness” on Friday in an investigation by French judges into allegations of possible fraud and misuse of public funds that date from her time as finance minister. As an assisted witness, Ms. Lagarde has not been placed under formal investigation but is considered to have been closely implicated in the case, which involves a half-billion-dollar state payout to Bernard Tapie, a businessman and politician who once served time in prison for his involvement in the fixing of soccer matches. Ms. Lagarde oversaw that payout in 2007 and 2008, while serving as finance minister under President Nicolas Sarkozy, whose candidacy Mr. Tapie had supported. The board of the International Monetary Fund has expressed its confidence in Ms. Lagarde. In a statement Friday, she said she had “always acted in the best public interest and in accordance with the law.”

headline: Canada: Mayor Denies Drug Allegations
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: After a week of avoiding journalists, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto on Friday denied accusations that he smoked crack cocaine.
lead_paragraph: After a week of avoiding journalists, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto on Friday denied accusations that he smoked crack cocaine. “I do not use crack cocaine, nor am I an addict of crack cocaine,” Mr. Ford, left, said as he read a statement during a brief news conference. He did not take questions. Last week Mr. Ford dismissed as “ridiculous” reports by The Toronto Star and the Web site Gawker that their reporters had viewed a video recording of Mr. Ford that appeared to show him smoking crack cocaine. The two organizations said they were shown the recording by drug dealers who hoped to sell it. The mayor’s statement followed the release of an open letter from six of Mr. Ford’s allies on the City Council asking him to address the reports. Some other members of the council told reporters on Friday that they found the mayor’s statement inadequate, given his history of initially denying embarrassing episodes only to later acknowledge the accusations as true.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Judge Finds Violations of Rights by Sheriff
abstract: The ruling handed down by a federal judge is peppered with stinging criticism of the policies and practices of Sheriff Joe Arpaio, saying the sheriff relied on racial profiling and illegal detentions.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A federal judge ruled on Friday that Sheriff Joe Arpaio and his deputies had violated the constitutional rights of Latinos by targeting them during raids and traffic stops here and throughout Maricopa County.

headline: Strategic Ignorance
keywords: ['Census', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Republicans are trying to restrict vital information with bills that would curtail and ban surveys by the Census Bureau.
lead_paragraph: In an age when knowledge is power, restricting knowledge is a power grab, creating the conditions of ignorance that allow bias, ideology and propaganda to flourish, unchallenged and unchecked.

headline: Get Churches Out of Public Schools
abstract: New York City rightly prohibits the use of public schools for regular religious services. The City Council wants to change that.
lead_paragraph: New York City prohibits the use of public school facilities for regular religious services. That policy makes sense for buildings that are used and maintained by taxpayers. But the City Council wants to eliminate that policy through a new state law. It voted 38 to 11 on Wednesday to pass a resolution asking the Legislature and Gov. Andrew Cuomo to approve legislation to permit religious services on public school properties when they are not in use.

headline: Deception on Gun Background Checks
abstract: Many senators who opposed better scrutiny for weapons buyers try to pretend the opposite.
lead_paragraph: A strange thing happened after 45 senators killed a bill to expand background checks for gun buyers five weeks ago: many of those same senators suddenly discovered a profound affection for background checks. They had been for them all along, it turns out, and wanted nothing more than to keep guns out of the hands of felons.

headline: Exercise and Academic Performance
abstract: Physical activity should be a core educational concern, not a dispensable option.
lead_paragraph: As schools everywhere strive to improve the academic performance of their students, many have cut physical education and recess periods to leave more time for sedentary classroom instruction. A sensible new report from the Institute of Medicine, a unit of the National Academy of Sciences, shows how shortsighted this trend can be. It found that exercise can significantly improve children’s cognitive abilities and their academic performance, as well as their health.

headline: Rangers Ask a Do-It-All Defenseman to Do a Little More
abstract: Ryan McDonagh, an emerging offensive threat, led the Rangers’ skaters in ice time in Game 4 and had a larger role on the power play.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — A potential solution to the Rangers’ power-play woes surfaced in Game 4 against the Boston Bruins, and Coach John Tortorella only wished he had thought of it earlier. After all, it seemed so obvious.

headline: As Tourists Come and Go, Harlem Churches Lose a 10% Lifeblood
abstract: At the heart of the struggle for the churches is a contradiction: As Harlem’s fortunes rise, tithing — the traditional source of the churches’ money — is fading away.
lead_paragraph: The tourists started lining up two hours before morning worship service on West 116th Street in Harlem. Most were dressed in everyday clothes, contrasting with the dark suits and prim dresses of the largely African-American congregation in the historic sanctuary of Canaan Baptist Church of Christ.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Vows: Emmania and Henry
abstract: Teenagers from separate worlds fell in love playing Dance, Dance Revolution. Henry Blum proposed to Emmania Rodriguez by installing an arcade version of the game in his grandmother’s basement.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers from separate worlds fell in love playing Dance, Dance Revolution. Henry Blum proposed to Emmania Rodriguez by installing an arcade version of the game in his grandmother’s basement.

headline: Creating Order From Chaos
abstract: As Syrians flee their homes, many end up in the sprawling refugee camp in Zaatari, Jordan. Kilian Kleinschmidt is tasked with settling thousands of families facing an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: As Syrians flee their homes, many end up in the sprawling refugee camp in Zaatari, Jordan. Kilian Kleinschmidt is tasked with settling thousands of families facing an uncertain future.

headline: Subway Doors Slammed Shut Just in Time to Save Her
abstract: A train operator’s quick thinking blocked a would-be attacker from catching a woman fleeing on a platform for the downtown No. 4 line.
lead_paragraph: Off the platform at the first station on the downtown No. 4 line is an office for subway employees, with cubbies for their bags, bulletin boards, video monitors and a break room. The conductor arrived for her late shift at 1:20 a.m. and signed in. Fifteen minutes later, her work began. She greeted the train operator — they are no longer known as motormen — in the first car before taking her place in the booth in the sixth, in the middle of the train. It left the terminal to begin its long journey through the Bronx and Manhattan to Brooklyn.

headline: This Is Not 2009
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Elections', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: The emergence of a new economic picture has dampened the outrage.
lead_paragraph: With the scent of scandal encircling the White House, some Republicans are already licking their chops over the 2014 midterm elections, while some Democrats are pre-emptively licking their wounds.

headline: Calm Boss Overseeing a Syrian Refugee Camp’s Chaos
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Kilian Kleinschmidt, who runs an overcrowded Syrian refugee camp in Jordan for the United Nations, is a ruddy-faced German who thrives in international disasters.
lead_paragraph: ZAATARI, Jordan — Kilian Kleinschmidt had a problem. The afternoon before Kuwait’s ambassador to Jordan was scheduled to visit the overcrowded Syrian refugee camp here, children vandalized mobile homes that Kuwait had donated, stealing windows, doors and floor mats.

headline: Where a Tribe’s History Comes to Life
abstract: A replica of a Shinnecock village at the Shinnecock Nation Cultural Center and Museum is intended to give visitors the sense that they are stepping inside an indigenous community of centuries ago.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Jason Johnson, clad in buckskin leggings, a breechcloth and a headdress of turkey feathers, was tending a fire and stripping the bark from tupelo logs in a wooded, two-acre plot behind the Shinnecock Nation Cultural Center and Museum in Southampton.

headline: Dispute Over Budget Deepens a Rift Within the G.O.P.
abstract: Republicans are locked in a dispute over future budget negotiations, splitting along generational and ideological lines on the party’s approach to dealing with the federal debt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans are locked in a widening internal dispute over future budget negotiations, splitting along generational and ideological lines on the party’s approach to the central issue that drove the conservative surge in the Obama era: how to deal with the federal debt.

headline: Corrections: May 25, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on May 25, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: They’re Tan and Toned, but They’re Not Very Nice
abstract: Joshua Conkel’s comedy “I Wanna Destroy You” involves a face-off with New York characters flaunting unappealing values and a sense of entitlement.
lead_paragraph: Mick is sick of the city. He misses lightning bugs and children on lawns and driving. And the New Yorkers in Joshua Conkel’s comedy “I Wanna Destroy You” are so hideous that you almost have to agree with him.

headline: Irreverent Sermonettes
abstract: David Steinberg truly makes this puzzle his own.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t believe I’ve had an easier and more fun entry into a Saturday puzzle in, well, ever. PURPLE HAZE is “all in my brain,” and even if you were never a fan of Jimi Hendrix, I’m sure you know this classic rock song. It was enough to get me rocking and laughing at one of my favorite clue/entry pairings in a long time: a “labor leader’s cry” might be “PUSH!” and if you’re like me, the response is likely to be to grab the labor leader by the collar and shriek “Shut up!  More ice chips!”

headline: New Alliance Emerges to Tighten Chemical Rules
keywords: ['Chemicals', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A vote by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg for a failed control gun bill gained him allies for the first credible bill in years to revamp the nation’s outmoded chemical safety law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first credible effort in years to revamp the nation’s outmoded chemical safety law grew in part from the Senate’s failure in April to enact a gun buyer background check bill.

headline: The Power Behind Manchester City Is Content to Stay Out of Sight in New York
abstract: Sheik Mansour bin Zayed al-Nahyan, whose investment group owns Manchester City and will pay for the New York City soccer club, has stayed largely out of day-to-day operations of the new team.
lead_paragraph: The setting was modest, the mood jovial, the dignitaries on hand pretty impressive. In the school cafeteria of P.S. 72 in East Harlem on Wednesday morning, professional soccer was nudged forward in New York City, with talk of a new team with prestigious owners and a new stadium designed specifically for the sport.

headline: Obama’s Gitmo Problem
abstract: It isn’t Congress’s fault that the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, hasn’t closed. It’s the president’s.
lead_paragraph: Late Wednesday afternoon, less than 24 hours before President Obama made his big national security speech — in which he said, for the umpteenth time, that the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, should be closed — a group of American lawyers representing Guantánamo detainees filed an emergency motion with the Federal District Court in the District of Columbia. The motion asked the court to order the removal of “unjustified burdens” that the military command at Guantánamo has placed on the detainees, making it nearly impossible for them to meet with their lawyers.

headline: Mexican Official Defends Accuracy of Data on Organized Crime
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Crime Rates', 'Missing Persons', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Interior Secretary Miguel Osorio Chong insisted that Mexico was making real progress in reducing organized crime killings.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Rejecting concerns that the government’s statistics were foggier than ever, Mexico’s top security official argued Friday that real progress was being made in reducing organized crime killings and that the number of people previously reported missing was inflated.

headline: All of City’s Public Swimming Beaches to Reopen by Memorial Day
abstract: City officials say they will fulfill a promise, made in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, to open all of the free beach areas in time for the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Under leaden skies, officials on Friday fulfilled a pledge made after Hurricane Sandy wreaked havoc on 14 miles of New York City beaches, announcing that all eight public swimming beaches would reopen in time for Memorial Day.

headline: Burgers and the Big Talk
abstract: Over their weekly date, a couple at Harlem Shake, which opened earlier this month, discussed plans for their future.
lead_paragraph: The doors were thrown open onto Lenox Avenue’s broad sidewalk, Michael Jackson boomed from the sound system — sometimes life in the big city isn’t so hard. Harlem Shake, which opened at 124th Street and Lenox Avenue earlier this month, already has lines out the door and unreasonable waits for its burgers and shakes. But on a summery evening last week, no one seemed to mind. The décor is retro diner, the restroom an homage to Jet magazine covers past. It’s what you’d expect a Harlem-themed restaurant in Tokyo to look like transported to Harlem. The principal owner Jelena Pasic, 38, said that the neighborhood reminds her of the small island in Croatia where she grew up. “People are much more personal than in the rest of New York,” she said. Proof that the restaurant isn’t located somewhere out of town: kale salad on the menu.

headline: New Computer Attacks Traced to Iran, Officials Say
abstract: The recent attacks seem to be aimed at sabotage rather than stealing information, United States officials say.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — American officials and corporate security experts examining a new wave of potentially destructive computer attacks striking American corporations, especially energy firms, say they have tracked the attacks back to Iran.

headline: For Now, Davis’s Struggles Stay in the Major Leagues
abstract: The Mets’ Ike Davis, who has been mired in a season-long slump, will remain the first baseman, Manager Terry Collins said.
lead_paragraph: After a day off for the Mets, Manager Terry Collins returned to Citi Field on Friday afternoon and picked up where he left off, answering questions about the job security of Ike Davis, the team’s struggling first baseman.

headline: States’ Policies on Health Care Exclude Some of the Poorest
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'States (US)', 'Poverty']
abstract: For millions of people below the poverty line, no assistance for health insurance will be available in states that have refused to expand Medicaid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The refusal by about half the states to expand Medicaid will leave millions of poor people ineligible for government-subsidized health insurance under President Obama’s health care law even as many others with higher incomes receive federal subsidies to buy insurance.

headline: Running a League, From Behind the Plate
abstract: Rich Ritchie is the commissioner of the Queens Lighted Softball Association, a nighttime league of which he is also the chief umpire.
lead_paragraph: Rich Ritchie is the commissioner of the Queens Lighted Softball Association, a nighttime league of which he is also the chief umpire.

headline: Softball’s Iron Fist
abstract: Rich Ritchie runs the Queens Lighted Softball Association, calls its balls and strikes, enforces its rules and loses few arguments.
lead_paragraph: Rich Ritchie, 61, has been organizing ballgames since he was a kid.

headline: Doctor Gets Eight Years in L.I.R.R. Fraud Scheme
abstract: Dr. Peter J. Ajemian pleaded guilty in January in a plot that allowed hundreds of retired railroad workers collect disability benefits they weren’t entitled to.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island doctor was sentenced Friday to eight years in prison for his role in a fraud scheme that allowed hundreds of retired Long Island Rail Road workers to collect disability benefits to which they were not entitled.

headline: Kentucky Operator to Cease Enrichment of Uranium
abstract: The closing of a plant in Paducah, Ky., could pose a problem for the American nuclear weapons arsenal over time but is not likely to affect civilian nuclear electric plants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The only American-owned plant for enriching uranium, a cold war relic near Paducah, Ky., will be shut down next month, its operator said on Friday. The closing could pose a problem for the American nuclear weapons arsenal over time but is not likely to affect civilian nuclear electric plants.

headline: ‘Oklahomans Don’t Stop Fighting’
abstract: Several Moore, Okla., residents, whose lives were somehow connected by Monday’s tornado and its aftermath, shared their experiences of enduring the storm.
lead_paragraph: Several Moore, Okla., residents, whose lives were somehow connected by Monday’s tornado and its aftermath, shared their experiences of enduring the storm.

headline: Bill on College Financial Aid for Undocumented Students Seems Stalled in Albany
keywords: ['Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The New York State Dream Act passed overwhelmingly in the Democratic-dominated Assembly, but the bill’s supporters acknowledged that its chances were slim in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: As immigration legislation moves forward on Capitol Hill, generating widespread debate and providing glimpses of an emerging bipartisan consensus, a less ambitious effort in Albany is playing out differently.

headline: Some of His Best Customers Are Canine
abstract: Pete Van Leeuwen, a founder of Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream, talks flavors, competition, and finding the sweet spot where everything comes into balance.
lead_paragraph: Pete Van Leeuwen started Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream in 2008 with his brother Ben, their partner, Laura O’Neill, and two classic yellow trucks. Now in their sixth year of business, they have six trucks and three stores in Brooklyn and Manhattan, as well as a Balinese restaurant (Selamat Pagi) in the front of their production facility. The first summer Mr. Van Leeuwen drove around, scooping ice cream. These days, with the food truck boom in New York City and their growing business — just this week they introduced vegan ice cream — Mr. Van Leeuwen, 36, spends his time organizing and troubleshooting, with occasional breaks for a pistachio cone, his favorite flavor.

headline: Rangers Game and Wedding Form a Blissful Union
abstract: Game 4 did not interrupt a wedding at Fort Tryon Park; rather, it was the entertainment.
lead_paragraph: For the longtime Rangers season-ticket holders Phil and Joan Boening and their two sons, Justin and James, tensions were agonizingly high Thursday evening.

headline: Militant Says He Is Behind Attack in Niger
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: If true, Mokhtar Belmokhtar’s claim would put one of the Sahel’s most hardened militants, whom Chad’s military said it had killed, back at the center of jihad.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Mokhtar Belmokhtar, the mastermind of the January seizure of an Algerian gas plant that left dozens of foreign hostages dead, has claimed responsibility for another terrorist attack: the suicide bombings on Thursday in Niger that killed about 30 people, including 24 soldiers and at least six jihadists.

headline: Come 5:30, She’s on the Bus
abstract: Marianna Scandole takes care of passengers on the Hampton Jitney and the Hampton Ambassador.
lead_paragraph: Some people go to great lengths to avoid getting stuck in Long Island beach traffic. Marianna Scandole does it for a living. Ms. Scandole, 26, is a host on the Hampton Jitney and the Hampton Ambassador, which carry lower- and higher-paying passengers through some of the region’s most illustrious clogged arteries. For Ms. Scandole, who previously worked as a nanny, the job is something of a career trial balloon. “I want to become a flight attendant, so I thought that would be an excellent way to get some practice in,” she said. She lives with her mother and younger sister in Hampton Bays.

headline: As Lacrosse Grows, the Diversity of Players Remains Largely Unchanged
abstract: The popularity of lacrosse has increased, but the diversity in the sport has lagged behind. Several minority players have said they have experienced situations or heard remarks related to race.
lead_paragraph: On a team in Southern California, more than 2,500 miles from the center of lacrosse’s universe on the Eastern Seaboard, Kyle Harrison no longer feels unsettled.

headline: Ex-Guatemalan President Extradited to U.S. in Corruption Case
keywords: ['Extradition', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Embezzlement', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: The extradition of Alfonso Portillo to face corruption charges came days after a genocide verdict was annulled against a former dictator, Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Guatemalan officials rousted an imprisoned former president on Friday, loaded him onto a jet and whisked him to New York to face long-pending corruption charges.

headline: Carousel Horses Return Home to Brooklyn
abstract: This weekend, the B&B Carousell horses will once again spin in the salubrious breezes on Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, the B&B Carousell horses will once again spin in the salubrious breezes on Coney Island.

headline: Time Lapse: The Making of a Carousel
abstract: As a part of Coney Island’s makeover, the B&B Carousell was dismantled and restored at a facility in Ohio. Workers reassembled the antique wooden carousel over several days in May.
lead_paragraph: As a part of Coney Island’s makeover, the B&B Carousell was dismantled and restored at a facility in Ohio. Workers reassembled the antique wooden carousel over several days in May.

headline: Summer’s Steeds, Back Home
abstract: After eight years away, 50 horses of the historic B&B Carousell are back in Coney Island with new coats of paint, refurbished joints and new tails.
lead_paragraph: One at a time, they loaded the horses into the truck. The dapple grays and the chestnut mares were maneuvered onto a tractor-trailer where they nestled snugly together, wrapped in moving blankets.

headline: Rio Struggles With Sex Crimes
abstract: Sexual assaults in Rio de Janeiro have cast a light on class differences in the city and have raised fears for women’s safety ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Summer Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Sexual assaults in Rio de Janeiro have cast a light on class differences in the city and have raised fears for women’s safety ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Summer Olympics.

headline: Public Rapes Outrage Brazil, Testing Ideas of Image and Class
abstract: A recent wave of rapes in Rio de Janeiro has cast a spotlight on the conflicted attitudes toward women in a country where many hold positions of power.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The attacks have stunned this city. In one, an assailant held a gun to the head of a 30-year-old woman while raping her in front of passengers on a bus as the driver proceeded down a main avenue. In another, a 14-year-old girl from a hillside slum was raped on one of Rio’s most famous stretches of beach.

headline: Yankees End Two-Game Skid but Lose Granderson to Injury
abstract: Curtis Granderson, in his eighth game back from a broken right forearm, sustained a broken bone in his left pinkie when he was hit by a pitch in the fifth.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — In a season characterized by a staggering run of injuries, the Yankees’ misfortune reached an almost absurd level Friday when Curtis Granderson sustained another broken bone in only his eighth game of the season.

headline: Haynes Johnson, Journalist and Author, Is Dead at 81
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Johnson was a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, television commentator and author who spent most of his career at The Washington Post and won wide acclaim for his coverage of the capital.
lead_paragraph: Haynes Johnson, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, television commentator and author known in particular for his long association with The Washington Post, died on Friday in Bethesda, Md. He was 81.

headline: Now That’s a Souvenir
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Tracing a structure’s journey from a Coast Guard pavilion at the 1964 World’s Fair to a family’s summer cabin in the Adirondacks.
lead_paragraph: They’ve been standing on the Flushing Bay Promenade, just north of the Mets’ stadium and across the water from La Guardia Airport, for nearly 50 years: two identical fiberglass shells. Not quite buildings, not quite sculptures, the twin structures look simultaneously retro and modern — a past vision of futurism.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 25, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, May 25, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “We like to believe in Brazil that we live in a peaceful, happy place, when the truth of our existence is far more complicated. It’s like we’re Narcissus gazing into a pool of sewage.”

headline: Application and Affidavit for Rosen Search Warrant
abstract: An affidavit details what information the United States government gathered from conversations between Stephen Jin-Woo Kim, a government employee, and an unnamed journalist believed to be James Rosen, the chief Washington correspondent for Fox News.
lead_paragraph: An affidavit details what information the United States government gathered from conversations between Stephen Jin-Woo Kim, a government employee, and an unnamed journalist believed to be James Rosen, the chief Washington correspondent for Fox News.

headline: Joyful Noise in Silent Barn, an Alt-Arts Mecca
abstract: The Silent Barn, in a renovated warehouse in Brooklyn, affords a usually itinerant cultural milieu a legal, perhaps permanent home.
lead_paragraph: The D.I.Y. arts scene — that illicit and usually itinerant cultural milieu — may have found a legal, if not a permanent, home for this summer in New York. It is called the Silent Barn, and it could be thought of as Brooklyn’s First Church of the Perpetual House Party.

headline: Georges Moustaki, Poetic French Singer, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Moustaki, who wrote “Milord” for Édith Piaf, was known for his poetic sensibility and melancholy ballads.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Georges Moustaki, a singer and songwriter who wrote Édith Piaf’s hit song “Milord” and won wide popularity in France for his poetic lyrics and melancholy ballads, died on Thursday in Nice, France. He was 79.

headline: Rogers Returning to M.L.S. With Galaxy
abstract: Robbie Rogers is expected to join the Los Angeles Galaxy ion Saturday, becoming the first openly gay player on a major men’s professional team in North America.
lead_paragraph: Robbie Rogers is expected to join the Los Angeles Galaxy on Saturday, becoming the first openly gay player on a major men’s professional team in North America.

headline: Flynn Robinson, Scorer on Dominant N.B.A. Club, Dies at 72
abstract: Robinson was a 1970 All-Star, a seven-season N.B.A. player and a productive reserve guard on the first Los Angeles Lakers title team, which had a 33-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: Flynn Robinson, a sharpshooting guard who came off the bench to add scoring punch for one of the greatest teams in N.B.A. history, the 1971-72 Los Angeles Lakers, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 72.

headline: A Painter Amid Friends
abstract: Jane Freilicher, who has an exhibition at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery in Midtown, was a star presence among her group of friends, which included several renowned poets of the New York School.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1949, John Ashbery, unleashed to the world from Harvard, arrived in New York to begin his long and productive creative life in a small loft building on Third Avenue near 16th Street. Mr. Ashbery was to spend the season in the apartment of his college friend Kenneth Koch, who was visiting his parents in Cincinnati, and he was to pick up the key from a woman, Jane Freilicher, who lived one floor up. The consequence of this quotidian exchange was a deeply connected friendship now in its sixth decade, nourished by the bohemian reverie that characterized Greenwich Village for so much of the 20th century and migrated to the east end of Long Island with the arrival of Memorial Day.

headline: Rogers Set to Join Los Angeles Galaxy
abstract: Robbie Rogers, who announced in February that he was gay and that he was retiring from soccer, is expected to be introduced by Major League Soccer’s Los Angeles franchise on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Robbie Rogers is expected to join the Los Angeles Galaxy and become the first openly gay player on a major men’s professional team in North America.

headline: Across U.S. Companies, Tax Rates Vary Greatly
abstract: Last week, in a Congressional hearing, Apple got grilled for its low-tax strategy. But not every business can copy that approach. Here is a look at what S.&P. 500 companies paid in corporate income taxes — federal, state, local and foreign — from 2007 to 2012, according to S&P Capital IQ.
lead_paragraph: Last week, in a Congressional hearing, Apple got grilled for its low-tax strategy. But not every business can copy that approach. Here is a look at what S.&P. 500 companies paid in corporate income taxes — federal, state, local and foreign — from 2007 to 2012, according to S&P Capital IQ.

headline: James’s Miscues Help Pacers Stop Heat to Tie Series
abstract: LeBron James scored 36 points, but his two late turnovers helped Indiana beat Miami to tie the Eastern Conference finals at one game each.
lead_paragraph: Give LeBron James an inch or two, a second or two, a half-step or a slight gap, and he will turn you into a historical footnote, a foil for his Hall of Fame highlight reel. This much, the Indiana Pacers had already learned, painfully, deeply, in the opener of the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: James L. Tolbert, 86, an Early Lawyer to Black Hollywood, Dies
abstract: Mr. Tolbert, a high school dropout, went on to play a central role in an early effort to improve the way that blacks were portrayed on film.
lead_paragraph: James L. Tolbert was in love. Marie Ross was too. But she had little interest in marrying a man who pieced together his income by hosting parties and concerts in empty buildings. One of his gimmicks: selling food and drink out of an old hearse.

headline: Stuck in the City? There’s Lots to Do
abstract: A sampling of worthy seasonal pursuits, across all five boroughs, that will make the months from Memorial Day to Labor Day bearable.
lead_paragraph: New York City cannot bear to be anything but the best. Even its notorious summer heat and humidity have to compete on the world stage, giving the tropics an annual run for their money. But while the less intrepid (and more affluent) flee to beach towns and other breezier climes, the city offers a wealth of summer diversions to those who stay put and embrace the swelter. The following is a sampling of worthy seasonal pursuits, across all five boroughs, that will make the months from Memorial Day to Labor Day much more bearable.

headline: Alton T. Lemon, Who Challenged State Aid to Religious Schools, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Lemon was a civil rights activist whose objection to a 1968 Pennsylvania law gave rise to a watershed 1971 Supreme Court decision.
lead_paragraph: Alton T. Lemon, a civil rights activist whose objection to state aid to religious schools gave rise to a watershed 1971 Supreme Court decision, died on May 4 in Jenkintown, Pa. He was 84.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) MAGIC MIKE (2012) In a role loosely inspired by his stint as a stripper in Florida, Channing Tatum (above left, with Matthew McConaughey) stars as the gyrating main attraction at the Xquisite dance club, in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called “Steven Soderbergh’s funny, enjoyable romp about male strippers and the American dream.” Alex Pettyfer plays Adam, a college dropout who is pushed onstage at Xquisite. At first Adam is resistant. Then Madonna’s “Like a Virgin” begins to throb. “What happens will be familiar if you’ve ever seen one of those variations on the fallen-woman movie,” Ms. Dargis wrote. “In the past the movies were very much preoccupied with the moral regulation of women, but here the stress is on Mike’s struggle to succeed as he juggles his part-time gigs (dancing, auto detailing and construction) with his desire to build custom furniture.” She added: “The collaboration between Mr. Soderbergh and the relatively untested Mr. Tatum is itself a gamble, one that has brought out the best in each. What could have been an embarrassing misfire hinted at by the movie’s misleading trailers is instead a smoothly distilled collaboration that balances Mr. Tatum’s heat and charm — and ambitions that are as transparent as Mike’s — with Mr. Soderbergh’s cool, cinematic intelligence and ongoing preoccupations.”

headline: Failing to Convince Assad
abstract: The goal of John Kerry’s meetings with his Arab and European counterparts was to eventually change Bashar al-Assad’s calculus. It is far from clear how that will happen.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan – As Secretary of State John Kerry and 10 European and Arab foreign ministers gathered here this week to discuss grand strategy, President Bashar al-Assad was taking decisive action. With the help of thousands of fighters from Hezbollah, Iran and Iraq, he was close to achieving some of his largest military gains in two years.

headline: Davis’s Woes Suspended, With Game, After the 8th
abstract: Ike Davis struck out four times before the Mets’ game against the Braves was stopped in a cold rain; it will resume Saturday night.

lead_paragraph: NEWS For more than a century, the Museum of Medical History in Berlin has exhibited assorted limbs, bones, tubercular lungs and fetuses, all in the name of science and enlightenment. Yet lately the curators are re-evaluating the principles that govern their displays as they confront a growing debate over what cultural organizations should be doing to preserve the dignity of the dead. Many of the world’s grand museums are hearing increasing demands for the return of human remains from former colonies or conquered peoples. Some are giving back bones and skulls that were once viewed as exotic trinkets and were traded by native peoples for calico or plundered in the late 1800s by scientists exploring racial differences. Doreen Carvajal reports from Berlin.

Now that the Senate has voted down new gun control laws and we have the president on the defensive — never thought I’d say it, but God bless the I.R.S.! — we have a real opportunity to guide Congress along a common-sense path that will further ensure the freedoms of peaceful, law-abiding citizens. Herewith, talking points on the next crucial phase of our work. Please distribute to all concerned elected officials who share our love of liberty and public safety.

headline: Foreign Projects Give Afghans Fashion, Skate Park and Now 10,000 Balloons
abstract: With more than a hundred billion dollars in the past dozen years, thousands of groups have tried to find ways to spend it.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Braving jeers and provoking smiles, volunteers spread through Kabul on Saturday, giving away 10,000 pink balloons as part of a performance art project called “We Believe in Balloons.”

headline: Francis’ Humility and Emphasis on the Poor Strike a New Tone at the Vatican
abstract: Pope Francis, eschewing some of the grandiose trappings of the papacy in favor of an emphasis on simplicity and modesty, has raised morale, observers say.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — He has criticized the “cult of money” and greed he sees driving the world financial system, reflecting his affinity for liberation theology. He has left Vatican officials struggling to keep up with his off-the-cuff remarks and impromptu forays into the crowds of tens of thousands that fill St. Peter’s Square during his audiences. He has delighted souvenir vendors near the Vatican by increasing tourist traffic.

headline: Turbine Plans Unnerve Fans of Condors in California
abstract: Environmentalists are worried that a wind-energy project near the Mojave Desert could affect the fragile condor population.
lead_paragraph: The California condor’s slow 20-year climb back from the brink of extinction has long been a fragile not-quite-success story in the conservation world. So when the news came on Friday that developers of a wind-energy project near the Mojave Desert would not face criminal charges if the blades killed a single condor, environmental groups expressed grave concern.

headline: Arizona’s Illegal Sheriff
abstract: A federal judge excoriated Joe Arpaio for illegally using race as a factor in neighborhood sweeps and traffic stops.
lead_paragraph: How do we know that Joe Arpaio, sheriff of Maricopa County, Ariz., is a racial profiler, an abuser of power who has subjected Latinos for years to unconstitutional arrests, detention and harassment?

headline: Seeking Serenity in a Patch of California Land
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Hmong Tribe', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Community gardens for immigrant groups can provide familiar foods that are hard to find in the grocery store. They can also be a balm for alienation and depression.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — Like Scotch broom and dandelions, despair can be invasive. This is why, every Monday, Lee Lee, a Hmong refugee, puts on her sun hat and flip-flops, grabs the hoe handmade by her father and brother in Laos and heads to the Hmong Village Community Garden here, where she tends rows of purple lemon grass, bitter melon and medicinal herbs along with other Hmong women.

headline: In California, Gardening for Mental Health
abstract: Community gardens for immigrant groups can provide more than just familiar foods hard to find in the grocery store; they can be a balm for alienation.
lead_paragraph: Community gardens for immigrant groups can provide more than just familiar foods hard to find in the grocery store; they can be a balm for alienation.

headline: What Mideast Crisis? Israelis Have Moved On
abstract: Instead of focusing on what is said to be their central challenge — how to share this land with another nation — Israelis are largely ignoring it.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, conventional wisdom has held that as long as Israel faces the external challenge of Arab — especially Palestinian — hostility it will never come to terms with its internal divisions. The left has sometimes used it as an argument: we must make peace with the Palestinians so that we can set our house in order — write a constitution, figure out the public role of religion. Others have viewed the threat as almost a silver lining keeping the place together: differences among Israeli Jews (religious or secular, Ashkenazic or Sephardic) are so profound, the argument goes, that if the society ever manages to turn its attention inward, it might tear itself apart.

headline: Verdicts Expected Soon for 2 Milosevic Agents
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The two men have been portrayed by prosecutors as the masterminds behind the covert operations during the 1990s wars in Bosnia and Croatia.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — He was the president’s man for all seasons, prosecutors said, ready to organize hit squads, permit the killing of prisoners, sign off on covert weapon shipments or mediate the release of peacekeepers. Jovica Stanisic, the onetime chief of the secret police, was widely thought to be the second most powerful man in Serbia during Slobodan Milosevic’s presidency.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 26
abstract: President Obama’s speech on national security and the recovery from last week’s tornado in Oklahoma are the focus of the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: Still echoing through Washington, President Obama’s speech Thursday on shifting the nation’s approach to counterterrorism will be up for debate on the Sunday shows.

headline: Amma’s Multifaceted Empire, Built on Hugs
abstract: Mata Amritanandamayi, known as Amma, is a globe-trotting guru who embraces the masses — and a get-it-done management style for her charities.
lead_paragraph: THERE are entourages — and then there is the retinue of Mata Amritanandamayi, a 59-year-old Indian guru known simply as Amma, or “mother.” On Friday, she began a two-month North American tour during which she will be accompanied by 275 volunteers. They plan to ride in four buses across the continent from Bellevue, Wash., to Marlborough, Mass., visiting 11 cities, including New York. And at each stop along the way, Amma will sit on stage for 15 hours at a stretch, greeting her thousands of devotees.

headline: Breeding the Nutrition Out of Our Food
abstract: Much of our produce is relatively low in phytonutrients — compounds that may reduce the risk of many diseases.
lead_paragraph: WE like the idea that food can be the answer to our ills, that if we eat nutritious foods we won’t need medicine or supplements. We have valued this notion for a long, long time. The Greek physician Hippocrates proclaimed nearly 2,500 years ago: “Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food.” Today, medical experts concur. If we heap our plates with fresh fruits and vegetables, they tell us, we will come closer to optimum health.

headline: Nutritional Weaklings in the Supermarket
abstract:
Heirloom varieties and wild species of produce
have been found to outshine their cultivated cousins.
lead_paragraph:
Heirloom varieties and wild species of produce
have been found to outshine their cultivated cousins.

headline: Made-for-TV Movies
abstract: Joon Pahk and Jeremy Horwitz produce some large grid, small screen entertainment for us.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — There was a time after I had my kids when I thought I would never get out to the theaters to see a movie again, at least not one that didn’t involve Pokemon. The Boy was not big on sitting for long periods of time, even with his small lap loaded with candy, so very often The Girl was left to watch a large portion of the movie by herself while I chased The Boy up the aisle and out into the lobby. Now that they’re older, of course, things are different and they are much more likely to chase me up the aisle as I stomp out (“What?! Bruce Willis was dead all along?? What the heck is that?! I want my money back!”)

headline: Indians Grow Impatient With Taciturn Premier Amid Troubles
abstract: In India, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh’s reticence was once considered a sign of integrity; now it is being seen as a weakness as corruption scandals shake his party.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — He speaks so softly that even his public comments are sometimes nearly inaudible. He has not held a formal news conference in India since 2011. And a pack of reporters were driven to hold a protest recently when he refused to participate in the routine political act of being photographed while filing for re-election in Assam State.

headline: Maoist Attack Kills at Least 16 in India
abstract: Maoist guerrillas ambushed a convoy of political leaders, leaving at least 16 dead, including a prominent politician and five police officers, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least 16 people, including a prominent politician, were killed Saturday when Maoist guerrillas ambushed a convoy of political leaders in Chhattisgarh State, the authorities said. Among the dead were five police officers.

headline: Bayern Munich, Champion of Germany, Adds European Title
abstract: Arjen Robben’s goal in the 89th minute gave Bayern Munich a 2-1 victory in the first all-German final in Champions League history.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Some saw this as the opening to an age of German soccer dominance, and maybe it will be. Maybe years from now Saturday’s Champions League final between Bayern Munich and Borussia Dortmund will be viewed as the start of the Bundesliga’s rise to the pinnacle of European sports.

headline: At the Bottom of the Top 10, but No. 1 at a Norway Event
abstract: Sergey Karjakin, a Russian grandmaster, emerged on top in a field of heavy hitters and defeated Levon Aronian, the No. 2 player in the world, on his way to taking the crown.
lead_paragraph: The Norway Chess 2013 tournament was among one competitor’s greatest triumphs, and the results offered hope to two others but were a disappointment — again — for the world champion.

headline: A Long Way From Church Street but Still in Sync
abstract: Lyle Lovett and Robert Earl Keen talk about meeting and sharing their musical dreams as Texas A&M students in the 1970s — and why working together is a joy for them both.
lead_paragraph: On a 1988 live recording of “The Front Porch Song,” which he wrote with Lyle Lovett when they were students at Texas A&M in the late ’70s, Robert Earl Keen pauses midway to describe the song’s inspiration. “We used to sit on this old porch on Church Street, right across from the Presbyterian church, and play bluegrass and folk music, and talk about girls and where we were going to move to when our parents got our grades,” he says. “Talk about someday becoming big songwriters.”

headline: Texas Lawmakers Put Down Their Swords
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'State Legislatures', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Education (K-12)', 'Water']

lead_paragraph: If Texas’ less-than-theatrical 83rd legislative session is remembered at all, it will be known for accords, not discord.

headline: Morris Renek, a Novelist of Gift and Determination, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Renek was a critically admired New York writer who created comic tales about historical criminals and modern urban life but never achieved the commercial success many thought he deserved.
lead_paragraph: Morris Renek, a critically admired New York novelist who wrote comic tales about historical criminals and modern urban life but never achieved the commercial success many thought he deserved, died on May 10 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Wayne Miller, Photographer of War and Peace, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Miller’s images, whether taken of the front lines, the streets of Chicago or the birth of his own son, intimately chronicled a world remaking itself.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Miller, a photographer whose intimate images from the front lines of war, the streets of Chicago’s South Side and his own family life captured a world in transition in the middle of the 20th century, died on Wednesday at his home in Orinda, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Teixeira Teary-Eyed Over Granderson’s Latest Setback
abstract: Mark Teixeira said that Curtis Granderson’s broken pinkie, eight games back from a rehabilitating a broken arm, was simply cruel.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Somehow, Mark Teixeira was far more emotional about Curtis Granderson’s broken left pinkie than Granderson appeared to be Friday night. Teixeira was at Tropicana Field when Granderson learned he would miss at least a month after he was hit by a pitch and broke the fifth metacarpal.

headline: Wayne Miller, Magnum Photographer, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Miller once said that what he wanted to do was “to photograph mankind and explain man to man.”
lead_paragraph: Mr. Miller once said that what he wanted to do was “to photograph mankind and explain man to man.”

lead_paragraph: GUNTERSVILLE, Ala. — In the middle of the enduring conflict between liberty and public welfare stands Joyce Osborn Wilson and her teeth-whitening business.

headline: Giffords Urges Graduates at Bard to ‘Be Courageous’
abstract: Gabrielle Giffords spoke for no more than two minutes at the commencement ceremony, where she also received an honorary degree, but she earned several standing ovations.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Speaking uncertainly but smiling broadly, Gabrielle Giffords, the former Arizona congresswoman who became a public face of the gun control movement after she was shot in 2011, delivered a kind of blessing in her commencement address to Bard College graduates here on Saturday afternoon, urging them to “be bold, be courageous, be your best.”

headline: Interpol Rebuffs Russia in Its Hunt for a Kremlin Critic
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Interpol rejected a request for a police hunt for William F. Browder, a British investment banker who accuses President Vladimir V. Putin’s government of rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Interpol has rejected a Russian request for a worldwide police hunt for William F. Browder, a British investment banker and a Kremlin nemesis who has made no secret of his whereabouts or of his battle against the government of President Vladimir V. Putin over accusations of human rights abuses.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']

lead_paragraph: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del. — The soldier bent to his work, careful as a diamond cutter. He carried no weapon or rucksack, just a small plastic ruler, which he used to align a name plate, just so, atop the breast pocket of an Army dress blue jacket, size 39R.

headline: A Day Later, Play Resumes, and So Do the Mets’ Woes
abstract: After losing to the Braves in extra innings in the game resumed from Friday night, the Mets dropped the originally scheduled game, 6-0.
lead_paragraph: There was one encouraging thing that could be said for the Mets at the end of a dismal Saturday during which they rang up two more losses in what is shaping up as a long season. Ike Davis, the monumentally struggling first baseman teetering on the verge of a demotion to the minor leagues, got a single.

abstract: For more than two months, a cross section of Yemen’s population has gathered, trying to hammer out the shape a future government will take.
lead_paragraph: For more than two months, 565 people representing a cross section of Yemen’s population have gathered in a luxury hotel on the outskirts of Sana, the capital, trying to hammer out the shape a future government will take.

headline: California Faces a New Quandary, Too Much Money
abstract: After years of battles over state budget deficits and spending cutbacks, an unexpected surplus has set off a debate about which programs to restore and how long the boon will last.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After years of grueling battles over state budget deficits and spending cuts, California has a new challenge on its hands: too much money. An unexpected surplus is fueling an argument over how the state should respond to its turn of good fortune.

lead_paragraph: From multibillion-dollar military aid to stealthy and secretive drone strikes, Pakistan, perhaps even more than Afghanistan, has been the central focus of America’s 12-year war on Islamist militancy.

headline: Rogers Says He’s Ready for a Role as a Pioneer

lead_paragraph: CARSON, Calif. — Robbie Rogers thought he had stepped away from his career as a professional soccer player the moment he pressed the button publishing a blog post announcing that he was gay. At the time, in February, he said, he could not imagine that he could be himself on and off the field.

headline: Offense Vanishes; Rangers Follow
abstract: The Rangers were bounced from the postseason, a victim of their ineffectual offense and an inability to counter the Bruins’ fourth line and a 22-year-old rookie.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Rangers trailed by a goal, nine minutes from elimination, when the puck found Ryan Callahan alone outside the blue line. The crowd at TD Garden fell silent. The Rangers stood on their bench and leaned over the boards as Callahan churned in on Boston goalie Tuukka Rask, their season on his stick blade.

headline: Overbay’s Homer in the 11th Caps a Stirring Comeback Against the Rays

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Duke was 15 minutes from a cakewalk to the national title game, sailing through its semifinal against Cornell with Saturday’s blustery wind at its back, looking undaunted and largely unobstructed, all of its diversified offensive machinations firing in full.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) BEHIND THE CANDELABRA (2013) Michael Douglas, above, stars as the piano showman Liberace, and Matt Damon is Scott Thorson, his chauffeur, lover and adopted son, in this film biography from the director Steven Soderbergh and the screenwriter Richard LaGravenese. Set in Las Vegas, Los Angeles and Palm Springs, the film chronicles the men’s relationship as Liberace picks up and possesses Mr. Thorson, has him cosmetically altered in his image and legally adopts him before discarding him for a younger model. “There’s something uncanny, even brilliant,” about Mr. Douglas’s impersonation of Liberace, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “Sashaying across Las Vegas stages and epic suburban living rooms with a drum major’s puffed-up grandeur and a lounge lizard’s predatory smile, Mr. Douglas gives a performance so assured, so free of camp or cringe, that you quickly surrender any doubts you might have had about his playing a  famously flamboyant, closeted-in-plain-sight gay entertainer.” At the same time, he said, “there’s something limited, and limiting, about Mr. Douglas’s portrayal. Its brilliance feels as if it were all on the surface, a matter of expertise and professionalism.” And the same could be said of Mr. Soderbergh’s film, he added. “A cerebral gloss on, and satire of, a big old Hollywood biopic, it’s full of smart, funny details — perfectly sewn in place, like the rhinestones on one of Mr. Douglas’s blinding costumes — but it’s short on heart, or heat.”

It’s my only child’s senior year of high school, a year in which we are preparing to transition to the next phase of our lives. Perched on metal bleachers with the other team parents, my husband and I watched the sun go down behind the scoreboard of what would be Anna’s last high school water polo game. We trundled through her schedule of classes during the last back-to-school night. I had Anna pick the tulips we would plant for her last spring at home (for now, anyway), and they bloomed in a riot of lovely, bulbous pastels.

It had been five years since he had been to the Cannes Film Festival with “Two Lovers,” which was also the last time he had directed a movie. Flanked by Marion Cotillard and Jeremy Renner, two of the stars from his latest, Mr. Gray, 44, looked content for a man who earlier that day had compared facing the journalist hordes to having a colonoscopy without anesthesia. headline: Ted Spagna’s Sleep Studies
abstract: A photographer, known for cataloging the rich language of sleep, first turned the camera on himself.
lead_paragraph: For sleep evangelists and connoisseurs, and even for sleep strivers, the publication this fall from Rizzoli of “Sleep” by Ted Spagna is a watershed event. Beginning in 1975, Spagna mounted time-lapse cameras in his subjects’ bedrooms, producing portraits from a “God’s-eye view” and cataloging, in full color, the rich language of sleep: tosses, turns, expressions, positions, intimacy, solitude. It was curiosity alone that led the photographer, who died in 1989, to his first sleeping subject: himself. “I was surprised to see another self that existed in sleep that I didn’t know about,” he has said. Looking at these photos, I’m reminded of John Steinbeck, who wrote, “It is a common experience that a problem difficult at night is resolved in the morning after the committee of sleep has worked on it.” Spagna, more than anyone else, took us inside the committee room.

lead_paragraph: In retrospect, I should have taken a last look at the nose I was born with. This was on the first Wednesday of November in 2011, the day of a scheduled appointment with a dermatological surgeon for Mohs micrographic surgery, the purpose of which was to carefully remove some previously discovered skin cancer from the lower left side of my nose. But it was also the fourth day after a surprise autumn snowstorm that had left our home in north central Connecticut without heat or electricity and the surrounding landscape devastated by thousands of fallen trees. On the morning of my procedure I washed my hair and sponged my body with a few quarts of water heated in a stockpot on a gas barbecue grill outside the house, threw on some clothes and rushed out the door. The entire exercise felt like an inconvenience. Looking back, taking proper care of my freckled, reddish skin, descended from somewhere on the moors of Ireland, had always felt like an inconvenience.

lead_paragraph: LEAD HILL, Ark. — It was supposed to be a fairy tale come to life, but the hard truth can be read on the signs along Highway 14. One trumpets, “A castle in the making” and “They’re building it. Come see it!” The other sign, more recent, is a lament: “Closed for the season.”

headline: Mapping the Great Indoors
abstract: Ecologists are increasingly interested in the great wildlife diversity indoors, where they’ve found that buildings contain identifiable microbial signatures of their human inhabitants.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — On a sunny Wednesday, with a faint haze hanging over the Rockies, Noah Fierer eyed the field site from the back of his colleague’s Ford Explorer. Two blocks east of a strip mall in Longmont, one of the world’s last underexplored ecosystems had come into view: a sandstone-colored ranch house, code-named Q. A pair of dogs barked in the backyard.

headline: The Jungle Indoors
abstract: Researchers are just beginning to understand the sheer number and type of organisms that live inside the home with us.
lead_paragraph: Researchers are just beginning to understand the sheer number and type of organisms that live inside the home with us.

headline: Next to You on the Subway
abstract: A study of air in the public transit labyrinth below New York City found multitudes of invisible critters but no cause for alarm.
lead_paragraph: Norman R. Pace, a microbiologist at the University of Colorado Boulder, pioneered the use of DNA to study microbes. He has searched for extremophiles (organisms that can exist in extreme environments) in the hot springs of Yellowstone National Park and once descended in the submersible Alvin to examine microbial life on hydrothermal vents. He greets visitors, like any microbiologist who has seen too much, with a fist bump.

headline: A Go-To Actor Who Is a Niche Unto Himself
abstract: John Malkovich, who will play the lead in “The Giacomo Variations” at City Center, recently discussed rakes, roués and his own more discreet charms.
lead_paragraph: There are actors more handsome than John Malkovich, more alluring, more dissolute. But if a director needs someone to play a legendary libertine — or even a Lothario-esque version of Mr. Malkovich himself, as in “Being John Malkovich” — guess who gets the call?

headline: Where Better to Play a Theremin Than on a Boat?
abstract: Rob Schwimmer also brought along a Continuum fingerboard for his concert at Bargemusic on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of his recital at Bargemusic in Brooklyn on Friday evening Rob Schwimmer performed Kurt Weill’s “Lost in the Stars” with a warm, smooth baritone that had great polish and sweetness in the upper range.

headline: 12 Minutes to Board, and a Security Line of 500
abstract: Tina Wells, chief and founder of Buzz Marketing Group, on unanticipated hiccups while flying.
lead_paragraph: I STARTED my company, the Buzz Marketing Group, when I was about 16 years old. I answered an ad to review products aimed at teenagers. I got a lot of samples to review, so I recruited friends to help, and by 1996, I was on my way.

headline: Tales Told From a Bar Stool, Each One More Shivery Than the Other
abstract: In “The Weir,” four men and a woman meet at a pub, where they crack jokes, drink too much, swap stories and reveal themselves slowly.
lead_paragraph: You’d think I’d have learned how to harden my heart.

headline: Now Resurfacing, the Myth of the Serpent Scorned
abstract: A young woman’s outrage animates an updated Japanese parable of transformation in “Dojoji: The Man Inside the Bell” at the Clurman Theater.
lead_paragraph: For all the differences infusing Eastern and Western artistic traditions, one can count on certain universal realities. For example: If you’re a young, female innocent in a canonical love story, chances are that things won’t go so swimmingly for you.

headline: A Mystery Buried Deep in a Canvas
abstract: A restoration reveals that a Jackson Pollock work was altered.
lead_paragraph: A restoration reveals that a Jackson Pollock work was altered.

headline: Joe Mantello on Broadway
abstract: No one told Joe Mantello that being a leading actor and a Tony Award-winning director was like shooting for the moon. And so, he did it his way.
lead_paragraph: No one told Joe Mantello that being a leading actor and a Tony Award-winning director was like shooting for the moon. And so, he did it his way.

headline: At High Speed, on the Road to a Driverless Future
abstract: By blending advanced computer vision techniques with low-cost video cameras, the Israeli company Mobileye is demonstrating how quickly autonomous driving can be commercialized.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Last month, on a freeway from Jerusalem to the Dead Sea, I sat in the driver’s seat of an Audi A7 while software connected to a video camera on the windshield drove the car at speeds up to 65 miles an hour — making a singular statement about the rapid progress in the development of self-driving cars.

headline: Powerhouse of the Uranium Enrichment Industry Seeks an Exit
abstract: Urenco, the global leader in its field, wants to sell for reasons of geopolitics, economics and the notion of an energy source that could turn deadly.
lead_paragraph: CAPENHURST, England — The first thing you notice when entering Building E23 on a tightly guarded site here in northwest England is the loud tick-tock. The sound resonates throughout the long, low-slung building where, behind secured doors, sit row upon row of tall thin tubes.

headline: A Pollock Restored, a Mystery Revealed
abstract: Conservators at the Museum of Modern Art have gained insights into how Jackson Pollock worked through a restoration of his “One: Number 31, 1950.”
lead_paragraph: Jackson Pollock’s unconventional working methods — spreading a piece of unstretched, unprimed canvas on the floor of his Long Island studio and then pouring, splattering and literally flinging industrial paints across its surface — have long been part of his myth, performance art executed without an audience.

headline: What to Watch on Day 3 at the French Open
abstract: Six matches, including Benoit Paire vs. Marcos Baghdatis, are worth following in early singles play at Roland Garros on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: If the suspect skies allow for a full day of play, here are six matches to earmark Tuesday at the French Open.

headline: The Music Behind Liberace’s Capes, Jewels and Candelabra
abstract: “Behind the Candelabra” explores Liberace’s personal life. Here a classical music critic explores his musicianship.
lead_paragraph: The director Steven Soderbergh and just about everyone associated with “Behind the Candelabra,” the new biographical film about Liberace, emphasized from the start that the movie was going to be about a love affair. A strange love affair, for sure — more a sordid co-dependency between Scott Thorson, a rootless young man, and Mr. Entertainment himself, Liberace, who was 40 years older.

headline: Never a Crime-Free Moment
abstract: A six-part series exploring the Brooklyn district attorney’s office has been challenged in court as a September primary for the job of district attorney approaches.
lead_paragraph: You can’t blame Abe George for crying foul over “Brooklyn DA.”

headline: Rough-Edged Atomic Pioneer
abstract: Ray Monk’s “Robert Oppenheimer: A Life Inside the Center” aspires to be more comprehensive than earlier volumes about that American physicist.
lead_paragraph: Ray Monk had begun work on his J. Robert Oppenheimer biography in 2005, when Kai Bird and Martin J. Sherwin’s “American Prometheus” was published. That book, billed as “the first full-scale biography” of Oppenheimer, the theoretical physicist, gave Mr. Monk good reason to worry. It covers scientific, historical, moral, political and personal aspects of Oppenheimer’s life, conveying his arrogance, brilliance, self-destructiveness and lady-killing charisma. What gaps remained for Mr. Monk to fill?

headline: New Albums by Laura Marling, Terence Blanchard, Frankie J and Cecile McLorin Salvant
abstract: This week’s releases include “Once I Was an Eagle,” by Laura Marling, and “Magnetic,” by the trumpeter Terence Blanchard.
lead_paragraph: “I will not be a victim of romance,” Laura Marling declares near the start of her magnificent new album, “Once I Was an Eagle” (Ribbon Music). That doesn’t stop her from plunging into it. In her new songs, love is combative, tempting, cruel, inscrutable, predatory and yet, occasionally, a comfort, with music to match every change of heart and mind. “Once I Was an Eagle” is the fourth album by this 23-year-old British songwriter, and her ambitions continue to grow.

headline: 20 Questions on Soap, Cereal and Related Oddities
abstract: Assorted queries about advertising, the media and popular culture.
lead_paragraph: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, the media and popular culture.

abstract: Hotels may send guests who have just ended their stay an e-mail survey asking about their experience and sometimes an additional e-mail if they do not respond.
lead_paragraph: Hotels want to hear your opinion of your stay.

headline: Same-Sex Couple Say, ‘I Do,’ as Italy Sticks to ‘I Don’t’
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The wedding of Massimiliano Benedetto and Giuseppe Ilaria in Rome last week was a symbolic step in a country that does not recognize same-sex unions of any kind.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The nuptials were traditional in almost every sense. The music was romantic. Teary vows were exchanged, along with shimmering rings, and a passionate first kiss was greeted with boisterous cheers, and more tears, by both families.

headline: Harvey Eager to Face Yankees, His Childhood Team
abstract: Matt Harvey, who grew up in Connecticut rooting for the Yankees, said he had always hoped to be a part of the Subway Series, something he will do Tuesday when he takes the mound for the Mets.
lead_paragraph: Interleague games between the Mets and Yankees have lost their luster and novelty since the earliest editions of the Subway Series. But Tuesday night’s matchup between Hiroki Kuroda and Matt Harvey was a major source of buzz before the start of the series Monday night at Citi Field.

headline: A Gay Marriage, in Spirit
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Two men made a political statement by going through the ritual in Rome, though gay couples have no legal standing in Italy.
lead_paragraph: Two men made a political statement by going through the ritual in Rome, though gay couples have no legal standing in Italy.

headline: At School Papers, the Ink Is Drying Up
abstract: Fewer resources, lack of interest and the Internet have led to fewer high school newspapers in the city’s public schools.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton News used to be the source for everything that mattered to its readers in the northwest Bronx. It published 10,000 copies every other week in the 1930s and even circulated overseas among Bronx residents fighting in World War II.

headline: Improving Dimitrov Knows Expectations Are Higher at French Open
abstract: Grigor Dimitrov, a 21-year-old Bulgarian, defeated Novak Djokovic in Madrid and took Rafael Nadal to three sets in Monte Carlo.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Grigor Dimitrov whistles as he recalls a particularly tough session of training last December. Having spent his teenage years at the Mouratoglou Academy in Paris, Dimitrov, a stylish Bulgarian, made the decision to break out of his comfort zone at the end of 2012, uprooting to the rather more chilly environment of Bromma, a suburb in western Stockholm. His goal? To join forces with the former world No. 2 Magnus Norman, the man he felt could help him make the transition from promising youngster to genuine world beater.

headline: King Gives Up Royal Yacht, but Donors Want It Back
abstract: The businesspeople who gave the $27 million, 136-foot yacht to King Juan Carlos of Spain 13 years ago want him to return it rather than give it to the government.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — In hard times like these, everyone has to make sacrifices. And King Juan Carlos of Spain wanted it known that he was doing his part, too.

headline: What Gives? The Pacers’ Defense Looks to Reassert Itself
abstract: The Heat scored 70 points in the first half — including 18 by LeBron James while he played in the post — in easily winning Game 3 Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The Pacers like to call themselves a defensive-minded team, and the numbers bear them out. The Pacers led the N.B.A. during the regular season in opponents’ field-goal percentage (.420) and 3-point field-goal percentage (.327), and were second to Memphis in points allowed (90.7).

headline: Kim Merker, Hand-Press Printer of Poets, Is Dead at 81
keywords: ['Printing and Allied Trades', 'Books and Literature', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: Mr. Merker, a native New Yorker, was a designer and typesetter who used presses he operated with his own inky hands to print beautiful books, often by emerging poets.
lead_paragraph: Kim Merker was a chain-smoking New Yorker with literary ambitions when he went to Iowa in the mid-1950s to study poetry. He became a wordsmith of another kind.

headline: By Inserting Itself Into Syrian War, Hezbollah Makes Dramatic Gamble
abstract: Hezbollah is betting its prestige and security by taking its followers on a new mission to crush the Syrian rebellion, an effort that could bring more power or defeat.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Fighting a pre-emptive war against foreign jihadists is not the usual mission for Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group best known for confronting Israel. So when its leader, Hassan Nasrallah, explained why he was sending fighters into Syria, he took care to remind his followers that they were not “living in Djibouti” but on the border of a country whose two-year uprising Hezbollah sees as a threat to its existence.

headline: Getting Ahead by Having Answers Instead of Questions
