headline: Entrepreneurs Help Build Start-Ups by the Batch
abstract: Investors with experience in technology companies are choosing to back multiple projects at one time, with more active roles than those of venture capitalists.
lead_paragraph: Just two years after its conception, Prism Skylabs has made enormous strides.

headline: Brazil: Mayor Punches Resident in Face
abstract: The mayor of Rio de Janeiro, Eduardo Paes, punched a constituent in the face after being called the Portuguese equivalent of “excrement” in a dispute at a restaurant.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Rio de Janeiro, Eduardo Paes, punched a constituent in the face after being called the Portuguese equivalent of “excrement” in a dispute before stunned diners at a Japanese restaurant. Mr. Paes issued a written apology to the city after the episode, which unfolded Sunday night when he went outside to smoke a cigarette during a meal with his wife and several others. But he qualified the apology by stating that it was unacceptable to face such insults during private moments with his wife. The constituent, Bernardo Botkay, a writer and a singer in a rock band, said he had directed his scorn at Mr. Paes because he believed that the mayor’s policies were benefiting a select group of real estate speculators and contributing to gentrification ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Summer Olympics, both of which will be held in Rio. “I think it is noteworthy to be physically attacked by the mayor,” Mr. Botkay said. “It clearly shows that he does not have what it takes to run the city.”

headline: Immigrant Measure Still Backed by Gays
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Homosexuality', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Gay rights advocates were angry when a provision they favored was knocked out of the immigration bill, but they are still supporting the legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers supporting a bipartisan bill in the Senate to overhaul the immigration system faced a surge of outrage last week from gay rights advocates after a provision those groups supported was left off the legislation in committee at the last minute.

headline: Europe and China Trade Talks End Bitterly
abstract: Trade negotiations turned into an exchange of recriminations over what the Europeans insist is unfairly low pricing for Chinese solar panels.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Trade negotiations between the European Union and China ended on Monday with mutual recriminations. China called on the European Union to refrain from imposing tariffs on solar panels, and the European trade commissioner complained that China was pressuring individual countries to prevent Europe from reaching a consensus.

headline: The Underachievers of Los Angeles
abstract: The final script has not been written on the 2013 Dodgers or their freeway rivals, the Angels. Either could still recover and mount a playoff run.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The baseball teams that met here on Monday, both with losing records and far from first place, are not alone among Southern California underachievers. The premier team in town, the Lakers, exited the N.B.A. playoffs without a victory despite a roster of stars.

headline: Sony’s Bread and Butter? It’s Not Electronics
abstract: Citing heavy losses in its electronics business, analysts say Sony should concentrate its efforts where they pay: selling life, auto and health insurance.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Sony is best known as a consumer electronics company, making PlayStation game consoles and televisions. And it loses money on almost every gadget it sells.

headline: The Forgotten Amerasians
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Filipino-Americans', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Filipinos with American fathers should have a path to U.S. citizenship.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — THE Senate Judiciary Committee approved an immigration reform bill last week that would gradually make citizenship possible for as many as 11 million undocumented immigrants. The bill is widely described as sweeping in scope. In fact, it is not quite sweeping enough, as it leaves the plight of another group of would-be Americans unaddressed.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FROM liberal internationalists to hawkish conservatives, a chorus of influential voices in Washington is suggesting that American intervention in Syria would also do serious damage to Bashar al-Assad’s close ally, Iran.

headline: An Addiction to Zealotry
abstract: In Virginia, a candidate’s hateful speech is testing the Republican Party’s ability to reach mainstream voters.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Republicans delivered a rousing surprise at their gubernatorial nominating convention this month. They chose E. W. Jackson, an African-American minister and lawyer, as their candidate for lieutenant governor after he delivered a thunderously right-wing speech.

headline: Moving On
abstract: Letting go of one’s library is about more than just clearing shelf space.
lead_paragraph: I have sold my books. Not all of them, but most of them. I held on to the books I might need while putting the finishing touches on a manuscript that is now with my publisher. I also kept the books I will likely need when I begin my next project in the fall. But the books that sustained my professional life for 50 years — books by and about Milton, Spenser, Shakespeare, Skelton, Sidney, Herbert, Marvell, Herrick, Donne, Jonson, Burton, Browne, Bacon, Dryden, Hobbes — are gone (I watched them being literally wheeled out the door), and now I look around and see acres of empty white bookshelves.

headline: Thanks for the Memories, Even the Ones to Forget
abstract: Before Monday’s Subway Series game, Mets fans and employees talked with Yankees closer Mariano Rivera, paying him respect for his accomplishments, even ones that came against their team.
lead_paragraph: For the past 27 seasons as a Mets season-ticket holder, 76-year-old Gloria Feit has watched her team routinely overshadowed by the hated Yankees. It has not always been for Feit to be a Mets fan, especially because her husband is a Yankees fan.

headline: Mexico: Dramatic Final Anoints a Hero
abstract: Moisés Muñoz scored a goal and made critical saves in the penalty kick shootout as Club América won Mexico’s Clausura Sunday night in dramatic fashion.
lead_paragraph: In a stirring final in Mexico’s Azteca Stadium, Club América goalkeeper Moisés Muñoz was his team’s offensive catalyst, sending the Clausura finals to extra time. Then, after a scoreless 30 minutes, he was the star of the penalty-kick shootout as Cruz Azul’s 15-year title drought continued in painful fashion.

lead_paragraph: We’re living in an empirical age. The most impressive intellectual feats have been achieved by physicists and biologists, and these fields have established a distinctive model of credibility.

headline: Even With Yanks Hurting, There’s Usually Pain to Spare for Mets
abstract: The hobbling Yankees have earned one of the top records in baseball. And the Mets, despite their victory Monday, have failed to coexist in the same region.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the Mets’ original sin is — and, really, we don’t have time to delve into all that right now — they and their dogged fans pay for it pretty much all the time.

headline: Rutgers Backs Athletic Director After Charge of Abuse
abstract: The Rutgers president, Robert L. Barchi, said that Julie Hermann’s job was not in jeopardy after allegations that she verbally abused players when she was the volleyball coach at Tennessee in the late 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Rutgers named Julie Hermann, a longtime official in Louisville’s athletic department, as its athletic director, hailing her as the right person to help repair the university’s image after a scandal involving the abusive behavior of its former men’s basketball coach.

headline: With Everyone a Critic, Hoteliers Struggle to Cope
abstract: Hotel executives are frantically trying to stay on top of online reviews. Many companies expect managers to respond personally to negative reviews.
lead_paragraph: SINCE people began traveling, everyone has shared opinions about hotels, but until fairly recently the evaluations were spread by word of mouth or through the august evaluations of recognized guidebook authors.

headline: Keep the Clunkers Away From the Polls
abstract: The Board of Elections needs to come up with some other solution to handle the tight primary schedule and not bring back the old lever-based machines.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Board of Elections has complained for weeks that the electronic voting machines first used in 2010 cannot handle the city’s tight primary elections schedule. But one solution, endorsed by the board and under consideration in Albany, seems absurd. The board and the State Legislature are talking about scrapping the new machines and replacing them with the old metal clunkers, with their creaky levers, that went out of production more than 30 years ago.

headline: Caution and the Common Core
abstract: States should have some flexibility as they move to the new and more demanding curriculum.
lead_paragraph: The rigorous Common Core learning standards that have been adopted by 45 states represent a once-in-a-generation opportunity for the United States to improve public schools nationally, bringing math, science and literacy education up to levels achieved by high-performing nations abroad.

headline: Border Injustice
abstract: The immigration system cannot abandon fairness in the rush to prosecute and punish.
lead_paragraph: Those who view fixing immigration as simply a matter of getting tougher on lawbreakers tend to overlook how tough the system already is, an ever-growing web of agents, cops, courts and prisons whose cruelty and deficiencies are appalling. Much attention has focused on the excesses of local law enforcement, exemplified by self-appointed immigration enforcers like Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., whose department was found guilty in federal court on Friday of violating the constitutional rights of Latinos for years through racially biased crime sweeps, arrests, detention and harassment.

headline: In Terror Shift, Obama Took a Long Path
abstract: President Obama’s decision to rewrite the playbook on counterterrorism policy dates to his re-election concerns, and it represents an effort to shape his legacy and to set the rules for his successors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The pivot in counterterrorism policy that President Obama announced last week was nearly two years in the making, but perhaps the most critical moment came last spring during a White House meeting as he talked about the future of the nation’s long-running terrorism war. Underlying the discussion was a simple fact: It was an election year. And Mr. Obama might lose.

lead_paragraph: FORT ERIE, Ontario — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration is known for its combative stance toward lawmakers, bureaucrats and reporters alike.

headline: Upset at a Call, Stakhovsky Goes the Social Media Route
abstract: The 101st-ranked Sergiy Stakhovsky didn’t catch a break from the umpire in a first-round loss at the French Open Monday, so he took his case to Twitter.
lead_paragraph: When 101st-ranked Sergiy Stakhovsky’s racquet proved insufficent to gain an edge on the No. 7 seed Richard Gasquet through the first two games on Court Suzanne Lenglen Monday, Stakhovsky found a more modern piece of equipment to try to swing the match his way: his iPhone.

headline: Reducing Some City Parks to the Status of Beggars
abstract: Central Park and the High Line have donors who can drop millions in a moment; other parks, frequently those outside Manhattan that don’t draw tourists, are getting desperate.
lead_paragraph: Steve Hindy, the Brooklyn Brewery baron and a fellow whose love of this city is manifest, serves as board member of the Prospect Park Alliance. He noticed the city was steadily edging away from its financial commitment.

headline: Johnson Falls to Montanes in See-Saw Battle
abstract: The 23-year-old American qualifier Steve Johnson battled Albert Montanes of Spain Monday at the French Open, but he fell in five sets.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Steve Johnson of the United States stroked 56 shots beyond the reach of Albert Montanes of Spain, but he came up short in a three-and-a-half hour duel that see-sawed to a 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, 3-6, 6-1 victory for Montanes.

headline: Something Happened on the Way to Bountiful: Everyone Sang Along
abstract: The Broadway experience does not typically include audience participation, but something unusual happens when Cicely Tyson performs “Blessed Assurance” in “The Trip to Bountiful.”
lead_paragraph: Not long after the curtain rises on the second act of “The Trip to Bountiful,” the Broadway revival of the Horton Foote play at the Stephen Sondheim Theater, something unusual happens. Cicely Tyson, as Mrs. Carrie Watts, sits on a bus station bench in a small Texas town. She is on the run from her abusive daughter-in-law and henpecked son in Houston, desperate to see the family farm in Bountiful once more before she dies.

headline: Citing Danger, Schumer Calls for Scrapping New Screening Plan for Statue of Liberty
keywords: ['Statue of Liberty', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Ellis and Liberty Islands are set to have new security checkpoints, but Senator Charles E. Schumer says that checking tourists after they have arrived leaves the statue vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer called on the National Park Service on Monday to scrap what he called a dangerous new security plan for the Statue of Liberty, saying that it could leave visitors to the tourist attraction vulnerable to a terrorist attack.

headline: Fit to Be Tied
abstract: The A.C.P.T. champion Dan Feyer returns for his third time at the constructing bat.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Dan Feyer is a solving machine, but once in a while he gets in the constructing mood and offers us a puzzle of his own making to solve. I loved this puzzle of his from 2011 (Across Lite, Solution, blog) and today marks his third time out. Kick back and solve this one with a nice, cold BREWSKI.

headline: Gardner Turns a Misplay Into a Highlight Catch
abstract: The Yankees’ Brett Gardner stewed over a ball he thought he should have caught against the Mets on Monday, and then got a chance to make up for it.
lead_paragraph: For almost five innings, Brett Gardner stewed over what he thought was his misplay on a ball hit by David Wright in the first inning of the Mets’ 2-1 win over the Yankees on Monday. Wright had hit a towering fly ball to right-center field. Gardner gave chase and then crashed into the wall. The ball bounced around, allowing Wright to reach third base.

headline: Japan: U.S. Pilot Rescued Off Okinawa
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Rescues']
abstract: Japanese rescuers saved an American fighter pilot from the waters off southern Japan after his F-15 fighter crashed into the ocean early Tuesday, Japanese officials said.
lead_paragraph: Japanese rescuers saved an American fighter pilot from the waters off southern Japan after his F-15 fighter crashed into the ocean early Tuesday, Japanese officials said. The F-15, which flew out of Kadena Air Base on Okinawa, crashed in the Pacific about 70 miles east of the island at 9 a.m. Tuesday, American military officials said. The Japanese authorities immediately sent boats and aircraft to the scene and spotted the pilot clinging to a raft, said Toru Michizaki of the Japanese Coast Guard in Okinawa. The pilot, whose name was not released, was rescued by members of the Japan Air Self-Defense Force, he said. American officials said the cause of the crash was under investigation.

headline: Racing’s Public Persona and Quiet Ambassador
abstract: Those who don’t follow horse racing closely may not be aware that as much as D. Wayne Lukas has been a public persona and a terrific television interview subject at major events, Lukas also serves on a regular basis as racing’s unofficial ambassador.
lead_paragraph: For 20 years in the 1980s through 2000, D. Wayne Lukas was a ubiquitous presence in the winner’s circle at Triple Crown races, amassing 13 wins in the spring classics – at one point racking up six victories in a row with four different horses from 1994 to 1996.  But he hadn’t set foot inside the celebratory enclosure at one of these three classic races in 13 years, since Commendable won the Belmont Stakes in 2000.

headline: Rocket and Gun Attacks Add to Fears That Syria’s Strife Is Reaching Lebanon
abstract: After three Lebanese soldiers were killed at a border checkpoint and four rockets hit a village, badly injuring a civilian, residents feared being targeted as the Syrian crisis spilled into Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: HERMEL, Lebanon — Four rockets hit this village near the Syrian border on Tuesday afternoon, badly wounding a woman who was sitting under an olive tree in her yard, residents said. Shortly before, gunmen killed three Lebanese soldiers at a border checkpoint in the Bekaa Valley, adding to fears that the crisis in Syria is spilling into Lebanon.

headline: Daily Report: The Fast-Approaching Future of Driverless Cars
abstract: By blending advanced computer vision techniques with low-cost video cameras, the Israeli company Mobileye Vision Technologies is demonstrating how quickly autonomous driving can be commercialized.
lead_paragraph: Last month, on a freeway from Jerusalem to the Dead Sea, John Markoff sat in the driver’s seat of an Audi A7 while software connected to a video camera on the windshield drove the car at speeds up to 65 miles an hour — making a singular statement about the rapid progress in the development of self-driving cars, he writes in The New York Times.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Union’s decision to lift its arms embargo on Syria, after a bitter, 13-hour debate in Brussels, is intended to put pressure on Russia and President Bashar al-Assad of Syria before peace talks scheduled in Geneva next month, with a message that the West will not allow the rebels to be defeated, senior European diplomats said Tuesday.

headline: The Cloud Company: People or Money?
abstract: The cloud-based enterprise software companies are increasingly getting into each other’s territory, blurring the once-clear distinctions between products and services, online and offline, or sales and advertising. lead_paragraph: Online technologies have made us question lots of assumptions. What is privacy? Which is better, ownership or sharing? Is the crowd wiser than a lone genius?

headline: Dance in the Birthplace of Pesto
abstract: A new weeklong festival near Genoa, Italy, is intended to bring modern dance to a region known more for its cuisine and scenery.
lead_paragraph: BOGLIASCO, Italy — The Ligurian region of Italy is better known for its magnificent coastline and its delicious cuisine (the birthplace of pesto!) than for dance. But Danza Contempo Ligure, a small festival based in Genoa, suggests that there is no shortage of choreographic activity. The final day of the new weeklong festival took place in Bogliasco, a small coastal village just beyond the Genoa city limits. The location was the Villa dei Pini, the grand house that belongs to the Bogliasco Foundation, an organization that provides residencies to artists and humanities scholars, and the participating choreographers made fine use of the villa’s beautiful gardens and coastal location despite unseasonally chilly weather.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Daniel Bergner on the Female ‘Viagra’
abstract: The author of this week’s cover article answers questions about what scientists now know about women’s sexuality — and how they’re trying to manipulate it.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Bergner, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about the development of a pill to stimulate female desire. His new book, “What Do Women Want?: Adventures in the Science of Female Desire” comes out next week.

headline: SAC Could Give the Justice Dept. a High-Value Target
abstract: Portraying SAC Capital Advisors as a den of thieves could send a message about how the Justice Department is policing Wall Street, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: The subpoenas issued to executives at SAC Capital Advisors to testify before a grand jury provide a powerful indication that prosecutors have made the firm the focus of their latest effort to crack down on insider trading. Unfortunately for SAC, it may also be a case of being in the wrong place at the wrong time.

lead_paragraph: Americans are in a buying mood, thanks largely to the housing recovery.

headline: The Gun Report: Memorial Day Edition
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Remember 6-month-old Jonylah Watkins, who was shot and killed on March 11 while sitting in her father’s lap in a minivan in Chicago? Authorities said Monday that the man accused in the shooting, which also wounded her father, was seeking revenge for the theft of a video game console. Koman Willis, a documented gang member with 38 previous arrests, was charged with first-degree murder.

headline: Divided Court, in 2 Rulings, Makes It Easier to Challenge Criminal Convictions
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The Supreme Court said a one-year filing deadline for prisoners seeking federal review of their state court convictions under a 1996 law may be relaxed if they present compelling evidence of their innocence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of 5-to-4 decisions that divided along ideological lines, the Supreme Court on Tuesday made it easier for inmates to challenge their convictions.

headline: Indian Cows Find Patrons in U.S.
abstract: A shelter in Uttar Pradesh that rescues cows from cow-lifter gangs is funded by Indian-Americans.
lead_paragraph: BARSANA, Uttar Pradesh — The cow’s status as a sacred being in Hinduism is increasingly being threatened as more wealthy Indians, even Hindus, are turning carnivorous, as Gardiner Harris of The New York Times recently reported. Meanwhile, the increasing demand for beef is driving gangs to steal cows that are wandering around Delhi so that the animals can be sold to slaughterhouses.Still, cows have plenty of protectors in India, and even beyond its borders. Thousands of miles away, Indian citizens living in the United States regularly send money to cow shelters in India like Mataji Gaushala, located in Barsana, near Mathura in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: New Ways to Use ‘Ancient’ Grains
abstract: Chewy, hearty grains like spelt, kamut and farro, often sold as wheat berries, are a relatively recent arrival on American plates.
lead_paragraph: “Ancient grains” seems to be a new buzz phrase in the world of whole foods (or maybe I’ve been missing something for a long time). The words describe grain varieties that have been eaten as staples for hundreds if not thousands of years. Some of these have fed people in far-flung parts of the world for a very long time but have been of little interest as a food on the American market. Grains like sorghum have been grown here but fed primarily to animals, whereas sorghum has been a staple for centuries in Africa and India.

headline: Online Currency Exchange Accused of Laundering $6 Billion
abstract: The case against Liberty Reserve, a global currency exchange, is believed to be the largest online money-laundering prosecution in history, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The operators of a global currency exchange ran a $6 billion money-laundering operation online, a central hub for criminals trafficking in everything from stolen identities to child pornography, federal prosecutors in New York said on Tuesday.

headline: Sorghum Salad With Cucumbers, Avocado and Cherry Tomatoes
abstract: Cooking the grains until they splay helps them absorb the dressing.
lead_paragraph: One thing I’ve learned about cooking sturdy grains like this (and the other grains we’re working with this week) for salads is that they will absorb dressing better if you let them cook until they burst or splay. In the case of sorghum, the grain is done after 50 minutes, but if you let it go for another 10 the grains will burst and the lemon juice and olive oil won’t slide off.

headline: Mack Emerman, Founder of Criteria Recording Studios, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Emerman founded the music-making studio in Miami, where artists like Eric Clapton, the Allman Brothers and James Brown made albums.
lead_paragraph: Mack Emerman, a jazz lover whose hobby recording bands at nightclubs led him to found Criteria Recording Studios in Miami, where dozens of celebrated pop and rock records were made, died on May 17 in Miami Beach. He was 89.

headline: Who Will Stay the Longest? Spurs Have Edge on Red Wings
abstract: San Antonio did what it usually does, win a playoff series, while the Red Wings have been pushed to a Game 7.
lead_paragraph: For a while this playoff season, the San Antonio Spurs and the Detroit Red Wings were locked in a battle for supremacy in the “team that wouldn’t go away” category and they were taking this battle quite seriously, despite coming at it from vastly different directions. The Red Wings were a somewhat faded version of their dynastic selves, stalwarts having retired and a new generation of players making Wings fans check their programs repeatedly, but still, making the N.H.L. playoffs for a 22nd straight season — and needing a big late-season push to do it — forced everyone to stop and pay homage.

headline: Women in Congress Confront the Military on Sexual Assault
abstract: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand is leading a bipartisan group of women in a fierce battle to change attitudes about sexual crimes in the military and the legal system used to address them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shocking the gridlocked Congress into action, a half dozen or so bipartisan female senators are escalating their war on sexual crimes in the military and deploying their outrage, clout and legions of supporters against a rigid military structure and its male-dominated ranks.

headline: A Rare, Pristine Subway Station: See It While You Can
abstract: For now, and perhaps for a limited time only, the recently reopened Smith-Ninth Street station in Brooklyn is the mass-transit portal of many New Yorkers’ dreams.
lead_paragraph: What’s spotlessly clean, freshly painted and doesn’t have rust stains and grime oozing down the walls like the backdrop of an ’80s horror/dystopian future flick? Chances are good that your first answer would not be “a New York City subway station” (except for some of the stations on the Upper East Side, which don’t really count).

headline: The Only Investing Pattern That Matters Is Behavioral
abstract: If you’re looking for a pattern in the stock market, you’re likely to find one. But investors would do better if they focused on their own behavioral patterns.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Anti-Polio Campaign Worker Is Shot Dead in Pakistan
abstract: The attack was the latest on volunteers trying to eradicate polio in northwestern Pakistan, one of three countries in the world where the disease is endemic.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A volunteer in a polio vaccination campaign was killed and her colleague wounded in an attack by militants near Peshawar on Tuesday, a district administration official said.

headline: Popular Governors, and Prospects for 2016
abstract: The Republicans have several widely popular governors in swing states and blue states. But they aren’t always the ones most frequently mentioned for 2016.
lead_paragraph: Last month, we examined the most unpopular governors facing re-election in 2014. Many of the governors with the poorest job approval ratings were Republicans in Democratic-leaning and swing states.

headline: Kipling Letter Says He Borrowed ‘Promiscuously’ for ‘The Jungle Book’
abstract: A British company is selling a letter in which Rudyard Kipling writes that “it is extremely possible that I have helped myself promiscuously” in writing a poem in “The Second Jungle Book.”
lead_paragraph: While Rudyard Kipling spun beloved characters out of creatures like a bear, a tiger, a snake and a panther for his classic story collection “The Jungle Book,” he may have been a bit of a vulture himself and made monkey’s uncles of his readers — at least according to a letter that suggests he made use of outside sources for a portion of the work.

headline: At the Biennale, Venice’s Locals Stage a Show of Their Own
abstract: While the international exhibition is in session, Caroline Corbetta, a curator in Venice, has teamed up with the online retailer yoox.com to turn the focus on local artists.
lead_paragraph: Every other year, the art world descends on Venice for the Biennale, a six-month-long flurry of artistic activity. This year’s Biennale, which opens for previews tomorrow, comprises an international exhibition, 88 different national pavilions and a host of collateral events and shows. The missing piece of the pie, according to Caroline Corbetta, the curator behind Il Crepaccio, a tiny exhibition space based out of the window of a restaurant in Milan, is the involvement of the young artists who actually live and work in Venice. “Every two years their city becomes the real center of the art world, but they draw no particular benefit in terms of visibility,” Corbetta said.

headline: One Area in Which Congress Excels: Naming Post Offices
abstract: Pillory Congress all you want as do-nothing or dysfunctional, as its critics often have. But in one respect, lawmakers in the Capitol are remarkably productive: they name post offices like nobody’s business.
lead_paragraph: Pillory Congress all you want as do-nothing or dysfunctional, as its critics often have. But in one respect, lawmakers in the Capitol are remarkably productive: they name post offices like nobody’s business.

headline: Tamping Down Expectations on China’s Growth
abstract: To understand the Chinese economy, it also helps to pay attention to changes in Chinese politics.
lead_paragraph: The prospects for China’s economy look so challenging for the remainder of 2013 that increasing numbers of usually cheerleading investment bank economists are cutting their rosy growth forecast for China. The release last Thursday of preliminary manufacturing data for May, which surprisingly indicated a contraction in manufacturing activity, was just one more in a series of weak data points.

headline: Jarring Injuries Marked Previous Bruins-Penguins Series
abstract: Boston and Pittsburgh do not have a long playoff history, but in two series Bruins players sustained serious injuries.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Bruins and the Pittsburgh Penguins don’t have a lot of playoff history between them. What they do have – at least from the Boston perspective – as they head into the Eastern Conference finals, which starts in Pittsburgh on Saturday night, is a history of cheap shots and dirty plays that felled two Bruins, one of them the widely admired Cam Neely, who was entering the prime of his Hall of Fame career.

headline: Seared Tofu With Sugar Snap Peas and Sesame Seeds
abstract: When preparing tofu, press as much water out of it as possible.
lead_paragraph: In What’s for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diner’s Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Rebecca Hall to Make Broadway Debut in Revival of 85-Year-Old Play
abstract: The British actress Rebecca Hall will appear in “Machinal,” which has not been on Broadway since the original production in 1928.
lead_paragraph: The British actress Rebecca Hall will make her Broadway debut next winter in a revival of Sophie Treadwell’s 1928 play, “Machinal,” playing a young woman who rebels against the cultural norms of 1920s America, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday. Ms. Hall is a regular presence on London stages, including in several Shakespeare productions directed by her father, Peter Hall. She performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2009 in the Bridge Project productions of “The Winter’s Tale” and “The Cherry Orchard.”

headline: Lulzsec Hacker Pleads Guilty
abstract: Jeremy Hammond, a member of the Lulzsec hacking group, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to hacking a global research firm and admitted to hacking several other groups.
lead_paragraph: 6:27 p.m. | Updated with additional comments from prosecutors and the defendant.

headline: Finding the Route to Happiness
abstract: A couple of new travel booking sites will sort your trip by pleasure, not pain.
lead_paragraph: Travel booking sites have caught on to the fact that people are willing to pay a little extra to avoid headaches like a four-hour layover in Dallas-Fort Worth airport. Hipmunk’s “agony” rating, for example, sorts flights by price, duration and the number of stops.

headline: Judge in Trayvon Martin Case Puts Limits on Defense
abstract: Lawyers for George Zimmerman, who is charged with second-degree murder, have been barred from mentioning Mr. Martin’s marijuana use, among other things, in opening arguments.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Lawyers for George Zimmerman, who is charged with second-degree murder in the killing of Trayvon Martin, will be barred from mentioning Mr. Martin’s marijuana use, history of fights or high school suspension during opening statements in Mr. Zimmerman’s trial, which begins June 10.

headline: Dean in E-Mail Searches Steps Down at Harvard
abstract: Evelynn M. Hammonds, the undergraduate dean, said her departure was not related to the e-mail searches that were carried out in the hunt for a leak.
lead_paragraph: The undergraduate dean at Harvard will step down this summer, she and the university announced on Tuesday, months after she came under fire for her handling of a search of some junior faculty members’ e-mail accounts.

headline: After Day 1, a Look at the Bike Share Program
abstract: With an assist from New York’s Transportation Department, here is a by-the-numbers look at the first day of the bike share program.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, New York City’s bike share program finally reached the streets — unlocking 6,000 bikes for public use across more than 300 stations in Manhattan and Brooklyn. With the skies clear and the streets relatively bare because of the Memorial Day holiday, riders engaged in a series of trial runs and joy rides, saving the commuting for Tuesday morning.

headline: Hobbled Vandeweghe Falls to Shvedova in First Round
abstract: An undisclosed injury and a rain delay helped untrack Coco Vandeweghe in a first-round loss to Yaroslava Shvedova at the French Open Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Coco Vandeweghe shrugged off a disastrous first set but could not overcome a determined Yaroslava Shvedova of Kazakhstan, losing, 0-6, 6-3, 2-6, in a rain-interrupted first-round match at the French Open Tuesday.

headline: Obama to Name New Leader of Economic Advisers Council
abstract: Jason Furman, the deputy director of the National Economic Council, is expected to be named chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, signaling a more powerful role for the group.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is expected to name Jason Furman, the deputy director of the National Economic Council, as the chairman of the president’s Council of Economic Advisers, according to a person familiar with the matter who declined to comment on the record.

lead_paragraph: Berlin might be a young, vibrant, creative city, but during the long, cold dark winter all that youth and vibrancy and creativity is cooped up indoors. This winter was particularly long and cold: average March temperatures were below freezing and it snowed on Good Friday.

headline: Valeant Shows How M.&A. Can Favor the Brave

But after watching Jack Sock over the past week, it seems Sock, a big-serving Nebraskan, may develop into a clay-courter of note in the years to come.

headline: Broadway Attendance Fell Six Percent This Season
abstract: Attendance at Broadway shows fell to its lowest level in eight years, but grosses were unchanged because of rising ticket prices.
lead_paragraph: Attendance at Broadway shows shrank by 6.2 percent during the 2012-13 theater season to its lowest level in eight years, with theater producers blaming Hurricane Sandy as well as a weak lineup of musicals and plays during the fall and winter. Approximately 11.57 million people attended Broadway productions during the season, compared to 12.33 million in the previous one, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers. The last time that attendance numbers were so low was the 2004-5 season, which drew 11.53 million people.

headline: The Holiday Masses Descend, and Bruckner Reverberates
abstract: Alan Gilbert led the New York Philharmonic in a Bruckner work at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

One such event is the New York Philharmonic’s annual free Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, which took place on Monday night. For this program, the music director Alan Gilbert conducted the orchestra in just one work: Bruckner’s 60-minute Symphony No. 3 in D minor.

abstract: The new “Arrested Development” episodes have had their critics, but plenty of viewers found jokes that made them laugh.
lead_paragraph: It’s been just over 60 hours since the new season of “Arrested Development” started streaming on Netflix. Some superfans had the  fortitude to watch all 15 episodes not long after sunrise on Sunday morning. Many of the rest of us are working our way through the show as much as the commitments of daily life  will allow. But just about everyone has an opinion about  favorite Bluth family moments from the new episodes, and whether it’s been worth the time to binge on the show.

lead_paragraph: My only real problem with “Hannah Arendt” is that it’s not a mini-series. Arendt was a writer of long books and a maker of complex arguments, so the two hours of Margarethe von Trotta’s ardent and intelligent film about her are bound to feel somewhat superficial. And the movie, even as it answers a hunger for engagement with the life of an extraordinary mind, may also awaken an appetite for more. Arendt’s work, a heady amalgam of philosophy, history, journalism and political theory, does not easily align with the academic fashions of the moment.

lead_paragraph: To View: The Influence of His HomelandLike his grandfather Diego Rivera, the artist Pedro Diego Alvarado-Rivera takes his inspiration from his native Mexico. His oils are vibrant, ripe still-life and landscape paintings that focus on the country’s fruits and vegetables, like his “Sandia Melonera,” right. A sampling will be on display through June 30: Refined Abundance II is at Ruiz-Healy Art, 900 Park Avenue (79th Street) by appointment from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday to Friday, ruizhealyart.com, (212) 452-1662.

headline: Wines for an Asian-Style Stew
abstract: You could open either red or white with this vegetable-and-veal stew.
lead_paragraph: Wine with Chinese food may seem counterintuitive, but the combination can work quite well, especially with the gentler spicing of Cantonese cuisine. Many wine lovers take advantage of bring-your-own-bottle policies to drink great wines at Cantonese restaurants. You could open either red or white with the Asian-style vegetable-and-veal stew in Mark Bittman’s Flexitarian column this week, as long as the wine has lively acidity so it isn’t buried under the assertive flavors of the food. I would lean toward a white, like a peppery grüner veltliner, especially one of the more age-worthy specimens. An Austrian riesling would also work well, and for a full dose of umami, why not a fino sherry? Among reds, a fresh, fragrant Chinon or Bourgueil from the Loire Valley would match well, and if you prefer a bolder wine, maybe a zinfandel from the lighter side of the spectrum.

headline: Rift Over Air Crash Roils Poland’s Artists
abstract: A political split over the cause of a 2010 air crash that killed 96 members of Poland’s political and military elite has spilled over into the country’s arts sphere.

Now the fissures have spread to the cultural realm, as filmmakers, writers and artists fiercely debate how — or even whether — to portray this still-visceral history.

lead_paragraph: Colorado’s highest court on Tuesday rejected a major challenge to how the state finances public schools, saying the system, while imperfect, conforms to the State Constitution. The ruling by the Colorado Supreme Court, which overturned a lower court’s decision, handed a stinging defeat to parents and school districts that argued that the financing formula was fundamentally unfair and unbalanced, and widened the gaps between “have” and “have-not” school districts. Many state officials welcomed the court’s ruling. They said it would remove the heated educational battle from the courts and return it to the hands of elected lawmakers, who have already taken steps to try to improve how Colorado finances its schools.

headline: My Near Miss
abstract: We can’t reduce medical errors without tackling the culture of shame.
lead_paragraph: IT was probably our eighth or ninth admission that day, but my intern and I had given up counting. I was midway through my medical residency, already a master of efficiency. You had to be, or you’d never keep up. This one was a classic eye-roller: a nursing home patient with dementia, sent to the emergency room for an altered mental status. When you were juggling patients with acute heart failure and rampant infections, it was hard to get worked up over a demented nonagenarian who was looking a little more demented.

headline: Shuttle Diplomacy, Kerry Style
abstract: Though he has divulged few details of his overall strategy, Secretary of State John Kerry seems to be moving in an encouraging fashion on reviving peace talks.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry has seemed perpetually in motion in the Middle East since he assumed office, shuttling from one meeting to another with top Israeli and Palestinian officials over the last four months in an effort to revive peace negotiations. He has divulged few details, and his overall strategy is unclear. But it would be foolish to write off his peacemaking diplomacy, as some have. So far, he seems to be moving in a determined and encouraging fashion on a series of interlocking steps.

headline: Exceptions to Harsh Rules
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Habeas Corpus', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials']
abstract: In two cases, the Supreme Court correctly said defendants should get federal habeas review.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court handed down two important criminal procedure decisions, both allowing defendants to seek habeas corpus review of their convictions in federal court. The 5-to-4 majority, with Justice Anthony Kennedy joining the court’s four moderate liberals, reached the right result in each case. But, in a larger sense, the two decisions show how much the scope of habeas review has been curtailed by the Supreme Court in the last three decades, so that it now must work around earlier precedents to avoid doing injustice.

headline: How to Get a Job
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: The rules have changed in today’s labor market. More employers care about whether a worker can add value, not where a college degree was earned.
lead_paragraph: Underneath the huge drop in demand that drove unemployment up to 9 percent during the recession, there’s been an important shift in the education-to-work model in America. Anyone who’s been looking for a job knows what I mean. It is best summed up by the mantra from the Harvard education expert Tony Wagner that the world doesn’t care anymore what you know; all it cares “is what you can do with what you know.” And since jobs are evolving so quickly, with so many new tools, a bachelor’s degree is no longer considered an adequate proxy by employers for your ability to do a particular job — and, therefore, be hired. So, more employers are designing their own tests to measure applicants’ skills. And they increasingly don’t care how those skills were acquired: home schooling, an online university, a massive open online course, or Yale. They just want to know one thing: Can you add value?

headline: France: Man Dies From New SARS-Like Infection

The man, who died of multiple organ failure in an isolation chamber in a hospital in Lille, is believed to have been infected while vacationing in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, in April. He was first hospitalized late last month, shortly after his return to France, with symptoms described only as digestive problems. While hospitalized, he infected a neighboring patient who remains hospitalized. The virus, known as a coronavirus, has killed 23 of the 44 people confirmed infected since September, most of them in Saudi Arabia.

headline: The Death and Life of Chicago
abstract: An innovative campaign to move “home-less people into people-less homes.”
lead_paragraph: On a 100-degree day last summer, on Chicago’s southernmost edge, Willie Fleming, who goes by J. R. (“It stands for Just Righteousness”), crept up to an abandoned ranch house shrouded in overgrown weeds. The overwhelmingly poor and black neighborhood sits beside a 150-acre, 1,500-unit public-housing complex and is about as far — literally and figuratively — from the Loop as you can get and still be in Chicago. Nearly a quarter of the homes in the area had been empty for at least two years. Usually when J. R. scouts for properties to break into and take over, he looks for ones with unmown grass, a sign of vacancy and disregard. But this was excessive. “I don’t come back here without my air gun,” he said, backing away. A young couple next door had set up lawn chairs on the sidewalk. An infant in only a diaper tottered around them. “That’s the dead-dog cemetery,” the man announced, motioning to the ranch house.

headline: Napoleon Perkins Loses His Leg
abstract: The harrowing medical journey of a Civil War amputee.
lead_paragraph: Napoleon Perkins dragged himself toward the plank road behind the Chancellor house, shot and shells plowing up the ground all around him and apple blossoms drifting into his hair. Moments before, during some of the fiercest fighting at the Battle of Chancellorsville in Virginia, Perkins had been unhitching one of his horses from a Fifth Maine artillery caisson when a rebel shell struck him in the right leg just above the knee. At first he did not realize how badly he had been wounded; but when he tried to walk to the rear, his leg buckled and nearly severed in two. Perkins managed to reach the road and began to crawl across it, but could go no farther. Dizzy but still conscious, he watched the Chancellor house and the nearby woods catch fire and burn, killing many of his comrades who had been similarly wounded in the fight, but could not flee the flames.

headline: What Do ‘50 Shades of Grey’ and a Desire Pill Have in Common?
abstract: The pill is supposed to work by tinkering with the brain’s chemistry. Does erotica do the same?

Bergner’s story is about women who lose interest in having sex. But when you dig a little, you find out that what these women really lose interest in is having sex with their long-term partners. And the women who are taking part in the drug trials are desperate to again feel some lust for their spouse.

headline: Grubman: Dish/Sprint Numbers Don’t Add Up to Shareholder Value
abstract: Jack Grubman, the former Citigroup telecommunications analyst and now an industry consultant, argues against a proposed Dish Network-Sprint deal.
lead_paragraph: Jack Grubman is a consultant to the telecommunications industry through his firm Magee Group. He was a top-ranked telecommunications research analyst on Wall Street in the 1980s and 1990s. In 2003, he settled a lawsuit with the Securities and Exchange Commission over accusations that his work for investment banking clients led him to publish misleading research reports on companies that his employer, Citigroup, advised. As part of the settlement, in which Mr. Grubman did not admit or deny the allegations, he was barred from the securities industry. Mr. Grubman has no role either as an adviser or an investor in any of the companies discussed in this essay. This is his first public commentary since his settlement a decade ago.

headline: 5 Stops on a California Cheese Trail
abstract: A tasting tour across the epicenter of California’s artisanal cheese movement offers far more than just exceptional bites.
lead_paragraph: Marcia Barinaga was showing me and seven other visitors around her ridge-top sheep ranch overlooking the long, slender finger of Tomales Bay and the hills of Point Reyes National Seashore in Marin County, north of San Francisco. As she told us about her flock of 100 East Friesians in a pasture where some of the less timid sheep had gathered around, she bussed the pinkish, wet nose of a ewe. It was an offhand gesture but a telling one, revealing a deep affection for the animals that provide the milk she transforms into cheese in the style of her Basque ancestors.

headline: Reducing Overhead
abstract: Passengers of American Airlines traveling with one personal carry-on item that fits under the seat and do not use the overhead bin can board earlier than some others.
lead_paragraph: Traveling light, without checking bags, saves passengers time on arrival and money in fees. Now, American Airlines has introduced a new incentive: people traveling with one personal carry-on item that fits under the seat in front of them and do not use the overhead bin can board earlier than some others. And customers don’t have to decide in advance; if they have carry-on bags that they were planning to place in overhead storage but wish to board early, they can gate-check one bag at no charge. (The typical fee is $25.) The carrier expects the system to reduce average boarding time, speed departures and thus increase on-time arrivals.

headline: A Passengers’ Bill of Rights
abstract: The trade group representing major cruise lines has recently adopted a passenger bill of rights that includes several measures suggested this year by Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York.
lead_paragraph: The trade group representing major cruise lines has recently adopted a passenger bill of rights that includes several measures suggested this year by Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York. The Cruise Lines International Association adopted 10 rights, including access to backup power, professional emergency medical care; timely information and crews properly trained in emergency and evacuation procedures. The rights apply to American passengers and those who buy their cruise in North America on North American member cruise lines, regardless of the flag the ship sails under. Mr. Schumer called the bill of rights “a step in the right direction” but said that he had questions on the content and its enforcement.

headline: Much to His Surprise, Fiery Tortorella Is Out
abstract: Coach John Tortorella was fired after the Rangers were eliminated by the Bruins in the second round of the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: As Rangers coach, John Tortorella was a creature of certitude — opinionated, volatile and confident to the point of arrogance. He drove his players to throw themselves in front of shots, occasionally criticized them in public and often insulted members of the news media. On Monday, as the Rangers packed up their locker room at the end of another season without a Stanley Cup, Tortorella spoke like a man certain he would be around to fix the team. He even said he was looking forward to training camp in the fall.

headline: Israeli Plan to Conscript Ultra-Orthodox Advances
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: A government panel approved a plan to phase out exemptions from military service for ultra-Orthodox Jewish men, a big step toward regulating a controversial issue.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Under popular pressure to fulfill campaign promises to make the burdens of citizenship more equitably shared, an Israeli government committee on Wednesday approved a proposal to phase out wholesale exemptions from military service for ultra-Orthodox Jewish men.

headline: Burdette Loses Track of Score, Then the Match
abstract: Mallory Burdette got ahead of herself in the second set of her match with Agnieszka Radwanska at the French Open.
lead_paragraph: Mallory Burdette was beginning to pull ahead of No. 4 Agnieszka Radwanska in their second-round match Wednesday morning on Court 1 at the French Open. But when Burdette briefly got ahead of herself, that all changed quickly.

headline: Homes for $820,000
abstract: An 1840 Greek Revival in Maine; a country place in Kentucky; and a 1997 house in San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: An 1840 Greek Revival in Maine; a country place in Kentucky; and a 1997 house in San Antonio.
