lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO

headline: Another Man Convicted in 2011 Killing of an Officer
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: A Queens man who participated in a botched drug robbery that led to the death of Officer Peter Figoski became the fourth defendant to be found or to plead guilty.
lead_paragraph: A Queens man who participated in a botched drug robbery that led to the shooting death of a New York police officer was convicted of second-degree murder and burglary on Wednesday, becoming the fourth member of his robbery crew to be convicted or to plead guilty.

headline: Nasdaq Is Fined $10 Million Over Mishandled Facebook Public Offering
abstract: The S.E.C.’s report said the exchange’s executives proceeded with trading although they knew of programming errors.
lead_paragraph: Nasdaq’s parent company will pay the largest fine ever levied against an exchange for “poor systems and decision making” both before and after the bungled Facebook initial public offering.

headline: U.S. Women on the Rise as Family Breadwinner
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Income']
abstract: Four in 10 households with children under age 18 now have a mother who is the sole or primary support.
lead_paragraph: Women are not only more likely to be the primary caregivers in a family. Increasingly, they are primary breadwinners, too.

headline: ‘Soul Doctor’ to Bring a Singing Rabbi to Broadway
abstract: The success of the musical may shed light on the purchasing power of Jewish theater-goers from the New York region, who were once the backbone of Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Is there still a sizable Jewish audience for Broadway shows? The musical “Soul Doctor” may shed light on the purchasing power of Jewish theatergoers from the New York region, who were once the backbone of Broadway, an industry that now caters primarily to tourists.

headline: Henry Morgentaler, 90, Dies; Abortion Defender in Canada
abstract: Dr. Morgentaler, who was heralded and vilified for his work and his views, won the landmark Canadian Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion nationally in 1988.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Henry Morgentaler, Canada’s most heralded and vilified abortion doctor, who was assaulted and imprisoned for defying restrictive laws but who won the landmark Canadian Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion nationally in 1988, died on Tuesday at his home in Toronto. He was 90.

headline: Food Matters | St.-Tropez’s Sophisticated New Palate
abstract: A lack of fine dining has always been St.-Tropez’s Achilles heel, but that’s changing with an influx of smart new restaurants.
lead_paragraph: No one saw it coming. This summer in St.-Tropez, people aren’t just talking the usual fame and fashion, they’re talking food. Food? In St.-Tropez? Mais, oui! In fact, the only new Michelin three-star restaurant in France this year is La Vague d’Or in St.-Tropez, and Bruno Doucet, the hottest bistro chef in Paris, opened a branch of his famously epicurean La Regalade at the sleek Benkirai Hotel last summer.

headline: Meet James Gorman, C.E.O. and Music Agent
abstract: James Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive and proud father, sent an e-mail on Wednesday promoting his daughter’s music career.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, it’s not uncommon for children to follow their parents into finance. However, Caroline Gorman, the daughter of Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James Gorman, appears headed down a much different path.

headline: How to Make Bank Bail-Ins Work
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: If debt investors are to shoulder the risk of suffering a loss, they will need more confidence about what lurks in banks’ balance sheets.
lead_paragraph: Regulators want banks to be able to go bust like ordinary companies. That means bondholders taking the pain if a bank fails. But if debt investors are to shoulder the risk of suffering a loss, they will need more confidence about what lurks in banks’ balance sheets.

headline: New Flickr: Vast Space for Storage, at No Cost
abstract: After years of falling short, Flickr was reborn last week. And every free account holder gets one terabyte of storage, a vast amount of space.
lead_paragraph: If you ever want to see just how much whining a million Interneters can produce, try giving them something wonderful at no charge.

headline: Knife Attack, Not Vehicle Strike, Killed British Soldier, Police Say
abstract: The Metropolitan Police’s statement on the death of Lee Rigby included a public appeal for anyone who saw the car in the area or who witnessed the attack to come forward.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The soldier who was killed on a London sidewalk last week died of “multiple incised wounds” that he suffered after he was hit by a car, and not from the impact of the vehicle, the Metropolitan Police said in a statement on Wednesday, giving a few details from the findings of a postmortem examination.

headline: Going Without Gluten
abstract: New makeup products are eliminating the current scourge of American diets.
lead_paragraph: It was probably inevitable that gluten, the current scourge of American diets, be eliminated from makeup as well. Even trace amounts, absorbed through lips or eyes, can impact those with celiac disease. The benefits to the rest of the population are less clear, but nonetheless a number of beauty brands, like the ones below, are capitalizing on the current mass aversion to the grain-derived protein.

headline: Cooking With Leaves
abstract: Aside from looking beautiful, your dinner can be wrapped in a green leaf for a number of reasons.
lead_paragraph: Aside from looking beautiful, your dinner can be wrapped in a green leaf for a number of reasons. This culinary technique protects food in a secure, impermeable package. Said leaf-wrapped food — meat or fish or savory mixture — may then be grilled, steamed or roasted. In the process, the leaves add a unique flavor and perfume to the dish.

headline: City’s Largest Public Employees Union Endorses Liu
abstract: The endorsement solidifies John C. Liu’s credentials as perhaps the most pro-union and liberal of the Democratic candidates for mayor.
lead_paragraph: In a boost to his embattled mayoral campaign, John C. Liu, the city comptroller, received the support on Wednesday of the city’s largest public employees union, District Council 37.

headline: Philharmonic Maps Out a Kaleidoscopic Biennial
abstract: From new-music premieres to art museum collaborations, the New York Philharmonic announced plans for an eclectic 11-day series next spring.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Philharmonic announced its 2013-14 season in January, it sketched out a major new initiative, the NY Phil Biennial, in broad terms and a sprinkling of intriguing details. On Wednesday, the orchestra filled in more of the blanks, making clear that it is expanding its contemporary-music activities well beyond the composer residencies, the new-music series Contact! and the special events that it has embraced since Alan Gilbert took over as the Philharmonic’s music director four years ago.

headline: Kremlin-Owned Network Hires Larry King
abstract: The news that the Russian government’s satellite news network Russia Today, or RT, has hired Larry King prompted a wave of derisive comments on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Thursday, 6:40 p.m.>The Russian government’s satellite news network Russia Today, or RT, announced on Wednesday that it had hired Larry King to “host a mold-breaking political talk show” for its American channel.

headline: Unheralded American Tries to Change That
abstract: Varvara Lepchenko, 27, an Uzbek-American ranked 25th on the women’s tennis tour, said that in the end the best way to raise her public profile would be to play better and produce better results.
lead_paragraph: A year ago at the French Open, Varvara Lepchenko was the last American standing, beating Sloane Stephens by a day. With her fourth-round showing, she realistically booked a spot on the United States Olympic team.

headline: A Second Democrat Calls for Silver to Resign
abstract: Assemblywoman Inez D. Barron of Brooklyn is the first Democratic woman to call for Sheldon Silver’s resignation over his handling of Vito Lopez’s sexual harassment case.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY – And then there were two.

headline: Snapshots From Venice
abstract: Highlights from the Venice Biennale by the chief art critic Holland Cotter with updates each day.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the Venice Biennale by the chief art critic Holland Cotter with updates each day.

headline: Dance New Amsterdam Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The organization will continue its daily operations and reorganize as it seeks to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, its executive director said.
lead_paragraph: After years of struggles, including possible eviction because of unpaid rent; cash flow problems; trouble getting foundation support; and the loss of a major rental partnership, Dance New Amsterdam, a dance space in Lower Manhattan, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the center’s board announced on Wednesday.

headline: Hosting a Dog? Check Your Insurance Coverage
abstract: Dog lovers should consider their insurance coverage before hosting pets for a fee.
lead_paragraph: What could be more comforting than heading out of town and leaving your dog not at a cramped kennel, but at the home of a canine-loving friend?

headline: An Endorsement That’s a Blessing
abstract: Benedict XVI, the pope emeritus, has forsaken his red shoes for brown loafers from Mexico, and a nation rejoices.
lead_paragraph: LEÓN, MEXICO — When Pope Benedict XVI retired in February, becoming the first pope to step down in 600 years, Vatican officials were bombarded with vexing questions, including some that may have seemed oddly trivial: What would he wear on his feet? Would he keep the signature red shoes of the papacy?

headline: Food Chronicle
abstract: New books by Elissa Altman, Julia Reed, Raymond Sokolov, Mika Brzezinski and Mark Russ Federman.
lead_paragraph: POOR MAN’S FEAST  A Love Story of Comfort, Desire, and the Art of Simple Cooking  By Elissa Altman  Chronicle, $27.50.

headline: The ‘Signature Strikes’ Program
abstract: The president suggested in a speech that he would set new standards for targeted killings overseas. But will anything really change?
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of a May 27 article in The Times about President Obama’s speech in which, among other things, he mentioned setting new standards for ordering drone strikes against non-Americans, there was this rather disturbing paragraph:

headline: Mozart Never Made It to America, but His Violin and Viola Are On the Way
abstract: A violin and a viola owned and played by Mozart will be used in performances in the United States in June.
lead_paragraph: Though he made his way all around Europe in his brief lifetime, Mozart never found his way to the United States. But a violin and viola that he owned and played will be making their first American appearances early next month, in concerts in Boston and New York. Both instruments will be heard at Jordan Hall during the Boston Early Music Festival, when the violinist Amandine Beyer and the violist Milos Valent offer a chamber music program with the pianist Kristian Bezuidenhout and the clarinetist Erich Hoeprich (June 10). The instruments will also be on display at the festival’s exhibition on June 12.

headline: Newsweek Is Put Up for Sale
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Magazines']
abstract: An internal memo widely circulated on the Internet disclosed plans to sell the magazine and focus on The Daily Beast.
lead_paragraph: Newsweek, the once-venerable magazine that experienced one of the most precipitous declines in media over the last decade, is up for sale.

headline: Was Wali ur-Rehman an ‘Imminent' Threat?
abstract: Wali ur-Rehman, deputy leader of the Pakistani Taliban, was killed by a drone strike in the North Waziristan area of Pakistan early Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Wali ur-Rehman, deputy leader of the Pakistani Taliban, was killed by a drone strike in the North Waziristan area of Pakistan early Wednesday morning.

headline: Another World to Conquer
abstract: Aby Rosen, already a real estate mogul and world-class art collector, is now setting his sights on the city’s night-life scene.
lead_paragraph: Aby Rosen, already a real estate mogul and world-class art collector, is now setting his sights on the city’s night-life scene.

headline: Making His Life the Party
abstract: Aby Rosen, already a real estate mogul and world-class art collector, is setting his sights on the city’s night life.
lead_paragraph: The Paramount Hotel in Times Square may not have hosted a spectacle like this since the ’40s, when Billy Rose, the hallowed New York showman, trotted out 6-foot-tall showgirls for Broadway divas and Hollywood stars.

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack a Red Cross Compound in Eastern Afghanistan
abstract: The violence shocked the Red Cross, which said it was the first time in its more than 30 years in Afghanistan that its offices had been attacked.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a shock to humanitarian aid workers, suicide bombers in eastern Afghanistan on Wednesday assaulted the offices of the International Committee of the Red Cross, an organization that has worked in the country for more than 30 years without suffering a concerted attack and has received praise from all sides.

headline: For Medicare, Immigrants Offer Surplus, Study Finds
abstract: The findings by researchers at Harvard Medical School go against the notion that immigrants are a drain on federal health care spending.
lead_paragraph: Immigrants have contributed billions of dollars more to Medicare in recent years than the program has paid out on their behalf, according to a new study, a pattern that goes against the notion that immigrants are a drain on federal health care spending.

headline: I.P.O. for Empire State Building Wins Backing of Shareholders
abstract: More than 80 percent of stakeholders have backed a planned I.P.O., but opposition remains.
lead_paragraph: After more than a year of intense behind-the-scenes battles, stakeholders that own the Empire State Building approved a plan this week to sell the 102-story tower as part of an initial public offering.

headline: Joséphine De La Baume, A Life Kissed by Success
abstract: Joséphine de La Baume, best known as the wife of the producer Mark Ronson, has a rebellious streak and is in a new vampire film.
lead_paragraph: Tiny, curvy and with a voice scratchy from cigarettes, Joséphine de La Baume was picking at a plate of sautéed greens at the Bowery Hotel. Outside, on a sunny April afternoon, a line of paparazzi waited impatiently.

headline: An Inside Look at the Beatles: Ringo’s Photos
abstract: A collection of photographs by Ringo Starr will be published next month as an e-book, and in December as a physical (and expensive) one.
lead_paragraph: During his lengthy solo turn in “A Hard Day’s Night,” Ringo Starr takes a walk around London with a camera, snapping pictures and getting into trouble. Perhaps because of that image, Mr. Starr came to be thought of as the biggest shutterbug among the Beatles, and until he lost much of his collection in a fire in Los Angeles in 1979 he was believed to be the group’s unofficial archivist and memorabilia collector.

headline: Bachmann: Three Missed Opportunities
abstract: The Times’s Michael D. Shear highlights the ways Michele Bachmann could have changed politics but didn’t.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Michael D. Shear highlights the ways Michele Bachmann could have changed politics but didn’t.

headline: Daft Punk Is No. 1 on Album Chart
abstract: The French dance duo had the second biggest opening week so far this year.
lead_paragraph: A long-awaited album by a beloved act, drenched in the sound of vintage disco-funk, gets a lot of advance promotion and opens at No. 1 with a bang. No, not Justin Timberlake’s latest, “The 20/20 Experience.” This week that accolade belongs to Daft Punk, the robot-hatted French dance duo, whose comeback album, “Random Access Memories” (Daft Life/Columbia), has a big start on the Billboard chart.

headline: Another Young American Woman Advances
abstract: Jamie Hampton, a 23-year-old American, defeated 25th-seeded Lucie Safarova of the Czech Republic in the first round of the French Open.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jamie Hampton won three three-set matches to reach the semifinals in Brussels last week, and she went the distance again Wednesday to send off 25th-seeded Lucie Safarova, 7-6 (5), 3-6, 9-7, in the first round of the French Open.

headline: World Coffee Champions
abstract: Two Americans take top honors in a coffee making competition in Melbourne, Australia.
lead_paragraph: Pete Licata of Parisi Artisan Coffee in Kansas City, Mo., won the  2013 World Barista Championship on Sunday in Melbourne, Australia, becoming only the second American to win the competition, which was established in 2000.

headline: Tech Career Advice From Google’s Women
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Senior women at Google give career advice from the trenches, as the technology industry seeks to right its gender imbalance.
lead_paragraph: The women at Google are outnumbered by the men, as is the case at almost all technology companies. Even so, talented women are playing major roles in building new technology, and they have some advice for others in the field.

headline: No Hard Feelings, as Ratner Gives $1 Million to Academy Museum
abstract: His donation to a planned movie museum comes after his unceremonious exit as the producer of the Academy Awards in 2011.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Brett Ratner is not one to hold a grudge.

headline: New York City Wants to Revive Old Voting Machines
abstract: Doubts over the capabilities of the electronic scanners used  in recent elections have prompted a call to pull the mechanical lever machines out of storage for the mayoral primary and runoff.
lead_paragraph: New York City has spent $95 million over the past few years to bring its election process into the 21st century, replacing its hulking lever voting machines with electronic scanners.

headline: Re-Imagining Penn Station
abstract: The Municipal Art Society invited architectural firms to convert Penn into a suitably grand gateway to the nation’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: New York’s Pennsylvania Station is a dog of a transit hub. So, the city’s Municipal Art Society invited architectural firms to dream up ways to turn the station into a suitably grand gateway to the nation’s largest city. Four top firms submitted plans that are dramatic, exciting and sadly improbable. They all face two monumental hurdles.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: Newly released fiction includes a pair of novels featuring old guys rallying for second chances, “Norwegian by Night” and “King of Cuba.”
lead_paragraph: Call it octogenarian chic: This month’s collection offers a pair of novels that feature old guys rallying for second chances. And there are two aggressively imaginative short story collections that resist any labels whatsoever.

headline: American Contractor Held in Cuba Loses a Lawsuit
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: With the dismissal of his case, Alan Gross may find it harder to pressure the United States to push for his release from a Cuban prison.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against the United States by an American contractor serving a 15-year sentence in Cuba for distributing communications equipment there under a State Department program, ending an effort to press the Obama administration into a financial payout and a more vigorous push for his release.

headline: In Match That Fulfills Potential, Monfils Dazzles Home Crowd
abstract: Gaël Monfils advanced to the third round with a 6-7 (5), 6-4, 7-6 (4), 6-2 win over Ernests Gulbis. Roger Federer also won Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ernests Gulbis and Gaël Monfils had never played a tour-level match against each other, but by the end of the third set of their match Wednesday at the French Open, they were chatting like old friends, joking about how long it was taking to resolve their tennis conflict on the Philippe Chatrier Court.

headline: A Calculator to Compare Closing Cost Options
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Is it better to pay closing costs upfront or build them into the cost of the loan and pay them over time?
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever bought a home knows how confusing it can be to decide on the best financing options. Is it better to pay closing costs upfront or build them into the cost of the loan and pay them over time?

headline: Seeing Chechnya’s Wonders, Long Before Getting There
abstract: Anthony Marra’s inventive first novel, “A Constellation of Vital Phenomena,” takes place in Chechnya, a war-weary landscape he first visited only last year, after most of it was written.
lead_paragraph: Six years after starting to think about Chechnya, the disputed Russian republic that became the setting for his acclaimed new novel, Anthony Marra visited for the first time last summer, signing up on the Internet for something called “The Seven Wonders of Chechnya Tour.”

headline: A New Castle in the Realm of Fiction
abstract: This firm step into fictional territory brings out Jeannette Walls’s ear for homespun speech as well as allusions to Charles Dickens, Lewis Carroll and Harper Lee.
lead_paragraph: Jeannette Walls’s new novel, “The Silver Star,” is systematically built, each brick put in place for a reason. It’s easy to understand why writing fiction makes Ms. Walls so methodical. Her memoir, “The Glass Castle,” told a far more painful story, and Ms. Walls surely knows that her personal history colors perceptions of whatever else she writes. “The Glass Castle” remains on best-seller lists eight years after it first appeared.

headline: Spandex (Mostly) on, Those Pole Dancers Return
abstract: “Showgirls! The Musical!” is a sendup of the 1995 movie “Showgirls,” which starred Elizabeth Berkley.
lead_paragraph: If ever there was a movie deserving of a sendup, it’s Paul Verhoeven’s 1995 turkey “Showgirls.” The lurid story of the rise of Nomi Malone from hitchhiker to pole dancer to Las Vegas star, the movie has a script (by Joe Eszterhas) that practically parodies itself. Its ruthless female rivalries, maudlin dialogue and tawdry show-business abuses are catnip for any devotee of camp.

headline: Take My Team … Please
abstract: The hits keep on coming for the Mets, but they are being issued by the front office — intentionally, unintentionally, sometimes witty but more often clumsy.
lead_paragraph: A curious pattern has emerged in recent years in which people high up in the Mets organization take shots at the team.

headline: Senior Editor at Poetry Magazine Gets the Top Job
abstract: Don Share, the author of 10 books, will succeed Christian Wiman as the magazine’s editor.
lead_paragraph: Don Share, a poet with 10 books to his credit, has been named the 12th editor of Poetry Magazine, the Chicago-based publication founded by Harriet Monroe in 1912.

headline: A Vegan With a Dark Side
abstract: The creator of Obsessive Compulsive Cosmetics looks to sci-fi films for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: “Venus’ flytraps are sort of my spirit animal,” David Klasfeld said, referring to the lusty pink and green plant tattoos curling around his bicep. “There’s a line from ‘Little Shop of Horrors’: they say the meek shall inherit, and for some reason people are always telling me how humble I am. But I do know what I’m doing, and if anything I’m trying to be aggressive.”

headline: Hundreds Celebrate France’s First Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The wedding came just 11 days after legislation permitting same-sex marriages and adoptions was signed into law by President François Hollande.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two men wed in the southern city of Montpellier on Wednesday in the first legal marriage between people of the same sex in France.

headline: Berkshire Unit in $5.6 Billion Deal for Nevada’s Largest Electric Utility
abstract: MidAmerican Energy Holdings, part of the Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate controlled by Warren Buffett, agreed to buy Nevada’s largest electric utility, NV Energy.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett dived back into the acquisition pool on Wednesday with a large bet in the energy sector. MidAmerican Energy Holdings, a unit of Mr. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, agreed to buy Nevada’s largest electric utility, NV Energy, for about $5.6 billion.

headline: Letters Threatening Mayor Tested Positive for Ricin
abstract: The first letter was opened at a New York City mail facility in Lower Manhattan on Friday, a second on Sunday in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Two letters that contained threats to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg — one addressed to him, the other to a lobbyist who works on his gun control campaign — have tested positive for the deadly poison ricin, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Colombia, Spain and Vatican City.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Colombia, Spain and Vatican City.

headline: Andy Cohen, Playing to a Tough Room
abstract: A Q& A with Andy Cohen on his first time going to the C.F.D.A. awards and his dream casting for a reality show.
lead_paragraph: Few industries are as ripe for parody as fashion, and yet few comedians have managed to get so much as a snicker out of a roomful of designers when they all come together for their annual awards night each June. Many have tried. Tracey Ullman spoofed the recession in 2009. Last year, Seth Meyers reprised Marc Jacobs in drag, which is a tough act to follow.

headline: Some Grub With Your Rub?
abstract: Here are some of the more interesting (and sometimes edible) farm-to-table spas and treatments around.
lead_paragraph: The farm-to-table trend that has sprouted up in dining rooms across the country is now finding its place in spa rooms from Laguna Beach, Calif., to Cambridge, Mass, with natural ingredients being grown on sprawling produce farms and in hotel rooftop gardens for the sole purpose of being picked, blended and then slathered on clients’ skin.

headline: On Piano, but Lauding a Trumpeter
abstract: Eliane Elias, the Brazilian pianist and singer, highlighted her new album, a tribute to Chet Baker, at Birdland.
lead_paragraph: What does the Brazilian jazz pianist and singer Eliane Elias have in common with Chet Baker? Not much, I would venture. But Ms. Elias’s new album, “I Thought About You (a Tribute to Chet Baker),” is her take on songs associated with the cool jazz trumpeter and singer whose music evokes a faraway gaze into a cloudy sky. Its release coincided with Ms. Elias’s Tuesday evening opening at Birdland, where she led a group that included Marc Johnson on bass, Steve Cardenas on guitar and Mauricio Zottarelli on drums.

headline: A Gala in Venice to Toast China’s Most Famous Dissident
abstract: The Lisson Gallery and T magazine paid homage to Ai Weiwei for his new exhibition, which opened today in Venice for the 55th Biennale.

headline: More Seek a Slice of the Pie
abstract: Credit the recession, or weariness with an increasingly exacting foodie culture, but serving pizza is becoming more common at upscale events in the city.
lead_paragraph: Who says pizza delivery is just for dorm rooms and children’s birthday parties?

headline: A Dose of Russian Music Spikes Up an American Season
abstract: New York City Ballet’s season is enlivened by older works by Robbins and Balanchine, and by some former apprentices in featured roles.
lead_paragraph: Every season by New York City Ballet is, in quantitative terms, the envy of the ballet world. During its current six-week season, for example, the company dances no fewer than 38 ballets. The first 25 were all to American music. Now the company is adding other fare, chiefly to music by Russian composers — principally Stravinsky and Tchaikovsky.

headline: 6 Bosnian Croats Convicted of Killing Muslims During War
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A United Nations tribunal in The Hague found that the former fighters had persecuted Muslim civilians as part of an “ethnic cleansing” campaign in Bosnia ordered by Croatia’s leaders.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Six Bosnian Croats were found guilty on Wednesday of persecuting and murdering Muslim civilians during the 1992-95 Bosnian war. The United Nations tribunal in The Hague that tried the six former fighters said the crimes were part of an “ethnic cleansing” campaign in Bosnia that was planned and coordinated by the leaders of neighboring Croatia.

headline: Winning the MRSA Battle in Hospitals
abstract: Treating every patient that enters an intensive care unit with special disinfectant soaps and ointments drastically reduces the spread of the drug-resistant bacteria MRSA and other bloodstream infections in hospitals, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Treating every single patient who enters an intensive care unit with special disinfectant soaps and ointments drastically reduces the spread of the drug-resistant bacteria MRSA and cuts the rate of bloodstream infections in hospitals, a new study shows.

headline: Comics’ Mother of  ‘the Weird Stuff’ Is Moving On
abstract: Karen Berger, the former executive editor of the comic book imprint Vertigo, ushered in several important writers and now worries for the future of the brand.
lead_paragraph: For Karen Berger, a day at the office used to mean happily invading other people’s dreams and bringing them to life. As the executive editor of the Vertigo imprint at DC Comics, she oversaw illustrated tales of fantasy, speculative fiction and outcast characters who did not fit into the publisher’s mainstream lineup of costumed adventurers.

headline: Promises, Promises
abstract: Domenic Denicola, one of the contributors to the Promises/A+ spec, visited The Times to discuss his work.
lead_paragraph: Async nightmares, the pyramid of doom, nested callback hierarchy, control flow: If you are familiar with any of these terms, you should be familiar with JavaScript promises.

headline: Having Fun Is Hard Work
abstract: Setting up camp in Manhattan is convenient for fans of Kate Spade.
lead_paragraph: As the 1990s waned, every upper middle-class woman in New York City seemed to be carrying a version of the same shoulder bag: a rectangular zippered tote with Kate Spade appliquéd in lowercase on the front, as if on a name tag for summer camp.

headline: Month of Breaking News Lifts CNN and Fox, but Sinks MSNBC
abstract: The freeing of three women in Cleveland and the Oklahoma tornado brought viewers to only two of the three main cable news channels.
lead_paragraph: A second straight month of big breaking events proved one thing: MSNBC is a television news channel that does not gain any advantage when news is being made.

headline: It’s Happy, It’s Danceable and It May Rule Summer
abstract: “Get Lucky,” a song from the French electronic duo Daft Punk that nods to disco, has struck a chord with a broad range of listeners.
lead_paragraph: Students in this year’s high school musical at the School of the Future in Manhattan were milling around the auditorium before a performance the other day, when a senior hooked his phone to the sound system and played a new song he had found online. The beat was pure 1970s disco — smooth vocals, a funky syncopated guitar riff riding over a tight drum-and-bass groove.

headline: Voters Speak, and Amazon Orders Shows
abstract: The company says it used customer feedback in choosing five shows for its Amazon Prime service.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, which has put its foray into original television programming up to a democratic vote, has ordered five series that will be offered on Amazon Prime, the company’s subscription service.

headline: UJA-Federation of New York’s Women’s Philanthropy
abstract: The world’s most successful single-session charity bridge game was started 49 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The UJA-Federation of New York’s Women’s Philanthropy pro-am is the world’s most successful single-session charity bridge game. It was started 49 years ago by Tubby and Sam Stayman and Victor Mitchell.

headline: Pace Picks Up in Fast Data Storage
abstract: Pure Storage, which makes big, fast data-storage devices, announced a new product and an important investor, signaling the continuing coming together of all parts of computing.
lead_paragraph: Get ready for some serious competition in what has been one of the sleepier, multibillion-dollar technology businesses.

headline: Modified Wheat Is Discovered in Oregon
abstract: The presence of the herbicide-resistant wheat, a type developed by Monsanto but never approved, could threaten exports of American wheat.
lead_paragraph: Unapproved genetically engineered wheat has been found growing on a farm in Oregon, federal officials said Wednesday, a development that could disrupt American exports of the grain.

headline: A Necessary Stop
abstract: At “Punk: Chaos to Couture,” the new fashion exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, visitors are immediately confronted with a re-creation of a filthy restroom of CBGB.
lead_paragraph: The breakout star of “Punk: Chaos to Couture,” the new fashion exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is neither the maverick designer Vivienne Westwood nor modern punks like Gareth Pugh and the sisters of Rodarte, but a toilet. At the show’s entrance, visitors are immediately confronted with a re-creation of a filthy restroom of CBGB, the Bowery club that was one of the birthplaces of punk, as it would have appeared in the mid-1970s — drawing reactions, at least among those who remember the original facilities, ranging from amazement to ire. There are three urinals, two toilets with the seats up, two sinks, a bare light bulb, a brick wall, countless used cigarette butts and a whole lot of graffiti, mostly the names of the bands that performed at the club.Patti Smith once said “all the action happened in the toilets,” according to Andrew Bolton, the curator of the exhibition, and it is a place where history is literally written on the walls.

headline: Former Bush Official Said to Be Obama Pick to Lead F.B.I.
abstract: James B. Comey earned a reputation for independence after leading an internal revolt in the administration of George W. Bush over the legality of its warrantless wiretapping program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to nominate James B. Comey, a former hedge fund executive who served as a senior Justice Department official under President George W. Bush, to replace Robert S. Mueller III as the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to two people with knowledge of the selection.

lead_paragraph: Summer Hours

headline: An Espresso Machine Called PrimaDonna
abstract: With a $3,000 price tag, the PrimaDonna S is for those who take their coffee seriously.
lead_paragraph: A different sort of person might test out the PrimaDonna S, a new espresso maker from DeLonghi, and rave that it brews barista-grade espresso in one minute. They might marvel at its fully automatic grinder with 13 settings, its dual heating systems (one for espresso, the other for heating and frothing milk) or the way a high-tech machine capable of making espresso, cappuccino, caffè latte and macchiato drinks at the touch of a button has been ingeniously designed to fit into a slim, stainless-steel box.

headline: The Rewards of Grafting
abstract: Bigger, juicier, better-tasting tomatoes, and more of them.
lead_paragraph: Bigger, juicier, better-tasting tomatoes, and more of them.

headline: In Defense of Grafting
abstract: Who could argue with more productive, disease-resistant fruit and vegetables? Lots of Americans apparently.
lead_paragraph: Grafted heirloom tomatoes are the hot tamale in the garden this year. And it makes sense when you think about it.

headline: Guarding a Fleet of Cooking Vessels
abstract: Treat your pans nicely or they might take revenge on your food.
lead_paragraph: As the family’s Sunday morning pancake and bacon chef, I have long scorned my stove’s front-left burner for its inability to distribute heat evenly. My quest for uncharred bacon, I knew in my bones, would fail unless the gods dropped a Viking range in my lap.

headline: At Rutgers, It’s Time to Move On
abstract: Politicians and other critics are calling for more firings at seemingly dysfunctional Rutgers University, but William C. Rhoden says it’s time for everyone to take a deep breath.
lead_paragraph: Politicians and other critics are calling for more firings at seemingly dysfunctional Rutgers University, but William C. Rhoden says it’s time for everyone to take a deep breath.

abstract: Matthew Lightner, the executive chef of Atera in TriBeCa, uses salt-and-pepper shakers, grinders and containers to suit a range of moods.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Lightner likes food with an element of surprise. As the executive chef of Atera, an 18-seat TriBeCa restaurant with two Michelin stars, he delights diners with a combination of foraged ingredients, technical innovation and unexpected presentations.

headline: Shopping for Salt-and-Pepper Shakers
abstract: Matthew Lightner, the executive chef of Atera, goes shopping for the most commonplace (and commonly overlooked) fixture on the dining table.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Lightner, the executive chef of Atera, goes shopping for the most commonplace (and commonly overlooked) fixture on the dining table.

headline: They’re Called ‘Troubles’ for a Reason
abstract: James Marsh’s “Shadow Dancer” is the latest film to explore the I.R.A. and Ireland’s turmoil during British occupation.
lead_paragraph: In the grim opening to James Marsh’s “Shadow Dancer,” a girl in Belfast sends her kid brother out on an errand and smack into the turmoil of British occupation in 1973. Cut 20 years later to the girl, now a young woman, riding the London Underground, destination unknown. Until, that is, her strange behavior reveals a new calling as an I.R.A. soldier.

lead_paragraph: A St. Petersburg apartment decorated to provoke conversation about a dark era in Russia’s history.

keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Nineteen Hundred Thirties']
abstract: An antiques dealer specializing in the early Soviet period decorates a new apartment in an ideologically sound style.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the restoration of a stately old top-floor apartment in one of this city’s fashionable neighborhoods, the owner swiveled to adopt an entirely new plan. It was more than a shift in the color scheme.

headline: In the Trees, Away From It All
abstract: A lofty brand of architecture is on display in the new reality television series “Treehouse Masters.”
lead_paragraph: A lofty brand of architecture is on display in the new reality television series “Treehouse Masters.”

headline: Houses for Dreamers (and Kids)
abstract: Pete Nelson, who builds treehouses that can cost six figures, says it’s all about plugging into the energy of the tree.
lead_paragraph: Pete Nelson, an owner of TreeHouse Workshop, outside Seattle, is an expert in his field: the design and building of treehouses. Such a distinction once guaranteed a book deal and, indeed, Mr. Nelson has written several lavishly illustrated books on the subject. But these days, being an expert at an esoteric trade more likely leads to a reality show, and on Friday “Treehouse Masters” has its premiere on Animal Planet. It follows Mr. Nelson, who is 50, and his crew as they build one over-the-top arboreal home after another.

headline: Otherworldly Glow
abstract: Jewel-like glass mosaic lamps from Istanbul fill an East Village shop.
lead_paragraph: “A customer walked in and said, ‘I expected you to be an 85-year-old fortune teller,’ ” said Melissa Benovic of Mosaic Lamps, in the East Village. Earlier this year, Ms. Benovic, who is in fact 35, opened the 300-square-foot boutique with her fiancé, Ilker Arslan, 36, a native of Turkey. They were inspired by a visit they had made three years ago to the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, where they saw shop after shop selling glass-mosaic lamps tinted emerald, ruby and cobalt. The fixtures, which have brass fittings and are lighted with LEDs, are not for reading, or for threading a needle. “They are mood-setting,” Ms. Benovic said. “They’re warm, and calming.” Prices range from $55 for a 10-inch-high lamp to $2,500 for a 43-inch-long chandelier. 208 East Sixth Street (Cooper Square). Information: (212) 228-1964 or mosaiclampsnyc.com.

headline: Plenty of Frames, but Not a Picture in Sight
abstract: Luis Pons’s new furniture collection is constructed from an assortment of frames.
lead_paragraph: Last week, at the Wanted Design show in New York, the Miami-based designer Luis Pons presented five furniture groups that incorporate picture frames. In the collection called Frame, for example, classical picture-frame moldings are applied to minimal 1950s-style credenzas, dressers and nightstands, concealing drawers, as shown here. Mr. Pons created his first Frame prototype in 2005, and has made custom versions since. But standard sizes and finishes are now available for the first time.

headline: Namaste, My Little Chickadee
abstract: Michele Quan’s handpainted ceramic houses are designed for small birds.
lead_paragraph: Michele Quan, originally a jewelry designer who made her name as a founder of the company Me&Ro, became a ceramist almost a decade ago and now works in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Many of her handmade stoneware and porcelain objects, including garlands and bells, are meant to dangle from trees. This is also the case with her latest: stoneware birdhouses. “I imagined these becoming part of the landscape, and how beautiful they could be, moving with the wind, with the ever-changing background,” she said. The tubular birdhouses are punctuated by a central hole sized for chickadees, bluebirds, wrens, sparrows and warblers. Other openings are for ventilation and drainage. Each piece is hand-painted, in motifs including stripes, flowers, stylized leaf clusters, a sun and moon, and Sanskrit calligraphy reading “Om mani padme hum,” the mantra of the bodhisattva of compassion. A hemp cord is attached for hanging. Prices range from $250 to $475. Information: mquan.com.

headline: Sales at Flor, Maine Woolens and Others
abstract: Discounts on appliances, kitchen accessories, flooring and more.
lead_paragraph: Furniture, appliances, kitchen and bath accessories and flooring, from B&B Italia, Clive Christian NY, SieMatic and Hastings Tile & Bath, among others, will be up to 85 percent off during the Architects and Designers Building sample sale, June 3 to 7 (the Next vanity at Hastings Tile & Bath, regularly $2,010, will be $804); 150 East 58th Street (Lexington Avenue), (212) 644-2766, adbuilding.com.

headline: A Cup Is at the Heart of a Trademark Dispute
abstract: Not only was Everyman Espresso, with storefronts in the East Village and SoHo, served with a cease-and-desist letter for its store mark, but the state wants compensation, too.
lead_paragraph: First came the tattoo, etched across the knuckles of Sam Penix’s right fist in 2009. It said “I [coffee cup] N Y,” the bold red cup leaping out from the black letters.

abstract: In the race for this year’s Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, the field is unusually competitive.
lead_paragraph: In the race for this year’s Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, the field is unusually competitive.

headline: Rhode Island’s Chafee to Join Democratic Party
abstract: Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, the only Independent governor in the nation and a former Republican senator, plans to switch to the Democratic Party as he faces a tough re-election fight next year.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, the only Independent governor in the nation, plans to switch to the Democratic Party as he faces a tough re-election fight next year.

headline: Video: At Rutgers, It’s Time to Move On
abstract: Politicians and other critics are calling for more firings at Rutgers, but William C. Rhoden says it’s time for everyone to take a deep breath.
lead_paragraph: The Rutgers athletics program has gone from one scandal to the next over the last two months. An abusive basketball coach and the athletic director lost their jobs and were replaced by a coach with a faulty résumé and an athletic director with a questionable past. All of that has brought Robert L. Barchi, the university president, fully into the cross hairs of his critics.

headline: Soldier Is Expected to Plead Guilty in Afghan Massacre
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Capital Punishment', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, charged with killing 16 civilians, will avoid the death penalty if military prosecutors agree to the plea, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier charged with killing 16 Afghan civilians in what is considered the deadliest war crime by a single American soldier in the post-9/11 era, will plead guilty to avoid the death penalty, his lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: Welcome Sight at the Stadium: Jeter Playing Catch
abstract: Derek Jeter, out since last October with a broken left ankle, was on the field playing catch at Yankee Stadium before Wednesday night’s game against the Mets.
lead_paragraph: A handful of Yankee fans who showed up early on Wednesday to watch batting practice saw something to help soothe the wounds from two losses to the Mets.

headline: As Glaciers Melt, Alpine Mountains Lose Their Glue, Threatening Swiss Village
abstract: In a stark example of what’s happening to Switzerland’s glaciers, global warming is melting the ice that buttresses the mountains around Grindelwald, menacing the region with rock slides and flood threats.
lead_paragraph: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland — Marco Bomio recalls that bright Sunday morning in June 2006 as if it were yesterday. Mr. Bomio, 59, a school principal and mountain guide, attended a religious service on a high mountain meadow to mark the founding of a local guide group.

headline: Bachmann’s Retirement Reduces Electoral Risk for G.O.P.
abstract: Some Democrats are giddy that the Tea Party provocateur Michele Bachmann has announced her intention to retire from Congress, but her decision may allow Republicans to avoid a toss-up race in what should be a reasonably safe district.
lead_paragraph: Some Democrats are giddy that the Tea Party provocateur and four-term incumbent Michele Bachmann has announced her intention to retire from Congress — but her decision may allow Republicans to avoid a toss-up race in what would otherwise be a reasonably safe district for the G.O.P.

headline: Twelve Tries to Indy Victory
abstract: Tony Kanaan, winner of the Indianapolis 500 after 12 tries, discussed his lucky charm and life after the race.
lead_paragraph: Tony Kanaan, winner of the Indianapolis 500 after 12 tries, discussed his lucky charm and life after the race.

headline: More Aggressive Action Urged to Curb Hospital Infections
abstract: Treating patients in intensive care units with special disinfectant soaps and ointments greatly reduces the spread of MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: Treating every patient who enters an intensive care unit with special disinfectant soaps and ointments greatly reduces the spread of MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, and cuts the rate of bloodstream infections in hospitals, a study shows. Currently, patients admitted to the I.C.U. are screened for MRSA, and those found to harbor it are placed in isolation. But a study published Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine found that using disinfectant soaps and ointments on every I.C.U. patient reduced bloodstream infections by up to 44 percent.

headline: Prosecutor in Argentina Sees Iranian Plot in Latin America
abstract: Alberto Nisman, who is investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center, said Iran had set up intelligence stations in Latin America to carry out terrorist attacks directly or through Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The special prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center here that killed 85 people released a report on Wednesday claiming that Iran had set up intelligence stations in different parts of Latin America with the aim of carrying out terrorist attacks directly or through Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese militant group.

headline: California: Arrest in Disneyland Blast
abstract: A Disneyland employee was arrested after a small explosion in the park’s Toon Town area, the police said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A Disneyland employee was arrested after a small explosion in the park’s Mickey’s Toontown area, the police said Wednesday. The employee, Christian Barnes, 22, was arrested Tuesday on suspicion of possessing a destructive device; he was being held on $1 million bail. Police believe a dry ice bomb was used Tuesday in a trash can. No one was injured.

headline: Roam the World and Keep the Cellphone on a Budget
abstract: After years of criticism, American mobile carriers now offer overseas calling packages at a small fraction of what they once cost.
lead_paragraph: Getting ready for a summer vacation abroad? Then you have a lot to anticipate: fine food, great wine, historical museums — and thousand-dollar cellphone bills.

headline: A Boost for Players Who Are Far From the Top
abstract: Under pressure from players, including some stars, organizers of Grand Slam events are increasing prize money for “first-week players” who might never get near No. 1.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — At the time, it was the best achievement of his burgeoning career. Somdev Devvarman was 18, had just finished playing juniors, and was a few months from starting at the University of Virginia, where he become a two-time N.C.A.A. singles champion. He was a wild-card entry into a futures event, the lowest rung in men’s professional tennis. He did not expect to win. He did.

headline: The Lock Gets an Update
abstract: The August Smart Lock can be installed over a regular door lock, but is controlled by a smartphone application that lets owners decide which keys work with the lock and for how long.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif. — Yves Béhar, an industrial designer, has helped shape the look of Jawbone headsets, the OUYA gaming console and worked with companies such as Samsung and Puma, and the One Laptop Per Child project.

headline: Woods’s Strong Start Is Lost in PGA Tour Drama
abstract: Tiger Woods has regained the No. 1 ranking and could pull off a feat that has eluded him throughout his career, but his sizzling start has been obscured by off-the-course headlines.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — The Surreal World, a reality TV show produced by PGA Tour Commissioner Tim Finchem and featuring a rotating cast of several dozen golfers from diverse backgrounds who interact on a different course each episode, is being pre-empted this week for a breaking news story.

headline: Tracing Images and Heeding Voices to Learn the Basics of Reading
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Children and Childhood', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)']
abstract: Many fundamental reading lessons that use games, like tracing letters and creating and pronouncing words, are available for Apple and Android tablets.
lead_paragraph: Whatever magical addictive power was infused into my iPad in the factory, it seems to have the strongest effect on my children, who are 2 and 4 years old. They don’t use the tablet just for silly games. They also love the applications that mix together education and play.

headline: New Jersey Sent Welfare Checks to Prisoners
abstract: A lack of internal controls at state agencies is blamed for nearly $24 million in various benefits going to 20,000 people behind bars.
lead_paragraph: Reining in welfare, unemployment benefits and state pension costs have become standard rallying cries for Republican politicians — particularly those with an eye on the White House. But Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who has often talked about his own cost-cutting credentials, was told on Wednesday that the state had been a bit too generous under his watch.

headline: Dish Raises Its Bid for Clearwire
abstract: Dish Network announced a plan to raise its tender offer for shares in Clearwire to $4.40 a share in cash, trumping the most recent takeover offer by Sprint Nextel less than two days before shareholders are set to vote on the latter’s offer.
lead_paragraph: What is Dish Network’s chairman, Charles W. Ergen, up to?

headline: Lewis A. Yocum Dies at 65; Repaired Arms and Careers in Baseball
abstract: Dr. Yocum performed Tommy John surgery on a number of major leaguers, saving the careers of many.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lewis A. Yocum, one of baseball’s most renowned orthopedic surgeons, who saved the careers of the Washington Nationals’ young pitching stars Stephen Strasburg and Jordan Zimmermann and numerous other major leaguers, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan Beach, Calif. He was 65.

headline: Rodman Not First Choice for North Korea Trip
abstract: The creators of “Vice,” an HBO newsmagazine, said the former basketball star Dennis Rodman was asked to visit North Korea after Michael Jordan said no.
lead_paragraph: Offended by criticism that Dennis Rodman’s basketball diplomacy was a marketing gimmick for their season finale on North Korea, the creators of “Vice,” a new HBO newsmagazine with a penchant for daredevilish themes, said Wednesday that Mr. Rodman had improved the program but was not even their first choice.

headline: Amid Protests Over Free Tuition, Mayor Urges Graduates to Donate
abstract: Speaking at Cooper Union’s commencement ceremony on Wednesday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg urged the new alumni to give back to their school.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg opened his address to newly minted Cooper Union graduates on Wednesday with a few well-researched jokes about some of the college’s best-loved institutions: the notoriously difficult professor; the grueling senior project; the campus watering hole.

headline: Clarence Burke Jr., Singer in the R&B Hit ‘O-o-h Child,’ Dies at 64
abstract: Mr. Burke was the lead singer of the Five Stairsteps, a sibling rhythm-and-blues group that had its best-known hit in 1970.
lead_paragraph: Clarence Burke Jr., the lead singer of the Five Stairsteps, a sibling rhythm-and-blues group that had its best-known hit in 1970 with “O-o-h Child,” died on Sunday in Marietta, Ga. He had turned 64 the day before.

headline: 2 Diplomats Met Uneven Fates in Benghazi Uproar
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: In the political tempest over the attacks on Americans in Benghazi, Libya, Victoria Nuland escaped the kind of harsh criticism leveled against Susan E. Rice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The political tempest over last September’s deadly attacks on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, has left a path of dented careers in its wake. But as with many storms, the residual damage is proving to be distinctly uneven.

headline: Documents Show Obama Officials in Tension Over British Banks
abstract: HSBC and Standard Chartered were fined for funneling illicit money, rather than indicted.
lead_paragraph: Government documents have recently emerged that offer a rare behind-the-scenes glimpse into the Obama administration’s decision-making as it prepared to take actions against two big British banks.

headline: Detroit’s Davos
abstract: Contemplating selling off the assets of a failing city.
lead_paragraph: ONCE a year, business and political leaders from metropolitan Detroit travel to an island resort that bans all motorized vehicles and talk about the regional economy.

headline: Ecology Lessons From the Cold War
keywords: ['Cold War Era', 'Biodiversity', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Biodiversity was a survival strategy for the next global conflict.
lead_paragraph: CORVALLIS, Ore. — TODAY the effort to preserve the planet’s biodiversity is often seen as a campaign to save the whales for their own sake, or to give polar bears a few more winters on the Arctic ice. But in the 1950s, when the concept was first discussed, it was understood that far more was at stake. The “conservation of variety,” as it was called during the early years of the cold war, was no less than a strategy of human survival.

headline: Gitmo’s Other Prisoner
abstract: President Obama has become imprisoned not at Guantanamo but by it.
lead_paragraph: On the front page of its Memorial Day weekend edition last Friday, USA Today ran an arresting article under the headline: From Boyhood to the Battlefield. The photo of a young boy with a baseball bat over his shoulder, staring forthrightly into the camera, promised a feel-good holiday story, a promise quickly dashed by the headline’s smaller type: “These children of 9/11 died fighting its war.”

headline: Winning the Close Ones Is Working Fine for the Kings
abstract: Los Angeles, the defending Stanley Cup champion, defeated San Jose in Game 7 to advance to the Western Conference finals. Last year, the Kings did not reach a Game 7 in any series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For a team that has been to the summit, the defending Stanley Cup champion Los Angeles Kings have managed to conquer quite an assortment of new challenges this postseason.

headline: Otto Muehl, Actionist Artist And Provocateur, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Muehl’s art was sometimes considered a threat to public morality; at other times it was simply considered a threat to public safety.
lead_paragraph: Otto Muehl, an artist whose work combined sex, violence, gastronomy and bodily effluence with unbridled abandon, died on Sunday at his commune near Faro in southern Portugal. He was 87 and had lived in Portugal since 1997, when he was released from an Austrian prison after being convicted of having sex with minors.

headline: Members of Rutgers Panel See Flawed Hiring Process
abstract: With questions mounting about Athletic Director Julie Hermann’s past, two members of the Rutgers search committee criticized a hiring process that they said felt secretive and rushed.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon, as politicians and major Rutgers donors were publicly criticizing the university for hiring Julie Hermann, an athletic director with a checkered history, the leaders of the search committee sent an e-mail to the group’s members assuring them that the process that led to Hermann’s hiring had been fair and transparent.

headline: Belief Is the Least Part of Faith
abstract: It is more helpful to think about faith as the questions people choose to focus on, rather than the propositions observers think they must hold.
lead_paragraph: Some Sundays ago, I was part of a sermon in my university’s church. It was the kind of ecumenical church in which I’d grown up. The minister and I sat on the proscenium above the congregation and below the stained-glass windows, and spoke about the ways that evangelical Christians understood God — a subject on which I had written a book. Afterward, there was a lunch open to the community. The questions people asked as we ate our avocado-and-cheese sandwiches circled around the puzzle of belief. Why do people believe in God? What is our evidence that there is an invisible agent who has a real impact on our lives? How can those people be so confident?

headline: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., a target of attacks from Republicans, faces fresh complaints over the Justice Department’s campaign against leaks to journalists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., a lightning rod of Republican attacks during President Obama’s first term, is now contending with a new round of criticism over the Justice Department’s campaign against leaks to the news media.

headline: Bachmann Bows Out
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If there’s one thing that Bachmann’s time in Congress has taught me it’s this: Don’t trust anything that comes out of her mouth.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota’s rhetorical Molotov-cocktail-throwing congresswoman, Michele Bachmann, will not be returning to the House of Representatives. (Pause for applause.)

headline: Michele, Here’s the Bell
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Michele Bachmann says that this will be her last term in Congress. This is truly the end of an era!
lead_paragraph: If Michele Bachmann leaves Congress, does that mean the end of the Light Bulb Freedom of Choice Act? That was pretty much my favorite Michele Bachmann piece of legislation.

headline: The School-to-Prison Pipeline
abstract: A task force urges New York City’s schools to adopt new approaches to discipline that would not criminalize minor misbehaviors.
lead_paragraph: School officials across the country responded to a surge in juvenile crime during the 1980s and the Columbine High School shootings a decade later by tightening disciplinary policies and increasing the number of police patrolling public schools. One unfortunate result has been the creation of a repressive environment in which young people are suspended, expelled or even arrested over minor misbehaviors — like talking back or disrupting class — that would once have been handled by the principal.

headline: An Opening to Strengthen Chemical Regulations
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Chemicals', 'Editorials']
abstract: A bipartisan bill introduced in the Senate deserves to be passed because it would be a significant advance over the current Toxic Substances Control Act.
lead_paragraph: A bill co-sponsored by eight Democrats and eight Republicans was introduced in the Senate last week to revise the Toxic Substances Control Act, which governs the regulation of chemicals used in consumer products and manufacturing processes. Almost everyone agrees that the law, enacted in 1976, is badly flawed because of the complexity, costs and delays it imposes on regulating chemicals.

headline: A Deal That Could Benefit Mobile Users
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wireless Communications', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Editorials']
abstract: Concessions by Sprint and SoftBank should satisfy national security concerns and make the telecommunications industry more competitive.
lead_paragraph: A federal government committee has cleared the proposed acquisition of Sprint by SoftBank, a Japanese telecommunications company, after securing concessions from both of them that should address national security concerns about the deal. Though they still have to clear a few more hurdles, the deal’s approval by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is encouraging news.

headline: Salvadoran Court Denies Abortion to Ailing Woman
abstract: In a 4-to-1 ruling, El Salvador’s highest court said that “the rights of the mother cannot be privileged over those” of the fetus. But the woman’s lawyer described the decision as “misogynistic.”
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — El Salvador’s highest court on Wednesday denied an appeal from a woman with a high-risk pregnancy to be allowed to undergo an abortion, upholding the country’s strict law banning abortion under any circumstances.

headline: What to Watch on Day 5 at the French Open
abstract: Six second-round matches worth viewing during Thursday’s action at Roland Garros.
lead_paragraph: With the tournament back on schedule after Tuesday’s postponements, here are six second-round matches worth viewing during Thursday’s action at Roland Garros. The rain, however, may again throw things off schedule.

headline: An Ode to John Tortorella
abstract: An appreciation of the former Rangers coach, in poem form, using his own words from his time with the team.
lead_paragraph: John Tortorella’s lasting legacy with the Rangers will not, alas, be a Stanley Cup. Instead, he will mostly be remembered for his verbal sparring with the New York news media. lead_paragraph: An Italian scholar said Wednesday that he had discovered the oldest known complete Torah scroll, dating from the 12th  to the 13th century. The roll, which contains the Pentateuch, or five books of Moses, was stored in the library of the University of Bologna and mistakenly catalogued as a document from the 17th century. Mauro Perani, a professor of Hebrew, said that the scroll was written and its segments of sheepskin sewed together between 1155 and 1225. He said that it was not the oldest known biblical text, but it was the oldest scroll of the Pentateuch found so far. Two independent studies corroborated the scroll’s age through carbon-dating tests, the university said.

headline: Venezuela: Anger Over Colombian President’s Meeting With Opposition Leader

lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan government reacted angrily to a meeting on Wednesday between an opposition leader and President Juan Manuel Santos of neighboring Colombia. The foreign minister of Venezuela, Elías Jaua, threatened to terminate his nation’s role as a facilitator of peace talks between Colombia and that country’s largest rebel group. Mr. Jaua lashed out in a television broadcast at Mr. Santos for meeting in Bogotá, Colombia, with the opposition leader Henrique Capriles Radonski, who narrowly lost an April election won by Nicolás Maduro, the handpicked successor of Venezuela’s longtime president, Hugo Chávez. Mr. Chávez died in March. “President Santos has taken a step that, it must be said, will lead in a painful way to the derailing of the good relations we have,” Mr. Jaua said. He said that Mr. Maduro had recalled the country’s representative to the peace talks to discuss the situation. Colombia and the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, began peace negotiations in Havana last fall. Mr. Santos had praised Mr. Chávez, who had close ties to the FARC, for helping bring them to the table.

headline: Colum McCann’s Radical Empathy
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: Four years after the publication of “Let the Great World Spin,” Colum McCann’s magnificent, cathartic 9/11 novel continues to help people cope with tragedy.
lead_paragraph: In Colum McCann’s apartment, on the ninth floor of an elegant building just off Central Park, there’s a room where he writes that looks as if it were airlifted in from the woods. It’s all rough-hewed floorboards and shelves made of unvarnished pine and two-by-fours and a long, thick cedar slab for a desk. At one end of that desk there’s a space that used to be a closet, but at McCann’s request, the friend who built the office took off the door and put a platform in there, and this is where McCann writes, “in the cupboard,” as he put it. “It concentrates my vision. No windows, two very tight walls.” He sits on a couple of cushions with his computer on his lap. On the wall beside him are dozens of messages scrawled by friends and kids and fellow writers and some by McCann himself: “What is the source of our first suffering? It lies in the fact that we hesitated to speak. It was born in the moment when we accumulated silent things within us.” “Keep yourself away from answers, but alive in the middle of the question.” “Stay rotten.” “Hi, Dad, I love you.”

headline: Perry Chen and Theaster Gates on Community-Driven Creativity
abstract: The Kickstarter co-founder Perry Chen understands how communities can fuel creativity. The artist Theaster Gates knows how creativity can invigorate a community. What happens when they put their heads together?
lead_paragraph: The Kickstarter co-founder Perry Chen understands how communities can fuel creativity. The artist Theaster Gates knows how creativity can invigorate a community. What happens when they put their heads together?At first glance, an Internet entrepreneur and an artist seem to operate in different creative spheres. Yet Perry Chen, the co-founder and C.E.O. of the crowd-funding Web site Kickstarter, and Theaster Gates, a Chicago art star-cum-urban planner, actually think they have a lot in common. Kickstarter began in 2009, and since then the site has raised more than $500 million for 40,000 projects — from Iraq war documentaries to Brooklyn restaurants — revolutionizing the way creative ideas are financed in the digital age. Theaster Gates’s artistic practice, which encompasses everything from sculpture to a roving choir, is in its way just as groundbreaking. On his own block on the South Side of Chicago, Gates has engineered a miniature urban utopia, turning the once-blighted buildings that surround him into artist residencies, a library and even a cinema house that shows works by aspiring filmmakers from the neighborhood. Both Gates’s and Chen’s work may inspire social change, but it’s the power of creativity, not of compassion, that spurs them from one genre-defying innovation to the next.

But next up is an Off Broadway play, “Cinderella/Cendrillon,” which will begin performances at New York Theater Workshop in May 2014, the theater announced on Thursday. The adaptation, based on the Brothers Grimm version of the tale, is written and directed by the French theater artist Joel Pommerat, who founded the Compagnie Louis Brouillard in 1990 and has worked at several Parisian theaters. The play has been translated into English and is the fourth and final production of the theater’s 2013-14 season.
