headline: From Quinn, a Memoir More Personal Than Political
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, offers a look at her transformation from middle-class Long Island daughter to front-runner for mayor of New York.
lead_paragraph: When her future wife made clear during one of their early dates that she could only be with a Yankees fan, Christine C. Quinn did not hesitate: “I dumped the Mets in a hot second.”

headline: Maison Premiere
abstract: Inside the lively oyster bar in Williamsburg that expanded its menu but kept its French Quarter feel.
lead_paragraph: Inside the lively oyster bar in Williamsburg that expanded its menu but kept its French Quarter feel.

headline: Revel in the Roar of the Crowd
abstract: At Maison Premiere in Williamsburg, the food is best appreciated as a series of lovely, fleeting moments.
lead_paragraph: The tight room is astonishingly loud, verging on raucous, but still the waiters murmur, hands behind their backs.

headline: Questions, and Opinions, About Flickr
abstract: Tips on downloading a photo, a complaint about the new presentation and other reader comments about the sudden changes to the online photo gallery Flickr.
lead_paragraph: My column this week about the new, revised Flickr has generated plenty of responses from readers.

headline: Resisting Conformity in Thailand
abstract: Thai schools are a drill sergeant’s dream. Discipline and conformity rule, but some students have begun calling for the abolition of the “mechanistic” education system.
lead_paragraph: Thai schools are a drill sergeant’s dream. Discipline and conformity rule, but some students have begun calling for the abolition of the “mechanistic” education system.

headline: The Icing on the Cake
abstract: It’s hard to take a bad photo of a sumptuous dessert.
lead_paragraph: Outtakes is a behind-the-scenes glimpse of images in the Dining section. Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

headline: Why We Are Hiring Outsiders to Critique Our Performance
abstract: Practice makes perfect only if you are practicing how to do things perfectly.
lead_paragraph: Sonu Panda is an animal.

headline: Lee Radziwill and Sofia Coppola, on Protecting Privacy
abstract: Sofia Coppola’s own life is the very picture of elegant discretion. Who better to critique a celebrity-obsessed generation that overshares and hyperconsumes?
lead_paragraph: Sofia Coppola’s own life is the very picture of elegant discretion. Who better to critique a celebrity-obsessed generation that overshares and hyperconsumes?

headline: The Gun Report: May 30, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On April 4, we reported that in ten U.S. states, gun deaths now outpace auto deaths.

headline: Mayor’s Fierce Stand Against Guns Creates Lightning Rod
abstract: By positioning himself as a counterweight to the politically potent firearms lobby, Michael R. Bloomberg has become a target.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the Connecticut school massacre in December, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took to television, radio and the Web to demand action on gun control.

headline: Why I Want to Choose the ‘Disadvantaged’ Local School (and Why I Might Not)
abstract: Our neighborhood has a charming, but struggling, neighborhood school — but the neighborhood kids don’t go there.
lead_paragraph: When I ask other parents of preschoolers in my urban San Diego neighborhood where they’re planning to send their little ones to kindergarten, the name of our local K-5 virtually never comes up. Because of the “Choice Program” in our district, parents can apply to send their kids to almost any public school in the system. So parents in our neighborhood opt for magnet schools, charter schools or even the garden-variety public school a couple of miles away that gets better test scores than our “zone school” does. Or they skip the public options altogether and commute to schools with the words “Country Day” or “Our Lady” in their names.

headline: Unions Press to End Special Trade Status for Bangladesh
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Organized Labor', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)']
abstract: After several deadly factory disasters in Bangladesh, Obama administration officials remain conflicted over what measures would work best to improve labor conditions there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After several deadly factory disasters in Bangladesh — including the collapse of an eight-story garment factory last month that left at least 1,127 people dead — labor advocates are stepping up pressure on the Obama administration, calling for it to convey its disapproval of working conditions in the country by revoking its special trade status.

headline: A Workout With Plenty of Bounce
abstract: At JumpLife, a group fitness studio in TriBeCa, the workout is on trampolines.
lead_paragraph: A group of 25 men and women jumped to the beat of Lady Gaga’s “Americano” in a darkened room amid the glittering of a disco ball, the flashing of neon lights and the streaking of green, blue and red lasers. The scene could have been mistaken for a happening nightclub, but it was actually a recent class at JumpLife, a fitness studio in TriBeCa where the bouncing takes place on personal, low-to-the-ground trampolines, not a dance floor.

headline: ‘The Big Bang Theory’ and ‘The Mary Tyler Moore Show':  A Comparison
abstract: Sheldon is the new Rhoda.
lead_paragraph: This past weekend’s Riff essay looked at “The Big Bang Theory” — a hit network sitcom that I was late to accept but quick to love. The show’s strong ensemble cast also brought to mind an unlikely comparison: “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” a more critically lauded success that featured, arguably, the best sitcom ensemble cast of all time. Here, an unscientific analysis of the main characters on “Mary Tyler Moore” with their surprising “Big Bang Theory” doubles.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: Tips on how an unmarried couple can split the costs of attending a wedding and dressing a nontraditional bridesmaid.
lead_paragraph: A Time to Step Back

headline: The Brooklyn Breaker of Ancient Codes
abstract: “The Riddle of the Labyrinth” by Margalit Fox honors an unheralded hero in the decoding of Linear B, an ancient script discovered in Crete.
lead_paragraph: The events of the past grow more alien as our distance from them increases, receding until they become, finally, unknowable. Unknowable, that is, but for those who take it upon themselves to decode the symbols, to examine what others see as indecipherable or unimportant, to sift a story from the chaff and to resurrect names, places, actions and ideas that would otherwise be lost.

headline: Dots, a Highly Addictive Game, Passes 3 Million Players
abstract: Dots is addictive and very popular. More than three million people have downloaded the game since its debut in May, and now there’s an updated version that increases the competitive ante.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon my entire family sat in my sister’s living room, fingers jabbing at our iPhones, as we yelled a series of numbers aloud: “124!” “217!” “Oh, I just got to 400!” We were playing Dots, the highly addictive free game from Betaworks. (I won, with 474 points.)

headline: When Painters Showed the War in More Than Blue and Gray
abstract: “The Civil War and American Art” at the Metropolitan Museum rounds out an earlier exhibition about photography and the war.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve seen the awesome, soul-wrenching “Photography and the American Civil War” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, you might suppose that a second exhibition about the war would be redundant. It’s not. “The Civil War and American Art,” also at the Met, is a gripping show that sheds further light on how the nation experienced its fratricidal conflict. Organized by Eleanor Jones Harvey, senior curator at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, it is not the broad survey that its title suggests. It is a lean, pointedly selective show, consisting of about 60 paintings, from 1852 to 1877 — including outstanding works by Frederic Edwin Church, Sanford Robinson Gifford and Winslow Homer — and 18 photographs taken during the war.

headline: Youth Brigade at French Open Is Dwindling
abstract: The last teenager in the men’s singles lost on Thursday at the French Open as the days of youngsters crowding the courts seem to be receding.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The last teenager in the men’s singles draw at the French Open lasted until 4:04 p.m. Paris time on Thursday, and Lucas Pouille, a young Frenchman, would have been eliminated sooner by Grigor Dimitrov if not for a couple of rain delays.

headline: Succession Carousel at General Electric
abstract: The potential exit of GE Capital’s chief shifts the spotlight onto succession for his boss, Jeffrey Immelt.
lead_paragraph: The potential exit of GE Capital’s chief shifts the spotlight onto his boss, Jeffrey Immelt. Michael Neal, who has led General Electric’s erstwhile high-flying lending unit for eight years, may be soon handing the helm to someone else, according to The Wall Street Journal. His departure raises the question of who will eventually succeed the conglomerate’s top dog.

headline: Can’t Smell or Breathe, but Checks Keep Coming
abstract: In “Marcellus Shale,” townspeople of Rock Valley (site of fracking) try just to sit back and enjoy the monthly checks from the gas company, but that isn’t always easy.
lead_paragraph: Things have changed in Rock Valley in 2016.

headline: Weight Loss May Ease Psoriasis
abstract: Losing weight may help to allay the red, scaly skin patches of psoriasis, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Losing weight may help reduce symptoms of psoriasis, a new study shows.

headline: This Time, a Growing Economy Stirs Unease
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Some argue for restraint in the face of a recovery in housing, interest rates and consumer confidence.
lead_paragraph: The American markets are getting worried again. But this time the fear is refreshingly different.

headline: Fastballs, Not Dunks, for 6-Foot-10 Hoosier
abstract: Aaron Slegers, a pitcher for Indiana University, is often mistaken for Cody Zeller, the 7-foot Hoosier basketball standout.
lead_paragraph: The gag works because it plays off an easy presumption. Who expects a nearly 7-foot athlete at Indiana University to play anything but basketball?

headline: Bloc Challenges Britain on Welfare Rules
abstract: The European Commission vowed to take the British authorities to court, accusing them of breaking bloc rules over who can receive benefits.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In a move certain to stoke British frustrations with the European Union, the 27-nation bloc’s executive arm is taking Britain to court over restrictions on who can receive social security benefits.

headline: A New Childhood Hazard: Medical Marijuana
abstract: At one Denver hospital, doctors are reporting a rise in marijuana poisonings in children, often after they ate brownies, cookies and other foods laced with medical marijuana.
lead_paragraph: Accidental ingestion of marijuana may be on the rise, according to a new report.

headline: Bank-Friendly Financial Reform
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The treasury secretary sometimes seems more interested in shielding the administration from criticism than in pushing for strong rules.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Jack Lew has defended financial reform recently, but on closer inspection, his defenses are oddly ambiguous.

headline: A Lunch That Tastes Like Nostalgia
abstract: Indulging in a ritual with the author Patricia Volk: tea sandwiches and salad at Bergdorf Goodman.
lead_paragraph: “I’M in your hands,” I told Patricia Volk as she led me through the Beauty Level of Bergdorf Goodman — otherwise known as the basement — into Goodman’s Cafe.

headline: Eastern Conference Finals Preview
abstract: How the Boston Bruins defense copes with wave after wave of Pittsburgh Penguins attackers should be intriguing.
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Penguins and the Boston Bruins have not met in the playoffs in 21 years, but you would not know from the simmering resentment Bruins fans feel toward the Penguins about Ulf Samuelsson’s hit during the 1991 playoffs that left Cam Neely with a career-shortening leg injury and Matt Cooke’s blindside hit during the 2009-10 season that gave Marc Savard a career-shortening concussion. Boston forward Milan Lucic noted this week that the Savard hit was “still in the back of your mind, but it’s not the focal point.”

headline: Western Conference Finals Preview
abstract: The Chicago Blackhawks have regained their offensive potency and the Los Angeles Kings have returned to their domineering defensive ways.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. Western Conference finals feature the 2012 champion Los Angeles Kings and the Chicago Blackhawks, who won the 2013 Presidents’ Trophy. This matchup features the last two teams from the West to win the Stanley Cup, though each team had its mettle tested by semifinal showdowns that reached seven games.

headline: Diverse Mix of Candidates Weigh In on an Obscure Jewish Ritual
abstract: Seven Democrats who want to be mayor were asked for their stances on a city requirement of a parental consent form for a specific Orthodox Jewish circumcision practice.
lead_paragraph: It is a measure of the multicultural finesse it takes to run for mayor in New York City that seven Democratic candidates — including some of Chinese, Latino, Irish and Italian backgrounds — have staked out positions on an Orthodox Jewish circumcision ritual that is obscure even to most Jews.

headline: Clip: 'American Mary'
abstract: A scene from "American Mary," directed by Jen and Sylvia Soska.
lead_paragraph: A scene from "American Mary," directed by Jen and Sylvia Soska.

headline: At Venice Biennale, Sarah Sze’s ‘Triple Point’
abstract: Sarah Sze, a sculptor who is representing the United States at the Venice Biennale, used found objects to create “Triple Point,” a series of intricate, disorienting environments.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — The Biennale doesn’t open to the public until Saturday, but the art world arrived early for a peek. Artists, curators and creators responsible for this vast assemblage of exhibitions here have been on hand to meet, greet and explain their work.

headline: Directors, and Twins, Who Distrust the Normal
abstract: The directors Jen and Sylvia Soska talk about “American Mary,” which centers on a world where people have their bodies surgically modified as a form of self-expression.
lead_paragraph: Lots of siblings make movies. The brothers Coen (“No Country for Old Men”) are Oscar winners. Andy and Lana Wachowski (“Cloud Atlas”) are a prominent brother-sister team (although Lana was once Larry). But sister directors? And not just sisters, but identical twins?

headline: Their Bedside Manners Need Work
abstract: A look at some horror movie physicians whose malpractice insurance must be abnormally high.
lead_paragraph: If Dr. Giggles ever took the Hippocratic Oath, his eyes must have glazed at the “abstain from doing harm” part. Otoscopes are meant to examine noses and ears, not be plunged into brains. But often in horror movies, doctors don’t heal, scalpels aren’t for surgery and “medicine” only makes life worse. Fans know that syringes crave eyeballs, not upper arms.

headline: Improvised Music at a Purposeful Home
abstract: The musician-run club ShapeShifter Lab, celebrating its one-year anniversary, has become a home for improvised music in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: SKYE STEELE had just raced through an intricate tune called “Man-Made Nemesis” last week at ShapeShifter Lab when he tucked his violin under one arm, issuing an invitation in the form of an order. All the musicians in the audience — he called out half a dozen by name — were implored to join his band, the Railroad Rodia, for a chantlike finale.

headline: What Is Reform Conservatism?
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Medicare', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An agenda for an almost-movement.
lead_paragraph: As I noted earlier this week, there’s been a lot of liberal discussion of conservative reformers recently, ranging from the Washington Monthly’s attempt at a taxonomy of the tendency to Mike Konczal’s recent piece expressing doubts (echoed by my colleague Paul Krugman) about whether the reforming tendency within conservatism adds up to anything significant at all. Reading through the responses to Konczal’s post from “reformish” types, I’m in the rare position of disagreeing ever-so-slightly with my friend and co-author Reihan Salam, who writes:

headline: A Traveling Tennis Fund-Raising Party Hits Paris
abstract: Robert R. Kinas brings a group of donors and tennis players to Grand Slams like the French Open to raise money for cancer research and enjoy a lot of parties.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Since 2006, Robert R. Kinas, tennis fanatic, blood cancer survivor and bankruptcy lawyer with the Las Vegas firm of Snell & Wilmer, has toured the world’s major tennis tournaments with friends and colleagues. They party, play tennis and raise money for cancer research.

headline: ‘Rain Room’ at the Barbican Center
abstract: The “Rain Room” is a 5,000-square-foot field of falling water that uses motion detectors to create a dry path for viewers as they walk through a downpour. It is currently installed at the MoMA.
lead_paragraph: The “Rain Room” is a 5,000-square-foot field of falling water that uses motion detectors to create a dry path for viewers as they walk through a downpour. It is currently installed at the MoMA.

headline: The Fall of Gnomes: Tasteful to Tacky
abstract: A history of hermits and garden gnomes; a new book about Fresnel lenses and the birth of the modern lighthouse; and two books about the trappings of wealth.
lead_paragraph: Posting statues of bearded gnomes in gardens is considered a kitschy affront to nature. But until well into the 1800s it signified that a homeowner had elite tastes for rustic landscape design and pleasant melancholy.

headline: Sexual Violence in India Among Hot-Button Topics at Edinburgh Fringe Festival
abstract: In total the festival will feature 2,871 shows at 273 venues.
lead_paragraph: The gang rape and subsequent death of a 23-year-old woman in New Delhi last year forms the basis for “Nirbhaya,” a new play by the writer and director Yael Farber, to be presented at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer. Ms. Farber, whose production of “Mies Julie” was one of the hottest Fringe shows last year (going on to play in New York and London), has assembled an all-Indian cast for the production, which explores sexual violence through personal stories from the performers.

headline: Plenty of Substance in a New Style
abstract: Bethanie Mattek-Sands, who has toned down her outfits on the court, used a new plan to beat the former champion Li Na at the French Open on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The dress made of tennis balls, the blue hair, the knee socks: together they had come to define Bethanie Mattek-Sands, a fashion iconoclast in a polo-shirt sport.

headline: Fastest Network? It All Depends
abstract: Tests of phone network sometimes get contradictory results, but here’s how to find the best network for you.
lead_paragraph: In a survey of 20 cities, Tech Hive found AT&T to have the fastest LTE service in America. An earlier survey of 77 cities by RootMetrics, a company that measures network performance, got similar rankings, but recorded very different speeds.

headline: Falling for the Anarchy She Was Sent to Fight
abstract: A group of anarchists near the Mason-Dixon line are determined to hold the poisoners and polluters of the executive class accountable for their actions.
lead_paragraph: “The East” is a neat little thriller about ends and means and ethical quandaries. The title refers to a mysterious network of anti-corporate militants whose activities — called “jams” — shade from prankish agitprop toward outright terrorism. The members of the group, who live off the grid in an abandoned house in the wilderness somewhere near the Mason-Dixon line, are determined to hold the poisoners and polluters of the executive class accountable for their actions. Sometimes, as in the case of a pharmaceutical company that has peddled dangerous antibiotics, this means giving the bosses a literal taste of their own medicine.

headline: James Among 3 Fined for Flopping
abstract: Miami’s LeBron James and Indiana’s David West and Lance Stephenson were fined $5,000 each for their theatrics in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It was not exactly Oscar night, but the N.B.A. singled out some of its best actors Thursday, and promptly penalized them for their work.

headline: City’s 911 Operators Use Pen and Paper as Computers Fail
keywords: ['Nine-One-One (911) (Emergency Phone Number)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: Officials said that despite the problems, every call had been answered and emergency workers continued to be dispatched across New York.
lead_paragraph: Emergency operators in New York City have been forced on at least three occasions since Wednesday to resort to using pen and paper to record 911 calls and dispatch workers after their computer system went dark.

headline: Andreas Schulze: ‘Windows’
abstract: A rare solo New York show by the German painter Andreas Schulze works with window images at Team Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Team Gallery

headline: Laddie John Dill: ‘Elementary’
abstract: Laddie John Dill’s “Elementary” gives a spiritual dimension to Light and Space art at Nyehaus.
lead_paragraph: Nyehaus

headline: Wall Street Turns to ‘Boot Camps’ to Train New Workers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: For fees that can exceed $1,000 a day per student, Training the Street, Wall Street Prep and other companies teach basic skills like spreadsheet building and database extraction.
lead_paragraph: Newly minted university graduates who have landed coveted jobs on Wall Street may have impressive résumés and sought-after references. But often, nuts-and-bolts skills like spreadsheet building and database extraction are not part of university curriculums.

headline: Margaret Weber
abstract: Deconstructed carpets are treated aesthetically in Margaret Weber’s show at Ramiken Crucible.
lead_paragraph: Ramiken Crucible

headline: Lisa Ross: ‘Living Shrines of Uyghur China’
abstract: Small shrines of the Uyghur China region are viewed as art in the photographs of Lisa Ross, showing at the Rubin Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Rubin Museum of Art

headline: A Mystery of Smithfield’s Big China Deal: What Continental Grain Will Do
abstract: With its proposed sale to Shuanghui International, Smithfield Foods appears to be eschewing a recommendation by Continental Grain, one of its biggest shareholders, to break itself up. It isn’t clear how Continental will respond.
lead_paragraph: Investors in Smithfield Foods, the pork processor, appeared largely pleased on Wednesday with its proposed $4.7 billion sale to a giant meat producer in China.

headline: Gallery | A Melting Pot of Celebrities Makes Immigration Reform Look Fashionable
abstract: An exclusive first look at portraits by the photographer Albert Watson of celebrities wearing fedoras, part of a new campaign to promote immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: What do the actress Julianne Moore, the funnyman John Leguizamo, the supermodel Christy Turlington Burns and the director George C. Wolfe have in common? They’re among the 15 celebrities brought together by We Belong Together, a new national initiative to promote immigration reform. On a rainy day last week, this melting pot of talent gathered at a West Village studio to have their portraits taken by the fashion photographer Albert Watson, who immigrated to the United States from Scotland in 1970. The resulting black-and-white photos are the calling card for Fedoras for Fairness, an ad campaign created by We Belong Together that makes its debut today with support from the celebrity activist Rosie Perez. “I’m really proud of being a first-generation Puerto Rican-American,” said the actress, adding that America is “supposed to be known as the nation of fairness of democracy and of justice. And right now, the way immigration stands, that is not applied.”

headline: U.N. Court Acquits 2 Serbs of War Crimes
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: In a surprise verdict, two close aides of the former Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic were found not liable for crimes committed by secret combat units they had commanded.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In one of the most surprising verdicts of its checkered prosecution of Balkan war crimes, a United Nations court on Thursday acquitted two close aides of the former Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, spurning the prosecution’s demand for life sentences for his once all-powerful secret police chief and the chief’s deputy.

headline: Watch Your Back, Even in the Family
abstract: Politics, secret agents and strained family relations are part of “Shadow Dancer,” a thriller set in Britain.
lead_paragraph: In the prologue of James Marsh’s taut, somber conspiracy thriller “Shadow Dancer,” the 12-year-old Collette McVeigh (Maria Laird), idly stringing beads into a necklace, ignores her father’s request to go out and buy cigarettes. It is 1973 in Belfast, and the city is a powder keg. Her younger brother goes instead, and is shot to death outside the house in cross-fire between British and Irish Republican Army forces. As the McVeigh home erupts in anguished chaos, the father casts a recriminatory glare at Collette, who is guilt-stricken.

headline: MARIA PETSCHNIG: ‘Petschnigs’ ’
abstract: A rec room environment sets off Maria Petschnig’s performance art at On Stellar Rays.
lead_paragraph: On Stellar Rays

headline: 20 More Cookbooks
abstract: An additional selection of some of the season’s notable cookbooks.
lead_paragraph: THE ANIMAL FARM BUTTERMILK COOKBOOK: Recipes and Reflections From a Small Vermont Dairy. By Diane St. Clair. (Andrews McMeel, $27.99.) A cult is gathering around buttermilk, and St. Clair may well be its high priestess, supplying her product to the French Laundry in California and specialty stores in the Northeast. Buttermilk makes biscuit light, takes the cloying sweetness out of French toast and works wonders in lasagna.

headline: Section A, Airplane Fragment
Policy Lessons From Texas
abstract: Evan Smith, editor in chief of The Texas Tribune, on how the 83rd Texas legislative session may inform the national debate on Medicaid expansion, immigration policy and the Tea Party.
lead_paragraph: Evan Smith, editor in chief of The Texas Tribune, on how the 83rd Texas legislative session may inform the national debate on Medicaid expansion, immigration policy and the Tea Party.

headline: Plague of Corruption Rises Anew in Indonesia
abstract: Despite their democratic turn, Indonesian political parties are increasingly turning to graft to finance their operations.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — Fifteen years ago, Indonesia took its first step toward democracy with the ouster of an authoritarian president. By 2009, the country had one of the most open electoral systems in Asia, with direct balloting to elect government officials, from the president all the way down to district chiefs and mayors.

headline: Cooking
abstract: An ode to bacon, several vegetarian options and the latest from Nigella Lawson are among the summer’s notable cookbooks.
lead_paragraph: A great rift has developed in the world of food. On one side, the unapologetic consumers of meat, red-faced and sweaty from their exertions over the barbecue grill and the smoking hog pit. On the other, the gentle leaf eaters, pale but confident — actuarially, ecologically and ethically. Judging by this season’s cookbooks, Team Green seems to be winning in a rout. But the carnivores are not going quietly.

headline: Fall Out Boy at Terminal 5
abstract: The band, back on tour after a nearly four-year hiatus, performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: The band, back on tour after a nearly four-year hiatus, performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night.

headline: If Only the Grapes Were the Whole Story
abstract: Wineries aren’t required to list ingredients. Don’t consumers deserve that information?
lead_paragraph: Wine has been described as the perfect beverage because the grapes contain all the ingredients necessary to create their transformation. Put grapes in a vat, and over time the yeasts coating the skins set alchemy in motion, converting the sugar in the juice into alcohol.

headline: Gardening
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: “The Flower of Empire,” Tatiana Holway’s lively case for the importance of the Amazonian water lily, is one of the season’s crop of gardening books.
lead_paragraph: Why do we have to go all the way around the world to find what’s in our own backyard? Gardeners have the answer, and it isn’t philosophical; it’s botanical. The way much of our “plant material,” as the nurserymen call it, arrived on American soil is as varied and inspiring a story of immigration as you can hope to hear. And for those of you who like what I think of as the “grain of sand” trend — the world in a bowl of salt or a mackerel — you’re in luck. Now we can find the world in a water lily or a ginkgo.

headline: Travel
abstract: This season’s travel books include new titles by three recently minted septuagenarians with more than a century’s worth of globe-trotting among them.
lead_paragraph: The best of this season’s travel books are marked by a generational split. Three footloose writers in their 30s and 40s probe the back alleys of Ho Chi Minh City, the bike-choked streets of Amsterdam and the ­Taliban-haunted steppes of northern Afghanistan — sometimes paying a price for their curiosity. At the other end of the spectrum stand three recently minted septuagenarians with more than a century’s worth of globe-­trotting among them. Yet their own stumbles and setbacks prove that older doesn’t always mean wiser.

headline: ‘James’
abstract: James, a resident from the West Village, explains why he won't vote for Christine C. Quinn.
lead_paragraph: James, a resident from the West Village, explains why he won't vote for Christine C. Quinn.

headline: A Choice Not as Easy as It Looked
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION', 'Families and Family Life', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: Hypothetically, donating sperm so friends can have a baby is a simple decision.
lead_paragraph: When my husband’s friend Maggie asked him if he would donate his sperm to get her soon-to-be wife pregnant, he said he had to ask me first. It’s the kind of hypothetical question one might pose at a dinner party: “If your friends, a lesbian couple, ask your husband to donate sperm so they can have a child, would you agree?”

headline: If Only This Comedian Could Dish It Right Back
abstract: Marina Zenovich’s “Omit the Logic” delves into Richard Pryor’s life through those who knew him best.
lead_paragraph: Watching the parade of comedy heavyweights and cultural heroes assembled for the biographical documentary “Richard Pryor: Omit the Logic,” my mind wandered to the roast of Pryor by the cast of his 1977 NBC television show. (The unedited version is on YouTube.) As you watch him being flayed by the largely unknown group that included future stars like Tim Reid, Robin Williams, Marsha Warfield, Sandra Bernhard and John Witherspoon — as usual, Pryor was ahead of the times — you can’t wait for him to get to the microphone and take revenge. When he does, he ad-libs a 13-minute rejoinder that’s as cruel and foul (and homophobic) as you might fear and as coruscatingly funny as you could hope.

headline: Retired in America, Reborn in Guatemala
abstract: The documentary “La Camioneta” follows the journey of a decommissioned American school bus as it travels from Virginia to Guatemala.
lead_paragraph: Mark Kendall’s quietly moving documentary, “La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus,” is as modest and farsighted as its cast of Guatemalans who make a living resurrecting discarded American school buses. The movie begins in rural Pennsylvania, where yellow buses — decommissioned after 8 to 12 years of use but still in good condition — are auctioned to bidders, many from Central America.

headline: No Sitting Duck
abstract: Questions about paying the baby sitter, respecting a patient’s privacy, paying child support past the expiration date and corralling the wait staff.
lead_paragraph: I am a nanny and work full time for a single family. Occasionally, I take baby-sitting jobs for other families on my free evenings and weekends. On these jobs, I have been asked often, by several different parents, if I will lower my hourly rate because their children will be sleeping for most of the time I am there. I am inclined to say no. My fee is fair. But since I’ve been asked so often, I thought I might check with you. How should I handle these requests?

headline: European Officials Move to Curb Overfishing
abstract: Officials hailed the deal as a landmark agreement, but environmentalists said it might not be ambitious enough.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Union on Thursday agreed to an overhaul of the region’s fisheries policy, a deal intended to make commercial fishing more sustainable.

headline: Section A, The Making of Struggle
‘Les Misérables’ Sets Broadway Opening Date
abstract: “Les Misérables” will run at the Imperial Theater and begin previews on March 1, 2014, with an opening night of March 23.
lead_paragraph: A Broadway revival of “Les Misérables” will run at the Imperial Theater and begin previews on March 1, 2014, with an opening night of March 23, the producer Cameron Mackintosh announced on Thursday. Casting is expected to be announced later this summer. The original production ran on Broadway from 1987 to 2003. A revival from 2006 to 2008 was described by Mr. Mackintosh as ill-conceived.

headline: Will Rangers Look to the Past for a New Coach?
abstract: Soon after the Rangers fired John Tortorella, the idea with the storybook appeal was in the air: Mark Messier as the next Rangers coach.
lead_paragraph: Almost immediately after the Rangers fired John Tortorella on Wednesday, the idea with the storybook appeal was in the air: Mark Messier as the next Rangers coach.

headline: Suspending Disbelief, as 4 Flee Handcuffs
abstract: “Now You See Me,” directed by Louis Leterrier, follows the exploits of a criminal group of magicians as they are pursued by a dogged F.B.I. agent.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing to watch a magician pull a rabbit out of a hat. It’s quite another to watch a movie of the same thing. Movies are themselves a kind of magic, dependent on technological wizardry. That’s why, when watching a film of a humble magic trick, you feel no sense of wonder, for the stunt has already been accomplished in a medium that’s all about illusion. So what, you shrug.

headline: Mystery in Seattle, but Paris Beckons
abstract: A deal with Netflix that helped save the AMC series “The Killing,” which returns on Sunday, may paradoxically hurt it by leading viewers to the French show “Spiral.”
lead_paragraph: “The Killing,” a spooky crime thriller set in a rain-soaked Seattle that was canceled after its second season, then revived, returns to AMC this Sunday for a third season with a new case, a mostly new cast and a conundrum.

headline: Jack Vance’s Influential Prose Will Live On
abstract: He was famously brusque, and he didn’t like to talk about the craft of writing. But the joy he took in language on the page was contagious.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Group Frames the Choice as Anyone but Quinn
abstract: A political action committee dedicated to thwarting Christine C. Quinn’s mayoral ambitions released three new advertisements on Thursday, featuring New Yorkers explaining why they do not like Ms. Quinn, the City Council speaker, and will not vote for her.
lead_paragraph: A political action committee dedicated to thwarting Christine C. Quinn’s mayoral ambitions released three new advertisements on Thursday, featuring New Yorkers explaining why they do not like Ms. Quinn, the City Council speaker, and will not vote for her. The committee, called NYC Is Not for Sale 2013, was founded by the president of Local 1180, which represents communications workers; an animal rights group that has sparred with Ms. Quinn over horse-drawn carriages; and a wealthy businesswoman. It is legally allowed to spend unlimited amounts on political advertising as long as it does not coordinate its activity with a candidate. The ads began running Thursday on several cable channels in the city, and was produced by The Advance Group.

lead_paragraph: Photos from Myanmar, India, France and Czech Republic.

headline: Returning With Punk and Pop Cred Intact
abstract: Fall Out Boy played cuts from its new album, “Save Rock and Roll,” during a show at Terminal 5 in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Fall Out Boy purposefully displayed its punk credentials at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night. Back on tour after a nearly four-year hiatus, with its first studio album since 2008, “Save Rock and Roll” (Decaydance/Island), Fall Out Boy slammed out its songs to a euphorically squealing, singing, moshing, crowd-surfing full house.

headline: Section B, The Search for Shepard’s Tone
Shifting Geometries and Swirling Dynamics
abstract: Justin Peck’s “In Creases,” presented by New York City Ballet on Wednesday, seemed to spring from a private dream world.
lead_paragraph: The striking originality of Justin Peck’s choreography for “In Creases,” which had its New York City premiere with City Ballet on Wednesday, is often strange. It includes constantly changing quasi-dramatic situations and pictorial configurations, all formally arranged and fluently connected, as if springing from some private dream world. The arrangement of its eight dancers abounds in novel geometries and other organizations. The patterns and angles change so regularly that it’s as if the stage itself were revolving.

headline: FX Adds to Comedy Slate With a Pilot for Tracy Morgan
abstract: The announcement of the show, called “Death Pact,” follows word that Billy Crystal would also be getting a sitcom pilot.
lead_paragraph: The cable channel FX continued its aggressive expansion into comedy on Thursday with the announcement that it has signed Tracy Morgan, formerly a star of “30 Rock” and “Saturday Night Live,” to headline a pilot for a new situation comedy.

headline: Into the Hormonal Wild
abstract: “The Kings of Summer,” directed by Jordan Vogt-Roberts, centers on three teenage boys who run away from home — but not very far — and live out a comic wilderness fantasy.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the strife between parents and their teenage children can be so bitter that even the tiniest set-to is charged with hostility that threatens to erupt into violence. The most amusing — and darkest — moments in Jordan Vogt-Roberts’s flighty comedy “The Kings of Summer,” set in suburban Ohio, pit Joe (Nick Robinson), a smart, hormonally overcharged 15-year-old, against his loving but cruelly sarcastic widowed father, Frank (Nick Offerman of “Parks and Recreation”).

headline: Workouts Continue as Belmont Field Swells
abstract: There is a little more than a week to go before the Belmont Stakes, and many of the contenders completed workouts this week. In all, 16 horses are under consideration for the race, which is the maximum field size.
lead_paragraph: There is a little more than a week to go before the Belmont Stakes, and many of the contenders completed workouts this week. Some of those will complete a final workout over the weekend or early next week.

headline: A Father-Son Outing Goes Terribly Wrong
abstract: “After Earth,” the Will Smith-Jaden Smith vehicle directed by M. Night Shyamalan, a boy and his dad crash-land on a planet that their ancestors ruined and fled.
lead_paragraph: A father-son encounter session tricked out with science-fiction clichés and steeped in motivational uplift, “After Earth” opens with a teenager, Kitai Raige (Jaden Smith), washing out from some kind of ranger academy. It’s a bummer because all he wants to do is please his father (Will Smith, Jaden’s father), a heroic if unfortunately named general, Cypher. Daddy Dearest has risen having honed tremendous self-control and a useful protective technique, “ghosting,” which renders him invisible to the monsters plaguing human civilization: the nonbearlike Ursa.

headline: Warning: Woman Wields a Scalpel
abstract: The scalpel takes center stage in this horror film from the Soska sisters about appearances and their manipulation.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t think it’s really fair that God gets to choose what we look like on the outside, do you?” says Beatress Johnson (Tristan Risk) in “American Mary,” a new horror movie from the twins Jen and Sylvia Soska. So Beatress has had work done. Lots of work: “14 different surgeries to get me to look like this” — a nightmare Betty Boop, with a synthetic, cartoonish face to supplement her ’50s homemaker dresses and a Kewpie-doll voice uttering the occasional obscene epithet.

lead_paragraph: Behind a white door in the basement of MoMA PS1, there’s a room that’s literally freezing cold. Inside are nearly a dozen boulder-size chunks of blue-tinged ice, fragments of a glacier in Iceland recovered by the celebrated artist Olafur Eliasson and transported here to create one of the more chilling artworks in “Expo 1: New York,” a sprawling, multisite extravaganza including a multitude of installations, shows-within-shows and events relating to the current and future state of our planet’s ecology.

headline: Angry Young Man in Kazakhstan
abstract: “Student,” by the Kazakh filmmaker Darezhan Omirbayev, takes its inspiration from Dostoyevsky’s “Crime and Punishment.”
lead_paragraph: Can a crime set you free? For the sullen young man at the center of “Student,” directed by the Kazakh filmmaker Darezhan Omirbayev, an experimental act of violence seems to yield moral clarity. Set in modern-day Kazakhstan, where the quiet is broken only by brutishness, this classically shot and edited film is a spare yet entrancing tale drawn with precise strokes.

headline: The Artist’s Force Field, Frozen in Time
abstract: The cast-iron building in SoHo where Donald Judd lived and worked has been restored and will be open to public tours, starting on Monday.
lead_paragraph: “Things that exist exist,” the Minimalist sculptor Donald Judd once wrote, “and everything is on their side.” His words are in a sense the credo of an empiricist, which was Judd’s preferred description of himself. He disdained the term Minimalist, along with the whole idea of art movements.

headline: Troubled Souls, Screaming to Be Heard
abstract: In “Run It,” the individual troubles of a high school student, a substitute teacher and two thugs are entwined.
lead_paragraph: The brothers Evangelos and George Giovanis, who directed “Run It,” have made films before (“Taking the Turn” and “Land of Nod”), but the experience doesn’t show in their latest. An entwined triptych of sorts unified by invective, slurs and characters demanding that others shut up, “Run It” is a very patchy affair.

headline: About Those Visitors From Other Planets
abstract: “Sirius,” a documentary by Amardeep Kaleka, seeks to induce government transparency about extraterrestrial life.
lead_paragraph: Before “The X-Files” there were cable-television U.F.O. shows, raising spooky questions and little shivers of wonder about the cosmos, with testimony from assorted astrophysicists and freethinkers. Amardeep Kaleka’s documentary “Sirius,” which seeks to induce government transparency about extraterrestrial life, rolls out eyewitnesses to U.F.O.’s and such, but also cross-pollinates with a more recent vintage of economic doomsaying.

headline: Two Artists on a Long Construction Journey
abstract: In “Triumph of the Wall,” the filmmaker Bill Stone records his fascination with a stonemason’s attempt to build a 1,000-foot wall on a Quebec estate.
lead_paragraph: There’s a reason that breaking rocks is a time-honored form of hard labor. In “Triumph of the Wall,” the first-time filmmaker Bill Stone all too faithfully records his morbid fascination with a stonemason’s attempt to build a 1,000-foot wall on a Quebec estate. Neither the very relaxed pace of this builder, Chris Overing, nor Mr. Stone’s sporadically amusing neuroses about his filmmaking make for a gripping documentary.

lead_paragraph: When, back in 2000, the sitcom “Spin City” moved production to Los Angeles from New York, few could have been happier than Richard Kind, a born-and-bred Easterner who played a clueless press secretary on the long-running series. headline: El Salvador: Doctors Can Induce Birth to Save Woman, Official Says
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Lupus Erythematosus', 'Birth Defects']
abstract: A 22-year-old woman who was denied an abortion by El Salvador’s Supreme Court can terminate her pregnancy at the first sign of danger, the health minister said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old woman who was denied an abortion by El Salvador’s Supreme Court can terminate her pregnancy at the first sign of danger, the health minister, María Isabel Rodríguez, said Thursday. “At this point, the interruption of the pregnancy is no longer an abortion,” Ms. Rodríguez said, “it is an induced birth.” Doctors say that the woman, known only as Beatriz, is carrying a fetus with a severe birth defect and almost no chance of surviving, and that she faces serious health risks if her pregnancy continues because she has lupus and related complications. After the Supreme Court’s ruling, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights called on the government to  “immediately adopt the necessary measures to protect the life, personal integrity and health” of Beatriz. Ms. Rodríguez said the woman could be induced to have either an abdominal or vaginal birth “because the important thing is saving Beatriz’s life.”

headline: Hate Speech on Facebook
abstract: The company has finally moved to further restrict hate speech directed at women, but its slow response may be indicative of a deeper problem in technology companies.
lead_paragraph: Facebook belatedly moved to further restrict hate speech that glorified violence against women after an organized social media campaign caused some companies like Nissan, the automaker, to withhold advertising from the site. The companies said they acted after they became aware that their ads might have appeared next to the offensive content.

headline: Grim Task of Identifying Factories’ Dead Overwhelms Bangladeshi Lab
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Forensic Science']
abstract: Anger over the Rana Plaza collapse has intensified the pressure on a small lab struggling to make DNA matches with the remains of about 300 unidentified victims.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Inside a small government laboratory here, there are about 300 test tubes, each labeled with masking tape and containing an extracted tooth or a shard of bone. Day and night, dozens of these tubes rest on metal trays that vibrate with a motorized monotony. The shaking decalcifies the bone in a process that requires two weeks before material can be gleaned for a DNA profile.

headline: Self-Driving Cars for Testing Are Supported by U.S.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Companies from Silicon Valley to Detroit to Germany are developing cars that park, steer and even drive themselves. Now the federal agency for traffic safety has said it wants to come along for the ride.

headline: Bridge Collapse Tears at a Town’s Economy
keywords: ['Skagit River Bridge (Wash)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: With cars and trucks detoured after the collapse of an Interstate 5 bridge, a Washington town of 8,500 is struggling.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Wash. — Interstate 5, before last week’s bridge collapse over the Skagit River on the south end of town, was the great pumping arterial source of economic life here. It brought Canadians, shopping for furniture or clothes. It brought day-tripping outlet mall lovers from Seattle. Through an embrace of retailing begun as a town plan in the 1980s, Burlington, population 8,500, grew to have the highest level of retail sales per capita of any city in the state.

lead_paragraph: Chivas USA became the 11th member of Major League Soccer nearly a decade ago, beginning play with the cachet that its parent club was Chivas Guadalajara, an immensely popular Mexican team.

headline: The Imperfect Immigrants
abstract: They were ordinary only in the way of all people who left behind extraordinary circumstances, and often their secrets did not travel with them.
lead_paragraph: VISNJA GORA, Slovenia — Exactly 100 years ago a man of 22 left this village on the eve of a great war to build a life in the United States. To Ignac Vrhovec, the tired old ground of his homeland was tangled in his ancestors’ encumbrances and spent by time. After he left, much of that land would change hands, from the Austro-Hungarian Empire, to Italy, to Nazi Germany.

headline: Getting a Fair Share From Multinationals
abstract: How can the United States government get more tax revenue from global corporations while letting them stay competitive?

headline: No Replacement for Corporate Taxes
abstract: Corporate income taxes need to be reformed, not abolished.
lead_paragraph: In response to the recent Senate hearing on tax avoidance at Apple, some pundits have argued that the best solution is to abolish the corporate income tax altogether. Their contention is that multinational corporations — which hold trillions of dollars in mostly untaxed profits offshore — are so complex and so expert at avoidance that even trying to tax them is pointless. It would be better, they say, to quit trying and to raise needed tax revenue in other ways. This would be a completely wrong approach.

headline: Promising African Development Fund Collapses
abstract: A program financed by the Agency for International Development is dissolving because of mismanagement, insider dealings and a lack of federal oversight.
lead_paragraph: The initiative began two decades ago, with the best of intentions, after apartheid fell and southern Africa’s future brightened.

headline: Attacks on Muslims in Myanmar
abstract: The government must speak and act against extremist violence if Myanmar wants to realize its democratic aspirations.
lead_paragraph: Terrifying anti-Muslim violence surged this week in Myanmar, exposing deep ethnic and religious tensions that are undermining efforts to stabilize the country and move forward with political and economic reforms. Myanmar’s democratic aspirations can never be fully realized if Muslims, who make up about 5 percent of the population, continue to be attacked and marginalized by Buddhists, the majority of the population. At least 44 people have died since March in sectarian mob violence.

headline: The Questions Keep Coming for Rutgers
abstract: New details about the vetting process for Rutgers’s new athletic director, Julie Hermann, raise serious questions about how she was chosen to restore a tarnished program.
lead_paragraph: It was a few weeks after Rutgers hired a well-regarded recruiting firm to identify and vet candidates to lead the university’s athletic program, which was still reeling from a scandal involving an abusive coach, when Julie Hermann, a leading applicant, turned to one of the firm’s final questions.

headline: Just in Time for Summer, the A Train Is Fully Restored
abstract: Seven months after Hurricane Sandy wiped a portion of the A train from the subway map, full service was restored to the peninsula on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The trains returned, at last, on a proper beach day, carrying toddlers in sundresses and men in shorter-than-short shorts, high school students prone to impromptu dance-offs and women whose toes dangled from their sandals.

lead_paragraph: At a break in the testimony, a few cordial people took seats near me and introduced themselves. Among them was Norris McDonald, who came to the legislative hearing in Lower Manhattan to testify about the future of the Indian Point nuclear power plant.

headline: From the Mouths of Babes
abstract: The ugly and destructive war on food stamps, which do good for both families and the economy, doesn’t make sense.
lead_paragraph: Like many observers, I usually read reports about political goings-on with a sort of weary cynicism. Every once in a while, however, politicians do something so wrong, substantively and morally, that cynicism just won’t cut it; it’s time to get really angry instead. So it is with the ugly, destructive war against food stamps.

Holder Jr., under fire over investigative tactics in leak cases, has opened internal discussions over tightening rules on when prosecutors may seek phone logs and other information that could identify reporters’ sources as he began a series of a meetings on Thursday with leaders of news media organizations.

headline: McIlroy’s Struggles Continue in First Round of the Memorial

headline: The Romantic Advantage
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: China may be the world’s second-largest economy, but when it comes to branding, the United States still wins.
lead_paragraph: In the race to be the world’s dominant economy, Americans have at least one clear advantage over the Chinese. We’re much better at branding. American companies have these eccentric failed novelists and personally difficult visionary founders who are fantastic at creating brands that consumers around the world flock to and will pay extra for. Chinese companies are terrible at this. Every few years, Chinese officials say they’re going to start an initiative to create compelling brands and the results are always disappointing.

headline: Franca Rame, Italian Actress and Playwright, Dies at 83
abstract: Ms. Rame often collaborated with her husband, the playwright Dario Fo, and it was difficult to tease out who had written what.
lead_paragraph: Franca Rame, an Italian actress and playwright whose work — including mordant, highly charged critiques of the Italian government, the Roman Catholic Church and the status of women — was often done in collaboration with her husband, the Nobel Prize-winning playwright Dario Fo, died on Wednesday at her home in Milan. She was 83.

headline: A New Step in Wrestling With the Bra
abstract: Jockey has devised a new way to measure bra sizes and is offering a $20 kit to help women get a better fit, in what could be a mass-market answer to custom fittings popular among women in boutiques and high-end department stores.
lead_paragraph: They are the measurements that many American women (and not a few American men) know so well: 32A, 34B, 36C.

abstract: A law enforcement official’s account of the shooting during an F.B.I. inquiry came several hours after the man’s Chechen father claimed that his son, Ibragim Todashev, had been unarmed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A man who was killed in Orlando, Fla., last week while being questioned by an F.B.I. agent about his relationship with Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects, had knocked the agent to the ground with a table and ran at him with a metal pole before being shot, according to a senior law enforcement official briefed on the matter.

headline: U.S. Combat Commanders Should Handle War Zone Investigations, Panel Says
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: After flaws in the case of Marines accused in a 2005 Iraq massacre prompted a review, a Defense Department panel proposed that American troops should not be investigated by the branches in which they serve.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Concerned about possible flaws in criminal proceedings against American troops accused of killing or abusing civilians in a war zone, a Defense Department panel has proposed that investigations and prosecutions of crimes be carried out by a senior commander in the theater of combat and not the branch of the armed services in which the accused serves.

headline: Words of Praise, and Loss, for Malcolm X’s Grandson
abstract: Looking beyond the troubles of his youth, family and friends remembered Malcolm Shabazz, who was fatally beaten on May 9 in Mexico City, as a reflection of his grandfather.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Shabazz never knew his grandfather, Malcolm X, but in his struggle to understand his legacy, he learned to quote the man verbatim, his aunt, Ilyasah Shabazz, recalled on Thursday during a memorial service for Mr. Shabazz at a church in Harlem. So studious was Mr. Shabazz that he would correct others, even if only a single word was out of place.

Lundqvist, the reigning Vezina Trophy winner, was a second too late in folding his left arm into his body, and the puck bounced into the net.

headline: A Little Groucho Marx, a Little King Solomon

lead_paragraph: “Terrible is the temptation to do good!” That observation lands with a satisfying sting in the new production of “The Caucasian Chalk Circle,” by Bertolt Brecht, that opened on Thursday at the Classic Stage Company. With his walking-dead demeanor and a slightly savage glint in his eye, Christopher Lloyd, portraying the narrator in the first part of the play, imbues that wry morsel of philosophy with a vivid jolt of irony.

headline: New Animal Law Is Welcome but, at the Outset, Expensive

lead_paragraph: Some Texas animal shelters have until January to comply with a new law that bans the use of compressed carbon monoxide to euthanize dogs and cats. Although the shelter operators say they welcome the change, they also say that adapting to the new requirements will be neither easy nor cheap.

headline: Massachusetts: State Sues Over Cod Limits
keywords: ['Cod (Fish)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: Effective May 1, federal regulators cut the catch for Gulf of Maine cod by 77 percent, saying the limit is the only way to rebuild stocks that scientists say are heavily depleted
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Martha Coakley filed a lawsuit on Thursday against the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in an effort to block federal rules that severely limit the amount of cod New England fishermen are allowed to catch annually. Effective May 1, federal regulators cut the catch for Gulf of Maine cod by 77 percent, saying the limit is the only way to rebuild stocks that scientists say are heavily depleted. Ms. Coakley’s complaint says regulators violated federal law by not giving due consideration to the economic impact of the cuts on fishermen and by failing to use the best available science.

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan inched closer to the end of deflation and factory output picked up, government data showed Friday, offering proof that the real economy is slowly catching up to the high expectations set by its recent bold economic policies.

lead_paragraph: Bobby Valentine’s 1997 Mets were a plucky group of overachievers who won their first Subway Series game against the Yankees, the defending World Series champions, but they did not sweep the series. The 1998 and ’99 Mets were brash contenders, but they could not do it, either. Nor could the 2000 Mets, who won the National League pennant, or the 2006 team that went deep into the playoffs.

Pannell, an attackman, helped the Big Red make the Final Four. He finished his career with 354 points, an N.C.A.A. record. Schwarzmann, a midfielder, won the award for a second consecutive year after helping the Terrapins to the N.C.A.A. title game, where they lost to North Carolina in triple overtime.

abstract: Robert Sturman, a California artist, traveled to Kenya to document the work of the Africa Yoga Project, a nonprofit group that teaches and employs yoga teachers and conducts free classes in institutions like prisons and orphanages.
lead_paragraph: The language of yoga is universal. That is the message of Robert Sturman, an artist from Santa Monica, Calif., who has traveled across the United States to capture the tranquillity and beauty of yoga. A month ago, Mr. Sturman traveled to Kenya to document the work of the Africa Yoga Project, a nonprofit organization that teaches and employs more than 70 local yoga teachers and conducts up to 300 free yoga classes for more than 5,000 people weekly in orphanages, prisons and other locales throughout the country.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (WE) BRIDEZILLAS This reality series kicks off its 10th and final season with the promise that these will be the worst-behaved brides ever. The temper tantrums begin as one woman feuds with her wedding planner, who just happens to be her future mother-in-law, and another (Ariel, above, with her husband, Brook) makes it clear to her entourage that she’s the boss. headline: Tickled by America’s Quirky Coincidences
abstract: Joshua Yospyn, a Washington-based photographer, has a knack for capturing the gleefully odd juxtapositions of America’s weird cultural and political landscape.
lead_paragraph: Inauguration day in President Abraham Lincoln’s time was on March 4. That’s also the photographer Joshua Yospyn’s birthday — and if you’re given to seeing meaning in coincidences, as he is, it’s a pretty big deal.

headline: What They Said: India’s Growth Slumps to a Decade Low
abstract: Analysts and politicians weigh in on the 5 percent growth of the Indian economy in the 2012-2013 fiscal.
lead_paragraph: The Indian economy grew 5 percent in the 2012-2013 fiscal year, the smallest rise in a decade, according to government data released Friday. The figure, which was in line with a February estimate of the Central Statistics Office, or C.S.O., dampened hopes of a swift revival of a once-booming economy.

headline: Protests Block Large Part of Central Frankfurt
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Demonstrators against economic austerity in Europe, organized by a group called Blockupy, immobilized a large part of central Frankfurt on Friday.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Demonstrators blocked a large swath of central Frankfurt on Friday to protest a variety of issues ranging from economic austerity in Europe to capitalism to labor conditions for workers in developing countries.

headline: How to Cure the College Dropout Syndrome
abstract: A conversation with Jeffrey Selingo, the author of “College (Un)Bound,” who argues that the higher-education system is both vital to the American economy and “broken.”
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Selingo, the former editor of The Chronicle of Higher Education and currently an editor at large there, is the author of a new book, “College (Un)Bound.” In it, he argues that the higher-education system is both vital to the American economy and “broken.” (An essay adapted from the book was published in the Education Life section of The Times last month.) My exchange with him, edited slightly, follows.

headline: Nashville’s Frist Center Shows Off Art Deco Cars
abstract: Housed in an Art Deco building that was once Nashville’s main post office, the Frist Center for the Visual Arts will be the site of a show of Art Deco cars over the summer.
lead_paragraph: When Nashville’s main post office opened in 1934, New Deal federal government programs were on the rise and the architectural style of federal buildings was stern and modernist. It was one of those big stately, solid buildings suggestive of the federal government’s power; tough-looking stone eagles stood sentinel on its facade.

headline: Unemployment Hits Record High in Euro Zone
abstract: The rate for the euro zone countries reached 12.2 percent in April, bringing the total number of unemployed job-seekers to 19.4 million.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Unemployment in the euro zone continued its relentless march higher in April, according to official data published Friday, hitting yet another record, amid a prolonged recession and the absence of a coordinated response by policy makers.

headline: Does Spelling Matter?
abstract: As a 13-year-old New Yorker beat the competition to win a prestigious American spelling bee, a British academic has been upsetting traditionalists by asking whether spelling really matters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A professor of English at one of the world’s most venerable centers of learning has outraged language purists by challenging whether spelling matters.

keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Small Business']
abstract: “We didn’t want to be perceived as just another wealth management firm,” said one owner.
lead_paragraph: In my last post — The Problem Social Media Cannot Solve — I profiled DCC Waterbeds, a company that makes waterbeds for cows – yes, really – and that generously shared a tale of what went wrong when the owners hired a friend to build a Web site. This week, I’ve found two small businesses eager to talk about how they managed to build Web sites they love.

lead_paragraph: Dell Inc. on Friday began its official campaign to support a proposed $24.4 billion sale of itself to Michael S. Dell and the investment firm Silver Lake, amid continued opposition to the deal.

lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department says that driverless cars should not yet be allowed, except for testing, but noted that some safety features could save lives, Claire Cain Miller and Matthew L. Wald report in The New York Times.

headline: China’s Ethnic Song and Dance
abstract: To China’s leadership, the country’s many ethnic minorities are good for entertainment — but they’d better not get out of line and express themselves.
lead_paragraph: In China’s worst single outburst of ethnic violence in four years, 21 people died last month in the far western region of Xinjiang. But never mind that. According to the deputy governor of Xinjiang, Shi Dagang, the region’s Muslim Uighur population is far too busy treating guests “to meat and wine, with song and dance” to create any problems. In fact, Shi insisted to reporters this week, “The ethnic minorities are simple-hearted and honest, very kind and unaffected. They love guests.”

lead_paragraph: This poem, one of 12 winners of our Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Scott, 18, from Phoenix.

keywords: ['Urban Areas', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Pedestrian Malls']
abstract: Nationwide, urban pedestrian zones — “parklets,” plazas and public spaces — are growing in popularity, as city dwellers seek alternatives to suburbs and cars.
lead_paragraph: In Brooklyn, the No. 3 subway line ends at New Lots Avenue, where passengers descend from the elevated tracks to what used to be a nasty intersection, trafficked by prostitutes, drug dealers — “You name it,” as Eddie Di Benedetto, the owner of Caterina’s Pizzeria, put it the other day. Not long ago, a coalition of local merchants and community leaders turned to the New York City Department of Transportation, which runs a program to make traffic circles, triangles and streets into pedestrian plazas.

abstract: Recent editions of Apple’s Mac OS X operating system include the QuickTime Player program that can record a video of desktop screen actions.
lead_paragraph: The QuickTime Player program included with recent versions of Mac OS X can do more than just play back video clips. It can also make a recording of the action on the computer screen, which can be helpful when creating tutorials or demonstrating how to do a  task. To get started, just go to the Mac’s Applications folder and open the QuickTime Player program.

abstract: Just a short walk from bustling Piazza San Marco, the little-known neighborhood of Castello Orientale — with its tourist-free streets and old-fashioned way of life — feels worlds away.

abstract: Fans noticed a new Belmont at the opening of the 1913 season; renovations had altered the familiar plant.
lead_paragraph: Fans noticed a new Belmont at the opening of the 1913 season; renovations had altered the familiar plant. Underneath an extensive diagram of the refurbished courses, The Daily Racing Form wrote that, “Since racing has been resumed over the most extensive and commodious plant in America it is fitting that readers should have an opportunity to refresh their memories as to its various courses.”

headline: At HSBC, a Board Member Who Can Keep Secrets
abstract: Jonathan Evans, the former director general of MI5, Britain’s domestic security and counterintelligence agency, may find that a new career in banking will suit him just fine. HSBC on Friday named him as an independent nonexecutive director of its board.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – From spy vs. spy to spy vs. banker?

headline: A Conversation With: Author and Filmmaker Vivek Bald
abstract: Mr. Bald on his recent book “Bengali Harlem and the Lost Histories of South Asian America” and his plans to turn it into a documentary.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker and author Vivek Bald’s book “Bengali Harlem and the Lost Histories of South Asian America” created a buzz within the South Asian-American community when it was released in November. Mr. Bald documents the histories of seldom-acknowledged groups of early South Asian migrants to the United States, like Muslim silk and cotton traders from West Bengal in the 1880s and Indian sailors who deserted British steamships in the early 20th century. They settled in New Orleans, Harlem in New York and New Jersey and formed strong community bonds with African-American and Hispanic communities.

headline: Debt and Growth: The State of the Debate
abstract: Nothing left but rubble.
lead_paragraph: So, after a brief diversion into issues of manners and etiquette, I hope we’re back to the substance. And there are really three points that have been established; I’m not sure that everyone understands that any one of those points is enough to refute most of the debt/deficit discussion of the past three years.

keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Various investigations and inquiries involving JPMorgan seem to be tangential to its business, and are being fed piecemeal through the news media to the detriment of the bank, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Richard E. Farley is a partner in the leveraged finance group of the law firm of Paul Hastings. He is writing a book titled “The Crisis Not Wasted: The Creation of Modern Financial Regulation During F.D.R.’s First Five Hundred Days,” a book on the creation of modern financial regulation during President Franklin Roosevelt’s first term of office.
