lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: The Heat’s One-Man Show
abstract: Sportswriters marveled at LeBron James’s Game 5 performance against the Pacers, but his teammates’ lack of support reminded even him of his Cleveland days.
lead_paragraph: At some point Thursday night in Game 5 of the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals LeBron James realized he was not only on a stage but on it by himself. His supporting cast had deserted him, leaving him as a one-man show. He was not the least bit happy about it, but the N.B.A. was not going to give him longer than a quarter to round up his Miami Heat cast members again, and screaming at them wasn’t working, so the LeBron Show went on.

headline: Losing My Father at War, One Letter at a Time
abstract: Kate Hoit shares her letters of losing her father to Alzheimer’s disease while she was deployed to Iraq as a photojournalist.
lead_paragraph: “War does not determine who is right — only who is left.” That’s what Bertrand Russell said.

headline: Office Romance: Renzo Piano’s Light
abstract: Isn’t it odd to think that most of us spend at least half our waking hours at work, and yet there are so few photographs of this part of our lives?
lead_paragraph: This is the first in a series of Instagrams by Kathy Ryan that find romance and beauty in the office life.

headline: Hollywood Agent
abstract: Despite the taint of failure, there remains something hopeful in the Hollywood of Matthew Specktor’s sprawling, atmospheric  novel.
lead_paragraph: It’s a man’s man’s man’s world, James Brown proclaimed in his celebrated wail inside a New York recording studio in 1966 — around the same time Beau Rosenwald, the focal character of Matthew Specktor’s sprawling, atmospheric second novel, “American Dream Machine,” sires two sons with two different women. One of those sons — the illegitimate one, Nate Myer — is the novel’s pensive narrator, and he presents his father as a cross between Augie March and Willy Loman: the child of a Queens shoemaker who works his way up from the mailroom of a former vaudeville agency in New York to representing A-list Hollywood stars while earning virulent enemies, a handful of ex-wives and millions of dollars along the perilous, ego-driven way.

headline: Don’t Be Disgusting
abstract: Giovanni Della Casa’s book on conduct, published in 1558 and now newly translated from the Italian, promotes civilized manners for their own sake.
lead_paragraph: In Renaissance Europe, Italy was Etiquette Central, attracting all the fascination and ridicule that go with that honor.

headline: Political Cartoons
abstract: An illustrated tour of political cartoons throughout history.
lead_paragraph: It has been eight years since a set of Danish cartoons portraying the prophet Muhammad incited rioting in much of the Muslim world. In the eyes of many Americans, the protests were incomprehensible, a collective temper tantrum spawned by dopey sketches. Muslims were accused, among much else, of lacking a sense of humor. But what if the outcry reflected less on Islamic culture than on cartoon culture, which has its own history of flare-ups and meltdowns? The question goes to the heart of Victor S. Navasky’s thoughtful and deftly illustrated book, “The Art of Controversy: Political Cartoons and Their Enduring Power.”

headline: Center Stage
abstract: The celebrities that pop up throughout Rita Moreno’s memoir include Marlon Brando, Elvis Presley and John F. Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: The next time you watch “West Side Story,” don’t believe every word Rita Moreno sings.

headline: I Wanna Be Adored
abstract: A biography of the band that, for a brief moment, held the future of rock ’n’ roll in its hands.
lead_paragraph: Some bands are famous for capturing the spirit of an era. Others are famous, or almost famous, for capturing the spirit of a fleeting moment — a bright, pivotal summer or even a single incandescent show — and then utterly squandering the whole opportunity.

headline: Pop Life
abstract: Touré’s critical study of Prince, based on lectures the author delivered at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: The cover of “Dirty Mind,” Prince’s ingenious/ingenuous 1980 exercise in self-reinvention, threw down a rose-scented gauntlet. It featured a black-and-white shot of a skinny young man who barely seemed out of his teens (he was 22), looking as much the racially and sexually ambiguous wild boy as a nice Minneapolis lad could. Sporting a thin gigolo mustache, a Joan Jett haircut and an open, oversize jacket that he could have swiped from a doorman at the Grand Hotel, Prince topped off his new image with a kerchief, bare chest and thong with a virile little tuft of hair peeking over the bikini line.

headline: Can I Use the Same Paper for Multiple College Courses?
abstract: Self-plagiarism, grounds for expulsion, an exercise in intellectual complexity or all of the above?
lead_paragraph: When I was in college, I’d sometimes write a single paper that would satisfy assignments in more than one course. For instance, I once wrote a paper on how “The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock” expressed satire; I submitted it for assignments in both my poetry course as well as my completely separate satire course. I did not disclose this to either professor. When I share this with people, half call the practice cheating, and the other half call it genius. My niece told me it would certainly be grounds for expulsion at her college. In my mind, I was adding a level of intellectual complexity to my studies. Was this an ethical practice, or was I cheating? JOE, CONNECTICUT

headline: Want to Save Civilization? Get in Line
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: From theme parks to airports, the simple queue is under attack.
lead_paragraph: The next time you’re stuck behind 250 shoppers in a checkout line that snakes around the aisles in a Trader Joe’s, take a moment to ponder exactly what’s going on. Yes, you’re standing in a queue. Yes, it can be the pits. Except that, all things considered, it’s also pretty great.

headline: Dwight Gooden Was Not Best Friends With Darryl Strawberry
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Celebrities', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The former Mets pitcher on real friendships and surviving “Celebrity Rehab.”
lead_paragraph: In your new book, “Doc: A Memoir,” you proclaim your sobriety. But in 1999, you said you were sober in another memoir, “Heat,” then wound up in jail years later after testing positive for cocaine use. Why should we believe you now?  At that time, I wasn’t completely honest with myself. I was still drinking. I had seven years where I only drank, but eventually, I was doing coke and drinking. Alcohol is a direct link to the drugs.

headline: The 5.19.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.

headline: They Do the ’Dos
abstract: Photographs of hairstylists in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of hairstylists in New York City.

headline: Jason Isbell, Unloaded
abstract: Sobriety isn’t always a songwriter’s friend, but it has brought out the best in the former Drive-By Trucker.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know how to cure a hangover, ask a musician, especially one who has recently been in rehab. “Pedialyte, that’s what you need,” Jason Isbell told me. He was standing outside a recording studio in suburban Nashville, lighting a cigarette. “It’s the stuff you give kids who are dehydrated from diarrhea. It’s like 10 Gatorades in one bottle.”

headline: ‘The Dog Bit Me’
abstract: I knew that Zeke wasn’t good with children. Why did I let my son get so close to him?
lead_paragraph: Three years ago my son was attacked by a dog. Otto was 2 at the time — a towheaded slip of a boy with bright blue eyes and porcelain skin you could practically see through. He was instinctively drawn to dogs, and we didn’t see any reason to discourage him. Of course I knew they could nip, and every once in a while break the skin. And I had heard the horrific news stories of those seemingly devil-possessed dogs who leapt on unsuspecting neighbors, inflicting actual, permanent harm. But regular dogs, I had no real fear of them. Not having seen a dog attack, I was completely ignorant about how bad it could be, how, in five seconds, a dog could tear the flesh off your bones. Or worse, the skin off your child’s face.

headline: Who Made That Ice-Cream Cone?
keywords: ['Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: Legends from the 1904 World’s Fair.
lead_paragraph: In the early 20th century, eating was still a formal affair, involving napkins, tables and rules of etiquette. Ice cream was served as a delicate sliver on a plate, then savored with a teaspoon.

headline: The Hollywood Fast Life of Stalker Sarah
abstract: The 17-year-old celebrity chaser is easily the most famous fan in the world.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon this winter, Sarah M., better known as “Stalker Sarah,” was sitting in the back of an In-N-Out Burger fidgeting with her iPhone and plotting how to get her picture taken with Harry Styles, the rakishly handsome frontman of the English boy band One Direction, or one of his bandmates. Sarah was dressed in her usual uniform of black leather jacket, black skinny jeans and black sneakers; her long brown hair was swept back into a neat ponytail, and her wispy bangs gently brushed the top of her signature wire-rimmed glasses, which accentuated her black eyeliner. It was more or less the same look she had worn in photographs over the years with Angelina Jolie, Brad Pitt, Justin Bieber, Julia Roberts, Oprah, Tim Tebow, Levi Johnston, Rod Blagojevich, Kris Humphries and many, many others. More than 6,000 photos of Sarah mugging with celebrities have been uploaded to the Internet. At 17, she is easily the most famous fan in the world.

headline: Mrs. Earp
abstract: Ann Kirschner tells the story of Josephine Marcus, for nearly 50 years Wyatt Earp’s common-law wife and a valiant frontierswoman in her own right.
lead_paragraph: The fabled shootout at the O.K. Corral rooted Wyatt Earp deep in the American psyche, or at least in its Western mythology. But Ann Kirschner has cleverly identified a parallel story buried under the debris of history: that of Josephine Marcus, for nearly 50 years Earp’s common-law wife and a valiant frontierswoman in her own right.

headline: Science
abstract: Edward O. Wilson offers encouragement and inspirational maxims to budding scientists.
lead_paragraph: Dear Professor Wilson:

headline: Good Dog
abstract: Sue Halpern writes about Pransky, a sweet 7-year-old Labradoodle who helps the residents of a nursing home.
lead_paragraph: For me, reading dog books is always a little bit fraught. There’s just no way around comparing the dogs in the book with the ones that share my home. And mine, you see, are just this side of feral; their virtues include not eating all six of my dining room chairs. I almost never read books about good dogs or working dogs if I can help it, and certainly not about therapy dogs. I mean, what kind of therapy dogs would my dogs make? Is there a person whose life is too neat, or too happy?

headline: Such Small Portions
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Books and Literature', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: Ruth R. Wisse recounts the long history of Jewish humor and brings it up to date.
lead_paragraph: From the praise heaped on it by some analysts of Jewish humor, one might almost think the chosen people were chosen for the quality of their jokes. Freud’s “Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious,” which was published in 1905, drew almost exclusively on Jewish stories, because, he maintained, they were the funniest and the most interesting. Salcia Landmann, a scholar of Yiddish who died in 2002, argued that Jewish humor is “more acute, more profound and richer in expression than that of any other people.”

headline: Tennis
abstract: The brash tennis star Jimmy Connors recounts his storied career.
lead_paragraph: “My timing could not have been better,” Jimmy Connors declares in “The Outsider,” referring to his becoming the world’s top-ranked tennis player in the mid-1970s, just as the sport entered a golden age and was transformed into a big business. Connors could also have been describing his game, which deployed a wacky steel-frame racket and a relentless “take the ball on the rise” style to win a record 109 singles titles, including eight Grand Slam championships, five of them at the United States Open.

headline: Gilded Cage
abstract: Patricia Volk recalls her tumultuous relationship with her mother, and with the work of the fashion designer Elsa Schiaparelli.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, a drunken woman made a dramatic emphatic gesture in a Manhattan cab that sent one of my vintage faux gold-and-turquoise Schiaparelli clip-on earrings flying somewhere into the back seat’s nether regions. This is not one of those taxi stories with a happy ending (the sole copy of the manuscript recovered; the priceless Strad delivered in time for the big concert). The driver spent several minutes kindly helping me search. Numbers were exchanged. Forms filed. All in vain.

headline: Miami Vice
abstract: In “The Prince of Paradise,” John Glatt tells a true story of murder and glitz in Miami Beach.
lead_paragraph: Summer is no time to be virtuous. So before you pack those classic tomes you’re determined to read on vacation, let me tempt you with a few guilty pleasures.

headline: Superheroes
abstract: Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster, the two creators of Superman,  sold their rights to the iconic character for next to nothing.
lead_paragraph: We all know who Superman is. If you’re younger than 75, you don’t even remember a time when he didn’t exist. With the possible exception of Mickey Mouse, the indestructible and incorruptible Man of Steel is surely the most famous fictional character ever created in cartoon form.

headline: Classic ’70s Television
abstract: New books go behind the scenes of two eponymous TV ventures: “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and “The Flip Wilson Show.”
lead_paragraph: Long after “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” ended its run, and a New York station was airing back-to-back reruns around 1:30 a.m., I remember watching and hearing the familiar “Love Is All Around” theme echoing from both my upstairs and downstairs neighbors. As “Friends” and “Seinfeld” would later, in its afterlife “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” became a reassuring, unfailingly funny end to the day, as much a social phenomenon as a sitcom.

headline: Winning
abstract: Robert Weintraub details baseball’s joyous reacclimatization after World War II.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, April 15, 1946, Jews observed Passover in Germany for the first time without fear since 1933. On the following Thursday, the League of Nations was dissolved. And on Sunday came the death of John Maynard Keynes. To the average American, however, the momentous week’s main event occurred on Tuesday, April 16 — when the unabashed Cardinals fan Harry Truman threw out the first pitch on opening day at Griffith Stadium in Washington, ending the presidential tradition’s four-year hiatus. (In 1942, faced with the Japanese invasion of the Philippines and the ensuing Bataan Death March, Franklin Roosevelt had deputized his vice president, Henry Wallace, to perform the ceremonial toss.)

headline: Doubleheader
abstract: The veteran sportswriter Allen Barra explores in depth the remarkable similarities between two great New York center fielders.
lead_paragraph: The first time I played ball against Willie Mays, in 1965, it was impossible to take my eyes off him. At bat, in the outfield and on the bases, he did everything differently from — and better than — anybody else. Mays’s style of play could come only from an impressive intelligence and a thoroughly cultivated knowledge of the game.

headline: Isner Rebounds and Ends Fifth-Set Struggles
abstract: The French Open win by John Isner is the first in his career from down two sets. It also snapped his streak of five consecutive fifth-set losses.
lead_paragraph: It was the first time two American men had faced each other in the main draw of the French Open since 2001, but John Isner and Ryan Harrison compensated for the drought by playing deep into a fifth set, with Isner coming back from down two sets and prevailing, 5-7, 6-7 (7), 6-3, 6-1, 8-6, in 3 hours 50 minutes.

headline: Country Living
abstract: Scott McClanahan writes of a world in West Virginia where existence is both tedious and shocking.
lead_paragraph: Grotesquerie is a fact of life for certain classes, the wallpaper for folks who dwell beneath a certain rung of the ladder. Those without health insurance, say. Or money for gas. Or dentists. My people were West Virginia factory workers and, as such, immersed in enough gothic absurdity to drown Flannery O’Connor. They were bawdy and hard-hewn and never surprised when tragedy befell their lives. They didn’t even call it tragedy, since tragedy was a thing that happened to rich folks with something to lose.

headline: Prog Rock
abstract: The anthology “Yes Is the Answer” celebrates prog rock in all its tomfoolery and excess.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Wilde once said, “Experience is the name everyone gives to their mistakes.” But for men born about a century after Wilde, mistakes tended to have more colorful names, like “Yes,” “Genesis” or “Emerson, Lake and Palmer.” These were the hairy dragon-kings of prog rock (short for “progressive”), the bands that ruled the FM airwaves of the 1970s, providing black-light initiations for their adolescent male devotees. Even after all these years, prog remains one of the most intrinsically silly of rock fads: concept albums, ornate time signatures, keyboard solos, lyrical ruminations on the tendency of mountains to fall out of the sky.

headline: In a Rooftop Gym, a Fitting Tribute to a Beloved Priest
abstract: Side Street: The Rev. John C. Flynn, who was no stranger to a basketball court, died last year at 83. Now he is being honored in the neighborhood he served: A court has been named for him at a Bronx school.
lead_paragraph: In the final years of his life, when his memory was fading but his strength remained solid, the Rev. John C. Flynn paced the halls of a Bronx nursing home, talking with the lonely, smiling to all – and swinging an imaginary golf club.

headline: Spy vs. Spy
abstract: A 33-year veteran of the C.I.A. turns his hand to espionage fiction.
lead_paragraph: The undisputed master of spy fiction, John le Carré, worked for British intelligence for several years before the international success of his third novel, “The Spy Who Came In From the Cold,” allowed him to retire from the secret world to become a full-time writer.

headline: Downtown
abstract: Scoundrels, artists and geniuses commingle in this ambitious history of Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Hail, hail, the gang’s all here: a galaxy of scoundrels, artists and geniuses commingle in John Strausbaugh’s ambitious 600-plus-page history of Greenwich Village. Strausbaugh — who presided over this newspaper’s “Weekend Explorer” series on New York City and wrote what felt like the entirety of The New York Press in its 1990s heyday — turns a collection of stories and profiles into something less like a textbook than a party spinning happily out of control.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Forty years after his death, J. R. R. Tolkien is on the hardcover fiction list again, this time with “The Fall of Arthur,” which makes its debut at No. 10.
lead_paragraph: LORD OF THE LIST: Forty years after his death, in 1973, J. R. R. Tolkien is on the hardcover fiction list again, this time with “The Fall of Arthur,” an unfinished epic poem that makes its debut at No. 10. Tolkien has had an active after­life; reviewing the book in The Los Angeles Times last month, Elizabeth Hand noted that it lists nine works published during his lifetime and 24 published posthumously (at least six of which have been best sellers). Hand liked the book, with some reservations: “ ‘The Fall of Arthur’ is a fascinating work, though perhaps more for the Tolkien completist than the casual ‘Lord of the Rings’ fan,” she wrote. “It focuses on the bloody aftermath of Queen Guinevere’s affair with Lancelot, greatest of Arthur’s knights, and is surprisingly powerful in its terse depiction of the affair’s devastating consequences.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE HANGING GARDEN,  by Patrick White. (Picador, paper, $15.) In this long fragment of a novel that White, the Australian Nobelist, left unfinished at his death 23 years ago, two refugee children are mistreated by a world that, by its lights, means no harm.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE REVISED FUNDAMENTALS OF CAREGIVING,  by Jonathan Evison. (Algonquin, $14.95.) Ben, the 39-year-old narrator of Evison’s bittersweet novel, has lost his children in an accident and is losing his wife to divorce. At the end of his rope, he takes a job as full-time caregiver to Trevor, an angry, girl-crazed teenager suffering from Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Together they take a madcap road trip, from Washington State to Utah, to visit Trevor’s estranged father.

headline: New Tricks for Old Grains
abstract: Everything old can be new again, especially when you are cooking with ancient grains, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.
lead_paragraph: Everything old can be new again, especially when you are cooking with ancient grains, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health. Ancients grains like farro and sorghum have been dietary staples for hundreds of years, but many of today’s eaters are just discovering their hearty flavor and chewy texture. Ms. Shulman writes:

headline: Bound for the Hamptons
abstract: The Book Review’s first use of “beach read,” Tao Lin’s new novel and more.
lead_paragraph: This week we offer our annual Summer Reading issue, which got me thinking about the etymology of “beach read.” I searched The Times’s archive for its first appearance. The recentness — May 2, 1993 — was a surprise. In her review of “Fearless,” Susan Isaacs wrote, “Rafael Yglesias’s novel deserves better praise than ‘Great page turner!’ or ‘Super beach read!’ ”

headline: Lady Vol
abstract: A memoir by Pat Summitt, the University of Tennessee women’s basketball coach who helped revolutionize the game and won eight national titles.
lead_paragraph: College coaches have to construct teams — complex organisms — from players who are often just figuring out who they are, as athletes and as adults. They’re supposed to remember that the pieces they are fitting together, on the court or the field, are also students. And they have to rebuild again and again, with every graduation.

headline: Sacred Hoopster
abstract: In “Eleven Rings,” Phil Jackson ruminates on the philosophy and the players that made him the most successful coach in NBA history.
lead_paragraph: In late March, apparently in order to help promote “Eleven Rings,” Phil Jackson joined Twitter with a splash. His first tweet received attention on various sports Web sites, including USA Today’s and ESPN.com, because its text read, in full, “11 champ;ipnsikp[ ringhs.” (An ad made the joke clear: he had tried to type while wearing all 11 rings.) Jackson’s fingers soon found the correct keys, and he was off and tweeting. One might have expected profound insights from Jackson, whose 11 N.B.A. rings came while leading the Chicago Bulls in the 1990s and the Los Angeles Lakers in the 2000s and 2010s. The news media had long cast him as the “Zen master,” an intellectual with an interest in Eastern thought who used Buddhism to manage the titanic egos of Michael Jordan, Shaquille O’Neal and Kobe Bryant. For the wizened sage mumbling his koans, isn’t a medium limited to 140 characters ideal?

headline: On Victory Day, Rabbi Honors Red Army’s Jewish Veterans
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Veterans', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: They defeated Hitler, but they did so on behalf of the Soviet Union, whose own anti-Semitism led millions of its Jews to flee once they were able.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — When Rabbi Naftali Estulin walked into the synagogue, the men were waiting for him. They had come with canes and walkers and medals. Some wore yarmulkes. Several covered their heads with hats lettered “LA VETERAN ASSN WWII.”

headline: Splish Splash
abstract: Four new picture books about rainy weather.
lead_paragraph: “Rain, rain, go away.” Kids have always chanted the familiar refrain — gazing out the window wistfully, chin on fist — as if they had the power to make it happen. But these days, what’s a little precipitation when there are peevish birds to be flung and other indoor, on-screen distractions? In an era in which the directive “Go play” no longer implies “outside,” the idea that rain may affect a child’s fun is perhaps a quaint one. But four new picture books remind us that no matter how cosseted we are by technology, a downpour still holds the power to move us.

headline: Out and About
abstract: A novel and a memoir about growing up with secrets in religious families.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Hartzler and Rafe Goldberg grow up mostly as polar opposites. Aaron comes from a fundamentalist Christian Kansas City family; Rafe is a child of modern-­hippie Boulder, Colo., (stereo)types. Aaron, the main character in the memoir “Rapture Practice,” is real; Rafe, the protagonist in Bill Konigsberg’s novel “Openly Straight,” is made up. But both wrestle, over several hundred pages, with their identities. And both share a secret: They’re liars.

headline: A West Hollywood Place-Setting for Christofle
abstract: The French silversmith opens a pop-up, in preparation for a Beverly Hills store.
lead_paragraph: Shoppers sauntering along Melrose Place might mistake Christofle’s pop-up shop for just another beautifully merchandised lifestyle store in a section of West Hollywood, Calif., that includes Marc Jacobs and Isabel Marant. Studio Christofle, as it’s called, opened in early May and looks unexpectedly eclectic for the home of a venerable French silver company. The styling and merchandising of the 1,100-square-foot space is a result of two strategic collaborations. JF Chen antiques furnished it with pieces like a 19th century Chinese wedding armoire (now styled with Christofle candelabra, pitchers and vases) and Marco Zanini’s throne-line Roma chair for Memphis. Arcana: Books on the Arts supplied rare art, architecture, fashion and design books. “Christofle has different faces,” said Stéphane Parmentier, the company’s creative director, who organized the store. “We are traditional, but we are also youthful and practical.”

headline: Apes
abstract: This graphic novel presents the stories of three women who profoundly changed our understanding of the great apes: Dian Fossey, Biruté Galdikas and Jane Goodall.
lead_paragraph: The stories of scientists create new scientists. Alexander von Humboldt — the most famous naturalist of the early 19th century — chronicled his epic expeditions, between 1799 and 1804, in his “Personal Narrative of a Journey to the Equinoctial Regions of the New Continent.” When a nature-loving student at Cambridge named Charles Darwin read the book, it changed his life. He read passages aloud to his professors and learned Spanish so that he could follow in Humboldt’s footsteps. Humboldt’s “Personal Narrative,” Darwin later wrote, “stirred up in me a burning zeal to add even the most humble contribution to the noble structure of Natural Science.” At age 22, he embarked on his own voyage around the world, out of which he would develop his theory of evolution.

headline: Secrets
abstract: In Emily Murdoch’s first novel, a girl is haunted by secrets.
lead_paragraph: The secrets we hold as children, especially those born from familial dysfunction, can be particularly pernicious: too young to handle our experience or verbalize our feelings, and mistakenly convinced we’re at fault for events beyond our control, we develop sophisticated systems of self-­defense that become second nature, deeply tied to our identity — until it’s time to let them go.

headline: Literary Excursions
abstract: Today’s tourists might learn something from the traveler-memoirists of earlier generations.
lead_paragraph: On a trip to Tulum last Christmas, I think I managed the true Epicurean ideal of hedonism, sipping gently of the tropical sun, bodysurfing more than I read, reading more than I ate, and eating more than I worried. The entire endeavor was calibrated to maximize pleasure and minimize hardship, and so I learned nothing. I relaxed. I kept myself entertained. I visited the local Mayan ruins and paid more consideration to the vigilant application of sun goop than to the historical artifacts on display. I had joined the neocolonialist community that, through sky miles and vacation days, has effectively turned the developing world into a Sandals resort.

headline: Healthy Appetites
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: New comics include “Relish,” Lucy Knisley’s memoir about various episodes in her life and what she was eating at the time.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Knisley has eaten well all her life, and everything she tastes is apparently a madeleine for some happy memory. She grew up with a mother who worked for David Bouley and an uncle who ran a gourmet shop; the cover of RELISH: My Life in the Kitchen (First Second, paper, $17.99) shows her lifting an olive to her open mouth, her eyes closed in elated anticipation. It’s a memoir with only the slightest hints of conflict or struggle, apart from an early scene in which young Lucy is attacked by a flock of geese. (“I have since eaten foie gras with great enjoyment and very little guilt,” she notes.) She maps out her emotional associations with her favorite foods — Venetian croissants, sautéed mushrooms, McDonald’s fries and so on — in a breezy clear-line style, lingering over treasured moments, like resting her hand against Richard Serra’s “Tilted Arc” during a catering gig. Between chapters, Knisley offers simple, neatly diagrammed recipes (chocolate chip cookies! pesto! sangria!). Her language, like her drawings, is precise and uncluttered: in one of the book’s liveliest sequences, 12-year-old Lucy and a friend wander through a little Mexican town, discovering treats like “sweet corn on a stick, with hot sauce and lime, which turned the corners of our mouths red.”

headline: A Mother’s Book Is Her Son’s Movie
abstract: “Tiger Eyes,” the first feature adaptation of Judy Blume’s 1981 novel, was directed by her son Lawrence Blume.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a view with a room — now you’ve seen it,” Judy Blume said, smiling and pulling shut the shade in her apartment overlooking Central Park West. It was morning and still bright inside her living room, done in soft colors and wood, with stuffed bookshelves and unpretentious modern art. Over the sofa hung a tasteful assemblage of female nudes. (Some were painted by a friend, Lincoln Perry, who is married to the author Ann Beattie. “But that is not Ann,” Ms. Blume noted.)

headline: She Cuts Quickly, and Quietly
abstract: Nancy Perez is the butcher at the Lambs Club in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

headline: Shakespeare in the Park
abstract: Under the stars at the Delacorte Theater is the quintessential free summer event in New York City: the Public Theater’s venerable Shakespeare in the Park program.
lead_paragraph: The Miser has spent more than a few warm summer nights in a seat under the stars at the Delacorte Theater, taking in what may well be the quintessential free summer event in New York City: the Public Theater’s venerable Shakespeare in the Park program. This year’s productions look as promising as ever: “The Comedy of Errors” runs from Tuesday through June 30, and a musical version of “Love’s Labour’s Lost,” adapted by the team that brought us “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” runs from July 23 through Aug. 18.

headline: German From Senegal Vies to Break Bundestag Barrier
abstract: Karamba Diaby, a Social Democrat who became a German citizen in 2001, could become the first black member of Parliament.
lead_paragraph: HALLE, Germany — When Karamba Diaby arrived in Germany as a student from Senegal he knew only two things in German: Bundesliga and BMW — the professional soccer league and the automobile manufacturer. The only hitch was that it was October 1985 and Mr. Diaby had landed in East Germany, where comrades frowned on both West German capitalist institutions.

headline: Kissing Away the Corporate Tax
abstract: Reducing corporate taxes can be offset by raising the tax rates on dividends, and the tax system can be made more progressive in the process.
lead_paragraph: My column on Wednesday startled some readers. Was I proposing to do away with corporate taxes simply because globalization is making it easier for multinational companies to avoid them? Should we really just roll over and accept defeat?

headline: Germany Counts Heads and Finds 1.5 Million Fewer Residents Than It Expected
abstract: Already deeply concerned about its rapidly dwindling population, Germany found 1.5 million fewer inhabitants than previously assumed.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It’s as if Leipzig, Hanover and Dresden had disappeared in the blink of an eye, statistically speaking.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "After Earth."

abstract: A stronger economy and slower growth in health spending have helped strengthen the financial outlook for the federal insurance program, the Obama administration said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The financial outlook for Medicare has improved because of a stronger economy and slower growth in health spending, and the financial condition of Social Security has not worsened but is still unsustainable, the Obama administration said Friday.

lead_paragraph: A meticulously renovated brick town house with an adjoining artist’s studio on a quaint historic corner in the West Village is poised to enter the market for the first time since 1997, when it was rescued from obsolescence by the art dealer Matthew Marks and his partner, Jack Bankowsky, a curator who was formerly the editor of Artforum magazine.

headline: I Enjoyed My Son’s Bris
abstract: Many Jewish mothers cover their eyes during their son’s bris and wait for it to be over. Instead, I found I enjoyed it.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks after my son’s bris, a friend of mine who had attended the ceremony told me that it looked as if I really enjoyed it. A Catholic from Ecuador and a bris first-timer, he said this without irony or judgment. He had no idea that most moms cower in the corner with covered eyes until the job is complete.

headline: This Week’s Movies: ‘After Earth,’ ‘The Kings of Summer’ and ‘The East’

lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “The East,” “After Earth” and “The Kings of Summer.” Here are all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Gaining the Upper Hand
abstract: In this market, it often takes a savvy strategy to beat out the competition in apartment sales.
lead_paragraph: With fewer homes on the market in New York City, real estate agents say that the more desirable ones are often receiving multiple offers. Even if the bidding does not escalate to a “war,” it takes a savvy strategy to beat out the competition.

headline: In a Seller’s Market, Every Minute Counts
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: With inventory tight in New York City, sellers have regained the edge in apartment sales. The winning bidders are the ones who act fast and get creative.
lead_paragraph: If there was any doubt that New York City real estate has become a seller’s market, consider the following: open houses are packed to capacity, bidding wars and all-cash offers have almost become the norm, and some listing prices actually rise, not drop, after a home is listed.

headline: Did the Mets Sweep, or Were the Yankees Swept?

lead_paragraph: The Mets’ four-game sweep of the Yankees was both surprising and unprecedented, and it raised interesting questions:

abstract: “The Prey” is a French thriller that opens for a run at the AMC Empire 25 in Midtown Manhattan on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it says something about Europe’s economic and unemployment troubles that a man who robs banks for a living is the good guy in “The Prey,” a French thriller that opens for a run at the AMC Empire 25 in Midtown Manhattan on Friday.

headline: Listen Up | Eleanor Friedberger’s ’70s Song Craft
abstract: The singer-songwriter, previously known as the frontwoman for the brother-sister duo Fiery Furnaces, has established herself as a solo artist to be reckoned with.
lead_paragraph: “I think we’re drawn to the decade we were born in,” said the singer-songwriter Eleanor Friedberger, who was born in 1976. “I love looking at ’70s interiors, textiles or graphic design and thinking, If I could turn this picture into music, what would it sound like?” Her songs do sound the way a Barbara D’Arcy room or Milton Glaser album cover looks: warm, inviting and groovy. Though she’s best known as the frontwoman for the Fiery Furnaces, the Brooklyn indie rock band she founded with her brother Matthew more than a decade ago, the release of “Personal Record” (Merge), her second solo album next week, should solidify her identity as a stand-alone musician. Steeped in the analog sounds of Me Decade icons like Harry Nilsson, Emitt Rhodes and Caetano Veloso, the album is more mellifluous and emotionally resonant than the Furnaces’ eccentric work. Instead, it builds on the classic song craft of Friedberger’s 2011 solo debut, “Last Summer,” interweaving bossa nova beats and British folk balladry with summer-road-trip rock ‘n’ roll. It’s as relatable — and as much a career high-water mark — as its title suggests. “I don’t get to hide under a band blanket,” she says of flying solo. “But it also feels more authentically me.”

headline: Serious Stuff, With Bare Midriffs
abstract: For serious ballet fans, there is no other place to be this week than the Metropolitan Opera House.
lead_paragraph: For serious ballet fans, there is no other place to be this week than the Metropolitan Opera House, where American Ballet Theater enters the third week of its spring season with its final performance of Alexei Ratmansky’s “Shostakovich Trilogy,” on Monday. The first section, “Symphony No. 9,” had its premiere during the company’s fall season last year, but the remaining two parts (“Chamber Symphony” and “Piano Concerto No. 1”) are brand new.

headline: Crowds Line Up for Manet in Venice
abstract: The hottest show in Venice has nothing to do with contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — One of the hottest tickets in town has nothing to do with the Biennale or even contemporary art. Every morning lines can be seen snaking around the Palazzo Ducale as crowds wait to get into “Manet. Return to Venice,” an exhibition of about 80 paintings, drawings and prints.

headline: Marvin Junior, 77, Robust, Earthy Baritone for the Dells
abstract: Mr. Junior’s voice was huge and powerful, and it held up through more than two dozen albums and 57 years of performing with the Dells.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Junior, whose raw but robust baritone served for half a century as the sturdy foundation for the Dells, a Chicago doo-wop and rhythm-and-blues group that was formed when he and most of its other members were in high school in the early 1950s, died on Wednesday at his home in Harvey, Ill. He was 77.

headline: Peaceful Protest Over Istanbul Park Turns Violent as Police Crack Down
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The police action, with water cannons and tear gas, was the latest crackdown by Turkey’s government against a movement challenging plans to redevelop a park.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Police officers attacked a group of peaceful demonstrators on Friday in Istanbul’s Taksim Square with water cannons and tear gas, sending scores of people, protesters and tourists alike, scurrying into shops and luxury hotels and turning the center of this city into a battle zone at the height of tourist season.

headline: On Path to Priesthood, and Then He Fell for Her
abstract: Over 30 years of marriage, Lynn Casmier-Paz and Augustine Paz have learned to split domestic duties and accept their differences.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Court Revives Financier’s Fraud Suit Against Citigroup Over the Sale of EMI
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A federal appeals court vacated a 2011 jury verdict clearing Citigroup of any wrongdoing over its role in the sale of EMI to Guy Hands’s private equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners, ruling that the trial court judge, Jed S. Rakoff, gave improper jury instructions.
lead_paragraph: The British financier Guy Hands will have another chance to try to prove his claim that he was defrauded by his longtime bankers at Citigroup.

headline: Breaking Out A Prisoner’s Tale
abstract: A formal description of Luigi Dallapiccola’s one-act “Il Prigioniero,” a bleak 12-tone opera about a despairing prisoner during the Spanish Inquisition, might not sound like a crowd pleaser.
lead_paragraph: A formal description of Luigi Dallapiccola’s one-act “Il Prigioniero,” a bleak 12-tone opera about a despairing prisoner during the Spanish Inquisition, might not sound like a crowd pleaser. Still, the conductor Alan Gilbert is giving New York Philharmonic audiences a rare chance to experience this sensual and mysterious 1950 work as part of Gilbert’s Playlist, a series devoted to his favorites. I share his enthusiasm for “Il Prigioniero,” which I first saw in a wrenching production at the Paris National Opera in 2008.

headline: Two Mothers, Many Problems
abstract: On Monday night, ABC Family bids farewell to the trials and tribulations of adolescent pregnancy with the finale of “The Secret Life of the American Teenager.”
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, ABC Family bids farewell to the trials and tribulations of adolescent pregnancy with the finale of “The Secret Life of the American Teenager,” at 8, and introduces a different kind of motherhood in its latest original drama, “The Fosters,” at 9. Created by Bradley Bredeweg (“Fly Girls”) and Peter Paige (“Queer as Folk”), with the pop star Jennifer Lopez leading the executive producers, “The Fosters” charts the twists and turns in the lives of Stef Foster (Teri Polo), a police officer, and her romantic partner, Lena Adams (Sherri Saum), a school vice principal. Together they’re mothers to Brandon (David Lambert), Stef’s biological son from a previous marriage, and the adopted twins Mariana (Cierra Ramirez) and Jesus (Jake T. Austin).

headline: Strong Bones Start in the Womb
abstract: Children born to mothers who get more vitamins from their diets develop stronger bones even years later, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Children born to mothers who get more vitamins from their diets develop stronger bones even years later, a new study shows.

headline: 1935 Play Becomes A Forget-Me-Not
abstract: “Cornelius” is getting its first London revival.
lead_paragraph: Nobody paid much attention when “Cornelius” opened in London in 1935, though the play was written by the popular novelist and dramatist J. B. Priestley and starred no less an actor than Ralph Richardson. But this portrait of capitalism, as one character calls it, a “game of snakes and ladders — without the ladders,” was perhaps too tough-minded for escapist Depression audiences and survived for a mere seven weeks before fading into the twilight of forgotten flops.

headline: Keep Calm and Carry On
abstract: Each of us has a finite reservoir of energy in any given day. But there are techniques to avoid feeling exhausted.
lead_paragraph: I had just finished facilitating a daylong workshop for a team of leaders at Walmart when I received a voicemail telling me my flight from Bentonville, Ark., that evening had been canceled and I would not be able to get home until sometime the next day.

headline: Kerry Castigates Russia Over Syria-Bound Missiles
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'International Relations']
abstract: It was Secretary of State John Kerry’s most pointed criticism so far of Russia’s supply of weaponry to the Syrian government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday strongly criticized Russia’s pledge to sell advanced antiaircraft weapons to Syria, suggesting that along with the growing involvement of Iran and Hezbollah in the fighting, the sale threatened to disrupt efforts to negotiate a political settlement and could destabilize the region.

headline: She’s Rearming Leonardo’s Ideas
abstract: The words “military industrial complex” are not the first ones that spring to mind when you think about Leonardo da Vinci.
lead_paragraph: The words “military industrial complex” are not the first ones that spring to mind when you think about Leonardo da Vinci, but his designs for outlandish weaponry for the powerful Duke of Milan, Ludovico Sforza, his patron, are among his most reproduced drawings.

headline: Duets of Disconnection
abstract: In duets choreographed by Christopher Wheeldon, there are no same-sex couples, and the women can seem subservient to men.
lead_paragraph: It’s a sign of Christopher Wheeldon’s eminence that his choreography, more than anyone else’s today, raises central issues about the nature of ballet. Is it an art of escapism or one that reflects vital features of the world we know? If it’s an art of ideals, what are they?

headline: Looking Back at ‘Lenny’s Playlist’
abstract: The newly digitized archives of the New York Philharmonic trace Leonard Bernstein’s efforts to win acceptance for avant-garde composers, with mixed results.
lead_paragraph: An evening celebrating symphonic jazz, a Stravinsky blowout, a rare 1940s opera revived: Gilbert’s Playlist, a monthlong festival of the New York Philharmonic, has arrived, honoring the programming proclivities of Alan Gilbert, the orchestra’s music director.

headline: Big Ticket | Treetop Park Views for $16,575,000
abstract: A 4,207-square-foot floor-through unit with four bedrooms and views of the park and surrounding historic neighborhood was the most expensive sale of the week.

M. Stern, the premier team that produced the premium price precedents set by 15 Central Park West, has recorded its first closing. A floor-through unit on the ninth floor sold for its full asking price of $16,575,000, an amount that escalated to $16,877,493.75 once the transfer taxes kicked in, and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.The 4,207-square-foot residence has four bedrooms and five and a half baths, and provides treetop views of the park and surrounding historic neighborhood with the addition of 35 large windows. The anticipated monthly carrying costs are $11,200. According to the developer, 8 of the available 16 residences, including a $42 million duplex penthouse with four terraces and two pools that was snapped up by Leslie Alexander, the owner of the Houston Rockets, went swiftly to contract for the full listing price despite being bought off the offering plan.

But this year is an unhappy anniversary for America’s northerly neighbor. It is 20 years since the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Los Angeles Kings to win the 1993 Stanley Cup; no Canadian team has won the championship since.

headline: Hidden in Plain Sight
abstract: “Various Small Books” is a collection of pictures and essays showing how other artists have copied, parodied or otherwise paid homage to the work of Ed Ruscha.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s, I purchased a half-dozen pocket-size paperback books that bore the name Ed Ruscha. I hadn’t heard of the California artist at the time — I just liked the look of his booklets. One was bound with ribbon; the rest were perfect binds. There were no cover pictures; only widely spaced titles typeset in a serif font that I also liked to use, called Stymie Bold. The cover designs were distinct yet understated, reminiscent of small-press poetry collections. Inside were photographic records of what each title promised — “Various Small Fires,”  “Thirtyfour Parking Lots,”  “Twentysix Gasoline Stations,”  “Nine Swimming Pools,”  “Crackers” (with text by Mason Williams on “How to Derive the Maximum Enjoyment From Crackers”) and “Babycakes” (with photographs of, yes, a baby and cakes). They were puzzling yet clearly ironic, prefiguring many books by today’s conceptual artists. The critical mass of decidedly mundane pictures gave them their allure. Marcel Duchamp’s “ready-mades” and Andy Warhol’s soup cans had already elevated everyday objects to the status of art, but Ruscha’s small books brought the ennobled vernacular back down to earth.

headline: What I Read That Summer

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘The Authority’ Saves Humanity
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Graphic Novels']
abstract: Volume one of the series from DC Comics is at No. 2 on the hardcover list.
lead_paragraph: At No. 2 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week is Volume 1 of “The Authority,” from DC Comics. The 12 issues included in this edition were written by Warren Ellis and illustrated by Bryan Hitch. The series was originally bought in 1999, and captured some creative magic. The heroes (Jenny Sparks, who embodied the spirit of the 20th Century; Apollo and Midnighter, crime-fighting lovers who were analogues of Superman and Batman; Jack Hawksmoor, who could communicate with and control cities) were captivating, and the artwork was exquisite. The first year found the heroes fighting bigger and bigger threats as a team. The first four issues featured a nation of terrorists who were bred to have Superman-like powers and who were bent on destroying major world cities. The middle story arc featured an invasion from a parallel word. The final four issues featured the team confronting no less than the incomprehensible godlike creator of the solar system that wanted to cleanse the universe of humanity. (The heroes won!) Versions of these heroes continue to be featured in “Stormwatch,” a monthly series published by DC, but there are only sparks of the audaciousness that were once a hallmark of the series.

On the right bank sat a busy Indian village, Govindghat, its one street lined with spartan hotels and shops brimming with Sikh religious items and souvenirs. On the left bank, a man wearing a frayed sweater-vest and a ski cap greeted me imploringly.

headline: On a Road Trip in Sicily, Churches Everywhere
abstract: Rolling countryside, stark valleys and recurring scenes of churches straight ahead on a drive through southeastern Sicily.
lead_paragraph: It happened each time we drove into one of southeastern Sicily’s hill towns. It could be a village or a big town, run-down or fixed-up, but as we drove uphill toward the historic center, the vision ahead was always roughly the same: a stunning Baroque church, honey-colored or pale white, decorated with columns or curves, angels or Cupids, shells or leaves, urns or shields, sometimes all of the above. A bell tower might be missing or there might be grass growing between the paving stones, but each of those churches exemplified what unfolds all across this corner of Sicily: an exuberant style that played itself out on facades of churches and palazzi in the wake of a devastating earthquake in 1693.

headline: In Tel Aviv, a Port Is Reborn
abstract: Over the last decade, the city’s Namal port has been transformed into a leisure destination, with a boardwalk, restaurants and a farmers’ market.
lead_paragraph: Tel Aviv, a seaside city, has no shortage of waterfront space. It has so much that when its port, Namal, began to fall into disuse four decades ago, overshadowed by a port to the south that became Israel’s main nexus of sea trade, it was shuttered. No one thought to rehabilitate it. There were plenty of other places to take advantage of the sea.

headline: Fired for Being Gay? Protections Are Piecemeal

abstract: Workplace protections for L.G.B.T. people amount to a patchwork of state and local laws and judicial decisions.
lead_paragraph: Jake, a 43-year-old worker at an auto parts warehouse in Ohio, often spends his lunch break in his car. headline: How to Write a Personal Essay That You Know Will Be Torn Apart in the Comments Section
abstract: Beware brave personal essay writer, because you are in for a world of brutal, self righteous, angry commentary.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen years ago I wrote a Lives column about retaking the SATs as an adult. I was 28 and felt it was high time I redeemed myself for my original scores, a set of numbers that had stalked me for a decade. In the essay, “Evening the Score,” I expressed the fear that my abysmal performance would land me in community college, not thinking for a second that I might offend anyone. Yet, I did. While unabashedly Yahooing myself a while later, I discovered I had been granted the (THE!) 2001 Shame Award by the Two Year College Association. It took a minute for the full weight of it to hit me. Ever so slowly, the smile spread across my face. I won! Not only was it one of the only awards I’d ever received, it proved that someone actually read my piece. My only regret was that I had been given the award in absentia (talk about shameful, I wasn’t even invited to that year’s T.W.C.A. convention, where the honor was announced) and therefore had no plaque or certificate to hang next to my four-year college diploma (which I did in fact earn, despite my standardized-test deficiencies).

headline: ‘The People’s Car: A Global History of the Volkswagen Beetle’
abstract: An excerpt from “The People’s Car: A Global History of the Volkswagen Beetle.”
lead_paragraph: After decades of austerity caused first by the Depression and prolonged by the Second World War, the fifties turned into a “golden age of the American automobile” that saw car registra­tions jump from 25.8 million in 1945 to 52.1 million in 1955. Lifestyle changes underpinned demand for cars. As the postwar suburban population grew by 43 percent between 1947 and 1953, daily routines, not least those of women who wished to visit the new suburban shopping malls and plazas, increasingly relied on access to individual transport. The car and the housing booms were intimately linked, with average individual expenditure on these items tripling in real terms between 1941 and 1961. By the end of the fifties, 40 percent of American drivers  were female — a far higher proportion than anywhere in Western Eu rope. As a dealer told a journalist investigating why Americans bought Volkswagens in 1955, the car “‘was just the thing for the wife to run around town in.’ Two- car suburbia is where Volkswagen has made its biggest inroads.” Market surveys from the fifties and early sixties also revealed that, while over 60 percent of Beetles registered in the United States served as second cars, about two- thirds of the customers who signed a purchase con­tract in a dealership had attended college. In short, Volkswagen attracted a foothold among the materially secure, white middle class whose members made up the bulk of suburbanites in the fifties.

headline: ‘Red Tape and White Knuckles’
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: An excerpt from “Red Tape and White Knuckles.”
lead_paragraph: Emerging from the forest under a black sky, I was met with a storm howling across the desolate plateau. The thunder moved nearer with every clap and the rain was ceaseless, coming down in sheets but the ground could no longer absorb it quickly enough and torrents of muddy water flowed past my wheels while huge chunks of the dirt road were disintegrating before my eyes. Overhanging trees and thorn bushes dangled in my path, scratching my face and ripping my waterproofs, allowing yet more rain to soak me quite literally, to the skin. This was wild, high, open country with not a glimmer of civilisation in sight; there were no people living here now, long since driven out in the civil war’s slashing and burning of the villages. I longed to see some evidence of the human hand at work, just a hut or a farmhouse, a truck or car. But the only signs of man’s existence were grim and sinister, in the shape of rusting tanks at the roadside and the crumbling concrete of improvised roadblocks.

headline: ‘The Stewardship of Historically Important Automobiles’
abstract: An excerpt from “The Stewardship of Historically Important Automobiles.”
lead_paragraph: The desire to respect well-preserved great automobiles is not a new idea. For decades, closet conservators have not come out because of the pristine restoration focus that dominated the hobby. They worried that their scruffy treasure would pale on the show field. They were told a ground-up is mandatory. Was the preservation motivated by parsimony? And of course a trophy was out of the question. The mainstream seemed to abhor imperfection. While acknowledging their vehicle was technical jewelry in every way, they shamelessly changed its colors, trim, and even its design. Scores of unusual animals were sacrificed to add wow to the trim. No nut, bolt, or tie-rod arm escaped the chrome plater’s tank. Wire wheel spokes scintillated on the podium. Novel colors were protected with clear coat. When it was easier to replace than fix, the choice was easy. Racing damage was a badge of courage.

headline: The Right Way to Do the Hillary Step
abstract: A 40-foot wall of rock and ice blocks the way to the summit of the world’s highest mountain. Climb it.
lead_paragraph: KETCHUM, Idaho — SIXTY years ago this week, as Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay approached the summit of the world’s highest mountain, they were stopped by a 40-foot wall of rock and ice. It was, Hillary later wrote, “a formidable looking problem ...We realized that at this altitude it might well spell the difference between success and failure.”

headline: A Village’s Bicentennial Celebrated in Sculpture
abstract: Contemporary works are placed outdoors throughout the historic districts of Ossining.
lead_paragraph: A tree made entirely of nails graces a 19th-century churchyard. A woman molded in bronze lounges by the library, legs outstretched, face turned toward the sky. Along the shore, a shard of crimson glass atop a towering column of rose-colored granite catches reflections from the Hudson River beyond.

headline: Editor’s Letter | Of Brains and Beauty
abstract: If our culture issue has a theme, it would seem to be about what happens when intelligence and rigor are brought to bear in the pursuit of the aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: If this issue has a theme, it would seem to be about what happens when intelligence and rigor are brought to bear in the pursuit of the aesthetic. As we all know, the intellect can be cruel and beauty can be shallow, but when these two get together, they can be a powerful force for good, and even happiness.

headline: A New Place to Find Aged Steak
abstract: All the chops on the menu at the Chophouse Grille are beef, but pasta, chicken, lobster tail, shrimp and fish add variety.
lead_paragraph: The Chophouse Grille, at the end of a short, set-back shopping strip on busy Route 6, is easy to miss. But local residents seem to have had no trouble finding this dining and drinking spot that Toni Vulaj and Matthew Camerino opened nine months ago. An after-work crowd fills the long, inviting bar to overflowing; and to secure a seat in the restaurant section, diners would be smart to have a reservation.

headline: Crowded Tables, Traditional Thai
abstract: The Elephant Trail successfully combines disparate flavors to produce authentic Thai dishes.
lead_paragraph: The Elephant Trail restaurant, in Avon, decorated throughout with pachyderms — on sequined wall hangings, a carved wooden mask and glass-covered tablecloths — serves a range of tasty Thai dishes, most of which are prepared with fresh, crispy vegetables and only a moderate amount of chili pepper.

headline: Lost in Love in the Maze of a Clever Stage
abstract: In a multilevel never-never land with hedges of artificial turf and whimsical, mixed-period costumes, “Twelfth Night” teems with mismatched romance and physical comedy.
lead_paragraph: It’s the kind of entrance an actor would happily sell his soul for — as the Duke in “Twelfth Night,” Lea Coco rises slowly from beneath center stage, lounging barelegged atop a gleaming white piano in his silky, undone shirt. What comes next is one of Shakespeare’s most famous opening lines: “If music be the food of love, play on,” Mr. Coco tells the pianist riding the stage elevator with him. And play on they do, as Darko Tresnjak’s beguiling production unspools from this surprising central image at the Hartford Stage.

headline: Dean Brooks, ‘Cuckoo’s Nest’ Doctor, Dies at 96
abstract: Dr. Brooks was the superintendent of an Oregon psychiatric hospital when he agreed to allow “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” to be filmed there.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Dean Brooks, the superintendent of the Oregon psychiatric hospital where the Oscar-winning picture “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” was shot — and who had a small, well-received on-screen role as the fictional hospital’s superintendent — died on Thursday at his home in Salem, Ore. He was 96.

headline: Two Ranger Forwards Have Shoulder Surgery
abstract: Ryan Callahan and Carl Hagelin are expected to miss at least part of training camp and perhaps the beginning of next season after each had surgery to repair a torn labrum in the left shoulder.
lead_paragraph: Rangers forwards Ryan Callahan and Carl Hagelin are expected to miss at least part of training camp and perhaps the beginning of next season after each underwent surgery to repair a torn labrum in the left shoulder on Friday.
